column2: George Mandel of Astoria, Queens, won the junior singles championship in the Eastern indoor tennis championships at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday. Mandel defeated Dave Freishtat of Baltimore in a two-and-a-half-hour match, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 11 -- 9.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 31 -- Commenting on the Djilas- Dedijer case, the Government charged today that "circles" broad had initiated a campaign against Communist-led Yugoslavia. The Government asserted this campaign was designed to force a change in the country's internal political system.
George K. Smith has been appointed sales manager in charge of the New York City and New Jersey area for Pleasant Valley Wine Company.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Dr. T. Norman Hurd, the retiring State Budget Director, said today that he was leaving State finances in a sound condition with State credit high.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -The largest single cancer-detection study ever launched -- involving 165,000 women -- has established new hope for widescale early detection and control of cancer of the cervix.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
HANOI, Vietnam, Dec. 31 -- The economic accords between Vietminh officials and Red China signed in Peiping a week ago are considered here to mark an important step in Vietminh policy.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill declared today that at the start of the New Year Britons could look back and congratulate themselves on their record of peace abroad and their rising standard of living at home.

ATLANTA, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A cure and preventive for malaria have been found through experiments in which prisoners at the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary subjected themselves voluntarily to the bite of malaria-infected mosquitoes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The director of the Pan American Sanitary Bureau issued today the following report on yellow fever:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Criminal Division of the Department of Justice reported today that drives against labor racketeering. Federal housing frauds and civil rights violations had been outstanding features of its 1954 activities.
TROY, N. Y., Dec. 31 (AP) -Yale and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute tied, 2 -- 2, tonight in R. P. I.'s fourth annual invitation hockey tournament.

The New York Stock Exchange in 1954 had the most prosperous year since 1933 with its volume of business totaling 573,374,622 shares. This compared with 354,851,325 shares traded in 1953 and with the record 1,124,990,980 shares marketed in 1929.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -Secretary of State John Foster Dulles indicated today that David K. E. Bruce was about ready to resign as special United States representative in Europe.
The decline in auto and farm implement business caused sales of the Detroit Harvester Company and its subsidiaries to fall 13 per cent and earnings 61 per cent in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.

The complete disallowance of advertising costs in a government contract is "quite improper and undesirable," according to a detailed study of how to use a government contract just issued by the Machinery and Allied Products Institute.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- Northeastern Steel Corporation filed a registration statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed public offering of securities for financing the expansion of the former hot rolled steel strip mill of the Stanley Works at Bridgeport, Conn.
Mayor Wagner participated yesterday in the swearing-in of 750 policemen, increasing the force to 20,848, the highest strength in its history.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 31 -- An increase of 15 cents an hour in the Federal floor on wages will be urged upon Congress by President Eisenhower Jan. 6.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today suspended the 10 per cent fare increase that Northeast Airlines of Boston had planned to put into effect tomorrow.
The New York Knickerbockers will share the spotlight with the Harlem Globetrotters tonight in a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.
The public market for new capital will be moderately active with the beginning of the new year.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The chief of police of La Rioja Province in western Argentina ordered the Roman Catholic Church today to cancel its traditional New Year's Eve and New Year's Day processions.
At risk of sounding moralistic, we recommend that home cooks start the New Year with some good resolutions.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 31 -- a full-scale war between the Chinese Nationalists and Communists may break out at "any time," Generalissimo Chiang Kai- shek, President o Nationalist China, said today in a New Year's message.
PROVIDENCE, Dec. 31 (AP)--Led by Lou Hitch, the Milwaukee Hawks defeated New York, 89--64, tonight in a National Basketball Association game at the Rhode Island Auditorium.

CAIRO, Dec. 31 -- The Suez Canal, perhaps the world's busiest shipping artery, was blocked early today when a tanker struck a bridge and dropped a 350-ton section of the structure athwart the waterway. The canal will be blocked probably for ten days.

Archbishop Boris, who was appointed recently as exarch of the Patriarchal Russian Orthodox Church, Moscow, for the Archdiocese of the Aleutian Islands and North America, arrived at noon yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The four-story apartment house at 416 St. Marks Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Reuben Speciner to Hugh and Louise Henry. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title to the property, which occupies a plot about 26 by 128 feet.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Ralph Guglielmi, Notre Dame's all-America quarterback, got up from his sick bed today and doctors told him there was "a chance" he could play for the East in the Shrine East-West football game tomorrow. The proceeds will aid crippled children.
ALBANY, Saturday, Jan. 1 -- Averell Harriman took the oath of office as Governor of New York in a private ceremony in the Executive Mansion at 12:01 o'clock this morning.
Three men were sentenced yesterday to prison terms of twenty-five years each for attempting to rob a Post Office truck carrying registered mail containing $5,000.

In extending our greetings today the word "happy" will be repeatedly on our lips. That is natural and right, since the search for happiness has always been one of the first concerns of mankind and the wish for happiness for another is the first sign of friendship.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A highscoring contest between two defensively vulnerable football teams, Duke and Nebraska, is in prospect tomorrow in the second game under the Orange Bowl pact with the Atlantic Coast and Big Seven Conferences.

Albert Silverman has purchased for investment the seven-story apartment house for fifty-four families at 2340 Seventh Avenue, corner of West 137th Street, from clients of Wien, Lane, Klein Purcell, attorneys. Assessed at $237,000, the property is 99 by 100 feet and contains two stores. It was sold subject to mortgages amounting to $205,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The incoming chairman of the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations said today he would put a stop to its one-man hearings.

AUCKLAND, N. Z., Saturday, Jan. 1 -- The United States icebreaker Atka arrived at Wellington this morning. She will load stores until Jan. 7, when she sails for a fifty-four-day research visit to the Antarctic.
ROME, Dec. 31 -- Pope Pius XII, now definitely convalescing, was allowed today to eat beefsteak for the first time since he fell gravely ill Dec. 2. Pius is 78 years old.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 -Navy and Mississippi, the respective football champions of the East and the Southeastern Conference, will be matched tomorrow in the Sugar Bowl before an expected gathering of 82,000
With a final rumble of energy, the bull market of 1954 thundered to a close yesterday.
CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 31 (UP) -State Attorney General Louis C. Wyman today accused Dr. Vannevar Bush of "pathological misstatements" in the scientist's criticism of government loyalty procedures.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- The first phase of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's reorganization of the United Nations goes into effect officially tomorrow.

From the nature of your reporting during the proceedings of the Special Committee of the House of Representatives to Investigate Tax Exempt Foundations, of which I have had the honor to be chairman, and your frequent editorial comments, I conclude that it is not likely that you would, of your own accord, present to the public the facts which would enable it to arrive at an unprejudiced judgment regarding the work of the committee.
TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- Emperor Hirohito's annual New Year poem set the usual earnest tone with which Japanese celebrated tonight this festival.

Trading in commodity futures on the New York exchanges ended yesterday between noon and 1 P. M. The half day or less of trading cut volume in all markets. Most of the activity was limited to evening holdings for the year-end.
The biggest year in bond refundings since 1947 came to a close yesterday. More bonds were retired before maturity in December than in any month since July, 1950.

MONTREAL, Dec. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian National Railways today reported increased net revenues for November compared with the same month of 1953 but indicated net earnings for the first 11 months of 1954 were $17,945,000 below the year-ago level.

A picture and text tribute to Dr. Albert Schweitzer and his work will be published Jan. 14 by Harper, entitled "The World of Albert Schweitzer." The photographer, Erica Anderson, made three trips to Lambarene, French Equatorial Africa, and two to Gunsbach, Alsace, Dr. Schweitzer's home.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- An alien who had for four years resisted the action under the McCarran Act was deported last night. He had carried his fight to the Supreme Court.
A city experiment in leasing a pier to a contracting stevedore, after a seven-year ban on this type of operation, has proved successful and may lead to similar use of some of the docks now idle.
THE first big sailfish flurry of the season hit off Stuart, Fla., yesterday. Some boats reached the Pelican Hotel dock with as many as twenty sailfish release flags flying from the outriggers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -The Army announced today it would release about 44,000 draftees ahead of schedule next spring to meet lowered manpower ceilings. The new figures were set by President Eisenhower and the Defense Department.
A 60-year-old man and his 19-year-old daughter died early yesterday morning in a fire in a four-story Bronx tenement.
The Government did some year end house cleaning yesterday. A a result Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock granted Government motions to dismiss indictment in fifty old cases.
United City Park Mines was the last stock traded on the Big Board in 1954, according to the ticker.

During the year of 1954 the United States has increased materially its capability for waging an atomic war. It has also strengthened its defenses against enemy atomic attack on the North American continent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey called for action "at the White House level" today on the ousting of Wolf Ladejinsky. The uproar exploded in a new blast of statements and counterstatements.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 31 -- Cooperation between United States soldiers and Korean civilians was never better than during the last twelve months.
Weinress Co. retired on last Thursday as a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange.

Vera Maxwell, always in search of the new and unusual in fabrics for her collections of suits and coats, spent two months in Ireland last summer. She returned with a rich collection of rainbow-hued woolens, each selected at the place it was made.

ONCE again in 1955 literature will probably lead all the arts in America. The theatre, architecture, sculpture, music, painting and the still adolescent electronic arts may do extravagantly well, for them, but it seems reasonable to imagine that they will not spectacularly threaten the supremacy of the printed page.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 31 -The Union County Park Commission today rejected a request by the Army for a guided missile site in the Watchung Reservation, between Summit and Scotch Plains.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- William Holden, Paramount actor, has agreed to co-star for Twentieth Century-Fox in "A Many Splendored Thing," based on the novel by Dr. Hart Suyin. Earlier the actor accepted an offer from Columbia to do its adaptation of the play, "Picnic." The latter is likely to be made first.

The end of one year and the beginning of a new one is a time when one looks backward, as well as -- full of fine resolve -- forward. Looking backward is frowned upon, in some quarters, as being an unproductive pastime.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Construction contracts involving about $18,500,000 were awarded today in the final hours of the Dewey Administration.
The Cross County Center at Yonkers sold $30,000,000 of goods in its first eight months, Sol G. Atlas, owner-builder, announced yesterday.

MOONACHIE, N. J., Dec. 31 -Edna, New Jersey's most traveled racing pigeon, who, despite the tender age of eight months has completed two round trips to the Mediterranean, languished in her loft here today as the S. S. Exford sailed away without her.

One of the problems impatiently awaiting disposition in the new Congress is the development of electric power from Niagara Falls. The opportunity for public benefit is tremendous, further delay indefensible.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 31, (UP) -- The radar "blipped," the alerts flashed and the interceptors roared off. When the alert was over, a perturbed couple from Virginia realized that security was not something they read about.

Duquesne turned back La Salle, 67 -- 65, in a tense, see-saw final at Madison Square Garden last night to repeat its 1953 victory in the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Holiday Festival basketball tournament.
Justice Jacob Panken of the Domestic Relations Court looked back yesterday over thirty years as a jurist and said he was still an optimist.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Wheat prices advanced sharply this morning, but there was free selling on the upturns, especially of the May delivery around the $2.30 mark. Other grains showed minor price changes. While soybeans moved up for a time, there was a reaction from the tops.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (UP) -- Willie Shoemaker booted Mr. Sullivan to a half-length victory in the $29,000 California Breeders' Trial Stakes to score his second victory of the day at Santa Anita Park and his 380th for the year, in which he again was the leading jockey in the nation.
A 2,600-watt surface unit said to heat 35 per cent faster than the company's 1954 models is a feature of the Hotpoint electric ranges to be introduced in this area early this month.

Much of the credit for New York's record of harmonious industrial relations belongs to the State Labor Department. Over the years this department has recognized that the welfare of workers and the industries in which they work are interdependent. All appointments to its wage boards and advisory committees have provided equal representation for workers and employers.
A strike of 600 fresh-fruit and vegetable handlers began at midnight yesterday amid optimism that it would be over by tomorrow, or, if not, that Governor Harriman would intervene.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 (UP) -- John Jacob Astor 3d filed a countersuit for annulment or divorce against his third wife, Dolores (Dolly) Fullman Astor. He charged that she had "shoved" him into marriage knowing that his Mexican divorce from the second Mrs. Astor was invalid.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan. 1 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov said today he would welcome diplomatic negotiations to settle disagreements in the Far East. But he gave no direct answer to the question whether he would welcome a Big Four conference of heads of government.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Ohio State's unbeaten Buckeyes, the nation's No. 1 football team, tonight remained a firm two-touchdown favorite to defeat Southern California tomorrow and give the Big Ten its eighth victory in nine Rose Bowl games with the Pacific Coast Conference.

The International Exchange Program of the American National Theatre and Academy wants to express its heartfelt appreciation for your splendid editorial on "Porgy and Bess" as a cultural ambassador. The tour to Yugoslavia (which will be followed by appearances in Greece and the Near East) is part of ANTA's newly expanded International Exchange Program.
For the fifth consecutive season the Metropolitan Opera had as its New Year's Eve attraction a performance of "Fledermaus."

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- An undermanned Canterbury (Conn.) School sextet put up a valiant struggle today before losing 5 -- 0, to Hebron (Me.) Academy, as play was resumed in the fourteenth annual Northwood School hockey tournament.
New York welcomed 1955 last night with the traditional outpouring of horn-blowers, bell- ringers and other makers of noises.
A merger of the Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company is under active discussion, again but on a basis wholly the opposite of the abortive proposal of 1951.

WILTON, Conn., Dec. 31 (AP) -George N. Vitt said tonight he thought it was "rash" and "improper" for the Department of Agriculture to use his letter to back up the department's security firing of Mr. Ladejinsky.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 -- An automobile body assembly line will begin operating across one of Detroit's widest and busiest thoroughfares some time this summer.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- The State's highest court today upheld the right of a 12-year-old boy to choose his religion.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- Insurance companies, staggered by claims resulting from Hurricanes Carol and Edna four months ago, increased windstorm rates by as much as 150 per cent in four New England states today.
Paul Keres, the Estonian member of the Soviet delegation at the Hastings chess congress, had recovered sufficiently from an attack of tonsillitis yesterday to start play in the main event.
GENEVA, Dec. 24 -- When a Zurich housewife is at her wits end about what to feed the family all she needs to do is pick up the telephone and dial 163.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Great Britain arranged to make an annual payment of $137,845,431 today to cut down its multi-billion dollar post-World War II debt to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles declared today that the free world made a "substantial" net gain in 1954 and "the danger of general war recedes."

The year of 1954 has passed into history as the year of decision which enabled the Western system of alliances to survive its severest test. This happy end, which really marks a new beginning, became France's New Year's gift to the world when her National Assembly approved the pacts of Paris.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The State Department received a note from the Soviet Union this morning, but officials refused to disclose its contents.

The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received $500 on the last day of 1954 in honor of Adolph Ochs, the late publisher of The Times. This donation from the J. M. Kaplan Fund is among the 232 gifts listed on the first day of 1955 by the appeal that Mr. Ochs began fortythree years ago.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Sir Roger Makins, British Ambassador to the United States, was one of more than 2,000 persons named in Queen Elizabeth II's honors list published here today.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Production of its 5,509,200th passenger car today marked the end of 1954 for the United States automobile industry, according to Ward's Automotive reports.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Stephen Messana's King Jolie, a 9-10 favorite, ended his 1954 campaign on a merry note when he blazed to victory in the San Marino Purse before a crowd of 9,723 that basked in a hot sun at Tropical Park today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The 1954 Social Security amendment, which increased the monthly checks of retired workers, already appears to be lowering the case load of Old Age Assistance.
A hold-up man robbed a West Side shoe store owner of $325 yesterday afternoon and returned to the store a few moments later to get a pair of shoes for which he had been fitted.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 31 -- The heads of the Brazilian Army, Navy and Air Force declared today they were not disposed to be candidates for the Presidency and did not wish a military man to be a candidate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' statement today reviewing foreign policy in the past year and looking ahead to 1955:

BONN, Germany, Dec. 31 -- The flight of Communist-governed Germans from the Eastern zone to West Germany decreased this year by two-thirds. In the last months of the year two Germans from the Western democratic-governed Federal Republic went to East Germany for every three who came the opposite way.

SPARKILL, N. Y., Dec. 31 -Fred Kennedy Sr., chief of police of Orangetown for twenty-five years, was relieved of his command and placed on vacation today pending investigation of charges that he had padded the departmental payroll in favor of his son. The action was taken by the Orangetown Board.
The United Epilepsy Association was the beneficiary of the annual entertainment known as the New Year's Eve Celebrity Ball held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

New York Central for the third successive year, was the stock most actively traded on the New York Stock Exchange in 1954. Total trading amounted to 5,484,100 shares. The market price of the stock ranged from a low of 18 5/8 to a high of 34 5/8 and closed at 33 1/2 for a gain of 14 3/4 points on the year.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- The Court of Appeals today ruled that marriage did not give a man the right to steal from his wife.
W. J. Amoss will become director of the Port of New Orleans today.
The Development Bank for Puerto Rico plains to follow an aggressive policy in 1955 in promoting Puerto Rico's economy, according to Guillermo Rodriguez, president of the bank.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Dr. Charles A. Laughead, the former Michigan State College physician who was discharged for predicting world doom, was found sane in an Ingham County probate court hearing today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- An Air Force weather forecaster hopes to plant a mechanical spy in the center of each future hurricane.
PARIS, Dec. 31 -- At a year-end Cabinet meeting today the French Government decided to remove the import quotas from 75 per cent of French trade.
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 -- Soviet commentators do not concede that France's final decision on arming West Germany has yet been taken.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- United States financial aid for the defense of Indochina, beginning tomorrow, will be made directly to Laos, Cambodia and South Vietnam instead of through France.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- The renaissance of the Independence Hall era of colonial Philadelphia has reached another milepost.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Joe Childress, Auburn fullback, and Quarterback Bobby Freeman ripped Baylor defenses today for a 33 -- 13 Gator Bowl football triumph.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Surprise was expressed in diplomatic quarters tonight at reports of Secretary of State Dulles' press conference statements about the defense of Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent over the week ended on Tuesday to 109.6 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Bateman of 40 East Eighty-eighth Street and Jungle Point, Palm Beach, Fla., gave a tea dance yesterday in the Carlton Suite of Carlton House for their debutante daughter, Miss Barbara Ellen Bateman.
The Wilson Line, operators of nine excursion boats in East Coast ports, has been acquired by the City Investing Company. Lawrence C. Campbell has been named president.
A small battalion of boys, sitting cowboy fashion on the floor, will sing a New Year's serenade this morning to a man who believes in boys and works for their future.
HONG KONG, Dec. 31 -- The Soviet Union is scheduled to turn over to Red China tomorrow its shares in four joint stock companies established in 1950 and 1951.
MADRID, Dec. 31 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco broadcast today a message touching on the monarchy.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Allen Quay, seventh-ranked United States junior tennis player from St. Petersburg, Fla., defeated Jean Noel Grinda, the French junior champion, in the final of the Orange Bowl tournament today, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The stock markets here ended the year cheerfully despite another small reaction in Government issues. Reports of a rise in productivity during November stimulated further buying of industrial shares.

The slow, halting, but on the whole steady, progress of Guatemala toward normalcy is continuing. The Constituent Assembly ratified yesterday the Government's agreement with the United Fruit Company, closing another chapter in the stormy history of that great American company.
A comparison of religious beliefs will be made in a series of addresses beginning next week at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 30 -- The Norfolk Municipal Airport will expand its radar "seeing eye" soon to give it a range extending to New York.
TAMALE, the Gold Coast, Dec. 11 -- Few places in Africa reflect more clearly the continent's political awareness than this remote market town, capital of the Gold Coast's Northern Territories.
RAMER, Ala., Dec. 31 (AP) -- A private plane crashed in a heavy rainstorm tonight killing four persons, including Hoke L. Vandigriff, wealthy Montgomery contractor-sportsman.
PROVIDENCE, Dec. 31 -- The State of Rhode Island banned today the importation of all members of the psittacine family -- parrots, parakeets, love birds -- because of the appearance of psittacosis.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- The United States cargo preference bill was strongly criticized today in Lloyd's List and Shipping Gazette Annual Review. It also carried warnings to the British shipbuilding industry that it must reduce costs to meet foreign competition, especially from West Germany.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- After a year of buoyant prosperity and record industrial production, Britain is entering 1955 under a threat of serious labor trouble.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 31 -- A Chinese Communist map inserted in a Chinese propaganda magazine on sale in New Delhi bookstores continues a custom Indian officials have found irritating -- "appropriating" territory India considers hers.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Two key labor union officials were replaced today as members of the Unemployment Insurance Advisory Council. The action was One of Governor Dewey's last official acts as Governor.
BARABOO, Wis., Dec. 31 (UP) -- The anti-McCarthy "Joe Must Go" Club was found guilty of twenty-one violations of state law today and fined $4,200.
MANILA, Dec. 31 -- Summing up his first year in office, President Ramon Magsaysay lists several major objectives in which progress has been made and to which his administration is dedicated.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations today received the British Government's good wishes today for his mission to Peiping.

Twin lambs were born early yesterday morning to one of four Dorset ewes among the animals in the Nativity presentation at the New York Botanical Garden's Christmas show. The ewes had been borrowed, along with a goat and six chickens, from the Bronx Zoo.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Suits to enjoin the Secretary of Labor from enforcing a minimum wage of $1 an hour in cotton textile mills working on Government contracts were attacked here today.
A nonstop "prayer chain" for world peace began last night in eleven communities over the country.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- A British physicist who has been studying friction has made a number of discoveries about ice that will increase the speed of all who use skis.
John F. O'Donnell, attorney for the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., was indicted yesterday on charges or willful failure to file individual income tax returns.

HONG KONG, Dec. 31 -- A protocol on Communist China's 1955 aid to North Korea was signed today in Peiping. According to the Peiping radio, this assistance will be extended in the form of "funds and material supplies."

DALLAS, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Arkansas and Georgia Tech, exponents of two of football's most crowdpleasing plays -- the fullback draw and the belly series -- will hurl their specialties at each other tomorrow before an expected crowd of 75,504 in the Cotton Bowl.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- One can now virtually assume that West Germany will start rearming within NATO in 1955. The single most difficult legislative labyrinth has been traversed. Further parliamentary processes should succeed. Therefore it is legitimate to speculate about Soviet reactions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Coast Guard today ordered its men to board all LST vessels arriving in any port and to cancel all certificates permitting this type of ship to engage in ocean and coastwise traffic.
Metropolitan area industrial plants that participated in this year's annual contest of the Greater New York Safety Council achieved a record low accident frequency.
New securities offered publicly here by underwriters rose in volume in December over the preceding month and a year before. Bond financing was the biggest for any December in twenty-eight years.

The people of New York have direct and vital concern with the continuing operation of the piers and with the vigorous enforcement of the Bi-State Compact designed to eliminate crime and racketeering on the waterfront. From this point of view the revised tentative agreement between the shippers and the I.L. A. promises well -- at least on the face of it.
Former City Councilman Albert V. Maniscalco, Staten Island Democrat, was elected yesterday as Borough President of Richmond. He succeeds Edward G. Baker, who has been elected to the Supreme Court.

ALBANY. Dec. 31 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke had been improperly convicted of compulsory prostitution because the trial judge had barred the public and the press from the courtroom.
Former State Senator Joseph A. Esquirol was disbarred by the Appellate Division yesterday on two charges of professional misconduct.

Averell Harriman named Julius Helfand of Brooklyn yesterday as chairman of the State Athletic Commission. He also picked Angela R. Parisi of Brooklyn as chairman of the Work men's Compensation Board. Mr. Harriman announced both selections on the eve of his inauguration as Governor in Albany today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -A new law extending unemployment insurance protection to about 2,500,000 Federal civilian workers and former workers becomes effective tomorrow in all states except Michigan.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Rain today forced postponement of the seventeenth annual Sugar Bowl track and field meet until Sunday. Then Wes Santee will try again for his cherished four-minute mile.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 31 -- Northern Mexico was celebrating today the opening of the United States border to imports of Mexican cattle after a nineteen-month ban because of the hoof and mouth disease.

Handicapped by warmer weather than last year but helped by the fact that a number of stores were open two nights last week against only one a year before, New York City's department stores matched sales of the same week a year ago in the week ended Jan. 1, according to estimates by merchants.
This year a Fifth Avenue store will keep up with modern tempo without abandoning many of the graceful touches that made it a favorite with New Yorkers a century ago.

WEST SAYVILLE, L. I., Jan. 1 -- The "terrific" growth of oysters and clams in Great South Bay in the last year has been attributed largely to the reopening of Moriches Inlet in September, 1953. This was asserted here today by Joseph Glancy of Shellfish, Inc., a veteran marine biologist.
Football television policy for 1955 will receive top attention at the forty-ninth annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

Many persons marked the end of the old year or the beginning of the new by remembering the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Altogether they sent in $2,024.86, which brought the total received so far to $372,975.24 from 10,988 donors.

NOT long ago a London editor was trying to guide his readers through the wilderness of the American party system. There are four parties, he explained -- liberal Republicans, conservative Republicans, conservative Democrats and liberal Democrats.

A FEW weeks ago, when the United Nations General Assembly was debating the resolution condemning Communist China for imprisonment of United States airmen and calling on the U. N. to exert every effort to obtain their freedom, a reporter asked Dag Hammarskjold whether he would go to Peiping himself, if that were necessary.

The Cabinet is again studying the East-West trade issue. "Officials Alarmed by Volume of Potential War Supplies Being Sold to Soviet Bloc," reads a Times headline. Both Washington and London are again tightening export controls.
On the surface, the Dodgers may appear to be standing pat for 1955 as repeated efforts to swing deals wind up in smoke.

America's medical schools face a crisis which can only be resolved by increased public interest and support, according to study entitled "The Challenge to Medical Education," issued by the Public Affairs Committee, 22 East, Thirty-eighth Street, New York City.
The device by the West to enlarge its European defense apparatus cleared a high hurdle last week. But many other hurdles still were ahead.

"Enterprising," "ambitious," "aggressive," are adjectives sometimes used to describe the characteristics of rising young business men. But the second career of Harvey Greenspan, which began when he was well past forty, also was distilled from such qualities and his success in his chosen field, the canning of citrus fruit, is still based on them.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 1 -- The Hampton Roads Maritime Association said in its thirty-fifth annual report here that the port area has enjoyed a banner year in 1954.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Jacob K. Javits opened his term as Attorney General today with a pledge that he would "take to the people" details of any significant investigation by his office with which the Harriman Administration refused to cooperate.
A routine police check of a swindle suspect seen in a shiny automobile led to the arrest yesterday of two men assertedly scheming "to take a bank."

THE recent airplane crash at Idlewild Airport has provoked a great deal of theorizing about why it happened. Dozens of possible contributing causes have been suggested: the instrument-landing gauge was faulty; the plane was coming in a bit slow and was stalled out by a freak gust of wind; the pilot had been on duty a long time and was fatigued; he was confused by the approach lights.

Not only possible, indeed, but a reality.

The sled is one of the crudest of vehicles. It far precedes the invention of the wheel in man's conquest of terrestial space. But it was in a sled that a new record for land travel was set last week -- a scientifically designed twentieth century sled that reached 632 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Senator James E. Murray said today that President Eisenhower's expected request for an increase in the minimum wage to 90 cents an hour is a "very good move," but doesn't go far enough.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Like many projects enthusiastically adopted in the hours of celebration but quickly dropped in the sober dawn of New Year's Day, many prospective investigations by the new Democratic Congress will never come off at all.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Veterans home loans jumped 25 per cent last year to pass the 400,000 mark, the Veterans Administration reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A vast area of South Jersey woodland, almost large enough for a city the size of Philadelphia, now belongs to the State of New Jersey as the result of a $2,000,000 purchase.

THOUSANDS of students have done the tough, mind-training exercises in the textbook by Morris R. Cohen and Ernest Nagel on "Logic and Scientific Method." THE Metropolitan Opera House, for a lyric theatre of its dimensions, reputation and repertory, is one of the most old-fashioned and ill-equipped for its purposes in the world. But the house has its atmosphere and its artistic history.

The appointment of Edward Corsi of New York as special assistant to the Secretary of State on refugee and migration matters is one more indication that in this sphere things have not been going satisfactorily. EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Quarterback Jesse Whittenton ran, passed and piloted Texas Western to its second straight Sun Bowl victory today, a 47-20 rout of Florida State.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Australia and England today were locked in a grim struggle for the first innings lead after two days' play in their third test match.

THE British contract bridge team, champions of Europe, will arrive in New York this week to play for the world championship against the American team that won the masters' team championship last summer. The match will begin next Sunday and 224 deals will be played at a leisurely pace throughout, the week, ending on Saturday, Jan. 15. All play will be at the Beekman Hotel, 575 Park Avenue.

Last week saw the usual holiday quiet in the wholesale markets, but retailers are eagerly looking forward to the openings of summer lines early in February, resident buying offices report. Meantime, manufacturers are beginning to ship large quantities of resort and early spring merchandise.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Jan. 1 -- Conditions at the Missouri State Penitentiary were denounced by a special investigating committee today.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 1 -- India's Christians have protested to the Government that attacks against foreign missionaries are widening into attacks against Christianity itself.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Several patronage disputes arose today to bedevil the new Democratic State Administration just as it was taking office.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- About $2,000,000,000 in state unemployment insurance was paid to jobless workers last year.

ISTANBUL, Turkey -- In a remarkable recovery from the most devastating fire in its 500-year history, Istanbul's Covered Bazaar, one of the most famous tourist attractions in the world, is now back in business. Late in the night of Nov. 26 a fire started in a quiltmaker's shop, presumably from a short-circuit.

Teachers College, Columbia University, has developed a center for the training of rural leaders in the United States and in underdeveloped countries. Its students have included field workers and directors in the rural extension services and farm organizations, officers in United States technical assistance programs in Africa and the free countries of Asia, ministers of rural and farm affairs of other Governments, professors of rural sociology and others working for the beterment of farm populations.

CAIRO, Jan. 1 -- Ocean shipping piled up today at both ends of the Suez Canal while engineers expressed hopes that the waterway could be cleared in three days to a week. It was blocked yesterday by debris from a wrecked bridge and tanker that hit it.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Bill Engelhardt, the nation's leading ground gainer among small colleges, passed and ran Omaha University to a 7-6 victory over Eastern Kentucky in the Tangerine Bowl tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- Jim Garrity, a 177-pound end from Penn State, kicked the point after touchdown in the fourth quarter that gave the East an upset 13-12 victory over the West in the thirtieth annual Shrine game today.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Coach Eddie Erdelatz of Navy relaxed in the dressing room after his team had whipped Mississippi today. "It was easier than I thought it would be," he said.

Floyd Patterson, the Brooklyn light heavyweight of more than ordinary promise, will appear in the star bout at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. He will tackle Willie Troy of Washington, D. C., in a contest limited to eight rounds because of Patterson's age.

Leaders in business and industry, education and the social sciences have founded a new organization to encourage the application of new scientific developments to the problems of human communications. WITH the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra getting ready for a tour of Europe in the spring, the music season made a very early start. Conductors of the opening series of subscription concerts were Igor Markevitch, Heinz Freudenthal and Sergiu Celibidache.
ROME, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Horse racing, carrying too much tax weight for its organizers, halted in Italy today. There was no sign when the tracks might open again.

THE painter - turned - novelist Mordecai Richler wrote "The Acrobats" at 22 after leaving his native Montreal to live abroad. The Western Hemisphere seems assured of adequate supplies of iron ore from its own resources for decades as the result of the major development program devoted to this key commodity in 1954. Canada and Latin America accelerated the output of new mines last year and added several iron ore bodies to mounting reserves of this principal ingredient of steel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 - President Eisenhower goes before a joint session of the new Democratic Congress Thursday to outline what he has characterized as a moderately progressive program. PARIS, Jan. 1 -- Dag Hammarskjold left Europe today for China, briefed on what the British and French think can be done to keep peace in Asia. DALLAS, Jan. 1 -- Georgia Tech, with three powerful fullbacks hammering the Arkansas line today, pulled out a 14-to-6 Cotton Bowl victory -- the ninth triumph in a brilliant Georgia Tech bowl career.

WHILE the automotive industry enters the new year with an outpouring of 1955 cars that shine, speed and perform as never before, the 1956 cars are being completed on the industry's drawing boards with a view to outshining, outspeeding and outperforming their predecessors Furthermore, the 1957 models are by now in the planning stage with hundreds of ideas being offered by engineers, body stylists and fabric designers.
PARIS, Jan. 1 -- A new diplomatic situation is expected to arise with official acceptance by France of the arming of West Germany.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Coach Woody Hayes of the victorious Ohio State Buckeyes complained after today's Rose Bowl game that the contest took place under the "worst playing conditions" they had encountered in four years.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Ohio State's smooth - clicking Buckeyes, led by Dave Leggett at quarterback, plowed through the mud of the Rose Bowl in a rainstorm to a 20-to-7 victory today over Southern California before 89,191 fans.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 1 -- Retail trade in the Tenth Federal Reserve District carried through from the record Christmas volume to assure a gain of about 3 per cent for the year. This was considerably better than reported for the entire country.

THE floodtide of Biblical novels bears both purple and prosy books on its crest. This one is prosy, pedestrian and inoffensive. The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor said yesterday it expected to strike 8,300 names from the longshoremen's register. The men are registered as longshoremen but "neither work nor make their effort to find work on the waterfront with any degree of regularity," it declared.

A FILMED conversation with Sir Osbert Sitwell, English poet and satirist, will be presented today from 5:30 to 6 P. M. by the National Broadcasting Company television network. Brush off woolly leaves such as those of African violets. Pinch back the tips of scented geraniums and other plants that look spindly.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Averell Harriman promised "a bold and adventurous administration" today as he was formally inaugurated to succeed Thomas E. Dewey as Governor of New York.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 1 -- A German-Italian commission is to be constituted this month to discuss an important aspect of the arming of West Germany. MONTREAL, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens stretched their first-place lead in the National Hockey League to six points with an easy 4-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings before 14,218 Forum fans tonight.

The high proportion of physically unfit young men has been the subject of continuing concern to the nation's defense authorities ever since 1940, when Congress enacted the first peacetime Selective Service Act. The rejection rate during the Second World War was far too high and it rose during the Korean conflict to the point where one-third of the men called for service had to be rejected -- mostly for physical reasons.

January was named for Janus, the two-faced deity who could look in both directions. He was a god of gates and beginnings, and the choice of Janus to symbolize the first month after the winter solstice was neither whim nor accident. This is a time when man, since the ancient days, has looked back as well as forward and drawn a kind of tally line and made his summations.

MOST visitors to Africa go out either to admire its landscapes, pursue its game, exploit its resources or analyze its anachronisms. Father Considine went out for a different reason. As a distinguished Catholic priest and Maryknoll missionary, he made his journey to inspect the work of the Church and must have come away feeling that the old continent was still largely dark.
Mr. Lunt's performance in "Quadrille" is an excellent lesson in playwriting, in acting, in creating in any form * * *.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- Arthur Devlin, who is hoping for his fourth berth on the American Olympic team, returned to his local hill today and turned in another of his fine ski jumping performances. It was an exhibition that proved the 32-year-old star still was in top form.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Pitt's Panthers jolted Penn's Quakers from the list of the nation's unbeaten college basketball teams tonight with an 81-75 overtime victory at the Palestra.

THE new year for gardeners opens with a roster of courses and lectures to fill in idle hours while they await the spring thaws and chores. And for those in the vicinity of New York, there are many from which to choose.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 1 -- The Colombo powers -- Pakistan, India, Ceylon, Burma and Indonesia -- have enhanced their influence in world affairs by completing arrangements at a meeting in Bogor, near here, for a conference of thirty Asian and African nations.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Determine, thoroughbred racing's 1954 money-winning king, wasted no time today in getting off to a good start for 1955. He raced to a smashing one-length victory in the $28,450 Malibu Sequet Stakes before a crowd of 30,000 at rain-drenched Santa Anita Park.

ADULTS will love reading this story out loud: It has delightful touches of sophisticated humor and provides opportunities for dramatic expression. But what about Johnny, who's patiently listening while papa is playing Charles Laughton?

SYRACUSE, Jan. 1 -- Syracuse University School of Journalism announced today a program leading to the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in Communications (press), beginning in February. Dr. George L. Bird, chairman of the graduate division of the school, will be in charge of the program.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- The Sugar Bowl game between Navy and Mississippi today was no contest. The midshipmen eleven from Annapolis picked up where it left off against Army in the Philadelphia Municipal Stadium and scored an overwhelming victory over the Rebels, 21 -- 0.

Prof. James McGregor Burns' recent comments on college debating -- "Debate Over Collegiate Debates" (Dec. 5) -- were mostly well taken. It seems to me, however, that he may have left a somewhat erroneous impression of some aspects of debate, and I am certain that he failed to give sufficient credit to debate as an educational venture.

GENEVA, Dec. 29 -- While President Eisenhower and Congress are being advised to make it easier for American capital to move abroad, economists here are worrying about the persistent tendency of capital to move the other way.

IN the summer of 1953, while the world was being stirred, in surprise and satisfaction, by the conquest of Mount Everest, a small party of climbers was undergoing about 900 miles to the westward one of the worst experiences in mountaineering history, an experience in which the human spirit was as brilliantly engaged as in the ordeal of Everest.

ALMOST all the top-flight writers of Western fiction are members of the Western Writers of America, a lively group which each year presents a roundup of the best of the year's short stories by its members. HOLSTERS AND HEROES (Macmillan, $2.95) -- twelve well-selected stories -- is a must for every aficionado of Western tales.
An acute nation-wide shortage of trained social workers is alarming many officials of public and private welfare agencies.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- A group of thirty-five persons were on hand today to wish former Governor Dewey and Mrs. Dewey godspeed and good luck when he took off from this city this afternoon following the inauguration of Mr. Harriman.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 1 -- In the woods north of here residents are seeking clarification of a law passed late in the eighteenth century. Traced back as far as 1796 and now known as Section 496 of the General Statutes, the law defines the qualifications of persons entitled to vote in town meetings.

This Wednesday the Eighty-fourth Congress convenes and organizes. The next day President Eisenhower will be escorted to the rostrum of the House to address the assembled Congress on the State of the Union. This will be the line-up spread before him:

NOW that "Animal Farm," England's first feature-length cartoon film, has been unveiled here, it may be revealed that the husband-and-wife team of John Halas and Joy Batchelor, who produced it for presentation by Louis de Rochemont, are preparing another decidedly unusual feature.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 1 -- President Eisenhower fixed Jan. 31 today as the terminal date for various veterans' wartime benefits granted in the Korean War.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 1 -- Arthur Knapp Jr. of Larchmont scored four straight victories with the interclub Agony in the twenty-third annual frostbite regatta off the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today.

Despite the fact that the United States is now an important world power, large numbers of boys and girls go through school with only a smattering of knowledge about contemporary events and world history. The National Council for the Social Studies in recent reports points out that the nation's high school students are not getting adequate instruction in such subjects as history, geography, current events and social studies generally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Dozens of the great and near-great in the world of football will get together here Saturday night for the twentieth annual Touchdown Club awards dinner with the spotlight fixed on a pair of quarterbacks, Ralph Guglielmi and Norm Van Brocklin.

A Midwest manufacturer is slated again to head pleasure boating's largest body. Kenneth B. Champ of Findlay, Ohio, who has to travel by auto to Lake Erie to reach his cruiser, heads the nomination of officers of the United States Power Squadrons.
William F. Talbert, the non- playing captain of the victorious United States Davis Cup team, has been named the No. 1 player by the ranking committee of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association.
New markets are opening in Western Europe for American lumber and the area's increasing dependency on overseas supply of the commodity promises a steady rise in these exports.

ONE of the liveliest and most interesting exhibitions of the season has emerged as part of the celebration of the diamond jubilee of the Archaeological Institute of America in Boston. The Fogg Museum has, in fact, put on two exhibitions at once -- the first consisting of examples of ancient art in American private collections and the second illustrating the scope and influence of Hellenistic art in Asia.

FOR more than two years, Japan has been startling the motion picture world with fine films. At least seven have won international awards, of which three. "Rashomon," "Ugetsu" and "Gate of Hell," have been released here, and others are to come.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 1 -- Egypt released today ten Israeli sailors detained on Sept. 28 when their 500-ton freighter, the Bat Galim, was seized in the Gulf of Suez.
OMAHA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Aircraft accidents in the Strategic Air Command, including everything from scraped wing tips to major accidents, hit a new low of thirteen for each 100,000 flying hours in 1954.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 1 -- The Rockefeller Foundation has granted $500,000 to Princeton University's special program in Near Eastern studies for research, teacher training and interdepartmental study.

THERE could hardly have been a more opportune time for a new biography of D. H. Lawrence and for the painstaking, thorough kind of book which Mr. Moore has written. During his lifetime Lawrence was much misunderstood as a doctrinaire novelist obsessed with sex, a half-truth concealing the whole truth more effectively than mere falsehood.
After the customary holiday lull, the art season resumes its activities with some forty exhibitions scheduled for the first week of the new year.
New Yorkers were urged yesterday by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum "to underplay the negative and play up the positive in the year ahead.

THE ruling hierarchy of the Eighty-fourth Congress is both a triumph for the middle-roaders, who personify it, and a clear expression of geographical political tradition. The South, so traditionally Democratic, is omnipresent in the Democratic leadership; no other section is represented at all at the top.

The Senate and the nation will be fortunate when Senator John L. McClellan takes over as chairman of the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations and its parent body, the Committee on Government Operations. They will be fortunate because the senior Senator from Arkansas, with evident sincerity, has promised to introduce some reforms into the investigative procedure.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 21 -- Tennessee's Legislature, convening Jan. 3, must enact laws under a revised Constitution.

TO criticize a theatre piece as too theatrical is as senseless as to criticize a piece of music for being too musical. There is only one kind of bad theatre: When the author's imagination steps outside the very area of illusion he has created. But as long as the dramatist creates within that area, almost no action on the stage is too violent or implausible.

Efforts of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York to make the city a better place in which to live and work will be furthered by the Feb. 15 benefit performance of Christopher Fry's play "The Dark Is Light Enough." The play starring Katharine Cornell, opens Feb. 9.

SEVERAL new photographic shows, the first announced for the new year, will open this week. Limelight Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, will exhibit the work of David Vestal, tomorrow through Feb. 14. The American Museum of Natural History's "The Camera at the Museum" opens Wednesday in the Corner Gallery at the museum.
English, psychology and history rank as the most popular major subjects among Barnard College upper-class students this year, according to a report issued by the registrar, Miss Margaret Giddings.
Columbia Records announced yesterday that it would reduce the price of most of its twelve-inch long-playing records to $3.98. The new price scale will go into effect tomorrow.

Although cost-of-living items in New York City set a record last July, the level of prices declined slightly in 1954, according to a year-end report released yesterday by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

THE introduction of color television should be speeded up in the public interest. That is the only possible conclusion to be drawn from the succession of beautiful holiday shows that only a handful of persons saw in natural hues. To shilly-shally around with black-and-white video a moment longer than necessary is manifestly absurd after the Christmas and New Year festivities on TV.

The Fund for the Advancement of Education has announced 200 fellowships for high school teachers for 1955-56. The purpose of the fellowships is to strengthen secondary school teaching and to stimulate consideration of liberal studies in secondary education.
The French National Assembly's narrow margin of approval for German rearmament last week and the bitter debate that was its corollary posed more problems for the New Year than they answered.
The year came to a close last week with a strong demonstration of investor confidence in the future economy of the nation. Stocks soared to new high levels in the heaviest trading in four years.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- Life is certainly real and often earnest in this Socialist society, but not on New Year's afternoon in the Hall of Columns of the House of Trade Unions when 1,000 happy children are dancing around the New Year's tree.

The Oppenheimer case was again brought to public notice last week with the publication of a book entitled "We Accuse," by Joseph and Stewart Alsop, and the circulation of a memorandum by the Atomic Energy Commission in rebuttal of points raised by the Alsops.
The year just ended was one in which great advances -- both medically and socially -- were made in rehabilitation and services to the handicapped.

SOON to arrive in the mails are the new season's catalogues with their promise of bright days to come. Always a welcome sight in winter, gardeners everywhere will pick and choose from their colorful pages those seeds and plants that they will want to order for the year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -World statesmen attending the Moral Re-Armament Assembly here said today their program answered "the most burning questions of the day."

THE dozen separate essays which go to make this book are remarkable not for their speculative profundity but for their dialectical neatness and descriptive clarity. This is as it should be. Mr. Ayer, who is Professor of Philosophy at the University of London, is conspicuous among contemporary philosophers who eschew preoccupation with traditional problems of "destiny" in honor of those that can be clearly understood and definitely answered.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The British Government began the new year by sprinkling cold water on Premier Malenkov's suggestion for a conference to settle Far Eastern problems.

The sugar quota for 1955, announced in mid-December by the Department of Agriculture, will be used as the springboard for a campaign to increase the allotment assigned to mainland cane and domestic beet sugar producers.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 1 -- School officials here will overlap junior and senior classes to accommodate in the high school 700 pupils from the burned-out Burdick Junior High School.

Moscow's announcement ten days ago of the execution of the former secret police chief, Victor S. Abakumov, revived memories of 1953's "doctors' plot." It stirred new speculation about possible intrigue and rivalry in the Kremlin.

ALBERT SALMI, who plays the violent, funny younger brother in "The Rainmaker," is a 26-year-old homme naturel of Finnish descent with patently blond hair, complementary blue eyes and a broad face full of what appears to be an unspecified foreboding, but which may be no more than an accident of physiognomy.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 1 -- Increased tonnages of all major commodities are possible for Great Lakes shipping next season.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The State Department disclosed late tonight that the Soviet Union had offered to release two United States citizens long held in Russia.

Prospects for the graduating class of 1955 are bright, according to a survey made by the placement department at Northwestern University. A group of 152 large and medium-sized companies report that they will hire 19 per cent more engineers and other technical graduates and 2 per cent more non-technical graduates than last year.
The new calendar that came the other day, to take its place on the wall and stay there for twelve months, deserves a second look.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Rusty Fairly's mixture of daring signal calling and flawless ball handling paid off in a surprise 20-to-13 Salad Bowl football triumph today for the Skyline Conference over the favored Border Conference senior all-stars.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- The new year will be one of great decision for Westchester's worst problem child -- the outmoded parkway system.

TOKYO, Jan. 1 -- The Japanese Government appears to be of two minds about accepting an invitation to the conference of Asian and African nations at Bandung, Indonesia, in late April. Authorities say all implications of this meeting will be thoroughly explored here before Tokyo accepts.

It is difficult indeed to enter the lists with Dr. Rajagopalachari whose highmindedness is again evidenced in his recent letter to The New York Times. His concern over the use of atomic weapons is shared by all.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- Department stores in the eight-county metropolitan Philadelphia area did 7 per cent more business in the five-week Christmas shopping period starting after Thanksgiving, than in the same period a year before.

EASTOH, Md. -- A new era in the affairs of Maryland's Eastern Shore is unfolding, brought about by the completion of the two big bridges, one across Chesapeake Bay and the other across the Delaware River below Wilmington, and their connecting superhighways, including the New Jersey Turnpike.
The Marine Historical Association, an organization devoted to providing a snug harbor for venerable ships, quietly observed its twenty-fifth anniversary on Christmas Day.

A third of all transfusions given in the city's hospitals during 1954 were provided through the total contribution of 144,480 pints of blood collected by the New York Regional Blood Program of the American Red Cross.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Nineteen Fifty-five is more than a new year. It marks the end of the first post-war decade, and the beginning of America's long trial of endurance in the Cold War.

THE most important and closely fought conservation issue of 1954 was the battle over the proposed invasion of Dinosaur National Monument for construction of the giant Echo Park Dam. Conservationists managed to stave off authorization of the structure at the last Congress; but there is no doubt at all that the struggle will begin again in the Eighty-fourth Congress with renewed vigor.

CAIRO, Jan. 1 -- British authorities turned over to Egypt today control of an eighty-seven-mile oil pipeline between Suez and Cairo under terms of the agreement for British evacuation of the Suez Canal zone.

TORONTO, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Jerry Toppazinni, a husky utility forward who seldom bothers goalies, beat Harry Lumley twice in the second period tonight to earn the Chicago Black Hawks a 2-2 tie With the Toronto Maple Leafs.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The foxes of Yorkshire, long accustomed to huntsmen in pink, will have to beware of huntsmen in army khaki soon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell today ended twenty-eight months as Democratic National Chairman.
Balmy weather provided a pleasant backdrop across the country yesterday for the big red "1" that appeared on 1955 calendars.

FROM now until mid-March the prime mover in the earth's weather machine takes on an additional job. It boosts along airliners on the Tokyo-Honolulu run so that they make the trip more than an hour faster than in spring and summer and omit the fuel stop at Wake Island.

LIANG YEN'S account of her childhood in a conservative Mongol family living in Peiping and her subsequent break with the traditions of that family in order to make her own way in the world is a fascinating account of one woman's independent course in modern China.

THE first seed of potential political controversy, touched off by an effort to bar Communists, has taken root in the newly established Writers Guild of America, West and East. The organization, which grew out of the overhaul of the Authors League of America, embraces the membership of the old Screen Writers Guild, the Radio Writers Guild and the Television Writers Group.
The Navy football team defeated Mississippi, 21 to 0, yesterday before 82,000 in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans. The middies scored twice on plunges by Joe Gattuso and once on a pass to John Weaver.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Epic King, a dark brown gelding who is rated strictly a sprinter, posted one of his best performances today in defeating Two Fisted by a neck in the mile-and- a-sixteenth New Year's Handicap at the Fair Grounds.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Spokesmen for United States foreign policy had a chilling reply today to the latest Soviet expression of willingness to negotiate solutions of problems in the Far East.

RESIDENTS of the Laurentian region are hard at it to make the 1955 Laurentian Winter Carnival, unfolding at Ste. Agathe des Monts Feb. 10-22, the best show of its kind. On near-by Lac des Sables a giant ice palace is being designed; a launching platform is being built on the hill behind it for the elaborate fireworks display.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Government is tightening the legal noose around the neck of the Communist party, but the consensus here is that the party still has a chance to cheat the hangman.

ALTHOUGH Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Saint of Bleecker Street" is opera, it is produced as a Broadway show. In the program, it is described as a "music drama in three acts," as if it were written by a Broadway song-writer in a more elevated mood than usual.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Six tie games prevented any major changes in the First Division standings of the English Soccer League today. Sunderland retained its one-point lead by playing a 1-1 draw with Tottenham.

The Fund for the Advancement of Education of the Ford Foundation is offering 150 faculty fellowships for the academic year 1955-56 to strengthen college teaching in the liberal arts and to stimulate widespread consideration of the purposes, means and ends of a liberal education.

HIS name was Virgil Kern and he was a night cop at Des Moines, Iowa. He was a lean, hard, tough cop with a lovely teen-age daughter and he had a desperate desire to keep her from the wickedness that sickened him when he flashed his light into cars parked on back streets.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The new flexible farm price support program became effective today, with its fate again up in the air.

The American Jewish Committee urged Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson yesterday to disavow as "irresponsible and scurrilous" a letter from a White Russian immigrant applauding the dismissal of Wolf Ladejinsky.

A NEW color film having a daylight sensitivity approaching that of average-speed black-and-white film will be made available this month for users of miniature cameras. It is Kodak Ektachrome film in twenty-exposure 35mm and eight-exposure 828 (bantam) rolls, priced, respectively, at $1.85 and $1 (processing extra) and offered in a daylight type and a flash type, the latter balanced for use with clear wire-filled lamps.

Prices of stocks, rising 49 per cent last year, discounted the expectation of higher earnings but they did not run wild, in the opinion of many observers. At the level at noon on Friday, prices on the fifty industrial stocks in the Standard Poor's index were 13.28 times the earnings. This compared favorably with the peak ratios of 19.45 in 1929, of 16.69 in 1937, of 20.07 in 1945 and of 17.46 in 1946.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The picketing of Yankee Stadium by the musicians' union last spring and summer was ruled unlawful today.

AS the big American plane rises over Delhi's dusty international airport, across a plain dotted with Mogul ruins, and puts an end to a period of seven years in India, memories tumble over one another with the speed of the churning propellers.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Governor and Mrs. Averell Harriman shook the hands of happy Democrats this evening at the rate of more than twenty-three a minute.

THE spring of 1906 started like any other for Chuck Randall and his chum Barney Burke. Spearing suckers in the brook, shooting crows, playing baseball against the French Indians and other activities dear to a New Hampshire boy's heart kept them busy.

State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits has asked all his staff to comply "in letter and spirit" with the new State Code of Ethics for legislators and public officials. It came into effect on Saturday, the day he took office.

Konigsberg, president of Standard Rolling Mills, has become vice president of Revere and will continue in active charge of the new Standard division of Revere.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2 (UP) -- Senora Jose Antonio Remon answered a telephone call at a dinner party tonight and learned that machine-gunners had made her a widow.
Winding up their best year of growth in 1954, the nation's savings and loan associations predict that the coming year will be even better.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Prices in Montgomery Ward Co.'s 1955 spring and summer catalogue average about 2 1/2 to 3 per cent less than the prices in the 1954 issue, the company announced today.
The star at the opening of the American Spaniel Club specialty in the Hotel Roosevelt last night was a cocker spaniel puppy who will be seven months old on Thursday.
Soaring coffee prices presented a problem to the housewife last year. However, her reaction to the sharp rise created greater difficulties for growers and roasters.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The British aviation industry, both military and civil, is passing through difficult times.
Floyd Patterson of Brooklyn, the fifth-ranking light heavyweight contender, will oppose Willie Troy, Washington middleweight, in a scheduled 8-round main bout at Madison Square Garden Friday night.
SOUTH BEND, IND., Jan. 2 (UP) -- Clarence E. Manion said tonight that Supreme Court reversals were threatening constitutional freedom and destroying an effective barrier against communism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Foreign Operations Administration has been circulating statistics to show the extent to which the United States economy has benefited from, or become dependent on, the foreign-aid program.

ATLANTA -- The Department of Labor's Regional Bureau of Labor Statistics, noting the strong increase in manufacturing employment in the Southeast in the final quarter of 1954, reported on average weekly earnings in October, a peak month.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 2 -- Dag Hammarskjold repeatedly refused today to concede any link between his journey to Peiping to try to free imprisoned United States airmen and the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

United States business leadership routed the forces of pessimism in 1954. Not only did it overcome a further mild adjustment in the nation's economy, but it also set in motion a recovery of industrial activity as the year ended. The net result was the second best business year ever.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- Puerto Rico is facing the new year confident that it promises to be the brightest in the economy of its 462-year-old history.
The left-wing International Fur and Leather Workers Union has made new moves toward "decommunization" in an effort to get into the American Federation of Labor.
The tobacco industry slipped somewhat during the year, but its leaders look ahead confidently.

DETROIT, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Red Kelly scored from a goal-mouth scramble with less than five minutes remaining tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 3-2 victory over the National Hockey League-leading Montreal Canadiens before 13,472 -- the largest crowd of the season at the Olympia.
SAN FRANCISCO -- A high degree of stability has marked the economy of the West Coast during the last year. Most economists and industrialists believe this stability will continue through 1955.

United States corporations set a new high record in 1954 in payment of fringe benefits to their workers. Supplements to wages and salaries in the form of welfare benefits rose to an annual rate of $10,400,000,000 for the first time. The ratio of such payments to total wages and salaries paid increased to 6.4 per cent, also a new high point.
The tightening job market, with its greater emphasis upon the skilled worker, is expected to place new demands on New York State's private trade schools.

Before private industry in the United States can take full advantage of its new opportunity for atomic energy development, one of the important questions that must be settled is how to get insurance coverage for the installations involved.
BALTIMORE -- Last year was the third best, in many respects, in the history of the Baltimore business and industrial area. Trends at the year's end encouraged optimism for a prosperous 1955.
A state mediator tried last night to hammer out a settlement of the two-day-old strike that threatens to cut off a major part of the city's fresh fruits and vegetables.

CHICAGO -- While the general outlook for agriculture in 1955 is "good," according to observers here, the portents for the dairy products industry is not so favorable, according to Ernest Baughman, economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- A new Government agency said today it did not plan "censorship" but wanted to advise editors what technical information might help a potential enemy if published currently.

In past years, it has been the custom to drop a few hints to Santa Claus in connection with prep schools. The Yule season, however, has come and gone. The result is that even if requests were made, Santa probably would be too well entrenched in his retreat at the North Pole to pay them much heed.

More United States Savings Bonds were sold last year than in 1953. But the gain was almost counterbalanced by increased redemptions. These turn-ins were larger to the extent of leaving a total outstanding on Nov. 1, of $58,186,000,000, compared with $57,775,000,000 a year earlier.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 2 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali condemned today the idea that democracy and communism could coexist, a policy advocated as practicable by Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India.
Television receiver manufacturers went back to work today plagued by a substantial 1954 inventory hangover, but they turned on the production heat just the same.
Amott, Baker Co., Inc., which hitherto has dealt in unlisted securities, has become a member corporation of the New York Stock Exchange.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The stock markets ended a most profitable year in fine style. Cheered by the sustained strength of Wall Street and by many favorable factors in the outlook, industrial equities rose to a new record. The Financial Times index was up to 184, as compared with 130.7 at the beginning of the year.
The year 1954 was one of adjustment for the textile industry. Surplus inventories carried over from the previous year were worked off and the industry geared its output to the lower demand.

LOS ANGELES -- Total capital investment for industrial development in Los Angeles County during the eleven-month period from January through November, 1954, surpassed the figure for the entire year of 1953, Charles Detoy, president of the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce, reported.
George Koltanowski of San Francisco, former chess champion of Belgium, opposed eight members of the New World Chess Club at 225 West 76th Street yesterday in a performance of blindfold play.

President Jose Antonio Remon, who was assassinated yesterday, was inaugurated on Oct. 1, 1952. He was a former chief of Panama's National Police. A professional soldier, he assumed the police post in 1947, and thereafter became known as the "strong man" of his country as well as a maker and breaker of Presidents.
The vanguard of a record 1,400 delegates to the forty-ninth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association convention arrived here yesterday.

The way things are made in the nation's factories is gradually being changed. Mechanical processes directed by men are more and more being directed by machines. The machines store up instructions and issue orders to the manufacturing units, just as was done by the men they replace.
PHILADELPHIA -- The new year finds manufacturers and businesses in this metropolitan district in the midst of a mild upswing and more optimistic than they have been for a long time.
Those little collapsible metal tubes for packaging toothpaste, ointments, and the like, use up a substantial amount of metal in the course of a year.
Panama's delegate to the United Nations said last night a woman who had pointed out President Jose Antonio Remon had been jailed in Panama.
HONOLULU -- Business men here are generally optimistic despite growing competition in Hawaii's major industries and a chronic unemployment problem.
The names of the new commanders of the recently established burglary squads in four boroughs of the city became known yesterday at Police Headquarters.
Virtually all of Centra! Amer-I ica has been bedeviled these days by tension. ]

By breathing billions of cubic feet of natural gas into giant underground "lungs" during the summer and "exhaling" into vast networks of pipelines during the winter, storage reservoirs have revolutionized winter peak supply problems for hundreds of cities.
Completely centralized buying through its Department of Purchase could save the city "untold millions," Commissioner Joseph V. Spagna declared yesterday.
The hotel industry, the fourth largest service group in the nation, expects to increase its dollar volume about 5 per cent this year.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 -- The deep South is ready to take Navy to its bosom as one of its own.
Railroads returned to the bond market in 1954 to effectuate long-term borrowings on the biggest scale since the end of the cheap-money period in the late Forties.
Civil rights made great gains last year, the annual report of the American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday.
Fordham University's basketball team, fresh from the Queens City tournament in Buffalo, will resume its regular-season campaign tonight in a game with Princeton at the Fordham gymnasium, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON -- Rumors that the Justice Department will recommend repeal of the McGuire Act were general among trade association executives and members as the year drew to a close.

The Minerva Soccer Club of the German-American League defeated the New York Americans of the American League, 2 -- 1, at Zerega Oval yesterday. The defeat eliminated the defending champions from the National Challenge Cup competition.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 -- Paramount has negotiated multiple picture contracts with William Wyler and Billy Wilder that provide for the director-producers to participate in profits of their films. The studio announced that the agreements run for a "period of years," but would not reveal the exact duration. The two men recently entered into profit-sharing deals as well with Allied Artists to make a group of pictures.
One three - dimensional bullet was added yesterday afternoon to the scores of filmed shots that enliven a motion picture called "Vera Cruz" at the Capitol Theatre.
