BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 2 -- Milovan Djilas and Vladimir Dedijer are expected to be called again this week before the district judge investigating their case.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 2 -- Two additional special messages, dealing with the Federal programs for health reinsurance and national highways, will be sent to Congress this month by President Eisenhower.

When business historians write the story of 1954 the consumer will undoubtedly emerge as the hero. About Easter time he began to feel that the widespread talk of a recession was exaggerated and started to buy the things he wanted.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" will receive its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday evening, Jan. 12. Dolores Wilson, who will sing her first Metropolitan Zerlina then, will be the newcomer to the cast.
Heavy toy inventories early last year may have held back manufacturers' sales, but retail activity continued to improve, as it has for more than a decade.
New equipment financing by railroads in the public market declined during 1954 for the third successive year.
Demand for memberships on the New York Stock Exchange in 1954 lifted prices for "seats" to their highest level since 1946. Heavier trading gave impetus to the sales.
HANOI, Vietnam, Jan. 1 -- Five thousand Vietminh troops paraded through Hanoi for five hours today in a New Year demonstration against "United States imperialism."

BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The free-scoring Celtics tied New York for second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association by defeating the Knicks, 113 -- 96, tonight at Boston Garden. The victors outscored their opponents, 38 -- 15, in the decisive third period.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The complex debate on German rearmament has had evident repercussions abroad that may yet affect France's diplomatic and strategic relationships. Voices again are heard in the United States demanding that less military reliance be placed upon this country because of the near anarchy in its politics.

GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Lloyd Johnson, American bobsledding world champion in 1953, was seriously injured in a sled crash today but doctors said he would recover in a few weeks.
The Board of Education has] written the final chapter to "The Mystery of the M/ssing Teachers."

Anxiety over tax regulations and legislation on social security changes had a retarding influence on pension planning in the early part of 1954. Once these questions were resolved, however, pension plan activity increased sharply and continued to go forward as the year ended. The new year is expected to bring a further expansion in this field.

Sulphur production in this country rose to a record high, estimated at 6,600,000 long tons last year, or 350,000 tons more than in 1953. And producers were trying to add further to the sulphur supply as the new year began.

ASK any baseball manager what he seeks most in a player and he'll respond, "The old hustle." It's an admirable quality, particularly in the other fellow. For fifteen years Bob Sieger of The Detroit News, a man of prodigious energy, tenderly assembled lists of carelessly spoken words. His eager ear picked up statements, prophecies and other foot-in-the-mouth remarks that the embarrassed sports figures wished they'd never made.
The report of Deputy Superintendent of Insurance Straub to Governor Dewey on union and employer welfare funds is a thoroughgoing and statesmanlike document -- most timely and useful.
A leader in the conservation of natural resources sent $25 yesterday to aid human victims of circumstance whose preservation is a goal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The Republican high command brought up a new "big gun" today for a potential battle of the budget.

CHICAGO -- A solid business and financial base was laid in the Middle West during 1954 upon which the coming business year will record possible gains and, at worst, hold the gains made in the year just closed. This was the consensus of a score of the region's business leaders.
The automatic merchandising industry made advanced strides in 1954 with gross sales approximating $1,750,000,000 against $1,500,000.000 the year before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland, who has differed with the President on foreign issues, expressed the belief today that there would be "a large measure of bipartisan cooperation in the matter of foreign and defense policies, and I hope on a good deal of the domestic program to be presented by the President."

ATHENS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Norman K. Donahoe, 27-year-old United States Navy fighter pilot and Korean war veteran, has a brand new 17-month-old child, half a dozen milk bottles and forty-eight disposable diapers. He is trying to get back to the United States as quickly as possible.

Last year was another record-breaking one for the construction industry. More than $52,000,000,000 of work -- private and public -- was estimated to have been put in place despite the general economic readjustment.
In the offing is a reunion of the E. Y. Harburg-Burton Lane-Fred Saidy team, creators of that inventive and delightful musical fantasy, "Finian's Rainbow."

GREENHAM, England, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- Many residents here are trying to sell their homes and get out of this once sleepy English village because of noise from United States Air Force six-engine jet bombers.

Much of the nation's research aimed at finding better materials to withstand the extreme high temperatures of jet engines and rockets of the future was concentrated on powder metallurgy in 1954, according to Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, president of the American Electro Metal Corporation, independent research organization.

Burlap consumption in the United States was about 5 per cent less in 1954 than the 824,400,000 yards consumed during 1953, according to the Burlap Council of the Indian Jute Mills Association in New York.

Adlai E. Stevenson urged the nation yesterday to maintain "confidence and courage" in the hope of a lasting peace. He warned that if Americans lost the will for peace they would "court destruction," the United Press reported.

The diplomatic colony of Washington is losing another old and valued friend with the departure this week of Alberto Tarchiani, the Italian Ambassador. Like Henri Bonnet of France, to whom we said a reluctant good-by last week, Signor Tarchiani has served in Washington for ten years.
NEW ORLEANS -- Continuing as a growth area, New Orleans ended 1954 with business in virtually all fields at a peak.
Unionized office employes of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., threatened yesterday to go on strike this week in a wage dispute.

NOW the Chinese elders are worried. For the first time in the one hundred years since their people settled in New York's Chinatown, city officials have actually given to the newspapers plans and drawings for modern housing that will chip away one corner of their community.

Easy money market conditions, lower interest rates, and the ample availability of credit were the prevailing factors in 1954, a year that marked the fortieth anniversary of the establishment of the Federal Reserve Banks.
The American Federation of Labor asserted yesterday that the revised waterfront peace agreement was still "the same sellout contract" rejected by the longshoremen less than a month ago.

With the nation's cotton growers operating this year under the tightest controls permitted under the Federal Agricultural Act, there are good prospects of a reduction in the large surplus of the staple that has been built up over the last few years.

BOSTON -- Signs of increased activity in the closing quarter of 1954 gave New England economists hope that the region had "resisted further decline" in the process of readjustment from wartime conditions.
Donald Harrington began a series of sermons yesterday on "The Great Problems of our Age" with an attack on present methods of dealing with juvenile crime.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, predicted tonight that Adlai E. Stevenson would defeat President Eisenhower overwhelmingly if the former Illinois Governor were nominated by the Democrats in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Eisenhower returned from Georgia tonight, rested and ready for the second half of his Administration.

Business activity in the rubber industry is picking up. Leading manufacturers of tires and other rubber products foresee a moderate improvement in sales volume over 1954 levels. However, the record highs of 1953 are expected to be matched or topped this year in only scattered products.
Population trends are pointing strongly toward the Southwest and -- contrary to predictions immediately after World War II -- away from the Southeast.
The United States more than held its own in 1954 as the world's leading trading nation.

CAIRO, Monday, Jan. 3 -- The Suez Canal was cleared for traffic late last night, and the first convoy of thirty-six ships was to start northward through the vital waterway today, according to information received by telephone from Suez, Egypt.
COLUMBUS, Ohio -- The Columbus metropolitan area had "one of the best, if not the best," year in its history in 1954, according to the research department of the Columbus Chamber of Commerce.
The revival of the public market for foreign dollar bonds to a status reminiscent of pre-depression days was carried further in 1954.

Although 1954 failed to produce a decisive move toward convertibility of the world's currencies, certain progress was made toward the freer trade and foreign exchange conditions sought by the International Monetary Fund.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. -- The Southern Association of Science and Industry reports that 500 regional, state and local organizations in the South will spend $10,000,000 this year to promote economic and technological progress programs.
DES MOINES, Iowa -- For farmers in the Midwest's wheat and corn belts and for the stockmen of the Great Plains 1954 was a year of contrasts.
Business on the American Stock Exchange last year was the heaviest since 1930, topping that of 1953 by almost 60 per cent.
ATLANTA -- The South now has about one-third of the nation's chemical industries and is employing 11,000 professional chemists, the Southern Association of Science and Industry reports.
Job opportunities in the state were tighter last year than in 1953, according to the year-end report of the State Labor Department's division of employment.

The oil industry of the United States has had another good year. Although earnings were a bit lower than in 1953, expansion and modernization programs proceeded at a record pace. At the year-end the industry was better equipped than ever before to meet the growing needs for petroleum products.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The National Association of Electric Companies said today that the controversy over the Dixon-Yates contract "may have largely concerned the wrong issues."

Ask a retailer to list his main problems and the chances are that worry about the future of his downtown operation will be among them. It is a worry that will grow in the coming year as the number of suburban stores increases.
Overcrowding of the city's detention prisons is caused in large measure by trial court delays, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh said yesterday.

Elizabeth Hilt, the creator of today's Patterns of The Times, American Design Series, is not unknown to our readers. Her designs have appeared twice before in this column -- on May 7, 1951, and April 6, 1953.

The 1954 earnings reports of the nation's independent freight car builders, except for Pullman, Inc., generally are expected to make disappointing reading for stockholders in the next several weeks. Pullman had a net income of $5.12 a share in the first nine months, compared with $5.02 in all of 1953:
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford said yesterday the United states "would be ready to use atomic weapons, if needed," should the Communists renew aggression in Korea.
The legal liquor business -- traditionally paced by prosperity -- is lagging behind an otherwise rising economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The United States appeared certain today to reject the Soviet demand for eleven children now in West Germany and New York, but diplomatic officials expect the Soviet Union to free two long-missing Americans as promised.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The skyrocketing price of tea is converting one of the basic necessities of British life into something of a luxury and stirring a tempest in Britain's political teapot.

The spectacular expansion of the nation's petrochemical industry continued unabated last year. There were signs, however, that the business of making chemicals out of crude oil and natural gas was showing signs of maturity.

WASHINGTON -- On the agricultural front, the year behind and the year ahead may be recorded today as periods in which greater recognition was given to the expanding interdependence of the farm, industry, business and labor.
The New Year offers a fair prospect to shipping men. They look forward to a mildly prosperous business of chartering for at least the first several months.

It is perhaps four thousand years since the first dream of a waterway connecting the Mediterranean and the Red Sea. It is more than eighty-five years since the modern Suez Canal, offspring of the impassioned and ultimately unfortunate de Lesseps, was opened to traffic. One might imagine that in this day of the airplane, railroad and automobile a canal might not be as important as it used to be.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France is getting ready to inaugurate a new phase of his program.
BOSTON -- Evidence of a renewed interest in the importance of lumbering operations in New England developed in the closing months of 1954.

Mass production of color television sets must wait for satisfactory picture tubes that will cost set manufacturers $75 to $140 more than they have been paying, Ross D. Siragusa declared. The head of Admiral Corporation, one of the country's leading video set makers, said:

It is drastic economic medicine which the Communist rulers of Rumania imposed upon their people last week. To abolish rationing, the Rumanian price level has been raised substantially, doubling or more than doubling the price of many basic commodities formerly procurable with ration cards.
Both production and consumption of milk rose last year and the 1955 output is expected to remain the same as in 1954, with consumption rising to new heights.

It is more or less generally agreed today, as we move into the tenth post-World War II year, that the first real evidence of permanent economic recovery in the Western world made its appearance some time during the period 1950-1951. It is almost as widely agreed that the Korean War was the turning point.

The ferrous scrap metal industry, a key supply source for steel mills and foundries, enters 1955 optimistic that the improved business generated in the last six months will carry at least into the second quarter of the new year.
The first Sunday of the new year was described yesterday as a good day to contemplate the last.
Mayor Wagner will return to his desk today prepared to announce soon a hatful of appointments to vacancies in the city's courts and his official administrative family.

A 53-year-old recluse was found dead last night in his East Side tenement flat. It was filled with relics of the past, $66 in cash, $7,000 in Government bonds and bank books carrying $13,000 in deposits. He had been dead for about ten days.
The Safie Brothers Company, Inc., of New York disclosed yesterday that it had offered to buy for $65 a share all common stock held in the treasury of Rice-Stix Company of St. Louis.
The coal industry thinks 1954, with bituminous production perhaps as low as 385,000,000 tons, must have been its worst.
Lower output per employe, unusually large employe turnover and other costly office ills result from putting office workers in space not suited for their requirements.
The most practical and attractive home appliances in history will tempt the housewife this year. They will carry slightly lower price tags than their 1954 counterparts.

The nine-story apartment house at 103 East Eighty-fourth Street as been sold by the Blind Brook Apartment Corporation to Park Avenue and 84th St., Inc., for investment. George F. J. Neuhann was the broker. The Green-rich Savings Bank made a mortage loan of $250,000 on the property in connection with the sale. Title was insured by the title Guarantee and Trust Company.
DENVER, Col. -- Increased economic activity in the Denver Rocky Mountain area was accompanied by a growth in population.

The nation's railroads had to live off some of their "fat" last year. This was particularly true for the big Eastern district systems -- those operating in the area roughly north of the Ohio River and east of Chicago and St. Louis -- which normally produce about 40 per cent of the industry's gross revenues.

Five horses that were winners of American Horse Shows Association division high score championships the year before repeated in 1954. The list was made public yesterday by Adrian Van Sinderen, the organization's president.

IN Western Germany today decent men are trying to live down their country's shame and to create a state and a society worthy to be called civilized. And other men are blatantly and proudly trying to justify and even to glorify every despicable attitude of mind and habit of thought that has been the curse of their country and of the world.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn. -- The prospective expenditure of more than $30,000,000 on the rejuvenation or expansion of industrial plants in this area will produce a satisfactory degree of prosperity this year. The outlook is good, provided one does not look too far ahead.
In terms of total production this country's paper and pulp industry ran at near-record levels in 1954.
The health of New Yorkers was "exceptionally good" in 1954. Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday The death rate was lower and the birth rate higher than in 1953.
SEATTLE -- The Pacific Northwest is assured of enough electricity to meet domestic and industrial demands through 1960. What may happen after that is something of a headache for power planners.
The sprained ego and mashed thumb brigade -- better known as "do-it-yourselfers" -- continued to contribute mightily to the nation's economy last year, accounting for about $6,000,000,000 in sales.
Wool prices were under pressure most of last year because of a world production record, competition from synthetic fibers and generally poor conditions in the textile field.

The investment trust industry, largely because of the increasing popularity of mutual funds, has reached the $5,500,000,000 level. This is a gain in asset value of $1,200,000,000 since the start of 1954. Leaders on the top-level management of investment companies, both of the open-end and closed-end type, expect 1955 to show a comparable gain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- In the last five years 184 subversives and 5,261 criminals have been deported.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 2 -- The Agony, skippered by Arthur Knapp Jr. of Larchmont, won Class B One Design and Interclub Class honors despite a third-place finish in the fifth race today with an aggregate of seven points.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Flying Wes Santee, America's hope for the four-minute mile, won the Sugar Bowl mile for the second straight year today, but his time was fourteen seconds from the cherished four-minute mark.

Examples of French art and furniture design may be seen at the Cassard Romano Company, 305 East Sixty-third Street. In the company's showroom modern French paintings and travel posters are exhibited above period furniture reproductions in Provincial, Louis XVI and Directoire styles.
Bank loans to business, industry and agriculture continued their downward trend through most of last year, more than offsetting the slight gains registered in 1953.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A field of largely traditional issues will open out before the Eighty-fourth Congress as it convenes Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Following is a table of the major issues to come before the Eighty-fourth Congress, which convenes here next Wednesday:

After an expansion of $500,000,000 during 1953, the volume of money in circulation -- currency and coin in the public's pockets and cash in the vaults of banks and tills of merchants -- changed little last year.
PANAMA, Jan. 2 -- Unidentified assailants shot and killed President Jose Antonio Remon with machine-gun fire tonight at the Juan Franco race track here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Officials here were shocked at the assassination tonight of President Jose Antonio Remon of Panama.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. -- For the third successive year the South's burgeoning industrialization served as a counterpoise to its drop in agricultural income. Thus the region was able to close 1954 with a strong last-quarter upsurge in manufacturing and merchandising.

DETROIT -- An even greater competitive battle for the automobile market in 1955 than there was in 1954 appears in prospect among the six United States manufacturers. That is good news for the buyer. It may be bad news for some of the smaller companies.
The Air Force's Military Air Transport Service completed an average of one ocean crossing every fifty-four minutes during 1954, it was announced today.

The nation's 527 mutual savings banks exceeded the $29,000,000,000 assets mark last year for the first time in their 137-year history. Industry executives expect that increasing income, together with rising employment, will provide the basis for a continued high level of savings.

Coming strongly into fashion's picture are patterned fabrics called Jacquards. The fabrics take their name from the Jacquard looms on which they were woven, looms that will weave into goods the most intricate of figures.
The chemical industry of the United States took the 1954 recession in its stride. It chalked up sales that may well have set a record high and is investing heavily in further growth in the new year.
Last year was a period of stabilization for the plastics industry following the spectacular sales gains of the preceding year.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) -- D. C. Keisacker of Miami, fighting waves kicked up by a twenty - mile - an - hour wind piloted his 266-cubic-inch hydroplane to victory in the international Grand Prix's $7,500 Paladium Trophy race today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Eight new Democratic Governors are taking over from Republicans this month.

The nation's aluminum makers racked up another new production record in 1954 -- their third in a row. And they foresaw even greater output this year with the completion of the huge aluminum expansion program, begun during the Korean emergency.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Rochester continued its fast drive toward the National Basketball Association leaders today with a 102-100 victory over Minneapolis before 2,391 fans. Odie Spears sank a one-hander with 52 seconds remaining to give the Royals their fifth triumph in their last six games.

DALLAS, Texas -- With business activity in this area of Texas having set new records in 1954, businessmen and economists in Dallas predict further gains in 1955 despite a jarring note from the city's largest single employer.
WASHINGTON -- "It takes all the running you can do to keep in the same place. If you want to get somewhere else, you must run at least twice as fast as that!"
ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Governor Harriman spent a quiet day at the Executive Mansion, resting from the strain of yesterday's inauguration ceremonies.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved within a narrow range last week. At the close of trading on Friday active future contracts were unchanged to 11 points -- 55 cents a bale -- below the close of the preceding week.

On Dec. 14 you published an editorial with reference to the capital budget item for the construction of a reservoir and appurtenant works at Cannonsville on the Delaware River. You recommended that this project be abandoned and that the city should instead develop a Hudson River project in accordance with the recommendations made by certain engineers to the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

Azam Khan, Pakistan professional, and G. Diehl Mateer Jr., top-ranking amateur in this country, reached the final round of the second United States open squash racquets tournament yesterday on the University Club's courts.

Like special other realms, Biblical scholars often receive from The New York Times their first information regarding significant happenings in their field. From your publication many learned of the discovery of the now famous Dead Sea scrolls. Only last week you reported the translation of Sumerian tablets containing an essay on the problem of suffering, which is dealt with at greater length in the Book of Job.
Hearings will begin today in New Orleans, on the disappearance of a converted landing ship with her crew last month on one of the world's most heavily traveled sea routes.

The experience gained from a quarter of a century of fairly continuous play against the best talent in the world told in favor of Samuel Reshevsky in the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy tournament which was concluded last night at the Marshall Chess Club.

American copper producers are now shipping metal as fast as they can turn it out -- still trying to catch up with a backlog of demand that built up during two months of widespread copper strikes last summer.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The brother of the assassinated Panama President tonight termed the killing "gangsterism."

In the course of this New Year's week-end emphasis has been placed upon two different proposals for talks to promote peace. In Paris, Premier Mendes-France has indicated that he will urge Britain and the United States to join in a four-Power conference with France and the Soviet Union some time in the spring.
American families continued to "eat high on the hog" in 1954 and this year are expected to fare even better.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 2 -- The three Western High Commissioners are involved in a race with time in an effort to assure West German payment of the debt due to the Jews for savings and possessions stolen by the Hitler regime.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- A Republican-dominated special commission has voted to recommend a $750,000,000 state highway bond issue.
This is the third and final of a series of articles on Russian food.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Hawks, led by Bob Harrison with 30 points, upset the Syracuse Nationals, 91 -- 79, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
Production caution will be the keynote of the room air-conditioning industry this year.

The domestic sugar market was quiet most of last year with prices ranging between a high of 6.27 cents a pound on March 11 and a low of 5.8 cents on Sept. 30 for raw sugar delivered in New York. However, the year ended on a note of confusion that was straightened out in the eleventh month.
The National Audubon Society concluded its fifty-fifth annual bird census here yesterday, with watchers counting 112 species in southern Nassau and 118 species on western Long Island.

HONG KONG, Jan. 2 -- Peiping has promulgated rules for the organization of urban residents' committees, urban street offices and public security stations, the Hsinhua (New China) News Agency reported tonight.
COLUMBIA, S. C. -- The fact that South Carolina has been one of the leading states in industrial gains since World War II is best explained this way:
ISMAILIA, Egypt, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The tanker World Peace was freed today from the wreckage of the El Firdan railway bridge.
WASHINGTON -- Last Dec. 7 the thirteenth anniversary of Pearl Harbor, a new directive on procurement policy was issued by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.
The feast of the Holy Name of Jesus was marked yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral with an exhortation for reverence for Christ's name.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The man President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles will be watching carefully in the Eighty-fourth Congress is the new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Population growth, improved living standards and industrial advances contributed to the electric power and light industry's best year since Thomas A. Edison invented the electric light bulb seventy-five years ago. Last year was a banner period for the nation's $28,000,000,000 electric industry.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Daily News, a long-time Republican adherent, announced today that it would be an "independent-Democratic newspaper."
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Tom Gola scored 34 points and controlled the rebounds as La Salle defeated St. Louis University, 88 -- 79, in basketball tonight.
Shoe and leather producers are eager to forget about 1954, a disappointing year because of heavy carryover and only normal consumer demand.

United States gold stock last year declined about $300,000,000 to $21,700,000,000, the lowest level for domestic gold holdings since August, 1947. This decrease maintained a trend that started in August, 1952.

WPAT in Paterson, N. J., is a radio station to make you forget about television. The outlet is doing just the thing that radio should be doing but that most people thought radio couldn't. It is offering continuous music from 7 to 10:30 o'clock each evening, and the commercials come only once every thirty minutes. For a little bit of heaven, try tuning to 930 kilocycles.
UTICA, N. Y., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Eighteen cars near the end of a long eastbound freight train jumped the rails tonight and blocked the four main line tracks of the New York Central Railroad.
This year, while some men are starting their day with electric toothbrushes their wives will be extracting breakfast essentials from refrigerators hanging on kitchen walls.
WASHINGTON -- How soon atomic energy may begin to compete with falling water or fossil fuels as a source of useful power is an arguable -- and hotly argued -- question these days.
Profit-sharing in industry gained wider acceptance in 1954. More profit-sharing plans are believed to have been adopted in the year than in any of the previous five.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 2 -- High officials are becoming confident they will be able to accept the Soviet offer to put up a steel plant in India.

The house heating division of the nation's gas industry, under the impetus of natural gas, is confident that sales of its equipment in 1955 "will continue to surpass those of competing fuels," H. Leigh Whitelaw, managing director of the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association, said yesterday in commenting on the industry's prospects for the coming year.
ALL kinds of painting by contemporary American artists are to be found in the many shows with which the galleries renewed their activities after the holiday lull.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Harriman said today that he planned to accept the Dewey Administration recommendations for the fifteen permanent members of the State University's board of trustees.

A hands-across-the-sea arrangement has been concluded between Advertising Associates of Philadelphia, Inc., and Portland Advertising Service, Ltd., Manchester, England. The plan involves no financial merger but serves, nevertheless, to give each agency in effect an overseas branch office.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (UP) -- James A. Michener, author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel "Tales of the South Pacific," was sued for divorce today.

PARIS -- After having remained stationary for three years, the French tourist industry reported an increase of 12 per cent in number of tourists for the first nine months of 1954 as compared with a similar period in 1953.

BERLIN -- While United States officials hope that in the coming year West Berlin will continue along the road toward prosperity, they concede that progress will depend on Soviet reaction to West German armament.

S. W. Brown, former chief engineer of the marine department of the Carrier Corporation, has set up his own office as a consulting engineer. He will specialize in the design and application of maritime air conditioning and refrigeration systems.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Two old faces and twelve new ones make up the Senate's "freshman class of '54."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A special House Campaign Investigating Committee today dropped complaints involving Congressional elections in Delaware and Illinois.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Parts of eighteen of twenty-one New Jersey counties have been declared off limits to Soviet citizens carrying Soviet passports, the State Department announced today.
Sylvan F. Chappuis has been named president of the Toledo Porcelain Enamel Products Company, subsidiary of the Bettinger Corporation.

West Virginia will meet New York University and Brigham Young will face Manhattan in a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The first game, pitting the Mountaineers against N. Y. U., is scheduled to begin at 7:45.
PARIS -- Although the total number of units in the French merchant fleet declined during 1954, a net gain of more than 46,000 tons was recorded over 1953.
The nation's steel industry scheduled its operations at 80.5 per cent of its newly rated capacity of 125,828,310 net tons a year this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Apparently of the opinion that fans may want to make their plans early for the new year, officials of the New York Yankees devoted the first business day of 1955 to the matter of announcing dates.

WELLINGTON, N. Z. -- In industry the most important development in New Zealand is the establishment of a major timber, pulp and paper trade. Huge man-made forests planted some thirty years ago are reaching the cutting stage, involving a great capital outlay for their exploitation. Already several large companies are building up a substantial export trade.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Reaves E. Peters, Big Seven Conference commissioner, said today the Conference would not rescind its rule against sending the same team to the Orange Bowl two years in a row.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Following is the list of United States areas closed to travel by Soviet citizen's in today's order by the State Department:

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands -- The Netherlands is experiencing boom conditions in most sections of industry as well as wholesale and retail trade. The outlook for 1955, barring international political complications or a slump in the United States, is for more of the same.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 3 -- Two thousand Moslem youth leaders from thirty-two countries opened an anti-Communist drive here today.

Anyone inclined to be complacent about the situation in Indochina should read with close attention the report of the New Year demonstration in Hanoi. This is now the capital and nerve center of the Communist-controlled Vietminh. It is also the capital of the supposedly "sovereign and autonomous" state that is to be a party to the forthcoming Asian-African conference.
The City Administration expects to press for inclusion of the proposed business income tax as a substitute for the existing gross business tax in its 1955-56 fiscal program.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics, racing against time to get a major league park and baseball club ready by April 12, sent out contracts to thirty-seven players today.
G. Diehl Mateer Jr., this country's top-ranking amateur, won the United States Open squash racquets championship last night at the University Club.
Deering, Milliken Co., Inc., one of the world's largest manufacturers of textiles, announced yesterday that it had raised its prices of cotton print cloths by about 5 per cent.

BECAUSE she sheds fresh light on everything she touches, Gina Bachauer is an absorbingly interesting pianist. Thus her recital last night at Town Hall -- her sixth since her United States debut in 1950 -- was a fascinating experience for all those lucky enough to hear it.

ATHENS -- Greece, a country two-thirds barren mountain slope, has always been poor. Throughout history her people have been obliged to seek livelihood in foreign lands. Only since recent developments in agriculture, supported largely by United States financial and technical aid, has Greece reached rudimentary self-sufficiency in food and normal necessities.

The Port of New York needs to win the understanding and cooperation of its longshoremen, Lloyd H. Dalzell, president of the Dalzell Towing Company, declared last night. He spoke at a dinner of the Newark Traffic Club in the Robert Treat Hotel, Newark.
Fresh fruits and vegetables disappeared from many independent stores yesterday as the three-day-old strike of produce handlers and drivers began to pinch.

PARIS -- On Aug. 10 the French National Assembly voted full powers to Premier Pierre Mendes-France to introduce a series of economic reforms by decree. This was to enable him to initiate his plan for "reconversion" of the French economy without every measure having to be adopted separately by the Assembly.

The conclusion of the fifth round of the international tournament at the annual chess congress in Hastings, England, found the two Russian grandmasters, Paul Keres and Vassily Smyslov, tied for the lead with scores of 4 -- 1 each, according to a report from London yesterday.
BERLIN -- East Germany enters the final year of its first Five-Year Plan with a prospect of achieving about 80 per cent of its original goal to double its output.
After twenty-four years of almost continuous public service, Thomas E. Dewey returned yesterday to making a living as a private citizen. He found the contrast most refreshing.
MADRID -- As one poet has said: "Spain is a land in which angels' footprints are often seen on the ground, and even its humblest people have a curious sense of unreality about things of this world."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- In analyzing the prospects for 1955, Swedish economists consider the possibility that the expansion of demand from 1953 to 1954 may unbalance the Swedish economy.
HARTFORD, Jan. 3 -- A special state commission today recommended an increase in the state sales tax from 3 to 4 per cent.
BRUSSELS, Belgium -- The improved climate for private enterprise in Belgium is again attracting United States business men and industrialists.

LISBON, Portugal -- Businessmen are much happier at the beginning of this year than they have been for some time. In the fall of 1952, the Portuguese Government announced a far-reaching $440,000,000 six-year improvement plan to bring greater prosperity to Portugal and her overseas possessions, but it was only in 1954 that business began to feel any effects.
WELLINGTON, N. Z. -- New Zealand is starting 1955 with several steps toward more liberal trade and exchange methods. On Jan. 1, the exchange allocation system was abolished.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Defense officials said today that enlistments might rise substantially this month in anticipation of the Jan. 31 cutoff date for Korean War veteran benefits.
Net assets of the Wellington Fund increased 42.9 per cent in 1954, according to the report issued for publication today by Walter L. Morgan, president.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Walter (Hoot) Evers became the seventeenth baseball player acquired today by Paul Richards since he became boss of the Baltimore Orioles in September.
A regular contributor to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund sent her $100 gift yesterday, but with more than her usual feeling of sympathy for the problems of others.

ROME -- Official sources estimate that the Italian national income for 1954 was no more than 4 per cent greater than in 1953, when it amounted to $17,428,000,000, and marked an increase of 7.5 per cent over that of 1952.
The top brass of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, whose forty-ninth annual convention gets into full swing tomorrow, accomplished some deck-clearing at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.
TUNIS, Tunisia -- The advent of home rule in Tunisia raises the question of how the Tunisian economy is to be kept alive.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Eisenhower Administration announced today that 3,002 Federal employes had been dismissed as security risks in the first sixteen months of its security program.
Kentucky's Wildcats, still unbeaten after a month of competition, easily retained their No. 1 ranking among the nation's major college basketball teams yesterday in the weekly Associated Press poll.
The controversy over the merits of AD-X2, a storage battery additive, went into its sixth year yesterday.
The year 1955 has got off to a warmer - than - average start in this city.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Reuters, the British Commonwealth's largest news agency, started use today of new high - speed teleprinters that tap out news at 100 words a minute -- half again as fast as the previous British standard.

Charles James, the brilliant dress designer, is rounding out his twenty-fifth year in business. He has twice received the Coty American Fashion Critic's Award and has also won an award from Neiman-Marcus, Dallas, Tex., specialty store.

The First Secretary of the Communist party of the Soviet Union, Nikita S. Khrushchev, has been much in the news lately. His condemnation of Soviet leaders in Uzbekistan has resulted in the removal of that region's Premier, Usman Yusupov, formerly a high Communist party as well as Government official.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- After declining $163,000,000 last month, Britain's gold and dollar reserves amounted to $2,762,000,000 at the end of the year, the Treasury said today. This was $244,000,000 more than the total at the end of 1953.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Moral Re-Armament was hailed today as the only thing that could save the world from the "godless materialism" of communism.
Joey Klein scored an upset victory over Gerald Dreyer at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night when Mark Conn, the referee, stopped the bout after seven rounds. The fight was set for ten.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Harriman charged today that the Eisenhower Administration had set its economic goals too low. Instead of trying to get the nation's economy back to the 1953 level, he said, it should be striving to make it even better.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -At the end of 1954 there were more skilled workmen in Latin America, more food in Western Europe and more arable land in several Asian countries than at the start of the year. Precise statistics are difficult to compile.

ROME -- The Italian Government has so far shown the most gingerly circumspection in its attitude toward convertibility. It believes convertibility to be desirable, and even necessary, as a long-term objective, but doubts its short-term feasibility.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- The nuclear study center at Saclay, near Paris, inaugurated today ninety courses designed especially for engineers in private industry. The action underlined the importance of atomic energy as a source of industrial power.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- No two American homes need look alike this year if the numerous styles on view at the annual Winter Home Furnishings Market are any indication. Merchandise introduced to buyers at this wholesale event will filter into stores from now until the end of March.

PARIS -- Trade with Communist China is only a small part of France's foreign commerce. It is figured at between 1,000,000,000 and 2,000,000,000 francs ($2,900,000 to $5,800,000). However, exact figures are dificult to obtain because trade with both Communist and Nationalist China is grouped in one category.

Supreme Court Justice Felix Benvenga denied an application yesterday by the Lionel Corporation, manufacturer of model trains and accessories, for a temporary injunction against several large department stores for selling their products at less than fair-traded prices. But the court held there was a triable issue and set Jan. 17 for hearing.

THE Harper Prize Novel contest winner for 1955 is "Trial,"* by Don M. Mankiewicz. It was chosen, from 886 entries by a board of judges composed of Bernard DeVoto, A. B. Guthrie Jr. and myself. Two years earlier the same three judges found no novel worthy of the prize and consequently no award was made for the 1953 contest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Administration may offer Wolf Ladejinsky a major post in the Asian economic aid program in an effort to ease the furor over his security dismissal.

JERUSALEM -- There are worries ahead for Israel's financial managers in every aspect of the economy. Even the export trade causes concern. Finance Minister Levi P. Eshkol says he is going to look into the economics of those export industries that import materials from hard-money countries but sell where the currency is not so valuable.
Despite stringent economies, the Transit Authority expects to run $4,000,000 to $5,000,000 in the red for the fiscal year ending next June 30.
Samuel Reshevsky, winner of the Rosenwald trophy tournament, which ended at the Marshall Chess Club on Sunday, was honored yesterday at a reception in the Park Sheraton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The foreign ministers of the eight Manila Pact powers will meet at Bangkok Feb. 23 to put military and economic life into the treaty they signed last September.
LONDON -- A note of caution and disappointment, struck by official spokesmen, marked the closing stages of a year that had begun with a flourish in the field of foreign trade.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 (UP) -- A seaman said today at a Coast Guard hearing into the mysterious disappearance of the freighter Southern Districts that the vessel was "just one big bucket of rust" and "the first ship that I'd ever been afraid to ride on."

Wall Street greeted the New Year yesterday with new highs for the stock averages and the heaviest first-day volume since the beginning of 1929. Two hundred and eighteen issues set price highs for 1954-55. No lows were recorded.

LONDON -- By the middle of last year it was apparent that Britain's economy was unusually buoyant; by December even cautious Government officials were saying 1954 was the most prosperous year Britain had known.

Three newcomers, two of them rookies, were among the players selected to participate in the fifth annual National Basketball Association's East-West all-star game to be held at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night, Jan. 18.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3--The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association has topped the $9,000,000,000 mark in resources.

A prediction was made yesterday that Federal funds for education would be withheld from states defying last year's Supreme Court ruling banning racial segregation in public education. The forecast was made by Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- While nearly all Britons are hopeful that the nation-wide railroad strike set for midnight Sunday will be averted, hundreds of concerns are making plans to transport their workers if there is no rail service.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy wound up his last hearing as inquiry chairman in typical fashion today.

The appointment of Giles C. Stedman as general manager of European operations for the United States Lines was announced yesterday by John M. Franklin, president. Mr. Stedman succeeds Thomas A. Monroe, who has been transferred to Washington.

GENEVA -- The national economies of Western Europe rounded the turn of the year at a forward clip of which few thought them capable twelve months ago. The pundits in various organizations responsible for spotting trends seem to be uncommonly close to agreement on the proposition that the period of growth witnessed during 1954 will continue for some time.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits proposed yesterday a conference on children and youth as a move against juvenile delinquency in the state.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- For the first time in the 167 years of Congress, Senators and House members this year will have a special secluded room for meditation.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3 -- Soviet workers in various fields are being positively encouraged to study the experience and methods of foreign countries with a view to improving their own techniques.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 -- Dag Hammarskjold was on the last stage of his journey to Communist China tonight. He left New Delhi after talking with high Indian officials, who believe Peiping may grasp the opportunity to win a substantial amount of political credit by freeing eleven United States airmen convicted as spies.
Nancy Davids has acquired for Broadway production "Sylvester," described as an "ominous comedy on a current peril," by Dale Wasserman and Jack Balch.
Alden L. Odt and Joseph Sondheimer have become partners in the Chicago investment counsel firm of Stein, Roe Farnham.

BERLIN -- The United States Air Force and Army have been buying increased amounts of goods in West Berlin. Care is taken to see that the items made here are non-military so that the Russians cannot use the export of such goods from the city as an excuse for counter-measures.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams is convinced he recruited an efficient corps of school-crossing guards -- 98 per cent of whom are women -- when he started the program last Sept. 13.

The year 1955 has begun in a terrible way for Panama and hence for all Latin America. However, the assassination of President Remon was so extraordinary and so senseless that one cannot take it as an omen. So far as Panama is concerned, it is not even typical because this is the first time a Panamanian President has been killed, and until 1951 even the ordinary and frequent political coups were bloodless.
There were those yesterday who described the present situation of R. K. O. Pictures Corporation as "forty-five million dollars in search of a boss."

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The Labor party announced today that if it returned to power it would restore government bulk buying of food imports. But it added that there would be no food rationing or allocations.

Sweet potatoes, now costing 3 to 6 cents a serving, are at their peak in flavor as well as in general availability in winter. As delicious as the freshly baked specimens are the pan-fried or glazed sweets that can be done with cooked tubers or with the canned variety.

NEW DELHI, India -- The Indian Government has adopted all possible measures to strengthen the sterling area by trying to expand exports while limiting imports to the minimum. The Indian rupee is an important sterling area currency, backed by reserves held in Britain.
CHICAGO, Jan, 3 (UP) -- Civilian defense budgets range from more than $3,600,000 in New York City to $16,657 in Dallas, Tex., a survey of twenty-four cities showed today.

NEW DELHI, India -- The Soviet Union, Communist China and Eastern European countries have been making a determined effort to expand trade relations with India. These efforts have met with some measure of success, as the Indian Government has been eager to explore new avenues of trade and commerce.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- The upholstered furniture industry will set a production record in 1955 after having suffered an 8 to 10 per cent decline last year, Delmar L. Kroehler, president of the Kroehler Manufacturing Company, Chicago, predicted today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The free world was urged by a House committee today to launch an all-out political, diplomatic and trade offensive against the Soviet Union and its satellites.

The Alleghany Corporation, railroad holding company, disclosed yesterday it has formulated a new plan of recapitalization designed to eliminate the more than $125 a share in dividend arrearages which have accumulated on its 136,744 shares of $5.50 cumulative preferred stock.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 3 -- A string of 11 points in a row that broke a 6-6 tie set Seton Hall's basketball team on the road to an 83-63 victory over Colby tonight. The triumph was the ninth for the Pirates in ten games.
BRUSSELS -- The Benelux common market for goods established in 1948-49 was supplemented in 1954 by a Benelux common market for capital.
TOKYO, Jan. 3 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrived tonight to discuss Japan's defense problems with American and Japanese officials.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- New procedures for settling anti-trust cases by consent decrees have speeded the work of the Justice Department's anti-trust division.

BRUSSELS -- With her balance of payments with the different monetary zones more or less in equilibrium, Belgium in 1954 freed still further her already liberalized foreign currency, making the Belgian franc largely convertible for the movement of capital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class I carriers during November at $76,000,000 compared with $60,000,000 in the same month in 1953. The report marked the first time since August, 1953, that monthly earnings were above those for the corresponding month of the previous year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- In spite of a significant drop in United States production, mines and factories abroad kept up their output in 1954 and even managed to show some gains.

Following is a list of fairs and exhibitions to be held abroad and in this country this year that may be of interest to United States concerns. The dates are those decided on by the organizers and are subject to change. Information may be obtained by writing to the Bureau of Foreign Commerce, Department of Commerce, Washington, 25, D. C., or to the consulate of the country concerned.
PARIS -- French labor entered the new year determined to profit as much as possible from the Government's effort to raise industrial production and to expand France's economy.
A black cocker spaniel that had made his show debut at the event a year ago came back to take the highest award of the American Spaniel Club's annual specialty in the Hotel Roosevelt last night.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight took the oath of office today for a four-year term.

The phrases "coexistence," "peaceful coexistence," "peaceful coexistence and cooperation" (Malenkov, October, 1952) are coming to have the power of a kind of ritual incantation. Especially impressive in this connection is the witness of a scholar of the stature of Prof. Ralph Barton Perry, in his letter to The Times of Dec. 27.

The shopper for moderate price dresses will be able to buy at Bergdorf Goodman, Fifth Avenue women's specialty shop, beginning next fall. At that time a new department, the store's first since March, 1928, will open under the name "Miss Bergdorf." It will specialize in moderate price lines.
VIENNA -- Austria faces 1955 with a record of expanding trade, increased production and higher productivity during the previous twelve months and the stage apparently set for its continuance.

International oil developments last year were highlighted by the settlement of the Iranian dispute. After a lapse of forty months, crude oil and its products from that country again were moving to markets in the free world.

ZURICH, Switzerland -- Switzerland is the only country in Europe that has never abandoned convertibility in principle. However, in self-defense, her financial dealings with countries that maintain foreign exchange restrictions are regulated by payments agreements.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Greentree Stable, owned by John Hay Whitney and his sister, Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson, scored its first victory of the winter, as well as its first of the New Year, when Maharajah outclassed seven other 4-year-olds today at Tropical Park.

MANILA -- The Philippines enter the new year with an expanding economy and an inadequate bank account. Faith in the future and hope for the best are undiminished after one year of President Ramon Magsaysay's Administration. But the job of making financial ends meet is a formidable one.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- The Netherlands is technically completely prepared and strong enough to join a general move toward convertibility. She will, however, not take this step unless in close cooperation with all or virtually all the O. E. E. C. countries.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 3 -- Foreign observers here were impressed by the report from Marshal Tito's entourage in India that the Yugoslav President had not been consulted on the Djilas-Dedijer case. The report, which was not published here, drew serious attention among diplomats.

Wholesale prices for two leading frozen orange juice brands -Minute Maid and Snow Crop -were cut yesterday. (The Minute Maid Corporation, pioneer maker of frozen juices, purchased the Snow Crop division of Clinton Foods on Oct. 51.)

During the past weeks, in an effort to adequately meet the increasing crime wave, the Mayor has approved an increase in the police force of more than a thousand men. In addition, in the East Harlem area, the Twenty-fifth Precinct has been "saturated" with new officers, more than doubling the number of officers in that area.
An $80-a-week clerk here, who won $140,000 in the Irish Sweepstake, has given $15,000 to fifteen charities.

It takes only a few days of warm weather, such as those at the end of December, to bring out all that is miserable and vile in mankind. Let the temperature rise once into the sixties and immediately there is talk through the house of spring cleaning.
New cookbooks, both basic and specialized, have appeared recently to swell the already extensive assortment of volumes for the kitchen

Two teen-agers -- one of them 16, the other 15 -- were arrested last night in a bullet-marked chase twenty minutes after they had held up a Second Avenue liquor store. The older boy was armed with a fully loaded Mauser automatic, the younger with an unloaded automatic.

A succession of sensational cases in which the Federal Government has seemed willing to lose the services of valuable and proved employes for the sake of an unattainable will-o'-the-wisp called "100 per cent security" has finally shocked public opinion into the realization that something must be wrong with our security procedures.
SEOUL, Korea -- South Korea's economy has taken a definite turn for the better. Barring a renewal of the war or internal dissension, the country is headed for higher levels in 1955.
ZURICH, Switzerland -- There is no manifest reason for Switzerland to fear that the economic well-being that prevailed through 1954 will diminish this year.

OSLO, Norway -- Premier Oscar Torp has declared that Norway must have a balanced budget for the next fiscal year starting July 1. A reduction of 300,000,000 kroner ($42,150,000) from the 4,000,000,000 kroner budget has been mentioned.
JERUSALEM -- Israel seems to be moving in ten-league boots toward the goal of economic selfs-sufficiency. But there are still eighty or ninety leagues to go.

CAIRO--Egypt's foreign trade this year will increase with the Western countries. West Germany's salesmen, who have brought about a remarkable increase in exports to the Middle East, will probably make that country Egypt's number one supplier, displacing the United States and Britain, which were running neck and neck at the end of the third quarter last year.

LONDON -- The Colombo Plan area -- which in 1954 grew by three new members -- had a generally successful year, under perhaps the first relatively "normal" economic conditions the area has experienced since the plan was begun in 1950.

ONE of the most surprising of Governor Harriman's appointments -- it was a surprise even to the recipient -- was the naming of Julius Helfand as chairman of the boxing commission. It was a case of the job seeking the man. And what a man it sought!

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- The Government has submitted to the National Assembly a bill to reorganize the Permanent Secretariat of National Defense, which was compromised last fall by disclosure of leaks to the Communist party from secret National Defense Committee meetings.
BONN, Germany -- The West German Economics Ministry is looking forward to another year of expansion.
TORONTO, Jan. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Globe and Mail, Canada's largest morning newspaper, will be offered for sale Jan. 10, it was announced tonight.
A contract has been signed by Webb Knapp, Inc., and associates for the purchase of the entire blockfront on the east side of Fifth Avenue between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets.

MELBOURNE, Australia -- "Australian children being born now should live to see the population reach 40,000,000," Harold Holt, Minister for Labor and Immigration, said last November. The commonwealth now has fewer than 9,000,000 citizens.
Sidewalk superintendents are having a difficult time of it at the site of New York's new Coliseum, at Columbus Circle.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Eighty-fourth Congress, opening Wednesday, will have the largest number of women ever to sit in the National Legislature.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- For the first time since it was founded, Yugoslavia's Communist-led Government will have trading opportunities on all sides this year. The settlement of the dispute with Italy over Trieste has cleared the commercial decks of Yugoslavia's Adriatic neighbor for real action.

A fifty-acre tract fronting 900 feet on Jericho Turnpike in Selden, L. I., has been purchased by Liebowitz Olinoff, builders, from the Pecoll Realty Corporation. The Chanin Agency and William G. Lewis were co-brokers in the transaction.

CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Yugoslav Government's charges against Milovan Djilas and Vladimir Dedijer were made "without consultation" with President Tito, Foreign Minister Koca Popovic said here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- In many parts of the world as 1954 merged into 1955, tens of thousands of tenant farmers breathed deep with pride in their new status as landowners. The agrarian reform movement, which has been gathering momentum consistently the last few years, accelerated still further during 1954.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The House Small Business Committee called today for a "thorough Congressional review" of defense procurement policies.
PARIS -- During 1954 considerable progress was made in housing construction. If this continues for the next three years, the shortage will be on the way to solution.
ANKARA, Turkey -- Turkey enters 1955 burdened with foreign debt and domestic inflation but determined to quicken still further the pace of her post-war economic revolution.

LONDON -- British industrial production established a new record in October and it was then running about 6 per cent higher than in 1953, Steel and motor manufacturing were among industries showing the best gains.

For the men in the Kremlin, 1955 shapes up as the year of decision, the year in which they have to start really delivering on all the many promises of the "abundant life" they have made since Stalin died.
The American Broadcasting Company television network will go calling on the Ozark country beginning Jan. 22, when it initiates "Ozark Jubilee" from Columbia, Mo., each Saturday from 9 to 10 P. M.

LISBON, Portugal -- The Ministry of Overseas Territories has issued a statement on extraordinary expenditures in 1955 in Angola, Mozambique and Goa. The funds come from extraordinary state revenue of these provinces. About half the projects are under the "Six-Year Improvement Plan." The plan is as follows:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- Preparations for the international technical conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy will get under way Jan. 17, when the seven-nation advisory committee will open its initial meeting.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A heavy supply sent butcher hogs tumbling 25 to 50 cents to new low prices since December, 1952, here today. Sows, which were relatively scarce, sold steady to 25 cents lower.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Harriman declined to comment today on the Diefendorf commission proposals for financing a $2,800,000,000 state highway program.

Phonograph records went on sale yesterday at the new, lower prices announced by manufacturers in the closing weeks of 1954, and two of the city's largest record retailers reported that business was unusually good for the Monday after the New Year holiday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Following is the Civil Service Commission's breakdown on security separations in the Government between May 28, 1953 and Sept. 30, 1954. Sub- Per* CozyAgency Fired Resigned .v'ersfom .version

ANKARA, Turkey -- Turkey has approved applications by eighty-seven foreign concerns or pooled groups to invest here under legislation enacted since 1951 to encourage entry of private foreign capital. Foreign participation in these undertakings is reported to exceed $26,826,000.

NEW DELHI, India -- With gains recorded in virtually all fields of national development, India enters the New Year in a mood of confident optimism. New records were set in both agricultural and industrial output. And the Indian Government can hardly be said to be in a bad financial position in comparison with others, although there are some dark spots in the picture.
Two Newark union officials were arrested yesterday for attempting to extort $1,000 from a New York concern that supplies guards for industrial plants.
Uncle Sam, who has been struggling with the problem of where to hold detained aliens here since the closing of Ellis Island, opened a new "dormitory" for them yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Inquiries reflecting confusion beat today about the ears of United States officials who announced new travel curbs of Soviet citizens.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Judge Edward Blythin today turned down two defense requests for a new trial for Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- Hugh S. Coyle, Lewisboro Supervisor and an attorney here, was elected by 31 to 8 today to a second term as chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 3 -- The West German Government announced today that Oskar Schlitter, counselor of embassy in London, had offered to resign from the diplomatic service because of alleged anti-British remarks made by his wife at a Christmas party there. He was recalled here yesterday.
HONG KONG -- In the following discussion all figures used are United States dollars based on a conversion rate of 5.8 Hong Kong dollars to one United States dollar.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland -- Although the Soviet Union has gone ahead of Britain in imports from Iceland, the United States remains this country's best customer. Trade with Britain slumped as a result of the continued boycott of Icelandic trawlers in British harbors, putting Britain in third place in Iceland's exports.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Harriman will take up tomorrow the problem of taxpayers who, for the first time, have two income tax bills to meet on the same day.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Yet another link in the 200,000-year-old chain of evolutionary events from near-ape to man has been unearthed from the limestone caves of the Transvaal in South Africa.
PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France is expected to meet soon with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to discuss unsettled points of last October's Saar agreement.

Major oil discoveries and rapid recent oil production increases promise to make the Bashkir region in the Urals the largest single source of Soviet petroleum next year, outstripping even Baku, a Pravda article reveals.

GENEVA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Salah ben Youssef, secretary general of the Tunisian nationalist Neo-Destour party, said here today that five months of negotiations had shown that the French Government of Premier Pierre Mendes-France was determined to "perpetuate the colonial regime in Tunisia."
PARIS -- Exports from France to Indochina have declined more than 20 per cent since the cessation of hostilities and the occupation of North Vietnam by the Communist-led Vietminh.

The weather smiled on New York and department store business boomed in December. It was crisp and cold in the important shopping days before Christmas and turned warm only during the relatively unimportant days after the holiday.

Arnulfo Arias has been a controversial and resilient figure in Panama for nearly a quarter of a century. His feud with Col. Jose Antonio Remon, the President who was machine-gunned to death at a race track Sunday night, has been a dominant fact in Panamanian politics.

MOSCOW -- A new and potentially significant factor has entered into the economic calculations of the Soviet Union. It is the Atlantic Powers' proposal to arm West Germany, which the Soviet Union chooses to consider a threat to itself.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 3 -- As Subject No. 231103, Sweden's Queen Louise received her card today under the National Health Insurance Scheme, which took effect with the new year. The Queen's sick benefit is equivalent to 60 cents daily in United States money for a maximum two years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had dipped for the second consecutive week.

ROME, Jan. 3 -- Pope Pius XII, in his delayed Christmas message, called on East and West today to live together in peace by building a "bridge of truth" based on the "divine moral order" and human beings, not political systems.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Eisenhower revealed to the Republican Congressional leaders today the text of his State of the Union Message.

A long-term refinancing program has been completed by Trans World Airlines, and a stand-by credit arranged with a group of major bankers, it was announced yesterday by A. Z. Leslie, vice president-finance.
The signals are all on the optimistic side for advertising abroad in the year ahead.
ROME, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Following are textual excerpts from the official Vatican translation of the Christmas message of Pope Pius XII:

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The body of Dianna Bixby, 32 years old, one of the nation's foremost woman fliers, was recovered today from the wreckage of her plane in the Gulf of California. It had crashed in a storm twenty-four hours earlier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, threatened today to order a Congressional investigation of the proposed merger of the Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

Paced by Ed Conlin and Billy Lyons, the Fordham University basketball team defeated Princeton, 66 -- 56, in the Rams' Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx last night. It was a hard-earned victory, the Maroon bouncing back from the short end of a 34-31 count at the intermission.

SINGAPORE -- The countries of Southeast Asia face the year 1955 with a feeling of uncertainty. In the purely economic sphere, reduced export earnings are causing concern. Economic worries are, moreover, being accentuated by the political fact of Chinese Communist power to the north and continuing internal Communist activity in each of the Southeast Asian territories.
PANAMA, Jan. 3 -- A ten-day suspension of five constitutional guarantees was decreed by the National Assembly today in the shocked aftermath of the assassination of Pres ident Jose Antonio Remon.

One of the several fiscal reforms to which the Eisenhower Administration addressed itself when it came to office was that of lengthening the average maturity of the federal debt, which was top-heavy with short-term obligations.
For the first time in recent history the United States will follow this year a program of increasing official participation in the great international trade fairs abroad.

A. C. Champlain Co, investment securities, also Thomas F. Walsh, attorney, John J. Crowe and Morton G. Millstein, certified public accountants; Havenor-Cayias, Inc, member of Salt Lake City Stock Exchange, branch office, and additional space to Clarke Dodge Co, stock brokers, in 82 Beaver Street; Wall Street Photo Print Service, in 80 Beaver St -- W. E. Dean Co, brokers.

HELSINKI, Finland -- The economic gains made by Finland in 1954 showed that the gloomy forecasts of 1953 were unrealistic. The favorable trend that began in the latter part of 1953 continued through 1954.
LONDON -- There will be a considerable increase in industrial investment this year and in 1956 accompanied by far-reaching mechanization and modernization of British industry.

LONDON -- The number of tourists visiting Britain in 1954 reached a new high at 850,000 as did receipts at 130,000,000, ($364,000,000). For 1953 the figures were 819,000 visitors and receipts of 126,000,000 ($352,800,000).

The 1955 Nash car line, featuring new front end styling, was announced yesterday by the Nash Motors division, American Motors Corporation. The new models will go on display here next month at which time New York City delivered prices will be disclosed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Army contends that it still has primacy over the Air Force and the Navy as the nation's most effective, all-around military arm.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 3 (AP) -Gamble - Skogmo, Inc., general merchandise concern with headquarters here, today announced sale of 140 stores and three warehouses in seven Western states to the Western Auto Supply Company of Kansas City.

The Swedes are showing unmistakeable signs of prosperity by American standards -- ownership of a new car. The Swedish-American News Exchange reports that they are moving from motorcycles to automobiles with what looks like acrobatic abandon.

Thirteen four-story walk-up apartments at 819 to 867 Hunts Point Avenue in the Bronx have been sold by Leon Brijansky to Joseph Melon. Each building is on a plot 39 by 100 feet. The property contains 117 apartments and was sold for cash above a mortgage of $183,000.
TRENTON, Jan. 3 -- The State Department of Labor and Industry plans a 100 per cent increase in the next fiscal year in its rehabilitation activities.

ROME -- Real wages failed to rise in Italy last year, while working hours lost through strikes increased, unemployment was unrelieved and the number of working days expended on public works dropped sharply.
A young: man accused of having stolen a new pair of size 11 shoes from a Ninth Avenue store last Friday had cause yesterday to regret that he had bothered with them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Following are the text of the State Department announcement of restrictions on travel by Soviet citizens in the United States, the text of a note from Secretary of State Dulles to George N. Zaroubin, Soviet Ambassador, and an outline of Soviet restrictions on travel by Americans for which the United States rules retaliate:
A 20-year-old United States Marine corporal is one of the eleven "children'' whose custody has been asked by the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Eisenhower extended his sympathy to the people of Panama today on the assassination of their President, Jose Antonio Remon.

PARIS -- In an article that appeared in the latest number of the quarterly La France Mecanicienne, Andre Morice, former Minister of Transport, discusses the recent trend toward expansion in the export of French machinery and tools. He points to the possibility of a great development in this field.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Howard Welsch, independent producer, reports having arranged with Howard Hughes, who has a new employment contract with Jane Russell, to borrow the star for "Portofino." Mr. Welsch expects to start filming in April on the action drama based on a screen play by Bernie Gyler.
PARIS. -- If 1955 should be as good for France as the year just ending, monetary stabilization will be in sight and economic recovery on a solid basis.

HONG KONG -- In 1954 Communist China, which depends on agriculture for the surpluses needed to finance industrialization, experienced the worst floods of the last century in the rice land areas of the Yangtze and Huai River Valleys.
TOKYO -- Political confusion in Japan threatens the solid achievements scored during last year in the nation's economic well-being.

PARIS -- The finances of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the defense efforts of the fourteen member nations reflect the general opinion that 1955 will be "the hinge year" between classic defense and atomic defense.

Nineteen years ago, shortly before Joseph Ferrantelli was born, his father was shot and killed in an attempted hold-up of his grocery store. Yesterday, on the other side of the fence, the youth admitted committing murder in a hold-up.
BONN, Germany -- The armament program will create new problems for West German economic planners.

A word of warm appreciation is due for Herman T. Stichman, who has just left office after serving as State Housing Commissioner in the Dewey Administration for ten years. Mr. Stichman has been a hard worker, and an imaginative, creative force in the cause of housing. New York City has reason to be particularly grateful for his services.
KARACHI, Pakistan -- Pakistan has become the testing ground of the new United States policy of switching the bulk of foreign aid from Europe to Asia.

WELLINGTON, N. Z. -- For the first time in more than a decade New Zealand is facing problems and uncertainties in 1955 in the disposal of some of her main products. This fact tends to dominate an economic outlook that is otherwise sound.
The General Motors Corporation announced plans yesterday to raise about $325,000,000 of capital funds by selling additional common stock through subscription rights to present shareholders.

OUR triless correspondent from the dunes of Dare, on the North Carolina outer banks, has just returned exhausted from a census check on the waterfowl at Pea Island Refuge. His comments on the situation are interesting, from a mathematical as well as an ornithological viewpoint.
The National City Bank of New York and its affiliate, the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, earned $33,766,726 in 1954, or $3.38 a share on National City's 10,000,000 outstanding shares.
PARIS -- The leaders of France and West Germany have agreed to make a common effort to develop the economy of the Saar to the widest possible degree.
Shippers' resistance started building up yesterday to a prospective increase in freight rates on virtually all trade routes out of this country.
Fresh complications developed yesterday in the effort of the left-wing International Fur and Leather Workers Union to gain admission to the American Federation of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The United States today put 27 per cent of its land area out of bounds to Soviet citizens.

Reflecting increased sales, the H. J. Heinz Company and its consolidated foreign subsidiaries reported a gain in net income for the six months ended Oct. 27 to $4,534,686 from $3,439,486 earned in the 1953 half.

CALGARY, Jan. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Imperial Oil, Ltd., said today it had reached general agreement with four other oil companies whereby Imperial would spend $9,000,000 to explore oil and gas possibilities of the Peace River area of British Columbia.

Gil Turner registered an upset victory over Italo Scortichini in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The Philadelphian gained the unanimous award over his Italian rival, to the satisfaction of everybody in the gathering of 1,388.

It has not always seemed during the past twelve months that civil rights and the concept of liberty were making rapid progress in this country.
