During part of that time there was reason to fear that in the attack on the evil doctrines of the extreme Left all bold and original thinking, totally unconnected as such thinking by its very nature is with communism or fascism, might come under a cloud.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark -The threat of a renewed deficit in the foreign trade balance of payments beclouds Denmark's economy.

BONN, Germany -- West Germany, on the basis of advance orders, expects its foreign trade to go on expanding through at least the first quarter of 1955. There is some difference of opinion between the highly optimistic Ministry of Economics and the central bank and similar more conservative sources on the degree to which the rising curve may flatten out.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The White House announced today the compulsory retirement of Charles D. Mahaffie as a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission because he had passed the age of 70.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Government and business leaders are unanimous in predicting a period of exceptional prosperity for the Union of South Africa. They insist the nation is fast overcoming its balance of payments difficulties and has a built-in defense in depth against any world recession.

Billy Talbert, the non-playing captain of the United States Davis Cup team, arrived at Idlewild International Airport last night. He brought with him the silver bowl that the United States tennis team won in Australia last week.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Jan. 3 -- The two leaders of the United States Navy's expedition to Antarctica were almost blown out to sea today when two helicopters in which they were riding were caught in a sudden gale.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- England's touring cricket team, sparked by Peter May, today led Australia by 119 runs halfway through the third test match here.

LONDON -- Most of the principal currencies of Europe were much more freely convertible into dollars at the end of 1954 than they had been at the beginning. But the goal of full technical "convertibility" seemed almost as far away as ever.

ROME -- A good year for industry in 1954 was partly offset by a bad year for agriculture. On balance, however, the Italian economy took another, though slight, step forward. The measure of the advance is given by an estimated 4 per cent increase in the national income.
PANAMA, Jan. 4 -- The United States and Cuban Governments were asked today to lend the services of investigators to help hunt the assassins of President Jose Antonio Remon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board has reported that consumer credit rose by $234 million in November. The largest increases were incharge accounts, credit on goods other than automobiles and personal loans.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Two veteran river pilots told a Coast Guard hearing today that the freighter Southern Districts had a slight but "normal" list when she left port a month ago to vanish with all hands.
Agriculture will remain the bedrock of Jamaica's economy this year despite its ever-growing industries.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Sales of the Hotpoint Company increased 50 per cent in the last six months of 1954 compared with the corresponding period of 1953, John F. McDaniel, vice president in charge of marketing, disclosed today in a year-end statement.

"Common Sense and World Affairs," a commentary by Dorothy Fosdick, will be published by Harcourt, Brace, Jan. 20. Miss Fosdick served for four years on the Policy Planning Staff of the State Department. She presents her views on our relations with the rest of the world and suggests principles for improving our international relations.
PANAMA -- Panama's two-year rise in production of basic foodstuffs for her own consumption is expected to continue in 1955.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The current version of the Good Design exhibit, which opened today, is a vividly colorful show.

The 1955 line of Packard cars was announced yesterday by the Studebaker - Packard Corporation. All models are equipped with V-8 valve-in-head engines and have been widely restyled. One engine has a 260-horsepower rating.

JOG JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 4 -- Observers in Indonesia agree that the most encouraging signs of progress in this new Southeast Asian republic are to be found in the hinterland. Conditions in Central Java bear this out.
The Eighty-fourth Congress, which convenes today, will debate vital issues of military policy and national security.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- Canada's "economic ribbon" along the United States border is rapidly expanding northward, and the country's great economic expansion is certain to continue, Dr. D. M. Stephens, president of the Engineering Institute of Canada, said at a meeting of engineers here.

Memo to investors: The Kremlin is bearish on the stock market boom. It thinks that people who buy stocks today are "small investors who are not wise to market manipulations" and will be "shorn" by the "big sharks."

The four-story apartment house for ten families on lot 27 by 100 feet at 1195 President Street in Brooklyn was sold by the Kastro Realty Corporation to Lloyd V. Lassner, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The buyer is an investor.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Harlem Globetrotters, who have traveled millions of miles to keep basketball dates the world over during the last nineteen years, missed their game in Chicago Stadium last night -- by a margin of ninety miles.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazil is entering on a year that will have to be marked by governmental belt-tightening, which will be complicated by the fact it is a presidential electoral year. Such measures are not calculated to win votes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Joseph S. Petersen Jr. was sentenced today to seven years in prison for removing secret documents from the files of the National Security Agency.

QUEBEC -- Exploitation of this province's vast mineral wealth increased last year. The value of mineral production is expected to reach $286,000,000 for the year, an all-time record. The previous high, in 1952, was $270,000,000. The 1953 total was $253,000,000.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- After many months of low supplies, New York City now has water to spare at its Cornell Dam.

GUATEMALA -- The construction of a completely new port on the Caribbean is one of two of the public works of former President Jacobo Arbenz Stuzman's Five-Year Plan that the present Government is carrying out.
An alien awaiting deportation escaped from hotel quarters that were used recently for detainees by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 4 -- Anyone whose property is assessed for at least $1,000 may vote at town meetings, Judge John J. Comley of the Fairfield County Superior Court ruled here today.

Two New Jersey towns remained at loggerheads with the State Highway Authority yesterday. As a result, one new section of the Garden State Parkway was closed, and, on another, cars crawled at twenty-five miles an hour.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Prices rose on the stock market here today despite the approach of the threatened railway strike. A rally in Government funds helped industrial shares to improve after an uncertain start. Oils again were active and strong.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Eighty-fourth Congress will open tomorrow with a Democratic majority leadership seemingly well disposed toward President Eisenhower.
Don Mueller yesterday became the Giants' tenth player to sign a 1955 contract. This pact doubtless cost the Polo Grounders a little something extra.

The city's monthly test of its 679 air-raid warning sirens yesterday showed that thirteen had mechanical defects. This compares with fourteen on Dec. 6, when the last test was conducted. There were two defective sirens yesterday in Manhattan, three in the Bronx, four in Brooklyn and four in Queens. Public participation was not asked.
How private enterprise in the United States can help under-developed nations is indicated in an analysis by the National Planning Association of operations in Peru by W. R. Grace Co.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Following is the text of the Republican legislative policy statement issued today by Walter J. Mahoney, Senate majority leader, and Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly:

TORONTO -- The year 1954 was a notable one for the Canadian uranium industry, particularly because it saw Rix Athabaska and Nesbitt-Labine become the country's first privately owned mines to go into production.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -England beat Australia by 128 runs in the third Cricket Test Match today.. The English gained a 2-1 lead in the series of five matches in the defense of the mythical Ashes -- the symbol of Anglo-Australian cricket supremacy.

Ninety-seven per cent of the 3.240 landlords who appeared in Housing and Buildings Court last July 29 in connection with housing offenses have "cleaned up" the violations, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh said yesterday.
The growing trend of United States companies to invest in Latin America is not a monopoly of the industrial giants.
A separate department for teen-age girls' apparel is the beat way to tap this growing market, retailers were told yesterday.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- Officials here said today they had received no information about enforcement of the State Department restrictions on the travel of Soviet citizens in New England.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- It was indicated tonight that Republicans would try tomorrow to get credit for improvement in the conduct of investigations.

TORONTO -- Canada's rapidly expanding oil industry showed nearly 6,000 producing wells and crude reserves of 2,500,000,000 barrels at the end of 1954. In the same period, natural gas reserves in the province of Alberta alone had mounted to an estimated 12,000,000,000 000 cubic feet.
"The Fourposter," Broadway's champion two-character play with a run of 632 performances to its credit, will be revived at 8 o'clock tonight at the City Center.
The year 1954 may become a milestone in the history of tourism in the Western Hemisphere, one to be celebrated happily in the future by national tourist offices of the Latin-American countries.
THE post-holiday half of the art season opens with a flurry of one-man exhibitions by artists of both fame and promise.
TOKYO, Jan. 4 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama outlined today a series of steps to develop closer relations between Japan and the Soviet Union and Red China.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- All Republican and Democratic leaders of the Senate and Assembly were renominated at a series of party caucuses here tonight.

MARIA GHISLAINE METTEN SAVAGE sits alone now a good part of the time in her apartment at 22 West Sixty-eighth Street. She is surrounded by hundreds of photographs, paintings and odd little mementos acquired in close to sixty years on opera stages all over the world.
Glowing with color, the spring millinery collection of Adolfo of Emme's is inspired by this designer's native Cuba.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, the United States singles champion, gained the semi-finals of the South Australia tennis tournament today, along with Mervyn Rose of Australia, Lennart Bergelin of Sweden and Roger Backer of England.
The placing of advertising by United States manufacturers in Latin American markets is gradually being put on a systematic basis, and the outlook is for much higher billings.
Sales of properties in the Stuyvesant Square section featured Manhattan deals reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- A Republican program covering eight major fields was announced today on the eve of the opening session of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The United States has formally asked Communist Hungary whether asylum has been granted to Noel and Herta Field.
The city's waterfront chief told longshoremen yesterday that their own welfare and the welfare of the port would be enhanced if they voted to ratify a new dock peace agreement today.

A Federal Trade Commission hearing examiner refused yesterday to receive in evidence a report of a committee of the National Academy of Sciences supporting the view of the National Bureau of Standards that AD-X2, controversial automobile battery additive, was worthless.

THEODORE LETTVIN, who made his New York debut as a pianist last season, gave a second recital last night in Town Hall. His program as well as his performances betokened a decided development on the part of a gifted young artist.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Harriman was disclosed today to have refused to speak at a dinner for Americans for Democratic Action.

Equipping a new plant abroad with machinery made in the United States is quite an undertaking, it is pointed out by Jerome F. Gould, head of the export packing concern bearing his name. The company recently was commissioned to export 50,000 cubic feet of heavy machinery for a factory of the Reynolds-Phillippine Corporation, newest subsidiary of the Reynolds Metals Company.

MOOSE KRAUSE is a large, amiable and perceptive operator who serves as athletic director at Notre Dame. Long before anyone else in college ranks was aware of it, the Moose warned that restricted football television by the National Collegiate Athletic Association was playing directly into the hands of the professionals.

Last night's concert by Leon Barzin and the National Orchestral Association at Carnegie Hall featured the first performance in this country of two works by the Danish composer Svend Erik Tarp -- "Comedy Overture No. 2" and Piano Concerto in C, Op. 39. The latter had as its soloist the Danish pianist Ellen Gilberg.
TOKYO, Jan. 4 -- Japan and the United States agreed formally today on a $2,000,000 payment for damages resulting from thermonuclear tests in the Marshall Islands this year.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- A severe shortage of electric power continued to hinder Costa Rican industrial development in 1954. In the dry season [January-May] two power cut-offs a day will have to be resorted to again. The unevenly distributed rainfall poses a severe problem in a country of nearly a million inhabitants, where the sole source of power is hydro-electricity.
A witness from the Department of State in Albany testified yesterday that the New York State Harness Racing Commission had neither filed nor repealed any racing rules in 1954.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- The exports of Parana pine to the dollar area maintain an even level, or about 10 per cent of all pine exports.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Ceylon has freed sheet rubber for export to countries other than Communist China because world prices have risen above those offered by China.
Brazil attempted to hold a coffee umbrella for all producing countries and while most areas moved their supplies at high prices the Brazilian industry was left holding the bean last year.

James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, said yesterday that he hoped to promote several world championship fights this year. One proposed match would involve Rocky Marciano, the heavyweight title-holder.
The Salvation Army will seek $1,250,000 in contributions here this year. Its appeal began yesterday.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- British Columbia, which depends for half its income, about $500,000,000 annually, on its timber, will conduct its second full scale inquiry in 1955 into many phases of its forest industries.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- Vancouver International Airport, already Canada's busiest, will add another major flight to its schedules in 1955 if the Federal Air Transport Board decides to allow Canadian Pacific Airlines to fly over the North Pole to Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

In the spring of 1954 the United States Atomic Energy Commission revealed one of the most important secrets since the original announcement by President Truman of our suc cessful development of the atomic bomb. In language so guarded that it has-escaped public notice until now, the Commission announced a new type of nuclear reactor for the generation of industrial power.
TORONTO -- With an estimated total of 750,000,000 shares in all categories traded, the Toronto Stock Exchange experienced in 1954 the second most active year in its history.

WINNIPEG, Man. -- Farmers in western Canada regard United States import restrictions on agricultural products "as thoroughly bad in principle." But they add that import quotas will have little practical effect this year.

SANTIAGO, Chile. -- The Government of President Carlos Ibanez del Campo is planning a "new deal" for the nation's ports. Over the course of six years it intends to spend 3,000,000,,000 pesos ($10,000,000) in brining the nation's harbors and shipping facilities to a new efficiency.
BIAK, Dutch New Guinea, Dec. 30 -- Ten years after the battle for Biak, its relics are still in evidence, although many have been overgrown by jungle and native villages.

Fifty-eight local housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed yesterday $135,817,000 on issues of short-term notes at interest rates ranging from 0.624 per cent to 0.86 per cent. The average borrowing rate was 0.731 per cent. The notes will come due on various dates from Aug. 5, 1955, to March 9, 1956.
Richard Schulze and his wife, Theodora, two Chicago musicians who recently moved to New York, presented the first of a series of three concerts of baroque music last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

CAIRO, Jan. 2 -- Nothing has been done to arrest the deterioration at the site of Cheops' solar ship. The damage, a result of neglect, has extended to the ship itself. Large cracks have opened in the shaft of the steering sweep lying atop it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board moved tonight to restrain speculation on the booming stock market.

The Red Cross appealed yesterday for women to serve as daytime volunteers with the regional blood program. The recruits, seriously needed to serve with bloodmobile units and at donor centers, will be trained in a new class beginning Jan. 18.

New York University defeated West Virginia, 79 to 78, and Manhattan College beat Brigham Young, 78 to 75, at Madison Square Garden last night. Despite the presence of two local teams on the card, only about 1,500 persons watched the college basketball double-header.
OTTAWA -- Development of Canadian waterpower reached a new peak in 1954.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The return of Congress tomorrow brings the political orators down to reality.

Leaders of the Republican majority in the New York Legislature have issued a statement of policy for the session opening in Albany today that offers a somewhat cautious hand of cooperation to Governor Harriman and at the same time lays down some major elements of a party program.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- One of the key sections of the ethics program set up by the Dewey Administration has proved unrevealing so far.

The performance of "The Dark Is Light Enough," with Katharine Cornell and Tyrone Power in the leading roles, on Feb. 11 at the ANTA Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for Recording for the Blind, Inc.
HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Relative stabilization of Bermuda's economy on the basis of 100,000 tourists a year is conceded to be the best that can be done under known conditions.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- After nearly forty years of controversy, work has actually begun on one of the two stretches of track that will complete the Pacific Great Eastern Railway from Vancouver to the Peace River region.
Russek's collection of Jerry Gilden resort fashions will prove good news for those going South. Shown yesterday at the store, they ranged in price, with one exception, from $10.95 to $17.95.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Controller Arthur Levitt filled three vacancies on his staff today. The three appointees are to be sworn in tomorrow by Carmine G. DeSapio. Secretary of State.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 4 -- The Communist regime in East Germany is reported to have run into trouble with neighboring Communist Poland and Communist Czechoslovakia over its leaders' Christmas period declaration that it will rearm if West Germany does.
Hurricane Hazel caused exceptional damage over a wide area last October, but its effects on Haiti will be felt by that country for several years to come.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- Uruguay's newly elected Council of Government will take power March 1, but it already is busy planning how to meet this small country's increasingly uncertain economic and financial condition.
MIAMI, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Orange Bowl football game between Duke and Nebraska, which drew howls of protest from sports writers and fans, was a big success financially, it was revealed today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Hogs recovered today from yesterday's sharp spill, generally gaining 25 to 50 cents. Salable receipts were 3,000 below the advance estimate. Trading started slow, but picked up speed toward the close.
GENEVA, Jan. 4 -- Western European Governments are preparing to announce new goals for trade liberalization.

Work was advanced in the Province of Ontario in 1954 on clearing large sections for the Trans-Canada Highway. When completed the highway will extend from the Quebec border, a few miles west of Montreal, to the Manitoba boundary, just west of Kenora.

A sale and lease-back transaction involving four bank properties on Long Island was announced yesterday. The deal amounted to close to $3,000,000, according to Walter A. Davis, vice president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, the broker.
A 56-year-old furrier plunged to his death from a fifth-floor office window last night. His fall produced unexpected consequences, setting off fears of an explosion and fire.

Prices of rubber tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange after several weeks of almost steady rises Profit-taking, speculator liquidation, stop-loss selling and short selling dropped futures 130 to 160 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a turnover of 2,890 tons.

A committee of holders of American Woolen $4 prior preferred stock will conduct an open meeting tomorrow at 3:45 P. M. in the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway. Possible action will be discussed on the proposed exchange of securities in the merger of the American Woolen Company, Textron, Inc., and Robbins Mills, Inc.
Football fatalities reached their highest peak since 1949 during the past season. They ran 7 per cent above the average in the twenty-three years that records have been kept.

The General Motors Corporation has announced plans for raising $325 millions through the sale of common stock. This is said to represent the largest piece of industrial financing to date, and the largest piece of financing ever undertaken by any corporation through the sale of common stock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Hoover Commission will notify Congress tomorrow that it must act on one of the most sweeping programs in modern memory for streamlining the Government.

It appears that for the sake of "good foreign policy" as interpreted by the State Department, the United States, which is looked up to by all small nations as the champion of the right of self-representation, liberty and freedom, has forsaken the just demands of Greece.

With tongue in cheek, but also with a serious pu)/oose, the American Government has expanded previous travel restrictions on most Soviet citizens by barrin them from nearly' a thousand counties and hundreds of cities comprising some 27 per cent of the land area of the United States.

The New York Rangers, who have not beaten the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden this season, will attempt to break the jinx tonight in a National Hockey League game at the Eighth Avenue Arena starting at 8:30.

YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territory -New and deeper seams of gold have been opened, uranium has been found and exploration has been started for oil in the Northwest, but at the year's end there was little evidence of any sharp upturn in general economic conditions.

Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen reserved decision yesterday on a motion by Nathaniel L. Goldstein, former Attorney General, to enjoin eleven men and three concerns from engaging in the sale of uranium and television securities within this state.

Dense smoke from a five-alarm fire that swept two Hudson River piers covered most of lower Manhattan late yesterday. It held up West Side Highway traffic briefly but ferry service to New Jersey continued from an adjacent pier.
CARACAS, Venezuela -- The boom in this nation has made it a focal point of interest to the economic world and has brought a stream of visitors.

"The Beachcomber," a Technicolor film version of W. Somerset Maugham's, story of the South Seas, co-starring Robert Newton. Glynis Johns and Donald Sinden, has been scheduled to have its American premiere on Saturday, Jan. 15 at the Trans- Lux Normandie Theatre, United Artists announced yesterday.

One of the most distinctive highway building achievements in South America -- or perhaps in the world -- provides a new lifeline for a nearly isolated section of Bolivia that is rich in raw materials.

An assertion that 80 per cent of 500,000 anti-Communist Poles who have become exiles since World War II support the Polish Council of National Unity was made here yesterday by the council's president, Dr. Tadeusz Bielecki.
OTTAWA -- Canada's Government, labor leaders and people are seeking an answer to the difficult question, "How many immigrants are good for Canada?"
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- A Republican-controlled Senate subcommittee voted 3 to 1 today against putting coffee futures trading under Government regulation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations took a new stride toward unity today.
OTTAWA -- The buoyant Canadian economy paused in 1954 to catch its breadth. But as 1954 ended, experts predicted new and greater progress this year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- The Western Big Three supported today Israel's demand that her ships be allowed to pass through the Suez Canal without interference from Egypt.
DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Coach Buddy Parker today signed a one-year football contract with the Detroit Lions. He said the pact was bigger and better than last year and "just the way I wanted it."
A steady expansion of trade between the United States and South America was predicted here yesterday by Dr. Alvaro Diaz, president of Flota Mercante Grancolombiana.
VIENNA, Jan. 4 -- Czechoslovakia and Hungary plan to stress heavy industry in the new year.
HONG KONG, Wednesday, Jan. 5 --Communist China announced the arrival of Dag Hammarskjold at Hankow yesterday afternoon. He is en route to Peiping.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Electric power shortage has been possibly the most serious bottleneck to Brazil's industrial development. Intensive work is going on to increase power output fast enough to keep pace with the potential development of industry.
A one-man crusade to cut traffic accidents by marking the outer edges of highways is starting to show results.

EDMONTON, Alberta -- This city of 200,000, the most northerly population center of Canada, is the base of a network of transportation and supply that stretches northwest to the Yukon Territory and Alaska; northward to the inland fisheries and mines of Great Slave Lake and Great Bear Lake. and on to the Arctic Ocean; and northeasterly to the fast-growing uranium mines of Lake Athabaska.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 4 -- The world's first multi-jet seaplane, theoretically able "to operate with complete flexibility in or near enemy waters," was taken off the secret list today.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- After twenty-two years of development, the oil deposits near the Strait of Magellan are on the verge of profitable exploitation. President Carlos Ibanez del Campo recently led a line of automobiles to a gasoline station to fill his tank, for the first time in history, with fuel refined from Chilean crude oil.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- Owners of small and medium-sized mines in Bolivia are hoping that the "revolutionary" Government of President Victor Paz Estenssoro will develop a new exchange policy this year for their production.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- A group of residents of Yonkers asked the state today to withhold educational aid funds from their city.
The development of special weather advisory notices for New York's shipping industry is a possibility, Ernest J. Christie, chief meteorologist at the Weather Bureau here, said yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 4 (AP)--Coach Eddie Erdelatz tonight pondered an offer of a new contract, reportedly for five years, to continue as Navy's football coach.

Mrs. Robert F. Wagner will give a reception and tea tomorrow afternoon at Gracie Mansion for members of the committee in charge of the plans for the dinner to be held on March 3 at the Commodore Hotel for the benefit of the State of New York Chapter, Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Only Don Platt among the favorites had any trouble in the Dixie tennis tournament today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia -- The Bolivian Government hopes this year to make the turning in the road that will take the country out of its "one-crop economy." It expects that oil will become one of its important sources of foreign exchange.
OTTAWA -- Prospects for a good year in sales of oats and barley despite United States import restrictions were indicated in a recent survey by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- In response to the growing demands of Latin-America's metallurgical industries, United Nations experts have embarked on a study to determine what types of consumer and capital goods they can best produce.
Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer last night described the regulations of the McCarran Act as "a wholly fantastic and grotesque way to meet the threat of espionage."

Executive chairmen and members of the men's committee for the sixteenth annual White Elephant Party, for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee, met yesterday afternoon at a cocktail party in the recently opened Knight Box of the Ambassador.
Six trustees and their alternates, representing both management and contract employes, have been appointed to administer the new welfare and pension plan for television performers.
Ben H. Guill, a former member of Congress from Texas and former executive assistant to the Postmaster General, was sworn in yesterday as the third member of the Federal Maritime Board.
Julius Helfand, the new chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday that he would appoint William Dahut of Brooklyn as a deputy commissioner and confidential aide.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- A highway from Hazelton, B. C., northeast of Prince Rupert, to Atlin and the Cassiar district in the northwest of the province, may be the next major communications project to be started as the opening of the province's northern frontiers goes on.

Two elderly persons -- a brother and a sister -- were found dead last night in their upper East Side apartment. They were the first victims this year of gas poisoning that took 105 lives here in 1954.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The number of serious crimes committed in the United States in 1954 was greater than in any previous year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Wolf Ladejinsky, labeled a security risk by one Government agency, will be asked by another to help direct the fight against communism in the Far East.

LIMA, Peru -- Peru continues to be one of the most stable of the South American republics. The 1955 outlook is exceptionally promising from the standpoint of financial stability, increased exports and development of natural resources and industries.
tatistica! evidence is beginrqng to come in to support the opinion of New York's retailers tli at a sales record was set last on th.
OTTAWA, Jan. 4 -- Two Canadian Cabinet Ministers announced today that they would fly to Washington Thursday to try to expedite renewal of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).
CALGARY, Alberta -- On Feb. 13, 1947, the Imperial Oil Company's discovery well No. 1 blew in at Leduc, Alberta, marking the beginning of a spectacular change in the province's economy.
VANCOUVER, B. C. -- Kitimat, one of Canada's newest industrial cities, will be on the route of the country's first commercial helicopter service being planned by Okanagan Helicopters Ltd.

MEXICO CITY -- With a loan of $61,000,000 from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Mexico has begun modernization of her 1,200-mile Pacific Coast railroad to speed economic development of the Northwest.

Uruguay's railroads will become the world's most completely dieselized transportation system in several Weeks. The state-owned railways now are awaiting delivery of the last two of sixty-four diesel-electric locomotives built in the United States at a cost of $10,000,000 by International General Electric and put aboard ship New Year's Eve.
LONDON. Jan. 4 -- Led by Prime Minister Churchill, the Government moved with urgent speed today to avert the nationwide railroad strike set for midnight Sunday.
A number of outstanding European athletes will compete in United States track and field meets this winter. Dan Ferris secretary treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, said yesterday.
Bigarrade, the orange-flavored sauce that is a classic French accompaniment to duck, has inspired a seasonal variation utilizing now-plentiful tangerines.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- The general economic scene in Puerto Rico is healthy, and prospects appear bright for 1955, according eto Rafael Carrion, President of the Banco Popular, the largest in Puerto Rico.

Diamonds may be a girl's best friend, as Carol Channing sang in "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes." But the solemn Pick's World Currency Report of yesterday discovered that even equities -- despite 1954's market -- did not do as well by the capitalist as did the paintings of the French post-impressionist school.

Directors of the Caterpillar Tractor Company voted yesterday to increase the authorized common stock from 5,000,000 to 10,000,000 shares to effect a two-for-one split as of April 20. There are now about 4,136,779 common shares outstanding.
TORONTO -- The year 1954 marked one of the biggest splurges in railway construction in recent Canadian history.
South America has been aptly described as the continent that leaped from mule-back into the air. There was no intervening period.
DETROIT, Jan. 5 -- Suburban Dearborn, made an "open city" for Soviet travel, will have a red carpet waiting if any citizens of the Soviet Union go there.
HARTFORD, Jan. 4 -- Connecticut's General Assembly, which meets every two years, will convene tomorrow.

The one-story industrial building containing 25,500 square feet of work space at 708 Twenty-third Street, in Union City, N. J., has been leased by the York Corporation to Varego, Inc., knitted goods manufacturer, in a deal negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc.
Young homemakers with a limited income would do well to design and make their own rugs, in the opinion of George Wells, prize-winning rug designer.

HAVANA -- Heavy clouds darkened Cuba's economy as 1955 began, but clearer skies were predicted with the return of constitutional government. Two years of the de facto regime, which began on March 10, 1952, when Gen. Fulgencio Batista seized control by a military coup, will end on Feb. 24 with his installation as the elected President. At the same time representatives elected to Congress, Provincial and municipal legislative bodies will be installed.

John L. Collyer, chairman of the B. F. Goodrich Company, proposed yesterday that the Government stop stockpiling natural rubber and dispose of any supplies in excess of the amount required for a national emergency.

EDMONTON, Alberta -- For the oil industry in Alberta, 1954 was a year of consolidation marked by some declines in field work, strong competitive bidding for land, increased production, substantial investments to expand marketing facilities and efforts to obtain additional markets.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -Latin America will need between 1,500,000 and 2,000,000 tons of additional pulp and paper supplies by 1965, according to estimates made by experts in this field.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic -- The more than 2,300,000 citizens of the Dominican Republic face 1955 confidently and expectantly. Their nation, in 1954, enjoyed one of the largest favorable trade balances in its history and all signs are that this year will be even better.
The new State Department limitations on travel by Soviet citizens in the United States apparently have only slight effect on the activities of Soviet business and press agencies in this city.
A fugitive, sought for almost a month after $250,000 worth of stolen property was found in his wife's apartment, was arrested last night in a Greenwich Village bar.
Eighteen city agencies asked Father Knickerbocker yesterday to increase their allowances in the next fiscal year by $863,279.

Despite a substantial rise in imports in relation to exports, Nicaragua's economy made significant progress last year. For the first time, cotton showed signs of replacing coffee as the country's most important export.

The treatment that the new Congress gives to President Eisenhower's proposals for a tariff-cutting foreign economic policy will command world-wide attention of the highest degree during the coming months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Americans saved $2,700,000,000 in liquid assets in the third quarter of 1954, slightly less than in the preceding three months, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
HAVANA -- Cuba has just completed financing the United Railways of Havana by a novel method.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought movie rights to "Something of Value," a novel by Robert Ruark, newspaper columnist, to be published in March by Doubleday.

BUENOS AIRES -- Business men and industrialists in Argentina have welcomed in the new year with an optimism markedly different from their sentiments in the last few years. They expect it to be a decisively favorable one.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Under a reorganization plan that became effective yesterday, the Immigration and Naturalization Service will reduce its personnel by about 100.

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- This province has gone through a remarkable year of capital expansion. Among the industries that shared in the growth were pulp and paper plants, oil refineries, the Aluminum Company of Canada, which started production, water development and home and office construction.

The Transit Authority is embarked on a long-range program to improve the city's subway system but a quarter-century of neglect cannot be reemdied overnight, Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, authority chairman, said yesterday.

HALIFAX, N. S. -- Formation of a Maritime Provinces Economic Council designed to investigate the possibilities for industrial and other development in Eastern Canada was probably the outstanding development of the year.

LIMA, Peru -- Peru's trade balance has been improving steadily. For the first ten months of 1954, January - October, the adverse trade balance was reduced to $2,637,060, as compared with an adverse one of $66,079,530 for the period in 1953. This was despite imports of $22,500,000 in July, the record month for 1954.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Royal Navy hit back tonight at critics who have questioned the value of aircraft carriers in the nuclear age and otherwise imputed "horse and buggy" ideas to the admirals.
GREENSBURG, Pa., Jan. 4 (AP) -The Westmoreland County courts today cited two newspaper publishers, three photographers, an editor and a reporter for contempt of court and ordered their arrest.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- A struggle for control of the Boston and Maine Railroad opened today.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Foreign Office announced today that a West German diplomat whose wife called Britain an enemy country at a Christmas party in London would not return there.
Governor Harriman prefers to get his information and discuss policy face-to-face.
SANTIAGO, Chile -- The new year finds Chile still harassed by inflation, but resolved to stem the tide by the end of 1956.
HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Jan. 4 -- The Vietminh authorities are laying the foundations for a tightly regimented police state.

Vassily Smyslov took the undisputed lead yesterday in the international tournament at the Hastings Chess Congress in England, according to a report from London. The Russian chess master played a draw in a Reti opening with Ludek Pachman of Czechoslovakia. Their sixth-round match lasted only twenty-three moves.
The New York State Civil Defense Commission announced yesterday that the Associated Railroads of New York State had provided a railroad operations expert to serve on the commission's staff.
The fashion editor of The New York Times, Miss Virginia Pope, will retire today, her thirtieth anniversary with the newspaper.

It is a matter of considerable importance to the people of New York State that T. Norman Hurd, the Budget Director in the Dewey Administration for the last four years, has been retained as fiscal consultant to the Republican majority in the Senate.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Brookmeade Stable's County Clare, with Willie Hartack hustling him along, proved an easy winner of the featured Shelborne Purse before 9,426 fans at Tropical Park today.

MEXICO CITY -- One of the most encouraging developments for private investment in Mexico or Latin America has been recent progress of the Mexican Power and Light Company, Ltd. -- Mexico's largest private company.
A 27-year-old thug was shot dead yesterday morning as he was attempting to rob a bank in the congested garment district, three blocks south of Times Square.

The Democratic party continues to maintain a better than two-to-one lead over the Republican party in the enrollment of voters in New York City. This was shown by figures on enrollment in last fall's registration, released yesterday by the Board of Elections.

Henri Bonnet, retiring French Ambassador, appealed last night for American confidence in France as a "full-fledged" ally with the will and ability to stand against Soviet expansion. He said it was his "cherished ambition" to continue working for closer French-American unity.
A questionnaire dealing with tardiness of trains on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad will itself be late by a week.

Trends in newsprint -- a commodity of prime importance to Canada and the United States -- presented an impressive picture of healthy growth last year. While the North American area continued a steady and more gradual rise in contrast to the spurts of recent years, other parts of the free world made their biggest gain in supply over pre-war years.

The Guaranty Trust Company increased its net profit 23 per cent to $27,714,013 for 1954 from $22,483,120 for 1953, it reported yesterday. Last year's earnings equaled $5.54 a share, compared with $4.49 in the preceding year.

Few Americans who often sample Jamaica rum or listen to Jamaica rhythm know that the British West Indian island has a garment industry able to take care of 80 per cent of its clothing needs. Only six years ago less than 20 per cent of apparel needed by Jamaica's 1,500,000 inhabitants was made on the island.
The first step in the building of a cross-Cuba canal that may help transform the nation's economy will be made this month.

"American Troops Smash Deeper Into Belgian Bulge," the morning newspapers told an anxious nation ten years ago. For three weeks, ever since Field Marshal von Runstedt's armored columns opened a huge hole in the American lines, the dispatches from the front had been almost uniformly discouraging.

The two most important economic developments in Paraguay last year were the introduction of a direct water service with the outside world and the proposal of tax exemption laws to induce foreign investment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, said today he and Senator Lister Hill, Democrat of Alabama, would introduce legislation to raise the national cotton-acreage allotment to 19,500,000 acres this year and restore the former five-acre minimum allotment.
An intensified Soviet economic offensive in Canada and Latin America seems clearly in prospect for 1955 as the logical follow-up of the trade gains realized last year.

It was with pleasure that I read Paul Kennedy's excellent article on the state of affairs in Central America in The New York Times for Dec. 26. His conclusions are similar to those which I have arrived at after a five-month residence there.
Tiny Tim this year melted a heart less hard than Scrooge's and in far shorter order. The result was a donation to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund that helped to lift the total to $381,654.43.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- Compania Anonima Venezolana de Pulpa y Papel is the name of a new company formed in Caracas in 1954 to manufacture paper from bagasse, the residue of sugar cane after the juice has been extracted.
VANCOUVER, B. C. -- Unemployment figures for British Columbia, issued by the National Employment Service, are not as clear cut as they appear on the surface.

A leading retailer yesterday called for the sale of women's hats by manufacturers closer to the season they are worn. An industry-wide promotional campaign was also urged by Lewis Davis, president of Bonwit Teller Company, Philadelphia.

ONE of the most admired biographies in all English literature, and one of the least read, is John Gibson Lockhart's "Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Bart." Five years ago at a jumble sale conducted by my children's school I bought all nine volumes of this formidable masterpiece. At one dollar for the set I could not resist the bargain.

VIENNA, Jan. 4 -- The Djilas-Dedijer protest against Yugoslavia's leadership is entirely without precedent in the Communist world. Both Partisan heroes and Marxists, they have challenged the very meaning of the prevailing ideology. They are rebelling against Titoism in precisely the way Tito rebelled against Stalinism.

ASBESTOS, Que. -- The asbestos industry of Quebec has spent, or is committed to spend, an estimated total of $75,000,000 on an expansion and development program that will make it one of the most highly mechanized mine-mill operations in the world.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 4 -- Columbia nipped Syracuse, 75 -- 74, in an overtime basketball game in Archbold Gymnasium tonight. Chet Forte poured in 29 points, including the final two game-winning foul points.
The confusion surrounding the status and affiliation of this port's 4,000 tugboat workers is to be referred today to the National Labor Relations Board.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. -- A leading Soviet physicist will be on the committee that will make preparations for the international conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy. He is Dmitri V. Skobeltsyn, a leading member of the Soviet Academy of Science.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 4 -- Salah ben Youssef, secretary general of the Neo-Destour (Nationalist) party, has caused confusion here by his statement impugning French intentions and demanding a national army for Tunisia.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Pit trade was quiet on the Board of Trade today and generally all grains held in a narrow range with moderate commission buying on the small recessions. There was little disposition to follow rallies.

OTTAWA -- Amateur prospectors play an important part in discovering Canada's mineral wealth. In Ontario there were 29,019 claims recorded in 1953. By the end of 1954, more than 50,000 claims were recorded. Mining officials estimate that at least three-fourths of these are registered by "week-end prospectors."
Central America led the hemisphere in the launching of new maritime projects in 1954.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico's "industry without chimneys," its huge tourist business, which is just about the country's largest single source of dollars, made a distinct comeback after the devaluation of the peso -- as well it should with tourists geting 12.50 pesos for each $1, which meant in many cases top hotel rooms for $3, or tee-bone steaks for $1.
Macy's New York yesterday assigned its second-in-command to direct its branch store program.

Thomas Jefferson Williams, whose hobby is "buying volcanoes," is a miner of tungsten and brimstone, chemical merchant, cattle rancher, head of fifteen companies in Argentina and reputedly one of the wealthiest North Americans in South America.

MONTREAL -- Montreal's two stock exchanges, the Montreal Stock Exchange and the Canadian Stock Exchange, had one of their busiest years in 1954. This was caused largely by the current easy money policy that kept interest rates down and made higher dividend yields more attractive to investors.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Ready made clothing has been launched in the market here this time it will stay.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 4 -- Borba, the official newspaper of the Socialist Alliance, accused the foreign press today of making an "organized" attack on Yugoslavia.
WINNIPEG, Man. -- Wheat farmers on the Canadian prairies took a heavy buffeting from weather and from world marketing conditions in 1954.
MEXICO CITY -- Mexico has adjusted to her 40 per cent devaluation of the peso last April. Free exchange of the peso has been successfully maintained and business is back to about normal.
Pencil heels, insteps cut down to narrow strips, tapered toes and vertical stitching reflected the long, slim look forecast for the spring in yesterday's showing of Fenton shoes by Saks Fifth Avenue.
VANCOUVER, B. C. -- Forty-six miles of railway, serving British Columbia's newest major industry, the Aluminum Company of Canada plant at Kitimat, 400 miles north of here, has been completed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The chairmanships of House committees, often called the citadels of Congressional power, return to the conservative South as Democrats take control of the Eighty-fourth Congress.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 4 (AP) -The Pennsylvania General Assembly opened its 141st regular session today with the twin problems of taxes and economy uppermost.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Gasoline "made in Brazil" will be placed on sale at Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo gas pumps by early February in small amounts that will be increased about April when three new refineries will be in full production.
GUATEMALA -- The year 1955 is one of great expectations and economic planning for Guatemala. However no drastic change in the structure of the economy, or the nature of its activities, is expected.
CARACAS, Venezuela -- The economy of Venezuela enjoyed another year of record prosperity in 1954, based chiefly on the high level of oil production and a boom in construction.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Capital for development and assured prices for raw materials are the great preoccupations of South America as 1955 opens.
VANCOUVER, B. C. -- The new year will see a start made on removal of a marine hazard that has plagued shipping men on this busy coast since the region was first opened to commerce.

The third and final section of The Times' New Year review of the world's economy is a reminder that our greatest commercial stake is right here in the Western Hemisphere. Either Latin America as a whole, or Canada taken separately, is a larger field of American investment and trade than Europe, Asia or Africa.

WHO are Communists and why -- was the subject of a television program conducted this week by Princeton University, starting its second season of presentations over the National Broadcasting Company's facilities (3 P. M. Sundays).
PUBLIC hunting is on its way out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A spurt in factory payrolls carried November personal income in the nation to a level corresponding to $287,500,000,000 on an annual basis, the Department of Commerce reported today. The figure was $1,250,000,000 higher than the rate for October and slightly higher than that for November, 1953.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Secretary of State Dulles has narrowed for the second time in less than a year the authority of his chief security officer, Scott McLeod.
An increase in the rapid transit fare is possible if the present deficit of the Transit Authority continues, Mayor Wagner warned yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- The drastic break in coffee prices during 1954 has given impetus to plans to diversity Colombia's economy. At present coffee comprises 95 per cent of the country's exports, in terms of foreign exchange.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Child-feeding programs undertaken by the United Nations have helped develop the dairy industries of Nicaragua and Chile, according to reports received by the United Nations Children's Fund.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Cocoa has now become Costa Rica's third most important export crop, surpassed only by coffee and bananas.

Most of the world's leading producers of sugar cane and refined sugar have their securities listed and traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which controls trading on the Exchange, require periodic sales, earnings, ownership, proxy statements and other accounting reports.

The Government Development Bank of Puerto Rico has had more than a decade of experience in helping economically backward areas help themselves. As a consequence the techniques and achievements of the bank have become object lessons for interests hopeful of promoting economic development in Latin America.

VANCOUVER. B. C. -- A scale model of First Narrows, the tide-swept passage to Vancouver harbor, has been completed at the University of British Columbia. Built by the National Research Council, the model will simulate tidal conditions in the busy shipping channel leading from English Bay, which is the outer harbor, into the near-landlocked inner harbor.
Liberalization of the present substitution rules, short of a return to "two platoon" play is proposed by the nation's football coaches.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The Security Division of the State Department in Chicago adopted a tightlipped attitude today when asked for details on how the department's order restricting travel by Soviet citizens in the Middle West would be enforced.
As Congress convenes at the stroke of noon today a new chapter -- the Eighty-fourth -- opens in the long and exciting history of this constitutional democracy of ours.

MONTREAL -- Canadian mills, in the face of increased world demands, broke the tonnage record during 1954 by producing almost 10,000,000 tons of pulp and paper valued at $1,200,000,000. This is an increase in tonnage of 2 per cent over the banner year of 1951.
MONTREAL -- Pulp and paper mills whose raw material is found in Canada's vast woodlands are happy about the progress made during 1954 in conservation and forest management.

Retailers of work clothing and men's casual wear report a marked improvement in business prior to Christmas and are optimistic on spring prospects, according to Arthur J. Rozett, executive director of the Work Clothes and Sportswear Show.
Your editorial "After Censure" in the issue of Dec. 5 stresses a most essential demand -- the taking of further steps regarding McCarthy.

In a continuation of Monday's closing-hour slump, stocks broke sharply at the opening yesterday. They recovered some of their gains in the second hour and then moved little in either direction for the rest of the session. Losses on the day were moderate.

The advertising agency is beginning to emerge from "the huckster era," but there is still a long way to go, William B. Lewis, president of Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., told the Poor Richard Club yesterday in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The State Department was beset today with questions and complaints about the effect of its order putting 27 per cent of the United States out of bounds to Soviet citizens. Up to now there has been no reaction from Moscow, however, or from the Soviet Embassy in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Government announced today resumption of its enforcement program against rat and insect infestation of grain.
A collection of 25,000 documents, furniture, paintings, silver and jewelry owned by the Livingston family has been given to the New York Historical Society.

After some delay the security officers of the Department of Agriculture have come out with their arguments against Wolf Ladejinsky, the United States agricultural attache in Japan. These arguments are twofold: first, in 1931-32 Ladejinsky served in the Amtorg, the Soviet trade organization; second, in 1943-44 Ladejinsky wrote articles criticizing Communist policies while at the same time he carried on correspondence with his relatives in Russia.
Ecuador is attempting to induce foreign capital to open industries in the country. Tax concessions have been made in many parts of the country and improved transportation facilities are planned.
A strike of 1,200 produce handlers that has affected the city's fresh fruit and vegetable supply went into its fifth day today with negotiators still deadlocked on wage issues.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -Baldwin B. Bane retired today as executive adviser to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

With respect to the reported agreement in principle between the United States and Spanish military authorities giving the Roman Catholic Church the right to sanction or forbid marriages between United States citizens of mixed religions in Spain, it appears that these are statements of fact:
This will be a year of business stability, with the gross national product up about 3 per cent, it was predicted yesterday by Leo Cherne, executive director of the Research Institute of America.

Ocean freight rates in the Japan-United States trade have climbed to the point where ship operators can cover costs and even start using the profit side of the ledger. They had dropped through the bottom a year ago as the result of a rate war.

"Kiddie rides" must not invade the city's retail districts, the City Planning Commission decided yesterday. In another action, the commission came to the conclusion that the used car lot was here to stay.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, despite a thirty-month layoff, knocked out Joe Rindone in the sixth round tonight to touch off a comback campaign aimed at regaining the middleweight title he gave up voluntarily in 1952.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, will reintroduce tomorrow his controversial amendment on the President's treaty-making powers.
Trailerships, Inc., which operates the Hudson River truck trailer service between Albany and New York, is considering the addition of two such services between this city and New England ports.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Following is the text of an exchange of correspondence between President Eisenhower and Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, on a ceiling for the Armed Forces:

William Kaufman, builder and developer, has purchased the fee to the blockfront on the east side of Third Avenue, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, where he plans to break ground next Monday for the construction of a twenty-story office building. He had leased the sitc in 1952 for eighty-nine years.
A 40-year-old woman choir singer, crippled in both arms since birth, was found murdered yesterday morning in a Queens back yard.
Nearly 1,000 business and professional men and volunteer workers attended a Dawn Patrol Breakfast yesterday to open the 1955 campaign for the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- The directors of the country's farm cooperatives were urged today to work more aggresively for new foreign markets.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Light to heavy rainfall in the Southwest drought areas was largely responsible for a weak trend in wheat prices today. The market was off as much as 2 1/4 cents at one time. But there was commission absorption on the setbacks, and with the corn market strong there was a partial recovery which, however, failed to hold.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower will go to Capitol Hill tomorrow to deliver his State of the Union Message.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Representative Martin Dies, Democrat of Texas, who headed the Un-American Activities Committee for seven stormy years, is again looking for a seat with the investigating group.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- West Germany has begun a campaign to consolidate its post-war economic miracle during the new year.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved in a moderate range yesterday, and active months lost 1 to 6 points.
The first four patients entered yesterday the city's new center for care of persons with chronic diseases that make breathing difficult. It is at the Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island.

With elections scheduled for the end of February, Premier Hatoyama has launched his election campaign on a platform of a more "independent" national policy which would seek to "normalize" relations with Communist China and Soviet Russia but continue close collaboration with the United States in matters of defense.

Daniza Ilitsch, Yugoslav-born soprano who made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera in 1947 as Desdemona and remained with the company two seasons, returned to Town Hall for a song recital last evening.
The long molded torso silhouette has influenced bridal designs as well as other branches of fashion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Democratic Eighty-fourth Congress convened today with leadership pledges to avoid harsh partisanship against the Eisenhower Administration.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- The two top stars in the twenty-eighth annual Dixie tennis tournament went into action today and eliminated lesser-known players with little trouble.
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley agreed yesterday to end the three-hour limit for doctors' parking near hospitals.
Support of the March of Dimes of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis has been expressed by national defense leaders, including Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.

HONG KONG, Jan. 5 -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, arrived in Peiping today. His mission is to seek the release of United Nations prisoners of the Korean war, including eleven United States fliers imprisoned as spies by Communist China.
The Transit Authority pleaded not guilty yesterday to Mayor Wagner's charge that it spends too little time on the job, and even less consulting with city officials.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Democratic legislators introduced today a bill that would remove the criminal penalties for playing bingo.

The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that it had completed preliminary negotiations with three other major metals mining concerns for the joint financing of the $200,000,000 Toquepala copper project in southern Peru.
Dock workers voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify a contract designed to bring two years of labor peace to the strike-swept waterfront.
AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 5 -- Edmund S. Muskie was assured today of the "same degree of cooperation as we would give to a Governor of our own party."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Post Prandial and Expletive, coupled as the Mrs. Louis Lazare entry, finished one, three in the feature at Tropical Park today. The pair was split at the wire by Mrs. Charles Silvers' Ruthred.

Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries had slightly lower earnings for the quarter through November than for the similar 1953 period, the report of the distilling company disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- The twelve Federal Reserve Banks earned $438,000,000 last year, or $75,000,000 less than in 1953, according to preliminary figures reported today by the Reserve System's Board of Governors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- The International Monetary Fund today announced it had expelled Czechoslovakia as a member, effective last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today plans to give 349,000 Reservists and Air Guardsmen specific assignments in advance. This would permit them to start defending America within two or three hours in the event of an enemy attack.

Liberty Hyde Bailey has passed on, as John Muir passed forty years ago, into that "choir invisible, whose music is the gladness of the world" The news of his death at 96 years comes along with the report of Dr. Oppenheimer's remarks at the Columbia University Bicentennial -- remarks so true, so sad and so illuminated, concerning the profound and strange transition which includes us all.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- The Rev. Charles G. Maloney has been appointed by Pope Pius XII to be Titular Bishop of Capsa and Auxiliary to Archbishop John A. Floersh of the Archdiocese of Louisville, Ky.
A sharp increase this year in sales of furniture on time was forecast yesterday by Sidney Feuchtwanger.

An increase of 2,306,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 157,228,000 barrels, compared with 154,922,000 a week earlier and 158,027,000 a year earlier.

A large delegation of friends and well wishers boarded the French liner Ile de France yesterday morning to bid farewell to Henri Bonnet, for the last ten years France's Ambassador to the United States.
Merger of the A. M. Byers Company and the Erie Forge and Steel corporation was approved by directors of the companies yesterday, subject to approval by stockholders at meetings to be called promptly.

TEANECK, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Students at Fairleigh Dickinson College here had an unusual chance today to take part in a big business operation. They opened and voted on the bids for the construction of a $325,000 dormitory.

Homemakers with restricted finances and traditional tastes may find just the dining and bedroom furniture they have been looking for in a new group of colonial and Early American pieces now at Gimbels.

Three young women who will be introduced formally at the twenty-second annual Polka Ball will be the guests of honor at a reception to be held tonight at the Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street. The ball will be held tomorrow night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Wolf Ladejinsky was cleared as a security risk today and hired by the Foreign Operations Administration for a key Far Eastern post in the fight against communism.
PARIS, Jan. 5 -- The French Government is expected to propose presently a gradual centralization of the control of arms production on the Continent.
Since 1869 the American Museum of Natural History has been compiling a photographic record of many phases of its activities at home and in the field.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- The Senate Government Operations Committee ordered a test case today against a witness who had invoked the Fifth Amendment.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- Bryna Productions, an independent company organized in 1950 by Kirk Douglas, the actor, is about to become active as a producing unit under a six-picture contract negotiated with United Artists. The latter, it is understood will provide part of the financing and participate in future profits.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Sales of most major appliances in 1955, excluding radios and television receivers, will increase 3 to 30 per cent over last year, industry executives predicted today.

ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Cornell put on a late surge to defeat Columbia tonight, 69 -- 55, and remain unbeaten in three games at the top of the Ivy Basketball League. The loss was Columbia's first in two league games.
Surely among the fine leaders in the Girl Scouts of America are many who must resent deeply the base abnegation of the publishers of the new Handbook.
Kid Gavilan, the former welterweight champion of the world, yesterday removed himself as an obstacle to a proposed 147-pound title match.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 (UP) -- The professionals served notice today that they were in shape to tear the Inglewood Country Club course apart tomorrow when the twenty-ninth annual Los Angeles open golf tournament gets under way.
Statistics and steaks are two main interests of William H. Chartener.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Navy's basketball team ended a four-game losing streak today by trouncing William and Mary, 77 -- 56.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower's recommendations for a liberal foreign trade program received top billing today in the new Congress.

HENRY RUSSELL SANDERS of U. C. L. A. will be formally inducted into office as Coach of the Year at Leone's Restaurant tonight, but there's one odd aspect to his landslide election by his fellow football coaches. Almost all of them are devotees of the T-formation. Red Sanders, however, is an old-fashioned guy who prefers to use the old-fashioned single wing. He did pretty well with it, too.

One of the nation's largest independent operating utilities, the $550,000,000 West Penn Electric Company, announced yesterday that the directors had approved a 2-for-1 split of the common stock. West Penn provides service in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia and Ohio.

ALTHOUGH Harvey Swados has a rather desperate tendency to write at the top of his voice, his first novel, "Out Went the Candle,"* shows that he will in due course learn to control the unthrottled eloquence. His reach-of-living themes still exceed his grasp. That is a good fault in beginning novelists.

Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, informed the board of directors yesterday that net income in 1954 was "about $9,000,000 before sinking fund reserves and including substantial year-end credits."
Vassily Smyslov of Russia won his seventh-round match in the international tournament at the annual chess congress in Hastings yesterday, according to a report from London.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower proposed tonight in a letter to Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, to reduce the strength of the armed forces, but not so steeply, as Mr. Wilson had announced on Dec. 20.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- A House Labor subcommittee said today that union officials, insurance concerns and trustees had engaged in a "wide range of questionable practices" in the administration of union welfare funds.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Sir Anthony Eden, Britain's Foreign Secretary, will visit Asian capitals next month, but not Peiping.

Commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges despite the break in prices on the stock exchange. Volume improved in most markets, Cottonseed oil registered the second largest number of trades in more than a year.
The American Football Coaches Association took a strong stand yesterday in favor of extending the period for spring practice.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Oregon's new Democratic Senator. Richard M. Neuberger, called tonight for an end to "character assassination" in American political campaigning.

LAUREL HOLLOW, L. I., Jan. 5 -- The Oyster Bay Town Board, invoking a special law for Nassau County, denied yesterday a petition for this tiny North Shore village to annex a community of 225 residents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Major John J. McManus has asked the Army to restore him to active duty, pleading he was having difficulty in earning a living because he had signed the honorable discharge of the controversial Major Irving Peress.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Saudi Arabia complained to the Security Council today that "ruthless military operations" by France against Algerian nationalists were a threat to peace.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- "The old malarky about one person's taste being as good as another's is completely false," according to Miss Bernice Fitz-Gibbon.

ZERMATT, Switzerland, Jan 5 (AP) -- Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, who was ousted as President of Guatemala in an anti-Communist revolt last summer, announced today he was negotiating with Swiss authorities for recognition of his Swiss citizenship.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 5 -- The Nationalist Government of Tunisia is under increasing pressure from extremist factions to take in intransigent position on home rule.

A $300-$400 decrease in the selling price here of 1955 Willys passenger cars and a $35 cut on the Kaiser Manhattan four-door sedan were announced yesterday by the Kaiser-Willys sales division of Willys Motors, Inc.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 5 -- The Cabinet approved today a Presidential decree declaring a state of siege in nine East Indonesian islands. The action was motivated by insurgent activity that has been going on sporadically in the islands for several years and recently increased in intensity.

Nearly 2,500,000 persons have paid a total of $2,200,000 in fifty-seven theatres to see Walt Disney's "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea" during the first nine days of its nation-wide release, according to the producer's representatives. . . . "The Country Girl" ended its third week last night at the Criterion with a gross of $68,900, the largest weekly take in the history of the theatre, according to Paramount Pictures.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Governor Harriman told the Legislature in his first annual message today that the state was in a "serious fiscal position."
THE average farmer, with a larger stake than the sportsman, has an equal interest in the future of public hunting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Foreign Operations Administration has authorized South Vietnam to spend its foreign-aid money anywhere in the world. Normally recipients of assistance are required to allot most of their procurements to the United States.

Now that the Big Market of 1954 is history, the experts are using everything from an abacus to an electronic computer to find how big it was and where it was biggest. Measurements were so manifold yesterday that one could take his choice almost without paying his money.
Details of two major advertising campaigns were announced yesterday:
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Following is the prepared text of Governor Harriman's Annual Message to the Legislature, delivered at a joint session here today:
PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France obtained today Cabinet approval for abolition of the present system of voting by proportional representation.
HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Jan. 5 -- Business enterprises in Communist-held North Vietnam are being given firm directives to orient their activity toward meeting the "needs of the people."

The City Council delayed action yesterday to help preserve the night broadcasting privilege held since 1943 by WNYC, the city radio station. The delay was occasioned by a last-minute objection by Joseph T. Sharkey, Vice Chairman of the Council.

Fordham University's basketball team staved off a late drive by St. Francis College to defeat its interborough rival, 64 -- 59, last night. About 900 fans watched the game in the Ram's gymnasium in the Bronx.

The Chicago Black Hawks continued to pick on the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The National Hockey League cellar dwellers subdued Coach Muzz Patrick's Blues, 3 to 2, to the disappointment of a crowd of 5,249.

Violla Rubber and Alan Robinson, producing partners for the incoming comedy, "Put Them All Together," have taken on a second venture for the current theatrical season. It is a new play by Anne Walters called "The Day After Tomorrow" in which Eddie Dowling will be starred.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower joined members of his Cabinet and Congress today in a service of Intercession and Holy Communion marking the convening of the new Congress.
Demolition is under way on three sites in the midtown area that are to be improved with new buildings. Two are on the Avenue of the Americas and the third is at 3 East Fifty-fourth Street.
The port's tugboat workers yesterday sought National Labor Relations Board certification for their switch of affiliation from District 50, United Mine Workers, to the American Federation of Labor.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Joseph F. Carlino, 37-year-old Nassau County Republican, was chosen today as majority leader of the Assembly.

The frugal fare that may become almost a financial necessity after the extravagant expenditures of the holidays need not be dull. Even beans and rice, staple foods for the thrifty the world around, may be presented with dash.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Centers George Scragg and George Hackl scored two goals apiece as Princeton University's hockey team downed Providence College, 6 -- 1, at Baker Rink to- night to even its season's record at three victories and three de- feats.
The Federal Reserve Board has put the financial community and the public on notice that it is not entirely happy about the present unwonted speculative activity in the nation's security markets.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Governor Harriman went on record today as having a financial interest in Brown Brothers Harriman Co.

SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia, Jan. 5 (UP) -- A large crowd cheered and cannon boomed a twenty-one-gun salute today as the Presidents of Bolivia and Brazil dedicated the Corumba-Santa Cruz railway [heavy line on map denoted by cross].
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith won vociferous support from 500 New Jersey Republicans today when he called for the re-election of President Eisenhower next year.

The Dodgers yesterday came up with their tenth and eleventh contract signers for the 1955 season. One was Joe Black, who, being a resident of Brooklyn, brought his pact in personally. The other contract was mailed from Crestline, Ohio, by Ed Roebuck.
The National City Bank expects 1955 to be more active and more competitive for business than 1954 was.
GENEVA, Jan. 5 -- The United States has informed other participants in the Geneva trade conference that it is prepared to accept limits on its freedom to subsidize exports of farm products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Washington's biennial pageant of political courtliness, otherwise known as the opening of Congress, suffused the Capitol today with a rare spirit of sweet charity and brotherly love.

A bronze head of Albert Einstein was presented to City College yesterday afternoon. The presentation commemorated Dr. Einstein's visit to the college in 1921, when he delivered his first series of lectures in this country on the theory of relativity.
A former master sergeant was convicted yesterday of extorting $4,000 from the father of a soldier overseas. The ex-sergeant had threatend that the soldier "won't return" unless the money was paid.
On the heels of the increase in margins ordered by Washington, the stock market yesterday took its worst beating since June 26, 1950, the day after the start of the Korean war.

George H. Hallett's objection to your editorial of Dec. 2 re parking for physicians' cars misses the point entirely. The executive secretary of the Citizens Union seems to feel that permitting doctors to park on the public highways is a special privilege granted for the benefit of the medical profession, whereas the editorial clearly pointed out that it is purely in the interest of the people served by the doctors, to wit, the general public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 29:
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru issued today a strong word of confidence that the bitter controversies dividing India and Pakistan would be settled.

The public hearings on an appear from the suspensions of eight drivers and the president of the Standardbred Horsemen's Association entered the final stages yesterday. State Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan conducted yesterday's session at the commission offices, 745 Fifth Avenue.
