BELGRADE, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Both Borba and Politika, Yugoslavia's two largest newspapers, denounced as an "invention" an nounced as an "invention" an Associated Press dispatch from Calcutta Monday in which Col. Gen. Koca Popovic, Yugoslav Foreign Secretary, was quoted as saying the action against M. Dedijer had been undertaken without consulting President Tito.
HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 4 -- This area, the subject of dispute between Indonesia and the Netherlands, is a friends to no man.

Several gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday were sent as tributes to persons who devoted themselves to the service of others. The gifts were among ninety-nine, totaling $2,678.25, that raised the total receipts to date to $384,332.68.

When the freighter Mormackite capsized in the Atlantic last October the families of the lost thirty-seven seamen asked a reasonable question: Why isn't there a law or a regulation requiring a ship to report by radio once a day? The men lost on the Mormackite and the few who survived were drifting and fighting sharks for several days before the search for them was even started.

The Manufacturers Trust Company has leased the third and fourth floors and part of the second floor in the twelve-story building at 44 Beaver Street where the twelfth floor now is occupied by its central note teller department.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Hog receipts again fell short of expectations today and butchers sold strong to 25 cents higher. Sows rose about 25 cents. Receipts of hogs were 3,000 below the advance estimate.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Stock prices rose here today with hopes that a railway strike would be averted.

HARTFORD, Jan. 5 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff was sworn in today as Governor of Connecticut. The inauguration was preceded by a ceremonial parade patterned on Colonial custom. The 4year-old Democrat seemed so preoccupied with the importance of the event that he could only occasionally and with effort muster a few fleeting smiles as he rode to the Capitol.
Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell will fly here this afternoon to help assure a peaceful reception for the peacemaker he chose to iron out labor disputes in the municipal transit system.
The congregations of many Eastern Orthodox churches will attend Christmas Eve services tonight and celebrate Christmas for three additional days. Tomorrow is Dec. 25 in the Julian calendar.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- Diaries that the late French novelist Romain Rolland bequeathed to the Lenin Library in Moscow in sealed packets were opened on New Year's Day, in accordance with his written instructions, the Moscow radio announced tonight.
Food distributors, criticized by farmers and consumers alike, were urged yesterday to improve their relations with the public.

In its thirty-fifth year as one of the nation's leading international radiotelegraph companies, R. C. A. Communications, Inc., processed more than 6,600,000 overseas messages, Thompson H. Mitchell, president, reported yesterday.

The fishing vessel Student Prince II, out of St. John, Nfld., reported last night by radio that she was sinking after being battered by an Atlantic store about 300 miles north of Bermuda, the Coast Guard here reported.

LONDON, Jan 5 -- A court of inquiry urged the National Union of Railwaymen to call off the nation-wide strike it has ordered for midnight Sunday. The union was also advised by the Government-appointed board to resume negotiations with the British Transport Commission.
The writer is only one of the many who have been impressed by the tenor and timing of the editorial entitled "The Capital Gains Tax" in The New York Times of Dec. 29.

Your recent editorial "Bipartisanship With Meaning" observes that "the indications from Washington are that a genuine era of bipartisan cooperation in the fields of foreign affairs and national defense may be commencing." You underline a significant aspect of our electoral system and its responsiveness to the needs of the nation.
The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that it had completed a mass clean-up of passenger equipment.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Governor Harriman ended a patronage dispute today by nominating Goodman Alexander Sarachan of Rochester as a Supreme Court justice in the Seventh Judicial District.

Yellow will be the predominating color for spring hats and their brims will range from large to small, judging from the Millinery Stabilization Commission's show yesterday at the Sheraton Astor Hotel. The commission is an organization composed of the 600 custom designers and manufacturers in the New York metropolitan area.

Averell Harriman's first annual message as Governor of New York is in large part constructive, offers a considerable number of proposals upon which reasonable men should be able to agree, and suggests that the plunge into new policy under a Democratic administration will be cautious rather than reckless.
The 1955 Hudson cars, offering a choice of engines and over-all styling changes, were announced yesterday by the Hudson motor division, American Motors Corporation.
MOSCOW, Jan. 5 -- A one-year agreement for the resumption of regular trade between Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union was signed here today.
A three - member fact - finding panel was named yesterday to formulate recommendations for ending the five-day strike of 1,200 produce handlers and truckmen.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 5 -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. announced today the establishment of a fund of $291,000 for grants to universities and colleges to help improve the teaching of science and mathematics.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 -- The East-West struggle for political position in Asia is turning into an economic battle, with India as a testing ground. Dry words like credit, rates of interest, production capacity have become charged with political importance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The freshly convened House of Representatives heard its Speaker put things on the line within two minutes after his election today.

A five-story apartment building housing twenty families and occupying a plot 50 by 100 feet at 261 East 188th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by an investing client of Paul Green, attorney, for cash over mortgages amounting to $43,500.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
Maxwell Anderson is writing the book for a ninety-minute musical play for television that will, in effect, be a preview of a lengthier Broadway stage play to be presented next fall.
Israel's determination to consolidate her position as a democratic nation despite the tensions in the Middle East was reiterated last night by her Ambassador.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Department of Commerce urged the apparel trade today to standardize size measurements of women's clothes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley said today United States diplomats overseas felt that weak state Department leadership and the Administration's security program had hurt foreign service morale.
IN PROSPECT, Jan de Hartog's "The Fourposter" seemed like too small a play for the big City Center. It contains only two characters and the City Center seats 3,000 people.

The Metropolitan Opera Association and Columbia Records announced yesterday the termination of a recording contract, made in 1947, which had given to Columbia the exclusive right to bill its operatic recordings "Metropolitan Opera productions."

Milliner Irene has produced a truly light-headed feeling in her spring collection that features organdy, sheer horsehair and featherweight linen straw as hat materials. The new designs were displayed yesterday in her showroom, 16 East Fifty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Herbert Hoover asked Congress today to extend President Eisenhower's reorganization powers.
Professional football came under fire yesterday at the forty-ninth convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association at the Hotel New Yorker.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Conflicts between state officials and three Essex County communities along the Garden State Parkway appeared close to settlement today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower gave a political boost today to a Republican Congressional hopeful from Florida.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer celebrated his seventy-ninth birthday today, surrounded by political friends but shunned by political opponents.
Ernest A. Gross, former Deputy United States Representative to the United Nations, was elected chairman of the Department of International Affairs of the National Council of Churches yesterday.

The 16-18 East Fifty-third Street Corporation has sold the two fifteen and eight story office buildings on plot 65 by 100 feet at that address to Hugh K. McGovern and Louis Denberg in a deal negotiated by Malcolm Smith of H. Clayton Smith Co., broker. Howard Geoghegan arranged a new first mortgage of $700,000 with a savings bank.

HONOLULU, Jan. 5 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford said today a blockade of Communist China's coast "would be an act of war." The Chairman of the Joint Chief of Staff thus supported the Administration's stand on the issue.
Mayor Wagner will discuss today with his colleagues on the Board of Estimate the 1955-56 fiscal program he plans to submit to the Legislature later this month.

There is something special about Konrad Adenauer's birthday this year. He was 79 yesterday. It is not like the rounding out of a decade, as was the case with Sir Winston Churchill's eightieth birthday on Nov. 30, but there has in recent months been an especially keen recognition of the fact that an enormous burden rests on the Chancellor's shoulders.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Two Federal bureaus will cooperate in the first census of the nation's mineral industries to be taken in fifteen years, it was announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Net operating earnings of Philadelphia banks showed a 6 per cent increase in 1954, although earnings before taxes were unchanged.
California borrowed $60,000,000 yesterday to help veterans finance the purchase of homes and farms.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The clearance of Wolf Ladejinsky today may mark a turning point in the Administration's controversial security program.
RUGGIERO RICCI gave a remarkable, indeed an extremely impressive violin recital last night in Carnegie Hall. His career has been a strange one.
Profits from the sale of securities enabled the Chase National Bank to increase its net earnings 34 per cent last year.

One glance at the "design" for the proposed redevelopment of the Baxter and Worth Streets area as shown in The New York Times of Dec. 30 and I knew that the end had come for Chinatown. The proposed buildings, by an architect whose name was not disclosed, are supposed to "retain Chinese influence."

The new dull Dacron polyester yarn that E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., will start producing commercially on Monday has been developed into an adaptable tricot knit fabric for the women's undergarment, blouse and children's dress trades.

BALBOA, C. Z., Jan. 5 -- A United States citizen is being held by Panama's secret police investigating the assassination of President Jose Antonio Remon. He is Irving Martin Lipstein, 34, a teacher, who was born in New York.
The resort and travel collection presented by B. Altman this week emphasized tweed coats and suits and fluffy but packable evening styles.

Now that the mid-winter social season for certain younger members of the family is, for the most part, over -- being elbowed out of the way by the resumption of home work -- it can be said that a number of things have been learned that may come in handy another day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- House investigators charged today that the United States Government had been bilked out of at least $1,000,000 in a tungsten scandal.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 5 -- The request of 50,000 Vietnamese refugees in Thailand to go to Communist - controlled North Vietnam if they may not remain here seems to have been granted.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 5 -- The Yugoslav press continued today its attacks on foreign newspapers. The main targets were foreign correspondents in Belgrade who were accused of distorting and exaggerating the Djilas-Dedijer case.

The six-story apartment house on lot 20 by 100 feet at 46 East Sixty-fifth Street has been sold by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pratt to an investor who plans to occupy the large triplex suite in the building. The house contains six apartments and was held at $155,000. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Eisenhower's call today for "positive, affirmative action now" on school construction was hailed on Capitol Hill as a change in Administration attitude.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- President Eisenhower's State of the Union message gave little reassurance to those Britons who were worried about the cut in the United States ground forces scheduled next year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- The San Francisco Mint will stop its coin making by June 30, and perhaps as early as March.
The owner of a three-story brownstone building in the Chelsea section of Manhattan is scheduled to appear in court today to answer a summons charging it with fifty housing violations.

The two Soviet players in the international tournament at the annual chess congress in Hastings, England, were again tied for first place as a result of play in the eighth and semi-final round, yesterday according to a report from London.
Pillsbury Mills, Inc., leading flour miller, sharply improved earnings in the six months ended Nov. 30.

THE New Year stock market's surge and retreat sent few audible or visible ripples just outside the exchanges and the brokerage offices. You wandered in vain for signs and signals of it in the financial district's narrow passes where mid-day is close kin to night.
Combining various eras of history and schools of art into a delightful pot-pourri of inspiration, Sally Victor has turned out another excellent spring millinery collection.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Dur-I ing the week ended yesterday,I the Federal Reserve Board re-I ported today, member bank re-I serves increased $333,000,000.

The merger of the American Woolen Company, Textron, Inc., and Robbins Mills, Inc., has entered its final phase. American Woolen and Textron mailed proxy statements to stockholders yesterday; Robbins' proxy statements will be mailed tomorrow.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Many of the fighters failed to show up tonight for a program in the Mechanics Building, but the fans, offered a chance to go home with their money, stayed on to watch the substitutes.

Department store business and profits improved in the third fiscal quarter of 1954 but not enough to carry them to the 1953 levels, according to a study released yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

President Eisenhower appealed yesterday to both of "our great parties" to support the objectives defined in his State of the Union message. There will be time later for a detailed consideration of these objectives, particularly when yesterday's message is supplemented by the additional messages which the President has promised to send.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- If this country's agricultural cooperatives expect to overcome higher operating costs and falling farm prices they must devote more effort to research and to the development of new markets.

The New York Knickerbockers stormed back with a second-half drive to defeat the Boston Celtics, 88 -- 83, in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden last night before 10,845 cheering fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- An office of Coordinator of Public Works was proposed today by President Eisenhower. In his Message on the State of the Union the President asserted that in times of threatened economic setback public works might prove a valuable sustaining force to the national economy.

REPORTS from the more frigid regions of New York and New England indicate that ice fishing is undergoing something of a revival, with many lakes reporting the presence of more ice shanties than have been seen in years.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture report on today's livestock markets follows:

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France left by air today for Italy. He planned a few days' rest before his talks with Premier Mario Scelba and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino next week in Rome.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Herbert Morrison, better-known as "our Erbert," to his London constituents, married a Lancashire business woman today.
A high official of the Girl Scouts of the U. S. A. declared yesterday that revisions of the organization's handbook did not indicate any shift in policies.

Now that Safe Driving Day has turned out to be something less than a complete success, perhaps the nation is ready for "Safe Auto Day." A letter from a reader recently appearing on this page alleged that the time had come "to evaluate the responsibility of the automobile manufacturer for the frightful slaughter on our highways."

BERLIN, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The East German Government said today it would no longer exercise tight central control over all industry. The announcement said many factories would be permitted to use their own initiative in filling production quotas.
LAKE CHARLES, La., Jan. 6 (UP) -- The pilot of one of two B-47 Stratojet bombers that collided over the Gulf of Mexico said today the other plane apparently had smashed down on his craft from above.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- It was generally agreed today that Mrs. George W. Malone, wife of the Republican Senator from Nevada, walked out of a Congressional dinner last night during a speech by Senator Richard L. Neuberger, freshman Democrat from Oregon.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. made a personal appeal yesterday for care and caution in the use of kerosene heaters. He spoke at three places in Harlem, while other members of his department carried the same message to districts on the lower East Side and in Brooklyn and the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Eighty-fourth Congress received President Eisenhower's legislative recommendations today with a good deal of unexcited hospitality.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Eisenhower made the following major proposals to Congress today in his State of the Union Message:
Feminine as well as high-style designs were included in the Brigance of Sportsmaker resort collection presented by Lord Taylor yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

Employes at the Federal Building, New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, and Pan American World Airways workers there donated 188 pints of blood to the regional Red Cross blood program Wednesday.
Will domestic producers of copper, the red metal that is essential to our economy, hold their prices at 30 cents a pound?

Out-of-town donors were prominent among contributors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. They were among seventy-six who sent $1,326.22, raising the total receipts to date to $385,658.90 from 11,474 donors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The President's requests to Congress today for legislation were so numerous, and some so controversial, that if he feels it incumbent on him to see them through, and the greater part favorably, the two remaining years of his current term will hardly be time enough.

Prices of fresh fruits and vegetables are up this week. A strike of the city's produce handlers and truckmen has curtailed independent merchants' supplies. Chains, which have their own distribution systems, are not affected by the strike.
HOLLANDIA, Netherlands, New Guinea, Jan. 5 -- Indonesia and the Netherlands, which are disputing the sovereignty of this area, agree that the native Papuan should be master of his own fate.

The current interest in Oriental designs, fabrics, accessories and art for the home is pointed up by a large collection of colorful Japanese wood-block-prints at B. Altman. This group of prints is representative of this old art from 1760 to 1860.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 6 (UP) -- The commander of the United States naval base here has apologized to the Trindad Government for an incident involving two Cabinet Ministers, it was reported today.

Net earnings of the New York Central Railroad in 1954 were "substantially in excess of $5,000,000, and gross operating revenues were about $710,000,000," Alfred E. Perlman, president, said yesterday. In 1953 Central carried $34,002,039 of $825,348,776 of operating revenues through to net income.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 6 -- Sweden's imports from the dollar area, already liberalized by the Swedish Government's step last October to remove bars on a major part of such imports, are further facilitated with the new year.
Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, chairman of the Transit Authority, slammed the door yesterday on Michael J. Quill's demand for a 17-cent hourly wage rise for the agency's employes.
Moving from a 40-34 lead at the half, Manhattan's basketball team last night went on to a 95-70 victory over City College at the Jaspers' Bronx gymnasium.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem said today the signing of the French-Indochinese agreements giving South Vietnam complete control of her economy "consecrates the real independence of the country."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The British boast that their Parliament has "a sense of occasion." This is a way of saying that Parliament, on its "big days," performs with a dignity, splendor and pagentry consistent with its rich and ancient tradition.
The chairman of the National Collegiate Basketball Committee yesterday said it would be "impossible" for college basketball players to take part in the Pan- American Games this year.
A 52-year-old grocer was beaten unconscious with a soda bottle yesterday. Fifteen minutes later a suspect was captured by a patrolman in a subway train.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The National Union of Railwaymen agreed tonight to "suspend" the nation-wide strike it had ordered for midnight Sunday.
WASHINGTON,. Jan. 6 (AP) -- The nation's best known amateur painter put in a plug today for all the arts.
Football coaches gathered here from colleges the country over did honor to Henry (Red) Sanders of U. C. L. A. last night at Leone's Restaurant.
The business of collecting baseball contracts continued to move at a brisk pace yesterday. The Yankees and Dodgers each had an important signer.

Arno H. Johnson, vice president and research director of the J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising agency, told the New York Credit and Financial Management Association yesterday that American production ability and purchasing power should provide in the next eighteen months a 10 per cent increase in sales, and by 1960 a third higher standard of living in the United States.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- The British Orient Line, which began a successful passenger run between North America and Australia last year, is planning to bid for round-the-world business.
Vibrant colors and unusual fabrics are highlighted in the collection gathered for Gimbels' cruise shop, which opens Monday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Public hearings to determine causes of the recent spectacular rise in the stock market were tentatively projected today by Senator J. William Fulbright.
The New York Academy of Medicine is becoming more and more an agency for the improvement of public health and welfare in the community, its new president said last night.

The United States Trust Company of New York reported as of Dec. 31, 1954, total deposits of $158,319,485 and total assets of $194,960,034, compared, respectively, with $139,132,647 and $174,534,865 on Sept. 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $30,691,607 against $27,323,048; holdings of United States Government securities to $81,643,494 against $74,154,187; and loans and discounts to $59,489,071 against $51,537,535.

Earning assets of New York commercial banks declined $346,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, despite the fact that a new high was registered for loans to brokers and dealers for carrying other than Treasury securities.
Independent milk dealers reported yesterday that a union leader had warned them that they would face strikes if they attempted to increase the milk loads on their trucks.

Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate agreed yesterday that $100,000,000 of new revenue would be needed to run the city properly in 1955-56. This amount will be needed, they held, even after allowing for savings and economies.

The building manager of a real estate concern and his chief guard were robbed of a $4,115 payroll yesterday by a gunman who was waiting for them in their office on the twenty-seventh floor of the 165 Broadway Building.
The nation's Eastern railroads and the big interstate trucking lines that operate east of the Mississippi have organized a joint policy board to study common problems and reconcile differences.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 6 -- French-German relations will enter a new phase when Premier Pierre Mendes-France and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer meet in Baden Baden Jan. 14.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked the Senate today to give "early and favorable consideration" to the mutual defense treaty between the United States and Nationalist China.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Robert T. Stevens, the Secretary of the Army, will resign just as soon as President Eisenhower has found a successor.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Bo Wininger of Oklahoma City, shaking off the handicap of rain, cold and gusty winds, shot a three-under-par 68 today to take the first-round lead in the $32,500 Los Angeles open golf tournament.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's Message on the State of the Union before a joint session of Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

CAIRO, Jan. 6 -- The leaders of Egypt's successful army revolution have ordered compensation paid to the heirs of an army colonel punished seventy-two years ago for leading an army uprising that failed.

" San Pietro," John Huston's documentary of World War II, will be featured Jan. 14 by Film Directions at the Hunter College Playhouse on a program called "Government and the Film." Also to be shown by the society, 30 Fifth Avenue, are the United Nations film, "Crossroads of Life;" "The Romance of Transportation," an animated cartoon from Canada, and the British-made documentary on Ceylon, "Waters of Life."

FOR some years now it has been my pleasure and my duty to report in this space that another fine historical novel is available. Literary snobs, who refuse to believe that all modern historical novels aren't so bad as most of them undoubtedly are, remain ignorant of the distinguished work being done in this field. Uncritical readers, who delight in the massproduced nonsense that is the most reliable of fictional staples, are not interested.
Douglas M. Black, president of Doubleday Co., received yesterday the Carey-Thomas Award on behalf of his concern's Anchor Series of paper books in general nonfiction,
Arthur Stark, executive director of the State Mediation Board, was installed yesterday as impartial adviser in disputes between the Transit Autority and Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, has purchased the Hampton Apartments at Parsons Boulevard and Sanford Avenue in Flushing, Queens, from the Jane Allison Company. The four-story garden type building occupies a plot 178 by 173 feet and contains fifty-eight apartments. The property is assessed at $265,000. Williams Co. were the brokers and E. Louis Gothelf was attorney for the buyer.
New model rooms at Bloomingdales have color schemes based on shades of blue.

The Police Department started distribution yesterday of crime prevention leaflets, entitled "Tips to the Ladies." The paper, prepared for mothers and housewives, contains a number of precautionary measures to protect the home, children and automobiles.
Columbia University's School of Medicine has received $830,000 toward the $1,250,000 goal of its two-year fund drive.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today its first bill of the session.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 6 -- Premier Adnan Menderes arrived here today on an official visit. The purpose of his trip is to align Iraq with Turkey in a new Middle Eastern security system.

The criticism by the Board of Water Supply of your excellent editorial recommending a final study of the upper Hudson River as a future source of water supply before proceeding with the extravagant and illusory Cannonsville project is without merit.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Jan. 6 -- Theodore Griffin went back today to his job as civilian Air Force inspector for the Government, from which he had been suspended last August as a "security risk."

DETROIT, Jan. 6 -- A new color microscope-television camera that can transmit microscopic studies over a closed circuit between laboratories has been developed by the research groups of three corporations.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Immense, a consistent 4-year-old son of Brookfield, raced to an impressive victory in the featured seventh race at Tropical Park today. It was the colt's third victory in six starts at the meeting.

MOBILE Ala., Jan. 6 (AP) -- The North coach, Paul Brown, seeking his fourth straight Senior Bowl victory, and Coach Steve Owen of the favored South team sent their squads through brisk workouts today to wind up heavy work for Saturday's football contest.
Figures compiled by the Tobacco Tax Council disclose a decline of 5 per cent in cigarette sales in November
The chocolate industry curtailed its use of cocoa sharply last year because of the high price of raw beans.
A Federal judge upheld yesterday a union's right to maintain an "educational" picket line outside a plant in which a rival union held official certification as sole bargaining agent.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 6 (UP) -- In a seventy-one-game, five-set match, Vic Seixas of Philadelphia gained the final of the South Australian tennis championship today. He defeated Australia's Mervin Rose, 4 -- 6, 8 -- 10, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 10 -- 8.

Under date of Dec. 26 your Washington correspondent stated that a reorganization of the Republican party in the South was planned. As The Mississippi member of the Republican National Committee over a long period of years I was deeply interested in this article, since it saw fit to mention my name.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Canada made a strong plea today for United States cooperation in redrafting the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

" The Letters of W. B. Yeats," edited with an introduction and notes by Allan Wade, will be issued by Macmillan on Feb. 21. They cover "almost the whole of Yeats' working life," and include many that were not available to his biographers.

President Maurice Podoloff of the National Basketball Association said yesterday that players owed money by the defunct Baltimore team would be paid, either by the clubs they now represent or by any new owners of the Baltimore franchise.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 7 -- This was Christmas morning in Russia, and a cruel snow-laden wind blowing straight out of the pages of Russian history and literature whipped across roofs and through the frozen streets of Moscow.
R. C. A Victor will record excerpts next week from "Un Ballo in Maschera," which opens tonight at the Metropolitan Opera.

Control of the Franklin Trust Company of Paterson, N. J., will be sold at public auction on Jan. 21, according to William H. Dillistin, chairman of the trustees of the segregated assets of the trust company. Mr. Dillistin said that about 20,540 shares, and in any event not less than 20,000 of the outstanding 30,000 shares, will be offered in one lot to the highest bidder.

THE new situation comedy series called "Norby," which was filmed in color at Pearl River, N. Y., was off to an extremely wobbly start at 7 P. M. Wednesday over the National Broadcasting Company network.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- It took Senators fifty-nine minutes to introduce 166 bills for the new session of Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Labor leaders liked the foreign policy aspects of President Eisenhower's message today, but little else. His proposals for dealing with the domestic economy were condemned by them as inadequate or worse.
Net income of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway last year declined 17 per cent to $39,900,000 from $48,100,000 in 1953, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Eisenhower appealed today to the Democratic-controlled Congress for "unhesitating cooperation" with the Republican-controlled Executive branch in a common quest for peace, prosperity and freedom.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- Moscow's foreign diplomatic colony has received a new year's gift from the Soviet Government -- a substantial reduction in rents.
ROME, Jan. 6 -- Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier, arrived in Naples by air from Paris this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Senators Price Daniel, Democrat of Texas, and Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, said today a decision had been reached to order a Senate investigation of the case of Dr. Irving Peress.
BUFFALO, Jan. 6 (UP) -- An Air Force B-47 Stratojet bomber has set a new United States military record with a 21,000-mile nonstop trip lasting nearly two days.

As a frequent air commuter between New York and Washington I've been asked many times by cab drivers why they must pay 25 cents for each fare picked up at the airports under the control of the Port of New York Authority.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The furniture and appliance outlook for 1955 is bright despite such problems as the growth of discount houses, industry representatives said today.

Floyd Patterson, Brooklyn light heavyweight, and Willie Troy of Washington will clash in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The contest is slated for eight rounds, and is expected to draw one of the largest boxing crowds of the season to the Garden.

The Guaranty Trust Company earned an average interest return of 2.98 per cent on its commercial loans in 1954, according to the annual report of the bank mailed to stockholders yesterday. The 1954 return compared with 3.06 per cent in 1953.

Thousands of yellow roses transformed the main ballroom of the Plaza into a garden last night for the second annual Ball of the Roses, a dinner dance and entertainment under the auspices of the volunteer committee and board of trustees of Roosevelt Hospital. Proceeds will be used to assist in reducing the hospital's annual deficit. The Celanese Corporation of America was the sponsor of the fete.
The New York City Council of the National Jewish Welfare Board gave a luncheon yesterday in honor of Mrs. Jerome J. Hanauer.
HONG KONG, Jan. 6 -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, conferred today in Peiping with Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier.

MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (UP) -Goalie Jacques Plante registered his third shutout of the National Hockey League season as the Montreal Canadiens trounced the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 -- 0, before 14,324 fans at the Forum tonight. Plante had to handle only twenty shots.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, Off Wellington, New Zealand, Friday, Jan. 7 -- This United States Navy icebreaker sailed today for Antarctica, opening a period of exploration of one of the last unmapped egions of the earth.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association finds itself confronted with its most serious crisis since the demise in 1951 of the Sanity Code.
TOKYO, Jan. 6 -- Japan wants to end the state of war with the Soviet Union, Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 529,452 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 31,627 cars or 5.6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 51,647 cars or 10.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 33,505 cars or 6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today designated Chan Gurney as Acting Chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board. The action breaks an administrative logjam that has built up at the board since the new year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 6 -- Joshua Logan, director and co-producer of such Broadway hits as "Mister Roberts" and "South Pacific," signed today with Columbia to direct his first motion picture. This will be the studio's adaptation of "Picnic," the Pulitzer Prize play by William Inge.
Brief speeches marked the swearing-in yesterday of William J. O'Shea, lawyer, as a Manhattan member of the Board of Education.
The Furness liner Queen of Bermuda raced 150 miles off course yesterday morning to save the ten-man crew of a fishing boat.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Public Service Commission began an inquiry today to determine the adequacy of the minimum liability insurance required of truck operators.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 6 -- The official Government news agency Tanjug indicated today that Milovan Djilas and Vladimir Dedijer would get "deserved punishment" as instruments of alleged foreign intervention in Yugoslav affairs.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- An emphasis on surface treatment rather than structural form seems the most persistent trend at the wholesale home furnishings markets in progress here.
HONG KONG, Jan. 6 -- A move by the Soviet Union's delegate to seat Communist China in a tradepromotion conference sponsored here by the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East failed today.

An adept actor, Eli Wallach doesn't mind demonstrating his versatility. Hailed for his performance as Sakini in the London reproduction of "The Teahouse of the August Moon," Mr. Wallach will relinquish the role to Dickie Henderson on Jan. 17.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Losses on pork operations lowered net income of Armour Co. in the fiscal year ended Oct. 30 to $1,557,092 from $10,339,164 in the preceding twelve months, F. W. Specht, chairman and president, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A new drive to impose rules of fair conduct on Congressional investigations got under way today.
AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 6 -- Edmund Sixtus Muskie took the oath of office today as the fifty-sixth Governor of Maine. He is the first Democrat elected to the position in twenty years.
Two big breaks developed yesterday in the employer front in the six-day-old strike of fresh fruit and vegetable handlers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- A former Government employe denied today that there had been any "irregularities" in a Thailand tungsten program criticized by a House subcommittee.
PANAMA, Jan. 6 -- Irving Martin Lipstein of Brooklyn denied today, according to a Panama secret police spokesman, any participation in the assassination Sunday of President Jose Antonio Remon.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Republican legislative leaders violently disputed today Governor Harriman's assertion that the state was facing a financial crisis.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 6 (Reuters) -- The British high command announced today it would start its biggest mop-up operation against the Mau Mau, anti-white terrorist bands.
A fantastic story is being unfolded here of a fortune founded on a $200 promissory note given in the early 1800's by a struggling attorney for a New York farm.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Supreme Court was asked today to look at the Government's loyalty program "with hindsight" and find that it was constitutionally invalid.
The Royal Order of Vasa Knighthood was conferred on Emmet J. McCormack yesterday at a ceremony aboard the Swedish American liner Kungsholm.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- An upstate Republican and a Brooklyn Democrat called today for a state investigation of religious and racial discrimination in housing.
Houston, Tex., announced plans yesterday to borrow $15,000,000 in the public market on March 4, for its Independent School District.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Arthur Godfrey, radio and television entertainer, was one of the guests of President Eisenhower at a stag dinner tonight.
The first two permanent sites around New York for Nike anti-aircraft guided missile batteries will be in limited operational readiness within about one month.

BARODA, India, Jan. 5 -- Dr. B. H. Bhabha, director of the Indian Government's atomic energy establishment, reviewed today the progress in exploiting monazite sands in Travancore Cochin for the production of atomic power.

The New York Shipping Association announced yesterday it would meet tomorrow with officials of the International Longshoremen's Association to put the new two-year waterfront peace pact into operation as soon as possible.

A billion dollars of funds set aside for pensions for public employes were invested in the bonds of corporations in 1954, according to a study issued yesterday by the Union Securities Corporation, investment banking house. These funds are set aside for pensions for teachers, firemen, policemen and civil servants.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Marty Pavelich scored an unassisted goal with a little more than four minutes remaining tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 3-3 tie with the Boston Bruins before 9,298 National Hockey League fans at Olympia.
PARIS, Jan. 6 -- In proposing the pooling of arms production in Western Europe, Premier Pierre Mendes-France has suggested a board having supranational status.
City College students took to the air yesterday in an effort to "strengthen the bond between students everywhere."

The shipping industry is disturbed by a persistent rumor that the boarding division of the Immigration Service is to be moved from Shipping Row in the lower Broadway area to the agency's headquarters at West Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue.
Stock sales mounted yesterday to their highest level since Hitler invaded Poland, as prices fell sharply again on the New York Stock Exchange.
Fines totaling $9,594,129 -- an increase of $2,021,486 over 1953 -- were collected in City Magistrates' Courts last year.

Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, one of the oldest settlement houses in the city, will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Desperate Hours" on the night of Feb. 14 at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

BAYONNE, N. J., Jan. 6 -- An underwater treasure of 14,460 live anti-aircraft shells, object of a Navy search since last March 7, was located by divers of the Navy's Salvage School here, nearly a month ago, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- India received permission today to buy a Super Constellation for use by Air India International on a new route into Communist China.
Skiers contemplating a trek to the northlands this week-end had good reason to show concern yesterday as rain visited metropolitan New York.

From forty to fifty colleges and organizations have requested film prints of Edward R. Murrow's televised interview with Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N. J.

ATHENS, Jan. 6 (Reuters) -The Greek Foreign Office issued a denial yesterday that Premier Alexander Papagos said on Dec. 15 that Greece's allies, including the United States, had "betrayed" Greece in the Cyprus dispute in the United Nations.

The Svenska Landslaget i Gymnastik has invaded the United States, but do not be alarmed. It's only a group of young men and women from Sweden, mostly blond, all slim and limber and all dedicated to gymnastics.
MIAMI, Jan. 6 (UP) -- High Gun and Determine, the leading money winners of 1954, drew top weight of 128 pounds today for the Feb. 19 running of the $100,000 Widener Handicap at Hialeah race course.
The Attorney General's 1952 list of known racketeers scheduled for deportation as undesirable aliens backfired yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- In a rare turf occurrence, two horses, Will Be There and Where Are We, owned by the same person, finished in a dead-heat for first in the feature at Tropical Park today.
Robert L. Graham has been appointed sales promotion coordinator of the Ford Instrument Company, a division of the Sperry Corporation.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Swarms of desert locusts that periodically invade British territory in Africa and the Middle East are being spotted by radar. The probable path of the swarms is plotted from Air Ministry offices and meteorological stations. Their advance warning is radioed to threatened regions so that measures can be taken to minimize the damage to crops.
Indications yesterdey were that the merger of the Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company would go through.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Represeintatives of domestic sugar producers -- both in and out of Congress -- disclosed today plans for a vigorous fight to win a greater share of the United States sugar market.
An increase of twenty-two State Supreme Court Justices in the New York metropolitan area was recommended yesterday by a State Bar Association committee.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 (AP) -- United States producers of cars and trucks opened 1955 by assembling 173,481 units this week, only 352 units short of the eighty-four-week record set in mid-December, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Farmers will have little reason to blame the flexible price support program if farm income drops during the coming year, the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, said today.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Concern over the West's prospects of completing the job of European unity and carrying out German rearmament is strong on the highest levels of the British Government.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 7 (UP) -- A group of business men concluded a deal today giving Columbus a baseball franchise in the International League, replacing the Red Bird club of the American Association.

HISTORY was made last night when Marian Anderson, the famous Negro contralto, as one of the fruits of her distinguished career, sang for the first time in the Metropolitan Opera House and for the first time in opera on any stage.
A new system of examining imported merchandise on the piers and assessing duties on it there, rather than having it trucked to the public stores, probably will be put in effect within a month or two.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner's salary negotiations with the Cleveland Indians, which excited the interest of Commissioner Ford Frick and some of baseball's best legal minds, ended today. The 33-year-old slugger accepted a "compromise reduction" of 25 per cent to about $50,000.

FOLLANSBEE, W. Va., Jan. 7 (UP) -- Housewives turned a steel mill into a banquet hall tonight and served a mammoth "victory" dinner for an Ohio millionaire who bought the mill to save the jobs of their men.

Louis Sachar, president of the Marshall Management Corporation, and Joseph Rosen have taken title to the thirteen-story and penthouse American Lithograph Building at 52 East Nineteenth Street which they bought recently from William Kaufman.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 7 -- A nine-month project to promote international understanding "emotionally" as well as intellectually has been started in this country by the Young Women's Christian Association.
The first major event of the 1955 indoor track and field season is scheduled for tonight. It's the annual championship carnival of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 7 -- Air pollution, in the opinion two experts here, will remain a major problem for at least ten to fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- A House Government Operations subcommittee accused the House Labor Committee today of failing to take an "obvious and fairly simple" move to protect union welfare funds against labor racketeers.
Some of the statements made by Robert Moses in his plan for the state's development of hydroelectric power at Niagara Falls were misleading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Democratic National Committee is privately circulating an analysis that attempts to tear to shreds much of President Eisenhower's Message to Congress on the State of the Union.

The case of Western New Guinea has been argued in the United Nations on a basis of Indonesian nationalism and its claim to take over this territory from Dutch administration. The United Nations did not accept the case for discussion. We believe that this decision was wise.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 7 -- The first International Assembly of Moslem Youth adjourned today.
ROME, Jan. 7 -- The United States and Italy signed an agreement today that will squeeze Iron Curtain countries out as suppliers of coal for Italy.

The New York blizzard of 1888 wafted from its long-spent fury some good for the city's less fortunate yesterday. It came to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in the form of a $500 contribution in the name of that big blow.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Republican and Democratic party chiefs traded charges today over whether the state faces a financial crisis.

With nothing to do between supper and midnight on New Year's Eve the head of the house stretched out on the living room sofa. He planned to lie there reading until the last few minutes of 1954, and then rise to whatever seemed fitting in the way of celebration.
Fluffy is no longer running around like a cat that has just swallowed a canary. The secret of the whereabouts of her litter, which had baffled some of the city's top investigative minds, is out.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Britain, carrying the second heaviest defense load in the free world, is engaged in a critical re-examination of her future defense program.
At refrigerated counters this week-end consumers will find both butter and eggs relatively low in cost. One chain is featuring butter at 65 cents a pound and large brown eggs at 47 cents a dozen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Democratic National Convention that will pick the party's next Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates has been set to open Aug. 27, 1956.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Defense Department reopened tonight the Peress case, completely clearing Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker in the promotion and discharge of the controversial dentist.

Today's new film is a Russian-made import, "The Emperor and the Golem," at the Stanley Theatre. The fantasy-comedy was produced in color by Slovak State Films under the direction of Martin Fric. It has a cast headed by Jan Weick in a dual role; Marie Vasova, Natasha Gollova and Jeri Plasky. Jan Werich and Jiri Brdeska wrote the original story, which Mr. Werich adapted. Artkino is distributing the offering, which has English titles.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams yesterday predicted a lower crime rate for the city a year from now. His prediction was based on the release of 1,200 to 1,500 patrolmen for active patrol by the school-crossing guard program.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Paced by two rookies, Paul Pettit and Frank Selvy, the Milwaukee Hawks defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 85 -- 75, tonight in a National Basketball Asosciation game before 3,500 fans.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Two of the lesser known professionals, Gardner Dickinson of St. Andrews, Ill., and Eric Monti of Los Angeles, swept into the lead at the midway mark of the $32,500 Los Angeles open today. They had 36-hole scores of 136.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Jan. 7 -- Australia is conducting the most extensive exploration in Antarctica. But the three-year program of the United States, which got under way with departure of this ship from New Zealand for Little America today, will ultimately be on a far larger scale.
Ray Eliot of Illinois was elected president of the American Football Coaches Association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today announced details of the way prices of "pulled" wool will be supported under the new Wool Act. The Department already has set up an incentive price plan to give cash payments to producers of shorn wool.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Three indictments against Manuel E. Kulukundis of New York, shipping magnate, were dismissed in Federal court today.

The figures on traffic fatalities over the Christmas and New Year's week-ends are finally in, and grim figures they are -- 687 persons killed in automobile accidents throughout the nation, 392 over the Christmas week-end and 295 over the New Year's week-end.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 7 -- The Central African Federation is having serious trouble in its copper and tobacco industries, which supply most of its revenue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The dismissal of John Paton Davies Jr. after twenty-three years as a career diplomat was "more drastic and cruel" than his own forced retirement, John Carter Vincent said today.
Men on both sides of the law will give blood today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
HONG KONG, Jan. 7 -- A "remarkable improvement" in Japan's balance of payments position was reported today.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Dr. Albert Schweitzer, Nobel Prize winner and noted humanitarian, has fled from his native village of Gunsbach in Alsace to his hospital in Africa to avoid fuss and confusion on his eightieth birthday, Jan. 14.

The owner of a rooming house in the Chelsea section disputed in court yesterday that he could be charged with violating the multiple dwelling law if the four persons living there were not actually tenants.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today announced that Edwin B. Swope would retire as warden of Alcatraz Penitentiary Jan. 31.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday that after February no more "Emergency Repair Service Parking Cards" would be issued for repairs of refrigerators, elevators and oil burners.

Three employes of the Railway Express Agency and a Brooklyn bartender were charged yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation with the theft of $100,000 worth of goods moving through interstate commerce in the last six months.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower's Highway Commission agreed substantially today on the principles of a $101,000,000,000, ten-year highway modernization program.

THE fishing reports from the warmer climes continue to reveal plenty of action both inshore and offshore. If the sailfish remain in the area from Stuart to Palm Beach, Fla., another week the international light tackle sailfish tournament will be a success.

The Health Department obtained yesterday from the Consolidated Edison Company an address list of 100,000 side-arm gas water heaters in the Manhattan area designated as critical for carbon monoxide deaths.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Government reported today that spending for new construction in 1954 reached $37,200,000,000.

Advocates of regional telecasting of college football games suffered a setback yesterday as the National Collegiate Athletic Association voted almost unanimously for a national television program in 1955.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The National Union of Railwaymen won a substantial victory today. The British Transport Commission agreed to increase the wages of 60,000 railroad employes by the equivalent of 70 cents to $1.12 a week.
ROME, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The Vatican announced today that a book written by a French priest containing "dangerous" psychological theories on chastity had been banned publicly.

Meeting a soldier or officer of the Salvation Army -- whether to receive or to give or just to talk -- is a refreshing experience. Both the young girl on the corner seeking contributions from passers-by or the ranking officer dealing in public relations impress the observer with that same sense of conviction and dedication which are such rare qualities in this age of relative values, sliding moral scales and plain cynicism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said today he would lay proposals for an investigation of boxing before the Senate Commerce Committee, but he indicated he didn't think the Senators would get into full-scale hearings "at this time."
The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday it had purchased the New Britain Broadcasting Company, operator television station WKNB-TV and radio station WKNB in New Britain, Conn.

Commodity futures prices on the New York exchanges reflected the stock market rise yesterday. Coffee, hides, burlap, copper, zinc, cocoa and cottonseed oil were firm. On the other hand, silk and soybean oil declined, while potatoes, sugar, rubber and wool showed mixed changes.

The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday an increase of 1 cent a pound in the price of primary aluminum, bringing aluminum pig to 21.5 cents and the slightly more purified ingot form to 23.2 cents.
BOSTON, Jan. 7 -- Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, identified today three friends who, he said, had gained control of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

ROME Jan. 7 -- Clemente Cardinal Micara, the Pope's Vicar General for the Diocese of Rome, instructed priests today to no longer offer special prayers "for the sick Pontiff." This was considered proof that the 78-year-old Pope, who has been convalescing for some time, is definitely on the way toward recovery.

Notre Dame and New York University will resume their basketball rivalry at Madison Square Garden tonight in the twenty-second game of a series that began in 1934. La Salle and Power Memorial will clash in a preliminary schoolboy contest.
Led by Bill Chrystal, who tallied 26 points, St. John's University's quintet defeated St. Francis College, 80 -- 71, in the forty-first game between the Brooklyn institutions last night.

On the east bank and at the head of navigation on the Hudson River lies the city of Troy (population 72,311). It occupies a large portion of the patroon grant some sixteen miles in extent made to Kiliaen Van Rensselaer by the Dutch East India Company in the Seventeenth Century.

Having set players for several important roles and attended to other production details, Robert Whitehead and Roger L. Stevens will place their production of "Bus Stop," the William Inge play, in rehearsal next Monday or Friday.

Two portraits of Walt Whitman, one showing the poet while still vigorous, but aging, and the other in earlier life, were purchased recently by Brooklyn College. They will be unveiled Thursday at the dedication of the college's new music and arts center, which will be known as Whitman Hall.

As New York becomes more built up, more populous and more hurried, it has ever-increasing need of its parks. And for many years, fortunately, we have had a Park Department that, despite restricted budgets and inadequate personnel, has made a supreme effort to keep up with the need and the demand.
Prices of cotton futures rose 10 to 15 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Consolidation of the city's three public library systems into a centralized unit was suggested yesterday by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
PANAMA, Jan. 7 -- Alejandro Remon, younger brother of the late President Jose Antonio Remon is expected to be appointed Minister of Government and Justice to succeed Catalino Arrocha Graell.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 7 -- Dr. Ivo Politeo, who defended Aloysius Cardinal Stepinac, has been named by Valdimir Dedijer as his attorney, the semi-official news agency Yugopress reported tonight. The agency reported also that the preliminary court investigation in the case of M. Dedijer, President Tito's biographer, and Milovan Djilas, the ousted former Vice President, was nearing its close.
George N. Vitt, who became involved last month in the controversy over the ouster of Wolf Ladejinsky, United States agricultural attache in Japan, has resigned as editor of a New York trade magazine.
SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Brazil and Bolivia agreed today to take steps for the speedy development of Bolivia's petroleum resources.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 -- Ninety - three embarking passengers carried their luggage through a picket line and the cruise liner Tradewind headed through the Golden Gate today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A scintillation counter patented this week by a Princeton research group represents an important advance in atomic radiation detectors.
The final witness was heard yesterday in the suspension appeal hearing before New York State Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

Barring a few exceptions, President Eisenhower's State of the Union message has been welcomed with a gratifying measure of agreement both at home and abroad. This is especially true of his reaffirmation of a policy of "peace through strength," which most free nations now accept as the fundamental basis of their safety in a world threatened by Soviet imperialism.

Family linens purchased a century ago are being returned these days to James McCutcheon, Inc., 609 Fifth Avenue. They are being taken back, not because of complaints, but as a tribute to the hundredth anniversary of the founding of the linen, specialty store.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 7 -- Robert J. McCarthy, 21-year-old Princeton University senior, received tonight The Daily Princetonian's award as the undergraduate making the "greatest physical and moral contributions to the University" through his extracurricular accomplishments.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The era in which Mary Driscoll was the only person who really understood the filing system of the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee has ended.

VIENNA, Jan. 7 -- The Djilas-Dedijer schism in Yugoslavia is embarrassing to Tito because it involves two of his oldest friends in the Communist leadership. It is even more embarrassing because these men, having tried communism and having fought for it, now reject its ideology.

After intervention by President Eisenhower this nation's former agricultural attache in Tokyo, Wolf Ladejinsky, has had his case resolved for the present. He is now cleared by both the Department of State and the Foreign Operations Administration and will work for the latter to try to bring the powerful weapon of land reform to bear in trying to save South Vietnam from Communist takeover.

Floyd Patterson had an easy time knocking out Willie Troy of Washington at Madison Square Garden last night. The Brooklyn light heavyweight punished Troy so badly that Referee Al Berl intervened after the fifth round had ended.
MOSCOW, Jan. 7 -- A vast Soviet drive to the east to open up new land and expand power and population in this country was proposed here tonight by Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party leader.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 7 (UP) -- Jockey Ray York received a sterling silver plate today from Santa Anita's director of racing for his quick thinking during an accident at Golden Gate Fields las fall, saving John Longden from possible injury.

The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, reported as of Dec. 31, 1954, total deposits of $2,476,975,255 and total assets of $2,729,643.148, compared, respectively, with $2,396,538,400 and $2,641,169,186 on June 30.

The first national exhibit of equipment for the retail industry opened on an optimistic note yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Attendance topped the 2,000 mark and exhibitors predicted that their business in 1955 would better that of 1954.

As has been noted often in recent months, Premier Mendes-France is nothing if not persistent. One cannot say that he has a one-track mind, for he has been galloping off in all directions -- Indochina, North Africa, West Germany, the Saar, Western European Union and a variety of domestic fields.

Walter Florell has taken the enchanted forest with its flowers, shadows and elfin sprites as the theme for his spring millinery collection. Presented yesterday at his showroom, 29 West Fifty-third Street, the collection stressed silhouettes that come deep on the head.

From its treasury of books on Christianity the library of the General Theological Seminary has selected rare printed Bibles for exhibition in commemoration of the 500th anniversary of the Gutenberg Bible.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The wife of a seaman missing with twenty-two others aboard the Southern Districts told a Coast Guard inquiry board today that her husband had said the vessel's engines "were all fouled up" and the bottom was "full of holes."

Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, confirmed yesterday that the gigantic XC-132 transport plane, which the Douglas Aircraft Company is building, would have a carrying capacity of eighty tons.

The cotton industry's ambassador for 1955 is De Lois Faulkner of Sallisaw, Okla., who observed her first visit to New York yesterday by feeding the squirrels in Central Park and making her first attempt at ice skating.

HONG KONG, Jan. 7 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, and Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China had another long meeting in Peiping today. It was their second formal session with their advisers since Mr. Hammarskjold arrived in Red China's capital Wednesday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Chief State Prosecutor Sunarjo said today he was convinced that if any Americans were involved in subversive activities in Indonesia "it is without the American Government's foreknowledge."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue estimates that 100,000 persons will pay more taxes than they should if they follow the new income tax form.

Consumers apparently have extended a warm welcome to fresh, packaged orange juice. Four brands of this product, which first appeared here last summer, are now available. One company reports that last November two trucks a week, with 12,000 quarts to a truck, were coming into New York with its juice. Now the rate of delivery is two trucks a day.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

Polish folk dances in the colorful costumes of various Polish provinces were features of the entertainment at the annual Polka Ball of the Kosciuszko Foundation held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event attracted representative groups from communities throughout New England and the East.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Hope for three perennial legislative proposals was virtually abandoned tonight.
MOGADISHU, Trust Territory of Somaliland, Dec. 22 -- Italy is trying here and elsewhere in East Africa to regain by economic and cultural penetration the sphere of influence she won and lost by war.
The week-old strike of fresh-fruit and vegetable handlers was settled last night.
GENEVA, Jan. 7 -- Complications have increased for the Geneva trade conference since the Christmas recess.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- With the right promotion efforts, automatic household washer sales in 1955 can rise 10 per cent from 1954 sales, V. F. Peterson, manager of automatic washer sales for the Norge division of Borg-Warner Corporation, asserted today.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Texas Council of Churches spoke out today against what it termed "attempted evasion" of the United States Supreme Court decision to desegregate public schools.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 7 -- The 1,239-ton exploration ship Kista Dan left Melbourne today for the Antarctic, carrying a relief party of fifteen men, twelve of whom have had previous experience with South Polar research expeditions.
DRAWINGS by eight of the Midtown Gallery's group of well-known artists make up the current show at the gallery, 17-A East Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- United States officials believe that land reform in South Vietnam could tip the scales in favor of the free world in the all-Vietnam elections due in July, 1956.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Unemployment declined slightly from early November to early December despite the usual tendency to increase at that time of the year.
HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 6 -- The Dutch here give the impression of being here to stay.

Frederick Brown, real estate operator and investor, has acquired the one and two-story taxpayer building at 2-22 Purchase Street in Rye, N. Y., from Vincent Astor. The property occupies an irregular plot about 220 by 146 feet at the corner of the Boston Post Road. Tenants include F. W. Woolworth and the House and Garden Store Corporation. Cartar, Ledyard Milburn were attorneys for the seller and Joshua Bernstein acted for the buyer.
Five mornings each week a trailer truck makes the sixty-four-mile run from the United States Assay Office, at South Street and Old Slip, to West Point, carrying sixteen tons of silver bars.

QUEBEC, Jan. 7 -- A three-man board with judicial power is to be appointed to supervise stock market activity in this province, Maurice Duplessis, Premier of Quebec, announced today. The group will be named soon after the second term of the provincial Legislature begins on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Grain futures opened strong on the Board of Trade today, with gains in wheat running to 1 cent. Later all futures sold off sharply, registering low marks around midday. After that, there was another recovery.
A growing number of Protestant clergymen and laymen are preparing for annual programs on the relation of Christian principles to American economic life.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, said today he had no intention of resigning.
An "impossible" childhood dream came true for Marian Anderson last night. She made her debut with the Metropolitan Opera.
TOKYO, Jan. 7 -- Japan's budding defense force will soon own all its own equipment as the result of agreements exchanged between the Japanese and United States governments today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The text of an analysis by the research division of the Democratic National Committee of the "Major Aspects of President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message to Congress" follows:

Vassily Smyslov and Paul Keres finished the premier chess tournament at Hastings in a tie for first place. Both Soviet representatives won their ninth-round matches, according to a report from London. The victories made their final scores 7 -- 2.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Removal of the railway strike threat last night encouraged heavy buying on the stock market today. Both Government funds and industrial shares responded with many good gains. The latter finished at the day's best, but the gilt-edges reacted in the afternoon on the further rise in United States Treasury bill rates.
GRINDEWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 7 (UP) -- Signora Giuliana Chenal Minuzzo today won the slalom run of the international women's ski meet.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The United States is getting a "run-around" in trying to locate Noel Field and his wife. Herta, a State Department spokesman said today.

In your issue of Dec. 22 your New Delhi correspondent reported that Tito, a guest of Nehru, told the Indian Parliament that the coexistence between the Soviet bloc and the free world should be an active one.
A jobless actor who refused to be typed as a typist has won a fight to collect unemployment insurance benefits while he is waiting for a job on stage.
The unhappiness of many American women today is owing in part to the uncertainties in their lives.
OTTAWA, Jan. 7 -- Some moderate remedies for Canada's mild economic setback were proposed to Parliament today by the Government.
HOWEVER exclusive the taste of the gallerygoer, he should be able to find much to interest him in the wide range of this week's many exhibitions.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Ten grateful crew members plucked from their fishing schooner sinking in heavy Atlantic seas reached port here today aboard the rescue ship, the liner Queen of Bermuda.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Two Japanese lovers who tried to leap into a volcano's seething "suicide crater" were rescued yesterday after thirty-three hours of suffering and terror on the crater's floor.
HICKORY, N. C., Jan. 7 -- The General Electric Company announced today that it will establish in this area a new $20,000,000 plant for manufacturing distribution transformers.
The Brazilian pianist Bernardo Segall made his appearance in a recital at Carnegie Hall last evening before a large and cordial audience.
TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Col. David A. Burchinal said today that it was bad weather that caused him to fly a B-47 more than 21,000 miles nonstop, a flight that shattered all records.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make a motion picture based on the life of Comdr. Frank (Spig) Spigwead, who was one of the first Annapolis graduates (class of '16)) to enter naval aviation and who later became associated with the studio as a scenario writer.
New York City is planning to borrow $65,200,000 about Jan. 19 on an issue of school, hospital and transit bonds similar to those sold last spring, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 7 -- French Premier Pierre Mendes - France will encounter strong resistance to his plan for pooling arms production when he meets Chancellor Konrad Adenauer next Friday near Baden-Baden.
Four manufacturers raised retail prices by 2 1/2 and 5 per cent on tires and tubes yesterday. Other makers were expected to take similar action.
CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 7 -- Harry W. Pierce, president of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, today denied reports that the huge shipyard would be liquidated.

THANKS to Clarence Derwent and Whitford Kane, the production of "The Merchant of Venice," which opened at the Finch Theatre last evening, has the benefit of two experienced performances. Mr. Derwent plays Shylock; Mr. Kane, Old Gobbo.
Stocks continued yesterday the rally begun late Thursday afternoon. Many leading issues registered gains of 1 to 5 points.
With the year-end holidays over the public market for new issues of prime securities gives promise of resuming the active pace of last fall.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 7 -- State censorship of motion pictures in Ohio has been ruled unconstitutional. A three-member District Court of Appeals yesterday declared void the film censorship law, which has been ineffective for a month under a state Supreme Court ruling on a previous censorship case.

The last time Herbert Stessin gave a piano recital in this city he impressed as a talented young pianist who needed a little more discipline. That was in the winter of 1950. His Town Hall recital last night was a decided step forward, and the audience heard some good piano-playing without the overstress that previously had marred his work.

While the Presidential nominating conventions of the major political parties are still many months in the future, I believe it is a matter of great importance and urgency, while the televised picture of the 1952 Democratic convention is not too far distant, to bring about drastic reforms in the entire nominating procedure.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Opposition was voiced on Capitol Hill today to any proposal that schools be built with Federal guaranteed loans rather than by outright grants.
New Yorkers shivered yesterday in the grip of a freezing northwest gale that toppled signs, chimneys and television aerials. Five persons were injured.

MADRID, Jan. 7 -- The United States apparently is popular in Spain these days. The press announced today that the American people had donated 250,000 Christmas food packages and that 90,000 had just been distributed to needy Spanish families. The rest will be made available by the end of this month.

TORONTO, Jan. 7 -- Canadian and American business men, in self interest, should promote a freer flow of trade and capital rather than hide behind quotas and other restrictions, Donald C. Bliss, United States Minister to Canada, said today.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The ailing mother of Samuel Sheppard shot herself today in a locked bedroom, police said.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Eisenhower's proposal for a Federal Advisory Commission on the Arts touched a subject on which fourteen bills were considered last year.

Julius Helfand, the new chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, presided at his first meeting of the board yesterday. A full calendar required his attention, and he handled all matters with competence and directness.
Hiring practices and the higher wages under the new two-year waterfront peace pact will go into effect with the start of work next Tuesday, union and employer spokesmen said yesterday.
Persons coping with the problems and relationships of average family living will be helped by the Child Study Association as a result of the association's annual theatre benefit.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 8 -- Stockholm diplomatic circles feel optimistic about Mr. Hammarskjold's Peiping mission. The general impression is that the Secretary is on the eve of success in obtaining the release of the imprisoned United States fliers and United Nations personnel.

SOME shrubs are planted not for their bloom in spring or summer but for their berries in winter. They are, in fact, more showy in fruit than in flower. Even one shrub with a profusion of berries that are scarlet or crimson, orange or blue or gray adds a welcome island of color to the small property when trees are bare and flowers do not bloom outdoors.

IT is possible -- nay, virtually unavoidable -- to interpret this fictional excursion into the field of aerodynamics on two levels of understanding. On the scientific level it may be considered as the story of a misguided zealot devoted body and soul to the advancement of knowledge.

TORONTO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Two top-ranking United States squash racquets players and two leading players from Pakistan today reached the semi-final round of the third pro-amateur tournament at the Toronto Badminton and Racquets Club.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- British coal output rose slightly in 1954, but failed to reach the target set by management and labor. Provisional figures just issued showed that production of mined coal rose by 1,738,000 tons -- more than 3,000,000 tons short of the objective.

THE Southern Democrat -- and the genus will here be rather arbitrarily described as though it were one man -- has returned to a place of unsurpassed power in the life of the United States. He bestrides the new Democratic Congress as so often, minority man though he is in his party, he bestrode Democratic Congresses in the past.

SOME misgivings were apparent last week concerning the well-being of the economy, particularly after stock values tumbled when many shareholders sought to cash in speculative profits. Security analysts were quick to point out that an "adjustment" had been overdue, and that only an excuse was needed to provide the spark.
A citizens committee to help crystallize public thinking about the city's schools is under consideration.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The Churchill Government will make no important changes this year in Britain's two-year draft or in the high level of her defense spending.

ICELAND is not exactly on the international concert artists' regular circuit. That two of America's most gifted young virtuosos, Isaac Stern, violinist, and Ervin Laszlo, pianist, should have converged on the island simultaneously last week was therefore an unusual occurrence.

BERLIN, Jan. 8 -- The Soviet Union today released two Americans who had been held in labor camps. One of the Americans, John H. Noble, 31, of Detroit, a civilian held by the Communists since July, 1945, jumped for joy at his release.
