BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 28 -- Generally good progress is being made in the exploration of Asia's mineral wealth, according to a study just released by the headquarters here of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East.

HERE are two books which compel comparisons though their arrival in the same season is accidental and each makes scant references to the other's subject. Even the manner of reference illuminates a difference -- both in writers and in men written about.

THIS is the story of public health nurse Paula Hoode and her school-teacher friend Agnes Miller, who take off for Mud Creek, Alberta, in the fond hope that life beyond the end of steel will provide "something different."
The Police Department has mobilize its entire uniformed force in a competition to promote highway safety and to reduce accidents.
South American cities continue to add to their populations, with the biggest gains apparently being made by Caracas, Venezuela; Sao Paulo, Brazil, and Lima, Peru.

TORONTO, Jan. 8 -- Sid Smith scored his nineteenth and twentieth goals of the season tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs whipped the New York Rangers, 5 -- 0, before 12,588 fans for their first victory in their last nine National Hockey League starts.
This week's art highlight is the Whitney Annual of contemporary American paintings, sculpture and drawings, which opens on Wednesday at the Whitney Museum, 22 West Fifty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- One of the hardest things to find these days is a dim view, so far as the business outlook is concerned.
The writer is a member of and the attorney for the Playwrights' Company.

WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont. -- The authorities at Yellowstone National Park close its roads on or about Oct. 15 every year, and visitors aren't catered to again in the 3,472-square-mile preserve until mid-June.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- A decree published today seeks to overcome the tendency toward concentration of French industry in big centers. The intention is to disperse industrial production over all of France.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 8 -- A jump shot in the last eleven seconds by Joe Helms gave Georgia Tech a 59-58 upset victory over Kentucky tonight and stopped the nation's No. 1 college basketball power after thirty-two straight victories.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 1 -- West Germany succeeded in establishing last year shipping lines to seventy-five ports in the principal parts of the world. The rebuilding for the second time in this century of the German merchant marine is being based on the principle that the airplane has come to stay.
ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Sunday, Jan. 9 -- This ship en route to Little America completed the first helicopter mail delivery in New Zealand history early today.

THESE next few weeks can be crucial ones for bulbs, corms and tubers stored in a cellar or garage, January and February may also be vital to several shallow-rooted perennials. An hour spent now in inspecting indoor and outdoor conditions will permit correction of troubles before they become serious.

MORE and more, as time goes on, I am struck by the unequal equation between the reader and his book. What the book has to give, whether trifling or great, is constant. always there at his command. But the reader's response is variable.

Shame on David Low for doing a disservice to history and the British by telling us, in "Old Low's History of Anglo-American Relations" (Dec. 19), that in the Seventeen Seventies the Tory Government was (or were?) "horrified by the French Revolution."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- General business registered a 10 per cent gain in Pennsylvania in November over October, while industrial activity picked up 1 per cent. In making this report, the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University also noted that industrial activity, down 9 per cent from a year ago, was at the lowest level for any November since 1949.
The 130th anniversary of the founding of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun was celebrated yesterday.

A COMPANIONABLE book of light satires, mostly in five-stress couplets, on the modern scene, "The Reckless Spenders" should give pleasure to many readers. Walker Gibson does not put his best wares on top; the poems toward the end of the collection are defter and keener than those at the beginning; for example, the poem "Garden," that concludes with two memorable couplets:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- By his address to Congress on the State of the Union, President Eisenhower left no further doubt that, as a creator of dilemmas for the political Opposition, he has taken rank with President F. D. Roosevelt.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia gained the United States first tournament title of the current Australian tennis season today when he defeated Lennart Berggelin of Sweden, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, 8 -- 6, in the South Australia final.
An oil portrait of King Philip IV of Spain, painted by Peter Paul Rubens in 1628 on his second visit to Madrid, was sold at auction yesterday for $16,000 to Duveen Bros., Inc.
HARTFORD, Jan. 7 -- A major shift of power occurred in the Republican party in Connecticut this week.
DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Mint Leaf, a 7-year-old bay mare, won the working hunter championship in the featured division of Ox Ridge Hunt Club's twenty-third annual horse show tonight.

FOUR weeks ago on this page, Dr. Celia B. Stendler, Professor of Education at the University of Illinois, contrasted certain child-rearing methods and aims of a group of Parisian parents with those of a number of American parents.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 8 -- Minnesota's yearly payroll slid below the $3,000,000,000 mark in 1954, but still was the second highest in the state's history, figures compiled by the State Employment Service show. The 1.4 per cent drop from the 1953 peak put 1954 earnings at $2,967,400,000.

Mr. Pritchett remarks of the "writer who works in a university": "I envy his security, his insulation, his easy access to knowledge, his immensely long holidays, his continuous contact with educated people, his traveling, scholarships and grants."

MOST of the recent books about interplanetary travel have been written by specialists concerned with selecting efficient fuels, designing rockets and accessory equipment and computing possible trajectories through space. As an astronomer, Robert Richardson looks beyond the inevitable solution of engineering problems.
One of the world's numerous small-scale shooting wars has increased in intensity in the last few weeks.

FOR many years the members of the dental profession have made an effort to dispel the fears of children and adults whose teeth need dental treatment. Naturally any exaggeration which is likely to suggest that such treatment is an ordeal or a complication becomes a threat to health and peace of mind.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A year after the crime, somebody in the Administration has come up with a simple mathematical definition of "massive retaliation."

MIAMI, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Johnny Gonsalves, a fancy fighter from Oakland, Calif., with a featherlike punch, obtained an unpopular draw with Wallace (Bud) Smith of Cincinnati tonight in a ten-round bout between lightweight contenders at the City Auditorium.

A MODEST experiment in bringing the Government of the United States to the people will enter its second stage this week when the Department of Labor opens a telephone booth in the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue.
Police headquarters here moved last night to send at least two New York detectives to Panama to assist in solving the Jan. 2 murder of President Jose Antonio Remon.

WHEN the young centurion Marcus Aquila took over his first command in a frontier garrison in ancient Britain his heart was set on a long and glorious military career. He was also determined to find out about his father who had been lost ten years earlier when the Ninth Legion had mysteriously vanished on its way to quell a rebellion in North Britain.

HIS recent short stories in Partisan Review and New World Writing served as promising calling cards for a major literary visit from Buffalo-born Harvey Swados. Unfortunately, his first novel is a rather long and sprawling visit -- drawing out a tale that covers two continents in World War II and occasionally droning us to sleep in the process.

IT is a familiar claim that around 1900 the composer Charles Ives (called by many "the father of American music'') anticipated some contemporary musical devices usually attributed to celebrated European composers. In a first book on this venerated New Englander, Henry Cowell, a well-known composer, and his wife Sidney Cowell inevitably stress this, giving freshness in the way of documentation.

* * * IN the article by V. S. Pritchett, "The Critic With the College Tie," in which he sets out some differences between the academic and "free" critic, Mr. Pritchett has refused a valuable opportunity to perceive and define the nature of the problem.

The twentieth annual theatre benefit for Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys at Millington, N. J., will be held at the Jan. 15 matinee performance of "Quadrille" at the Coronet theatre. The romantic comedy stars Alfred Lunt, Lynn Fontane, Brian Aherne and Edna Best.

Expanding school systems across the country have stepped up the demand for young, professionally trained public school administrators and supervisors, Dr. Fritz-Borgeson, Professor of Education at New York University, reported last week. Director of the university's program on administration internship, Dr. Borgeson said that all of the institution's 1953-54 interns are now placed in leadership positions.
The Organization of American States has, adopted resolutions designed to spur improvement of the maritime transportation facilities of the twenty-one American republics.

BEGINNING today, duplicate bridge will be big news for a week. The British team, champions of Europe, and the American team that won the American Contract Bridge League's masters' team championship last summer in the national tournament at Washington are scheduled to begin eight days' play for the "world championship."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Senate Democratic leaders said today they were confident of giving every freshman Democratic Senator a major committee post in the new Congress.
TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- The Right Rev. Alfred L. Banyard was elected Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey today at a special convention in the Trinity Cathedral here.

HOME owners who take pride in their handiwork in the outdoor vegetable garden can transfer their skill to the basement and do an equally good job of producing fresh crops. Two vegetables, rhubarb and endive, lend themselves admirably to this effort.
TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- The New Jersey Legislature will open the 1955 session here at noon on Tuesday.
Your correspondent Jack Raymond has reported extensively on the new and sudden rift in the high ranks of the Yugoslav Communist party.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 8 -- High officials of the Republic of Korea are reported to be strongly opposed to the use of atomic weapons to counter any renewed Communist aggression in this direction. Their reason is that if the Communists retaliated with atomic weapons of their own, most of the sufferers would be Koreans.
TOKYO, Jan. 8 -- Faced with elections and a boiling international situation, Japanese political leaders acted this week as if they were hopping on a hot gridle and did not want to fall into the fire.

Fred Wilt seems as spry as ever at the ripe old athletic age of 34. Here from Indianapolis in the interests of the New York Athletic Club, the galloping F. B. I. man romped to an easy victory in the one-mile run at last night's Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships.

ONE consolation for the resignation of so many brilliant State Department officials in recent years is that they write such good books. How they do it after years of committee work and official jargon is a mystery, but men such as George F. Kennan, Paul Nitze, John P. Davies, Charles Burton Marshall and Louis J. Halle still have ideas and can express them.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Wholesale trade in Chicago was placed at $14,500,000,000 for 1954 by the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry, a 7 per cent decline from the 1953 total of $15,600,000,000. In the metropolitan area of Chicago, including the city, wholesale volume was estimated at $16,500,000,000 last year, compared with $17,800,000,000 the year before.

The assignment of Mr. Ladejinsky to Vietnam is not merely a happy solution to a series of blunders. It is also the assignment of a competent person to a difficult and complex task. Once more the problem of land holding in Asia is brought sharply into focus.

ST. THOMAS, V. I -- Beyond St. Thomas, at the northern end of the Leeward Islands, lie five tiny islands too small to be found except on the largest maps. Twenty-four hours' sail from the Virgin Islands, or a short plane flight, these islands live in a completely different world, so far undiscovered by most tourists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The House Armed Services Committee today called Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson to testify publicly on President Eisenhower's proposed military manpower cuts.

The New York State Association for Crippled Children, Inc., 257 Fourth Avenue, last year served 19,106 handicapped persons, including 15,322 children, Edward A. Styles, executive director, reported yesterday. This was an increase of 20 per cent over 1953.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 3 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin is examining the possibility of siphoning off into Costa Rica some of Puerto Rico's surplus population.
Retailers are likely to clarify their stand on fair trade and may amend their position on excise taxes at the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association this week.

In the last six months there has been little change in the news censorship picture around the world. This is the finding in the latest survey of internal and international censorship by The Associated Press.

Webster Aitken late yesterday afternoon gave the first of three Town Hall piano recitals devoted to six sonatas by Schubert. He played the D major, Op. 53, and the G major, Op. 78. The subsequent recitals, on Jan. 15 and 22, also will contain two sonatas on each program.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 8 -- A variety of motivations figured in the decision of the Colombo Prime Ministers last week to sponsor the conference of Asian and African nations now scheduled to meet in Indonesia in April.

WHEN Ginger Clyde, her brother Hal and their aunt Barby bought a home in Vermont, Hal's rehabilitation began. Confined to a wheel chair by a wound acquired in the Korean war, Hal needed the impetus of new surroundings to restore his interest in people and in his former career, architecture.

Frank E. (Jimmy) Kilroe has placed Summer Tan at the head of a list of 3-year-olds of 1955. The colt, owned by Mrs. Russell A. Firestone, has drawn the top weight of 128 pounds for the Experimental Free Handicap.

The Giants are still rolling up clean sweeps. The world champions scored another yesterday when the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association announced that all three of its annual awards had been carried off by the astonishing Polo Grounders.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 8 -- Frank Eidom, hard-running Southern Methodist halfback, powered the South to two second-half touchdowns today and a 12-6 victory over the North in the sixth senior bowl game. A crowd of 34,000 saw the contest.
Paul Moor's recent article brought back interesting memories and shed some light on Prof. Hermann Abendroth's whereabouts since the days after the Nazi surrender.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Peress case, reopened last night by a new Army report, may become the target of one of the first investigations in the new Democratic Congress.

THE new year brings with it some good, dissimilar exhibitions of landscape painting, cheering remindders that if nature's mysteries are being exploded by the scientist they are still a source of wonder and wild delight for the artist.

No matter what other birds come to the feeding station for suet or seeds, it's the chickadees that really repay a person for keeping a winter table set outdoors. The rare visitors, those seldom seen in the area, may make the bird-watcher's eyes gleam, but little Mr. Black-Cap and his mate warm the heart.
MOGADISHU, Trust Territory of Somaliland, Dec. 23 -- The economy of Somaliland will float on oil or it is unlikely to float at all when the territory becomes independent in 1960.

I notice that Mr. Crowther has made some admirable selections in choosing the ten best films of the year. I refer to "Mr. Hulot's Holiday," "The Little Kidnappers," "Genevieve" and "Seven Brides For Seven Brothers."

WILLIAM MENSCHING is a man who runs a colossal workshop that covers a floor area of 14,000 square feet and has unlimited modern equipment. But like a do-it-yourself amateur in a cluttered basement corner, he would like to have more room.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 8 -- Bowden Wyatt, who created football strongholds at Wyoming and Arkansas, today was named head coach at Tennessee, where he will face the task of rebuilding a gridiron empire.
A rookie patrolman captured one of four hold-up men who pistol-whipped and beat half a dozen persons in a small Harlem hotel yesterday at 2:45 P. M.

OF all the first-person accounts of terror, heroism and human endurance which have been written by raft-bound castaways this is probably the most harrowing. Ensio Tiira tells of his ordeal simply. He and a Swedish friend, Ericsson, were members of the French Foreign Legion in Africa.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 8 -- New problems of international law may arise from the Fisheries Act passed by Commonwealth Parliament nearly two years ago.
THE recent deer season seems to have been a successful one for the majority of the muzzle-loader enthusiasts who have reported on their hunting with this antique but effective rifle.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Confidence in United States leadership and understanding of the basic aims of American foreign policy are increasing slowly in Western Europe. However, the other side of the picture should not be over-looked.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 8 -- The government of Fairfield County, a relic of the Colonial era, is carried on these days by two men and a woman in a suite of small offices occupying one corner of the courthouse here.

ABOUT thirty - five men and women employed by local travel agencies which are members of the New York Chapter, American Society of Travel Agents, will start going to school Wednesday night to learn how to become better travel-agency employes.
The two top-seeded teams advanced to the semi-finals in the twenty-second Arthur H. Lockett invitation squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday at the University Club.

THIS past week I saw Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Saint of Bleecker Street." Parts of it excited me very much, but the production's total effect left me confused and angry. I felt the author had never made up his mind properly what he wanted to say.
Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore described his borough yesterday as "one of America's leading centers of diversified industry."

" EVERY generation," Arthur Bryant tells us, "needs its popular history written in a way it can understand"; and "The Story of England,'' of which the book under review is only the first volume, represents a serious effort on his part to tell the story in popular form and style for his generation.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The State Mental Hygiene Department reported today that patients in state institutions had shown "significant improvement" after treatment with two new drugs.
Students enrolling for a freshman course are rarely asked to join the faculty, but Fordham College made an exception in the case of Dr. William O. Trapp.

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons are serving on the junior and debutante committees for the annual Animal Kingdom Ball, a dinner dance, to be held on Jan. 27 in the main ballroom of the Pierre. Proceeds will aid the adoption service clinic of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation is offering to its fellow aircraft makers -- and to industries as far afield as beer and chocolate -- commercial adaptations of the science of ultrasonics.

SELDOM has the wide range of abstraction been more clearly evident than in recently opened one-man shows. Among these, moreover, one may see how it has come to overlap with the so personal statements of the artist's attitude which have coma to be loosely grouped together as expressionism. And through both runs a recurrent vein of suggestion in many forms.

Trading in commodity futures on the New York exchanges was heavy last year. Almost all items registered higher volume than in 1953. Potato trading was the heaviest since that contract opened in 1948, and the coffee volume was the largest since 1941.

IN October, 1815, a British man-of- war, the Northumberland, entered the port of Jamestown, capital of St. Helena, a little volcanic island in the South Atlantic. There it put ashore a prisoner, the man whom the world knew as the Emperor Napoleon but whom his official jailers called General Bonaparte.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan 8 (AP) -- Chinese Communist guns today resumed their shelling of Nationist- held Quemoy and Little Quemoy islands following yesterday's artillery duel, described as the heaviest action of the new year.

A meeting of educators to discuss the anti-intellectual upsurge in the country has been called by Goddard College, Plainfield, Vt. It is sponsored by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, Dr. Alvin Johnson, Marshall Field, Norman Thomas and other leaders, and will be held Jan. 16 at the Carnegie Endowment Building, United Nations Plaza.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 -- Eric Monti of Los Angeles moved into a one-stroke lead at the end of the third round of the $32,500 Los Angeles open golf tournament today. Monti shot a 69 for a fifty-four-hole total of 205.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 8 -- The first week of 1955 had a good start and volume measured about 5 per cent above a year ago. Widespread promotions were in evidence and assortments were not so plentiful as in the 1954 period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Republican leaders charged the Democratic National Committee today with "irresponsible" efforts to repudiate and undermine pledges of Democratic Congressional leaders to cooperate with President Eisenhower.

THE fifth anniversary of the death of Richard Strauss (Sept. 8, 1949), was observed with the publication by Willi Schuh of a remarkable book, "Letters to the Parents" (Briefe an die Eltern, Atlantis Verlag, Zurich). It has been the subject of much critical discussion recently by European and British critics.
Gold and enamel baubles and other precious materials are among the items that will be auctioned Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 8 (UP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that Adlai E. Stevenson was "the party's best qualified candidate for president in 1956."
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- A Newburgh amateur radio operator has been piercing Russia's Iron Curtain regularly during the last ten days with a powerful shortwave raido transmitter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren and Benjamin M. McKelway, editor of The Washington Evening Star, have been elected to the board of trustees of the National Geographic Society.
Wall Street started the new year on the front pages last week. The stock market got off on the right foot but then stumbled.

WHATEVER some (including those who may never read them) think of the historical novel, in the hands of a Shirley Barker it becomes a work of power, of informed imagination and deeply felt narrative. Within a few years she has made herself one of the masters of her field, and her newest is at least equal to her best; which makes it a richly successful book.

A merchant seaman was found shot in a car at Broadway and Sixty-fifth Street shortly after noon yesterday, and he died two hours later. His nephew, who had hailed a passing motorist for aid and fled when the latter telephoned the police, surrendered at 5:30 P. M.

Of New York's three most recently elected Democratic Governors, Alfred E. Smith (1923-28) never had a Democratic majority in his Assembly and had one in his Senate only in 1923-24; Franklin D. Roosevelt (1929-32) never had a majority in either House, and Herbert H. Lehman (1933-42) had a slim majority in both Houses only once, in 1935.

MORE than 100 trucks -- tinted red, white and blue -- start rolling here from Detroit this week. They convey hundreds of tons of equipment and exhibits for the General Motors Motorama of 1955 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Jan. 20-25.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 8 -- The West German Government is considering the importing of tanks and heavy weapons for its future military establishment. The plan is designed to prevent burdening the prosperous civilian economy with a costly but marginal armament business.
Sincerest congratulations for the articles "Real Religion and False" by Barbara Ward (Dec. 19) and "A Turning Point in Man's Destiny" by Arnold J. Toynbee (Dec. 26).
The nation's savings banks sold more than $67,000,000 of life insurance last year, increasing the amount in force as of Jan. 1, 1955, to a new record total of $797,068,000.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- Boston University's basketball team required an extra five-minute period this afternoon before pinning a 73-to-70 defeat on Army. It was a tense struggle with the visitors triumphing after trailing most of the way.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Sammy Boulmetis whipped Helianthus under the wire inches in front of four others today to win the $18,250 Robert E. Lee Handicap before 13,434 racing fans at Tropical Park.
IN his early plays Clifford Odets wrote with violence and tension. In "The Flowering Peach," now on view at the Belasco, he is writing with sociable humor and affection for all his people.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, convicted wife-slayer, received permission today to leave his jail cell Monday afternoon to attend the funeral of his mother who committed suicide yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The World Assembly for Moral Re-Armament was told today that Communist control of labor unions in three key industrial areas of the world was being challenged successfully.

LAST week's "See It Now" interview with Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N. J., was an interesting item of television on several different grounds.
THE most revolutionary contribution of designers to home furnishings in the past century -- and one which reached a peak of popularity last year -- is the molded chair.
That the old Simplicissimus fell victim to Hitlerism simply is not true. It went Nazi right away, and its cartoons now show that it pokes fun against everything but a new rise of nazism in Germany.

THE most recent item of the series of books published by the Conquistador firm of Paris, in which men of many professions discuss their work, is "Je suis chef d'Orchestre" tre" by Charles Munch, conductor the Boston Symphony. The book book will soon be issued by Oxford University Press in an English translation by Leonard Burkat.

" ALL things presenting themselves to the mind in violent contrasts and impressive forms lent a tone of excitement and of passion to everyday life and tended to produce that perpetual oscillation between despair and distracted joy, between cruelty and pious tenderness which characterized life in the Middle Ages * * *.

WHAT has happened to composers of fine songs? Are there any in the world today? Plenty of stuff is being produced which is presumed to be good; but there is no sustenance in it and practically nothing that asks for a second hearing.

TOBST in thought I sat on the deck of the barge, struggling to find the elementary and universal conception of the ethical which I had not discovered in any philosophy. Sheet after sheet I covered with disconnected sentences, merely to keep myself concentrated on the problem.

MORNING begins with music; a flock of awakened pigeons wheels over the curving roofs, fluting mournfully through the little bamboo whistles strapped to their legs. In Peiping even the pigeons go to work. On festivals and the holy days of Marxism they trail long ribbons of pastel silk, carving arabesques against the decorated eaves, for the Chinese obstinately continue to invest the Revolution with at least a few of the pleasantly useless fantasies of feudalism.

JAMES WONG HOWE, the cinematographer who added directorial chores to his regular technical assignments, is preparing to independently produce, direct and photograph another feature this spring. Howe, who made his directorial debut more than a year ago with "Go, Man, Go!" after more than thirty-eight years of varied camera work, has formed an independent company called Sun Films, under the aegis of which he will direct and photograph an untitled feature.
In Peiping last week two men met in secret conference, the outcome of which may have major repercussions in the East-West conflict. They were:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Mrs. Erika Glaser Wallach, foster daughter of Noel and Herta Field, has communicated with relatives from a Soviet prison camp at Vorkuta in northern European Russia, it was disclosed today.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- For the first time the Chinese Communist regime is expected to have an exhibition of goods in the Lyons trade fair in April.

IT is much too soon to assess the situation precipitated by Victor about two weeks ago when it drastically reduced the price of its classical LP disks. Some retailers and record companies are acting as though the world has come to an end.
There will be five new members on the committee that will set up the program for the televising of college football games this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- A research scientist said tonight that the United States could launch several space satellites by 1957 for less than the cost of one long-range bomber.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hamarskjold is expected to wind up his conversations with Chinese Communist Premier Chou En-lai after a fourth meeting Monday, United Nations officials said today.

JUST before Christmas, at the famous old Savoy Theatre, a phenomenon occurred. A new detective play by Agatha Christie was staged, failed to please a majority of the critics, and seems unlikely to run more than, shall we say, six months.

PROPERLY proud off being America's oldest art institution, the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts will open on Jan. 16 its 150th Annual Exhibition. As this is an historical occasion it will include work by no living artist but will feature instead a grand "flashback" to 1805 of notable participants in its career.
Basing a story on some of his own conjectures about the crash of the Italian airliner, William Faulkner presents the readers of The New York Times with an interesting display of literary skill.
Confusion over the full meaning of the Presidential order terminating wartime veterans' benefits as of Jan. 31 has led to a "wait and see" reaction by potential Army enlistees.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- This port-conscious community of 22,000 has developed a five-phase campaign designed to re-establish it as the shipping center it was a half-century ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The White House announced today that five United States ships carrying food to flood victims on both sides of the Iron Curtain arrived at European ports last week.

A Japanese incendiary paper balloon intact after more than a decade has been found in the Yukon. During World War II, Air Corps pilots stationed on the Aleutian chain shot down eight or ten of the airborne incendiaries each day. They were similar to the one found last week.
STATISTICIANS, for whom the turn of the year is always a busy time, have produced some remarkable figures on the airlines' safety record during 1954.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Educational Policies Commission declared today that the public schools "must continue as supporters and guardians of the American way of life."

The first buyers in the city in 1955 were optimistic about prospects for the spring season, resident buying offices report. Stocks are generally low and most stores ended 1954 with a rush of business. The offices report that attendance at their clinics has been heavier than usual.

The Meadow Brook Blues defeated the Long Island Rough Riders, 11 -- 10, last night in the feature polo match at the Squadron A Armory. In the opener, which began the indoor season, the Squadron A trio crushed the New York Athletic Club team, 18 to 6.

LET a reviewer make a comment on the technique of singing, and the heavens open. Arguments pro and con flood the mail, concurring, denouncing, advocating this or that method guaranteed to be a rediscovery of the lost art of bel canto.
THE streets of New York may be bone dry or soaking with rain during much of the winter, yet skiers in the metropolitan area can often find good snow at spots within a four-hour drive of the city.

DALLAS, Jan. 8 -- A year-end bank call issued last Monday found banks of the Southwest in better condition than they had been a year earlier. In major cities new high records in deposits and resources were being tallied.

IN actual practice how many great men have ever fulfilled, or are ever likely to fulfill, the conditions which alone render power innocuous to the ruler as well as to the ruled? Obviously, very few. Except by saints, the problem of power is finally insoluble.

" Real Religion -- and False" shows that though we live in the atomic age science has failed to completely enlighten the dark caverns of not only the brain of ordinary people but of our leading intellectuals.

It has been more than a year now since Rudolph S. Hecht went around the world. He feels he is getting out of touch with events, so he plans to set out again soon. This time it will be westward, with Japan as the first stop.

This is the week when the vacation calendar goes topsy-turvy. Summer (at least an indoor summer) comes to New York during these wintry January days. It brings delights for thousands of city landlubbers and their inland country cousins who want to plan and dream about next July's lazy days.

Victor R. McKay Jr., unemployed engineer, last week became the first beneficiary of the vacation plan negotiated last June by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, C. I. O., and the American Merchant Marine Institute.

The first of the six James S. Carpentier Lectures for 1955 of Columbia University's School of Law will be given tomorrow evening at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

IT is stimulating and immensely agreeable to have Paul Draper back in the wilds of Broadway, getting us all mixed up again about the difference between the highbrow and the popular entertainer. As everybody knows, the two things are remote and irreconcilable -- as everybody knows, at least, until he is all confused by a session with Mr. Draper at the Bijou.

AFTER the Columbia Broadcasting System recently wrapped Ed Sullivan in a twenty-year contract and took him home for its very own, the National Broadcasting Company, which had tried to lure the columnist away from C. B. S., began looking for another personality to head a variety program.
FRESNO, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Pedro Azcarate, as he herded a few sheep in the Pyrenees near his home in the Spanish province of Navarre, dreamed of coming to the United States.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 8 -- Golden Abbey, ridden by Johnny Longden, showed his heels by three lengths today to a field of nine California-foaled horses in the $28,000 Santa Catalina Handicap at Santa Anita. Correlation, the even-money favorite, finished out of the money.

THE word "philosophy" is stretched to its broadest connotations by this ponderous and strange book. Dagobert D. Runes, whose output of writing and compilations is extensive but erratic, seems to have missed the chance to create a worth-while volume by adopting too grandiose a pattern.

ATLANTA, Jan. 8 -- Department store sales in the Southeast since Christmas have exceeded expectations. The Sixth Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta reported that in the week after Christmas dollar volume in the area increased 25 per cent over the corresponding week of the previous year -- the highest percentage gain in the nation.

RICHMOND, Jan. 8 -- Although Fifth District department stores failed to set a new high in 1954, they ended the year with a 5 per cent gain for the final month. Volume for the year was equal to that of 1953, when a new high was established.

LAST week Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield made several announcements important to philately. Each disclosure has to do with the Post Office Department's plans for issuing commemorative stamps during the new year. Here are the highlights:
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- A new electronic camera for telescopic photography may open the universe to wider examination.
Neighborhood "television parties," reminiscent of 1947, will spring back into vogue this year if Sylvester L. Weaver Jr. is right.

RIVALRY between the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company over television coverage of Hollywood has taken a new turn. N. B. C., which did much to break down movie industry resistance by putting the Academy Awards program on television the last two years, next month will televise as well for the first time, the announcement of the Academy nominations as a preliminary to the "Oscar" presentations in March.

TWO of the largest airlines on the Atlantic Coast are now ready to handle what is expected to be a record crowd heading for Florida during the next four months. Eastern Airlines announces that its biggest airlift is now in operation between New York and Florida and National Airlines is offering its first winter package vacations there in response to demands for a budget plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Representative Victor L. Anfuso, Democrat of Brooklyn asked Congress today to rewrite the McCarran-Walter Act almost completely to make it "conform with American concepts of justice and fair play."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Navy is going to ask Congress to take back some of its old shipbuilding permits this session and pass a new law covering an up-to-date fleet.
DETROIT, Jan. 8 -- Automobiles and trucks were rolling off the assembly lines at the rate of twenty-four a minute this first week of 1955.
A ten-volume documentary history of the Jews in the United States will be published under the sponsorship of the American Jewish Tercentenary Committee.

THANKS to the recent Vivaldi's revival and the record industry's old habit of coupling lesser-known works to best-sellers, a number of almost forgotten composers aide being dragged up from obscurity on Vivaldi's cocktails. Frantisek Krommer-Kramar is an example.

HUGO CLAUS, 25 this year, was introduced to the American reader last April by Charles Rolo in a special Atlantic supplement on writing in the Low Countries. Mr. Claus was represented by a short story about adolescence in a Belgian slum.

Wider use of tests to identify talented youth is urged in the annual report of the Educational Testing Service, a nonprofit organization sponsored by the Carnegie Foundation for Education. Through these tests, says Dr. Henry Chauncey, president of the service, it will be possible for the nation to help ease its growing shortage of trained scientists.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- Thor Frantzen of the Norway Ski Club of New York City tonight captured the Swedish ski club's jumping tournament at this 50-meter hill after jumps of 128 and 137 feet. He topped a Class A field of nine that included Art Devlin, two-time United States Olympian from the Sno Birds of Lake Placid. Devlin fell after the second of two 141 foot leaps.
A review of the four-and-a-half-year special rackets investigation carried out by the December 1949 Kings County grand jury and the District Attorney's office was released yesterday.

The Institute of International Education has elected Edward M. M. Warburg and Mrs. George Hamlin Shaw as trustees.

Every real music lover must be delighted over the triumphant debut of Miss Marian Anderson at the Metropolitan Opera House. Happily, it was a triumph not merely for Miss Anderson but for the whole world of the fine arts.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -- The Soviet armed forces newspaper, Krasnaya Zvezda (Red Star), said today that President Eisenhower's Message on the State of the Union was a "blueprint for the intensification of the arms race."

ASTRIKING thing about the plays of Shakespeare that the moviemakers are continuing to expose is the wealth of exciting melodrama that lies concealed within their splendid poetry. The city's need for $100,000,000 of additional revenue in 1955-56 was explained yesterday by Mayor Wagner to representatives of Governor Harriman's Administration and spokesmen for the Democratic minority in the Legislature.

DAVID VESTAL'S first one-man show, which opened last week at the Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, contains representative pictures from several periods in his development as a photographer.

Recently I had occasion to see our theatre through the eyes of a London cousin and two friends from Paris. I took them to see a dozen shows. I confess I was ashamed of our theatre and more deeply ashamed not to have recognized my responsibility to it.

LOS ANGELES -- For its first time visitors, Los Angeles is offering a new tour program this winter which should help to simplify sight-seeing and make it more enjoyable. For its repeat customers, the city has a new sight which will be open to the public today for the first time.

President Eisenhower has now delivered his third message on the State of the Union. When he delivered his first one he followed by less than a month the message that President Truman, in the last few days of his incumbency, had sent to Congress, as was his duty under the Constitution.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Jan. 8 (AP) -- President John T. Caldwell of the University of Arkansas said today that he regretted football Coach Bowden Wyatt's decision to leave the state, and added: "It is unfortunate that any contract can be treated as a one-way obligation."

MUSKEGON, Mich., Jan. 8 (UP) -- The police said today that a husband who locked up the telephone every day so his wife would do more housework was acting within his rights. There is nothing they can do about it, they announced.
VIENNA, Jan. 8 -- Whether an opera star who accepts contracts behind the Iron Curtain should be allowed to sing also in the West will be discussed by authorities of the Vienna State Opera next week.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 8 -- The prospect that the West German army will soon materialize has raised difficult questions for the Supreme Allied Headquarters here.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 8 -- Government expenditure in the Federal Republic of West Germany is now absorbing one-third of the gross national product. It has doubled since 1949, according to new figures issued by the Finance Ministry.

For the past three years elementary-school enrollment has increased at the rate of about 1,000,000 children a year. Estimates are that this growth will continue for at least another six years, perhaps even longer. Almost every grade-school system is seeking competent teachers to keep pace with the rising enrollment.

The package -- box, can, bottle, six-pack unit, re-use container and all their related items -- is taking on increased stature as an advertising medium. Further, package design is gaining in terms of dollars in the advertiser's budget.
PAUL SMITH'S, N. Y., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Tauno Pulkkinen of the Finnish Ski Club of New York today won the Class A title in the New York State cross-country meet at Paul Smith's College.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A Republican fiscal adviser gave his answer today to these questions: "If former Governor Dewey saved $142,000,000 where is it and who's got it?"

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- In pressing for a new conference with the Soviet Union, Premier Pierre Mendes-France will not make any proposal regarding Germany to replace that made by the United States, Britain and France in Berlin last January.

Long-term borrowings of state and municipal governments during 1954 reached $6,953,303,918, the highest total ever recorded for a twelve-month period. It represented a rise of more than 25 per cent over the record of $5,557,887,369 set the year before.

McNew, Dr. William Robbins and Paul Frese when they address the opening session of the Flower Arrangement Symposium and Post Graduate Course to be held Tuesday in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at Eighty-third Street, New York, N. Y.

Opportunities to study and teach in France are available to American graduate students, according to an announcement by Dr. Kenneth Holland, president of the Institute of International Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street, New York City. The French Government is offering thirty university fellowships through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and forty teaching assistantships through the Ministry of Education.

The retirement age in the United States should be raised from 65 to 70 years because of the rapidly increasing population of the Communist countries, in the opinion of Leonard W. Mayo. He is chairman of the Commission on Chronic Illness and an authority on problems of the aging.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The Massachusetts Boxing Commission today lifted the suspension of Ted Murray after an investigation disclosed a Boston matchmaker, John Buckley, who charged his fight cards were "sabotaged," did not have a contract with the New York middleweight.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Watch out for aphids on house plants, especially on ivy and geraniums. Spray with nicotine sulfate, taking care to cover the under sides of the leaves. The annual Mardi Gras Ball of the New York Junior League will be held on the night of Feb. 17 in the main ballroom of the Sheraton Astor Hotel. Mrs. W. Mahlon Dickerson is chairman of the executive committee for the fete, which, as in previous seasons, will be a benefit for the league's welfare trust fund.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- John Slezak, a colorful figure in the Eisenhower Administration, resigned as Under Secretary of the Army today.

Racing away for 52 points in the second half, Notre Dame's basketball team routed New York University, 93 to 74, in the twenty-second meeting in their rivalry at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The Touchdown Club honored many of the nation's football greats tonight and treated them to a dinner attended by supreme court justices, Senators and Congressmen.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Jan. 9 -- State policemen arrested Anthony Staikos, a cook, today and charged him with kidnapping 16-year-old Joel Robert Katz of Yonkers.
The New York Americans and the Brooklyn Hispanos played to a 5-5 tie in their American Soccer League game yesterday at Zerega Oval. The Americans led by 3 -- 2 at the turn.

The two most important financial news stories last week appeared within forty-eight hours of each other, and the central figure in each was the stock market. Both illustrated long-debated, and quite different, aspects of the market as an institution.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Jan. 8 -- The stopover of this Antarctic-bound Navy icebreaker at Wellington, N. Z., just completed, prompted many New Zealanders to exclaim that their country was about to lose by default a region of 175,000 square miles or so that successive New Zealand Governments have claimed.
Rudolf Kempe, the German conductor, will make his debut at the Metropolitan Opera in the season's first "Tannhaeuser," on Wednesday evening, Jan. 19.

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, former world champion, met some powerful opposition at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday in his first test at simultaneous play here against twenty-four players. They were seated at eighteen tables, including six consultation parties.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Five Japanese-American orphans who have been adopted by couples in the United States arrived here today by plane from Tokyo.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation has produced a set of television programs for small children so widely admired and gratefully received by British parents that they may be given a trial by some TV stations in the United States.

HONOLULU, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Quarterback Paul Larson of California and Fullback Carroll Hardy of Colorado passed and ran the college All-Stars to a 33-13 victory today over the Hawaii All-Stars in the ninth Hula Bowl game before 21,000.
The city's chief waterfront developer predicted yesterday that the Port of New York would experience "the greatest resurgence and increase in trade that it has known in many years."
ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 9 -- On Thursday a Swiss banking consortium win sponsor the issue of a 4 per cent 50,000,000 Swiss franc ($11,667,000) loan to the Compagnie Francaise des Petroles.

The Composers Forum presented its first opera at its concert at the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University Saturday night. It was Hugo Weisgall's "The Stronger," a twenty-five-minute work based on a two-character play by Strindberg.
FOR DIX, N. J., Jan. 9 -- Col. Earl L. Ringler, whose name Roy M. Cohn once threatened he would "not forget," has been promoted to deputy assistant commander of the Sixty-ninth Infantry Division.
In an attack yesterday upon the Russian interpretation of "peaceful coexistence," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman called upon church leaders to "mobilize the minds of men for peace."
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 7 -- Although the Dutch press has been reticent in recent weeks about guilder revaluation, the problem is still alive.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Harriman will send to the Senate for confirmation tomorrow night the nomination of his brother, E. Roland Harriman of Arden, as a member of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.
New York will honor today the lifeboat crew and two officers of the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda for the mid-ocean rescue of ten Newfoundland fishermen last Thursday.
The Samovar, a small, new establishment at 210 West Ninety-fourth Street, is a combination bakery and restaurant.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 9 -- A plan for unification of American Protestantism is in the hands of denominational leaders for study.
A hold-up suspect was wounded fatally last night in a pistol battle with two policemen. Eleven shots were fired outside a cigar store at Columbus Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 9 -- India has made it clear to Communist China that she favors an agreement leading to Peiping's release of imprisoned United States airmen as soon as possible.
PARIS, Jan. 9 -- The French National Assembly will reconvene Tuesday, with every party except that of the Communists divided.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Union Pacific's City of Saline puffed in today ten minutes ahead of time, marking the end of the era of steam locomotives in Union Station here.

Carefree family holiday celebrations may seem particularly remote to many parents and children as household routines once again become adjusted to school-time schedules, especially the evening homework sessions.
The increasing demand for tonnage on the West Coast has made shipowners happy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Government announced plans today to help private industry develop and operate experimental atomic power plants.

The five-story building at 9 East Forty-seventh Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, has been purchased by Leo Kossove, operator, from Louis Denberg and Hugh McGovern. It was renovated recently and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $137,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- The State Civil Defense Commission has distributed more than $1,600,000 worth of emergency medical supplies to ten major "target" cities of the state. Lieut. Gen. C. R. Huebner, the commission chairman, reported this today.
Recent years have seen the Yankees undergo a vast turnover in personnel. But in one department they haven't changed in six years and there won't be any change in 1955.

There was nothing equivocal about the British reply to a Soviet request for circulation of Vietminh charges of violation of the Geneva agreement. Since Britain had provided, along with the Soviet Union, a chairman for the Geneva conference, Moscow asked that Britain join in approaching the other conference members with the Communist attack on the French, Vietnamese and Americans, which had already been put out by the Vietminh radio broadcasts.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 9 (UP) -- Sam Snead, the defending champion, carded a 65 to take top pro honors in the one-day Macnaughton pro-amateur golf tourney here today.

During the past year 163 new oceangoing ships showed their pennants in the Port of New York and received the harbor's traditional warm welcome. The world's merchant marine long ago passed the pre-war mark in tonnage, and in most of the maritime men is the shipwrights and joiners are still busy, with more orders waiting.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Jan. 9 (AP) --Tony Callipare of Rochester won the senior men's title in the twenty-third annual Eastern States speed skating championships today. Gloria Beam of Grossinger captured the senior women's title.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 9 -- Stringent repressive measures by the Government of Premier Nuri as-Said have again forced Iraq's Communists underground and disrupted their drive for political power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Costa Rica said today she was threatened by "an army of adventurers training openly in Nicaragua." She will ask the Organization of American States to take action tomorrow to keep the peace.
GLEN HEAD, L. I., Jan. 9 -- A 13-year-old boy ambushed his stepmother here last night as she returned home from shopping, killing her at the front door with a single shot from a .22-calibre rifle.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 9 -- President Jose Figueres said today he awaited "with confidence" the outcome of the council's meeting.

The Emerald Association inducted Municipal Court Justice Harold J. Crawford of Queens as its president yesterday. Archbishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn presented the President's Medal to Justice Crawford. The ceremony took place at the Cathedral Club, 85 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn.
The City of New York has issued and awarded to twenty-three banks and trust companies an additional $10,000,000 of bond anticipation notes, Lawrence E. Gerosa, City Controller, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The establishment of a bipartisan commission to re-examine the entire Federal-security program will be proposed to the Senate tomorrow.
In one dim elegant room on Fourteenth Street last night everybody forgot about time.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9 -- The small decline in steel activity a few weeks ago has been followed by a sharp rebound after the holidays.

Before the largest turnout of the local National Hockey League season, the Canadiens of Montreal crushed the New York Rangers last night. The Flying Frenchmen, absolutely uncooperative before the 13,607 onlookers, rolled up a 7-to-1 triumph over the hapless New York sextet.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Eddie Moylan, little control specialist from Trenton, N. J., played his best in the clutch today to beat Bernard Bartzen for the men's championship in the annual Dixie tennis tournament.

A nation in which the citizens sense the true purpose of belief in God will have "a lively and sensitive conscience," the Rev. Robert J. McCracken said in a sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church.

GREELEY SQUARE ornithologists have been flocking to Gimbels' northernmost window since last Wednesday to study eight live flamingos splashing around in simulated native habitat before a resort-wear display.

CAIRO, Jan. 9 -- Jefferson Caffery, retiring United States Ambassador, received official recognition tonight for the major role he has played in improving relations among Egypt, the United States and its allies.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 9 -- The Steel Helmet, an ultra-nationalist veterans' organization, declared today that the German people saw no chance for survival in an atomic war and accordingly had no enthusiasm for a new German Army.
A Republican state Senator assailed yesterday Governor Harriman's references to housing in his Annual Message to the Legislature.
Teen-aged panelists on the New York Times Youth Forum agreed yesterday that a rearmed Germany was essential to world peace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A report criticizing frequent trips to Europe by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and his predecessors as damaging to the prestige of United States Ambassadors abroad was released today.

Last year the New York City taxpayer was presented with a bill for $300,000 to repair damage done to the public schools by vandals. An additional $200,000 had to be spent in the five boroughs to make good the ravages inflicted on park property by hoodlums and thoughtless, untrained youngsters. But there was one group of 102,203 boys too busy being Boy Scouts to be attracted by depredations.

ATHENS, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Opposition morning newspaper Eleftheria, under orders to stop printing reports about an Air Force controversy, hit back today at Premier Alexander Papagos' Government. The paper charged he had "perpetrated the greatest political deceit since Greece gained her independence."

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Harriman received a report today on plans now being made by the Port of New York Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to ease the flow of traffic into and out of the New York metropolitan area.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Although the stock markets have made a good start in the New Year they were subject last week to sharper fluctuations, than have been experienced for some time.

Recovered from the Nazis, a silver Kiddush cup formerly used in Jewish rituals in Germany to sanctify sacramental wine was given yesterday to Congregation B'nai Jeshurun on the occasion of its 130th anniversary.
The first steps toward final determination of the future control of this port's 4,000 tugboatmen will be taken today at the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Dave Volk, Baltimore cab driver, rolled a fifteen-game 2,010 last night to capture the twenty-fifth annual United States classic of the National Duckpin Bowling Congress.

Cotton prices moved in a wider trading range last week but net changes were insignificant. Active futures contracts traded on the New York Cotton Exchange closed Friday at prices 30 cents a bale lower to 5 cents a bale higher than a week earlier.

VIENNA, Jan. 9 -- Soviet initiative has waned in Central Europe since Tito defected from Moscow's military bloc and signed an alliance with Greece and Turkey. The "new course" policy instituted in the satellites after Stalin's death disclosed cracks in the monolithic empire. Once agreements to rearm Western Germany are ratified the Russian position will definitely shift to the defensive.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 9 -- Miss Louise Bogan and Miss Leonie Adams, both of New York, were named today to share the $1,000 Bollingen Prize in Poetry of the Yale University Library.
LEXINGTON. Ky., Jan. 9 (AP) -- "We will live on that one a long time."

FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Adolf Galland, one of Germany's leading air aces of World War II, came back to West Germany tonight amid reports that he would head a new air force in a rearmed Germany.
The Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences announced yesterday the election of Robert E. Gross, president and board chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, as its president for 1955.

The Ford Foundation's announcement today of $4,650,000 in grants to four law schools to help them in developing programs of international legal studies is of high importance. The primary purpose is "to develop greater understanding of international affairs among Americans trained in law."

NEXT to "Frankenstein," the most famous golem legend concerns the symbolical manmade robot that almost toppled the Prague court of Rudolph II in the late sixteenth century. The Czechs themselves are telling the story in "The Emperor and the Golem," which Artkino presented Saturday at the Stanley.
The two key proposals in Mayor Wagner's fiscal program for 1955-56 are being studied by the Joint Conference for Better Government in New York City.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday grants totalling $4,650,000 to spur training and research in international legal problems and issues of foreign policy.
MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- When does the Soviet Union expect the United States to launch the aggressive war that it has been repeatedly said here is being prepared? The answer seems to be: Not just yet.

The friendly controversy last fall about whether the AndoverExeter football game was the seventy-fourth in their series or the seventy-fifth continues. Lately, however, it has furnished the ammunition for conversation in another sphere.
ROME, Jan. 9 -- Dissension among leaders of the Italian Communist party became clearly visible today when two rebel chieftains openly snubbed Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- Roy Sherwood, national ski-jumping champion, who has been on the sidelines with an ailing knee, made his debut this winter a successful one today. He soared 151 feet to clinch the Franklin D. Roosevelt Trophy with the longest jump of the day.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- High tariffs as obstacles to freer trade in Europe will be discussed for the first time by the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation at its meeting here Thursday. The council will be asked to authorize retaliation when tariffs hamper the movement to abolish import quotas.
The city's litterbugs may soon be paying fines of at least $10, if Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain has his way.

TORONTO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- G. Diehl Mateer Jr., 26-year-old Philadelphia amateur, won the third annual pro-amateur squash racquets tournament here today. He defeated Azam Khan of Pakistan in the final at the Badminton and Racquet Club, 11 -- 5, 15 -- 11, 13 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 10.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- All the talk down here about President Eisenhower's "moderate progressivism" has, perhaps inevitably, produced a definition of an "immoderate progressive": A man who favors full unemployment with a guaranteed annual wage.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 -- The United States must do everything in its power to bring Israelis and Arabs to the same conference table, Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts said today.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A carnival dancer held in a second kidnapings within nineteen months was quoted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today as having explained both cases this way:
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Secret Service agents disclosed today that they had arrested twelve persons in breaking up a counterfeit ring with $300,000 in phony $20 bills.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins and the Toronto Maple Leafs battled to a 1-1 deadlock before a crowd of 10,552 in a National Hockey League game tonight.

The Russian Government's action in releasing two American citizens from its slave labor camps is the latest in a series of moves evidently designed to woo United States public opinion. After all the fervent Soviet denials that slave labor exists in Russia, it can have been no small decision for Moscow to decide to free these Americans who had witnessed for themselves the realities of one of the most dreaded slave labor camps, Vorkuta.

Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman yesterday became commander of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division of the Army Reserve. He succeeded Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, who retired last Dec. 31 after reaching the mandatory retirement age of 62 years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The American Chemical Society said today the new Office of Strategic Information would do "more harm than good."

I have read with some regret an Associated Press report in your paper regarding the war debts still owed by England to the United States. Anyone reading it and not being familiar with the facts could not be blamed if he were to say, "England does not pay her debts." May I therefore present those facts.
The Hanover Bank had a net profit in 1954 of $11,966,000, or $8.86 a share, according to the bank's annual report issued yesterday in advance of its annual meeting on Jan. 19.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 9 -- An Egyptian suffragette who won a promise of political rights for women with an eight-day hunger strike last year today assailed polygamy.

Even though tickets to the top-flight shows may seem to be nonexistent, Broadway the-atregoers will be able to see them out of town. Such a procedure will be inaugurated on Jan. 29 when the national company of "The Pajama Game" begins its tour in New Haven.

PANAMA, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Political tension developed tonight in the coalition Government of President Jose Ramon Guizado, which is trying to solve the mystery of who machine-gunned President Jose Antonio Remon to death a week ago.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Rival Republican and Democratic plans for liberalizing unemployment insurance benefits and coverage will be submitted formally to the Legislature tomorrow.
Four of the country's foremost traffic experts are studying the police traffic operation here with a view to a possible reorganization of the antiquated set-up.
Another ensemble from Italy lived up to its advance reputation when I Musici was presented in its United States debut late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by the Concert Society.
United States Attorney J. Edward Lumbard said yesterday that for maximum efficiency his office needed a $350,000 budget increase and a 50 per cent addition to his present staff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Military manpower, farm policy and the Administration's internal security program shaped up today as major issues on which President Eisenhower might be headed for trouble with the Democratic Eighty-fourth Congress.
The Liberal party sent yesterday to Governor Harriman and the Republican-controlled Legislature a program containing 200 recommendations.

BENGHAZI, Libya, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Libyan Premier Mustafa Halim said today France had agreed to withdraw her troops from the Fezzan province [diagonally shaded area on map] of this now independent kingdom.
Gottlieb Duttweiler, the low mark-up "rolling store" man from Switzerland, is carrying his long campaign for lower consumer prices to other lands.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Organized labor's No. 1 target today is not what it used to be.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System has behaved most sensibly with regard to its latest show. "Professional Father." Apparently powerless to keep the program off the air entirely, it has done the next best thing. It has scheduled the attraction opposite George Gobel on N. B. C. at 10 o'clock Saturday nights; this should serve almost as well.

The Interracial Fellowship Chorus showed again last night what an asset it is to the city's musical life. For its eighth annual winter concert, it engaged capable soloists and a good chamber orchestra and presented an uncut performance of "Judas Maccabaeus" that was a rare pleasure for the serious music lover.
A group of civil engineering students took to the air yesterday in their study of one of the most "down-to-earth" of the sciences -- geology.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Eisenhower will send to a receptive Congress tomorrow a special message detailing his recommendations for a liberalized foreign trade program.
One of the first signs of spring in fashion is the appearance of prints in the wardrobe.
Adlai E. Stevenson, titular leader of the Democratic party, will join in a non-political discussion on the "Conversation" radio program March 12.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland of California, indicated today he would renew his demand for a blackade of Communist China if the United Nations did not succeed in freeing imprisoned United States airmen.

George Romney, president of the American Motors Corporation, told stockholders in the annual report that increasing production of 1955 Nash and Hudson cars over the next few months should return operations to a profitable basis.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The new French plan for a European arms production pool has been received critically by the British Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- New Democratic members of Congress assailed Vice President Richard M. Nixon's campaign tactics today. They told each other that President Eisenhower's political popularity was not all it was believed to be.

The Right Rev. G. Ashton Oldham, who retired five years ago as Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Albany, began a second retirement yesterday. He preached his final sermon as temporary rector of the Church of the Ascension, at Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.

An apartment house for fifty-four families on plot 153 by 104 feet at 736 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of West 151st Street, has been sold by the Uptown Owners Corporation to an investing client of Oscar Goldberg in a deal negotiated by Pearce, Mayer Greer, brokers.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 9 (UP) -- A member of the Communist Vietminh delegation to last year's Geneva conference has fled Red-held North Vietnam and asked the French at Haiphong for political asylum, South Vietnamese officials said today.
LONDON, Jan. 9 (Reuters) -- The British Medical Journal asserted today that United States and British experiments had shown a "clear-cut relationship" between smoking and heart diseases.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Thailand and Burma, the two greatest rice exporting countries of Asia, have complained recently about the United States program for disposal of surplus agricultural products.
MOGADISHU, Trust Territory of Somaliland, Dec. 24 -- Future presidents, premiers and other officials of the nascent state of Somaliland are being groomed in a "school for statesmen" here.
The Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams said yesterday that the "popular belief" that God was being "mocked or sneered at" in the present day was wrong.
Forty-seven leading Americans urged yesterday that with some exceptions restrictions on trade with Communist nations be removed.
The return of West Germany to commercial aviation on April 1 will see all three of the Axis powers of World War II flying again for the first time since the end of the war.
The freshmen who "heel" for The Yale Daily News ofen go on to big things. John A Neumark of New York, now a sophomore at 19, already is cashing in on an idea he had last year.
The New York Knickerbockers yesterday came from 15 points back and defeated the Philadelphia Warriors, 86 -- 84, in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -Vice President Richard M. Nixon celebrated his forty-second birthday anniversary today by welcoming several freshmen Senators and their families to Washington.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 9 -- The conference on private investment in Latin America scheduled for the end of February in New Orleans has aroused keen interest in Brazil, where the need of more foreign capital is strongly felt.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 9 -- A law published today sets the peacetime active strength of Brazil's armed forces at about 250,000 exclusive of commissioned officers. The number of officers is not given.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 9 -- West Germany's new national radio station was unable to start broadcasting last week as planned because of a conflict over broadcasting freedom.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. MacCarthy, who has renewed his demand for a new Senate investigation of the Peress case, left Washington unexpectedly tonight for an undisclosed purpose.
The Transit Authority reviewed yesterday "with some satisfaction'' its first fiscal year, which ended last June 30.

Moderate gains in sales and earnings were made by Wilson Co., Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended last Oct. 30, according to the annual report of James D Cooney, president, released today.
The contract bridge champions of Europe last night took an early sixteen-hand lead of 1,570 points over the United States in the 1955 team-of-four world's championship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- An all-aluminum screen for drive- in theatres that reflects three times more light brightness than a normal white-paint screen is regarded by the Motion Picture Research Council as being the most important of ten "significant" motion-picture developments achieved by the organization in 1954.

Having staged the successful Broadway production of "The Fifth Season," Gregory Ratoff has purchased the screen rights to Sylvia Regan's comedy. Mr. Ratoff will not only attend to the direction of the picture in the CinemaScope process, but he will also act the part in which Menasha Skulnik scored.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- William F. Knowland, Senate Republican leader, sidestepped questions today whether he would support President Eisenhower for renomination.
The Rev. Harry J. Wolff, in sermon yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, said that "there are far too many broken homes in America."

Solomon, that most civilized of pianists, gave a recital Saturday evening before a sold-out audience at the Hunter College Auditorium. A finished workman, a pianist of taste, Solomon instills in his listeners a comfortable feeling of security.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 5 -- Tuskegee Institute's George Washington Carver Foundation is the central source in this country of HeLa cells, currently being used in the evaluation tests of the Salk polio vaccine.
Jesus Christ made himself history's greatest security risk, the Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay declared in a sermon yesterday.

Carol Smith, contralto, gave her second Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon. She is no strange to the local scene, having given a previous recital in 1951 and having made frequent appearances with the Bach Aria Group.
Retailers are concerned about expenses, but are confident that they will improve sales and profits in the first half of 1955, according to a survey by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 8 (AP) -- German stock exchanges registered an unprecedented postwar bull market in 1954, with gains averaging 70 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP) -Gene Littler of Palm Springs, Calif., won the top money in the $32,500 Los Angeles open golf tournament today with a final 2under-par 69 for a 72-hole score of 276.
Boys from the poorer sections of New York and Boston will enjoy two-week vacations this summer as a result of the fourth annual theatre benefit for Brantwood Camp, Peterboro, N. H.

DUMONT, N. J., Jan. 10 -- An official of the New York Central Railroad told a public meeting here tonight that the trend to bus travel made it necessary for the line to eliminate its West Shore passenger service and its ferry service from Weehawken to Cortlandt and Forty-second Streets, New York.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Intense competition will continue in the appliance industry, D. A. Packard, general sales manager of the Kelvinator division of the American Motors Corporation, said here today.
While the average cook may think of vinegars as pretty much alike, the epicure recognizes great nuances.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 10 -- Thailand's problem of evacuating 50,000 Vietnamese refugees may be handed to the Foreign Ministers of the eight Manila Pact nations when they meet here Feb. 23. Their conference is designed to set up a collective defense apparatus for Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has "an inescapable statutory duty to examine" the legality of the Dixon-Yates private power contract, the State of Tennessee contended today.
Business groups favoring freer trade policies were encouraged yesterday by the President's bid for tariff cuts.

In his first message to the Legislature Governor Harriman sketched a program for dealing with the problem of mental health that deserves public understanding and support. In this program he emphasized measures of prevention. A large proportion of the inmates of the state's hospitals would have been spared a harrowing experience -- and the state saved the expense of their upkeep and treatment -- had their troubles been diagnosed and treated when they first began.

The mission of Secretary General Hammarskjold to Peiping for the liberation of imprisoned American fliers and other United Nations personnel has ended with results still to be disclosed. The trip itself, and the length of his conferences with Premier Chou En-lai, testify to the earnestness of Mr. Hammarskjold's effort to carry out the United Nations resolution.
TRENTON, Jan. 10 -- The Legislature met here today long enough to aid the widow of a state employe who died 138 minutes too soon for her to collect nearly $10,000 in annuity benefits.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- British defense leaders view a major war as unlikely before 1960 because of the United States' continuing strategic-bombing lead over the Soviet Union, reports here say.

Calvin MacCracken, seeded No. 1, advanced to the third round of the New York State singles squash racquets championship yesterday. The Princeton Club player turned back J. C. Botts of the same club, 16 -- 14, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 12, at the Downtown Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- If those slaves to habit, the Democratic and Republican National Committees, actually summon the courage to execute their announced plans, the assembly dates of the two major political conventions in 1956 will make sense for the first time since the age of electronics and safe aviation began.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 10 -India and the United States are about to resume six-year-old negotiations for a treaty of friendship. On both sides there is a feeling of confidence that the pact will be signed soon.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, which banned television coverage some years ago on the theory that it hurt box-office receipts, will stage a special show for home views on March 29 from 8 to 9 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Senate made it certain today that it intended to get to the bottom of the Peress case.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 10 -- Yugoslavia and Communist China announced today that they had established diplomatic relations.

Nearly 100 of Staten Island's gasoline station and garage operators assembled yesterday for the first briefing in the city on operation of the new motor vehicle inspection law. The first question from the floor was:
January is a good month in which to resolve to check the home and make repairs to eliminate causes of accidents, it is pointed out by the National Safety Council.
St. Francis College of Brooklyn defeated Fairleigh Dickinson of Rutherford, N. J., 61 -- 52, at the Second Corps Armory last night. A crowd of 1,000 witnessed the contest.
There was an authentic note of exuberance in the "Young in Heart" collection presented yesterday by the milliner William J.
A "corporation" of children in Northampton, Mass., shared some of its year's profits with the New York Times Neediest Cases in spite of serious shortages incurred at Christmas time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 -The National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, unaffiliated, withdrew today from an election to determine a collective bargaining agent for unlicensed seagoing personnel on the West Coast.
