WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Eisenhower Administration is expected to recommend that retail and service employes be brought under the Fair Labor Standards (wage and hour) Act.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. 10 (AP) -Four motions filed by The Kansas City Star in the government's anti-trust suit against the newspaper were overruled today by United States District Judge Richard M. Duncan.
The Very Rev. James A. Pike, dean of New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine), sharply criticized Christian laymen yesterday for not taking a more active part in the ideological war on communism.
A contribution of $8,074 from The New York Times to the scholarship fund of the Fashion Institute of Technology was announced yesterday by Dr. Lawrence L. Bethel, president of the institute.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 10 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas announced today the first Cabinet reorganization since he took office Sept. 1 last. No reason was given for the shake-up.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- High world prices for cocoa are financing development projects in the Trust Territory of Togoland under British administration, according to a supplementary report on the area released today.

Seton Hall University, sporting a 10-1 won-lost record, will meet Wake Forest in the feature game of a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. Iona College will oppose St. Bonaventure in the opening contest at 7:45.

Four men charged by the Waterfront Commission with engaging in "a conspiratorial plot" to obtain a permanent license to operate the New York Port Stevedoring Company moved yesterday to withdraw the application.
More power to Mayor Wagner, who has given the go-ahead signal to the Sanitation Department to fine all litter-bugs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- The United States will pass up a delegate's seat, but will send an observer to the first session of the newly established Commission on International Commodity Trade. The Commission will open its meetings here next Monday.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 10 (AP) -- More than 100 Argentine magazines suspended publication today. They took this drastic action in an effort to force a showdown on a three-month-old dispute over who would distribute their copies outside the city of Buenos Aires.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -President Eisenhower submitted to the Senate again today the nomination of Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
Johnny Podres, one of the youngest regular pitchers in the major leagues, signed his 1955 Brooklyn Dodger contract yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A $12,000,000 anti-trust suit against thirteen major league baseball teams may be dismissed on a compromise settlement payment of $200,000. The suit was filed three years ago by the now bankrupt Liberty Broadcasting System of Dallas.
Retailers were told yesterday to prepare for better business.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold ended his mission to Peiping today. He held his fourth and last meeting with Chou Enlai, Premier of Communist China, in an attempt to obtain the release of United Nations prisoners captured during the Korean war.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- A plan to dress up the General Assembly Hall has been quietly shelved. The reasons are mainly artistic, but also political.

Manufacturers Trust Company had net operating earnings of $14,807,253, or $5.88 a share last year, compared with $14,636.023 or $5.81 a share in 1953. There were 2,519,500 shares of stock outstanding at the end of both periods.

Shaw's "The Doctor's Dilemma" will be revived tonight at the Phoenix Theatre by T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton. Because of the play's great length, the producers stress that the opening night curtain will rise promptly at 8 o'clock.
A 9-year-old boy was revived by artificial respiration yesterday after almost drowning in the first few minutes of his first swimming lesson.

The letter of Augustin G. Rudd published Dec. 31 displays a lack of understanding of the concept of free inquiry in the free society. It might be well to point out, if in only a small way, some of the more obvious faults of the views expressed there.

The improvement in the prospects of the President's trade and tariff program can be partially measured by comparing the timetable for last year and this. On Jan. 23, 1954, the President's Commission on Foreign Economic Policy, headed by Clarence B. Randall, issued a report which has formed the basis for the Administration's proposals in this field.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) -Representative James P. Richards, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, charged today that President Eisenhower's promised bipartisan approach to foreign policy has been nothing but "talk."
GENEVA, Jan. 10 -- The world is likely to have a troublesome surplus of "legal" opium soon, the United Nations Permanent Central Opium Board believes.

The six-story loft building with stores on plot 50 by 100 feet at 28-30 West Twenty-second Street has been sold by Duo Equities, Inc., to M. Z. Berger Co. The buyer, an importer of watches, hardware and general merchandise, will occupy a portion of the building in conjunction with its affilitate, the Better Homes Tool Company.

The weather man has been even more unpleasant than usual this winter. Well, nothing is gained by indulging in personalities, so let it be said that the man's boss, nature, has risen to new heights of disagreeableness. New heights even for nature.
Please permit both a correction of fact and a slight amendment to statements in Topics of The Times of Jan. 5 concerning the tenth anniversary of the Battle of Bastogne.
The nation's retailers were advised yesterday to spurn any "bait" offered them by the Administration to bring their industry under minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act.
Many students in the city's high schools lack a sense of responsibility, have little respect for school authority and have poor reading ability.

Sound evidence that simple safety measures rather than grandiose programs hold the answer to cutting highway accidents has been provided by the experiment of painting white lines to mark the outer edges of roads. A small section of Westchester County's Hutchinson River Parkway so treated reduced mishaps by 50 per cent and Connecticut has broadened an initial test program to paint the full length of its Merritt-Wilbur Cross Parkway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Federal Trade Commission, reversing a previous opinion, today held that the Eastman Kodak Company of Rochester, N. Y., may lawfully maintain its fair trade contracts with retailers.
ROME, Jan. 10 -- French Premier Pierre Mendes-France arrived in Rome by auto tonight for two days of negotiations with the Italian Government.
Two mass blood donations will be received in Queens today by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
WASHINGTON Jan. 10 -- President Eisenhower gave a stag dinner of unusual interest tonight.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 10 -- With Forward John De Voe hitting for a personal record of 24 points, Princeton's basketball team stopped Dartmouth, 65 -- 50, in an Ivy League contest in Dillon Gym tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that contingent bequests to charity, the actual value of which could not be determined in advance, were not deductible for Federal estate tax purposes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -Thomas E. Dewey came out "prayerfully" tonight for an Eisenhower -Nixon ticket in 1956.

The United States bridge squad, after a near-disastrous setback Sunday, rallied yesterday to whittle 1,350 points from the 2,870-point lead amassed by its aggressive British opponents in the 1955 team-of-four contract bridge world championship.
DETROIT, Jan. 10 -- Carburetor modification to reduce smog-producing automobile exhaust was forecast today by several industry engineers and experts.

Mike Wolk, the defending 100-yard breaststroke champion, led a field of six into qualifying berths in the opening day of trials for the Public School Athletic League individual titles yesterday at Brooklyn Tech. The trials will continue daily through Thursday. The finals will be staged Jan. 28 at New York University.
MOOSONEE, Ont., Jan. 7 -- Indian trappers and white settlers and their families crowded a Quonset hut last night to watch an outstanding repertory company perform George Bernard Shaw's "St. Joan."
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Democratic legislative leaders today challenged Republican charges that they had failed to show any interest in middle-income housing.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff expressed here tonight his "grave concern" over the financing of the New England Thruway in Connecticut and disclosed what he proposed to do about it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -Sales, gifts and bartering have resulted in actual or proposed disposal abroad of almost $671,000,000 worth of surplus farm products, President Eisenhower told Congress today.

GYOR, Hungary, Jan. 10 (AP)--Hungarian peasants, victims of the 1954 Danube flood, expressed "warmest thanks and deep gratitude" to the people of the United States today for wheat and corn distributed by the Red Cross in this provincial town.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The United States intends soon to press Moscow for the release of Pvt. William Verdine of Starks, La.

Special diversions are being planned for the annual Blue Ridge Ball, which will be held on Jan. 28 in the ballroom of the Pierre. The dinner dance, the forty-fifth entertainment of its kind, will benefit the Blue Ridge School at St. George, Greene County, Va.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 -- Warner Brothers is talking with Van Johnson about playing the lead opposite Jane Wyman on "Miracle in the Rain." The romantic drama is an adaptation of a story written some years ago by Ben Hecht.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Georgia Kaolin Company lost in the Supreme Court today an attempt to collect $1,261,000 from the Federal Government because of damage to minerals lands by artillery practice at Camp Wheeler.
This is the season when baseball's two major leagues publish their official championship schedules for the forthcoming campaign.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 10 -- The extent of West German economic recovery was questioned today. Der Volkswirt, an authoritative publication devoted to economic and financial studies, said in an article by Dr. Kurt Richebaecher that the methods used by German statisticians to calculate the gross national product produced a result that did not correspond to reality.

THERE is no objection whatever to receiving gifted ensembles from abroad with hospitality, but it would be well not to lose sight of the accomplishments of our own artists. The Musicians Guild is a case in point, and its fine concert at Town Hall last night was further evidence, if proof be needed.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Police squads besieged today the Chacachacare Island leper colony, whose 300 patients seized control of the institution from the staff and declared themselves "on strike."
A welfare fund for employes of the Metropolitan Opera Association will be established with proceeds from the benefit performance of Strauss' "Arabella" at the Metropolitan on Thursday, Feb. 10.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Jan. 10 (AP) -- George W. Norgan of this city, who is accused by the United States of failing to pay millions in income taxes from lush liquor profits during World War II, today denied the charges. He said he would fight a $10,000,000 tax lien.

The First Boston Corporation and associated underwriters will market today $40,000,000 of 3 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds, due in 1975, of the Duke Power Company. The securities are priced at 100.751 to yield an interest return of about 2.95 per cent.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- British officials welcomed today the foreign economic policy outlined to Congress by President Eisenhower.
"Dylan Thomas: A Literary Study," by Derek Stanford, will be published Monday by Citadel Press. The author, who is a poet, examines Thomas' verse, prosewritings, film-scenarios and dramatic works.
CAIRO, Jan. 10 -- Discovery of a potentially rich oil pool in the Sinai Peninsula of Egypt was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner today ordered the P. D. Manufacturing Company, Inc., of 19-02 Steinway Street, Astoria, Queens, New York, to stop selling automotive products to competing purchasers at different prices.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- A bill providing for the sale of milk in New York state in one gallon containers Was introduced tonight by Assemblyman Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn.
JONES BEACH, L. I., Jan. 10 -- An Air Force C-46 cargo plane crashed in the Atlantic Ocean six and a half miles southwest of here at 7:30 o'clock tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Supreme Court rejected today an attempt by New York City to establish a right to collect a privilege tax upon the gross receipts of a New Jersey corporation.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 10 -- At least 100 Communist Chinese planes pounded the Tachen Islands from dawn until late afternoon today in one of the biggest air raids of the civil war, the Defense Ministry announced.

NEWARK, Jan. 10 -- Anthony P. Miele of West Orange announced today his resignation as Essex County Republican Chairman because of "increasing personal business obligations." In a letter to 2,000 members of the Essex Clean Government Organization and of the Republican County Committee, Mr. 35iele declared that his business interests, which include a joint business venture with his brother Joseph in South America, made his resignation necessary now.

The city's shipping industry turned out in force yesterday morning to pay tribute to the heroic lifeboat crew of the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda for its mid-ocean rescue last week of ten Newfoundland fishermen.

The days are long since gone when a quarrel between two Latin-American countries, however small, can be shrugged off as a local incident of minor importance. Today all twentyone nations of the Organization of American States are directly concerned in the complaint of Costa Rica against Nicaragua.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 10 (UP) -- The Foxcatcher Farm's Parlo, the 1954 3-year-old filly champion, was the first thoroughbred named for the $25,000 added New Castle and the $110,000 added Delaware Handicaps under a unique "bargain rate" nomination plan announced today by Delaware Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -A top White House aide disclosed today some details of the religious life of President Eisenhower. He told how the President revised his State of the Union Message last week to emphasize a conviction that "man's spirit must be released for his work here on earth."
BONN, Germany, Jan. 10 -- A Communist version of "Hansel and Gretel" is being presented as a play behind the Iron Curtain.

PANAMA, Jan. 10 (AP) -- President Jose Ramon Guizado announced in a nation-wide broadcast tonight that Panama's new treaty with the United States covering use of the Panama Canal would be signed Jan. 25.

Three relatively minor changes recommended by the American Football Coaches Association last week were discussed for the first time by the National Collegiate Athletic Conference Rules Committee yesterday at the New Yorker.

Producers of apparel accessories exhibiting at the Boys Apparel Buyers Association's show at the Commodore Hotel said yesterday that retailers were ordering substantial quantities for February and March delivery. Shirt, pajama, belt, slack and tie manufacturers reported that stores wanted immediate delivery as well as apparel for pro-Easter selling.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Miss Jean Whitney's scheduled wedding is off and her fiance and his brother face arraignment tonight in connection with an alleged attempt to bilk her of $11,000 in a fake hold-up.
PARIS, Jan. 10 -- Spain and Yugoslavia are seeking to become members of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation. The organization now has seventeen members.

The number of ship-borne or air-borne passengers using the Port of New York last year increased almost 10 per cent over 1953, Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs, reported here yesterday. He listed 2,013,541 travelers, compared with 1,926,053 in 1953.

THE selection of Rembrandt etchings at Robert McDonald's, '55 East Fifty-fifth Street, is a small one, but, as the artist's mastery and poignant feeling are revealed in every line he ever drew, the size hardly matters.

Loomis J. Grossman, real estate operator and investor, has sold the gasoline station at Jerusalem Avenue and Hawthorne Street in Hempstead, L. I., to an investing client of George Kean Co. The property is under lease to the Esso Standard Oil Company. Heller Grossman were attorneys for the buyer.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Westchester imposed its first ban today on the use of a county park by nonresidents. The Board of Supervisors directed unanimously that only Westchester residents be admitted this year to the Saxon Woods golf course in Scarsdale.

Aluminium Limited, the world's second largest producer of aluminum ingot, is expanding today its outstanding common stock by 904,314 new shares in a move to raise about $41,000,000 to enlarge power generation facilities at the company's smelter plant at Kitimat, B. C.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Eddie Erdelatz denied tonight that he had ever mentioned terms and money of a contract reportedly offered him by the Los Angeles Rams to leave the Naval Academy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -Following is a brief glossary of some technical terms used by President Eisenhower in his special message today:

The seven New York daily newspapers did rather well in 1954, in comparison with the year before. Five of the seven had increases in linage. The seven papers printed 152,989,095 lines of advertising, against 149,493,117 in 1953, an increase of 2.34 per cent, according to a study based on figures supplied by Media Records.

Acting with unusual dispatch, the National Labor Relations Board cleared the way yesterday for continued collective bargaining relations between this port's tugboat owners and Local 333, United Marine Division of the American Federation of Labor.
Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today.

THE latest compilation of world records for salt water fish, by the International Game Fish Association, indicates that 1954 was an exciting angling year for at least forty-two anglers who attained the "record book."

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- A letter from Guy de Moncy Burgess, a Foreign Office official who disappeared in May, 1951, and is believed to be serving Russia behind the Iron Curtain, was received by his mother here on Christmas Day.
With several months of winter still ahead of us homemakers might wish to take stock of their house heating to determine fuel costs and wastage and how both might be reduced.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Tom Heinsohn scored 35 points for Holy Cross tonight as the Crusaders avenged their Sugar Bowl loss to Notre Dame by routing the Irish, 93 -- 57. It was the first Holy Cross basketball victory over Notre Dame in five games dating from 1934.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- There were signs tonight that Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersesy, might tone down his scheduled fight to remove Senator Joseph R. McCarthy from the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 -- The Methodist Church in the United States is "in the midst of the greatest building boom in its history," the Rev. Dr. Earl R. Brown of New York said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review the conviction of thirteen Communist leaders for conspiracy to advocate the violent overthrow of the Government of the United States.
"Salome" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening, with Clifford Harvuot singing the role of Jochanaan for the first time with the company.
An army of insects large enough to denude a small park while living, but now safely mounted for scientific research, has been left to the American Museum of Natural History.
The Alrae Hotel, 37 East Sixty-fourth Street, was revisited early yesterday by three hold-up men who had taken $4,000 in cash and jewels from the hotel safe on Columbus Day.

Symphony No. 10 by Dmitri Shostakovich was selected yesterday by the New York Music Critics Circle as the finest orchestral work introduced here last year. The Russian composer's work won the symphonic award on the first ballot at the Circle's annual award meeting in the clubroom of The New York Times.

Edward B. Schulkind, in a letter published Dec. 9, discusses the relationship of the courts to arbitration and takes issue with the views expressed by Samuel H. Hofstadter, judge of the Supreme Court of New York, which appeared a short time earlier.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Nassau Republican legislators decided today to press for restoration of the former New York City and Nassau County shares of race track revenue.
There was little change in sales and earnings for the Glidden Company in the fiscal year ended last Oct. 31, according to the annual report.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 10 (UP) -- A twin-engined National Airlines Lodestar burst into flames on takeoff here today, but the ten passengers and three crewmen escaped the gasolinefed fire without injury. The plane exploded.

Yesterday the Department of Air Pollution Control started one of its "drives," sending teams of inspectors out on foot and in cars to look for violators. If this is more effective than the usual methods the question can be immediately raised why isn't it done that way year-round? Yesterday fifty-one violation notices (to first offenders) and seventeen summonses were served, about four times the daily average.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Ted Atkinson was booed loud and long by the majority in the crowd of 10,668 at Tropical Park today. The jeering came when his mount, Belair Stud's Ambient, a 9-to-20 favorite, finished second to J. M. Seider's Uncle Gus in the featured seventh race.

MINEOLA L. I., Jan. 10 -- Kenneth R. Corcoran Jr., the 13-yearold Glen Head boy who killed his stepmother Saturday night with a .22 caliber rifle, is being held for a hearing in Nassau County Children's Court here on a juvenile delinquency charge.
Stocks opened sharply higher yesterday, held about even to noon and then pushed gently upward for the balance of the session on the New York Stock Exchange.

Bobby Bell, Youngstown, Ohio, featherweight, extended his winning streak to nine last night by gaining a unanimous decision over Rudy Garcia of Los Angeles in the ten-round feature at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.
The storm raged. The mountain labored and brought forth a mouse. That seems to be the procedure of the Transit Authority -- they are offering to print timetables.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Republican legislative leaders asked today for a list of projects affected by Governor Harriman's order blocking new construction contracts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- President Eisenhower's new foreign aid requests, if approved, would push total United States gifts and loans to other nations to more than $50,000,000,000 since World War II ended.
A pickle works, a bakery and a freighter were snared yesterday in the net of air pollution control inspectors in the first day of a two-week drive on smoke offenders.

Howard Cann and Ken Norton, basketball coaches at New York University and Manhattan, respectively, have been complaining about the new bonus foul rule. eYsterday, they agreed to act in an effort to have the regulation eliminated.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Jan. 10 -The Monmouth County grand jury will meet in special session tomorrow to consider the kidnap charge against Anthony Staikos, unemployed cook of Matawan Township, N. J. He is accused of kidnapping Joel R. Katz, 16year-old Yonkers high school student, last Friday.

Total assets of the Lehman Corporation, one of the nation's largest closed-end investment trusts, aggregated $190,329,780 on Dec. 31, Robert Lehman, president, and Monroe C. Gutman, chairman of the executive committee, reported to stockholders yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Members of the House of Representatives introduced 1,738 bills on opening day when the Eighty-fourth Congress convened Jan. 5.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Amateur space-flight enthusiasts here are complaining that Government security measures have put an end to "all free discussion" of topics relating to astronautics, satellite observation vehicles and other aspects of guided missiles.

Laddie Northridge followed a garden theme in his spring and summer millinery collection shown yesterday at the Pierre Hotel by matching the colors of earth, sun and blossoms in organdy, silk and straw.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for new power to reduce foreign trade barriers.

SHORTLY after D. H. Lawrence's death in 1930 the literary vultures began to gather. Women who had worshiped him from afar, or from close up, squabbled in print about who had understood him best. They could not deny that he had loved his wife devotedly, but they quarreled over his literary remains. The spectacle, says Harry T. Moore, was enough to make Lawrence seem ridiculous, too, and did his reputation great disservice.

Kid Gavilan, the Cuban who used to hold the welterweight championship of the world, signed yesterday to meet Ernie Durando, Bayonne middleweight, at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 4. The contest will be fought over the ten-round route.
Johnny Brown, Chicago welterweight, and Hector Constance of Trinidad fought to a draw in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short term borrowing costs had gone up after dipping for two weeks.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 10 -- Yale University has received from the John A. Hartford Foundation a $3,160,000 grant for research and training in biophysics. This includes $460,000 for construction of a research laboratory on the foundation's property in Valhalla, N. Y.
The landlord of a Harlem tenement, where a tenant was burned fatally on Dec. 23, was indicted yesterday for manslaughter.

Wool prices broke sharply yesterday in early trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. The activity was influenced by reports that prices at the Austrailan auctions, which reopened yesterday after about a month's suspension, were unchanged to 5 per cent lower than at the previous sales. London prices also were easier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Eisenhower's recommendations on tariff policy in his special message today amounted to an appeal for continuation of a program instituted twenty years ago under Franklin D. Roosevelt.
The annual entertainment known as Le Bal Blanc will be held on Thursday night in the ballroom of the Ambassador for the benefit of the House of Free Russia, Inc.
Approval of the merger of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company with the American Home Assurance Company was announced yesterday by William S. Youngman Jr., chairman of both companies.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

One of the final acts of the retiring Italian Ambassador, Alberto Tarchiani, yesterday was to decorate E. Roland Harriman, chairman of the American National Red Cross. Ambassador Tarchiani presented, at the Pierre Hotel, the Merit Gold Medal of the Italian Red Cross in recognition of the aid given in the last two years by the American Red Cross to Italian flood victims.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Alben W. Barkley, former Vice President of the United States, now returned as "the junior" Senator from Kentucky, got back his old major committee posts today.

The President has sent a lengthy and detailed accounting to Congress of the progress that has been made to date in disposing of surplus farm commodities abroad. This progress report covers the first six months of operation under the legislation passed by Congress granting the Administration this authority.
Ten of the fourteen cash prizes awarded to architecture students in the latest competition of the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design have been captured by the University of Illinois.
The $10 to $25 "stiff" fine proposed by Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain for litterbugs may be just a bit stiffer than the city can enforce.

Residents of this area have contributed $350,000,000 to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York in the sixteen campaigns it has conducted since 1939. This was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of its board of directors at 220 West Fifty-eighth Street.

MEMORIAL exhibitions of paintings by two artists opened yesterday at the Riverside Museum, 310 Riverside Drive. The work and careers of the two present certain points of similarity, but diverged greatly in development.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Alleghany Corporation, in the Supreme Court today, lost an attempt to force the James Foundation of New York to deliver stock that involved possible control of the Western Pacific Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Council of the Organization of American States called on Nicaragua and Costa Rica today to take steps to avoid any aggravation of tension.
The woman who holds the scales of justice has become a reality instead of a symbol in City Court, and her name, appropriately, is Justice Amsterdam.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Prices for all grains turned weak today after a period of early steadiness, the demand being quickly satisfied. Late in the session it became apparent that holders generally were discouraged, and there was further long liquidation.

The congratulations of the New York community go out to the Young Women's Christian Association as it begins a series of observances of its centennial year. Appropriately, the main goal of the centenary will be the strengthening of the Y. W. C. A. program here and overseas.

Fordham University's basketball team scored its highest total this season by defeating the Wagner quintet, 81-62, on the Rams' home court last night. The Rams' previous high was 78 points in their victory over Yale.
John Frederics looked to the stock market for the names of his new spring millinery on display yesterday.
TORONTO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- One of the causes of the failure of many immigrant families to establish themselves in new ventures in Canada is homesickness on the part of the wives.

Events today: Herbert Burtis, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Julian Olevsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Glenn Gould, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Sylvia Marlowe, harpsichordist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:40.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today on foreign economic policy:

The Department of Agriculture announced yesterday the sale to Turkey of $12,400,000 worth of surplus American wheat, oats and barley. Half of it will be transported in American-flag vessels under the so-called "fifty-fifty" law.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 1 -- Indian students who toured the Soviet Union have come away with suitcases full of expensive souvenirs, a dash of economic envy and a collection of doubts.

THE Yankees made considerable fuss about the signing of Casey Stengel's coaching staff for still another year. They should because the Bronx Bombers have full reason to be proud of contributions which have been made by Messrs. Frank Crosetti, Bill Dickey and Jim Turner. This trio comes close to ranking at the top of what is now regarded as a highly competitive and highly specialized field.

A new one-story building at 99 North First Street in Brooklyn has been leased by the Sandler Medical Gases, Inc., from the Kraman Realty Corporation. The lessee will use the premises for the processing and distribution of medical and commercial gases. The Kalmon Dolgin Company was the broker in the transaction.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Governor Harriman warned his department heads today that he would not stand for any of their subordinates treating state posts as part-time jobs.

OTTAWA, Jan. 10 -- The Canadian Government introduced legislation today to prevent the use of Canadian water to generate power for factories in the United States. The bill specifies that a Federal lease is necessary for any construction affecting the natural flow of an international river.

A new program of expansion at Montauk, L. I., has been announced by the Montauk Beach Company. A cabana layout for the Montauk Surf Club is estimated to cost more than $100,000. It has been designed by Robert Fitch Smith of Miami, Fla., architect.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 11 -- A rebel force attacked and occupied the Costa Rican town of Villa Quesada shortly after dawn today.
A 22-YEAR-OLD pianist from Toronto named Glenn Gould played a debut recital of unusual promise at Town Hall last evening.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- William A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, says his company may have to decide this year whether to buy a fleet of jet airplanes for commercial use.
Monday's collection for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 365 pints of blood, including 133 taken at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I.
New York hotel workers will get pensions in a novel television ceremony Feb. 11.

Following is the text of the address by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, entitled "The Peace We Seek," delivered at the centennial inaugural luncheon of the Young Women's Christian Association of the United States at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday:
Beginning with the Feb. 13 contest against Montreal, the New York Rangers will start their remaining Sunday night National Hockey League home games at 7 o'clock at Madison Square Garden.

Sylvia Marlowe is one of our most distinguished harpsichordists and last night an audience with many celebrities packed Carnegie Recital Hall to hear her. Couperin, Rameau, Bach and Scarlatti were her early composers, John Lessard and Alexei Haieff her moderns.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped 25 to 50 cents today as 17,000 salable head were unloaded on the market. At the close just about all offerings showed the 50 cents decline.
Commonwealth Edison Company borrowed $50,000,000 in the public market yesterday on 3 1/3 per cent fifty-year sinking fund debentures at a net interest cost of 3.156 per cent.

Early in 1954 the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate approved a rezoning of retail districts, with major attention on Times Square, to prevent further invasion of objectionable use of property for business of a honky-tonk variety.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The free world's goodwill and President Eisenhower's "atoms-for-peace" plan are the United States' most hopeful assets in the "cold war," Lewis L. Strauss said today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 -- The Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals was petitioned today to stop a National Labor Relations Board election among West Coast unlicensed seagoing personnel.
Design interest was centered on the midriff in yesterday's showing of spring bridal fashions at Ohrbach's.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Marty Marion, the former Mr. Short-I stop of the'St Louis Cardinals,I today finally became the official 1955 manager of the Chicago White Sox. He predicted a pen-] nant season for the Pale Hose.

The University of Kentucky remained the nation's No. 1 college basketball team yesterday in the weekly Associated Press poll, but rival Southeastern Conference teams will have a chance to knock the Wildcats from the top rung during the next few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, demanded today a full investigation into what he called "the unusual procedure" of a Government agency selecting a high bidder to negotiate for buildling grain elevators in Pakistan.
Night baseball in the National League will make a listed gain of eleven games in 1955, according to the schedule released yesterday.
Eight more city agencies appeared yesterday before Budget Director Abraham D. Beams to explain why they need increased allowances for 1955-56.

Material for thirteen advertisements, ranging from one-inch items to 1,000-line displays, has been sent to 5,000 dailies and weeklies throughout the country in an intensive drive to help restore freedom of the press behind the Iron Curtain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The United States brushed aside today a charge by the Soviet Union that Brig. Gen. John D. Stevenson had threatened an atomic bomb attack on Russia.
Return to the city of its former full 5 per cent pari-mutuel race track tax, yielding about $12,000,000 annually, will be part of the city's legislative program this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Senate Republicans began today to exploit, to the discomfiture of the Democratic leadership, the existing division within the Congressional and organizational wings of the Democratic party.

The six-story apartment house accommodating eighty - three families at 595 East 170th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Cottage Realty Company to the Arnoll Realty Corporation for cash above mortagages of $249,657.
Westchester County was accused yesterday New York's City Council of possible "discrimination and segregation in its ban on non-resident golfers from the Saxon Woods Golf Course.

Eight of the nation's major municipal housing authorities having subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration borrowed $118,060,000 yesterday on serial bonds maturing over forty years at an average interest cost of 2.3376 per cent.
WEATHER provided the real waterfowl conservation factor during the late and somewhat lamented duck season, according to letters from wildfowlers from Maine to North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Eisenhower is expected to disclose tomorrow Administration measures to improve the controversial loyalty-security program. The White House has under way a series of minor reforms designed to make the security check fairer to individuals.
Wearable little hats were shown in the Beatrice Martin collection presented yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 -- The United Steelworkers, C. I. O., today started a program of attitude research to find out what members thought about about their union, the services it provided and the conduct of its affairs.
A home-made bomb exploded in a parcel locker in the Long Island Rail Road promenade of Pennsylvania Station during rush hour last night. No one was hurt and there was little hubbub among commuters.

The $1,426,000 fireboat John D. McKean was delivered to the city more than four months ago and hasn't yet fought a fire. Officially the 128-foot boat is still "undergoing tests," but it became known yesterday that embarrassed city officials fear the highly touted fire-fighter is a lemon. speeds required for fireboats she shook so badly that the engineers feared for the integrity of her plumbing system and slowed her down.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Soviet Union agreed today to release the last of three Americans held several years in Soviet labor camps. He is Pvt. William A. Verdine of Starks, La.
The election of Gottlieb Hammer as president of the American Israeli Shipping Company, representatives here for the Zim-Israel Navigation Company, was announced yesterday.

J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., reported yesterday for 1954 net earnings of $5,362,965, or $17.88 on each of the 300,000 capital shares outstanding. Henry C. Alexander, president, said these were the highest earnings in the fifteen-year corporate history of the bank, and that they compared with $4,912,941, or $16.38 a share, in 1953.

The Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases will benefit from a rummage luncheon and fashion show on Feb. 8 in the ballroom of the Ambassador. The annual event is being given by the Trifles and Treasures Thrift Shop of the Society of Memorial Cancer Center.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Price fluctuations were choppy in the grain trade here today. There was a rally from early low spots but offerings in all pits were liberal on rallies.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Nationalist warplanes struck back at the Chinese Communists today for yesterday's big bombing of the Tachen islands, attacking the Red-held island and mainland positions.
The worm has turned in the legal arena of fair trade battles and the traditional defendant has become a plaintiff.
In reaction to your editorial entitled "Health and the Schools."
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 11 -- The radiation from current atomic tests to which people generally are exposed, it was said today, is enough to cause genetic alterations in thousands of future babies.

Three of the European track and field stars who will compete here this winter were introduced to the local coaches, officials and writers yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the Track Writers Association at Leone's Restaurant.
An international syndicate is ready to spring into action for the purpose of putting on plays in London and New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Administration plans to end segregation by September in the schools of the atomic city of Oak Ridge.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 11 -- Officials at Mitchel Air Force Base are considering the feasibility of salvaging the C-46 cargo plane that was ditched last night in the Atlantic Ocean six miles off Jones Beach.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Costa Rican Government expressed the "hope" today that it would receive United States military assistance to "repel the forces of invasion."

A Gallic cyclone in the likeness of three French artists blew into the city the other day. In New York to paint the town, the three have set up easels on street corners from Greenwich Village to Harlem, from Grand Central to Grant's Tomb.
GENEVA, Jan. 11 -- President Eisenhower's special message on international economic policy has done little to improve the bargaining position of the United States at the Geneva trade conference.
The Board of Education announced its tentative budget request for 1955-56 yesterday. School officials said it would provide "record services for the city's children."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission today suspended the middleweight contender, Joey Giardello, for seventy-five days and then reinstated the fighter on the payment of a $500 fine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner issued today a preliminary order to bar The Trade Union Courier from representing that it was endorsed by the American Federation of Labor.
A double feature fashion show was staged yesterday at Bergdorf Goodman. The first half was given over to resort styles for the southern scene. The second was a preview of new spring coats and suits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Record sales of $18,000,000,000 in December brought the 1954 volume for all retail stores in the country to almost $171,000,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. This was about equal to the 1953 volume.

The Giants held the center of the local baseball contract-signing stage alone yesterday. The world champions came up with the attested documents of two rookie southpaw pitchers and one of their star pinch-hitters, Bill Taylor.
The "false start" proved to be a lively topic for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Football Rules Committee at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

One reason for the confidence investors show in today's stock market is the belief that Wall Street is so closely supervised that a collapse such as that of 1929 is impossible. This confidence was dramatized just last week by the rebound from the drop in stock prices induced by the raising of margin requirements.
Directors of the New York Central Railroad Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a common share payable on March 10 to stockholders of record on Feb. 4.

I was interested in your editorial comment of Jan. 4 that "it has not always seemed during the past twelve months that civil rights and the concept of liberty were making rapid progress in this country." I thought that you might be interested in the Freedom Agenda Program being undertaken in the field of individual liberties by the Carrie Chapman Catt Memorial Fund.
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- At least 16,000 young Soviet men and women have enrolled for the second wave of migration to the new agricultural lands in Siberia, Kazakhstan and the Urals.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, declared here that some Administration foreign policies had harmed this nation's standing in the free world.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 11 -- An agreement covering a grant of $60,000,000 of United States economic aid to Pakistan was signed today by Ambassador Horace A. Hildreth and Mohammed Ali, Pakistani Finance Minister.
The Citizens Budget Commission will present its 1954 civic service awards at the organization's twenty-third annual dinner tonight at the Plaza Hotel.

The nation's steel-makers turned out 8,281,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings in December, more than in any other month since November, 1953, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Eddie Erdelatz decided today to sign for another five-year hitch with the Navy football team he restored to glory in his first tour as skipper.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The disputed Dixon-Yates contract got a good report today from staff lawyers of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senate Republicans voted today to expand their Policy Committee to include all elements and viewpoints of the party.

JULIAN OLEVSKY appeared at Carnegie Hall last night to make music. At the same time, if incidentally, the young American violinist filed a progress report on his growth as an interpreter. If one who heard him some five years ago can trust his memory, Mr. Olevsky, who is not yet 30, has been broadening his sympathies and developing his musicianship.

The Administration's bill to extend and increase the President's authority to lower tariffs is generally regarded as the heart of the President's foreign trade program and is expected to be given top priority in any legislative proposals.
Col. John A. McNulty of Teaneck, N. J., was unanimously re-elected to a third term as president of the New York A. C. at the organization's annual meeting last night at the city clubhouse.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 11 -- Maryland's hunters were divided into at least three opposing camps today following the arrest of two top state conservation officials, charged with violation of Federal and state game laws.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 11 -- The Indian Government announced today its decision to curtail the number of flights of the two United States airlines operating through this country.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Yale tore up Jordan Olivar's contract today and gave its head football coach a new one to run through 1957.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- K. G. Marshall's Judge J. B., a 5-year-old son of Deliberator, rescued battered form players when he won the feature seventh race at Tropical Park today.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- Frozen shrimp from Panama was reported today to be the chief cause of the illness suffered by 305 persons at a Christmas party here Dec. 23.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Following is the text of the extemporaneous remarks of Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, before a National Press Club luncheon today:
CAIRO, Jan. 11 -- Anti-American propaganda, by all appearances Communist-inspired, has scored a marked success in important Egyptian periodicals in recent weeks.

Hanging on grimly against a furious late rally by their rivals from New Jersey, Wake Forest upset Seton Hall, 71 -- 63, at Madison Square Garden last night. In the opener of the college basketball double header, witnessed by 5,821 spectators, St. Bonaventure routed Iona, 69 -- 54.

The Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation, said to be the world's largest manufacturer of gummed sealing tape and household paper napkins, announced yesterday the election of a new president and two key executives.

EVERYTHING is present and accounted for in the Phoenix' production of "The Doctor's Dilemma" (which opened last evening) excepting for one vital ingredient. The sardonic crackle of G. B. Shaw is missing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- A United Nations spokesman said today that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold had "made progress" toward bringing about the release of eleven United States airmen and other United Nations personnel held in China.
Executives of two Wall Street baanks said yesterday that savings banks of the state should have statutory authority to invest in the capital stock of the state's commercial banks.
The downtown retailer need not despair, a prominent merchant asserted yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- Greater use of automation in industry is expected to produce new and better jobs rather than unemployment.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The Legislature was asked today to enact a state-supported program for the education and rehabilitation of the mentally retarded between the ages of 5 and 21.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Eisenhower Administration today resumed its campaign to put the Post Office on a sound business footing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- A man who described himself as "Bimbo" warned the police today that the lives of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Representative Dewey Short were "in danger."

BAYPORT, L. I., Jan. 11 -- An expectant mother and her 9-year-old daughter were fatally injured here today when struck by a car after alighting from a bus. The accident, at 6:15 P. M., occurred less than a hundred feet from their home on McConnell Avenue.

There is animated discussion in Malaya about the possibility of the declaration of a general amnesty for Communist terrorists. The two leading political organizations in the Malayan Federation -- one Malay and one Chinese -- are suggesting the advisability of this course.
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- Accusations that the United States is trying to promote an armed uprising against the present Syrian Government have appeared here several times lately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- A Senate Armed Services subcommittee said today this nation's allies were faced with a shortage of ammunition, primarily because of too little production and "failure" of this country's off-shore procurement program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Eisenhower intends to ask Congress to authorize two more high-level State Department positions, the White House said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower appointed commissions today to help plan the 200th anniversary celebrations for John Marshall and Alexander Hamilton.
Day - long legal maneuvering failed to save twelve convicted secondary Communist leaders from going to jail yesterday.

In his speech in New York yesterday Secretary Dulles made a clear and much-needed distinction between the true peace sought by the democracies and the false "peace" propounded by the Communists. A full realization of this distinction could well mean for some nations the difference between falling into a Communist trap and escaping it.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Jan. 11 -- A Swarthmore College psychology student killed a sleeping schoolmate with a rifle early today in retaliation for a series of pranks.
ROME, Jan. 11 -- The French Premier, Pierre Mendes-France, celebrated his forty-eighth birthday by bargaining with the Italian Government today on his proposed European armament pool.

A large subscription has been reported for the Albert Schweitzer Eightieth Birthday Concert to be held on Friday night at Town Hall for the benefit of Dr. Schweitzer's hospital in Lambarene, French Equatorial Africa. Mrs. Richard Derby is chairman of the benefit committee.
QUEBEC, Jan. 11 -- The Quebec Government gave formal notice today of a bill to appoint a three- man judicial commission to regulate stock market activities in the Province.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- The Soviet Union said today that Soviet scientists and sailors had been making yearly visits to the Antarctic region and carrying out "large - scale observations" there.

Every day the people of the United States lift twenty-five or thirty thousand tons of newsprint from their doorsteps, mailboxes or newsstands. With the total load shared by some fifty or sixty million individuals, nobody has to be responsible for more than a few pounds all by himself, and this will vary depending upon where one lives and what day of the week it happens to be.
Los Angeles, Calif., sold $20,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent school district bonds in the public market yesterday.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, Jan. 12 -- The outcome of Mr. Hammarskjold's mission to Peiping remained a briefcase secret last night as the United Nations Secretary General arrived in British Hong Kong after completing an eight-day visit to China.
John D. Rockefeller Jr., in a two-sentence letter, gave $20,000,000 in securities yesterday to a fund to strengthen Protestant theological education in this country.
John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, counseled the nation yesterday to be "slow to anger" in efforts to free United States and other prisoners of war still held by the Chinese Communists.
MARINO, Italy, Jan. 11 -- An institute for advanced Communist study was inaugurated on a hillside south of Rome today.

A new motion-picture society called "Film Experimentalists" has been organized with headquarters at 118-56 155th Street, Jamaica, Queens. Scheduled for showing at 8:00 P. M. in the Gold Room of the Capitol Hotel are the following: a "complete version" of "The Birth of a Nation," Jan. 24; Alf Sjoberg's "Himlaspelet."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Federal Court of Claims ruled today that Austria, after the German armed forces surrendered, was not enemy territory. It also held that an executive agreement could not impair constitutional rights.

OWING to an unusually heavy exhibition schedule, the Whitney museum this year is combining its annual exhibition of contemporary American painting with its annual exhibition of sculpture, water-colors and drawings.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Bail of $50,000 each was set today for two key defendants in an alleged plot to kill Paul Hall, secretary-treasurer of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L.
TRENTON, Jan. 11 -- Excerpts from the message of Gov. Robert B. Meyner to the New Jersey Legislature today follow:

Lace, according to the Lace Institute, will appear this spring in all manner of fashionable clothing, ranging from raincoats to hats, to ball gowns. Garments from both Parisian and American designers were displayed yesterday in an institute-sponsored fashion show at the Pierre Hotel.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 11 -- Methodist Church women began an intensive campaign today to obtain full clergy rights for those of their sex who had selected the ministry as a vocation.
The predicted two years of waterfront peace got off to a stormy start yesterday.
This country's two largest liners were filled to more than 90 per cent of their passenger capacity on their trans-Atlantic voyages last year, the United States Lines reported here yesterday.

Europe led the United States by 1.830 points last night in the two-team contest for the 1955 contract bridge team - of - four world championship. Ninety-six hands had been played out of a scheduled 224.

In a television interview last night, Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, declared that the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, which he heads, would investigate the stock market because its recent action was "reminiscent of 1929."

Negotiations aimed at merging the Bronx County Trust Company into the Bank of the Manhattan Company are nearing completion at the same time that final talks are taking place on the proposed merger of the Chase National Bank into the Manhattan Company institution.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Blanton Collier, Kentucky football coach, received an undisclosed salary rise and a contract extension today.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The advance of industrial shares faltered on the stock market here today. They reacted on profit-taking, caused partly by another sharp decline in Government securities.

Net income of the O. A. Sutton Corporation, Inc. of Wichita, Kansas, in the fiscal year ended last November rose to $1,471,277 from $445,120 earned in the preceding fiscal year, it reported yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 11 -- Standardization of weapons will be accepted by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer when he confers Friday with Premier Mendes- France at Baden-Baden. An arms pool that provides for production controls will be unacceptable.
THERE is a curious history back of the eighteen-story apartment house at 60 Sutton Place South, between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets.

BAYVILLE, L. I., Jan. 11 -- This village on Long Island Sound has no railroad depot and word came today from the Hendrickson Bus Company that bus service is to be discontinued during week-ends. High operating costs were given as the reason.

A syndicate organized by Jack Fein has leased the sixteen-story office and showroom building at 80 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Fourteenth Street, for an initial term of twenty-two years. The property is owned by the 80 Fifth Avenue Corporation, which was represented by Louis Sachar, president of the Marshall Management Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Eisenhower urged Congress today to raise the pay of 1,500,000 Federal employes and to increase postal rates.
The United States Polo Association, governing body for the outdoor game, and the Indoor Polo Association of America, became one organization yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A bill to extend the G. I. loan program until July 25, 1960, was introduced today by Alabama's Democratic Senators, John J. Sparkman and Lister Hill.
ATLANTA, Jan. 11 -- Samuel Marvin Griffin of Bainbridge took the oath of office today as Georgia's seventy-second Governor.
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Army newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda (Red Star) published today aerial pictures of United States atomic plants at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Hanford, Wash.

EDDIE ERDELATZ will remain with the Atlantic Fleet, billeted at Annapolis for the next five years. For the past few days Eddie had been as footloose as a sailor on shore leave and Navy's big brass was understandably worried. Some of the gold-braided strategists were afraid that Eddie would go A. W. O. L., taking off over the hills for Los Angeles and a juicy berth with the professional Rams at double his Navy salary.
HARTFORD, Jan. 11 -- An investigation of charges of brutality at the New Haven County Home for Children was voted today by the county's Senators and Representatives in the General Assembly.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 11 -- In Military economic and political affairs, Israel never can compete with continental or imperial powers, Israel's Ambassador to the United States said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Eisenhower received in detail today a Federal-state-local highway program that would cost $101,000,000,000. The President's highway advisory committee conceived a program to be realized in ten years, but designed with the traffic needs of twenty to thirty years in mind. by Gen. Lucius D. Clay (ret.), offered no suggestions how state and local governments might raise funds to carry out their share of the program.

Forty per cent of apartment dwellers questioned here recently by the Consolidated Edison Company reported trouble with electrical appliances because of inadequate wiring. This statement was made last night by James O. Covington, manager of the company's adequate wiring bureau, at a meeting of the Electrical Women's Round Table in the Gramery Park Hotel.

In May, 1943, Capt. John Starr of the French section, British Intelligence, parachuted into France to organize resistance groups. His code name was "Bob." Two months later he was m captured by the Gestapo and taken to their headquarters in Paris where he learned that the Germans not-only knew all about the work of his section, but actually were running much of the underground movement themselves.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Teams from California and Florida shared the lead as the tenth annual international light tackle sailfish tournament opened today with eighty-nine anglers getting only twenty-four strikes and taking five sailfish.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The State Senate urged today strong efforts by the United States to win freedom for a Yonkers resident, one of the eleven fliers held prisoner by the Chinese Communists.

Fighting has started in Costa Rica. This is the salient and alarming fact of yesterday's news. Let us not forget that Costa Rica is an American state, on our doorstep, so to speak, and incidentally one of the few true democracies in Latin America.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell was nominated yesterday for Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, U. S. A.
Wholesale purchases for the spring of 1955 show a sizable increase compared with a year ago, according to exhibitors at the Women's Sportswear Show in the New Yorker Hotel.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The French National Assembly today elected Pierre Schneiter of the Popular Republican party as its Speaker. He defeated Andre Le Troquer, the Socialist incumbent.

Three Police Department applications to tap telephone wires were denied yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter. The Court held that "a tapped wire is the greatest invasion of privacy possible."
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Aneurin Bevan urged tonight that Britain throw off United States restraint and seek an early peace conference with the Soviet Union.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 (AP) -- John H. Noble, one of the two Americans released by the Russians last Saturday, said today that eight United States fliers shot down in Europe in 1950 might be alive in Soviet prison camps.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Educators in liberal arts who have been protesting the diluting effect of overspecialization heard the "vocational facts of life" today.

The massive road-building program proposed yesterday by President Eisenhower's Advisory Committee on Highways denotes at last acceptance of the principle that the United States can no longer be satisfied with the making of small plans for the automobile.
BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- The executive committee of the Boston and Maine Railroad showed no disposition today to bargain with interests that claim to have gained working control of the road.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 11 -- The campaign for the release of German war criminals has been renewed on the basis of efforts to free the eleven United States fliers sentenced in Peiping as "spies."
TRENTON, Jan. 11 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, outlined today a broad program of legislation and made a strong appeal for its adoption by the Republican-controlled Legislature.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 11 (UP) -- A C-119 Flying Boxcar crowded with paratroopers crashed and burned near here late today and thirty-seven of the thirty-nine men aboard bailed out before the plane went down.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A private memorandum circulated by the Democratic National Committee questions the wisdom of Senate ratification of the United States mutual defense treaty with the Republic of China.
HALIFAX, N. S., Jan. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Crew members of the leaking British freighter La Orilla stuck to their ship in the stormy North Atlantic tonight as another craft stood by.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford said today that he would favor an Allied blockade of the Chinese coast if milder measures failed to bring the release of Americans held by the Communists.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Claire Bloom, the British actress who made her film debut opposite Charles Chaplin in "Limelight," will co-star with Richard Burton and Fredric Mareh in "Alexander the Great."
Enmity between Costa Rica and Nicaragua is a result of animosity between the Presidents of these countries dating back to 1948.
Subway cars may continue to be overcrowded but big "brains" will figure out how to make them comfortable.

Magistrate Milton Solomon and Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health, conferred yesterday for fifty minutes, but there was little to indicate that the two officials had resolved their differences.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Traffic congestion is strangling New York and other major cities in the country, Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the National Academy of Sciences, declared today.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Jan. 11 -- A veteran of two Antarctic expeditions waved a red flag over the heads of this Navy icebreaker's crew today and said: "I am not a Communist, but this brightly colored flag can save your life."
I should like to request your assistance in making commerce and industry aware of the knowledge and experience military personnel acquire while performing their patriotic duties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the two special messages sent to Congress today by President Eisenhower, one for the Post Office Department asking increases in pay and postal rates, the other proposing a wage rise and a voluntary health program for Federal employes:
In a day of relatively light volume -- the smallest since Dec. 30 -- the stock market opened higher yesterday drifted lower until about 1 P. M. and then rallied mildly to the close.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- "The World of Sholom Aleichem," three of Sholom Aleichem's stories dramatized by Arnold Perl, was welcomed tonight, but not too enthusiastically, by the London newspaper critics. It opened at the suburban Embassy Theatre.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Governor Harriman told Democratic and Republican legislative leaders today that the state would need $50,000,000 to $75,000,000 more than was now in sight to balance its new budget.
The Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, noted Protestant theologian, was appointed vice president of Union Theological Seminary yesterday.

IN reviving the late Sidney Howard's play "Yellow Jack" on Monday evening, the National Broadcasting Company and the Playwrights Company offered an excellent production and some of the finest acting of this season in a drama that has grown a little dated.

TRENTON, Jan. 11 -- Apprised that Gov. Robert B. Meyner intended to read his 15,000-word annual message at a joint session of the Legislature today, leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate apparently felt impelled to act.
Roy M. Cohn last night accused Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, and John G. Adams, department counselor, of pursuing a course of "cover up" instead of "candor" in the Peress case.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 11 (UP) -- Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs 5-year-old gelding, Joe Jones, survived a claim of foul today as he set a mile record at Santa Anita in winning the $10,000 Long Beach Handicap.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The White House is recruiting Cabinet officers as witnesses for President Eisenhower's foreign trade program at Congressional hearings next week.

VIENNA, Jan. 11 -- While complaining about West Germany's rearmament Moscow is unilaterally violating four international agreements restricting military forces. The Soviet Union has already created an East German army of seven divisions, three of them mechanized.

All manner of strange, bizarre things were happening in the Bronx yesterday. Shiny white, seagoing pleasure cruisers, intended for family vacations next summer, began arriving from various points of the compass at the portals of the Kingsbridge Armory.

Gene Adler of Tilden High led five other qualifiers into the 200-yard free-style final of the city Public Schools Athletic League championship yesterday at Brooklyn Tech. Adler was clocked in 2:03.7. His closest rival, Marty Maloney of Brooklyn Tech, competed in another heat and was timed in 2:06.8.

Alexander Schneider, who left the post of second violinist of the Budapest String Quartet in 1944, last night made an unexpected return appearance with the group at the Young Men's and Young Womben's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Dr. John K. Norton, Columbia University educator, today strongly put the case for Federal aid to school construction in a closed strategy conference here.
The automobile was condemned yesterday as a Frankenstein monster and major reason some industries have moved out of New York.
On Jan. 6 Senator Bricker again introduced the Bricker amendment in the Senate.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 11 -- Any disposal of United States farm surpluses on world markets should be done in consultation with other exporting countries, Commerce Minister John McEwen said here tonight.
The first Air Force jet fighter developed specially for photo-reconnaissance missions is now being delivered to operational units.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- The Army said tonight it would be economically feasible to operate ocean ferries between the continental United States and Alaska carrying loaded rail cars and highway trailers.

ONE of the ablest and most original of living English novelists is C. P. Snow, author of "The New Men."* A distinguished physicist, the chief of scientific personnel for the Ministry of Labour in World War II, an influential literary critic and a prolific novelist, Mr. Snow has for some years been at work on a series of related novels about life in modern England.
The egg was the subject of discussion as well as the piece de resistance at a breakfast for food writers yesterday at the restaurant of Mme. Romaine de Lyon, 133 East Fifty-sixth Street.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Republicans are preparing rigid regulations to keep gamblers from making a racket of bingo, if and when it is legalized.
The Park Association of New York City, Inc., selected yesterday two recipients for its 1954 citation for outstanding contributions to the parks and playgrounds of the city.
The Corporation Counsel's office has told the Board of Education it can require teachers who are ex-Communists to disclose the names of party associates.

A ship's carpenter accused of having run away and gone to sea after a fatal hit-and-run accident more than three years ago made the mistake yesterday of speaking Italian in the wrong place. As a result he was arrested on charges of vehicular homicide and leaving the scene of an accident.

TOKYO, Jan. 11 -- Part of the funds paid to the United States for surplus wheat will be returned to the Tokyo Government to support Japan's growing defense industry. The rest of the wheat revenue will serve the same purpose indirectly through United States purchase of Japanese materials to be sent other countries under the Mutual Security Program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, proposed today that non-scheduled airlines be certified by the Civil Aeronautics Board within a specific period or go out of business.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Eisenhower made his political plans a studied enigma today, again presenting himself as the leader of a middle, moderate view.

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 12 (AP) -- A multi-million-dollar merger of the Taylor Oil and Gas Company of Taylor, Tex., and Delhi Oil Corporation of Dallas was announced today. The new name will be Delhi-Taylor Oil Company, with headquarters here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- For the second time in less than a year the Government acted today to tighten trade barriers against imported watches.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association will meet with other interested national groups to look for solutions to the problems of doing business in downtown areas, Philip M. Talbott, new president of the retail group, said yesterday.
It has been only fourteen shopping days since Christmas, and one of the biggest buying sprees is under way in midtown New York.

Wool prices rose sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading was influenced by reports of a dock labor crisis in Australia. Strength of futures in London and on the Continent also bolstered prices. Tops rose 2.1 to 3 cents a pound and grease wool 2.2 to 3.2 cents.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- A bipartisan judicial deal of the first magnitude was in the making here today. It would involve the creation of twenty to twenty-one new places on the Supreme Court and their division between Democrats and Republicans.

Certainly most people in America and probably many in other countries of the free world have been eagerly watching the journey to Peiping of the Secretary General of the United Nations. They are momentarily expecting a report of success or failure.

Mayor Wagner made several points in his address to the Citizens Budget Commission's annual dinner last night that need to be remembered in the weeks ahead by those who, at budget-making and tax-raising time, are critical of the costs of government.

The Kings County Trust Company of Brooklyn reported as of Dec. 31, 1954, total deposits of $51,381,519 and total assets of $60,892,887, compared; respectively, with $53,323,840 and $62,991,077 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $10,770,686 against $11,061,806; holdings of United States Government securities to $12,817,762 against $14,677,288, and loans and discounts to $13,630,044 against $11,542,607.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The new Senate Republican Policy Committee set out today to end all-too-frequent traffic jams on the Senate floor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The Army said tonight it had revoked the promotion of Cpl. Marvin S. Belsky and reprimanded the officer who gave it to him.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the first eight trading sessions of this month came to 34,325,618 shares -- more than the turnover for all twenty sessions last January, when the total was 33,374,561. And some market observers willing to go out on a limb this early are predicting that this month's trading may well turn out to be the second largest for any January in the exchange's history.
Charges of bribery against two former automobile union officials were dismissed in Special Sessions yesterday. They were accused of receiving illegally $12,000 from a Queens hardware company.

An increase last week of 3,728,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, supplies amounted to 160,956,000 barrels, compared with 157,228,000 a week earlier and 160,324,000 a year ago.
Governor Harriman is planning to give new businesses in this state the kind of technical aid the Federal Government has been giving farmers for many years.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The lavishly mounted "Night of the Ball," which opened at the New Theatre tonight, brought only the most diluted praise from the London critics.
The Carlton Avenue branch of the Brooklyn-Queens Young Men's Christian Association, the last all-Negro "Y" in the city, will be closed officially on March 31.
Confidence that unions and employers could clean their own houses and make state regulation of welfare funds unnecessary was voiced yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Isador Lubin.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 12 -- Fifteen persons were killed this morning when a Trans World Airlines plane and a private DC-3 collided in the air.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Eisenhower took the middle of the road today in the Wolf Ladejinsky "security risk" case.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped to a new low since December, 1952, today. Butchers lost 25 to 50 cents and sows about 25 cents. The report of the Department of Agriculture on the livestock markets follows:

The ten-story and penthouse apartment building at 12 to 20 East Ninety-seventh Street has been purchased by Nathan Wilson, operator, from the Nari Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Imre Von Schreiber, broker.

In the year ahead we hope more attention will be given to the positive approach to traffic congestion, to prevention rather than small, piecemeal, incomplete remedies. This means, in a metropolitan area like New York, trying to get people to leave their cars at home if possible, or midway at least, before they get into the heart of the traffic mess.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Louis Wolfson today advanced a new plan to win stockholders' support in his proxy battle for control of Montgomery Ward Co.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Jan. 12 -- With increasing determination, Argentina is establishing herself on the Palmer Peninsula of Antarctica. The area is claimed by Britain and Chile as well as Argentina.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Liberal arts educators were advised here today to spend less time asserting how superior a liberal education was and more time proving it.
Mayor Wagner warned last night that the city's needs required "a greater amount of taxes." At the same time he contended that his administration was making "substantial progress" against waste.
FOXHUNTING normally falls into one of two categories, formal or informal. But the annual Valentine Fox Hunt held at Nags Head, N. C., seems to combine the two.

COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, outside Villa Quesada, Costa Rica, Jan. 12 -- Col. Francisco Orlich, Minister of Public Works and commander of the Government forces in the field, stood grimly interrogating rebel prisoners today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- President Eisenhower will nominate James A. McConnell of Ithaca, N. Y., to be Assistant Secretary of Agriculture and a member of the board of the Commodity Credit Corporation, the White House announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration made public today details of the new contributory health insurance program for Federal workers it will lay before Congress.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 12 -- The Board of World Peace of the Methodist Church today voiced strong opposition to Universal Military Training.
National advertising continued its upward climb in November, and some new records are in prospect when returns for all of 1954 are in.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- In a single news conference, President Eisenhower underscored today the principles that guide his Administration.
New hiring procedures designed to increase regular employment on the port's docks were promulgated yesterday by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.
The Football Rules Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday announced six changes in the regulations. They are effective immediately.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Rocky Castellani of Cleveland used hit-and-hold tactics tonight to gain a unanimous twelve-round decision over Holly Mims. The victory may bring Castellani another shot at the middleweight crown.

Stockholders of the New York Trust Company approved at their annual meeting yesterday a change in the capitalization to permit a split of each $25 par value share into two shares of the same par value.

Along about sundown tomorrow night, thousands of electric lights -- incandescent, fluorescent and otherwise -- will be turned on to make an artificial sunny summer's day of the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Ali futures of grain and soybeans were under pressure of free selling early today. But apparently those on the bear side grew too numerous, and efforts to cover shorts caused a good recovery in wheat from the low spots.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Governor Harriman and J. Irwin Shapiro, State Commissioner of Investigations, declined today to comment on reports that a new investigation of the Luciano case had been ordered.

The Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations will erect a granite monument in Battery Park in memory of Emma Lazarus, who wrote the sonnet ("Give me your tired, your poor, * * *"), inscribed on the Statue of Liberty.
