LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The stock markets did an about-turn during today's quieter trading. Government funds started strongly but lost part of their gains in the afternoon. By contrast, industrial and oil shares rallied after falling sharply in the morning.

President Eisenhower's comments at his press conference yesterday about the federal employe security program in general and the Ladejinsky case in particular have only compounded the confusion already existing in the public mind and, so far as we can see, within the Government itself.
Stock prices receded for the first two hours of yesterday's market and then climbed slowly. Final prices were near the highs of the day but still below the Tuesday close.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 12 -- Willie Mays and Ruben Gomez, both of the New York Giants, had a fist fight yesterday during batting practice of the Santurce team of the Puerto Rican Winter League on which they also are team-mates. The fight ended when Manager Herman Franks, also of the Giants, rushed between them.

HONG KONG, Jan. 12 -- The conference of the trade subcommittee of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East ended today, as it began, with a Soviet complaint on the nonparticipation of Red China.
The way was opened yesterday for a new rush of "windfall" suits by tenants of cooperative housing against builders who obtained Government-guaranteed loans.
Former President Harry S. Truman, who canceled an appearance on "Person to Person" because his wife thought their house should be redecorated first, has been rebooked as a guest March 4.

The world's fastest pre-telegraphic communications system -- more than one-third faster than the fabulous Pony Express -- has been discovered in the mountains and jungles of Peru, Victor Von Hagen, leader of the Inca Highway Expedition, reported on his recent return to New York.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Marian Anderson, who said she once had dreamed of singing a Metropolitan Opera role on the stage of Philadelphia's Academy of Music, fulfilled the dream last night.

After almost two years of study the Temporary Commission on the Courts has made public its plan for giving New York State's complex and costly court system more efficient administration. The commission proposes the creation of a Judicial Conference of nine judges: the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals; the presiding judges of the four appellate departments; and four Supreme Court trial judges -- one from each department.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A serious effort will be made within the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy to free much restricted information to aid peacetime development of electric power from the atom.

A Brooklyn laborer, displeased with Coney Island Hospital service, took one of its ambulances last night to get quicker care. He got it faster than he wanted. The police dispatched him, in the same ambulance, to the prison ward of Kings County Hospital, where, resting comfortably, he has nothing now to worry about except a grand larceny charge.

DENVER, Jan. 12 -- Robert L. Howsam, president and general manager of the Denver Bears Baseball Club of the American Association, was elected a director of the Central Bank and Trust Company yesterday.
St. Louis, Mo., sold $11,690,000 of various purpose bonds at public bidding yesterday at a net interest cost of 1.5083 per cent.

" DON GIOVANNI" returned last night to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time this season, and though it did not have a performance worthy of Mozart's genius, it was good to have the masterpiece back on any terms.
A two-week engagement here at the Playhouse, beginning Feb 7, will open the farewell tour of the United States by Vicente Escudero, gypsy dancer who has not been seen here for twenty years.

The similarities of current fashions and those of the past were pointed up yesterday in a show presented by the International Silk Association, U. S. A., Inc. In the galleries of the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute slim models wearing the silks of today stood beside figures garbed in yesterday's splendor.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Princeton overpowered Army's hockey team, 6 to 1, at Smith Rink today.
Gustavo dwelt on two themes in this spring millinery collection shown yesterday at the Peacock Cafe, 158 West Fifty-sixth Street.
Senator Wayne L. Morse, independent of Oregon, said last night there was a "strong probability" that he would campaign for Senate re-election next year on the Democratic ticket.
HALIFAX, N. S., Jan. 12 (UP) -- A crippled British freighter and its thirty-five crewmen fought for survival today in the gale-swept Atlantic 280 miles south of Newfoundland.

Maritime Administrator Louis S. Rothschild has invited United States shipowners in the coastal and intercoastal trades to two meetings in Washington to discuss ways to revive a once thriving commerce.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Noel Field has confirmed by letter his decision to remain in Communist Hungary, the State Department said today.

Two deals involving Fifth Avenue properties were announced yesterday by Louis Cooper, who has purchased the rex-story and penthouse offices at 435 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-eighth and. Thirty-ninth Streets, and has leased the six-story office andI showroom building at 377 Fifth] Avenue, between Thirty-fifth and[ Thirty-sixth Streets.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12 -- Senator Francis Case declared today that President Eisenhower's vast highway modernization proposal was based largely on accomplishments of the Republican-controlled Eighty-third Congress.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton, the favorite, advanced to the quarter-finals of the Florida West Coast tennis tournament today with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Lonnie Jordan of Montgomery, Ala.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point lower to 1 point higher yesterday. Trading was in a narrow range.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 12 (UP) -- Gov. James F. Byrnes called on South Carolina's Legislature today to take two steps toward preserving school segregation.

Wendy Lucht, 5 years old, and her brother Alec, 4, who are one of the youngest sets of brother and sister to cross the Atlantic alone in a long time, arrived yesterday on the Custard liner Queen Elizabeth.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- Twentieth Century-Fox closed a deal in New York today for purchase of screen rights to the new play "Anastasia."

WHEN Marty Marion formally signed a contract as manager of the White Sox the other day, he shamelessly predicted that his heroes would win the American League pennant this year and that the Indians had "a little better chance" than the Yankees of finishing second. Don't wake him up, folks. Let him dream.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad began swinging another stick yesterday in its attempt to "beat the bushes for all the commuter and passenger traffic we can get."

Closer cooperation with newspapers on advertising problems was urged on department store executives yesterday by Harold S. Barnes, director of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

The president of the National Safety Council, in a statement reminiscent of many others over the past several decades, speaks of the death toll from auto accidents over the holidays as "a tidal wave of carelessness, selfishness and cold indifference * * * that should shame any civilized nation."
Color proved a lively medium for Jay Thorpe's dramatization of resort fashions yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Charles L. Brown, dean of the Hahnemann Medical College of Philadelphia, has been appointed dean of the new Seton Hall College of Medicine in Jersey City.

" Cinerama Holiday," produced by Louis de Rochemont as the second feature in the new process, has been scheduled to have its world premiere Feb. 8 at the Warner Theatre. The engagement of "This Is Cinerama" will end the preceding Sunday with a record of 2,165 showings.
Walt Whitman Hall at Brooklyn College will be dedicated tonight in the first part of a three-day ceremony to honor the American poet.
The Yankees and the Dodgers broke even on contract signings yesterday. Each club came up with two pitchers and the same total of contented players, fifteen.
LONDON, Jan. 12 (Reuters) -- Bishop Auckland, a leading Northern amateur club, swept into the fourth round of the English Soccer Assocation Cup competition today.

Premier Mendes-France is busily conferring with other European statesmen on the construction of the new Europe for which the Western European Union laid the foundation. He has just completed a series of conferences with the leaders of Italy and will begin a similar series with Chancellor Adenauer and his colleagues tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The author of a staff report criticizing the Postmaster General, Arthur E. Summerfield, was dismissed by the Senate Appropriations Committee today.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Republican legislative leadership was committed today to an extension of residential rent control beyond the present expiration date of June 30.
Jose (Pepe) Figueres, President of Costa Rica, is a United States-trained engineer who established a prosperous coffee bag and rope factory in Costa Rica's jungle.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The United States would not normally use nuclear weapons in a "brushfire" war, President Eisenhower said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The smoking habit was cited today as a possible road accident hazard.
" The Hollywood Ice Revue," which has given a total of 247 performances in New York during the last seventeen years, begins a nineteen-day engagement at Madison Square Garden tonight at 8:30 o'clock.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Allie Reynolds, the highest paid pitcher in the New York Yankees history, pondered his 1955 contract offer today and renewed intimations that his playing days were about over.

TOKYO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Tanny Campo, 112 pounds, of the Philippines floored Hiroyuki Tezaki, 112, of Japan for no count in the eleventh round as he punched out a unanimous twelve-round decision to retain his Orient flyweight championship tonight.
An appeal to New Yorkers of all faiths to support the campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York was made yesterday by city and state officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The American Bar Association announced today the establishment of a special committee to give free legal assistance to Government workers who might be involved in security cases.

DIAMONDS are a mystery writer's best friend. They are, by and large, just about the most satisfactorily fabulous treasures to have steeped in jeopardy while knaves and desperate men busily steal and sleuth and slay. True, a priceless batch of secret battle plans is always welcome in these charades. Paintings informally borrowed from the Louvre are good, too.
A railroad yard, little used remnant of a colorful era when the Big Three reigned as the gridiron powers, will vanish soon from the Princeton University scene.
With only eighty hands remaining to be played, the United States trailed Europe by 1,240 points last night in the 1955 official team-of-four contract bridge world championship play.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 -- A Filipino who conducted the Guam Symphony Orchestra at the age of 20 has been asked by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to leave this country by Feb. 1.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Upsets featured the card at Tropical Park today. There was a daily double pay-off of $981.40, the highest of the meeting, and Stephen Messana's Old Baasket pulled a surprise by winning the feature.
Anastasio Somoza, commanding general of the Nicaraguan National Guard and President of Nicaragua, runs his Central American country like a feudal fief.
Several small appliances and utensils are among the new equipment for the kitchen just beginning to appear in stores here.
Mushrooms have been thought to be magical.
Fordham got in the last telling blows of a seesaw basketball contest with Columbia last night. The final score was 71 -- 68, with the Rams moving ahead to stay with less than three minutes to play.
Chung-mon Kang is a cadet with a special purpose at The Citadel, the military college in South Carolina.
ROME, Jan. 8 -- A fresco by Piero della Francesca has been discovered in Sansepolcro, the Umbrian town where the fifteenth-century painter was born and died.

MADRID, Jan. 12 -- The Spanish Government announced today that it had demanded the restitution of $570,000,000 in gold coin and bullion shipped to the Soviet Union by the Republican Government in 1936.

NEWARK, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A cargo checker here charged today that a lawyer for the New Jersey-New York Waterfront Commission threatened to lift his work permit if he did not testify at the present trial of eight longshoremen on kick-back charges. The checker, Samuel Lipton of 26 Stegman Terrace, Jersey City, named the lawyer as Ronald J. Cracas of New York City.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 12 -- Turkey and Iraq announced tonight that they had decided to conclude a regional defense agreement open to other Middle Eastern states.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 12 -- President Anastasio Somoza tonight challenged President Jose Figueres of Costa Rica to meet him at the Nicaraguan-Costa Rican frontier "with revolvers" to settle the dispute between their two countries.

YONKERS, Jan. 12 -- Already hard-pressed to find jobs for workmen left behind when the huge Alexander Smith Carpet mills moved to the South recently, this city of 160,000 was threatened today with loss of the Otis Elevator Company's big plant.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 12 -- Iraq's oil revenues will be increased as much as one-fifth under the new price fixing formula now being worked out by the Government and the companies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China, in his talks with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold stressed the "threat" of an American-inspired invasion of the Chinese mainland.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The United States is willing to contribute $271,000,000 to a European fund to finance trade for weaker national economies when the economically stronger nations make their currencies convertible. Convertibility involves the free exchange of currencies into each other.
Three hundred and fifty years of Italian history are spanned in the latest exhibit of the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., Jan. 12 (UP) -- Master Sgt. William H. Olson, 40-year-old veteran of twenty years in the Army, has been charged with collaborating with Chinese Communists and informing on fellow-soldiers while a prisoner in Korea.

While building construction in Queens continues at a tremendous rate, it appears that little or no consideration has been given to the transportation of the new residents to Manhattan during the morning rush hour and then back to Queens in the evening.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Administration announced today a new offer to sell butter for export on a competitive bid basis in an effort to move 10,000,000 pounds.

Sandy Saddler, Harlem boxer who holds the featherweight championship of the world, agreed yesterday to defend his crown against Teddy (Red Top) Davis of Hartford, Conn. The pair will meet in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 25, under the promotion of the International Boxing Club.
A wide-ranging dispute in the drug industry over the discovery of the antibiotic, tetracycline, appeared yesterday to have reached a decisive stage.
Yale University's swimming team stretched its streak to 117 dual-meet victories by defeating Columbia, 67 -- 17, at the University Hall pool yesterday.
Springtime comes early to Macy's Plan-A-Home Row section where a series of room settings keyed to new apple blossom-patterned fabrics will open tomorrow.
The New York State Racing Commission yesterday held a meeting at its offices and emerged only with a statement that another meeting would be held next Wednesday morning. The statement:

Mircea Vasiliu, illustrator and former Rumanian refugee from the Communists, has written his autobiography. Titled "The Pleasure Is Mine," it will be published next Wednesday by Harper. Mr. Vasiliu grew up in Rumania when diplomacy was "The Career."
ROME, Jan. 12 -- The dissatisfaction of the Communists with their leader, Palmiro Togliatti, came out into the open today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- House investigators charged today that "loose handling" and disagreement among United States medical officials left 12,000,000 faulty anti-hookworm pills "deteriorating in warehouses in Indochina."
Two Bronx women pleaded guilty in Bronx Special Sessions Court yesterday to conspiring to kill the husband of one of them. Justice Doris I. Byrne set Feb. 2 for sentencing.

The Board of Estimate is scheduled to consider today a local law, passed by the Council Dec. 14, to amend the City Charter and set up a reorganized and expanded Department of Commerce and Public Events. Such a department has existed for about fifteen years, but it has been only an orphan and charity ward, sometimes with honorary and political rather than a businesslike foundation.

An adequate supply of privately owned American ship tonnage is available to carry shipments abroad under the foreign aid program, according to James B. Stuart, president of the American Tramp Shipowners Association.
The Governor's Room at City Hall, which houses priceless art works and antique furniture, was threatened yesterday with a new invasion -- this one by the City Council.
HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 10 -- The first prisoners of the conflict between the Indonesians and the Dutch for possession of Netherlands New Guinea are in the jail here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Democratic National Committee today stepped up the tempo of its personal attacks on President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 5:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the volume of futures trading in farm products last year was about the same as in 1953. It said most leading markets had "relatively stable trading conditions."
Reduced sales lowered the net profit of the Midwest Piping Company, Inc., to $1,165,447 in the nine months to Nov. 30 from $1,741,428 in the corresponding period of the prior year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Following is as unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse, as required by White House rules:

The Baltimore Museum of Art will be the beneficiary of an exhibition of the museum's Cone Collection of paintings by Matisse, which will open with a preview here on the night of Jan. 24 at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.
In a showing of spring bridal fashions yesterday Best Co. cleared many of the objections voiced by girls who often serve as bridesmaids.

Two professors at Columbia University received the "Great Teacher" awards of the university's Society of Older Graduates last night at a dinner in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 12 -- Rebel forces carried out today what appeared to be terroristic strafing operations in a widespread area of Costa Rica. The raids extended from Puerto Limon on the central Caribbean coast to Liberia in the northwest near the Pacific.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 12 (UP) -- Battle Dance, under a hustling ride by Eddie Arcaro, raced to a surprise victory today in the $18,100 Los Feiiz stakes for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita. The favored Tollesboro ran a dismal tenth.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- British exports last year were the highest ever, both in value and volume.
The preview of the new Air Force Academy, conducted last week at Columbia University, emphasized curriculum and environment rather than athletics.

An experimental "dream" truck with front-wheel drive was announced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation Truck and Coach Division. The vehicle, designated L'Universelle' is a panel delivery truck. With minor manufacturing changes and replacement of the rear body panel windows, it can be converted into a small bus, taxi, station wagon or sportsman's car, according to Philip J. Monaghan, general manager of the division.
Citing an "old French saying, 'mieux vaut tard que jamais,'" Dr. Charles N. Breyner sent his contribution to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:...
The liquor industry was urged yesterday to speed agreement on a bill to extend the tax-free bonding period on whisky beyond the present eight years.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- The six New England Governors voted unanimously today to appoint a committee to study all regional transportation problems. The move stemmed from a revived effort to merge the New York, New Haven and Hartford and the Boston and Main Railroads.
David L. Rike, president of the Rike-Kumler Company of Dayton, Ohio, received last night the 1954 award as "Retailer of the Year" from Tobe and Associates, fashion and merchandising consultants.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 13 -- The London press erupted in condemnation of the British Broadcasting Corporation today after a broadcast that declared "orthodox Christianity is no longer tenable."
The city is withholding 10 per cent of the cost of its new fireboat, the John D. McKean, while efforts are made to correct excessive vibration.
CHARLES MUNCH and the Boston Symphony Orchestra played a program that was too long last night in Carnegie Hall.

Some pleasant playing in lighter phases of the repertory was offered last night at the piano recital that Aurora Mauro-Cottone gave in Town Hall. It was when she tackled such an ambitious work as Chopin's Sonata in B flat minor that she took on a little more than she could handle.
The New York Boxing Writrs Association will hold its twenty-ninth annual dinner tonight in the grand ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker. A gathering of 500 is expected to attend the event.

The New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs played to a scoreless tie in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Despite the indecisive ending, the crowd of 5,185 did not take too unkindly to the contest.
Mayor Wagner is "cutting down on evening affairs," he told the Citizens Budget Commission last night.
The Hamilton Watch Company yesterday acquired all the stock of the Hathaway Instrument Company, Denver producer of electronic instruments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A drive in support of a proposal that Congress invite the Chief Justice of the United States to address a joint session annually on the state of the Federal judiciary was under way today.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Jan. 12 -- Robert B. Bechtel, who killed a fellow student at Swarthmore College yesterday, was held without bail today. According to the police he said he was "after four or five students" because they had been playing pranks on him.
Health Department inspectors served a summons yesterday on the landlord of a Brooklyn home in which a mother and her five children were overcome by carbon monoxide poisoning.
Great Britain's largest electronics concern is negotiating for the controlling interest in Capitol Records, Inc., one of this country's "Big Four" phonograph record producers.

B. Earl Puckett, chairman of the board of Allied Stores Corporation reported yesterday that the cost of the ten shopping centers he expects to have in operation within three years will total $292,720,000. The cost of the seven centers not yet completed totals $237,600,000.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Republican chairman of a joint legislative committee urged Mayor Wagner today to drop his plan for a supplemental New York City multiple dwelling code.
A thirty-seven-year fight to re-establish union bargaining rights in the Danbury, Conn., hat plant of the Frank H. Lee Company ended in success for the union yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Governor Harriman today appraised President Eisenhower's domestic, program as "utterly inadequate" except for the proposal on highways.

Cartoonists have bunches of fun with the stock situation of an employe standing before the boss' desk asking for a raise. But then cartoonists are free-lance people who don't have bosses and don't have to ask for raises.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A team of military lawyers will go along with combat troops when they engage in mock atomic warfare exercises in Texas next month.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- The Premiers of France and Italy have agreed that the West should take the initiative in easing East-West tension. It is understood, however, that no such move is to be made until all the signers have ratified the Paris agreements on the creation of the Western European Union.
Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, provided a small footnote to history yesterday.

A 16-year-old girl was stabbed at 8:30 P. M. yesterday by an unidentified man while she was waiting for a train in the Willoughby Avenue station of the IND subway in Brooklyn. She and her assailant, who escaped, weer alone on the station platform at the time, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The United States responded today to a plea from the Organization of American States to help end the fighting in Costa Rica. Washington agreed to send planes to observe the disturbances.
HANOI, Vietnam, Jan. 12 -- The North Vietnamese Army has dispersed a group of 10,000 Roman Catholics who sought to reach Haiphong and refuge.

One maxim of the retailing business is that the personality of a store is an accurate reflection of the personality of its top management. It is accurate in the case of Philip M. Talbott, just elected president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, who is senior vice president and secretary of Woodward Lothrop in Washington, D. C.

The poverty of Soviet farmers is one of the key facts of the current Soviet scene, a major factor behind the reforms that have been introduced by Malenkov and Khrushchev since Stalin's death. Measurement of this poverty has been difficult in recent years because of the blackout on adequate statistics.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 13 -- Apartheid, South Africa's system of race discrimination, will apply to 400 Negro members of the United States aircraft carrier Midway when she anchors at Capetown Saturday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 13 -- Mrs. Irma Corcoran, who was shot dead by her 13-year-old stepson outside their Glen Head home last Saturday night, had been warned four months ago by a psychiatrist that the boy was subject to a breakdown.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Strong opposition from the South threatened today to block efforts to unite three American sections of the Presbyterian Church.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Governor Harriman today appointed Philip M. Kaiser of Brooklyn as a special assistant to handle problems concerning the aged and aging.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- It was inevitable that objections would arise to the proposal by Representative Kenneth B. Keating that the Chief Justice of the United States shall address annually a joint session of Congress on "the State of the judiciary." It was also desirable that these protests Should be strong because of two implications of the proposal that quickly suggest themselves.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Two Republican Senators announced today that they would ask the Senate to protest formally against use of colored stripes on this year's income tax forms.

Plans for a major nuclear engineering congress at which a vast store of scientific information to be de-classified by the Atomic Energy Commission will be made available were discussed here yesterday.

A special meeting of the executive committee of the National Boxing Association will be held here today. At the session, the Sandy Saddler and Robert Cohen cases will be discussed. The members also will hear the world light heavyweight champion, Archie Moore, plead for a match with the world heavyweight titleholder, Rocky Marciano.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, proposed an emergency program today to train more scientists and engineers.
TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- New Jersey officials have drawn a draft on the South Amboy Trust Company in an effort to recover $300,000 in state deposits that the bank maintains do not exist.

GUIDO CANTELLI, young, elegant of figure and of style, conducted his first concert of this season as guest leader of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. One would fain remark that on this occasion Mr. Cantelli gave some of his most distinguished performances.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Governor Harriman estimated today that next year's state budget would be at least $100,000,000 higher than this year's $1,143,000,000 total.

"Manon" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera last evening, with Giacinto Prandelli singing the Chevalier des Grieux for the first time with the local company. Licia Albanese and Frank Valentino made their first appearance of the season as Manon and Lescaut, respectively.

The Dow Chemical Company enjoyed a substantial increase in sales in the six months ended last November, over the prior year's period, but earnings were little changed, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 13 -- Iraq will renew her pleas for larger and more important allocations of United States military equipment in the light of the decision to conclude a regional security agreement with Turkey.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Boston's high-scoring Celtics tonight went over the 100-point mark for the twenty-first time this season as they routed the New York Knickerbockers, 116 -- 100, in a National Basketball Association game at Convention Hall.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 13 -- President Jose Figueres said today that rebel forces who attacked his Government three days ago were fleeing toward Nicaragua and now held only two towns, both near the Nicaraguan border.
Fifty-two Customs Service employes in the New York area have been reduced in grade and salary, it became known yesterday.

The all-English contract bridge team, representing Europe, led the United States team by 3,070 points yesterday in the 1955 team-of-four play for the world championship. Only thirty-two hands remain to be played.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Jan. 12 -- A member of this expedition to Antarctica turned to a lookout on the bridge of the Atka this morning and said: "Does that iceberg have a radio mast on it with the American flag flying?"
DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- The Society of Automotive Engineers took a ride into the future today in an imagined car twenty-five feet long, low slung, and electronically controlled, at 200 miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Reports heard here that the invaders of Costa Rica had been crushed were premature, the Costa Rican Embassy said tonight.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- While the negotiations for Tunisia's internal autonomy came to a halt, the Government turned its attention today to Morocco.

The First Measurable Snowfall of the season finally arrived at 4:50 A. M. yesterday. It was the latest F. M. S. since 1928, and that was on Jan. 20. At 4:35 P. M., when the snowfall stopped, 1.1 inches of snow had been recorded by the Weather Bureau at Battery Place.

YONKERS, Jan. 13 -- City Manager Charles L. Curran, fearing a possible transfer of the 1955 Yonkers Raceway program to Roosevelt Raceway, today sought to keep the harness races here. A shift would cost the city at least $250,000 in admission taxes.

Midtown Realty Ventures, a syndicate of investors represented by Albert C. Drucker, attorney, has bought the fifteen-story apartment house for eighteen families at 132 East Seventy-second Street from the Alpha Realty Company. Assessed at $270,000, the property is 40 by 102.2 feet and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $197,400. The Maxwell Brody Company was the broker.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The South Vietnamese Government has drawn up a plan to cut its regular army from 217,000 to 100,000 men by next Dec. 30, it was reliably reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The United States appeared heading for trouble today, over the Administration's program for the disposal of farm products.

IZMIR, Turkey, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Turkish tobacco brought record prices at the annual auction concluded in this Aegean tobacco region center. Prices ranged from 2.45 to 3.65 Turkish lire a kilogram, or about 15 per cent higher than last year's sale.

Today's new film is "The Green Scarf," a British melodrama with Michael Redgrave, Ann Todd, Kieron Moore and Leo Genn, at the Palace. Bertram Ostrer and Albert Fennell produced the Associated Artists release, and George More O'Ferrall directed from a script by Gordon Wellesley.
A policy of "protectionism" in international trade will harm the United States by leading to greater East-West trade without regard to security, a top government official warned yesterday.
A baby was reborn in Pennsylvania Station last night. After seventeen months as an orphan and a flying trip across the world, Roni Marie Donahoe was delivered to her mother.

The battle over rights to the antibiotic tetracycline took further complicated turns yesterday with major drug companies asserting they would continue selling it despite conflicting patent claims and pending lawsuits.
TOKYO, Jan. 13 -- The top United States military commander in the Far East urged the Japanese today to do more to prepare themselves for defense against possible Communist aggression.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- The Security Council today ended its debate on Suez shipping. A majority was agreed that Israel should be allowed to use the vital waterway, but Egypt refused to let Israeli ships through the canal.
A lawyer with an international reputation and four long-time bankers with a combined total of more than 150 years of experience are slated to take over the top management of the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Two Brooklyn children died yesterday when fire swept their apartment during the absence of their mother. The police believe the children may have started the fire by overturning a kerosene stove.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- A French effort to delay further freeing of trade in Western Europe made it doubtful today how far the Organization for European Economic Cooperation would go in this direction.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- "India is the key to Asia and Nehru is the key to India."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Following are the texts of two Messages to Congress by President Eisenhower, one proposing extension of the draft law and enactment of a new military Reserve program, the other proposing pay increases and other benefits for members Of the armed forces:

ROME, Jan. 13 -- Italy and France are convinced that the West must take the initiative to ease the tension between the East and the West, Pierre Mendes-France said at a news conference today. Both also are determined, however, that there shall be no East-West talks before all powers concerned have ratified the pact treating the Western European Union and permitting the armament of West Germany, he added.

ONE of the nation's prized football coaching portfolios is the post at Tennessee. For the better part of three decades General Bob Neyland, a great man in the profession, directed the destinies of the Volunteers with cold, precise efficiency. His power-geared single-wing attack was one of the most feared in the sport and rare was the season when his orange-jerseyed juggernaut wasn't crunching toward the top rank in the national championship list.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Thousands of Americans will honor Dr. Albert Schweitzer on his eightieth birthday tomorrow with tributes in words, music and dollars. The great humanitarian, meanwhile, will be working as usual in his hospital in Lambarene, French Equatorial Africa.
A LOOK of sadness comes over Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain when he reads reports from all over the world on the amount of what he calls "avoidable litter" in urban centers.

DENVER, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A special United States court today overthrew a 1953 Interstate Commerce Commission decision denying the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad equal freight rates with the Union Pacific Railroad through the Ogden, Utah, gateway.

When it comes to snow -- and when snow comes -- the populace is split right down the middle. Half of the people consider snow a horrid thing, sent from the sky to plague those on the ground. The sight of snow corning ever downward means, for them, shovels and skids, mittens swallowed by snowbanks, wet woolens and necks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The House of Representatives approved without contest today the assignments of Democrats to its nineteen standing committees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Four builders who made "windfall profits" under a Government housing program have tentatively agreed to return more than a million dollars, Federal housing officials reported today.

The property at 56 Oakwood Avenue in Orange, N. J., has been purchased from the estate of Charles Sauer by Liebmann Breweries, Inc., manufacturer of Rheingold Beer. Occupied for the past forty-five years as a lumber yard, the property comprises about 10,000 square feet of building and adjoining land.

The General Electric Company said yesterday it would give "substantially more" than $1,000,000 to educational institutions in the 1955-56 academic year to help alleviate the "critical shortage of professional manpower throughout the nation."

BAYONNE, N. J., Jan. 13 -- Navy divers were working sixty feet below the surface of Gravesend Bay today on the job of recovering 14,460 rounds of live anti-aircraft ammunition that had been dumped into the bay last March.

Mrs. Harold S. Osborne gave a tea Wednesday afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East Sixty-sixth Street, for members of the committee serving with her in behalf of the performance of "The Dark Is Light Enough" for the benefit of the New York Chapter of Jackson Laboratory Association.
Courses designed to satisfy a number of tastes will be offered in the city soon to parents and their children.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Capital Transit Company announced today it would employ Negroes as bus and trolley operators for the first time.

Management of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad now estimates that the company's net income last year was about $3,700,000. This estimated net, which is before deduction of heavy sinking fund requirements and includes a Federal tax carry-back credit, compares with $6,651,879 earned in 1953.
ROME, Jan. 13 -- The funeral today of former Marshal Rodolfo Graziani turned into one of the greatest neo-Fascist demonstrations since World War II.
Communism's victims were helped last night by Le Bal Blanc, the White Ball, which was held in the ballroom of the Ambassador.

Today Albert Schweitzer will celebrate with modest simplicity his eightieth birthday. The world acclaims him not only as a musician, historian, theologian and philosopher, but also as an extraordinary physician. With the spirit of a missionary he has devoted almost thirty years of his life to curing the sick on the edge of the primeval forest in French Equatorial Africa.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 12 -- Using more than 2,000,000 tons of wheat a year, and with national production scarcely 500,000 tons, Brazil is experiencing serious trouble in purchasing wheat from countries demanding hard currency.
The city's fiscal problems and legislative program for 1955-56 will be discussed today by Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner at luncheon in Gracie Mansion.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The stock market was in a cheerful mood today. Government funds improved after a hesitant start and industrial shares were firm all day, though most price changes were small, South African gold mining issues continued weak.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The Board of Trade announced today that many additional items formerly on the list of goods embargoed for sale to the Soviet bloc would be freed from export licensing contracts Monday unless intended for Communist China, Tibet or Macao, which is a Portuguese possession.
After a firm opening, stocks declined in the third and fourth hours of yesterday's session and only partly recovered their losses by a show of strength near the close.

ADD the name of Joseph Schull to the ranks of television's growing list of fine dramatists. A winner of a number of major drama awards in Canada, he contributed to the Elgin Theatre on Wednesday evening an uncommonly sensitive and poignant love story beautifully interpreted by Kim Stanley.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower proposed today to improve the morale and efficiency of the armed forces by increasing servise pay, allowances and benefits by almost $1,000,000,000.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 13 -- The drive to mobilize West Germany's industrial workers in a solid front against ratification of the Paris agreements is getting fully under way here.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 13 -- Ivan Mestrovic, Croatian sculptor, will join the faculty of the University of Notre Dame in September, the university announced today.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation achieved record sales of $80,559,994 in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, an increase of 6.1 per cent over the previous high of $75,926,546 the year before. Consolidated net income, however, declinecl to $1,884,976 from $2,988,432.

ALMOST as certain as taxes, Arthur M. Wirtz' ice minions "cometh" to New York annually at this time of frost. But, unlike the chill-producing fiscal bites, the impresario's young men and women who opened last night at Madison Square Garden in the 1955 edition of "Hollywood Ice Revue," are a heart-warming and colorful lot.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- The new Speaker called on the National Assembly in his keynote speech today to join him in restoring the prestige of Parliament and French democracy.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- British gas turbine manufacturers declare that they have designed a marine engine with an efficiency ratio at least 5 per cent higher than any marine turbine previously tested.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Air Force has a jet fighter-bomber that can leap into the air from a truck. The Republic F-84 Thunderjet, a warhorse of the Korean war, is the plane that has taken to motoring, raising some interesting possibilities for future combat.
The General Waterworks Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire control of twenty-one operating water properties in central Pennsylvania.

Stockholders of the Joy Manufacturing Company at their annual meeting yesterday in Pittsburgh, approved an increase in the debt limit from $10,000,000 to $20,000,000. The company has some $6,000,000 in debt. J. D. A. Morrow, president of the mining equipment manufacturer, reported that the business boom in foreign countries is resulting in increased sales of machines and equipment and that Joy's foreign manufacturing subsidiaries are operating profitably.

Your editorial of Jan. 2 on the need for more physical education teachers in our public schools reminds me of a story attributed to Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins. When asked to divulge the secret of his marvelous physique, he replied that whenever he felt like exercising he would lie down until the feeling left him.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Mr. Smith came to Washington yesterday -- Mr. Harrison Smith of The Saturday Review, that is -- and made a record for a Library of Congress broadcast.
A registration statement covering the proposed public sale of 300,000 shares of common stock of the Allied Stores Corporation has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Juvenile delinquency, is increasing in the city and cannot be controlled unless the police force is increased, Police Commissioner Francis W, H. Adams told the Women's City Club yesterday.
Recognition of the young child's need for a warm family life has prompted the Spence - Chapin Adoption Service to speed the placement of babies in its care.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Union handed notes to representatives of the Western European Union powers last night protesting their plan to arm West Germany. The Russians contended the plan would violate the Geneva Convention barring weapons of mass destruction.
Nelly Don's familiar shirtwaist dress has the new long torso line in her spring and summer collection, presented yesterday at Macy's.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower told some of the nation's leading educators here today that they could make a contribution to world unity by helping combat the forces of materialism.
Claire McCardell's flair for unusual color, imaginatively used, was evident in her spring and resort fashions collection for Lord Taylor, shown yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

The decision of the Port of New York Authority to finance a $500,000 study -- to be used in cooperation with the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission -- of the whole railroad passenger problem as it concerns Manhattan and northern New Jersey is as welcome as it is unexpected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, asked the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today for approval of the Southeast Asian defense pact and got an instant promise of early action.

The Citizens and Southern National Bank, Savannah, Ga., reported as of Dec. 31, 1954, total deposits of $388,920,559 and total assets of $420,601,269, compared, respectively, with $362,390,158 and $389,156,702 on Dec. 31, 1953. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $106,370,340 against $108,999.382; holdings of United States Government securities to $124,284,469 against $110,100,286 and loans to $185,566,808 against $165,579,680.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 13 -- President Izhak Ben-Zvi today called on the people of Israel to celebrate Maimonides Year in honor of the medieval philosopher who died 750 years ago.

Walt Whitman Hall, which was dedicated at Brooklyn College last night, was described by Dr. Joseph B. Cavallaro, president of the Board of Higher Education, as Brooklyn's first "adequate center for cultural and community activities."

In your editorial headed "Slaughter on the Road" it is stated very aptly that it is caused by "* * * relatively few people who are reckless, heedless, irresponsible, incompetent, selfish, or all of these." And then you wonder "* * * how few or how numerous such people are * * *."

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 13 -- Ruben Gomez today made special efforts to deny that he had had a fist fight with Willie Mays. Ruben visited the newspapers El Mundo and El Imparcial to offer his Version. He also talked with the several radio broadcasters who had commented on the scuffle.

The city's voluntary hospitals, providing services to 1,200,000 patients annually, have reported the highest losses in their history. Confronted with rising costs, the United Hospital Fund of New York yesterday forecast even larger operating deficits.
The winter season of the New York City Ballet will open at the City Center on' Feb. 15. During the engagement two new works by George Balanchine will be added to the repertoire.
The Port of New York Authority agreed yesterday to put up $500,000 for a broad new study of railroad service between Manhattan and New Jersey.

Tomorrow the Post Office is issuing a new three-cent stamp Commemorating the 150th anniversary of the establishment of this country's first art institution, and the principal figure in the design is that of a man less well known than he deserves to be in this generation.

Ogden R. Reid, vice president of The New York Herald Tribune, and his wife boarded the outbound superliner United States from a bobbing tugboat off the Battery yesterday. The reason was a last-minute mixup over Mrs. Reid's passport.

The recent letter of L. B. McKay on "Age Limits on Employment" states the real cause of age discrimination -- namely, group insurance premium rates. The United States Supreme Court should declare this practice discrimination, just the same as discrimination against race, color or creed.

The resignation of two more directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, friendly to Frederic C. Dumaine Jr., former president, was announced yesterday. They are William M. Hickey, president of the United Corporation, investment holding company, and J. Francis Smith, president of J. E. Smith Co., Inc., Waterbury, Conn., lumber and building materials company.
Twelve scholars have been commissioned to make what is intended to be an objective historical investigation of the penetration of Communist influence in American life.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 13 -- Danish political parties were reported today to have agreed to a Government request for further postponement of parliamentary debate on ratification of the Paris agreements to arm West Germany and admitting it to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Twenty-one power-boat daredevils are being admitted this week to marine racing's most exclusive organization -- the Gulf 100-Mile-an-Hour Club. Each qualified by driving a power boat during 1954 at 100 miles an hour or faster, over a body of water in the United States.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The British Cabinet was reported to be considering today the possibility of limiting the immigration of subjects of the Queen into the home country. The step, would be aimed at Negro immigrants from the West Indies, who have caused ousing problems in several cities.
Week-end market baskets should bulge with values. Good buys in food as a result of price cuts are widespread.
IF ice-fishermen are hardy, it is difficult to find a term to describe those who brave the off-shore waters and sharp winds in order to carry home a bag of cod, haddock and whiting.
The huge bank that would result from a merger of the Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company would function under a 1799 charter that does not even mention the banking business.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (UP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed suit in Federal Court today to prevent racial discrimination in homes and apartments insured by the Federal Housing Administration.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower called on Congress today to strengthen the citizen Reserves to meet the perils of the atomic age.

Recent attendance figures for sports events at Madison Square Garden suggest that, except possibly in boxing, the downward trend from the peaks reached in the years immediately following World War II has been arrested.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $396,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 -- The Cleveland chapter of the National Conference of Christians and Jews voted to secede from the parent body in a spirited meeting tonight.
The demand for shipping space to Europe is such that shippers are finding it difficult to obtain spot bookings for eastbound cargoes.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 -- The American Road Builders Association reported today that the engineering profession and highway industry could handle the President's highway program.

Commercial finance companies that Supply immediate credit needs of small and medium-size businesses were estimated yesterday to have lent $3,200,000,000 in 1954. This was about 15 per cent more than in 1953.
HARTFORD, Jan. 13 -- Inmates at the Connecticut State Prison get 15 cents a day for work, and one has written to the General Assembly that he cannot live on it.

Litterbugs groaned at the stiff fines levied on them in Upper Manhattan Court yesterday. Magistrate Louis Kaplan continued his rigorous support of the anti-litter campaign initiated by Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain five days ago.

FOR some fanciful reason Boris Margo entitles his current exhibition of sculpture, bas-reliefs and non-objective paintings at the Betty Parsons Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, "City Lights." It would be difficult to associate his substantial art with anything so flickering and transitory.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 13 -- William Sloane, editorial director for Funk and Wagnals Company and Wilfred Funk, Inc., New York, was named today to head the Rutgers University Press, beginning April 1.

Members of the committee in charge of arrangements for the second annual house and garden tour for the benefit of the Patients Welfare Fund of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation met yesterday at a luncheon given at the institute.

Yesterday's snowfall sent a surge of hope among skiers who anticipated sport this week-end on metropolitan slopes. Unfortunately, the cover was far from adequate and pilgrimages to the northlands are in order again.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Edward O. Yackel a Republican member of the State Liquor Authority since 1947, said today he would forward a letter of resignation to Governor Harriman tomorrow.

Flako Products Corporation, through Roy S. Durstine, Inc., is offering a pair and an extra of nylon hosiery as a promotion for its Pie Crust Mix. For $1 and a boxtop the purchaser gets three 51 gauge, 15 denier nylon stockings, described as a $1.85 value.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- A new crisis among Long Island's famous bay scallops sent Conservation Commissioner Louis A. Wehle rushing to the scene today.

The merger of the Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company would give the enlarged bank deposits of more than $6,800,000,000, restoring the Chase name to the leadership in New York banking.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 13 (AP) -- A sixty-nine-day strike that was marked by police-picket clashes and court suits came to an end tonight when employes at three plants of the Underwood Corporation accepted a contract.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Producers cut hog shipments today after three days of sharply declining prices and the market responded with substantial gains. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

Quite a mystery developed yesterday regarding the New York home of "Plain and Fancy." Anthony B. Farrell, owner of the Hellinger, was uncertain whether the musical would open there Jan. 27, as announced. Richard Kollmar, co-producer of the show, was equally vague, saying there was nothing "definitive" about the booking.
The Transit Authority is close to agreement on a deal that would produce timetables for night subway riders -- and revenue for the authority.
HANOI, Vietnam, Jan. 12 -- North Vietnam is becoming involved in an economic pinch caused by the removal of French economic enterprises.
Twenty-two adult pupils played Indian on Wednesday evening at the final session of a class at the American Museum of Natural History.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 -- James Hilton's will, in which the English-born novelist provided for his first wife but not for his second, was admitted to probate today by Superior Judge Victor R. Hansen. Both marriages ended in divorce.

In his message on our defense manpower requirements President Eisenhower referred several times to what he called a proper military posture in relation to our danger and our needs. This seems to us to be a felicitous phrase. We must stand erect.

Since Mr. John announced that the Petit Trianon, with the more simple life affected there by the French court of Marie Antoinette, was the source of inspiration for new spring millinery collection, one could not be too sure in advance just what the hats would be.
The job of laymen in religion is to take over enough business and social functions from clergymen to permit them "to minister to our souls," Admiral Ben Moreell declared last night.
ROME, Jan. 13 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Italian Communist leader, seems to have won his battle against rebels in his own party -- at leash for the moment.

SAN JOSE, Jan. 13 -- The international investigating commission for the Organization of American States recommended to the Council of the Organization tonight action tomorrow to establish peaceful air patrols over the Costa Rican border.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 13 -- Nicaragua offered today to help patrol the Warfare that President Anastasio Somoza is accused of having unleashed in Costa Rica.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 13 -- The "perfected" text of a plan to unite the Protestant churches of the United States was made public here today.
HONG KONG, Jan. 13 -- The appointment of Liu Hsiao to succeed Chang Wen-tien as Communist, China's Ambassador to the Soviet Union was announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) A woman walked onto the floor of the House of Representatives today and asked Speaker Sam Rayburn for permission to make a speech.

I was pleased to read one particular section of your editorial of Jan. 6 on "The Governor's Message" in which you suggested that "short-cutting the constitutional process to hasten the legalization of charity bingo is bad business; bingo is gambling, and the people have a right to speak on the question at the polls, no matter how innocuous you and we believe bingo to be."

The liquor industry generally had lower whisky sales in 1954, but the National Distillers Products Corporation expects to show an increase when its final figures are in. With this cheering news, John E. Bierwirth, National's president, closed yesterday a two-day meeting of the concern's officials and 200 distributors at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 13 (UP) -- Betty Grable's and Harry James' speedy gelding, James Session, closed fast today to capture the $10,000 Beverly Hills Purse at Santa Anita Park by a half-length.

NEWARK, Jan. 13 -- A benefit performance, with child-enchanting feats of music, magic and comedy, will be held next Saturday at the Mosque Theatre in memory of an 8-year-old boy who died of polio last year.

An ultra-high-frequency television station in Asbury Park, N. J., sought yesterday to drop its present channel and obtain a new one in the very-high-frequency band. It said that the lack of U. H. F. sets and converters in its viewing area "makes it impossible to continue under the present set-up."
BONN, Germany, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The highest German cultural award, the Pour le Merite, has been given to Dr. Arthur H. Compton of St. Louis and six other foreigners.
UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Spain has asked for the privilege of establishing a permanent observer at the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Chairman J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today he has named a new staff director for the Senate Banking Committee who already has started gathering material for a committee study of the stock market.

Repayments by sales finance companies and commodity dealers were major factors in a $32,000,000 decline in business borrowings from New York City banks in the last fiscal week. Such loans declined by the same amount in the like period of 1954.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 13 (UP) -- Willie Mays and Ruben Gomez of the New York Giants shrugged off their baseball diamond brawl today as just a flare-up. At the same time it was determined that Mays had suffered a knee injury.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Italy made a plea today for United States aid to raise the standard of living in Italy.

Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's trip to Peiping and back has taken him around the world. It has been full of drama and of irony. Here, on the one hand, is the Secretary General of an international organization of sixty members. There, on the other hand, is the so-called People's Republic of China, which controls nearly one-fourth of the population of the globe but which has not succeeded in gaining entrance into the United Nations.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A controversial question of amateurism arose today with the Rev. Robert Richards, Olympic pole vault champion, a surprised man in the middle.

Carl (Bobo) Olson, the middle-weight champion of the world, received the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque at the annual dinner of the New York Boxing Writers Association last night. The event, held at the Hotel New Yorker, attracted a capacity turnout of 500 persons, including many boxing notables of the past and present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Eisenhower today designated the Jewish Restitution Successor Organization, a New York charitable membership corporation, to receive the unclaimed property of certain deceased victims of Nazi persecution.

New York has been welcoming a National Motor Boat Show every January for more than a half-century. The annual exposition makes seafarers out of landlubbers. It sees hordes of little tykes towing and leading their fathers into the arena and up to smiling salesmen who are ready with order books and dotted lines.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- E. Rieber's Noble Lad, responding willingly to strong urging by Alfonso Coy, won the featured seventh race at Tropical Park today before 10,881 spectators. It was the colt's second start here and his second triumph.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 13 (AP) -- New Nationalists bomber raids and air and sea battles were reported today around the Tachens, fortress islands threatened with Communist invasion 200 miles north of Formosa.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 -- Two top economists and leading industrial and financial leaders of this area predicted today that business conditions would improve this year.
BADEN - BADEN, Germany, Jan. 13 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer and Pierre Mendes-France will begin tomorrow a series of important conferences. The agenda will cover four main fields:
A plan for merging the Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company has been approved by the directors of both concerns.
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley rejected yesterday doctors' pleas that they be permitted to park for three hours in restricted areas.
Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M., and "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, and "La Boheme," Carl Fischer Concert Hall, both at 8.
A "crash program" for dealing with juvenile delinquency in New York State was urged yesterday by Attorney General Jacob K. Javits.
A new fabric, Nylebrode, was presented in the collection of bridal designs by Maurer Originals shown recently by Saks 34th at the Maurer showroom, 491 Seventh Avenue.

MANY young pianists these days give the impression of being men very much in a hurry. Paul Badura-Skoda, in his Town Hall recital last night, was not in a hurry at all. He did not play as though he were in a terrible rush to get somewhere.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- The British Broadcasting Corporation, caught in the center of one of the liveliest religious controversies the country has known in years, today scheduled a debate on the merits of orthodox Christianity against "scientific humanism."

Your newspaper has been reporting the possibility of a split in Communist ranks in Yugoslavia in view of the fact that Milovan Djilas, former President of the Yugoslav Communist Parliament and chief party theoretician, and Vladimir Dedijer, former editor of the Communist party newspaper, member of the Parliament and of the Politburo and biographer of Tito, have -- made non-conformist statements.

Commodity futures closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, sugar, potatoes, soybean oil and copper were mixed; wool, cottonseed oil, rubber, zinc and lead declined, and cocoa, hides, burlap and silk rose. Trading was light.
MADRAS, India, Jan. 12 -- Madras will be visited soon by a Government committee looking for hints on how to help the whole country travel the prohibitionist road.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Daily Herald said today a top secret document giving details of Britain's most advanced discoveries in the use of atomic energy for industrial purposes had been stolen.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 13 -- Leo A. Hoegh became Governor of Iowa today in a simple inaugural ceremony.
The Board of Estimate at an executive session yesterday ordered an investigation into the purchase of the 128-foot fireboat John D. McKean.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock refused yesterday to release twelve convicted secondary Communist leaders in bail pending final determination of a defense motion for a rehearing on the Supreme Court's refusal to review the case. He had revoked their bail on Tuesday.

The latest gift by John D. Rockefeller Jr. is announced with brevity. To the trustees of the Sealantic Fund, Inc., a philanthropic corporation he set up some years ago, he wrote: "I am giving your corporation as of this date securities having a present market value of approximately $20,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Young men reaching the age of military obligation would have these general choices under the military manpower program submitted to Congress today by President Eisenhower:
Television will help to speed the new conveyor belt shuttle between Times Square and Grand Central.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The one-act Democratic production, "Chamber of Smears," was presented with a minimum of scenery today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- The motel business has reached such proportions in this country that Universal proposes to make it the subject of a motion picture. "Motel" is the tentative title of the project to be produced by Albert J. Cohen from a script to be written by Ray Buffum.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has just acquired its first painting by Salvador Dali, the Spanish artist. The picture, a work more than six feet high entitled "The Crucifixion," came to the museum as a gift from Chester Dale. It will be on exhibition in the museum's great hall today.
A bill to provide for glorifying the city and spreading its fame throughout the land was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The United States will ask India to accept John Sherman Cooper of Kentucky as its next Ambassador to New Delhi.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The ten-year rule of Prime Minister William Alexander Bustamante is over. But he said no successor could match his accomplishments "perhaps within 100 years."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, demanded today that the Army dishonorably discharge Pfc. Marvin S. Belsky, a drafted physician who refused to say last March whether he was a Communist.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Commissioner of Education, has dismissed an appeal by eleven teachers discharged or suspended by the New York City Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Scott McLeod, who has been under Congressional fire for the slowness of the refugee relief program, said today that he favored a revision of the present law to make immigration easier.
Combined net earnings of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank for 1954 amounted to $15,005,499, according to the 131st annual report being mailed to stockholders today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., permanent United States representative to the United Nations, expressed confidence tonight that the eleven United States airmen imprisoned by Communist China would be freed.

The one consolation to be drawn from the strife in Costa Rica is that the international mechanism of the hemisphere is working with admirable speed and judgment. It looks now as if President Figueres of Costa Rica is getting the upper hand of his enemies inside and outside of his country and this is a result that all Americans, North and South, who are concerned with democracy in the hemisphere will be glad to see.

CAIRO, Jan. 13 -- Neither Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser nor any other responsible Government official would comment for publication today prior to receipt of full details of the Baghdad agreement between Iraq and Turkey.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retired, today described this country as caught in a vast traffic jam.
Sandusky, Ohio, sold $3,740,000 of school district bonds due from 1956 to 1977 at competitive bidding here yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 13 -- Gov. Edmund S. Muskie called on the Republican - dominated Legislature today to provide $5,000,000 annually in new tax revenue to finance "firm steps forward along a broad front."
Jackie Robinson signed a contract for his ninth straight season With the Brooklyn Dodgers yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Unseeded Dave Harum of the University of Miami chased Sidney Schwartz, seeded second, out of the Florida West Coast tennis tournament today in the biggest upset so far.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 13 -- Health and welfare agencies must be prepared for the emergencies of war or any other crisis, a national meeting of community leaders heard today.

A community blood donation will be given in Richmond Hill, Queens, today to the regional Red Cross blood program. The collection will be made at the Pilgrim Congregational Church, 104th Street and Eighty-ninth Avenue, Richmond Hill.
Bexar County, Texas, sold $3,090,000 of road district bonds in the public market yesterday. The bonds mature from 1957 to 1978.
Helping children to develop their characters should be the principal objective of programs in all children's museums, Mrs. Miriam C. Stryker said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Pressure continued heavy on soybean futures with rallies failing to hold even in the January contract. Prospects were for heavier deliveries on January contracts as more soybeans are being shipped here from the Northwest, and soybeans are also being unloaded from winter storage boats at Chicago.

William Alexander Bustamante, who was defeated in the Jamaican elections on Wednesday, was a big fish in the little Caribbean pond. That colorful region would seem a bit drab if the flamboyant and attractive "Busta" disappeared, but he has only been thrown into the opposition through the defeat of his Labor party by the People's National party, headed by Norman Manley, a Queen's Counsel and one of the top lawyers of the island.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 14 (UP) -- The Federal Government dropped criminal charges against Roy A. Roberts, president of The Kansas City Star today, but said its anti-trust action, against the newspaper would begin Monday as scheduled.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Jan. 12 -- The Antarctic gave this ship a warm welcome today. Although there were a few snow flurries, the weather was remarkably mild and almost no icepack was encountered.
Throngs of vacation-eager and boat-hungry skippers and ambitious neophytes last night attended the opening of the National Motor Boat Show in the enormous armory on Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 14 -- The Yugoslav Government's official spokesman linked West Germans today with circles allegedly engaged in "an organized campaign" against Yugoslavia.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Public Service Commission approved today the first 20-cent local bus fare in the state.

The smog of uncertainty hovering over the New York opening place and date for "Plain and Fancy," the musical with the Amish community background, has cleared away. The attraction, adhering to its original schedule, will have its Broadway premiere at the Mark Hellinger Theatre on Jan. 27.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 (UP) -- The Amateur Athletic Union district office today ruled that Rev. Bob Richards, the 1952 Olympic pole vault champion, did not receive an automobile on a television program, but that his church did.

The last mail from the United States Navy icebreaker, the Atka, bound for Antarctica, was received yesterday in New York. Airmail letters from The New York Times correspondent, Walter Sullivan, with the Navy's expedition there under Comdr. Glen Jacobsen, arrived here six days after they had been lifted ashore by helicopter as the ship sailed past Dunedin, New Zealand.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 14 -- Gale force winds stripped tons of valuable topsoil from eastern Suffolk County farms today, whipping up one of the worst dust storms in recent memory.
General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein has written to Governor Harriman requesting clemency for one of three youths convicted of first-degree murder last March.
HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Jan. 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner warned here tonight that some Americans were prone to forget the Bill of Rights in their fight against one or another form of totalitarianism.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Europe's cold spell stopped the clock today -- the clock with the most personality and the farthest heard voice in the world, Big Ben.
Four American Airlines DC-6's had a bad day yesterday, but it all ended well. One plane had caught fire and three had to return to La Guardia Airport because of suspected mechanical defects.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Senator Mike Mansfield introduced a resolution today to authorize creation of a joint Congressional committee to supervise activities of the Central Intelligence Agency.
PARIS, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A French translation of Christopher Fry's "A Sleep of Prisoners" got a stormy reception last night at its Paris Premiere. Boos mingled with applause.

Mrs. Hortense W. Gabel, a leader in voluntary agencies opposing discrimination in housing, was sworn in yesterday as general counsel to the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission. It is one of the state's highest legal posts to be filled by a woman.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Duilio Loi, the lightweight champion of Europe, scored a unanimous decision over Glen Flanagan of St. Paul in his American ring debut tonight.

It would not be considered good practice to place in the hands of a child a loaded gun with the admonishment not to use it. How then can we expect the public to refrain from try ing out the maximum speed of a recently acquired 1955 shiny, new high-powered job?

Governor Harriman's position on restoration of the full 5 per cent pari-mutuel racing tax to New York and other communities remained obscure yesterday after a two-hour luncheon meeting with Mayor Wagner.
The President of Panama, Jose Ramon Guizado, is a quiet-mannered but firm business man who made a fortune as a construction engineer.
Ted Williams will not play baseball next season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.1 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- While French officials were studying the latest Soviet Union protest against the Paris agreements for German rearmament, the Soviet Ambassador, Sergi A. Vinogradov, was recalled today to Moscow for consultation.
The contract bridge champions of Europe won the 1955 team-of-four world championship last night from the United States by the overwhelming score of 5,420 points.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 14 -- The largest expansion program in Hofstra College's history has been voted by the board of trustees. It calls for a $2,000,000 expenditure.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 14 -- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns proposed today that Israel and Syria divide the demilitarized zone lying between the countries into administrative areas. Inhabitants of the areas would trade with the adjacent part of the state having control over them.

Mayor Wagner may have made some excellent head of department appointments, as your recent editorial commented upon. He has failed in formulating the taxes to secure the necessary funds for proper functioning of the city.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Nine British pilots are expected to arrive in Hamburg tomorrow to take temporary command of the airliners of the revived German airline Lufthansa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Communist party today was denied its request for a rehearing on the ruling that the party was a Communist-action organization required by the Internal Security Act to register with the Attorney General.

President Eisenhower's two messages on increased pay for federal employes are important not only to the million and a half workers directly affected but for the science and art of labor-management relations. They are the fruit of a carefully considered and highly commendable effort to apply to the federal civil service the most enlightened employment practices of American private industry.
A record sum of $401,938.79 was reached by the forty-third annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Jan 14 (AP) -- Bob Feller signed his seventeenth contract with the Cleveland Indians today and ventured that he would win about forty more games before his baseball career ends. He has 262 victories.
Employes of the Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company were assured by their top bosses yesterday that the proposed merger of the two banks would not require any lay-off of help.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The stock markets remained firm today despite slowing down of business. British funds continued to improve. By the close some undated issues gained as much as seven shillings sixpence ($1.05), and long and medium term issues by lesser amounts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- President Eisenhower set up today a seven-member commission to recommend ways of streamlining the veterans' pension program and relating it to the Social Security System.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Charles D. Mahaffie accepted compulsory retirement from the Interstate Commerce Commission today when the White House announced the nomination of a successor.
GREENPORT, L. I., Jan. 14 -- A speedy decision that will let this community's scallop fleet get back to work was made here today by Louis A. Wehle, the new State Conservation Commissioner.

VIENNA, Jan. 14 -- The Russians were asked bluntly today in the Allied Control Council for Austria whether their repeated accusations that the West intended to partition the country were designed to camouflage their own intent to do so.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Forty-two Senators today called for stiffer narcotics laws.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- United States industrial production climbed in December for the fourth straight month, and construction activity and retail sales reached new peaks.

While admitting that New York City is "rife with violence," State Supreme Court Justice Hofstadter believes that the way to combat crime in this metropolis is by building up the police force rather than increasing the use of such easy but odious devices as wiretaps.
YONKERS, Jan. 14 -- The labor union of the Otis Elevator Company's employes here protested today against "secrecy" concerning tomorrow's meeting of workmen with Leroy A. Petersen, president of Otis.
The annual conclave of the United States Power Squadrons will be held today at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel. Representatives of 23,000 members in 166 boating centers from coast to coast will attend.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Under Secretary, said he had read "with great interest" Moscow's announcement that it would share with world scientists the experience of operating what it has called the first atomic-driven industrial power plant.
In the course of a single decision handed down yesterday in the State Supreme Court in Queens, a labor union both lost and won the right to picket.
WASHINGTON. Jan. 14 -- The National Bureau of Standards this week received a patent on an atomic clock, which was built in Washington and installed at the bureau's laboratories in Boulder, Colo.

Two five-story buildings, containing thirteen apartments, at 311 and 313 West Seventy-first Street have been sold by Elizabeth Caliger to a customer of Nassoit Sulzberger Co., brokers in the transaction. The property occupies a plot 33 by 100 feet.
