The market for new issues of corporate debt securities is giving signs of backing up after the sale of $126,000,000 of public utility and railroad bonds and debentures early this week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- At least two more agricultural attaches are being scrutinized by the Department of Agriculture under security and technical requirements standards.
BERLIN, Jan. 14 (AP) -- John M. Noble of Detroit, released last week by the Russians after nine and a half years of Soviet captivity, left for home today clutching a book on the Soviet Union.

Commodity futures closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light, generally limited to evening of holding for the weekend. Coffee, sugar, wool and copper moved mixed; hides, potatoes, cottonseed oil and soybean oil were lower, and cocoa, zinc, rubber and silk ended higher.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Knocking six strokes off par with 66's, Jerry Barber of Los Angeles and Stan Leonard of Canada led the way through the first round of the $15,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Organization of American States asked Nicaragua tonight to try to stop war equipment from moving from that country into Costa Rica.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- The Ford division of the Ford Motor Company estimates the new car market this year at 6,000,000 units, of which its share will be "25 per cent plus." L. D. Crusoe, vice president of the company and general manager of the division, made this forecast today after attending the Chicago Automobile Show.

" Carmen" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera last evening, with four singers making first appearances of the season in principal roles. These were Nell Rankin as Carmen, Richard Tucker as Don Jose, Robert Merrill as Escamillo and Osie Hawkins as Zuniga.
One of the visitors, Rear Adm. Louis B. Olson, Commandant of the Third Coast Guard District, made a significant announcement to boat owners.
LIBERIA, Costa Rica, Jan. 14 -- Preparations are being completed in this bombed and strafed city for what the Government hopes will be a final drive on the rebel forces.
MADRID, Jan. 14 -- The Spanish Government was understood today to have decided to support a United States relief program for Spain despite the protest of Spanish dairy producers.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Another of l%Tiami's Harum brothers pulled an upset in the Florida West Coast tennis tournament today, when A1 ousted Jean Noel Grinda. French junior l champion, in straight sets.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- For the first time in more than a century, an American won a silver medal today for life saving from the seas off Britain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Four Fairchild O-119 Flying Boxcars among planes carrying 3,000 paratroopers have suffered misadventures en route to Exercise Snow Bird in Alaska.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 14 -- Two lumber yards, a restaurant and a dwelling were destroyed and a second house was damaged today in a two-alarm fire that closed Route 1 for four hours.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 14 (UP) -- Porterhouse, a star 2-year-old but a disappointment last year, today equaled the six-furlong track record at Santa Anita, winning the Wisteria Vine Purse in 1:09.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Government announced tonight its border forces had shot dead one resisting "American spy" and captured another after they had been parachuted into Soviet Estonia last summer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that an aide had edited a news confeernce transcript of his remarks on the Dixon-Yates contract to conform with a prior written statement.
THE international character of the New York art world is strikingly illustrated this week in exhibitions by a Belgian, a Norwegian and an American painter.
The Department of Hospitals reported yesterday that the shortage of professional nurses was not reflected in the care patients were receiving in municipal institutions.
December sales of the nation's chain and mail order stores bettered those of the same month of 1953 by 5.6 per cent, according to a survey by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Eisenhower pleaded today for calmness in the face of "disappointment" over efforts to win the immediate release of eleven United States airmen jailed by Communist China.

A portion of the Lord estate in the Woodmere Park section of Woodmere, L. I., has been sold by Robert M. Lee to a building syndicate headed by Isadore Yedvarb and Sam Silverstein. The property comprises 100 home sites which will be developed with dwellings in the $27,500 to $32,000 price group.
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Jan. 14 (AP) -- The University of Arkansas will officially hire Wichita University's Jack Mitchell as football coach tomorrow morning.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and list of winter sports conditions:

Last year Father Knickerbocker fined erring motorists $8,721,325.
An Air Force test pilot skillfully belly-landed a jet fighter at 180 miles an hour yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, after the engine had "flamed out" at 40,000 feet.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 14 (UP) -- Willie Mays was booed for the first time in his career last night but today he was a hero once again to all Puerto Rican league baseball fans.

Today's new film is "The Beachcomber," a British-made adaptation of the W. Somerset Maugham story, at the Trans-Lux Normandie Theatre. Glynis Johns, Robert Newton and Donald Sinden are co-starred. William MacQuitty produced the Technicolor comedy and Muriel Box directed from a screen play by Sydney Box.
The Transit Authority asked yesterday for changes in state law that would check abuses of its sickleave hystem. Its plan would save $3,000,000 a year, the authority says.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- The Navy announced tonight that the atomic-powered submarine Nautilus was scheduled to begin sea trials Monday.

Pre-market testing of carpets and rugs for cleanability is still a rarity among manufacturers, speakers from the National Institute of Rug Cleaning told a rug care workshop at the Statler Hotel yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Dr. Schweitzer wrote a letter to "friends of the hospital," which was published in The London News Chronicle.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Steel warehouses are expecting a good year in 1955, their leaders said today. One spokesman predicted the fourth best year in history.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 14 -- United States intelligence services have been checking for months reports that an invasion of Costa Rica was being prepared from Nicaragua. But nothing was discovered to support the reports.

YONKERS, Jan. 14 -- In the face of current criticism against the administration of its school system, the Board of Education last night gave a vote of confidence to Dr. Stanley S. Wynstra, Superintendent of Schools, and raised his salary.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is preparing a modern-day French musical comedy called "Gaby" for its Gallic star, Leslie Caron.

Stocks drowsed through an uninspiring session yesterday and closed lower. Volume was off to 2,630,000 shares, the lowest since Nov. 1, and only 1,248 issues were traded. Of those, 572 fell, 396 rose and 280 were unchanged.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A ten-year Allied effort to break the power of German cartels is about to end.
Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that starting this spring it would provide daily service to Europe from Chicago. It will be Chicago's first direct overseas air service daily.

THE recently completed plans for the new Sports and Vacation Show, scheduled for Kingsbridge Armory on March 4 to 13, indicate that New York hunters and fishermen will have an opportunity to enjoy their first real "outdoor" show in many years.

Unnecessary haste in exposing the 4,700-year-old funerary bark of the Pharoah Cheops and faulty planning are causing serious damage to a rare archaeological discovery, Prof. Jotham Johnson of New York University said last night.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Recently at a formal soiree Kumao Nishimura, Japan's suave and enigmatic Ambassador in Paris, suggested to his Polish colleague, Stanislas Gajewski, that Tokyo was deeply interested in "normalizing" its relationships with the Communist nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The twenty-ninth Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense today urged Congress to enlarge the definition of treason to include conspiracy to overthrow the United States Government by force.
A bout between Raton Macias, a Mexican, and Mario D'Agata, a Italian, will be recognized by the National Boxing Association as being for the world bantamweight title.

Billy Rose announced last night that his next entertainment venture would be a "permanent world's fair" in mid-Manhattan. But the man he named as his chief associate in the venture said the whole affair was "far from a fait accompli."
LOS ANGELES, Calif Jan. 14 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman said today the Asiatic mainland was a volcano that might erupt at any time.
Governor Harriman declared last night that his Administration would demonstrate "the contrast , between Democratic boldness here and Republican timidity in Washington."

TOKYO, Jan. 14 -- The leaders of Japan's left and right-wing Socialists have agreed to work for early merger of their groups.

BADEN - BADEN. Saturday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial translation of the text of the communique issued here early today on the meeting of Premier Mendes-France and Chancellor Adenauer...
The New York Shipbuilding Corporation and the union that controls the 7,000 workers at its Camden, N. J., yard became embroiled again yesterday, in another of a long succession of squabbles.

Merger of the Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company, just announced jointly by the directors of these two institutions, will (on the reasonable assumption that it is approved by the stockholders of both banks and by the State Banking Department) represent a rare synthesis of size and historic banking tradition.
Merger plans of two Long Island banks and two upstate banks were announced yesterday.

" THE WORLD OF ALBERT SCHWEITZER,"* a book of photographs by Erica Anderson with text by Eugene Exman, is a splendid panorama of a vigorous genius in action on behalf of the health, harmony and happiness of mankind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The New York Central Railroad and Alleghany Corporation received permission from the Interstate Commerce Commission today to go ahead with their joint plan to acquire direct control of the Boston and Albany Railroad and two smaller lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (;P)-- The Bureau of Mines reported today that stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum totaled 259,460,000 barrels last Saturday, a decreas of 2,026,000 barrels for the week. Domestic etude decreased 698,000. Foreign crude decreased 1,328,000. D%ily average production was 6 574,000 barrels, I an increase of 231,000. Runs to! stills averaged 7,389,000, an in-I crease of 93,000.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 14 -- Within a few weeks Bermudians and British subjects who live here will be able to travel to the United States without passport or visa. This is part of a move by the United States to ease travel restrictions.
A 45-year-old woman was shot dead early yesterday morning as she lay sleeping in her home in Springfield Gardens, Queens. It was the second murder of a woman reported by Queens police in ten days.

The sixteenth annual White Elephant Party, a buffet dinner dance, was held in the ballroom of the Ambassador last night for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- A judge said in an inquest report today that Ed Sanders' ring death here last month was close to legalized murder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- The proposed merger in New York of the Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company raised a protest today from a member of Congress and a representative of small business.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 14 -- The Board of Social and Economic Relations of the Methodist Church called today on the 9,000,000 members of the denomination in this country to practice as well as preach the precept that racial segregation is un-Christian.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (UP) -- The New York Rangers routed Chicago tonight, 6 to 2, for their second victory in their last twenty-two games. The Broadway Blues increased their edge to 7 points over the Black Hawks, the cellar club of the National Hockey League.

PARIS, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- Dr. Albert Schweitzer, Nobel Prize winner and humanitarian, told the French radio network that he was "too weak" to broadcast a message tonight on a program celebrating his eightieth birthday.
EASTON, Pa., Jan. 14 -- Lafayette College today received a grant of $1,249,892.60 from the Olin Foundation for a building to be devoted to the sciences basic to engineering.

BADEN - BADEN, Germany, Saturday, Jan. 15 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Premier Pierre Mendes-France said last night they had achieved substantial progress on all questions concerning French-German relations.

The Soviet Government has announced that it will contribute to the United Nations discussions on peaceful use of atomic energy by making available technical and scientific information it has obtained from the 5,000-kilowatt atomic power plant which Moscow had earlier announced as beginning operation last June 27.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- William Zeckendorf, New York real estate developer, and an associate received a patent this week for a circular apartment house with a central well for elevators and utilities.
Gale winds and waves off the East Coast bludgeoned four ships into distress condition yesterday and pushed others into port.
HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., Jan. 14 -- Three high school seniors, missing from their homes here since Monday, were being held in Key West, Fla., today as the father of one left to bring them back.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations indicated today that Communist China might release eleven United States airmen if tension between that country and the United States lessened.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted today to investigate the stock market. It will seek the causes of a sixteen-month bull market in securities.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 14 -- The Nationalist legislative Yuan, or Parliament, ratified the United States-Chinese mutual defense treaty unanimously today.
The steel nerves of a war-veteran policeman and the alertness and courage of a slight. 70-year-old jeweler combined yesterday to thwart a hold-up on Madison Avenue.
KOTA NICA, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 7 -- A few acres of land here in the muddy Gabau Valley may some day determine the economic future of all of Netherlands or West New Guinea.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 14 (AP) -- The State Council of Churches outlined today a ten-point program its legislative committee was urging for action by the Legislature.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 14 (UP) -- Gov. James F. Byrnes, who retires Tuesday, said today his work during World War II as Director of War Mobilization was his "most important" job during forty-five years of public life.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- The talks between Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, and Chou En-lai, Chinese Premier and Foreign Minister, in Peiping were "intense, earnest and continuous."
The re-election of Paul Hall as secretary-treasurer of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., is indicated as the union's elections close today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Senate today unanimously passed a new anti-Communist resolution. Then it plunged into bitter debate during which Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was twice ordered to take his seat for impugning the sincerity of other Senators.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 14 -- The Navy launched a full-scale dependents' deluxe train here today when 371 wives and children of naval personnel started the trek to the West Coast.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers cooled off once red-hot Fort Wayne, 97 -- 83, tonight for the Pistons' third straight National Basketball Association defeat.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- A final offer by the Philadelphia Transportation Company averted tonight a city-wide transit strike two hours before the midnight deadline.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The American Automobile Association today urged a Federal interstate road system "undarkened anywhere by the shadow of a toll gate."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, took a "show me" attitude today toward the Soviet Union's offer to share atomic power information with other nations.

PERTH, Australia, Jan 14 (UP) -- Mike Green of Miami Beach, Fla., a 17-year-old junior tennis player, who accompanied the Davis Cup team to Australia to gain tournament experience, upset Rex Hartwig of Australia, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 5, today in an exhibition.

The Fund for the Republic's study of communism in American life begins far later than it should have to do the most good; but it is welcome, none the less. At last we are promised an objective assembly of facts and of the conclusions to which they will lead -- free from the profoundly dis tracting emotions which the great Russian Soviet threat has let loose.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 14 -- The exclusive use of group activities to deal with juvenile delinquency was criticized today at a national meeting of community leaders.
An unorthodox suggestion for the home-cooking of steak comes from John C. Bruno, whose Pen and Pencil restaurant at 205 East Forty-fifth Street is in the heart of what is known as Steak Row.

Escarole, excellent in quality now and reasonable in cost at 12 cents a pound, has many culinary possibilities. The tender inner leaves contribute fine flavor to salads, and the tougher outside leaves may be cooked and served in various combinations.

Merger plans have been arranged by the Hooker Electrochemical Company of Niagara Falls and Durez Plastics and Chemicals, Inc., of North Tonawanda on a share-for-share basis, officials of the companies disclosed yesterday.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 14 -- Mr. Dulles and Mr. Lodge flew to Offutt Air Force Base today for the secret briefing by General Le May.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits recommended yesterday that the state provide public defenders for youthful offenders unable to retain counsel.
The natural gas men of Texas may be trying to outsmart the United States Government.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 14 -- You spend a sunny, windy morning here with Max Hirsch and you learn all sorts of things. Such as:
MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- The Hamilton Thistles, victors in 1954, were eliminated in the first round of the Douglas Medal curling bonspiel at the St. Andrew's club today.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Decisions designed to bring freer international trade in West Europe and to pave the way for freeing currencies from controls were taken today by the finance ministers of seventeen countries. The ministers were sitting as the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

Red blood cells appeared as large as baseballs and tiny bits of hay-fever-producing pollen looked like spiny basketballs yesterday as C. B. S. Laboratories demonstrated a new high power microscope. Even living cells can be enlarged up to 15,000 times with the device, which enlarges electronically and projects in full color optical images from a conventional microscope adapted for the work.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The Conservative party has won the parliamentary by-election in South Norfolk, a marginal constituency, by a reduced majority.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 14 -- The Turkish Premier, Adnan Menderes, denounced today "shortsighted and ill-willed circles'' for opposing the decision by Turkey and Iraq to conclude a regional defense alliance open to other Middle East states.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- The Soviet Union said today that it was ready to share the scientific and technical experience "piled up" in the operation of an atom-driven industrial power plant.

PANAMA, Saturday, Jan. 15 -- President Jose Ramon Guizado asked the National Assembly early today for a leave of absence. He sought to step aside pending investigation of charges of personal involvement in the murder of his predecessor, President Jose Antonio Remon.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 14 -- South Africa plans to move eventually all 178,000 Negroes in the western region of Cape Province.
BINGHAMTON, Jan. 14 -- The board of trustees of the Binghamton Public Library directed the library director, Marcus Wright, in a formal statement of policy today to resist "volunteer" censors.

Stockholders of D. Emil Klein Company, cigar makers, at a special meeting here yesterday, voted to sell a substantial part of the company's assets to Waitt Bond, Inc., which also makes cigars. It also was voted to amend the certificate of incorporation by changing the D. Emil Klien name to Demlein Corporation. Finally, the dissolution of the company was authorized at such time as the directors may determine.

The United States Ambassador to France said last night that the French Government s changed fiscal policies, tax reform and other measures seemed to have placed that country "on the threshold of a new economic and industrial revolution that could bring astonishing progress in the next ten years."

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 14 -- Recent progress in surgery of the heart has probably made a deeper impression at the third Inter-American meeting of the American College of Surgeons than any other single subject.
All Christians have been urged by the Commission on Faith and Order of the World Council of Churches to pray daily in the week beginning next Tuesday for Christian unity.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 14 -- Dr. George Stoddard, director of the Self Study Committee of New York University, unveiled tonight what he described as an entirely new proposal for the teaching of the liberal arts. He outlined his proposal in a talk before faculty members at Hofstra College.
GROSSINGER, N. Y., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Don McDermott of Englewood Cliffs, N. J., captured the 500 and 5,000-meter races in the Eastern Olympic speed skating trials today.

Federal contracts totaling $1,394,688 that might have gone elsewhere were won by small business men of the New York area last year through the intervention of the regional office of the Small Business Administration. Six additional contracts valued at $670,000 are pending.
Experimental cars will be shown at the General Motors Motorama opening Thursday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 15 -- Captain George Brooke set a Yale scoring record with five goals to lead the Blue to an 8-0 victory over Army in hockey tonight. Brooke also assisted twice.

Weather played a big part tn enabling store sales to go ahead of a year ago by about 15 per cent in the week ended yesterday. There were two days of nearblizzard in 1954 and two days of extreme cold. Last week a light snow on Thursday cut into early gains.
The Department of Hospitals is closing two more of its older tuberculosis hospitals because of the decline in the need for beds since the new antimicrobial drugs became available.

MAYBE "Not for Love" can best be described as a typical Horatio Alger story thrown into reverse. The poor, unwanted, neglected hero makes good -- so to speak -- not by honesty and kind deeds but by utter ruthlessness; not his virtue but his animality is oppressively underlined; and instead of living on and on in material comfort to ripe old benevolence he dies at 70 a mean and obliterative death.

Even for one intensely interested in a gratifying service experience, the active duty period (totaling 11 1/2 years of which 9 1/2 were commissioned service) was a sore disappointment. I tendered my resignation about two years ago with no regrets.

Representative Francis E. Walter, co-author of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act, last night accused Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer of having disseminated a "new set of totally confused ideas" in condemning the act.

SAFETY HARBOR, Fla. -- This winter Florida's west coast is acquiring its own outdoor dramatic spectacle based on a regional theme and employing a large, cast of actors, dancers and musicians. Tourists driving into the state will see large billboards along the main highways announcing the production, "Florida Aflame," which is to be presented hero in Safety Harbor starting Saturday and continuing nightly except Mondays through April 17.

The good news came from Baden-Baden, Germany, yesterday that Chancellor Adenauer and Premier Mendes-France had made "substantial progress" toward agreement on French-German relations. The statement, issued at the close of what our correspondent, M. S. Handler, called "a grueling day of conversations," emphasized the belief "that France and Germany would best serve the welfare of the two nations, European unity and world peace by cooperating closely with the community of free nations in all fields."
FROM the deck of our sidewheel steamer, we admired Buenos Aires' skyline as, on the dock below us, scores of emotional Argentines hugged and bussed each other amid parting lamentations.
The Bronx Power Squadron, chartered in 1946, has as its sphere of influence the shorelines of Bronx County with home waters in and about City Island.

MONTREAL -- Every day now many snowbirds holidaying at Laurentian Mountain resorts both north and east of here are having the time of their lives without so much as putting a foot into a ski harness -- for all that the Laurentians are the most fully developed ski region in all Canada.

Already apprehensive voices have been raised concerning the program of general military training and a revitalized reserve that was sent forth to Congress by President Eisenhower last week. We do not share in this apprehension. On the contrary, we see cogent reasons, both practical and ethical, why this program should recommend itself to thoughtful persons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today accused Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, of "deliberate deception" in the Peress case.
TWO flights up in a brownstone house on Jane Street in Greenwich Village is the room where Charity Bailey leads a group of children in informal preparation for her show called "Sing-a-Song."
YONKERS, Jan. 15 -- The Otis Elevator Company issued an ultimatum today to 2,100 employes and city officials. It said: Cooperate to cut costs or the company will move to a new plant in the Midwest.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 15 -- A jump-shot at 17:13 of the first half added a scoring record to those belonging to Princeton's captain, Hal Haabestad. With the basket, Haabestad became the first player in Tiger history to score 1,000 points in three years. His 27 points led Princeton to a 63-54 Ivy League victory over Harvard in Dillon Gym tonight.

THERE was once a high school girl in Seton Hall Academy, Greensburg, Pa. Her name was Ethel Danforth and, after a career as a reporter on The Pittsburgh Press, she entered Maryknoll and emerged as Sister Maria del Rey.

A NEW lens system, in which the rear component is permanently fixed in the camera but the front component is replaceable by accessory components to achieve a semi-telephoto or wide-angle effect, is the principal feature of the Kodak Retina IIIc 35mm camera, recently announced by Eastman Kodak Company.

MIAMI BEACH -- Down this way the stock market is not the business barometer it is up around Wall Street. Here what happened over the Christmas and New Year week-ends and at the horse track is the basic guide to the season ahead.

Art Dunn of Sewanhaka High, who won his first indoor mile, recently repeated the performance last night in the sixth annual Cardinal Hayes interscholastic track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory. More than 2,400 athletes from 122 schools competed in the meet.

JUDGING from this extraordinary collection of nine short stories, Shirley Ann Grau is quite likely to be one of the chief literary discoveries of recent years. One has to go back to Eudora Welty's first book, "A Curtain of Green," for a comparable performance.

SOME twenty-odd years ago there flourished an ironic type of murder novel, suavely literate and rich in subacid observation of human mores and motivations -- a school in which Francis Iles was headmaster and Richard Hull, Edwin Greenwood and Anthony Rolls were among his brightest prefects.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Commander in Chief of the United States Army in Europe said today the Soviet Union was waging an all-out political fight against West Germany's arming, but apparently was not increasing Russian military forces in East Germany.

WE aren't sure of our terra firma here, but a Bible has come back into print, called "The Septuagint Bible," that is supposed to be the one that Jesus knew -- and obviously doesn't include the New Testament. Septuagint (SEP-too-uh-jint) means seventy.
Modern science has proved the oldtime almanac right once more. Weather scientists now believe that winter's January thaw, faithfully predicted in almanacs, actually does occur.
NEWARK, Jan. 15 -- The New Jersey Law Enforcement Council stepped over the heads of local police here and in Woodbridge yesterday to lead dramatic raids against an alleged $5,000,000 lottery ring.

LOS ANGELES, Calif. -- The pioneers who struggled across Death Valley a century ago almost unquestionably would succumb to astonishment rather than the rigors of nature if they could peer across its baking sands a few weeks hence.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Unseasonably mild weather as well as extreme cold causes winter injury to some trees and shrubs. Temperature of 60 degrees or more increases transpiration of evergreens and, unless this moisture loss is replenished, leaves and twigs will show damage. Mulches minimize the effects. Burlap is a shield against sun burning.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. -- Squawks from motorists from coast to coast that they have been gypped on speeding charges while driving through New Mexico seem to be engendering some improvement in the situation at last.

THIS is the third volume in Charles Angoff's fictional portrayal of Jewish-American life in the past half century. All that was present and potential in the preceding two volumes, "Journey to the Dawn" and "In the Morning Light," ripens in "The Sun at Noon" and achieves a cumulative artistic effect that is extraordinary.

A SPRAWLING, brawling historical, "Louisiana Cavalier," has just above everything -- settings that range from the Sun King's Versailles to the outposts of his Mississippi kingdom, sea-fights off the Azores, erotic festivals among the Natchez Indians, the enmities of hell-roaring kinsmen, love, pursuit and capitulation in forest Eden and silken boudoir.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- That hardy perennial, proposed reform of the rules of Congressional investigating committees, is rising in the new Democratic Eighty-fourth Congress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A renewed effort to bar so-called "hate" publications from the mail is not meeting with widespread support among Government officials here.

I OFTEN wonder whether Americans do not become a little tired of being told by Europeans that their cultural roots do not strike deep enough, that they are vigorous but immature and that the differences -- admittedly numerous and remarkable -- between European and American culture can be traced to America's lack of tradition.

LAKE PLACID -- A skiing enthusiast who likes to try out a different area every week-end was talking about some of his findings of recent years. One of the things that surprised him, he said, was the great progress made in the development of ski centers in the Adirondacks.

President Eisenhower and the Eighty-fourth Congress have now had ten days in which to work together. The President's half dozen messages have been well received and the Senate seems favorably disposed toward the Southeast Asian defense pact and the mutual defense treaty with the Chinese Nationalist Government on Formosa.

A full twelve-hour Saturday, following Friday night's preview teaser, provided National Motor Boat Show excitement to throngs yesterday in Kingsbridge Armory, the Bronx. They came early. Even in 28-degree temperature and with a light snow falling, Capt. John J. Quinn of the 50th Precinct reported 3,000 in line, four abreast, and stringing up Jerome Avenue, waiting for the opening ship's gong at 11 o'clock.

A DEMONSTRATION of the abacus in the teaching of elementary mathematics at a recent meeting of the Central Association of Science and Mathematics Teachers in Chicago has opened the eyes of pedagogues to a new look at an old mathematical device -- the ancients' equivalent of the adding machine.

NEW YEAR this year rang in the lawmaking season for some 6,500 state legislators in forty-two states (the others meet in the spring or in even-numbered years). January is the month most State Representatives (or Assemblymen) and Senators leave their farms, insurance offices and law practices to gather at their state capitols for the opening of the 1955 legislative sessions.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN didn't do any handsprings when he read that the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and the National Broadcasting Company had decided to put the announcement of the Academy nominations, Feb. 12, on television as a forerunner to the "Oscar" presentation ceremony in March.

THE adroit and witty advocate who has been known as the Gerald Du Maurier of the British bar showed us earlier this year, in his "Cases in Court," that he can tell a case for the reading public very nearly as well as he can present it before a jury.

THE tourist, swathed in suntan oil and a brief bathing suit and doing nothing more significant than lolling on a beach in the West Indies or Latin America, or at a sunny Sicilian winter resort, does not look much like an instrument of high United States foreign policy.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- An atmosphere of mutual respect for the other's powers and capabilities has marked the start of formal relations between Governor Harriman and his Democratic state administration on the one hand and the Republican-controlled Legislature on the other.

THE only solution to the public hunting problem, according to the majority of sportsmen who have commented on the situation, lies in the establishment of a simple but sound landowner-sportsman program.
SINCE actors do not write their own material, there must be a fine literary quality in "Anastasia" somewhere. For the second act contains the most exhilarating dramatic scene of the season.

Encouraging results on a project for the treatment and counseling of families in which there is mental illness has been reported by one of the country's largest family service agencies.

The Communist regime that rules China is, for most of the world, shrouded in mystery. There have been brief glimpses of the "New Life" in that vast land, and a steady flow of propaganda on what that life means. But the essential mystery remains. It involves the great questions: What are her aims, and how is the free world to deal with her?

NORTH CONWAY, N. H. -- In its efforts to match up supply with the booming winter-sports demand New Hampshire this season offers two new Alpine lifts plus several extra rope tows, and now figures it can haul well over 50,000 skiers an hour up the state's snowy hills and mountains.

MIDDLETOWN SPRINGS, Vt. -- Modern American skiing has now reached its majority. It was twenty-one winters ago that a wheezy little rope tow in the Green Mountains became the nation's first lift. It cost $300, put up by three weary skiers -- $100 apiece -- and set off a multi-million -dollar chain reaction which is still going on.
The opening of competition for the fifth annual Grantland Rice Fellowship has been announced by Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

THIS month of January, 1955, brings with it a number of musical anniversaries -- too many, in fact, to be fully listed here. The most important of these, of course, comes on the 27th, Mozart's birthday.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- The Exchange Club here has been suspended by the national organization because of the election of a Negro to membership, club officials reported today.

The board of governors of the Thistle Class of sailing craft set Aug. 24 to 26 as the dates for its national championship regatta. The choice was small at a Princeton Club meeting yesterday. The event will be on Lake St. Claire at Detroit.

SEVERAL years ago in this column I made some mention of the practice, beloved by some, and detested by others, of reading aloud. I spoke of its decline, and was interested to note, in the correspondence which followed, how many people wrote in to say that in their families, at least, the practice was still honored.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 15 -With a growing oil fortune at her disposal, Iraq is in the position of being able to pick and choose among her many commercial suitors.

Are there schisms in the Soviet hierarchy? Under the protection of secrecy do the men in the Kremlin engage in great struggles and debates the outcome of which influence Soviet domestic and foreign policy? Here are key questions for Western diplomatic and intelligence specialists charged with forecasting Moscow's course so that timely countermeasures can be taken.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 15 -- Princeton swimmers defeated Dartmouth, 46 -- 38, today with a victory in the final event, the 400-yard free-style relay.

BUFFALO, Jan. 15 -- After fifty-two years of progress in all types of motor-boat racing, the American Power Boat Association has come to be recognized as the American authority of the Union for International Motor-boating.

Hollins College (Va.) has set up a new foreign program of study and travel to be supervised by the faculty. The students will go to the Sorbonne in Paris in February of their sophomore year and return to the Hollins campus at the end of January in their junior year.

A shortage of one-design asses to choose from is not one of the problems confronting the person contemplating small-boat sailing competition. The problems are more likely to be factors of price and oppositions.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 15 -- The assassination of President Jose Antonio Remon of Panama and its dramatic aftermath and the current fighting in Costa Rica, have a common denominator in that they are manifestations of deep-rooted political, economic and social dislocations.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Chris Chataway won the three-mile exhibition race at the Wanderers Club track today in 14 minute 39.4 seconds. The British runner's time was 9 seconds slower than the South African record.

THE season is here, shining like a second sun on the arc of islands that span the Caribbean Sea from Cuba to Trinidad. The season is the time of the perfect tropical winter, of carnival highjinks and, later, of Easter celebrations, of resort hotels that leap in price and tourists who leap to pay.

THE story of the Wild West has been told from the viewpoint of the adventurer, the gold miner, the cowpuncher. It has, in fact, been retold so many times that one may be pardoned for concluding that no new facet could possibly be discovered.

Modernism ONE of the reasons, I believe, why the Modern movement has lasted longer than many assaults on the bastion of American taste is quite simply that it appeals to a morality that is deeply embedded in our history.

THE banning of two Broadway plays in Britain this season has once again focused attention on the usually inconspicuous office of the Lord Chamberlain, who combines absolute power over the local public stage with such incongruous duties as managing Royal garden parties.

TWO years ago the contemporary English sculptor Reg Butler sprang into somewhat notorious recognition by his winning the internationally organized Unknown Prisoner Competition. It was courageous of the judges to have awarded him the prize.

Two sales in popular categories -- American and English furniture and decorations of the eighteenth century and modern paintings -- will be held this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 15 -- The University of Massachusetts' hockey team spoiled the dedication of the Walter S. Orr rink as it nipped Amherst, 5 -- 4, today.
With more and more boat owners turning to sporting events, the Eastern Cruiser Association is planning an increased number of predicted-log and other tests of piloting skills this year.
A large Siberian city has arisen under unexplained circumstances in the last few years in one of the Soviet areas closed to foreign travel.
Top drivers convened yesterday for the annual Gulf Marine Racing Hall of Fame breakfast at the Belmont Plaza Hotel. Thirteen were inducted into this select fraternity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- President Eisenhower at midterm is a changed man -- a man of increasing political awareness, with a firmer grip on the problems of world leadership.
New York Port of Embarkation officials have just had their first experimental peek at television.
Recent material in the Soviet press has shed new light on the direction of Soviet thinking and research with regard to the generation of electric power from atomic sources.
The city fathers are looking for a copy of some proposed legislation that apparently has vanished.

THE two-week revival of "The Time of Your Life" at the City Center beginning Wednesday represents the only play by me to be professionally produced on Broadway in more than ten years. I have every hope and very nearly every reason to believe the play will be effectively performed by an excellent cast working for a minimum wage -- but the production will be for two weeks and it will be a revival.

FOR those who have not met Robert Nathan before, the timorous gaiety and quixotic thrusts of "Sir Henry" might well induce a state of pleasant shock. Nathan buffs who have answered the bell a score or more times (most recently with last year's "The Train in the Meadow") will simply settle back for another sunny souffle.
RICHMOND, Jan. 15 -- The American Power Boat Association today has become a modern and efficient operating organization.

RETAIL business is booming, if the Federal Reserve Board figures on department store sales are any criterion. The first week of 1955 brought sales gains averaging 13 per cent over those of the comparable week in 1954, indicating that New Year resolutions to curtail spending this year were less numerous than they were a year ago.
Workmen toiled through last night under floodlights to transfer a pair of railroad tracks to a temporary wooden trestle near the Harlem River.

COCONUT GROVE, Fla., Jan. 15 -- The newest hotels along Florida's Gold Coast are going in for yacht docks and basins. At Miami Beach alone, seven hotels operate yacht docks as part of their facilities. A larger number have made arrangements whereby guests' yachts can get special attention at commercial docks.
McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J., Jan. 15 -- This airfield at the edge of Fort Dix, an uncongested fighter base in recent years, is about to become a major airline station -- an Idlewild in uniform.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The latest Soviet attempt to forestall arming Western Germany is regarded here as unimportant in itself but potentially distracting for the cause of European unity.

The report for 1954 of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as parent concern of the Bell System, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $480,460,000. Figures for December are partly estimated. This was equal to $10.41 a share on the company's outstanding capital stock.

For a few brief hours last week press wires sizzled with the incredible news that the dream of every longshot player had been realized when a nonillion-to-one shot had come home. Sadly, it was not true. It was only an insignificant 51-to-1 shot.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sunday, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Nationalist Chinese bombers attacked the Red China mainland Friday night and early yesterday for the first time since signing of the Nationalist-United States mutual defense pact on Dec. 2, the Defense Ministry said last night.
GENEVA, Jan. 14 -- European economic analysts and commentators, who take their time about such things, have by now given 1955 a pretty good once-over and found the prospects fine.
HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 15 (UP) -- A young mother who robbed a package liquor store with her baby in her arms was arrested today when she tried to bail her husband out of jail with the loot.

SPEAKING of the discovery and exploration of the great mountain Amne Machin, on the China-Tibet frontier, in his review of Leonard Clark's "The Marching Wind," your reviewer Roy Chapman Andrews writes that the undersigned "saw it from a distance of seventy-five miles."
Bullish enthusiasm that had propelled stock prices sharply higher in the last sixteen months subsided somewhat last week.

THE 1955 issue of "Universal Photo Almanac" (New York: Falk Publishing Company, $2.50) is primarily a how-to-do-it compilation in the manner of the monthly photographic magazines. Its principal value is in the technical data sections, the picture market list and the bibliography, which are brought up to date and provide a useful source of information in these fields.
Sixty-five groups representing advertising, publishing and printing industries have planned a week-long series of events for Printing Week, which starts tomorrow.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 15 -Yale extended its consecutive dual swimming meet winning streak to 118 today, defeating Army, 70 -- 14. The triumph was the Eli's fifth of the season and the fourth in Eastern League competition.

WHEN Joe DiMaggio resolutely turned his back on a $100,000 salary and retired from baseball, it was expected that he'd be elected to baseball's Hall of Fame by the biggest landslide since Franklin D. Roosevelt swept every state except Maine and Vermont. By this time, however, the Yankee Clipper knows how Tom Dewey felt in 1948. To the vast embarrassment of the pollsters the Jolter fluffed it badly.
BARTOK: Divertimento for String Orchestra; Two Portraits; RIAS Symphony conducted by Ferenc Fricsay (Decca). Spirited performances, led by a conductor with real temperament. Clear recorded sound.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 10 -- Political activity by former Premier David Ben-Gurion is stirring speculation as to whether he intends to return to leadership of the nation.
Willie Mays will return to San Juan, Puerto Rico, to participate in the play-offs with the Santurce club, but he will not play winter baseball again.

THE Schneider String Quartet goes merrily along in its series of Haydn quartets, coming to the fore with the six quartets of that composer's Op. 2 on three Haydn Society disks. Nos. 3 and 5 of this set contain two horns, played here by Weldon and Kathleen Wilber.

An automobile powered by a 300-horsepower engine was presented yesterday by the Chrysler division, Chrysler Corporation. The new model will go on display tomorrow at the Chrysler International Auto Salon, 405 Lexington Avenue.
William Sylvester Cole, companion of a hold-up man shot by a policeman at a Madison Avenue jewelry store Friday evening, was held without bail yesterday.
A luncheon-meeting tomorrow may have a bearing on whether the headquarters of the nation's five top engineering societies will remain in New York.

The sail course is the newest addition to the curriculum of the United States Power Squadrons and has already taken the lead position in the elective courses. During the past year fifty-three squadrons taught the subject, with a total enrollment of 488 students.
PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Flood alerts were given throughout many areas of France today as unseasonable warmth and heavy rains sent rivers and streams dangerously high.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 14 -Deputy Leader Wilhelm Mellies of the Social Democratic party told the Deputies of his party today that if the Paris agreements were ratified no living German might see the reunification of Germany.

NO exhibition the Whitney Museum ever staged has reflected more clearly the current ferment of the art world. A group of tough latecomers in the family of plastics has successfully invaded the tool field and is reported to be cutting production costs right and left in manufacturing industries.

THOUGH spring may seem to be far away now, it is just around the corner for those organizations that are making preparations for the major 1955 flower shows. Of course, New Yorkers now know that the International Flower Show will not be held in the city this year, but will be postponed until 1956.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Senator Prescott Bush said today the public "will collect the dividends" on the Senate Banking Committee's impending study of the stock market.

IT is indeed gratifying that Elmer Rice has discovered "theatre on the campus." The quality of work he describes at Michigan, in a recent article in your section, has been going on there and elsewhere for some time.

MOST of the denizens of this unhappy novel are Irish-Parish nomads. Lu Rienzi, a spoiled, selfish and unhappy Irish lady despite her name, has come to France because she is pregnant and hopes to find her vanished lover there.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Racing outboard records set in 1954 by motors that were formerly considered outclassed in that division have generated interest on the part of many drivers in the purely stock classes.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Patty Berg took the lead in the first round of the thirty-six-hole Sea Island women's open golf tournament today with a par 37, 39 -- 76, but she plans to go back to her old putter tomorrow.

AMONG the more recent films put in 16mm. circulation it is especially interesting to find two paying tribute to Edison and indirectly, the nontheatrical field itself. One commemorates the inventor's 107th birthday anniversary; the other the seventy-fifth anniversary of the first practical incandescent lamp.
BERNE, Switzerland. NOW that Wilhelm Furtwaengler has been buried in Heidelberg, the question of succession is the ripest topic of speculation in the musical world of Central Europe.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 15 -The Israeli Government charged tonight that Syrians were not treating Israeli prisoners of war in accordance with the Geneva convention of 1949.
The major political parties have been urged to consider the Coliseum, now being built at Columbus Circle, as the site for the 1956 Presidential nominating conventions.

HELEN MacINNES -- the original Helen MacInnes of "Above Suspicion" and "Assignment in Brittany" -- is with us again. This is good news indeed. Sometimes, for novels on end, she has strayed from the field of atmospheric suspense which she creates so well into the world of reality.
The Bissell family is out to prove that the vacuum cleaner never will push the carpet sweeper out of the American home.

AMONG all the wide variety of pictures that have opened hereabouts in the past few weeks -- and which, for one reason or another, have not yet been mentioned in this space -- perhaps the most certainly intriguing, as a sheer entertainment exercise, is Walt Disney's "live-action" version of "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea."
Long Island University's oldest woman day student -- a pink- cheeked brunette of 39 years -- carries a schedule that would astound many a harassed New York housewife.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Senator Barry M. Goldwater predicted today that President Eisenhower would run for re-election next year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The Bureau of Mines reported today that minerals production last year totaled $13,820,000,000, or 4 per cent below the record $14,408,000,000 output of 1953.

The construction of a "northern tier" for the Middle Eastern defense structure has taken a long spurt forward as a result of the decision by Turkey and Iraq to conclude a mutual defense alliance against aggression and to call on other Middle Eastern states to join this undertaking.
Tuesday night 900 clothing workers will gather at Webster Hall to celebrate the fortieth anniversary of the founding of their union, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O.

An increasing interest in piloting courses from the inland sections of the country -- even from areas where it is hard to realize there is sufficient water to float a boat -- indicates that the Middle West will soon be as enthusiastically boat-minded as the Eastern and Western Seaboards.

VIJAYAVADA, India, Jan. 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru appealed today for election support to prevent Andhra from becoming the first Communist-ruled state in India. The Indian leader has been making this appeal for the last two days as his ten-year-old plane carried him from town to town in Andhra.
Snow fell here yesterday for the second time in three days, but it caused little inconvenience.
The New York Power Squadron is now entering its forty-first year.

Mr. Baldwin stated that the new Uniform Code of Military Justice had in fact delayed the administration of justice. I spent about a year in Korea with the Third Infantry Division as defense counsel and law officer.

DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- Among the split-second performers who jockey the racing power boats over the regatta courses, where the fireworks are served on the water rather than above it, the year-long competition was dominated by two trophy-laden pilots and a 6-year-old boy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy said today he was taking up with the Justice Department for possible prosecution the case of the "cover" Senate investigators placed on his mail in the fall of 1952.

The upcountry farmer getting sawlogs out of his wood lot this week is timing it just about right. It's mid- January and the moon is in the last quarter. Those logs will be seasoned to make good lumber, straight planks and flat boards.
PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Scandinavian representatives today complained at the high prices maintained by the European Coal and Steel Community in Luxembourg.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 15 -- Rear Admiral Harold O. Larson, Commander of Destroyer Flotilla Four, has been ordered to duty in the Department of Defense as director of armed forces information and education. He will assume his new duties in mid-February, the Navy announced.

Dr. Charles W. Cole, president of Amherst College, has advised the board of trustees against enlarging the college to meet growing needs of the population. Aside from the loss of social and educational values that follow when small colleges get too big, he pointed out that it would cost Amherst $15,000,000 to increase its enrollment by half and provide adequate facilities.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14 -- A slate of thirty-five candidates for election to seventeen Harvard University alumni offices has been selected by the nominating committee of the Alumni Association.
The memory of seventy-six persons affiliated with Columbia University who died last year will be honored today.

HOW does our musical life look to one who, because he is of it and yet not of it, has a certain amount of detachment? It looks all right. It has made considerable progress, particularly in the orchestral field.
KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Skimming often on one ski over a course almost solid with ice, Austria's Anderl Molterer won the international Hahnenkamm downhill race for men today.

I would like to suggest that Elmer Rice visit my campus -- the University of Utah in Salt Lake City -- where he would find at least five theatres, all very much "alive"! For instance, the University Theatre (the major group) presents each year five productions and not of the "John Loves Mary" variety, as entertaining as that may be.
A YOUNG friend of ours came home from school one afternoon in something less than the best of spirits. It seems he'd had a substitute teacher that day and events had not been to his liking.
MADRID, Jan. 15 -- Prince Juan Carlos of Bourbon, son of the pretender to the Spanish throne, is scheduled to arrive in Madrid Tuesday to begin an education designed to fit him to be king.

THE airlines can take much of the credit for the contemporary custom of winter holidays in addition to summer ones. Speed of the airplane has made it possible to leave a crowded midwinter desk and take off for holidays north, south, east or west, and still get back to work in a couple of weeks.

HONG KONG, Jan. 15 -- Officially sponsored mass rallies are still being held in Red China to register protests against the United States-Chinese Nationalist mutual security pact and to mobilize the people behind the Peiping regime's "liberate Taiwan" [Formosa] campaign.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Joe Miceli, New York welterweight, stood off the bull-like rushes of Italo Scortichini. Italian middleweight, to gain a draw in their nationally televised fight tonight.

As a result of an experiment started three years ago by Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy and the New York City Department of Welfare, an impressive number of physically handicapped relief clients are being rehabilitated to employment. If current plans materialize, the number will be increased not only in the city but throughout the state.

Jack T. Franklin of the Old Dominion Boat Club, Alexandria, Va., was re-elected a president of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen at the annual convention of the group at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 15 -- Irish-bred Poona II raced to a world record for a mile and a sixteenth in the $28,100 San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita today. The favored Determine finished fourth in a field of seven.

ATLANTA, Jan. 15 -- Department store sales in the Southeast last week were maintained substantially above levels of a year ago. Merchants in most centers reported demands for apparel, home furnishings and appliances were exceeding expectations.
THEY say it happens to everyone. If you ski long enough and hard enough, you will break something at least once. Statistics prove it makes no difference how young you are or how well you ski.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The apparent agreement among leading Republicans and Democrats to shorten the 1956 Presidential campaign is regarded in many quarters here as an effort to assure a return match between the 1952 opponents, Dwight D. Eisenhower and Adlai E. Stevenson.

SINCE foreign books have been brought to this country from colonial times on, the importation of a single Japanese novel might not appear to be an especially world-shaking event. Yet on both sides of the Pacific, in America and Japan, this simple event is being hailed as of real international importance, and political more than literary.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn will ask Budget Director Abraham D. Beame this week to approve a $6,671,451 budget for the next fiscal year. The figure represents an increase of $126,940 over last year's.

Despite City Planning Commission warnings of inadequacy the city has gone ahead with plans for a pedestrian overpass across Henry Hudson Parkway in Riverdale. The overpass will cross between West 235th Street and 236th Street.

THE New York City Ballet will add two new works by George Balanchine to its repertoire during its forthcoming winter season at the City Center, beginning Feb. 15. One of them will be a large piece called "Roma," set to three movements of Bizet's suite of the same name, with scenery and costumes by Eugene Berman.

The Meadow Brook Blues defeated the New York Athletic Club polo team, 12 -- 11, in the feature game last night at the Squadron A armory. Phil Iglehart paced the triumph with seven goals and registered the winning marker in the final seconds of the game.

MONTREAL, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings spotted Montreal three early goals tonight and then rallied for a 4-3 victory. The triumph vaulted Detroit into a first-place tie with the Canadiens in the National Hockey League.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 15 -- New automobile transactions in Cuyahoga County aggregated 74,000 last year, making 1954 the third best auto sales year in history. The year-to-year decline was only 4 per cent despite a factory production drop of 10 per cent.
PARIS, Jan. 9 -- Introduction of a new two-year period in the educational training of French scientists has been announced by Jean Berthoin, French Minister of Education.

THE Kremlin, with its fortress walls, twelve to sixteen feet thick, its nineteen watch towers, barbicans and battlements, its four cathedrals and numerous churches and chapels with bulbous domes catching the sun from their onion-skin casings of beaten gold, its great palaces and offices of state, is the heart of MOSCOW and the heart of Russia, old and new.
A great debate on military policy opened in Washington last week as the President sent to Congress his military manpower and reserve program.

MARGARETVILLE -- Because the central and northern sections of the Catskill Mountains had only a limited amount of snow in scattered spots during the early part of the winter, an unusual number of skiers, who would normally have stopped off near here at winter-sports centers like Phoenicia and Highmount, drove right through this Delaware County village last month on their way up north to Snowy Acres near Cobleskill or Mount Otsego at Cooperstown.

THE big problem in bridge, it seems, does not lie in slam bidding or control-showing or defense against opponents' shut-out bids or any of the other situations for which fancy conventions are devised. The big problem is to reach games that can be made.

BEYOND question, Charles George Gordon was an extraordinary man. Born, in 1833, of an upper-class British military family -- his mother was an Enderby connected with a famous New England shipowning family -- and with no previous connections with the East, he had instinctively an understanding of oriental and primitive peoples and a power over them, unaccountable and astonishing.

HOME greenhouse "veterans" invariably complain about insufficient space, but to a novice the empty benches and shelves in his new greenhouse may look tremendously spacious. It is amazing how quickly they can be filled and transformed into a lively show.

PARIS, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Foreign Ministry would like to know what the United States Embassy wants done with the large bronze statue of Lafayette that school children sent years ago in appreciation of the Statue of Liberty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative to the United Nations, remained "confident" today, amid expressions of doubt and disappointment, that Communist China would release the eleven imprisoned American airmen.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 (AP) -- In one of the sharpest attacks on any American peaonality in recent times, The Literary Gazette today Icalled ]Vfrs..Clare Soothe Luce,/ United States Ambassador to Italy, a "gauleiter in a, skirt."

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- Addison B. Hastings and his Ardsley No. 3 rink, and the host St. Andrew's Curling Club's No. 3 unit, skipped by W. Lincoln Seibert, reached the semi-finals of the Archibald Douglas Medal bonspiel today.
A new Tammany district leader has set into motion plans to give respectability to the political clubhouse.

Last July President Eisenhower, acting on the recommendation of the Tariff Commission, ordered a 50 per cent increase in the customs duties on watches having seventeen or more jewels. Since Mr. Eisenhower, as his recent message reminded us, believes in at least a "moderate" reduction in international trade barriers, this action surprised many persons.

NOTHING is so fascinating as human nature. This is an old saw. Writers have always known it. So have philosophers. But now in our psychiatry-conscious time specific insights and precepts heretofore unformalized have filtered into our thought, and we find them, sometimes used with subtlety and skill -- but more often not -- in nearly every type of writing.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15 -- Following closely after the official announcement that December department store sales in the St. Louis area and the Eighth District were 3 per cent above a year ago, with the full year showing no change, it was disclosed that debits at banks here for December were 7 per cent above a year ago at $2,414,308,000.

ELIZABETH CADELL'S novels must be the perfect answer to the often overheard plea in bookstores for something good but not too serious. They do have a vein of seriousness, but it comes to the surface in pleasant ways and through most refreshing dialogue.

Events last week dramatized the role played in American stock markets by the men who are known as "specialists." A Walter Winchell television tip resulted in a tidal wave of buying orders for the American shares of the Pantepec Oil Company, which holds concessions in Venezuela. The outcome was what was said to be the largest block of shares ever put together on a major stock exchange in this country -- 357,600 shares.
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 15 -- Bevis Longstreth scored the winning goal with less than five minutes left in the game today as Princeton's hockey team defeated Brown, 4 -- 3.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- Army's basketball team notched its first victory of the season today by upsetting New York University, 63 to 59, at the field house.

PRESSED to name Debussy's most famous ballet, the man in the street would be likely to reply, "L'Apresmidi d'un faune." But Debussy did not write this work as a ballet. It was an orchestral prelude that Nijinsky turned into a ballet twenty years after its composition.

IN a quarto-sized volume of fifty-four heavily illustrated pages Mable Pyne outlines the history and beliefs of the major living religions. Following a short introduction to some of the beliefs and practices of ancient men, she surveys briefly Hinduism.

President Eisenhower outlined last week the Administration's proposals in the field of foreign trade and tariffs. What follows is an explanation of how tariffs work, how they have fluctuated through the years and what the President now requests.
This letter is prompted by William Faulkner's letter published on Dec. 26 in which he commented on the recent Italian airliner crash at Idlewild.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- British scientists are dropping small quantities of irradiated tracer chemicals into the Thames in an attempt to find out how the mud that causes floods in the river is distributed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The multibillion dollar highway program formally proposed to President Eisenhower this week underwent vigorous attack today.

At the U. N. tomorrow, technical experts representing seven countries, including the U. S. and Russia, will meet with Secretary General Hammarskjold to lay the groundwork for the first world conference on the atom. The conference has been called by the U. N. Assembly in response to President Eisenhower's proposal of December, 1953, for a world atom pool.
The question of who should forecast the weather for the shipping industry was answered in several ways yesterday by Government and private meteorologists.

PALACE intrigues, pagan rites and prophecies of doom swayed ancient Samaria during the reign of Ahab and his Queen Jezebel. The First Book of Kings chronicles the disasters of strife-torn Israel when Jezebel brought Baal worship from her native Tyre.

BRUNSWICK, Ga. -- Jekyll Island, famed for more than a half-century as the exclusive private retreat of a group of about a hundred millionaires whose names made financial history in the United States, is now easily accessible to the public by means of a new $800,000 steel and concrete bridge from the mainland.

SON of a wanton, grandson of a sort of female fiend, Hubertus van Groenwegel started out in life with a strict moral code, determined to triumph over the wild blood in his veins. One of the minor mysteries of American politics is that the question, "Will the President seek a second term?" continues to evoke such interest, considering the fact that since the Civil War only Rutherford B. Hayes has said he wouldn't.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 13 -- The dispute over court jurisdiction for damage suits in the sinking of the freighter Mormackite may be decided by two life preservers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Philip Young, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, said today that the gains made by the Federal merit system in 1954 were "without parallel."

TOKYO, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -- A faint radio signal heard here today told fear-stricken Japanese fishermen that the "devil's sea," mystery graveyard of nine ships in the last five years, had at last been cheated or a victim.

The challenges facing banking in the post-war world of expanded production and diffused individual buying power are underscored by the merger decision just taken by two of New York's most renowned banks.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 -- Scimitar, a gray 5-year-old horse that hadn't won a race since 1953, surprised form players today when he took the $41,500 Tropical Handicap, closing feature at Tropical Park Race Track, before a crowd of 14,379.

A 19-year-old youth, who was charged last fall with having kidnapped another teen-ager, told the police last night that four youths had abducted him at knife-point and had kept him prisoner in a car for ten hours.

THE "Heroes of God Series" -- to which these three books belong -- is a splendid project, recently begun. It is based on the simple premise that there is no logical reason why children should be bored when they read about religion.

Lawrence E. Davies' special article in The Times of Jan. 9 explains how efficiently 1,135 Spanish sheepherders have been brought to the United States in recent years in part by charging their cases against Spain's small annual quota of 250 for many future years.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France told the French people by radio tonight that his talks this week with West German and Italian leaders had shown "encouraging" agreement for negotiations with the Soviet Union.

Retailers closed the forty-fourth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Statler Hotel last week in a mood far lighter than that of a year ago.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight proposed a record state budget exceeding $1,500,000,000 this week and immediately ran into heavy opposition among California legislators to a big tax increase program.

IN "Saints Alive" Arnold L. Haskell tells the stories of six well-known Roman Catholic saints, three men and three women. They are: Saints Joan of Arc, Thomas More, Bernadette, Anthony of Padua, Therese of Lisieux and the Cure d'Ars.

RUTLAND, Vt. -- What Vermonters believe will become the most lavish new ski development in the nation -- at Mount Snow, in the south central part of the state -- already displays a first installation consisting of two new-style chair lifts and other gleaming appurtenances.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Retailers in the Third Federal Reserve District are looking at 1955 with considerable optimism because of the record sales tallied by most of them during the Thanksgiving-Christmas season. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia noted that Christmas buying had extended well beyond the traditional gift-type merchandise.

George W. Sutton told the council meeting of the American Power Boat Association at the Belmont Plaza Hotel yesterday that 1954, the first year the A. P. B. A. had been the sole authority for the United States in international motor boating, was a constructive one.

TO THE EDITOR: James MacGregor Burns, setting forth in "Republicans, Democrats: Who's Who?" (Jan. 2) his arguments for a reshaping of the parties along conservative and liberal lines, writes: "An essential element of democratic government, they [political scientists] feel, is the presenting of relatively clear and simple alternatives to the great mass of the people who are bewildered * * *." I dissent.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings at the Pierre for the performance of "Tosca" on the night of Feb. 5 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Vassar Club of New York.
A fireman forced his way through the smoke and flame of a burning three-room apartment in Queens early yesterday to rescue a mother and her 3-year-old son.

NEW ORLEANS -- To the two traditional attractions of Louisiana -- Mardi Gras and the Spring Fiesta of New Orleans -- has been added this year the state-wide celebration of the bicentennial of the migration of the spirited Acadians from Nova Scotia to this state.

Numerous editorials and articles in local papers have recently dealt with the subject of the study of Russia and the Russian language in the United States. The general tenor of the articles indicates a "laziness" or "lack of interest" in the young folk for not attempting the rather difficult language, and a "scared and frightened" youth who consider the negative effects and potential or actual discrimination against students seriously engaging in such studies.

PARIS, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Auto crash injuries will keep Robert Cohen from defending the world bantamweight boxing title against Willis Toweel in Johannesburg, South Africa, on March 5, his manager said today.
CAIRO, Jan 15 -- The Middle East, one of the world's chronic trouble spots, is in a state of abnormal quiescence as the new year begins.
New Yorkers can now enjoy fresh crab meat sold here with the assurance of double protection against food poisoning.
