HANS SCHWIEGER has been engaged as general music director of the Aspen Festival by Mack Harrell, Szymon Goldberg, Rudolf Firkusny, Reginald Kell, Darius Milhaud, the New Music String Quartet and the other musicians who have taken over its management. He will be in charge of both the school and the concurrent festival that the former Aspen Institute faculty members will run at the Colorado town.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Jan. 16 -- The Council of the Organization of American States weighed early today a proposal calling upon the American republics to provide war material to Costa Rica to help her resist aggression.
COLORADO, SPRINGS, Colo., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The commander of the nation's anti-aircraft guns said today he was "happy with the over-all readiness and effectiveness" of anti-aircraft units.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- United States officials, watching the changes in Panama's Government, expressed hope today that the new President. Ricardo Arias Espinosa, would bring stability to the republic's internal affairs.

THIS is a timely book. Marshall MacDuffie explains in the preface that he considers himself to have been the subject of a Soviet experiment. As head of an U. N. R. A. mission in the Ukraine, which distributed some $180,000,000 in relief supplies, he had become acquainted with Nikita S. Khrushchev, now Secretary of the Central Committee of the Russian Communist party.

IN a professional French kitchen no pan is used more often than the sauteuse. The cook in his starched white ensemble, with a snowy napkin tucked around his throat like a scarf, reaches for this long-handled utensil almost as often as an American housewife plies her can opener.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- A local boy took the honors in tonight's annual Metropolitan Ski Jumping Clubs' tournament at this 50-meter hill but a Class B competitor won most of the cheers of a crowd estimated at 3,000.

TAMPA, Fla. -- On Monday, Jan. 24, overnight passenger ship service from Tampa to Havana, Cuba, with a stop at Key West will be restored for the first time since World War II. The Peninsular band Occidental Steamship Company, which operates the Florida out of Miami to Havana, has purchased a twin-screw turbine ship Denali from the Alaska Steamship Company.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 15 -- Tecolote Tunnel, $43,816,000 project of the Bureau of Reclamation, was holed through (cross) at 10:27 A. M. today.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 15 -- The West German Government's statisticians have been trying to calculate how many Germans are evading regular employment through premature retirement under the pension and social security system.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- The Soviet Union renewed its demands today for four-power talks on reuniting Germany and offered meanwhile to "normalize relations" with the Bonn Republic.
UNION, Conn., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Three persons, including two Marines, were killed in two separate but related accidents on the Wilbur Cross Highway here today.

TO THE EDITOR: Permit me to say that I think Prof. Arnold J. Toynbee cogently presented the "awful truth" about our secularized Western civilization in his "A Turning Point in Man's Destiny" (Dec. 26).
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 15 -- President Joao Cafe Filho set in operation today a huge hyro-electric power plant at Paulo Affonso Falls on the Sao Francisco River.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Jack Mitchell, 30-year-old head coach at Wichita University and a former assistant under DeWitt Weaver at Texas Tech, was named officially here today as University of Arkansas football coach at $12,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Led by the President, spokesmen for the Republican party set forth this week in organized fashion to defend Vice President Richard M. Nixon from mounting charges by Democratic spokesmen that he had "maligned and slandered" their party and its candidates in the 1954 campaign and "sweepingly" impugned the loyalty and patriotism of all Democrats. Criticism of this general nature came also from sections of the press and the public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A 33-year-old Oklahoman who started out to be an architect and engineer and then switched to political science is laying the groundwork for a Senate study of the stock market.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold briefed the permament representatives of five nations at the United Nations today on his talks in Peiping. His purpose in going to Peiping was to obtain the release of eleven United States airmen and other United Nations personnel held by Red China.

THE railroads are actively bidding for winter resort travel on the basis of their impressive safety record, the assurance that departure will be made regardless of the weather, plus on-time arrival in most cases. While fares have not been reduced, new equipment, more comforts and budget meals have added to the pleasure of travel by rail.

WINTER vacationists this season can make their selection from the largest list of cruises offered in a decade. Depending on tastes and pocket books, such nearby places as Bermuda and Nassau or such far-away points as ports in the South Pacific may be visited.

TWO years ago this week, President Eisenhower was inaugurated as the thirty-fourth President of the United States and, soon after, delivered his first State of the Union message. It reflected the views of a naturally optimistic man, hopeful that he could not only contain the Communists, but liberate the satellites.

The annual tea and cocktail dance for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York will be held on Thursday afternoon in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane under the auspices of the Lower East Side Committee.
To speed southbound rush- hour service some I. R. T. subway express trains, beginning tomorrow, will be routed through the Ninety-sixth Street and Broadway station on the local tracks.

MEXICO CITY -- Although prices have gone up somewhat since last spring's devaluation of the peso, Mexico's magnificent Pacific resort, Acapulco, will be less expensive to dollar-bearing tourists than it was last year.

OMAHA, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The father of an Omaha pilot held by the Chinese Reds told today of an unexpected visit with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States delegate to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Eisenhower has devised a little private lecture for the benefit of intimates who inquire about his plans for re-election. He doesn't tell them whether he will run again, but he emphasizes that no political party should gamble too much on the future actions of any individual.

TRENTON, Jan. 15 -- The 1955 New Jersey Legislature which convened here last Tuesday, will resume its deliberations on Monday. At that time the Republican majority will consider important matters of policy.
In a sermon to a Jewish congregation yesterday a Christian clergyman dwelt on goals and pitfalls in "the present greater turning to religion."

LONDON, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -- Snow and ice today struck a severe blow at the British soccer schedule, forcing postponement of forty-one of the sixty-two scheduled English and Scottish league games. Three matches were halted before play was completed.
Duquesne's basketball team stopped Fordham's winning streak last night. Before a near-sellout gathering at the Maroon gymnasium, the Dukes triumphed, 67 to 56.

IN a forest about forty miles from Saigon, inside small brown tents that scarcely withstand the monsoon, families crouch on straw mats and mud, ten and fifteen persons to a tent. They came by ship from the north, to escape communism. They have little rice, no medicines; they are catching rain water in tins.

The New York Knickerbockers defeated the Fort Wayne Pistons in a National Basketball Association game at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. A crowd of 4,000 fans cheered as the New Yorkers rolled up 106 points to their rivals' 87.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- It doesn't take much snow to make the Poconos a haven for skiers. For most of the slopes of northeastern Pennsylvania, only three inches of snow can start things teeming, and resort owners have been hoping that January and February will find their hillsides and trails covered -- or at least covered a little.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 -- The sole purpose of the United States Power Squadrons is to make boating safe and interesting to those participating in yachting.

DRIVING to Florida these days, I gather, is not much of a job. The vacationist begins by picking his route, choosing from among a number of excellent and highly publicized national highways or combining various routes to include places he wants to see.

WITH its third annual show, "Photography Sampler 1955," Mrs. Alice Vielehr's Little Gallery in the Hudson Park Branch of the New York Public Library, 10 Seventh Avenue, South, definitely establishes this annual event as a rare opportunity for promising photographers to show their pictures to a public audience, usually for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The report noted that the Federal budget document frequently was "too vague" in describing the use to which funds were put.

American colleges and universities were urged last week to take a critical view of themselves and to see whether they were doing a competent job in teaching the liberal arts. Too much over-specialization and too great an emphasis on vocational and technical education, it was held, had caused a lowering of the standards expected of the nation's liberal arts colleges.

FIFTEEN years ago a whole generation of German youth, in arms and uniforms, stood poised on the expanded frontiers of the Third Reich, prepared in their disciplined and devoted way to overrun on signal their neighbors to the east and west. In 1933, in Nuremberg, the new Reichskanzler had told them that "on the youth of Germany are set all our hopes, our people's confidence, and our faith."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- The old Kingsley plantation on Fort George Island east of Jacksonville, one of the outstanding historical spots in Florida, has been purchased by the Florida Board of Parks and Historic Memorials for a public attraction.

A prominent geneticist took issue last week with the Atomic Energy Commission's claim that the level of radiation reaching populated areas after atomic or hydrogen bomb tests is "far below the levels which could be harmful in any way to human beings."

PERIODICALLY some child not yet able to read properly puts aside toys for part of an evening, becomes a Broadway star and makes people wonder about the role of a child away from footlights. HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Jan. 15 -- A state of alert has been declared in this French corner of Communist North Vietnam as a result of public service strikes that will probably take place Monday.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 15 (UP) -- Scientists of eight Midwestern universities are designing an atom smasher to generate energy of 20,000,000,000 to 30,000,000,000 volts.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The first of Britain's new steam catapults for aircraft carriers will be installed on the 45,000-ton fleet carrier Ark Royal, which is due for sea duty early this year, the Admiralty announced today.

MARACAIBO, Venezuela, Jan. 15 -- A $20,000,000 gas conservation plant -- which shoots compressed gas back into oil wells to increase productivity -- was dedicated here today by Creole Petroleum Corporation, the big producing subsidiary of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Committee for Economic Development urged today some major changes in the preparation and form of the Federal budget.

TEN years after, the brutalities of war seem no less harsh; but now the participants, especially on the lower levels, become individuals. This helps all novels. Good and evil can be seen on both sides of the battle lines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn turned social host today for the first time in seven years.

To historians, Inwood is where Hendrick Hudson powwowed with the Indians after anchoring the Half Moon offshore. To northbound motorists on the West Side Highway, it is that stretch of woodland where one digs for a dime before the first toll-gate.

Capturing first place in three of four point-scoring relays, City College upset Adelphi, the defending champion, and won the Collegiate Track Conference's second annual winter relay carnival at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

A FINE performance of movements of the Hamilton suite taken from the twenty original pieces that Handel composed as the famous "Water Music" was given by the Boston Symphony, Charles Munch conductor, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

Alternate-side parking will be extended tomorrow to the Kings-bridge-Bedford Park section of the Bronx.

With many stores looking ahead to a record spring season, interest has been high at resident buying office clinics. Stocks are generally low and merchants are placing orders that are considerably heavier than those of a year ago.
HARTFORD, Jan. 15 -- Decisions on major appointments will be made in the next few days by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff and his chief political adviser, the Democratic State Chairman, John M. Bailey.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 -- Plans for two twenty-knot passenger liners to be built by the Oceanic Steamship Company for service between this coast and the South Pacific have been filed with the Federal Maritime Board in Washington.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 15 -- The commanding officer of the United States aircraft carrier Midway, Capt. Reynold D. Hogle, and the United States Consul General in Capetown. John Stone, conferred after the ship docked here today.

PANAMA, Jan. 15 -- Ricardo Arias Espinosa, 42 years old, was sworn in as Panama's President today shortly after the National Assembly, meeting in a dramatic pre-dawn session, impeached and dismissed President Jose Ramon Guizado.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 15 -- The rebels' radio in Costa Rica said today partisans of Gen. Rafael Calderon Guardia, former Costa Rica President, were pushing east from the Pacific coast to join troops led by Capt. Teodoro Picado Jr., the rebels' field commander.

ESSEX, Md., Jan. 15 -- A greater number of inboard races will be planned for 1955 by the American Power Boat Association Inboard Race Commission. I feel the coming season will be the best yet for inboard racing, exceeding the membership and regatta figures of 1954.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 15 (UP) -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton and Al Harum of Coral Gables, Fla., today battled their way into the final of the Florida West Coast tennis tourney.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- The Bethel Baptist Church, with a congregation of eighty Negroes -- most of them employed on near-by estates -- will open bids Thursday for a $45,000 edifice on Maple Avenue.

THIS unique combination of sketchbook and notebook by two "dedicated" Pennsylvania German artists, Kiehl Newswanger and his son, Christian, is one of the most original and authentic works to come out of the folk life of the "plain people."
WEST PALM BEACH, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A court order today upset a $400,000 trust fund that would have benefited a grandson of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Business volume in the Chicago area continued on a high plane in December, the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago indicated. The report showed that increased activity in August has continued through the last five months of the year.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A. E. Matthews, 85 years of age, the grand old man of the English theatre, has missed his first performances in seventy years. He was unable to go on Thursday night or last night.
The first year of the International Sugar Agreement was more successful than most of its critics had expected and came close to filling the hopes of its backers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- An Agriculture Department official tonight scoffed at reports that there was mystery involved in the status of eleven agricultural attaches whose future was undecided.

ASIAN scientists warn that time may be running out in man's battle there against one of his most deadly enemies -- malaria. The hope has been that DDT would eradicate the mosquitoes that carry malaria.

THE new version of the Rheingold Theatre makes the point that its stars are choosing their own vehicles and doing the stories they personally like best. Apparently the folk who make beer haven't been in show business too long.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The Communist party exerts an influence in France vastly out of proportion to its membership. While party prestige and membership both have dropped considerably since 1946, the decrease in membership has been greater than the decrease in influence.

The Spice Islands are again the scene of strife after a long period of calm. Here is armed resistance to the new Republic of Indonesia. In the distant past, when the Spice Islands got their name, the strife was international.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- The sesquicentennial exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts regarded as the oldest art institute in the United States, was previewed tonight by members, guests and the press.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 15 -- Scoring 11 points in the second overtime period, Seton Hall turned back St. Peter's College, 80 -- 77, before 3,033 fans tonight. The losers made eight counters in the second extra session.
The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association elected officers, adopted its sectional rankings and awarded championship tournaments yesterday.

FOR nature lovers winter is one of the best times of year to explore the countryside. It is the time to see the symmetry of leafless trees and the tracery of bare branches against the sky. It is also the time to find the evergreen leaves of trailing arbutus and the red berries of wintergreen and partridgeberry.

Edward M. M. Warburg, president of the United Jewish Appeal and one of its founders sixteen years ago, will be the guest of honor at a testimonial dinner next Saturday night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Certain to be passed by the present session of the Legislature, it replaces the old act under which "boiler room" operators in Montreal managed to high-pressure Canadian and American investors into purchase of poor Canadian stocks.

VILLIVAKKAM, India, Monday, Jan. 17 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Nehru urged his Congress party leaders today to concentrate on building "a welfare state and a Socialist economy" in India.

Louis J. Glickman, real estate investor, has purchased the one-story garage at 200 East Ninety-eighth Street in Brooklyn. The building is on an irregular plot 165 by 163 feet at Kings Highway. It was acquired for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $115,000.
William Lombardy, New York State champion, yesterday defeated Allen Kaufman to attain a score of 8 1/2 -- 1 1/2 and tie Franklin Howard of East Orange, N. J., for the Marshall Chess Club title.

The Fifth Avenue Association urged yesterday that the city dispose at once of the old Board of Education building at 500 Park Avenue. This was in line with its campaign to have the city get rid of property it owns in high-tax areas.

The Polish Falcons of Elizabeth, N. J., yesterday defeated the New York Americans by 3 -- 2 in an American Soccer League game at Zerega Oval in the Bronx. Honors were even at halftime, at which time each side had tallied twice.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 16 -- Much criticism of modern education is "greatly exaggerated,'' Dr. Benjamin F. Wright, president of Smith College, declared today in his annual report.

The investment company business during 1954 experienced the best year in its history, registering new highs in assets, in sales, in the number of shareholders and in distributions to stockholders, the National Association of Investment Companies announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- More than 3,000 United States parachutists and other Army and Air Force units are engaged in a significant test of men, materiel and tactics in Alaska.

Philip J. Cruise, New York City Housing Authority chairman, proposed yesterday fixing a maximum legal occupancy for apartments in all buildings in the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- State Department officials disclosed last week that a ship bearing planes and other arms for Nicaragua had entered the Panama Canal. They gave no indication that the United States would consider stopping the shipment.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 -- (UP) -- Wes Santee, American mile champion, and Jim Terril and Bob McMillen raced to triple dead heat today in an exhibition 880-yard run. Their scheduled mile performance was called off because of a rain-soaked track in Memorial Coliseum.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Grain markets had an irregular trend last week with no outstanding news to sway prices either way. There was selling of wheat early in the week after light to fairly heavy rains in the Southwest drought areas.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- An obscure dealer in automobile accessories who was put on a trade association blacklist because he sold tires below list price has become the central figure in a drive to obtain a Government ban on monopolistic practices.

Cotton prices gave ground last week in moderate trading. Active future contracts traded on the New York Cotton Exchange closed Friday 95 cents to $1.60 a bale below the levels of a week earlier. It was the third successive week of net declines.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would buy back from its dealers new and unused passenger cars in "excess supply."

TAIPEI Formosa, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A Chinese Communist warship was reported damaged by shore guns off the Tachens today and there was another air raid alert in that island group 200 miles north of Formosa.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 16 -- Favorable Congressional action is expected for a project to replace the Belt Line Railroad bridge between Norfolk and Portsmouth. The project is expected to cost approximately $2,400,000.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- Einar Sissener of Boston, an exchange student from Norway, captured the New York State ski jumping championship and the Harold E. Doerr Memorial trophy before 16,500 today.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins knocked the Montreal Canadiens out of first place in the National Hockey League for the first time this season with a 6-0 triumph before a crowd of 12,863 tonight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- Filming will be resumed tomorrow on "Blood Alley," with John Wayne, co-producer of the picture, taking over the starring role vacated last week by Robert Mitchum.
KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Austria's ski aces dominated the international two-day Hahnenkamm races which ended today while three Americans fared poorly.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Led by the San Francisco passing combination of Quarterback Y. A. Tittle and End Billy Wilson, the West rallied in the final quarter today to defeat the East, 26-19, in the fifth annual Pro Bowl game at Memorial Coliseum.
For their showing of spring and resort fashions this week, Delman made satin - textured shoes from pigskin and, turning from beast to bird, covered pumps and sandals with feathers.
President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua said last night that he had put in an urgent request to the United States for four planes to match the same number shipped yesterday to Costa Rica.
The Hebrew University in Jerusalem, holding its first convocation away from Israel, conferred the degree of Honorary Fellow yesterday upon nine prominent Americans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The Senate Democratic leadership is trying to find whether Congress seeks an independent, bipartisan commission on the Administration's personnel security program.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- The State Employment Service is stepping up its efforts to find suitable jobs for disabled persons who have been rehabilitated for work.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Two United States airmen on duty in Germany won the European junior bobsled championship today. They defeated the Swiss team by one-fifth of a second in a snowstorm.

NOTHING in months has excited the television industry as much as the Kraft Television Theatre's production of "Patterns," an original play by Rod Serling. The enthusiasm is justified. In writing, acting and direction, "Patterns" will stand as one of the high points in the TV medium's evolution.
The letter of James A. Patterson on "Greek Claims to Cyprus" contained many inaccuracies which should not be allowed to pass unanswered.

IT'S time to complete the ballot from the Baseball Writers Association for candidates to the Hall of Fame. The name of Joe Di-Maggio was entered first, not that the top position carries any more weight than the tenth or last place. The deciding factor is the appearance on 75 per cent of the lists filed.

Since 1876 the Legal Aid Society has been protecting the rights of those unable to pay for legal services. In 1954 some 60,000 needy clients were helped by the society's staff of forty-six lawyers and thirty-six clerical workers, in addition to many volunteers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Republicans and Democrats chase each other in and out of control of Congress with all the gusto and persistence of a bunch of Keystone Cops.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The standard of living in the United States has doubled in the last fifty years, despite the dwindling purchasing power of the dollar, a University of Chicago sociologist reported today.

TORONTO, Jan. 16 -- Robert H. Saunders, chairman of the Hydroelectric Power Commission of Ontario, died early today in London, Ont., as a result of injuries received Saturday in the crash of a company plane that had carried him hundreds of thousands of miles.

This is another one of those "Weeks" that we are constantly being called upon to notice in one or more special ways. The current choices are five in number and include such diverse topics as the Civil Service, the virtue of being thrifty, the Junior Chamber of Commerce, and the delights of drinking your tea hot.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Governor Harriman will ask the Legislature tomorrow to broaden the jurisdiction of state minimum wage boards.
PANAMA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Antonio Cerda of Argentina today won the Panama open golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 273.

There is irony in Moscow's latest move to block ratification of the Paris and London agreements for Western unity and the rearmament of Germany. For months the Kremlin propagandists have pictured the Adenauer regime as a group of blood- thirsty "revanchists," panting uncontrollably to revive the Wehrmacht and resume where Hitler left off in his efforts to enslave Europe.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 16 -- Rebel airplanes continue in control of the air in the Costa Rican combat zones to the north of this capital, the investigating commission for the Organization of American States said here late this afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The pace in the stock markets continued to quicken last week as business expanded to its highest level since 1947, when the era of very cheap money was fully established.
A $600,000,000 program to meet the arterial highway demands of the metropolitan area for the next two decades was put forward yesterday.

Efforts to legalize bingo for the benefit of religious and charitable organizations were decried yesterday by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Diocese of New York.
Six new films, including importations from England and Russia, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
An economist and a resident buying executive agree that the outlook for retailing is good.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Jan. 16 -- The response to last week's offer of 3 1/4 per cent Government bonds was very good. Private subscriptions came to 410,000,000 guilders; and Government institutions took 190,000,000. [The guilder is traded in New York at about 3.8 to the dollar.]
SEA ISLAND, Ga., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Jackie Pung of Honolulu I registered a four-stroke victory in the Sea Island women's open golf tournament today, scoring a 73 for a 151 total.
ROME, Jan. 16 -- The indications now are that Parliament will not have completed ratification of the Western European Union pact by Feb. 15, as the Government had hoped.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator John L. McClellan said tonight he expected to call top Army officials to testify again on the Peress case.

The 1955 Studebaker automobile line has been re-engineered to place the models in a more favorable competitive position, it ,vas announced yesterday by the Studebaker division of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation. The new models will go on display here Jan. 27, with no change in the New York City deUverecf prices.
The country could have produced twice as many automobiles at it turned out last year, Walter P. Reuther asserted yesterday.

The three-story factory building at 43 to 53 Keap Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Goodman George, Inc., to Keap Street Properties, Inc., which insured title with the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
HONOLULU, Jan. 12 -- Hawaii's 23,000 members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union are considering a break with their parent West Coast union.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 16 -- The West German press office issued a statement today rejecting the Soviet Government's offer to establish diplomatic relations, to hold internationally supervised "free elections" in all Germany and to reunify the country on the basis of armed neutralization.
United States diplomatic recognition of Communist China as a realistic action was favored yesterday by three of six college students in the New York Times Youth Forum.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- The momentum of housing construction in the last two months of 1954 is being carried over into the first quarter of this year, the nation's builders were told here today.

CAIRO, Jan. 16 -- The Egyptian Government said tonight the agreement of Iraq to sign a defense pact with Turkey posed a threat to the existence of the Arab League. It called upon the Premiers of all Arab states to meet here next Saturday in an effort to avert the crisis.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Nguyen Van Hue and four battalions under his command have broken with the Hoa Hao religious sect and offered themselves unconditionally for service in the Vietnamese national army.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- The best sales year in the history of the small appliance and housewares industry was forecast today by W. H. Sahloff, vice president and general manager of General Electric's small appliance division. He spoke at the Housewares Show at the Navy Pier here.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- An individual bank stockholder has brought suit in Supreme Court in Westchester and New York Counties to halt what he describes as a "scandalous and outrageous financial manipulation."

BONN, Germany, Jan. 16 -- A number of proposals to create a flexible international arms pool will be submitted by Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister of Economy, at the conference of the Western European Union tomorrow in Paris.
Cargo shippers who think that business will be good and shipowners who are not so certain got together last week. They arranged transactions that made a record total for recent years.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 16 -- Thousands of Greek Cypriotes defied Government orders today when they milled about a church here displaying the Greek colors and chanting slogans hostile to British rule.

TRENTON, Jan. 16 -- The New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce warned today that, unless new taxes were adopted, the state would be confronted with a deficit of $14,400,000 or more by the end of the 1957-58 fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A couple of changes are brewing in President Eisenhower's White house family.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16 -- The strong upward movement in steel activity that began in the fourth quarter of 1954 continued last week, with additional evidence that the recovery phase has by no means run its course.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The National Coal Association said today Government policies threatening to do "irreparable damage" to the coal industry must be corrected.
Solutions to the problem of "anti-intellectualism in America" were sought yesterday by six scholars in the social sciences.
Seven persons on a Jamaica B. M. T. subway train were thrown to the floor and injured last night when a passenger pulled the emergency cord after the train doors had failed to open.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia, said today he was gathering information for a possible inquiry into what he called "monopoly practices in radio and television."
Advocates of a restudy of the nation's loyalty-security program intend to press for the appointment of a special Federal survey commission.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Albert Schweitzer invited only two outsiders to his eightieth birthday celebrations in the heart of French Equatorial Africa two days ago. The two were Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India, and Robert Gardner McGregor Jr., United States Consul General in Leopoldville.
The Bendix Aviation Corporation had a record net income of $25,537,771, equal to $11.23 a share, in the fiscal year through September, its twenty-fifth year.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 11 -- Organized moneylenders, the bane of Pakistan's poverty-stricken millions, are driving victims to suicide.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- A top aide of President Eisenhower said today that the President would run for re-election in 1956 "if he feels the American people want him" to do so.

Gimbels New York has appointed Charles H. Werber Jr. as general manager for branch store development and operations and William B. Gorman as general manager, Joseph L. Eckhouse, executive head of the store, announced over the week-end.

A combined net asset value of $139,113.279 at the end of 1954 was shown yesterday in the annual statements of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation and its affiliate, the United States and International Securities Corporation.

Bold selling techniques that are the basis of merchandising success in the United States are admired in Great Britain and other parts of Europe but business men there are reluctant to try them, according to two teams of American business executives.
Michael J. Quill disclosed yesterday that he had begun a "$38,000,000 treasure hunt" through the books of the Transit Authority.
PHILADELPHIA. Jan. 16 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Repubilican of South Dakota, said today the greatest peril facing Americans was "a growing and a great dangerous 'ism.'"

Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas announced on Jan. 6 that, as incoming chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee he "probably" would institute an inquiry into the spectacular rise in the stock market. At the end of last week Mr. Fulbright revealed that he had already put his words into action.

The Communist party and the Government of the Soviet Union appear to have returned to the Stalinist policy of building up heavy, industry with maximum rapidity to enhance the Soviet military-economic potential.
Last Christmas John G. Howard, headmaster at the Northwood School in Lake Placid, was talking about the school's basketball team.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations is reported to feel that it would be useful if United States treaty commitments to Nationalist China were clarified.

Storing paprika in the refrigerator is a trick housewives might borrow from the spice trade. Coolness preserves color and flavor in this lively seasoning, which, used by many cooks, is as essential as salt to those of Hungarian background.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The Popular Republican party today renewed its opposition to the Cabinet of Premier Pierre Mendes-France and to the ratification of the Paris agreements for the formation of a western European union.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- The No. 1 rink from The Country Club of Brookline, Mass., skipped by W. Donald Swan, won the Archibald Douglas Medal as the three-day bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club was completed today.

The rule that American personnel of the armed services shall conform to the laws of the country in which they happen to be stationed or which they visit may be sound enough in principle. But there are exceptions. The visit of the United States carrier Midway to Cape Town is one of them.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- A revision of state income tax exemption is under study as a possible means of obtaining additional revenue without increasing tax rates.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- A crowd of about 24,000 is expected at Hialeah Park tomorrow for the opening of Florida's biggest racing show.
Jutting out into the East River from the Bronx is a diminutive peninsula, the name of which has become a sore point of spelling among New York authorities.

The all - Beethoven program that Guido Cantelli presented with the Philharmonic-Symphony in Carnegie Hall Saturday night featured Robert Casadesus as piano soloist in the "Emperor" Concerto. Also on the program were the "Pastoral" Symphony, which had been conducted the previous Thursday evening, and the "Egmont" Overture.
Bankers acceptances outstand-t ing in the United States increased seasonally during December to the highest total since April, 1932, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 16 (UP) -- A pair of 30-foot putts, dropped when the pressure was toughest, gave Dr. Cary Middlecoff the $2,500 first prize in the pro-division of the annual $15,000 Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tournament today.
The awesome touch-me-not newness of Christmas dolls should be wearing off by now and little girls will be ready to concentrate on some serious playing.

The twelfth and midpoint week of the Metropolitan Opera's season will begin Monday evening, Jan. 24, with a performance of "Madama Butterfly." The week will see several Metropolitan "firsts" and two debuts, one of them the appearance of the second Negro artist to be engaged by the company.

LENINGRAD, Jan. 15 -- Seen from Moscow, Soviet Russia is a young country hurrying toward the Communist future. In the capital one sometimes gets the impression that history really began only with the Bolshevik Revolution thirty-seven years ago.
The National Broadcasting Company is trying to arrange a color telecast of "Peter Pan," currently on Broadway with Mary Martin in the title role, for Monday, March 7, from 8 to 9:30 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- An Administration with a strong resistance to economic controls nevertheless is preparing against the day when it may have to impose them.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Would you like to know how a major league baseball team spends its money? Have a look at some of the 1954 expenditures of the Phillies.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The British plan to fire a series of explosive charges from one side of Antarctica to the other in an attempt to plumb the depths of the polar icecap.
The Philadelphia Woodwind Quintet, a doughty group of Philadelphia Orchestra members, made its Town Hall debut late yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Concert Society.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The American Government is now taking over from France responsibility for maintaining independence in rump Indochina. Two acts of the Ngo Dinh Diem Administration in South Vietnam are directly traceable to United States influence.
A cock's crow yesterday afternoon was the signal for raiding policemen to move in on a Harlem basement and seize twenty-seven men at a gamecock fight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The twelve-day-old Eighty-fourth Congress has yet to get up its full head of steam.
Gale winds and angry Atlantic seas claimed one fishing boat and caused two more ships to send out calls for assistance, the Coast Guard reported yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Ministers and ambassadors of seven Western European countries will meet here tomorrow to discuss the French proposal for gradual pooling of their production of armament.
Dr. Harold C. Urey, Nobel Prize winner, said yesterday he believed government leaders should know more about scientists and their problems.

The reported choice of former Senator John Sherman Cooper of Kentucky as our next Ambassador to India is a fortunate one. He has the qualifications to do a splendid job in a difficult post at a difficult time. He does not have experience in the Far East, but he does have extensive experience in the United Nations.

Boys and girls 13 to 18 years old have a wider range of interests than readers in any other age group, Miss Margaret C. Scoggin, supervisor of young people's services for the New York Public Library, reports.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- In the next two weeks the Government will conduct an offensive to obtain the passage of the 1955 budget by the end of the month. The aim will be to restrict supplementary expenses that might upset the financial balance.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 17 -- Four F-51 Mustang fighter planes bought from the United States arrived today to help defend Costa Rica from rebels.
Jim (Junior) Gilliam, the Dodgers' switch-hitting second baseman, signed his 1955 contract yesterday. He was the twenty-first Brooklyn player to agree to terms.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- United Nations officials and members of the United States delegation declined to comment on Senator Knowland's speech.
NOW is the time to check on the condition of fly rods, waders and the supply of flies and leathers, for the trout season will open in New York in exactly eighty-two days.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- No man in Washington, perhaps, is unhappier over the Administration's failure to come up with a balanced budget this year than is Rowland R. Hughes.
Loew's, Inc., in its fiscal year ended last August, increased the consolidated net profit to $6,577,311 from $4,380,603 the year before, according to the annual statement to be released today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Costa Rican Embassy said tonight captured insurgents had reported that their leader, Teodoro Picado Jr., had been killed in action. However, the Embassy cautioned that there was no absolute confirmation.

After many false starts, the men's clothing industry has finally opened a promotional campaign. During the last two weeks a small group of manufacturers have quietly begun to collect funds for an industry-wide drive, it was learned yesterday at the International Association of Clothing Designers' ninetieth semi-annual convention at the Statler Hotel.

In this ripe old age of the earth, as men begin to peer outward into space and plan voyages among the planets, the older sort of exploration is coming to its close. Except for some peaks of the Himalayas, the last of the unknown, or barely known, areas of the globe is the Antarctic Continent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that 8 per cent more beef cattle were on feed for the quality slaughter market on Jan. 1 than a year earlier. The number was reported at 5,816,000 head, compared with 5,394,000 a year earlier and with 4,893,000 for the five-year (1949-53) Jan. 1 average.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman refused yesterday to set aside the conviction and death sentences of three men who killed a Reader's Digest messenger.

THOMAS SCHERMAN and the Little Orchestra Society, with whom adventurous program-making is customary, last night offered in Town Hall a nearly complete performance of Beethoven's ballet score, "The Creatures of Prometheus," Op. 43.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Argentina announced today that she had established a scientific base on the shores of the Weddell Sea, 800 miles from the South Pole.

FIFTEEN paintings by Picasso, from 1920 to 1944, make up the current exhibition at the Paul Rosenberg Gallery, 20 East Seventy-ninth Street. All are on loan from private collections except one, and that is from the Norton Gallery and School of Art in Florida.

A prediction that advertisers would spend $1,300,000,000 in television in 1955 was made last evening by Robert W. Sarnoff, executive vice president of the National Broadcasting Company. The figure would be almost double the amount spent in the electronic medium in 1953.
ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- A labor official charged today that "big business forces" were trying to undermine the state's unemployment insurance program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- An indictment charging Ray Brennan, a Chicago newspaper reporter, with impersonating a Federal employe was dismissed today at the request of the Government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for $3,530,000,000 in new money for foreign military, economic and technical aid in the fiscal year 1956.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 17 (AP) -Appellate Court judges granted Dr. Samuel Sheppard a further stay of his life sentence today, but held under advisement his plea for freedom on bail.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Donald M. Bernard, president of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association, said today that "newspapers were never more vital, never more necessary, nor newspaper advertising more important to the economy of the nation."
MOSCOW, Jan. 16 -- A marked change has taken place in the election campaign tactics of the Soviet Communist party since 1951.
More trouble on this port's docks loomed yesterday as longshoremen and their employers joined in sharp criticism of the Waterfront Commission's first attempt to provide more steady pier work.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Eisenhower's budget called today for $103,000,000 in Federal funds for new ships, but not a dollar to aid state training of the men to man them.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 17 -- Die Burger, which usually expresses the views of the Strijdom Government, said today the visit of the United States carrier Midway to Capetown, "which was to serve to improve relations between the United States and South Africa, has been misused by a couple of American politicians to create feeling against our country."
The suspension of a Queens College faculty member for refusing to answer questions concerning alleged Communist party membership before 1953 was announced last night by the Board of Higher Education.

The Western European Union began yesterday to function as an entity, even before final ratification of the pacts creating it, when its interim committee met in Paris to consider the project of a European armament pool. This project, under which a Union authority with supranational powers could control the production, standardization and distribution of all arms for the Union armies, is pressed by Premier Mendes-France for political, military and economic reasons.
PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The West European conference on the pooling of arms production began today in an atmosphere filled with doubts of the scope of its achievements.

And now we have a grant of $2,000,000 toward restoring the ancient Greek Agora. With all the misery existing throughout the living world one wonders if we should not, at least for the present, concern ourselves with our present problems and let the past remain as it is till we knock poverty and the resulting misery out of human existence.
The new traffic school for problem drivers will get under way tomorrow night. The class of twenty male pupils includes two taxicab and two truck drivers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Increased funds for the law enforcement arms of the Government were asked by President Eisenhower today in his Budget Message.

The two-story business building at 3712 Bergenline Avenue in iUnion City, N. J., has been sold by Samuel Stein to the Blivet CorI poration, an investment group headed by Ted and Jess Ganor of Perth Amboy. The sale was negoJ tiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.
Moving a single desk a mile and a half in Manhattan can cost as much as $37; the same desk can be shipped from New York to Boston for $7.50.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -The Defense Department formally asked Congress today to vote a $729,700,000-a-year military pay rise. The aim is to make service careers more attractive.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Yugoslav spokesman said today President Tito, ending an eleven-day state visit to Burma, had offered to equip a Burmese army brigade. Burma, in return, will send rice to Yugoslavia.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Warner Brothers is understood to have the inside track for film rights to Mac Hyman's current best-seller novel, "No Time for Sergeants."
EDISON, N. J., Jan. 17 -- The four-day walkout at the Lincoln- Mercury plant ended today as 1,685 members of Local 980, United automobile Workers, C. I. O., went back to work.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, and Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, urged the Congress today to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for three years.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., Jan. 17 (UP) -- Six Army privates were convicted today of mutiny and sentenced to seven years at hard labor, dishonorable discharge and forfeiture of all pay and allowances. Five are 18-year-olds, the sixth is 21.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan 17 (AP) -- The Government opened its antitrust case against The Kansas City Star Company today.

Floyd Patterson, Brooklyn light heavyweight, stopped Don Grant of Los Angeles in the main bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night. The fight, scheduled for ten rounds, was halted at 1:13 of the fifth to spare Grant further punishment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Administration is counting on record high personal income for the American people in the months just ahead.
Three thousand visitors attended the opening yesterday of a show at the Chrysler International Auto Salon, 405 Lexington Avenue. The exhibition will continue through Jan. 28.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Eisenhower laid before Congress today a budget geared to the maintenance indefinitely of what he called "an insecure peace."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A big world farm production last year has created surpluses that are leading some countries to try controlling production and changing patterns of agricultural output, the Department of Agriculture said today.
New York practical nurses again this year will seek legislation to win full voting representation on the State Board of Nurse Examiners.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 17 -- The damaged freighter Steelore was moving today toward port at Morehead City, N. C., in tow of a tug.

Reduced taxes and realization of security profits in contrast to losses in 1953 were major factors in increasing earnings of Chase National Bank last year. According to the annual report net operating earnings were $31,144,000, or $4.21 a share, compared with $3.67 a share in 1953.

In an $8,000,000 transaction, Richard S. Robie, Boston financier, became last night the head of a new corporation that will operate the second largest automotive rental business in the world, the Avis System.
The fifth version of the National Basketball Association's All-Star basketball game will be played at Madison Square Garden tonight. As usual, each section will be represented by ten players.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 17 -- Placards appeared on walls throughout West Germany today with the slogan, "Never Again," "Act Now." The posters were part of the campaign of the Social Democratic party and the big labor unions against the Paris agreements on West German armament and sovereignty.

Ken Smith, New York Mirror baseball writer, was the honored guest at the James P. Dawson Memorial dinner held by the New York Chapter, Baseball Writers' Association of America, at Toots Shor's Restaurant last night.
North Atlantic passenger travel continued its upward trend last year.

The Museum of Modern Art has just acquired its first sculpture by the French artist, Auguste Rodin, an over-life-size figure in bronze entitled "St. John the Baptist Preaching." The new acquisition, bought through the museum's Mrs. Simon Guggenheim Fund, is on exhibit on the first floor of the museum, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -A $3,000,000 grants-in-aid item for starting the states on a campaign against juvenile delinquency was asked today by President Eisenhower in the health, education and welfare section of his budget message.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Grain futures were weak on the Board of Trade throughout the session today, with pressure particularly heavy in wheat and oats. Rye was strong, however.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Jan. 17 -- Malaya's Communist rebels will not be offered an amnesty at present. This decision was made today at a meeting of the committee deciding strategy and tactics in the war against the Communists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -President Eisenhower today ordered a review of the "entire structure" of the nation's veterans' pension and compensation laws.

Alfred H. Caspary, stockbroker, who died Jan. 7 at the age of 77, left between $10,000,000 and $15,000,000 to his friend and executor, George Murnane of Syosset, L. I., for distribution in his discretion.

Travelers lost, stranded or just confused, will be aided by the proceeds from the world premiere of the film, "Cinerama Holiday," on Feb. 8 at the Warner Theatre. Fifty years of service to the traveler by the Travelers Aid Society of New York will be celebrated at the showing of the Stanley Warner Cinerama Corporation film.

The vigorous position taken by Secretary Dulles as first witness has got the hearings on the three-year reciprocal trade bill off to a good start. It seems that the Administration is determined to fight for this measure in a way that it was fought for only by the Democrats last year.

Staten Island was wondering yesterday how to bridge the gap between its semi-rural isolation and the prospect of modern highway transport. The announcement over the week-end that Staten Island was to have its first direct link with Brooklyn by a proposed Narrows Bridge was viewed as a mixed bane and boon.
PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The Ministry of Finance has started a counter-offensive against rebellious shopkeepers who have been campaigning against taxes.

Rugs thick as summer grass or thin and hard as an enameled painting are to be found in the new V'Soske collection of hand-hooked and crafted floor-coverings. They are available through decorators at the Lord Adams showroom at 4 East Fifty-third Street.
OTTAWA, Jan. 17 -- A temporary solution of the problem of double taxation in the Province of Quebec was offered today by Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Sandy Saddler, the featherweight champion, knocked out Lulu Perez in the fourth-round of a scheduled ten-round benefit fight tonight. It was virtually an effortless tune-up for Sandy's title match next month against Teddy (Red Top) Davis.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Tuesday, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Communists rained more than 200 bombs today on the Chinese Nationalist Tachen Islands and near-by Yikiangshan, 200 miles north of Formosa, the Defense Ministry said.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, Ambassador to Italy, declared tonight that Allied nations denied markets in the United States "will have to look elsewhere -- and they will look behind the Iron Curtain."
Two waves of selling hit the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, at the end of the second hour and at the close.
TRENTON, Jan. 17 -- A Republican caucus to determine policy in dealing with Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, will be convened in Princeton on Friday morning.
Fund-raising efforts to hasten the materialization of the projected Girls Town, Inc., will be furthered by a card party on Saturday in the Georgian Room of the Statler.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Republican bills to continue the 10 per cent forgiveness in state income taxes and the 25 per cent abatement in unincorporated business taxes were submitted to the Legislature tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Creation of a powerful new subcommittee to handle all funds for Government power projects was announced today by the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

It is along about now that each member of the reading public decides that what he most needs is a bookplate. The reason is simple, although not altogether a credit to the human race. Each member of this desirable public received a number of books for Christmas, received them with great welcome.
Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, said yesterday he could see no reason for the Government to develop all the power for all the people.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Australia will challenge in the American Zone of the 1955 Davis Cup tournament.

PANAMA, Jan. 17 -- The National Assembly appointed a five- man commission today to consider charges that former President Jose Ramon Guizado was implicated in the murder of his predecessor, Col. Jose Antonio Remon.

The five-story dwelling at 331 Riverside Drive and the adjoining vacant plot, 25 by 100 feet, at' 332 Riverside Drive, are under contract of sale by Fred H. Hill, as president of the Hansair Realty Corporation, to the American Buddhist Academy.

Department store executives in New York City started last week unworried about bettering the sales totals of the same week a year ago. The pattern of purchasing has been stronger than in early 1954. Last year, the week was very snowy and cold, a situation not conducive at all to shopping.

The desirability of keeping the headquarters of five leading engineering societies in New York was upheld yesterday by speakers at a luncheon in the Plaza Hotel. Four other cities -- Pittsburgh, Chicago, Philadelphia and Washington -- have made bids to attract the groups away from here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- The Fourth Marine Regiment will be shifted from Japan to the Marine Corps Air Station at Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii, the Defense Department announced today.
Some proposed legislation that was believed to have vanished somewhere between Albany and City Hall hasn't. It was just "in transit."

A block of 450,000 shares of Duquesne Light Company stock priced at $15,662,500 will be placed on the market today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., Stone Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Justice Philip Halpern of Buffalo recommended today that the Subcommission on Prevention of Discrimination undertake a world study of restrictions of religious rights.

GROTON, Conn., Jan. 17 -- Atomic-powered transportation became a reality today. At 11:01 A. M., without benefit of champagne or speeches, a nuclear engine pushed the 300-foot submarine Nautilus back from her dock here and out into the Thames River.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -Budget cuts and the use of more Federal money for research and education spelled out today the Administration's faith in its farm program and its partnership policy in the development of natural resources.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Mark Van Doren tonight appraised Walt Whitman as a great poet but so unsure of himself that he "tinkered with his text."
Mr. and Mrs. Myron C. Taylor have donated $1,000,000 to the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York to build and maintain a diocesan center on six acres of the Taylor estate at Locust Valley, L. I.
United States foreign policy is trying "to make it clear that aggression can be and will be severely punished," a high defense official said last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Politically speaking, President Eisenhower is a year behind schedule and still has not met in full the budget objectives of his 1952 Morningside Heights agreement with the late Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Hialeah Park opened its gates today for forty days of racing and a crowd of 24,451 saw Blessbull win the $21,700 Inaugural Handicap in track record time.
A Bronx detective, father of a 6-year-old boy, devoted his two days off to finding a stray dog that had bitten his son's playmate Sunday.
Two former airmen, one a German who might "have been shot if Hitler wasn't so busy," the other an American whose life the German saved, toasted each other and their friendship yesterday in New York.

Continued stability in the price of silver this year is expected by Handy Harman, refiners and fabricators of precious metals. In its annual review, the firm explained that its prediction was "subject to legislative developments in Washington and to any change of policy on the part of Mexico."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Some relief for the hard-pressed national parks was contained in the President's budget today.
NEWARK, Jan. 17 -- Two precinct plainclothesmen were ordered to night patrol duty with the uniformed force today as an investigation of possible laxity in the Newark Police Department got under way.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Following is an abbreviated glossary of some of the technical terms used in President Eisenhower's Budget Message:

The Feb. 14 performance of Christopher Fry's play, "The Dark Is Light Enough," starring Katharine Cornell and Tyrone Power, will aid the Prescott Neighborhood House, 247 East Fifty-third Street, which has taken a block of seats.
" Festival," a comedy by Sam and Bella Spewack, spoofing the world of music, opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Longacre Theatre.

The National Biscuit Company, which attained a new sales record in 1954, plans to spend about $20,000,000 on capital improvements this year, George H. Coppers, president, said in the preliminary annual report yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 17 (AP) -- An evaluating team in its study of the University of Maryland said the school "has violated the rules of the Atlantic Coast Conference and the National Collegiate Athletic Association with respect to recruitment of athletes."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A national defense budget of approximately $34,000,000,000 was proposed today by President Eisenhower for the fiscal year 1956. The Air Force would receive almost half this sum.
The Carborundum Company, producer of coated abrasives, has acquired the Curtis Machine Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Lincoln Park Industries, Inc.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Sir Anthony Eden asked Communist China to move cautiously in the danger areas of the Far East in a talk broadcast tonight to the British people.
The President's military budget for the year starting next July 1 poses major and dangerous service problems for the future.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Jan. 16 -- With fifty helicopter flights, the U. S. S. Atka was able to move a working party ashore at little America yesterday. By the time the party came back aboard it had hauled out more than a ton of equipment.

A new volume of Jim Corbett's experiences among the people and jungle creatures of India will be issued Jan. 27 by Oxford University Press. It is titled "The Temple Tiger and More Man Eaters of Kumaon." Mr. Corbett, who now lives in Pax Two in Nyeri, Kenya, East Africa, is the author of "Jungle Lore," "My India," "The Man-Eating Leopard of Rudraprayag" and "Man-Eaters of Kumaon."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations attacked in Supreme Court today the Federal loyalty and security programs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Eisenhower is preparing to ask Congress for authority to impose a ninety-day price and wage freeze in event of a national emergency.
Settling down for a full week's dry-land cruise and trimming ship to stay on even keel, the National Motor Boat Show fairly got down to business yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Geneva was selected today as the site of the world's first international conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy.
Richard Gump, San Francisco merchant and designer, said here yesterday that good taste was not necessarily synonymous with good design.
Lobster splits, lengthwise halves of frozen rock lobster tails, are an innovation from New Zealand now available in Gristede stores here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. I7 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today dismissed its ten-year-old charges that the Automatic Canteen Company of America induces and obtains illegal price advantages over its competitors in buying candy and confectionery items.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Westchester County received from engineers today a $60,740,000 plan for modernizing the parkway routes in the corridor between New York City and New England.
Kentucky maintained a long lead in the sixth weekly Associated Press poll of the nation's top college basketball teams yesterday.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Cash bonuses were offered as added incentives today for Canadian and United States professional golf players in the fourth annual John Jay Hopkins Trophy team matches tomorrow and Wednesday.
The cost of borrowing through the commercial paper market was increased yesterday by dealers and at least one major finance company.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 17 -- The Organization of American States commission investigating the fighting in Costa Rica arrived in Managua this morning after having postponed its trip twice.
NIMBORAN VALLEY, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 8 -- In New Guinea even the simplest task is complex.

THE best basketball game this observer ever saw was the All-Star show last year between the East and the West at Madison Square Garden. Admittedly that's a rather large and extravagant statement. Yet the same thing was said by each of the 16,477 other eyewitnesses who have been encountered.

An official visit by Prime Minister Nehru to the former French colony of Pondicherry on the east coast of the Indian subcontinent writes the end to the long history of French colonial holdings in this area. The agreements reached -- whereby this colony goes under Indian rule -- must still be ratified legislatively and until they are Pondicherry is still nominally under French sovereignty, but the change has been made.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 17 -- The sale of ready-packaged, dressed cuts of meat on Sundays does not violate a city ordinance, Magistrate Michael F. Reilly ruled today.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- United States, British and Turkish officers will start talks here Wednesday on the defense of Turkey and neighboring areas.
The Philharmonia Orchestra of London will make its first tour of the United States in October, under the direction of Herbert von Karajan.
ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The Senate confirmed unanimously tonight the first four Democratic members of Governor Harriman's cabinet to receive the lawmakers stamp of approval. There was no debate.

HONG KONG, Jan. 17 -- A "labor emulation" drive in which workers "pledge" to forgo their lunar New Year holiday and surpass their production targets is now being coupled with the "Liberate Formosa" campaign in Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -According to one way of looking at it, the budget that President Eisenhower sent to Congress today was balanced. In fact, it showed a surplus.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- Communist China and four other Governments allied with the Soviet Union are to receive atomic materials and equipment from Moscow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A new and heated controversy developed tonight over Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's five-year-old list of ninety alleged Communists in the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- All Executive budgets are as rosy as the dawn of the ever-receding day when they promise to show a true balance, and President Eisenhower's for fiscal 1956, submitted to Congress today, was no exception. But its under- tones seemed unusually optimistic, for it envisaged that the Government would get all the breaks -- on revenue collections, on the cost of military procurement and on the national economy as a whole.

The President's annual message on the budget, delivered to the Congress yesterday, contains one short and happily phrased statement of philosophy that will remain with many readers after the myriad of other words and the regiment after regiment of accompanying statistics have become a blur.

CORNER BROOK, Nfld., Jan. 17 (AP) -- A United States Navy Super-Constellation ditched in the foggy Gulf of St. Lawrence today and all thirteen persons aboard were feared drowned. Search ships and planes reported no signs of life.

The American League schedule, just released, reveals that only 208 games under the lights have been arranged. This makes the junior circuit considerably more conservative than the National League, which carded 250 floodlight affairs.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Senator William F. Knowland declared today that United Nations efforts to free American service men from Communist Chinese prisons had failed.
BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Jackie Robinson said today that the 1955 season will be his last in baseball if he is bothered by injuries as much as he was last season.
Commercial exports and imports of the United States this year are expected to register moderate increases over levels of 1954, the National Foreign Trade Council reported yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Witnesses were called today in a Supreme Court suit brought by a bank stockholder to prevent transfer of control of the Colonial Trust Company, New York, to a "nonbanking, foreign (Ohio) industrial corporation."

The Lord's Day Alliance of the United States approved yesterday a report opposing commercial dealings on Sunday and condemning attempts to legalize bingo in New York State. The alliance met in annual session at the Marble Collegiate Church. Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 16 -- The political tension that has persisted here for mnoths appeared virtually eliminated today. It was announced that Edmundo Noriega, a member of the Chamber of Deputies, had left for exile in Buenos Aires.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 17 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister M. P. Koirala's 18-year-old son was arrested today for urging the overthrow of his father's regime.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Justice Department asked Congress today to make twenty years in prison and $20,000 fine the maximum penalty for sedition.

CAIRO, Jan. 16 -- The Egyptian Antiquities Department has begun efforts to arrest the deterioration of the site of the ancient solar ship of Cheops. The department has been stung by criticism here and abroad.
BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Timothy G. Sughrue, president of the Boston and Maine Railroad, defended the management today against attacks by a faction seeking to gain control.

Heavy attendance and substantial over-all buying sent the local wholesale winter furniture and carpet markets off to a flying start yesterday. A similar picture prevailed at the New York Lamp Show, which ran into its second day in the New Yorker Hotel.
MADRAS, India, Jan. 17 -- The Indian National Congress, the ruling party, met here today and set the nation's goal as a socialistic pattern of society.
John H. Noble, back from his life as a prisoner in Russia since 1945, found no freedom here yesterday.

Governor Harriman complains, as to his problem in making a state budget for the new fiscal year: "I find that without any notice, without any statement to the people, the expenses will be over $100,000,000 more this year than last year, without any commensurate income, on projects which were approved by the last State Legislature, submitted by my predecessor.
Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, predicted yesterday that the national economy would reach a new peak in 1955.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday it would receive bids next Tuesday on $19,230,000 of notes to continue the temporary financing of two state-aided low-rent projects, Frederick Douglass Houses in Manhattan and Marlboro Houses in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Color and convenience are stressed at a huge exposition of building products being held here in conjunction with the annual convention of the National Association of Home Builders.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday it would receive bids next Tuesday on $19,230,000 of notes to continue the temporary financing of two state-aided low-rent projects, Frederick Douglass Houses in Manhattan and Marlboro Houses in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Color and convenience are stressed at a huge exposition of building products being held here in conjunction with the annual convention of the National Association of Home Builders.
In addition to the introduction of a selection of 200 styles, the highlight of Macy's showing of bridal attire yesterday was the announcement of a custom-made service in wedding gowns.

On behalf of the Inter-American Association for Democracy and Freedom I would like to thank you for your excellent coverage of the Costa Rican-Nicaraguan conflict and particularly for your excellent editorials which so fairly appraised the situation.
ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Governor Harriman appealed today for bipartisan support for a resolution asking Congress to raise the national minimum wage to $1.25 an hour.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Jan. 19 -- The Massachusetts State Prison was in a state of siege early today. Twelve state troopers held machine guns trained on an isolated cell block known as Cherry Hill, where five prison guards were being held as hostages.

A contract for the puchase of the Woodrow Wilson Hotel at 114-16 West Forty-seventh Street has been signed by Jack Brause, real estate operator and investor. The property, on a plot about 37 by 100 feet, contains two stores and sixty rooms in fifty units.

A $2,000,000 annual program to aid higher education was announced yesterday by Harlow H. Curtice, president of General Motors. Cash scholarships and grants will be allotted to 306 colleges and universities throughout the country.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The telephone service throughout many areas of France was interrupted or completely cut today as swollen rivers overflowed their banks and ripped up underground cables.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The stock markets here were less cheerful today, though early losses were largely recovered. Light selling induced partly by yesterday's weakness in Wall Street found prices sensitive on the last day of the bookkeeping account.

THE thirteenth annual exhibition organized by Audubon Artists, Inc., will open with a reception and private showing this evening in the galleries of the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at which medals will be presented and other awards announced.
Robert Trachtenberg, 16-yearold member of the Brooklyn "kill for thrill" gang, was committed yesterday to a youth institution for an indefinite period.

The New York Rangers and the league-leading Detroit Red Wings will meet in a National Hockey League game in Madison Square Garden tonight. It will be the only hockey contest in the Garden until Feb. 6.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The export instruction is aimed at stimulating sales of some highpriced Brazilian goods through more favorable but fixed rates of exchange.

Shearson, Hammill Co. and associates are offering today 180,000 shares of common stock of Food Mart, Inc., at $10.50 a share. Of the total, 50,000 shares are being sold by the company and the remaining 130,000 shares for the account of controlling stockholders.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The one geographical area where Republican foreign policy appears to differ substantially from its Democratic predecessors is West and South Asia. For two years Washington has chosen to emphasize ties with Pakistan at the risk of courting hostility in India.

RUDOLF FIRKUSNY was the soloist with the American Chamber Orchestra last night when it gave the second of three concerts it is offering this season at Town Hall. It was a token of the excellence to which Robert Scholz has brought the ensemble that it was not overshadowed by the Czech-born pianist.

Stocks rallied yesterday to wipe out about a third of Monday's losses. The advance was headed by the aircrafts, favored apparently because of the fighting in the islands along the coast of Communist China.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday but active months inched ahead one to eight points (5 cents to 40 cents a bale).

The New York State Constitution provides in Article I, Section 9, that no kind of gambling (except parimutuel within the race track) "shall hereafter be authorized or allowed within this state." Article XIX provides that amendments to the Constitution must be ratified by the people.

PANAMA, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Former President Arnulfo Arias charged today that he had been arrested illegally and subjected to "inhumane" treatment while held in jail following the murder of his successor, President Remon.
Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, declared last night that the United States did not need "a congress of intellectuals" to devise a code of ethics for the Atomic Age.

The board of trustees of the Museum of the City of New York yesterday elected Peter S. Paine as president. He succeeded John Sloane, chairman of W. J. Sloane, who resigned after seven years in the post.
TRENTON, Jan. 18 -- In an effort to recover the money the late Harold G. Hoffman embezzled, New Jersey has decided to sue the South Amboy Trust Company for about $400,000.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17 -- Administrative restrictions on political activities here will be abolished when the restoration of capitalism becomes economically impossible, Edvard Kardelj, Yugoslavia's First Vice President, declared recently. He also said he did not exclude the possibility of the future emergence of political parties of a Western type.
New York banks will play an expanding role and enjoy corresponding earnings in the near future, N. Baxter Jackson, chairman of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank, said yesterday.

They're Getting Longer Don't look now, but the days are getting longer. Of this there is a mass of proof. In the first place, the official charts say the sun rises a little earlier each time, and lingers on so as to set a little later.

Three separate payroll robberies were committed against women messengers in Manhattan yesterday. Two of the payrolls, totaling $4,164 were retrieved, but the third, involving $1,950, was carried away by thugs.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 18 (UP) -- Heavy rains and a 40-mile-anhour gale washed out the fourth annual Hopkins Trophy golf matches between, the United States and Canada today. The teams were tied at the end of nine holes.

As the National Motor Boat Show reached its midstream mark yesterday, five days down and five to go, it vas an adult procession that sailed to Kingsbridge Armory. They looked, they saw, and a good many were conquered by smooth-talking salesmen.

CIVITAVECCHIA, Italy, Jan 18 (AP) -- The Greek passenger ship Corinthia crashed into a reef in a Mediterranean storm today, but brilliant seamanship by the crew of an Italian vessel rescued all 167 passengers.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- A long-smoldering dispute within the Republican party over development of Niagara Falls water power broke into the open today.
DETROIT, Jan. 18 -- This city's two major expressways were linked today with the opening of part of a new $15,300,000, fourteen-bridge interchange.
A resolution demanding that the state give the city the right to impose the tax on pari-mutuel racing pools at its former full 5 per cent rate was adopted yesterday by the City Council.
The Committee for Economic Development released a study early this week under the title "Control of Federal Expenditures." The basic theme of that study was summed up in these words:
The "up" signal was pressed yesterday on wages for 15,000 elevator operators, handymen and porters in Manhattan's towering office and loft buildings.

Consolidated net profit of the United States Lines Company and its subsidiaries is estimated at $4,545,000 for 1954, John M. Franklin, president, reported yesterday in a preliminary statement. In the preceding year the net was $6,587,789.
