Two new films will open at first-run theatres today. "Young At Heart," a Warner Brothers musical drama in WarnerColor, co-starring Doris Day and Frank Sinatra, is at the Paramount. Henry Blanke produced and Gordon Douglas directed, from a screen play by Julius J. Epstein and Lenore Coffee, from a Liam O'Brien adaptation of a Fannie Hurst story.

A tanker that has been ready for more than six months will finally get to sea tomorrow. With her departure from the Camden, N. J., yard of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a bargain in tankers -- she was offered for sale at a reported 25 per cent below cost -will disappear from the market.
The Federal Reserve System has not adopted a restrictive credit policy to supplant that of "active ease," which lapsed last month, according to authoritative banking opinion here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today the inquiry of the Organization of American States into the Costa Rican crisis was "a test of the effectiveness of the machinery of collective security in the Western Hemisphere."

LAST night it was the turn of the music world to be lampooned on a Broadway stage. In the hands of the Spewacks, Bella and Samuel, veterans in the art of fun-making, the subject offered promising possibilities.
I read with great interest the editorial in your issue of Jan. 15 entitled, "The Wiretapping Question."
The lively interest being shown in the stock market so far this month is evidenced not only in the large volume but also in the number of issues being traded.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 -Although the intentions are high, the achievements are small. The intentions are to give in New Orleans the world premieres of two vivid short plays that Tennessee Williams wrote when he was living in New Orleans a decade ago, supporting himself by working in a restaurant.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Hungary's Communist regime is caught between declining living standards and concessions to the peasants intended to raise production.

Dan Ferris, secretary-treasrer of the Amateur Athletic Union, told the track writers at Leone's Restaurant yesterday that the A. A. U. had erred in crediting Herm Wyatt with a world indoor high jump record.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 18 -- The appointment of Prof. Daniel C. Sayre, director of the James Forrestal Research Center here, as associate dean of the university's School of Engineering was announced today.

The second of the two-volume work with the over-all title "Assignment to Catastrophe," by Maj. Gen. Sir Edward L. Spears, will be issued Feb. 24 by A. A. Wyn. The new book, called "The Fall of France," begins with June 1, 1940, the day after the Paris Conference.

COASTAL sports fishermen touched off their first broadside of 1955 in a letter to Louis A. Wehle, the new State Conservation Commissioner. The anglers have requested support in the battle to make the striped bass a "hook and line" fish.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Brazil took two important steps today to attract foreign investments and place her exports in a stronger competitive position in world markets.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 -- Two of the nation's oldest airlines tangled on paper today over which was older.

THE twenty-five-year association of Ben Shahn with the Downtown Gallery is celebrated with a large retrospective of his paintings and drawings at the gallery, 32 East Fifty-first Street. Appropriately, the earliest picture here, a wry little water-color of Don Quixote, was the first to have been exhibited at this gallery.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Henry (Nick) Cullop today was named manager of the Columbus Jets International League baseball club for the 1955 season.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Jim Tatum, athletic director of the University of Maryland, today explained that charges claiming the school had violated Atlantic Coast Conference and National Collegiate recruiting rules were based on a single case of a youngster changing his mind.

IT is highly unlikely that any citizen of a foreign country knows as much about this country as Denis W. Brogan, a learned and eloquent Scot who has devoted a good part of his distinguished career to explaining Americans to Europeans and to themselves. In fact, Mr. Brogan knows more about American history, government and politics than all save a few illustrious Americans.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Pay increases ranging from ninety-eight cents to $1.82 a week were awarded today to 260,000 employes of Britain's nationalized railroads.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A record for state social functions is being set at the White House this week.
The Board of Education's tentative budget estimate for next year drew a little praise and a lot of criticism at a public hearing yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The Harriman administration opened a battle today for the right of voters to initiate amendments to the State Constitution.

Dean James A. Pike declared yesterday that use of scientific birth control methods was no more artificial than any means that man has used to attain spiritual ends. Parents have a positive duty to use them in planning their families, the Protestant Episcopal clergyman added.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Credit for putting into effect the thinking of the Eisenhower administration on housing and community development was given here today to the private construction industry.
Wood County, W. Va., borrowed $3,700,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of school bonds maturing from 1956 to 1970.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- In the presence of Hollywood celebrities, a copy of an old-fashioned nickelodeon, forerunner of the modern movie palace, was dedicated at the Franklin Institute here this afternoon.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 18 -The financing of the GreenwichKillingly Expressway was a major topic of discussion today among Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democratic and Republican legislative leaders and a special committee named by the Governor to study the financing.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 18 -- Israel's Foreign Ministry criticized today a suggestion that the demilitarization zone along the Syrian border be divided to aid in pacifying the area.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Women Republicans were called to meet here May 9, 10 and 11 to start a program of campaign activities aimed at women voters in the 1956 Presidential campaign.
MONTREAL, Jan. 18 (AP) -Montreal, Toronto and Detroit swept eleven of the twelve berths on the National Hockey League's two All-Star teams today, the mid-point in the season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Secretary of State Dulles discounted the loss of Yikiang Island today on the ground that it was of no particular importance. In the Pentagon, however, its capture by the Chinese Communists was depicted as portending an eventual assault on the Nationalist-held Tachen Islands to the south.

The problem of illuminating the dark has been with us ever since man discovered fire. This week two events in the field of lighting, the Lamp Show at the New Yorker Hotel and an exhibit of Light in Architecture at the Architectural League of New York, offer interesting contrasts.

The Advertising Club of New York is planning a concerted attack on myths and false beliefs still surrounding advertising. Even now there are advertisers who use the medium to attack advertising. An example is that of the clothing manufacturer whose commercial announcement on radio includes the phrase, "----- and this isn't just advertising."
William Saroyan's Pulitzer Prize and Critics Circle award play, "The Time of Your Life," will be revived for two weeks at the City Center, beginning this evening at 8 o'clock.

The five-story apartment house known as Prospect Court at 406 Prospect Avenue in Hackensack, N. J., has been sold by Pasquale Bisciotti to the Bilrod Realty Corporation. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker in the transaction. The property occupies a plot 164 by 184 feet at the corner of Passaic Street.
MADRID, Jan. 18 -- Prince Juan Carlos of Bourbon arrived in Madrid this morning greeted by shouts of "Long live the King's son!"

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The French idea of creating an arms production pool with somewhat supranational powers emerged in a battered state from today's meeting of the representatives of the seven European nations discussing the subject here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that the United States would give somewhat more emphasis to Asian aid programs.

A few months ago I wrote to your newspaper in an appeal to those who would like to help us with our Christmas parties for destitute Korean child ren living in the villages near the Communist line. It was very kind of you to publish our letter; the readers of The New York Times responded most generously.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Governor Harriman rebuked Republican legislative leaders tonight for opposing a short-cut to legalizing bingo.

Georgia's attractiveness for industry was detailed to 100 leading New York executives yesterday at the start of a "goodwill mission" by Marvin Griffin, the state's new Governor. He told luncheon guests at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel that Georgia, once solely an agricultural state, had reached an economic balance between faming and industry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -Judge Luther W. Youngdahl struck down today for the second time a perjury indictment against Owen Lattimore.
The 1954 Research Corporation Award was presented last night to Dr. Willis E. Lamb Jr., Professor of Physics at Stanford University.
The North German Lloyd liner Berlin, honoring the name of Germany's former capital and displaying the traditional black hull of a German liner, arrived here yesterday.
WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 18 -This town agreed tonight to abandon its campaign against a Nike site midway between the Merritt Parkway and the Boston Post Road here.

The Chinese Communists have launched an amphibious invasion of the thinly held offshore island of Yikiang and "conquered" it. The island itself, a tiny and scarcely habitable rock 225 miles north of Formosa but only 20 miles from the mainland, is far outside of the Formosan and Pescadores areas which the United States will be pledged to defend under its proposed mutual defense treaty with the Chinese Nationalist Government.

PANAMA, Jan. 18 -- The Supreme Court refused today to try the case of Jose Ramon Guizado, suspended President of Panama accused of complicity in the murder of his predecessor, Col. Jose Antonio Remon.
Steve Allen, star of the National Broadcasting Company's television show, "Tonight," received last night the Distinguished Service Award of the Young Men's Board of Trade, Inc.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Joseph L. Mankiewicz' independent company, Figaro, will make four more pictures for United Artists.

The share of the consumer's dollar going to the men's clothing industry has dropped from 11.9 per cent in 1929 to 8.4 per cent last year, Isidore Grossman, president of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange, said yesterday.

To the five engineering societies, civil, mechanical, electrical, mining and chemical, that are being tempted to move their headquarters elsewhere we want to say that New York City would hate to see you go. We will not say anything against Pittsburgh, Chicago, Philadelphia and Washington, which are bidding you welcome. Fine cities.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 18 (UP) -- The smallest crowd of the meeting, 11,000 persons, today saw Calumet Farm's Sweet Nell splash to a neck victory at Santa Anita in the $6,000 National Resources Purse.
DETROIT, Jan. 18 -- Army officials asserted today that millions of dollars were being saved through the military standardization program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The old McCarthy committee reopened today under new management and new rules.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Legislation was proposed today by two Long Island Republicans to allow savings banks to open branch offices within the county in which their main office is located.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- The old colonial house on North Street that was the home of the late Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of The New York Times, is scheduled to become a school-house.

The long torso silhouette, originated in Paris, was endorsed again yesterday when it appeared in a showing of resort fashions at S. Klein. Bathing suits, sportswear and evening dresses all received the low hipline treatment.
The city's multimillion-dollar men's clothing industry backed Governor Harriman yesterday in his appeal for a Federal minimum wage of $1.25 an hour.
May I congratulate you on, and heartily endorse, your editorial bemoaning the fact that the Narrows Bridge blueprints by-pass rapid transit facilities?
ROME, Jan. 18 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, began today to wreak his revenge on leaders who rebelled against him.
Ten thousand girls who are waiting to become Girl Scouts here must go on waiting because funds, adult volunteers and troop meeting places are lacking.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 18 -George Bell Timmerman Jr., inaugurated today as South Carolina's seventy-ninth Governor, called on Congress to "curb" the Supreme Court's power and return to the states their "traditional right to regulate their own schools."
The following was written by Ewing Poteet, music editor of The New Orleans Item.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -The National Association for Advancement of Colored People asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to reverse its decision that it has no jurisdiction over segregation in railroad station restaurants.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Liberty ships of World War II are re-enlisting for atomic sentry duty.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Fritz Crisler cautioned today against state legislatures going too far into the matter of telecasting college football.

Chief Magistrate Murtagh's figures on the collection of fines from traffic cases in the Magistrate's Courts are encouraging to those who believe, as we do, in "no fix" traffic tickets and efficient methods of handling traffic summonses. Through such policies, Mr. Murtagh reports, the Magistrate's Courts last year collected a bumper crop of traffic fines, totaling $8,721,325, and collected fines from 95 per cent of all motorists haled into court for traffic violations.

Politically glamorous though it may be, the projected St. Lawrence Seaway is really a boondoggle that will never pay for itself, Austin J. Tobin declared yesterday. The executive director of the Port of New York Authority spoke at a luncheon of the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Hal Price Headley's Aesthete, unsuccessful in seven starts in 1954, led home a field of fillies and mares in the Azure Skies purse at Hialeah Park today.
Joseph and Stewart Alsop, columnists, received last night the $1,000 Lauterbach Award of the Authors Guild, given annually for writings contributing to civil liberties.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- A clear call for greater freedom in Soviet scientific research and for open competition among rival schools of scientific thought has been published here.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 18 -- The German Federation of Labor in Hamburg staged a public demonstration today against a meeting of neo-Nazis to organize a new political organization. The federation summoned the workers to demonstrate after the Hamburg Senate had forbidden a meeting of organized labor near the hall in which the neo-Nazi groups were meeting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower created today in his own Executive organization a committee to prevent racial, creed or color bias in Government jobs.
HONG KONG, Jan. 18 -- The Chinese Communists announced tonight they had captured Nationalistheld Yikiang Island in an amphibious assault.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 18 -George M. Leader was inaugurated today as the first Democratic Governor of Pennsylvania in sixteen years.

Ed Sullivan is arranging a one-hour salute to radio on his Columbia Broadcasting System television program, but there were definite indications yesterday that the National Broadcasting Company would not permit any of its contract performers to appear.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Democratic National Committee will meet tomorrow afternoon to elect Mathew H. McCloskey of Philadelphia as its treasurer. He will be charged with raising the funds to wage the 1956 Presidential campaign.

Prices rose on the New York commodity futures markets yesterday in dull trading. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, rubber, wool, burlap, silk, zinc, copper, cottonseed oil and soybean oil went up, potatoes ended mixed and hides declined.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Charlie Ross, Yale guard, turned in an outstanding performance by tying the game at the end of regulation time and again in the first overtime tonight. Then Dave Hobson took over as the Elis scored an upset double overtime Ivy League basketball victory over Dartmouth, 83 -- 79.

A mixture of many materials is one of the most distinctive characteristics of mid-twentieth century furniture design. Reaffirmation of this fact may be seen in two collections introduced here this week.

TWO important works by Heitor Villa-Lobos were heard for the first time in New York when the Brazilian composer conducted a program last night consisting exclusively of his compositions in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The White House authorized television and newsreel camera men today to make sound movies of Presidential news conferences for possible public showings. This innovation will start with President Eisenhower's weekly meeting with the press tomorrow.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan.5 -- A newly perfected technique enables scholars and laymen to scrutinize reproductions of the most important inscriptions and bas-reliefs of the ancient world.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 18 -The Shinnecock Tribe of Indians won today an action to evict a real-estate development company from about dine acres of Suffolk County.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 18 -- Government troops and the rebels were in combat again today after a lull since Saturday.

An attempt to refloat the Panamanian freighter Lake Charles will be made tomorrow. Victim of a ship crash on Nov. 18, she has been "hung" on an underwater ledge just off the East Rive Drive at Grand Street.

LEO DUROCHER breezed into town the other day. He never just comes to town. That's too pedestrian. The Dandy Little Manager swooshes in like a cyclone. What's more, he also bubbles like. champagne and it's a heady concoction that he offers. A listener can get intoxicated by his words.
Commercial paper dealers yesterday increased the yield offered to buyers of these notes by one-eighth of a percentage point for the second day.

Forty years ago a group of New York clothing workers gathered in old Webster Hall on East Eleventh Street and formed the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union. Last night many of the same group met again in the same place -- with hundreds of others besides -- to celebrate what the union had accomplished during the intervening stretch of years.

A "watchdog" committee was set up last night by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to determine what steps were being taken to assure more jobs for Negroes in radio and television.

SUNDRY musical maters have been on the television agenda of late and each in its own way has been rewarding viewing. Certainly a viewer could hardly ask for a greater degree of contrast than was to be found in the two major items: a generous sampling of the new Gian-Carlo Menotti opera, "The Saint of Bleecker Street," and a revival of the Victor Herbert operetta. "Naughty Marietta."
Aleer J. Couri, United States Appraiser of Merchandise, announced yesterday another step in his experimental campaign to facilitate the movement of cargo from shipside to consignee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Instant and iceless orange and grapefruit juices, developed experimentally by the Department of Agriculture, are being commercially produced.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Atomic Energy Commission and its laboratory directors ended today a two-day review of its employesecurity procedures and found them generally "excellent."
ALBANY, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The State Public Health Council is revising the Sanitary Code for the atomic age.
The men's and boys' wear industries held a luncheon yesterday for the benefit of the 1955 fund campaign of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Harold E. Stassen proclaimed today his full confidence in Wolf Ladejinsky. He said he believed the Russian-born land reform expert would aid the cause of freedom in his new job in Vietnam.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., the world's largest operating electric and gas utility, reported yesterday a net income of $50,289,300 for 1954. This was after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges and equaled $2.98 a share on the company's outstanding common stock.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 18 -- Twenty-five F-51 fighters and an undetermined number of Thompson sub-machine guns are being unloaded in Nicaragua's Pacific port of Corinto, President Anastasio Somoza said today.

Boston's Bill Sherman and Bob Cousy paced a last-period drive to give the East a 100-to91 victory over the West in the National Basketball Association's fifth annual All-Star game last night. The swift-moving contest at Madison Square Garden was witnessed by 13,148 spectators.
ARMONK, N. Y., Jan. 18 -Plans to preserve part of the scenic Mianus Gorge as a geologic wonder and wildlife sanctuary moved forward today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, will report to Secretary of State Dulles here tomorrow on his mission to Peiping.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 18 -The West German Government began the reorganization of its Foreign Office and diplomatic service today.
Construction of the first commercial heliport in mid-Manhattan may begin in two or three months.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18 -- A seven-nation scientific committee representing the Soviet Union, India and the West began work today on the agenda for the conference on peaceful use of atomic energy. The conference will meet in Geneva, most likely in August.
HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Jan. 18 -- The evacuation of Haiphong has begun. The great harbor where troops and supplies for the war in Tonkin used to arrive is beginning to look like a little provincial town.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -Congress was asked today to set up a special commission of Government officials and private citizens to investigate the entire Federal security program.

Eleven 4-H boys from South Carolina, winners of this year's annual sweet potato-growing contest sponsored by the A. P., are in town. this week seeing the sights as part of their award. The prize winners, each of whom grew an acre of the tubers under supervision of county agents, had the distinction of harvesting the highest proportion of top-grade specimens.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Butcher hogs dropped 25 to 50 cents while sows sold steady to 25 cents lower today despite the fact that salable receipts fell 3,000 below the advance estimate to 12,000.

A small, upholstered footstool from the White House, lent by Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, will be among the many highly prized relics and objects of art from private collections, museums and historic houses that will be on display during the East Side House Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory from next Monday through Jan. 29.

Under present principles of international law each nation has complete sovereignty and jurisdiction over the air space above its territory. In the absence of treaty agreement each nation is free to bar foreign planes from its air space or to admit them on its own terms.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, introduced legislation today to correct "the most serious inequities" in the McCarran-Walter Immigration Law.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Eisenhower believes that this country's information program directed to foreign peoples should consist exclusively of unvarnished facts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -A New York financier said today he had no doubt about the ability of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation to finance reconversion of its "Little Inch" natural gas pipeline to petroleum products and construction of a substitute gas line.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Department of Justice asked Congress today to authorize rewards up to $500,000 for information on illegal shipments into this country or illegal acquisition here of atomic weapons or special nuclear material.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The United Stats, though not a participant, has a dominating influence in the current talks on a European arms pool.
The New England Power Company borrowed $25,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of thirty-year first-mortgage bonds at an interest cost of 3.17 per cent.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 18 -Southern Presbyterians rejected today a plan to merge the three largest Presbyterian groups in the country.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Governor Harriman's new budget is expected to recommend a special $4,000,000 educational grant to New York City.

The new Northeastern Steel Corporation has signed an agreement to purchase the stock of the New England Steel Development Corporation, a subsidiary of the New England Council. This was announced jointly yesterday by Walter Raleigh, executive vice president of the council, and Walter P. Jacob, chairman of Northeastern Steel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Prices for grain and soybean futures were strong and higher in the early trade. But the market advance failed to enlist much outside support and prices went into a tailspin later in the session. Outside of the political developments in the Far East there was little bullish news to stimulate buying.

GENEVA, Jan. 18 -- The French Government has been severely criticized by the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) for maintaining special import taxes in violation of the agreement. The contracting parties are the governing body for the thirty-four countries that adhere to the tariff system and trade rules established under the agreement.

SAN JOSE, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A rebel radio broadcast, heard in Managua, said 200 rebels had landed near Limon in an amphibious operation. The Costa Rican port is on the Caribbean coast seventy miles east of San Jose.
A GROUP of middle-aged gentlemen in town got talking about the weather the other day and how modern winters are sissy periods compared with those they passed through in youth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, came out today for increased trade with Communist countries. His statement, made while he was supporting President Eisenhower's request for a three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, represented a considerable change from views he had held in the past.

In the sleepy Umbrian town of Borgo San Sepolcro is a great art treasure, the magnificent fresco of the Resurrection painted by the fifteenth century master Piero della Francesca. The discovery of anything by his hand is a major event; and especial interest is added when it is identified on the wall of a building in his native town.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18 -Turkey's Premier has asked the Egyptian Government to receive him on an official visit designed to persuade Cairo to join Turkey and Iraq in a regional security organization.
The two-month crime spree of an escaped convict -- a narcotics addict -- was ended yesterday with his arrest by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents. Two men and two women were held as accessories.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -The Democratic National Committee supplied Democrats in Congress today with another "confidential" memorandum. It suggested that President Eisenhower's budget ignored Republican campaign pledges and parts of his own legislative program.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Dr. Julius B. Maller was appointed Director of Research and Statistics in the Department of Audit and Control by Controller Arthur Levitt today.
VIENNA, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Austria's famous dancing horses -those of the Spanish riding school of the Habsburg' emperors -- will return to Vienna soon after long exile in the West.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18 -- The Harvard Divinity School will admit qualified women as regular students beginning next fall. They will be permitted to take the regular threeyear graduate course, leading to the degree of bachelor of theology, as well as advanced studies for the degrees of master of theology and doctor of theology, George H. Williams, acting dean, said today.

Leo Durocher, in fine voiced, held his annual mid-winter bull session at the Giants' West Forty-second Street offices yesterday. His observations are always interesting, even though some have been heard before.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 19 -The initiative must come from the Soviet Union for ending the state of war between that country and Japan, Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu said today.

Robert R. Young and his associates spent well over $1,000,000 last year in soliciting the proxies that gave them control of the New York Central Railroad. This was in addition to the more than $25,000,000 that the group invested in more than 1,000,000 shares, or 17 per cent, of the railroad's stock for their own accounts.
A mistrial was declared yesterday at an income tax evasion trial in Brooklyn Federal Court because the foreman of the jury fell dead on his way to court.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 19 (UP) -- Former President Truman politely told Amy Vanderbilt, etiquette writer, today that he did not care what people called him but he always addressed Herbert Hoover as "Mr. President."

United Cerebral Palsy of New York raised $916,000 last year, more than 85 per cent of which went for research, training and direct services to many of the estimated 32,000 New Yorkers who suffer from the disease.

NEW FAIRFIELD, Conn., Jan. 19 -- An old-fashioned New England town meeting decided here tonight to hold a referendum a week from Saturday on the question of ceding 260 choice acres on Lake Candlewood to the town of Brookfield.
A holding corporation organized by the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art has purchased the old Bible House property for $675,000.

For the first time in a year there was a change in November in the age of accounts receivable, according to a survey by the Credit Research Foundation of the National Association of Credit Men. In November, 1954, the average age was 33.9 days, compared with 32.7 days in August, at which level it had been virtually unchanged since November, 1953.

Carl Furillo yesterday became the twenty-second Dodger to sign his contract. The right fielder, with one of the strongest and most accurate throwing arms in either league, also became the second Brooklyn regular to take a cut in salary. Jackie Robinson was the first.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- A tentative agenda for the first world conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy, was completed today by a seven-member committee of scientists from the Soviet Union, India and the West.

The April 12 performance of the Paul Gregory-Charles Laughton production "Three for Tonight" has been taken over by the Fiftieth Anniversary Women's Committee of Greer, a children's community in Dutchess County, N. Y. The play, starring Harry Belafonte and Marge and Gower Champion, opens here March 21.
Cotton futures advanced 13 to 24 points (65 cents to $1.20 a bale) yesterday with a moderate amount of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Lilly Dache proved herself an amusing and adept impresario yesterday as she extolled the merits of perfume, her hair styles and hair cosmetics, millinery, and boutique fashions. The occasion was the introduction of a new hair salon in her establishment at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street.

A "when issued" market has been established for the debentures of the proposed textile company Textron American, Inc., Royal Little, chairman of Textron Incorporated, said yesterday. Some $400,000 of them have been sold, he reported.

An increase last of 1,242,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 162,198,000 barrels, compared with 160,956,000 a week earlier and 163,560,000 a year earlier.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Governor Harriman was the principal speaker tonight at the annual farm dinner of the State Agricultural Society. Earlier today the society had taken issue with many of his views on farm policy.
MADRID, Jan. 19 -- Prince Juan Carlos of Bourbon said today he was facing six months of hard work to prepare for entrance examinations to the Military Academy of Saragossa.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 18 -- The Algerian Assembly convened in extraordinary session today.

BIAK, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 4 -- Herman Womsiwor, who knows what it is like to be hidden in a soldier's duffel bag, is not a typical native of New Guinea. But he is an example of how an individual can in thirteen years emerge from a primitive culture and become a useful member of modern society.

MADRID, Jan. 19 -- Pedro Rodriguez, Spanish dress designer, in his spring and summer collection shown today, reaffirmed his belief that women should dress for men and thus does not sacrifice a feminine silhouette to fashion.
Patrolman Edward M. Caffrey, whose three years on the force have brought him two citations, was the hero of a West Side tenement fire yesterday morning.

As a retired engineer from city service who is interested in proper supply of water to the City of New York, I want to thank the authorities of the Board of Water Supply for the very explanatory letters which have appeared in The Times.

Today's new film is "The Bridges at Toko-ri," a Paramount drama in color with William Holden, Grace Kelly, Fredric March and Mickey Rooney, at the Radio City Music Hall. William Perlberg and George Seaton produced and Mark Robson directed. Valentine Davies' screen play is adapted from the James A. Michener novel of the same name. Robert Strauss, Charles McGraw and Keiko Awaji head the supporting cast.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 19 -- The notably cheerful workers at the Abilities, Inc., plant had a specially warm welcome today for Richard F. Wood, a member of Britain's Parliament. They knew that the young man shared with them the ability to overcome physical handicaps.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Rocky Graziano's turbulent life story, from youth on New York's Lower East Side to middleweight boxing champion, will be dramatized on the screen by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer.
A 65 per cent increase in police for the crowded Morningside area was announced yesterday by the Police Department.

Next to marking off one's own birthdays there is nothing that makes one feel older than observing birthdays of one's children -- especially when they are growing fast and tall enough to look one in the eye.

THREE trucks will drive away from Connie Mack Stadium this morning, loaded with the office furniture, trophies, uniforms and other equipment that are the last physical assets of the defunct Philadelphia Athletics. These assets will be following the franchise to Kansas City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)--Vice President Richard M. Nixon, in a stunt to help the March of Dimes campaign against polio, changed his well-tailored coat for a mackinaw today and worked for half an hour at a filling station.
A program to stimulate official efforts by the state to combat alcoholism was proposed yesterday by a committee of the New York State Bar Association.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Over Britain's largest radio hook-up and to an audience attracted by one of the biggest controversies in years two housewives tonight debated the existence of God.

The twelve-story office building on plot 36 by 95 feet at 660 Madison Avenue is under contract of sale to the Pacwest Realty Corporation, an affiliate of interests which own the Pierre Hotel at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street. The seller is Herbert J. Schmitz.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
The Bach Aria Group gave its second concert of the season last night in Town Hall. Many familiar soloists previously heard with the organization were present.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower put a damper today on a proposal for increased trade in nonstrategic goods with Communist countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The President is quoted directly where the quotations are authorized. In other sections his remarks are given in indirect discourse, as required by White House rules.
A 100 per cent stock dividend has been authorized by directors of the Rotary Electric Steel Company, according to M. K. Schnurr, president.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 19--Oscar Sevilla Sacasa, the Foreign Minister, warned tonight that Nicaragua was reinforcing her southern border because of what his Government charged was a violation of this frontier by the fighter planes sold to Costa Rica by the United States.

Seaboard and Western Gains in Air Cargo -- City Fitting Pier for Italian Line Seaboard and Western Arlines reported yesterday that in the past year it had flown 10,066,231 revenue ton miles, compared with 4,770,139 in 1953.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 19 -- President Anastasio Somoza said tonight that two F-51 fighter planes from Costa Rica violated Nicaraguan territory this afternoon by flying over the border. He called the resulting situation "very tense," and said it could become an "international conflict."
ROME, Jan. 19 -- The Chamber of Deputies confirmed its confidence in Premier Mario Scelba's Government this afternoon by 281 votes to 256 with three abstentions.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- In the most prolific scoring exhibition by an Army sextet in seven years, the cadets rebounded from a week-end defeat to crush Amherst College, 10 to 3, at Smith Rink today.
TOKYO, Jan. 19 -- Japan offered her highly industrialized resources to other nations of the free world today for a combined effort to halt communism among Asia's impoverished masses.
Mrs. Anna M. Kross, Commissioner of Correction, said yesterday she was asking the city for a supplemental budget of $500,000 for a rehabilitation program.

IN reviving William Saroyan's "The Time of Your Life" last night, the City Center has rendered a valuable service to all those who love and treasure the theatre. Indeed, it is good to behold and hear again this ode to the human race that Mr. Saroyan penned in the flush of his youth and enthusiasm.

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., Jan. 14 -- One hundred French Impressionist and post - Impressionist paintings, most of which have not been seen in Western Europe for at least forty years, may be displayed in Brussels next fall if Soviet consent is given.
THE Federal migratory waterfowl regulations have been called many things by many people. So reference to the fine-print clause involving the "baiting" of ducks as "gobbledegook" is hardly surprising.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Charles E. Wilson restored Annie Lee Moss to an Army job today, but transferred her from the Pentagon.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday named Bartlett T. Miller as vice president in charge of merchandising, a new post. Sanford B. Cousins succeeded him as vice president in charge of public relations.
The Colonial Trust Company had perhaps the stormiest stockholders' meeting of its twenty-five year history yesterday.

Theatregoers attending last night's performance of "Festival" at the Longacre Theatre were treated to an extra bit of "show business." Bella Spewack, coauthor of the comedy with her husband, Sam, made a speech in defense of her new stage product.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- One of Britain's leading bankers cautioned today against the dangers of inflation. D. J. Roberts, chairman of the National Provincial Bank, Ltd., said in the bank's annual report that "a policy of tolerating or even deliberately engendering a dose of inflation" would be possible for Britain only if the rest of the world was doing much the same.

PHILIPSBURG, Pa., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A Trans World Airlines twinengine Martin, carrying forty passengers and a crew of three from Pittsburgh to New York, made a safe emergency landing at a small airport near here tonight.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Democratic leader of the Assembly predicted today that state taxes would be increased at this legislative session.

We cannot believe that majority public opinion is being expressed by the two Republican legislators who, in flagrant contradiction of their party's platform pledge in last fall's election campaign, have proposed turning over Niagara Falls power development to privately owned utility companies.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The Kaiser-Willys Company plans to manufacture 40,000 motor vehicles a year in Argentina under a contract signed today with the Argentine Government.

CAIRO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Premier Nuri as-Said of Iraq, who aroused bitter criticism in some Arab states by agreeing to an Iraqi-Turkish defense pact, will not attend the Arab League Premiers' conference here on Saturday. Egypt called the meeting to discuss the pact.
Thomas P. Lynch, president of Bronx County Trust Company, yesterday reported to the stockholders' meeting the terms under which the bank is to be sold to the Bank of Manhattan Company.

A one-story taxpayer at the northeast corner of Hillside Avenue and 169th Street in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies to the Hillside Homelawn Corporation, of which John Daniel is president. The property, on a plot 158 by 100 feet, is assessed at $280,000.
It became apparent last night that two blocks of Leggett Avenue in the Bronx would not be changed to Jaburg Avenue without a fight.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 19 -- Mrs. Ruth Davenport of Bronxville, N. Y., today commended a Connecticut state policeman on Merritt Parkway patrol for arresting her 19-year-old son last month on a charge of speeding.

Pork loins, especially abundant and low in cost at this time, can be used in many festive ways. Butterfly chops and crown roast are two of the interesting ways in which this ever popular meat can be presented to guests.

Remote control is the answer to the household help problem, or so one would surmise from the Frigidaire Kitchen of Tomorrow, which goes on view today at the General Motors Motorama in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
A three-year interracial, interfaith project to encourage the adoption of Negro and Puerto Rican children has been started here.

Expecting too little of a child can sometimes be as harmful in its own way as expecting too much of him, Dr. Frederick H. Allen, director of the Philadelphia Child Guidance Clinic, said yesterday. He spoke at the annual Luella Palmer memorial conference for teachers of kindergarten and early grades.

I enjoyed the felicitous editorial with respect to the merging of the Chase and Manhattan banks. Possibly, as a result of a decade of service as a member of the Banking Board of our state, I felt a deep disappointment that there was no comment with respect to the danger implicit in the merger.

THE first televising on film of a Presidential press conference, shown last evening on the major networks, was highly successful. As a program, it was immensely informative and educational on a number of different grounds, not the least of which was a new insight into President Eisenhower as personality on the TV screen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- A Senate Banking subcommittee today blamed a frost in Brazil, inadequate crop reporting and irregularities on the coffee exchange for last year's sharp rise in coffee prices.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The British Labor party has fired the first salvos of a full-scale political offensive against the defense policy of the Conservative Government.

Army, Air Force and Navy recruiting officials in the New York area agreed yesterday that the Jan. 31 deadline for many veterans' benefits had caused a substantial increase in applications for enlistment.

The metropolitan New York area now contains about 9.1 per cent of the country's commercial businesses, says Dun Bradstreet in the 1955 Reference Book. The credit checking agency points out that the number of such enterprises in the area has increased more than 15 per cent in the last ten years.

LONDON, Jan. 19--The stock markets were buoyant today at the start of a new bookkeeping account. Demand broadened and many prices rose sharply under the combined influence of the rally in Wall Street, favorable exchequer revenue figures, and higher profit statements in company reports.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Goss Printing Press Company announced today it had purchased the Rockford (Ill.) plant of Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company. The price was not disclosed. R. C. Corlett, Goss president, said rising demand for Goss products necessitated expansion of production facilities.
Youthful criminals "pose a very considerable threat to the peace and safety of the citizens," a Kings County grand jury asserted yesterday.
Evander Childs High of the Bronx won the Public Schools Athletic League dual-meet swimming championship by defeating Brooklyn Tech, 41 -- 26, in the Seward Park pool yesterday.

Giving their best performance of the National Hockey League season, the New York Rangers shut out the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. The Broadway Blues stepped into the league leaders as if the Wings were any old team, and set the visitors down by the score of 2 to 0.

In an effort to end the armed clashes around the Chinese offshore islands before they grow to more dangerous proportions President Eisenhower has made what amounts to a bid to the United Nations to intervene and arrange a cease-fire between the attacking Communists and the Chinese Nationalists.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Paul Ramadier, Socialist leader and former Premier, was selected tonight as probable successor to Jean Monnet as president of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community.

Without fanfare, or even widespread public knowledge, a profound revolution in transportation is reaching for a climax. For the first time in history airplanes now carry more long-distance -- what are called "intercity" -- passengers than railroad coaches and are even neck and neck with buses, which still hold a narrow lead over planes.
MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Menolene, bred in Kentucky and raised in Florida, led from wire to wire today to capture the $20,400 Jasmine. Stakes at Hialeah Park.
The formation of Life Insurance Investors, Inc., a new type of investment concern, was announced yesterday by Raymond T. Smith, president.
New York City borrowed $65,200,000 in the public market yesterday to finance school and hospital construction and to buy transit equipment.
GENEVA, Jan. 19 -- A report sharply critical of the European Coal and Steel Community has been approved by the governing body of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 19 (AP) --Two of the F-51 fighter planes went into action late today, strafing rebel positions at El Amo, near the Nicaraguan border.

A regrouping of the United States for the Sears Cup semi-final eliminations was reported by J. A. B. Smith, chairman of the committee for junior sailing, at the annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union last night. The meeting was held in the New York Yacht Club.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Earl W. Smith of El Cerrito, Calif., has been elected president of the National Association of Home Builders. He succeeds Richard G. Hughes of Pampa, Tex.

TEANECK, N. J., Jan. 19 -- A meeting held here tonight by the New York Central Railroad to explain its application to drop its West Shore passenger service and its Hudson River ferries drew only 125 persons. Some of those left before the session was over.
Twenty of New York's problem drivers began attending a custom-made traffic school last night.
On an eight-hour visit to New York yesterday George Jessel made final arrangements for a four-week appearance here at the Playhouse in a one-man show to be called "Recital Comique."
Five thousand invited guests attended the preview yesterday of the General Motors Motorama at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The show will be open to the public at 1 P. M. today.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Dr. Persia Campbell stepped into the new state job of Consumer Counsel to the Governor today, saying she would be his lookout in the market place.

Events today: F. Mark Siebert, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; New York Concert Choir and Orchestra, Margaret Hillis conducting, Ania Dorfmann, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. asked Congress anew today to set up a core of "public defenders" in criminal cases for those unable to pay lawyers' fees.

"Patterns," the play that was highly acclaimed after its presentation last week on "Kraft Television Theatre," found itself setting a new kind of TV pattern yesterday. It was booked for a repeat performance that will occur only four weeks after the original showing, a development believed to be unique in live television drama.

The building of a $220,000,000 bridge across the Narrows from Staten Island to Brooklyn, as proposed in the Port Authority-Triborough Authority joint study, will mean the crossing of New York City's last sea frontier. It will open Richmond County to urban development such as it alone, of New York City's five boroughs, has escaped.
HONG KONG, Jan. 19--Communist planes today loosed what appeared to be their biggest-attack against Nationalist positions off the Southeast China coast.

George P. Monaghan, the State Harness Racing Commissioner, said yesterday that final decision on the charges against Edward T. Dougherty and eight harness racing drivers under suspension probably would not be made until early next month.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Jan. 19 -- Working under compressed air between a 240-ton steel shield and an eleven-foot-thick concrete barricade, 150 sandhogs began today the underwater tunneling for the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.

Of all the prose and poetry inspired by the Statue of Liberty the best-known and best-loved is a sonnet by a shy young woman who was born and died in New York City many years ago. She was Emma Lazarus, a poetess and writer of great distinction, but one whose memory rests today almost entirely on the fourteen lines she penned in 1883.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower's suggestion that the United Nations might try to bring about a ceasefire in the Strait of Formosa was welcomed here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The State Department denied today that it was trying to hamper the sales of surplus farm products abroad.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Commission house absorption of grain and soybean futures took the early slack out of the pits today and there was a sharp upturn all along the line. Short covering followed.
ATLANTA, Jan. 19 -- Formal dedication of the new $400,000 Protestant radio and television center took place today.

The appointments of Assistant Corporation Counsel Samuel D. Johnson and Assistant Bronx District Attorney Martin Kraus as justices of the Municipal Court were announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The posts carry annual salaries of $15,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The United States barred Soviet citizens today from photographing or sketching military installations, ports, railroad junctions, and other places of strategic importance in this country.

"One of Churchill's political meetings was mobbed and then routed. Knaves from Soho battered down platforms, brass knuckles appeared, and clubs and staves and modern improvisations of Little John's single stick. And thugs! I even saw many I knew by sight, from previous overflows of ill feeling for one cause or another, or for money they wanted but didn't own."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The common sense, candor and civility with which the President's replies to his news conference questions were imbued today were not in the least new expressions of his personality. They are characteristic, a fact well known to those who have engaged him over the years in discussions of matters within the growing scope of his authority and information.
The American Bar Association has created a special committee to survey criminal law administration throughout the country in a project designed to "make justice more certain."
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- High rivers continued to pour over their banks today, isolating many low-lying communities.
WASHINGTON, Jan 19 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Debate in the Advisory Council of the Republic on the Paris agreements for Germany's rearming will open Feb. 8. A vote by Feb. 13 is probable.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- On the eve of his second anniversary in the White House, President Eisenhower looked backward today with obvious satisfaction and forward with expressions of quiet confidence.
One of the city's biggest fur storage warehouses was kept in business yesterday by a union-management agreement to reduce operating costs.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The outlook for the French plan for a West European arms production pool appeared unfavorable tonight. Representatives of the seven nations concerned have been discussing the plan for two days.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- An Agriculture Department spokesman said today cobalt was a "good buy" in exchange for surplus butter.
High Bridge over the Harlem River and High Bridge Tower on the Manhattan side are to be preserved for public enjoyment as part of the city's park system.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 19 -- Judge John Drewen dismissed in Superior Court today a two-count indictment for false swearing in 1953 against Paul Hanly, deputy warden of the Hudson County. Penitentiary and a son-in-law of former Mayor John V. Kenny.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Republicans of the House of Representatives completed today the manning of committees for the new Congress.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- Two of twenty men arrested were still being held by the Hamburg authorities tonight after last night's clash resulting from a workers' demonstration against a neo-Fascist rally in the out-skirts of Hamburg.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Segregation of high school pupils by sex has been suggested by Hiram Bingham, former Connecticut Senator, as a solution to one phase of the school segregation problem.

Herbert Fishbach, president of Herbert Charles Co., has sold the five-story office building at 4 East Forty-sixth Street to Harry Horwitz, real estate operator. The sale was negotiated by Herbert Charles Co. as brokers.

The New York State Racing Commission assigned 1955 racing dates yesterday in accordance with the pattern followed last year. This action left the Empire City Racing Association out in the cold. Empire City, inoperative in 1954, had hoped to get back into the picture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Intelligence reports from South Vietnam indicate that Premier Ngo Dinh Diem is extending the area of his control. He is thereby whittling down the influence of the Communists on the one hand and the religious-political sects on the other, according to this information.

The men's clothing industry will reflect the general improvement in business conditions expected this year, but will not received its fair share of the consumer dollar, according to George M. Epstein, president of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- A bill that would permit Civil Defense volunteers to lend organized assistance during natural disasters was introduced in the Legislature today.

The Dow Chemical Company and Shwayder Brothers, luggage manufacturer, joined yesterday in introducing what they called the first mass-produced consumer product made of Dow's magnesium. The light, strong metal was restricted to military use not very long ago.
BOSTON, Thursday, Jan. 20 -- Hope developed late last night for an end to the two-day siege at the Massachusetts State Prison.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Administration efforts to avoid public controversies over conflicting security risk decisions were disclosed today by President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A comprehensive inquiry into the "development, growth and state" of the atomic energy industry will be undertaken by the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.
Employes of downtown financial and investment concerns are scheduled to give blood today to the Red Cross in Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets.

The printing industry in New York City is worried about the prospect of price increases by paper mills. The mills make various papers used by advertising typographers and others in the field. Newsprint mills are not involved in the contemplated rises.
I should like to point out two misstatements in the letter by Dr. Tulio Franco Franco, Dominican representative to the United Nations, in The New York Times of Jan. 15.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower said today he would like to see the United Nations try to work out a cease-fire in the Strait of Formosa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A two-price support plan for wheat, designed to give growers full parity for wheat sold for food in this country, was proposed today by Representative Clifford R. Hope, Republican of Kansas.
A pair of gloves, two shoehorns and a stuffed armadillo brought $10 yesterday as 125 eager bidders competed for a variety of imported goods ranging from a mink stole to foreign postage stamps.

Plans for financing the new Capital Court shopping center of the Ed. Schuster Co., Inc., department store enterprise at Milwaukee, Wis., were announced yesterday by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Robert W. Baird Co., Inc., investment bankers.

Improved living standards at home are keeping many migratory birds away from their usual winter resorts. This was reported yesterday as the National Audubon Society began to tabulate the results of its fifty-fifth annual bird count.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Mathew H. McCloskey, wealthy Philadelphia contractor, was elected unanimously today treasurer of the Democratic National Committee.

THE Symphony of the Air, formerly the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, proved that it was quite an ensemble several months ago when it gave a concert without a conductor. It played another concert at Carnegie Hall last night, this time with a conductor, Leonard Bernstein. It is still a magnificent orchestra, and Mr. Bernstein reminded us that he can be a brilliant conductor.

The President's press conference yesterday produced evidence that the much publicized Ladejinsky case has had at least one desirable result. A unit of the Department of Justice has been set up which will handle controversies between different agencies regarding security evaluations of particular individuals, and, where necessary, particularly difficult cases will be brought to President Eisenhower himself for decision.
TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner is studying a report that details the accomplishments of the bi-state Waterfront Commission and includes recommendations for improving its efficiency.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Motor Vehicles Bureau said today that the fee in upstate New York for auto inspection required by a new state law will be $2 or less.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 12:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for the period Nov. 28 to Jan. 1 averaged 32,070 bales for each working day. This compared with 32,902 bales for the corresponding period a year earlier and 36,087 a month earlier.
CHICAGO Jan. 19 (AP)--Producers again cut shipments of hogs to market today and prices showed a minor response. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

BONN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- The Western powers were reported today to be preparing to ask the Soviet Government whether it would participate in a four-power conference to reunify Germany after ratification of the Paris agreements.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Stabilizer fins are to be fitted to the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth at a cost of about 250,000 ($700,000). The work will start after the liner gets into Southampton tomorrow from New York.

TORONTO, Jan. 19 (UP) -- John McCormack, rated among hockey's top defensemen, scored one of his infrequent goals early in the third period tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 3-3 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.

Millions of persons from California to New England witnessed President Eisenhower's press conference last night as four television networks presented filmed excerpts of the White House question-and-answer period.

A syndicate headed by Estabrook Co. will place on the market today $9,200,000 of new securities of the Northeastern Steel Corporation, formed last month to expand steel production in New England to meet the needs of the area.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Legislation that would bar the manufacture, distribution, transportation or sale of realistic toy pistols was introduced in the Legislature today at the request of the Wagner Administration.
NEWARK, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A commuter representative strongly criticized today the Interstate Commerce Commission for approving a 10 per cent commutation fare rise for six railroads serving New Jersey.

Operations of Continental Motors Corporation and consolidated subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 resulted in a net profit of $4,542,748, equal to $1.38 a share, it was anonunced yesterday by C. J. Reese, president.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The deep hat, worn to the back, predominates in the showings of spring hat collections here. But, in contrast to the head-fitting designs of this winter, these tend to be smaller and brighter in color.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A new civil rights drive is taking form in the Senate.

Gross operating income of the Sinclair Oil Corporation.and its subsidiaries for 1954 exceeded $1,000,000,000 for the first time in the company's history, P. C. Spencer, president, reported at the regular board meeting here yesterday.

George C. Textor, who joined the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York in 1916 as an office boy, was elected president of the bank at the annual meeting yesterday. He had been an officer since 1927 and executive vice president since 1950.

Stocks rose in the early trading yesterday and pushed almost to the best levels of the week on President Eisenhower's optimistic statements, but then fell back in the final hour. The result was a small net gain on the day.
The number of cargo-ship conferences that have announced plans to increase ocean freight rates was swelled to twelve yesterday as two more associations joined the ranks.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A United States team of professional golfers turned back the challenge of Canada in the Hopkins International Trophy series today. The host squad triumphed by a score of 17 points to 10. The victory was the fourth straight for the United States in the annual tournament.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- The 53,000-ton American liner United States docked here twenty-four hours late today after weathering hurricane winds with the aid of protective, burned-on coatings on her bows and rudder.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- In history's first test of its kind, two doctors in different cities concurred via color television today in diagnosing a breast cancer in a woman.
Murder came back to the waterfront yesterday in the second week of the "new era" of port peace.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 -The California State Supreme Court has ruled an employer may discharge workers on the ground of communism even if they presumably are protected by union contracts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Eisenhower dug up one of his campaign speeches today to indicate that his progress toward balancing the budget was consistent with his pledges as a candidate.
Although it was part of the National Motor Boat Show week excitement, yesterday's big event did not take place in the enormous Kingsbridge Armory.
PANAMA, Jan. 19 -- The Government is determined to sign as quickly as possible the new Panama Canal treaty negotiated with the United States by President Jose Antonio Remon before his assassination.

The aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange -- stocks borrowed and sold for later replacement in the hope that the new price will be lower -- fell 248,367 shares between Dec. 15 and Jan. 14, the Exchange reported yesterday.
GROTON, Conn., Jan. 19 (UP) -- The atomic-powered submarine Nautilus has completed successfully her surface trials and will put to sea tomorrow for her first underwater operations.
CAIRO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Aristotle Onassis, one-time immigrant boy whose oil tanker deal with Saudi Arabia is being contested by the world's biggest oil companies, flew to Cairo today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The comeback campaign of Ray Robinson, the former middleweight champion, faltered tonight. Ralph (Tiger) Jones, beaten twelve times in forty-seven pro fights, punched out a ten-round decision over Sugar Ray in the Chicago Stadium.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- Substantial production gains in Soviet industry in 1954, including some surprising figures for consumer goods, were announced here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Legislative measures were introduced in the House today to make General of the Army Douglas MacArthur "General of the Armies of the United States."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 20 (UP) -- United Auto Workers today voted overwhelmingly authorization to strike against the Studebaker-Packard Corporation plant here over grievances on production schedules, union officials said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 644,940 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 42,737 cars, or 7.1 per cent more than for the preceding week; 25,069 ears, or 4 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 60,077 cars, or 8.5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
Mayor Wagner was accused yesterday of backing away from a 1953 campaign promise to support a city bill to create an independent Commission on Intergroup Relations.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 20 -- The Swedish Federation of Labor is up in arms against the labor-dominated Government over anti-inflation measures as they affect trade union demands for higher wages.

Potato prices opened stronger yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. There was speculator purchasing, short covering and buying by local dealers. Trading was influenced by the lack of delivery notices and the Government stock-on-hand report which showed a decline in Maine supplies.
A proposed interstate compact to deal with the growing number of juvenile delinquents is being prepared for submission to various state legislatures this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The General Motors Corporation invited its stockholders today to share in its faith in an expanding market.
The New York Philharmonic has canceled its plans for a European tour next September because of a dispute with the Musicians Union over rehearsals.

Complete playing dates for the sixteen-week repertory of three English plays, starring Maurice Schwartz, have been set by the Russel-Farrow Productions, in association with Cy Metric, sponsors of the venture.
The Urban League of Greater New York moved again yesterday to defend the working rights of Negro longshoremen.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 -- Newspapers are giving much space this week to draw a contrast between the alleged attitudes of the Soviet Union and the United States toward the use of atomic energy for peaceful purposes.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 21 -- The United States, Britain and New Zealand have been holding talks for some months at the United Nations in New York on chances of a cease-fire along the China coast, it was confirmed here today.

Green peppers are a bright, cheerful note on winter vegetable stands -- and a good buy, to boot. A pound costs 19 cents in most markets this week, according to the City Department of Markets. Last year at this time the price was 39 cents a pound, and the year before it was 29 cents.
YONKERS, Jan. 20 -- The Otis Elevator Company offered to its employes' union today its terms for the company to continue operations here.
Uncle Sam's letter carriers can gird themselves for another heavy task. The General Motors Corporation is preparing to mail an important document to each of its 460,000 owners early next month.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Mickey Wright of San Diego took a two-stroke lead after eighteen holes of the Tampa Women's Open Golf Tournament with a 74.
The Board of Education decided yesterday on its budget request for 1955-56. The request -- for a total outlay of $314,449,116 for operating expenses -- will now be sent to the Budget Director.
LEEDS, England, Jan. 20 -- The Labor party here in the bustling, prosperous north is confident it will turn the Conservatives out at the next general election.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Jim Weatherall, former All-America tackle at Oklahoma who played last season in Canada with the Edmonton Eskimos, was signed today by the Philadelphia Eagles.
The Duquesne Light Company sold to underwriters yesterday $8,000,000 of new preferred stock to finance new construction projects, including the nuclear power plant at Shippingport, Pa.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Governor Harriman urged today that state rent controls be tightened and extended for two more years. He presented his proposals in a special message to the Legislature.

The Finewool Merchandise Company in a purchase for occupancy has acquired the four-story store and loft building at 84 Franklin Street from the Wyco Sales Company. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker in the transaction.
ROME, Jan. 20 -- The "Light Touch" is the name Aurora Battilocchi, the first of the Roman couturiers to open, gives her collection.

Stiff breezes made the cold seem colder yesterday as forty-five-mile-an-hour gusts whipped the city and neighboring areas. Temperatures ranged from 20.5 degrees at 7:30 A. M. to a high of 32 at 2:40 P. M. These were not unusual for the season and heavily bundled men and women who noticed the thermometers wondered if their discomfort were not more in their minds than in the mercury.
The centennial of the publication of Walt Whitman's "Leaves of Grass" was marked last night at the forty-fifth annual dinner of the Poetry Society of America.

ONCE upon a time Sugar Ray Robinson was a thing of beauty in the ring. That's rather incongruous verbiage to be using in describing a prizefighter. But Sugar Ray was no ordinary prizefighter. He was an artist at his trade, a master craftsman. He could outbox the boxers and outpunch the punchers. He had blinding speed of hands, feet and brain. Watching him work was sheer delight.

The General Foods Corporation achieved in the nine months ended Dec. 31, a record in sales and earnings for any similar three-quarter period, according to the report of Charles G. Mortimer, president. The report was issued for publication today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Jose Ferrer, who recently acquired rights from John Huston for Barnaby Conrad's "Matador," will co-produce, direct and star in the film under a three company deal completed today.

The All America, trouble-shooting cable ship of the All America Cables and Radio, Inc., is back in port after five years of patrolling in the Caribbean and off the west coast of South America. The 1,819-ton yacht-like vessel is undergoing extensive repair and refurbishing in the Todd Shipyards Corporation yard in Hoboken, N. J. In six weeks she will head to sea again on one of the loneliest assignments in the maritime field.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Jan. 20 (UP) -- A New York University instructor and a New Jersey housewife were found dead today in an auto parked in Glenerie State Park near here.

Industrial Commissioner Lubin performs a useful service in directing public attention to the high standards of probity and achievement maintained by many union welfare funds. It is too easy to forget their number in the revulsion that attends exposure of kickbacks, graft and maladministration in some highly publicized funds.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 20 -- (UP) -- History Book, a 4-1 shot, outsprinted his opposition today to gain a nose victory over Correspondent in the $7,500 Lions Club Handicap at Santa Anita.

BERLIN, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A United States soldier was released by the Russians today after six years' captivity. He was in such poor shape the Army ordered hospital care first rather than the usual interrogation.

Stated positively or negatively, it turns up time and again. It turned up the other day in a report of a survey made by the placement department at Northwestern University. The survey disclosed such good news as the prospect of higher starting salaries this year than last for both technical and nontechnical graduates and the near-doubling of the starting salaries of graduates who were hired by industry five years ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 20 -- The left-wing International Fur and Leather Workers Union was urged late today to approve a proposed merger agreement. Under the plan the 75,000 fur workers would join the 265,000-member Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America, A. F. L.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations established contact today with several other members of the Security Council on the prospects for a resolution calling for a cease-fire in the Formosa Strait.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the appointment of three City Magistrates to fill vacancies.

The performance of "Silk Stockings" on the night of April 27 at the Imperial Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Neighborhood Children's Center. The benefit, planned previously for Feb. 7, was changed because of the postponement of the production's opening.
Your recent editorial "Traffic Congestion in 1955" sets forth several interesting and constructive suggestions.
Wednesday was not the first time that President Eisenhower had faced television and newsreel cameras, but it was the first time that he had ever done it at a regular Presidential press conference.
Directors of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad declared a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock yesterday, payable on March 14 to holders of record of Feb. 11.
The Soviet economy turned in a mixed performance last year with many disappointing as well as bright features, the latest Soviet Government economic report indicates.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Friday, Jan. 21 -- Nationalist planes attacked Red ships swarming around the imperiled Tachen Islands yesterday, sinking at least forty-four craft, including nine gunboats, the Defense Ministry reported.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower prescribed for the American economy today treatment to promote long-term growth rather than hypodermic shots in the arm.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson will spend the next ten days pondering whether he should quit his comeback attempt after his decisive defeat by Ralph (Tiger) Jones at the Chicago Stadium last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $104,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
BOSTON, Friday, Jan. 21 -- Four embittered convicts continued early today their defiance of authority from an isolated cell bock at the Massachusetts State Prison.

Mr. Cantelli, before his collapse, was able to present in its completeness his interpretation of the Brahms Third Symphony, upon which he evidently expended the greatest care and sympathetic comprehension.
A demonstration of safety items built into Chrysler automobiles was staged yesterday at the corporation's international salon at Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street.
Katie C. Horan was 100 years old yesterday and a host of friends crowded the parlor of the Mary Manning Walsh Home to help her over the century mark.
MIAMI, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Dave Singer's Hangover, a 13-1 shot, launched his winter campaign with a triumph in the Driftwood Purse at Hialeah Park before 18,137 fans today.

In submitting his annual Economic Report to Congress yesterday the President sent with it the customary message, concluding with thirty-three specific legislative proposals. The message was more than a covering letter; it was an attempt to present the highlights of the report, "largely in the words of the report itself."

The role of religion in building family security and sound standards for the young is the theme of a new play, "Point of Beginning," presented yesterday at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South.

PORT ARTHUR, Tex., Jan. 20 -- The Gulf Oil Corporation announced today that it will undertake a multimillion-dollar expansion program at its refinery here. The corporation did not disclose how much the program will cost, but industrial sources indicated that it may exceed $25,000,000.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 20 -- The Cabinet decided tonight to establish a state of siege throughout the country as a result of an uprising earlier in the day. Civil rights were restricted and press censorship was established.
BOSTON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Leo LaBine's goal in the third period gave the Boston Bruins a come-from-behind 3-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings before a Boston Garden crowd of 7,715 tonight.

ROME, Jan. 20 -- Artists demonstrated today against commercialism, movies, motor traffic and noise but were routed by the police. The scene was the picturesque Via Margutta in the heart of Rome's Bohemian quarter off the Piazza di Spagna or Spanish Square.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Department store sales in the United States last week were 16 per cent above sales in the similar 1954 week, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Governor Harriman said last night in Brooklyn that President Eisenhower's annual Economic report to Congress made little mention of moral and spiritual values.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- A 61-year-old clergyman in the State Senate reopened his campaign today for a state inquiry into whether New York divorce laws should be changed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower walked into a top secret meeting today and found a secret he did not expect. It was a surprise arranged by his Cabinet, the National Security Council and his staff.
Thirty-six thousand visitors flocked to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday for the opening session of the $2,000,000 General Motors Motorama.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Norway's movie houses today announced a nation-wide boycott of movies produced by Warner Brothers after the American company had asked more money for the showing of two "super films."
CAIRO, Jan. 20 -- The Premiers of four Arab states are scheduled to arrive here tomorrow to sit with Egypt in judgment on Iraq for going outside the Arab League to sign a defense pact with Turkey.
