Dr. Frederick Kettner, founder of the Biosophical Institute, has a new book scheduled for Feb. 4 publication by Vantage Press. Entitled "Biosophy and Spiritual Democracy," the volume presents Dr. Kettner's philosophy of spiritual awareness and world peace.

The constant narrowing of the demarcation between traditional and modern decors is forcefully pointed up in a series of newly furnished rooms at Macy's. This continuing trend is particularly evident in five rooms that have been labeled "traditional" by the store and in which are arranged pieces from a new group introduced under the name of "Trans Orient."
SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 20 -- Vietnamese, French and United States officials have agreed on the reorganization of the Vietnamese national army, it was announced today.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Premier Pierre Mendes - France announced tonight the reorganization of his Cabinet. The principal change will be that he will turn over the Foreign Ministry to Edgar Faure, the present Minister of Finance.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 20 -- The issue involved in the strike vote was what union officials termed "the company's violation of article seventeen of the company-union contract." This article, which was added to the contract last Aug. 9, has to do with production standards.

The National Urban League received yesterday a $7,500 grant from the Philip Murray Memorial Foundation. The gift is to assist the league in starting its Southern industry project to increase industrial employment of Negroes.

The American Steel Foundries has acquired all the outstanding stock of the Pipe Line Service Corporation of Franklin Park, Ill., for an undisclosed sum, according to Charles C. Jarchow, president of A. S. F. Pipe Line coats and wraps steel pipe to prolong its life, particularly when installed underground.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Representative Noah M. Mason, Republican of Illinois, today attacked extension of the Reciprocal Trade agreements Act.
Plenty of skiing from Belleayre Mountain in the central Catskills all the way to the Laurentians of Canada -- that was the picture yesterday as metropolitan devotees made plans for week-end junkets.

GENEVA, Jan. 20 -- There is an urgent need to examine the effects of radiation from nuclear reactors on the public health of communities in which they are situated, the World Health Organization said today.

Dr. Carlos Davila of Chile, secretary-general of the Organization of American States, was openly rebuked yesterday by the Rev. Benjamin Nunez, permanent Costa Rican representative to the United Nations. Father Nunez refused to take lightly a reference by Dr. Davila to the duel to which President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua challenged President Jose Figueres of Costa Rica Jan. 12. Dr. Davila addressed a luncheon of the Overseas Press Club at 35 East Thirty-ninth Street.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 20 -- After two years as a private citizen, former President Truman said today he did not think anything could ever happen in the United States to send the nation into a permanent decline.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway will be retained as Army Chief of Staff after he reaches the statutory retirement age in March.
NEWARK, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Four New Jersey athletes were honored tonight at the Newark Athletic Club's fifteenth annual all-sports awards dinner.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Town Hall, 5:30; and "Vittorio" and "Salome," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15.

Yellow, the color that has scored such success in many spring fashions, has left its mark on bridal designs, too. Yesterday, in Gimbels' showing of wedding attire, it was interesting to note that yellow had risen to top place in color for attendants.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee announced today it would study the nomination of John Marshall Harlan of New York to the Supreme Court.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Governor Harriman today appointed Edward T. Dickinson of Syracuse as Commissioner of Commerce.
LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Jan. 19 -- The fabulous tale of Baron Munchausen, in which the snow was so deep he hitched his horse to a church steeple, has almost come true here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Hogs dropped 25 to 50 cents on all weights in the livestock market today, reflecting salable receipts of 16,000 head. Trading was slow at the start but offerings were actively taken at the price decline.

The State of Louisiana announced yesterday plans to borrow $10,000,000 through the sale of bonds to finance payment of cash bonuses to veterans of the Korean War. Bids on the bonds will be received on March 3.
An "all out" drive to restore football at Fordham was launched last night by a special committee of the university's alumni association.
A 15-year-old girl and an 18-year-old boy were found guilty last night of the hammer-knife murder of the girl's mother last March 4.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- Dr. B. H. Bhabha, head of India's Atomic Energy Commission, said today that even the United States, which leads in atomic research, stood to gain from a fuller sharing of scientific data.

Our City Council, which never behaves so foolishly as when it is engaged in foolish business, has voted 23 to 2 to rename two blocks of Leggett Avenue in the Bronx. The new name would be Jaburg, in honor of the president of R. C. Williams Co., Inc., wholesale grocers, who were unhappy on a street named Leggett because one of their competitors, situated well downtown in Manhattan, is named Leggett.

THERE was good news at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for admirers of Italian opera and especially of Italian tenors. Giuseppe Campora, a young man from Italy, joined the company, singing Rodolfo in "La Boheme," and you may be sure that he will be around for a long time, Mr. Campora has a voice, and he can sing.
The editorial entitled "Jenkins Bill: Fourth Try" contained in your Jan. 12 issue represents a very dangerous over-simplification of a complex issue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is on the White House social blacklist.

Yesterday was an anniversary for Ex-President Truman as well as for President Eisenhower. For President Eisenhower it was a brief breathing space half way through his term of office. Tribulations and achievements lay behind him. Troubles and possible achievements lay ahead.
THE latest report from the British West Indies indicates that Jamaica, too often ignored by the winter-dodging angler, is making a strong bid for the blue-marlin specialist.

SOMEWHERE a few degrees south of the Equator and not very far north of Australia lies the imaginary island of New Brabant, which much resembles New Guinea with a dash or two of Borneo thrown in for seasoning. On the north coast is the Sultanate of Namua, a kingdom the size of Portugal.
Twenty-five thousand employes of the Consolidated Edison System will receive a "package" pay and pension increase of 8.8 cents an hour under a new wage agreement.
PARIS, Jan. 20 -- The Rhone River, fed by heavy rains in the valley most of the day, constituted the most serious threat tonight to flood-ridden France.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, who attended his mother's funeral only ten days ago, was taken from the Cuyahoga County jail again today for the funeral of his father.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 20 (UP) -- The nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus made her first test dive today and stayed submerged for an hour, the Navy announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Treasury's year-end statement, issued today, showed that the Government had closed its books Dec. 31 with a $9,294,000,000 deficit.
CAIRO, Jan. 19 -- The political and bureaucratic storms that have beset the funerary ship of Cheops have not abated.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Democratic legislators saw a good chance today that Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner of New York City could reach a compromise on the division of pari-mutuel revenue that formerly went to the city.

The Amerotron Corporation, sales and management company for the American Woolen Company, Textron Incorporated and Robbins Mills, Inc., opened yesterday a two-day trade showing of fabrics for the three companies in the Plaza Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Mrs. Agnes Meyer charged tonight that a rising "anti-intellectualism" in this country was driving brains out of Government.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Jan. 20 -- Britain's decision to prepare three airfields in north Malaya for jet aircraft operations is considered in informed quarters here as important in strengthening Southeast Asian defenses.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Following are excerpts from President Eisenhower's Economic Report sent to Congress today:

A method of removing the gray or yellow discoloration that develop in white nylon slips after long usage has been devised by duPont. It is said to have proved satisfactory on more than 80 per cent of garments tested.
Rules designed to cut down fumes from gasoline buses in the city were approved yesterday by the Board of Air Pollution Control.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The strategists of the Democratic party are fully aware of the political potential for the Republicans in bringing the President's news conferences directly to the eyes and ears of a national audience. But they are appraising this new situation with philosophic calm.
Declining a token royalty of $500, Sir Winston Churchill has granted formal permission to the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network to dramatize a little known incident in his youth.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 20 -- (AP) -- Beau Jack, the former lightweight champion, scored an unspectacular ten-round unanimous decision over Eddie Green of Kannapolis, N. C., tonight. The bout was Jack's first in his attempt at a comeback. Jack weighed 147 pounds, Green 159.
Initial measures to carry out a power and resources development project in Colombia -- it would be modeled after the Tennessee Valley Authority system -- were announced here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The House of Representatives' Committee on Un-American Activities voted today to cut down its expense account.
Because of an unusual situation in Pantepec Oil Company's American shares, the aggregate short position of the American Stock Exchange rose between Dec. 15 and Jan. 14.
The Budd Company, one of the country's leading makers of automotive parts and railway passenger cars, made its bid yesterday for an entirely different kind of business.
The human aleatory urge, as expressed by playing bingo under wholesome conditions, received strong support yesterday.
The waterfront's code of silence frustrated the police yesterday in their search for the slayer of Walter C. Smith, roving organizer for the crime-ridden International Longshoremen's Association.
The tube division Of the Radio Corporation of America is planning a year-long consumer-media advertising campaign to tell television set owners of the tubes it makes for replacement purposes.

New York Stock Exchange activity dwindled yesterday to 2,210,000 shares, the lowest level since Nov. 1. It compared with 2,760,000 on Wednesday. Each trading session since Monday has shown a drop in turnover.

Today's new film is "Six Bridges to Cross," a Universal-International melodrama with Tony Curtis, Julia Adams and George Nader, at the Palace. Aaron Rosenberg produced and Joseph Pevney directed from a screen play by Sydney Boehm, based on a story by Joseph F. Dinneen. J. C. Flippen, Sal Mineo and Jan Merlin head the supporting cast.

PANAMA, Jan. 20 -- The charges against former President Jose Ramon Guizado, accused of complicity in the murder of his predecessor, Col. Jose Antonio Remon, are expected to be ready for presentation tomorrow.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan 20 -- President Jose Figueres made it clear today that he would intensify his efforts for sanctions against Nicaragua by the Organization of American States.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 20 -- A special Cabinet meeting was held today to consider the effects of the nationwide agitation of the Social Democrats and trade unions against rearmament and the industrial managers of the Ruhr.

The Yankees yesterday brought their twentieth player into the fold for the 1955 season. He was Bill Skowron, whose signed contract arrived from Austin, Minn., where the husky youngster is spending the winter as a plumber's helper.

Election of Alfred P. Frame and Charles S. Mitchell as directors of the Cities Service Company was announced yesterday by W. Alton Jones, chairman. They fill vacancies on the board left by the resignations of Herbert R. Straight and E. H. Johnston, both retired.
Robert J. Bernard, formerly with the Cross Brown Company, has joined the sales department of the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Organization of American States investigating commission in Central America said in a preliminary report today it could find no evidence that Costa Rican P-51's violated the Nicaraguan border yesterday.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 20 -- The Chinese Nationalists are profoundly disappointed and resentful over the United States suggestion that the United Nations seek a cease-fire along the southeast China coast.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt of Houston carded seven straight birdies, shot a 7-under-par 29 for the first nine and finished with a 64 today to take the lead in the first round of the $15,000 San Diego open golf tournament.
Arguing that a popular sport must be a safe sport, the newly organized American Boat and Yacht Council is building its program on safety.

The agreement through which Niles-Bement-Pond Company would acquire a major interest in the Bell Aircraft Company was termed yesterday a "most important and constructive forward step" by C. W. Deeds, chairman of Niles.
Loans to business by major New York banks declined $41,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower is understood to be contemplating a request to Congress, under certain possible circumstances, for authority to intervene militarily to defend Formosa.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 20 -- Nicaragua and Costa Rica have accepted an Organization of American States' plan to establish land and air buffer zones along the northwestern Costa Rican border.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Department of Justice asked today that the Government be permitted to recover damages sustained as a result of anti-trust law violations.

The following dispatch was written by John Abney, United Press picture bureau manager in Mexico City, who was captured by rebel forces in the Costa Rican fighting. He arrived in Managua, Nicaragua, Wednesday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20 -- Yugoslavia's Acting President restated tonight the regime's firm opposition to a multiparty political system, coupling it with "state bureaucratic despotism."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The growing popularity of private pension plans may be affecting the structure of the national economy.

The most decisive endorsement thus far of the Western European Union has been provided by Belgium, whose lower house of Parliament yesterday approved the Paris pacts by a vote of 181 to 9, with only two abstentions. This is a vote equaled only by Norway and a few smaller countries dealing with the expansion of the North Atlantic alliance alone.

The best response for American industries to increased foreign competition is further application of advanced techniques, rather than protective tariffs, a management consultant executive declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Senator William F. Knowland today voiced a less uncompromising attitude on the issue of United States service men imprisoned in Communist China.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics are gone -- bag and baggage. Two moving vans donated by a Kansas City company carted the last reminders of the Athletics from Connie Mack Stadium today.

The forty-two-family apartment house at 1110 Anderson Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Enkells Rakoff, operators, to an investing client of Farber-Wittman, Inc., brokers. The buyer paid cash over mortgages of $167,000.
PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 20 -- Robert P. Tristram Coffin, Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, collapsed tonight at a speaking engagement and died at a hospital.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Eisenhower set 1956 today as the definite target for a "general, though modest" tax cut.

When Louise King assumes the leading feminine role in "The Seven Year Itch" Monday evening, the most heartfelt encouragement for her should be coming from a theatre party including several top United Nations officials.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) -- Steel headed the list of items which made 1954 a record year for British exports, the Board of Trade announced today.

On Jan. 12 your paper reported that "a private memorandum" had been circulated by the Democratic National Committee questioning the wisdom of Senate ratification of the Mutual Defense Treaty between the United States and the Republic of China.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- In Moscow's first comment on the travel restrictions imposed on Soviet citizens in the United States Pravda declared today that "the real restrictions on American citizens wishing to visit the Soviet Union arise in America itself."
A five-month undercover investigation reached a climax yesterday with the arrest of a hundred narcotics peddlers in four Eastern cities.
The "when issued" market for debentures of the projected textile company Textron American, Inc., has been withdrawn pending clarification of its legal, aspects, it was learned yesterday.
ATHENS, Jan. 20 -- "Porgy and Bess" brought laughter and tears to sophisticated Athenians tonight at the Royal Theatre, which was packed to capacity.

Charles R. Benson, a 39-year-old Army veteran, survived a plunge from the eighth floor of the Veterans Administration building at 252 Seventh Avenue yesterday morning. He landed on top of a car parked in Seventh Avenue between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Streets.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- Traffic in Westchester is entering an era of bottlenecks.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- One step ahead of next week's London dress shows, H. and M. Rayne presented today their spring and summer shoe collection.

Reports from Vietnam are not uniform in trend or significance. There is enough bad news to make any thoughtful person apprehensive. There is enough good news to make sanguine persons hopeful. The situation is obviously fluid and the tone of the news is a matter of emphasis rather than of fact.
Records for production and consumption of newsprint were set last year in the United States and Canada, according to reports issued yesterday by two trade organizations.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 20 -- Representative Herbert Bonner of North Carolina, chairman of the House Merchant Marine Committee, said today that his committee would take a close look at the Administration's tanker trade-in and building program. Mr. Bonner said further that the committee would set up a special study on the situation. This will be operated by expert outside consultants.
Thomas Schippers, 24-year-old American conductor, will make his debut at the Metropolitan Opera next season, Rudolf Bing, general manager, announced yesterday.
The Government has put up four of its thirty-five new, fast Mariner-type cargo ships for sale to American owners.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Dean Geary F. Eppley said today investigation shows no case of anyone on the University of Maryland athletic staff ever violating Atlantic Coast Conference or National Collegiate Athletic Association rules on recruiting athletes.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, paced by Maurice Richard's twenty-third hat trick, moved back into a first-place tie in the National Hockey League tonight with a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Attorneys for Louis E. Wolfson today asserted that the method of electing Montgomery Ward Co. directors violates the Illinois Constitution.
Guido Cantelli, young guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, collapsed during the mid-concert intermission at Carnegie Hall last night, apparently as the result of a virus infection.
A combination turbine-and-propeller power plant that will allow the present transports to fly fifteen to eighty-five miles an hour faster is now available.

The Army recruiting center at 39 Whitehall Street will be open tomorrow from 8:30 A. M. to noon to accommodate January high school graduates who wish to enlist before Jan. 31 to be eligible for benefits provided by the Veterans Readjustment Assistance Act of 1952. This special service will be available on the suggestion of the Board of Education.
THE old Wesley Oak under which Methodism's founder preached in Georgia two centuries ago is up in this region now in the form of a dozen ten-foot beams.

Better use of manpower will mean that sixty-two of every 100 men in the Army will be available for combat duty by June, Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens forecast here yesterday. He compared the figure with 43 per cent at the end of World War II, and 53 per cent in mid-1953.

CAIRO, Jan. 20 -- Major oil companies have begun a boycott against the oil tanker fleet of Aristotle Onassis, Greek-born Argentine shipping magnate. They hope to force the modification of his allegedly monopolistic oil shipping contract with the Saudi Arabian government.

The first units of a fleet of 300 new fifty-ton refrigerator railroad cars will start skimming along the rails for the Railway Express Agency, Inc., late in the second quarter of this year. The purchase of the new equipment was announced yesterday by A. L. Hammell, president of the nation-wide transportation company.
The Transit Authority abandoned plans yesterday for drastic cuts in Brooklyn bus and trolley operations that were to have saved $3,500,000 a year.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Following is the text of Governor Harriman's special message on rent control sent to the Legislature today:

A seldom-performed but fascinating work, Beethoven's Fantasy for Piano, Chorus and Orchestra, was performed by Margaret Hillis and the New York Concert Choir and Orchestra at Town Hall last evening. Ania Dorfmann was piano soloist.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Today's outbreak apparently was the biggest blow attempted against Castillo Armas' Government since the then irregulars drove out the Red-supported Government of President Arbenz last June.
A grand jury inquiry touched off when a prisoner walked out of City Prison posing as another inmate resulted yesterday in criminal charges against seven licensed bondsmen and an unlicensed agent.

A tract of 177 acres on New Hauppauge-Nescoset. Road and Town Line Road in Smithtown, L. I., has been purchased by a group headed by Harry Leibowitz. The new owners plan to develop the property with 525 dwellings in the medium price class.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The Commonwealth Edison Company announced today two major developments in its program to divest itself of its subsidiary, the Northern Illinois Gas Company.

Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain won the commendation of Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh yesterday for his campaign against littering through the imposition of stiffer fines on offenders.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Navy received a patent this week for a method of decoying fish by appealing to their sense of smell.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad today approved a 3-for-1 split of the line's common stock by an 85.5 per cent majority vote.

A possibility still exists that the New York Philharmonic Symphony may make its projected European tour this summer if mediators can compose differences between the orchestra's management and Local 802 of the Musicians Union.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 21 (AP) -- West German exports reached a new monthly high in December, the Federal Statistics Office announced today.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 21 -- The West German Cabinet met again today to discuss the situation created by the struggle of the Social Democratic party and trade unions against the Paris agreements.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, in Antarctica, Jan. 17 -- A section of the Antarctic icecap as large as Long Island has broken off and floated north, possibly in one piece, according to a survey completed today by this ship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Prof. I. I. Rabi, United States physicist, charged today that Moscow was making "political propaganda" of a scientific committee planning for the "atoms for peace" conference to be held in Geneva next summer.
The Giants and Dodgers put on a splurge of activity yesterday to give further indication another baseball campaign is not far away.

Governor Harriman has refused to name a special prosecutor for the trial of Michael Garcia, who stunned a Queens murder trial last December when he tossed two coins at an assistant district attorney, shouting "I'm no Judas."
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 21 -- Officials of Local 5, the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., today demanded meetings with "top management" of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation.
SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today it would begin a series of tests at the southern Navada Proving Grounds next month.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 21 -- A strike set for tomorrow against Connecticut's two largest bus companies was canceled today when the union and management agreed to arbitration.
Stocks started slowly yesterday but rose steadily and closed at the best price levels of the week.
NEWARK, Jan. 21 -- An additional 400,000 telephone patrons in Essex, Hudson and Union Counties will be able to dial New York directly starting at 7 A. M. tomorrow.

The annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Yorkville Community Association held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza attracted a representative gathering of members of society. Red and white flowers were used in the decorations.
The Shipping employers of the port have filed criticisms of the new longshore-hiring regulations with the Waterfront Commission and have asked the bi-state agency for a conference on the rules.

Louis and Edward Schuchman have sold the five-story apartment house at 883 Boulevard East in Weehawken, N. J., to the Estree Realty Company, represented by A. Zorn, attorney, in a transaction negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.
Four concerts devoted to music by Pulitzer Prize winners will be given in Carnegie Hall by the Symphony of the Air, the former N. B. C. Symphony.

DETROIT, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The nation's auto factories will assemble 163,266 passenger cars this week, the second highest car volume in history, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. It added that "but for the lack of major components at Chrysler Corporation, this week's volume would have established a new high record.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Conferences on bank robbery, designed to improve cooperation among law enforcement agencies, will be held throughout the United States this year under the auspices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
During 1954 the Federal-state program for vocational rehabilitation of the disabled "restored nearly 56,000 handicapped men and women to useful and productive lives."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The texts of a message from the Air Force to the next of kin of the fifteen United States airmen held by Red China, and a statement by Henry Suydam, State Department press officer:
CAIRO, Jan. 21 -- Arab leaders arrived here today in a mood to conciliate rather than condemn Iraq for seeking security outside the Arab League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The United States Consumers Price Index last December dipped to its lowest level since May, 1953. It also showed a drop for the entire calendar year, for the first time since 1949.
The nineteenth annual dinner of the Catholic Youth Organization of the Archdiocese of New York will be held at the Park Lane Hotel Monday night.

New York is probably the dirtiest big city in the world, outside of Asia. The time has come for the people of New York to grapple with this disgrace and to wipe it out. New York should be made, and kept, the cleanest, as well as the greatest, city in the country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Clayton A. Lowry, ousted official of the local painters union, was convicted today of extorting money from a contractor.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Department of Correction reported today that major crime increased 8.3 per cent in the state last year.

Anthony M. Livoti, one of three City Magistrates sworn in yesterday by Mayor Wagner, collapsed soon after taking his oath of office. He was revived in a few minutes. At his home, 62-56 Sixty-first Street, Ridgewood, he said he felt no ill effects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The State Department tried today to dissuade relatives from visiting American airmen imprisoned in China. However, it will allow those who insist on accepting Peiping's offer to make the trip.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Department of Justice asked Congress today to increase from $5,000 to $50,000 the maximum fine for violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Seven unofficial peacemakers walked without escort across a no-man's-land at the Massachusetts State Prison today and brought a passive end to a siege of four desperate convicts.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Irene Gilbert of Dublin treated Park Lane today to her first showing in this country.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 21 -- A former junta head today was reported arrested and exiled as the country remained quiet after the Government reported having smashed a Communist-inspired plot.

The special meeting of the American Republics Corporation held yesterday in Wilmington, Del., to act upon a proposal to settle its properties and assets and dissolve the company, was adjourned until Feb. 11. T. Rieber, chairman and president, said the adjournment was the result of a delay in obtaining an expected income-tax ruling.
A fairly dismal program of contemporary music was presented at Town Hall yesterday afternoon by the National Association for American Composers and Conductors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Defense Department sent to Congress today its own draft of a modified Universal Military Training program calling for a reserve of 5,000,000 men.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight today declared his support for President Eisenhower for renomination in 1956. However, he avoided endorsing Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

Representative B. Carroll Reece renewed his attack last night on critics of his investigation of foundations. The Tennessee Republican spoke on radio station WMCA in rebuttal to an attack on him made over the same station last Friday by its owner, Nathan Straus.
Following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente again will preside when Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke comes to trial March 7 before a blue ribbon jury on charges of compulsory prostitution.
Rabbi William F. Rosenblum marked the completion last night of twenty-five years as spiritual leader of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.
The National Motor Boat Show, which is making an indelible impression on yachting conscious Metropolitan New York, winds up its annual midwinter run tomorrow in Kingsbridge Armory, the Bronx.

WHILE he did nothing last night in Carnegie Hall to unsettle his reputation as a rising young pianist, Friedrich Gulda nevertheless did manage to raise some questions about his interpretations. He also did some things that this listener had not noticed in previous recitals by him.

While we have every sympathy with Mayor Wagner and his budget- making and tax-raising problem, his difficulties in making ends meet should not be permitted to obscure the fact that New York City's public school teachers need and deserve a salary increase.
Of the plethora of reports that the railroads must file, probably none is read more eagerly outside the industry than the car-loading statistics.

" HOMECOMING," by Jiro Osaragi, is a singularly illuminating novel about Japan in the dark backwash of war. We are undoubtedly going to have a renaissance of Japanese writing translated for Western eyes, and this subtly and skillfully blended mixture of just what you would expect and just what you would not expect makes an excellent beginning.
Underwriting activity promises to continue at only a moderate pace.
The concept of smaller regular forces supplemented by "Ready Reserves" is meaningless, unless the composition and training methods of the latter are specified.

BAHAWALPUR, Pakistan, Jan. 21 -- Chien Tuan-sheng of Red China drew the longest applause of all foreign scientists introduced today at the opening session of the six-day conference sponsored by the Pakistan Association for the Advancement of Science.

Franco Autori, associate conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony, who took over the direction of Thursday evening's Carnegie Hall concert when the guest conductor Guido Cantelli became ill, will lead the orchestra tonight and tomorrow. Nathan Milstein, violinist, will be the soloist, playing the Beethoven Concerto.

Relatives of seventeen Americans jailed in Red China were for the most part dubious about taking advantage of the invitation to visit the prisoners extended to them yesterday by the Peiping Government.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, Jan. 22 -- The evacuation of non-combatants from the Tachen Islands, including United States military advisers, nurses and civilians, has already begun, informed Chinese Nationalist sources disclosed early today.

FREDELL LACK, the violinist, played a recital of considerable distinction at Town Hall last evening. The chief and virtually the only shortcoming of Miss Lack's program was her venture into unaccompanied Bach, namely, the first two movements of the Sonata in A minor.

YONKERS, Jan. 21 -- The Otis Elevator Company's terms laid down to its employes' union for continuing operations here include revisions in bonus incentives and full latitude to transfer workers from other areas to Yonkers, a union spokesman said today.

Rare ceremonial objects from the thirteenth to the twentieth century, from the collection of the Jewish Museum, are being shown in a commemorative exhibition that opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
When you're 7 years old -- and even if you are a member of the intellectually select third grade at Hunter College Elementary School -- a yellow toy rabbit can be pretty important.

A recently completed survey on the views of Americans in regard to communism and civil liberties is being prepared for publication in book form. The survey was made under the sponsorship of the Fund for the Republic. Other viewpoints it sought were on fighting Russia, willingness to buy soap advertised by a Communist radio singer, reducing our atomic bomb production and reporting to the F.B.I. neighbors suspected of being Communists.
MIAMI, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt won his first purse of the Hialeah meeting when Outsmart accounted for the feature before 17,785 fans today.

The five-story loft building on lot 28 by 159 feet at 359 Broadway, south of Franklin Street, has been sold by the S. F. H. Realty Corporation to Mark Tennenbaum, Emil Tanner and Leo Beller, exporters and importers, who plan to occupy the major portion of the building for their textile business.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt of Houston, Tex., reached the midway mark of the $15,000 San Diego open golf tournament today with a 36-hole score of 131 and a four-stroke lead over his nearest rivals.
Half of the total research and development potential of the nation is now engaged in atomic energy and aerodynamics studies for national defense, it was estimated here last night.
THIS week's many exhibitions of painting and sculpture have little in common beyond the right of self-expression to take widely differing forms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- In the Senate measures were introduced today to encourage states to hold Presidential preference primaries and to liberalize the legal limits on Congressional and Presidential campaign spending.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed former Senator Robert C. Hendrickson of New Jersey today as Ambassador to New Zealand and former Gov. John Lodge of Connecticut as Ambassador to Spain.
Events today: Dorothy White, folk-singer, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 3 P. M.; "Un Ballo in Maschera," Metropolitan Opera, 2, and Webster Aitken, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Louise Suggs and Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias took the lead in the seventy-two-hole $5,000 Tampa women's open golf tournament today with thirty-six-hole totals of 146, four under women's par.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Chicago's campaign for industrial expansion and a large share of the nation's water-borne commerce received encouragement this week.
GROTON, Conn., Jan. 21 (UP) -- The atomic submarine Nautilus left Long Island Sound for the open sea today.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation will not sell the Capehart-Farnsworth Company, one of its divisions, Maj. Gen. William H. Harrison, president of the parent corporation, said yesterday.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 21 -- Top Chinese Nationalist officials here were silent tonight on reports from Washington that President Eisenhower was planning to ask Congress to approve use of the United States Seventh Fleet to evacuate the Nationalist garrison from the Tachen Islands.
The length of immunity and degree of protection the new Salk vaccine will confer against poliomyelitis remain unknown, research scientists concluded here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senate leaders were alerted today to expect a Presidential message on Monday asking "if-and-when" authorization for United States air and naval participation in the defense of Formosa.

Purchasing by processors, commission house covering and dealer buying touched off stop-loss ordering of cocoa futures yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The close was 67 to 88 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on 278 lots, the greatest volume of the month.

Henry G. Waltemade of the Bronx, newly elected president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, was honored yesterday at a luncheon at the Roosevelt Hotel sponsored by Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Jan. 21 -- Gen. William M. Hoge, commander of the United States Army in Europe, said here today the new strategy in Germany is not to yield any ground unless forced to if attacked.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- A strong public appeal for greater air strength in the Royal Navy was made today by Admiral of the Fleet Sir Rhoderick McGrigor, First Sea Lord.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 21 -- Two Israeli soldiers were wounded this morning in the center of the city between the Jordanian and Israeli sectors.

On Jan. 8 you published a letter from Kennedy Stevenson under the caption "Power Plan for Niagara -- Disagreement Expressed With Recent Statements by Robert Moses." You described the writer as "formerly a utilities analyst."

As the actual shooting gradually dies down in Costa Rica we are being faced with some unpleasant realities. The situation in Central America is critical. It may not be an exaggeration to say that it is steadily deteriorating, and it is at least generally true to say that the greater part of the Caribbean area is involved, directly or indirectly, in this ferment.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Chicago's "phantom philanthropist" struck again today. He walked up to a youth on a street corner and handed him $250.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, heroes of the United States' victory over Australia in the Davis Cup challenge round last month, easily won their first-round matches in the Australian tennis championship today.
Another in a long series of efforts to revivify the Shakespeare Garden in Central Park will be initiated tomorrow.

A seven-man investing group that had acquired 30 per cent of the common stock of Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., of St. Louis moved into control of the company yesterday. They were named to seven of the twelve directorships.

The people of Formosa can correct the deficiencies in their diet "easily and economically" by enriching the rice that forms their basic food, Dr. Norman Jolliffe, nutrition expert of the city's Health Department, said yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The Seine, fed by swollen tributaries and by rain that fell most of the day, flooded some sections of the Paris river front today.

Many a city animal during the year. will enjoy medical care thanks to the theatre benefit planned by the Speyer Hospital for Animals. The hospital has taken over the preview performance of "The Desperate Hours" on Feb. 9. The play, featuring Karl Malden and Paul Newman, opens Feb. 10 at the Barrymore.

THE Atlantic salmon decline, which has become increasingly apparent over the past twenty-five years, can be halted only through the cooperation of all the "special interest" groups concerned, according to the report of the Atlantic Salmon Association.

Robert P. Tristram Coffin had two great loves -- one can really call them passions -- poetry and Maine. And out of Maine he made the poetry: the bitter tang of the sea, the pungency of fir and bayberry, "the cranberries touched red by frost." "This is my country," he wrote, and nowhere in his writings is his native state long absent, either the place or the people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The former chief of Air Force Intelligence in Berlin was ordered today to show cause why he should not be dismissed from the service for associating with Irmgard Schmidt, convicted spy for the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The National Press Club decided today on a referendum of its active members on the admission of Louis R. Lautier, a Negro.
MADRAS, India, Jan. 21 -- India's Congress party has been giving itself a public and sharp scolding, with the help of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 21 -- Premier Adnan Menderes appealed to Egypt tonight to join Turkey and Iraq in forging a new Middle Eastern security system.
The store price of milk, which usually begins declining at this season, probably will hold through April.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 21 -- The Indian Government has decided to start a new strategic industry for the manufacture of synthetic fuel as a state-owned enterprise with foreign participation.
All indications point to a prosperous first quarter for home furnishings manufacturers.
Television and radio advertisers, whose "pitchmen" often have irritated home audiences, may be prosecuted for unlawful practices.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Choppy fluctuations were the rule in the grain pits today. Offerings were ample on the hard spots, while demand broadened rather automatically on the small reactions.

PANAMA, Jan. 21 -- President Ricardo Arias Espinosa called on the people of Panama tonight to concentrate on continuing what he termed the progressive work of the slain President Jose Antonio Remon, rather than cultivate vengeance in his name.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- An important new development in color television broadcasting equipment was revealed here today by the General Electric Company.
For the first time this year, the temperature yesterday dropped below 20 degrees, producing the coldest reading of the winter -- 14.8 at 7:50 A. M.
The New York State Waterways Association elected officers yesterday at its forty-fifth annual meeting.

Outside, what not long ago was a garden is a stretch of lumpy earth, turned over before the first frost, and sticking up in it here and there is a stake hopefully marking the whereabouts of a perennial or biennial.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama formally announced today plans to dissolve the lower house of the Japanese Parliament and to hold "a fair and clean election" Feb. 27.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits, a Republican, yesterday assailed the Eisenhower Administration's security clearance system as exemplified in the Wolf Ladejinsky case.

BUFFALO, N, Y., Jan. 21 (AP) -- The board of directors of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced plans last night for "the immediate construction" of what it termed the largest steam-electric generating unit in the state. The announcement was made by Earle J. Machold, president, after the board met here. Mr. Machold said the new 200,000 kilowatt unit, costing approximately $30,000,000, would be installed in the company's steam-electric station in suburban Tonawanda.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- Public tribute has been paid here to the contribution of the United States and other countries to the Soviet Union's knowledge of heart surgery. The tribute came from Alexander Bakulev, president of the Soviet Academy of Medical Science, at last night's opening session of the All-Union Congress of Surgeons in Moscow.
Net income of the Hercules Cement Corporation last year more than doubled that for 1953, according to the report of D. S. MacBride, president, issued yesterday.
Representatives of eighteen states made a tentative agreement yesterday to deal cooperatively with the growing number of juvenile delinquents who cross state lines.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania's basketball team gained its eleventh victory in thirteen games, easily defeating Army, 81 -- 61, before a crowd of 2,077 at the Palestra tonight.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Bill Stewart ended his colorful twenty-two-year career as a National League umpire in a typical dispute today. He retired in protest because he had not been promoted to supervisor of umpires.

IN her paintings at Galerie Moderne, 49 West Fifty-third Street, May Stevens keeps to subdued palette in which low blues and whitish grays predominate. Black linear elements are stressed only to define form necessarily in helping to hold the designs.

Warner Brothers has added to its properties "The Violent Land," Wayne D. Overholser's new novel about frontier days in Oregon. Henry Blanke, studio staff producer, has been elected to make the film as soon as he completes "The McConnell Story," and "Faithfully Yours."

A dispatch from Cairo in yesterday's New York Times mistakenly referred to widely publicized charges of corruption made against the Argentine-Greek tanker owner Aristotle Onassis, by his "brother-in-law and shipping rival, Stavros Niarchos."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Bureau of Indian Affairs does not know what it costs to serve lunch to Indian school children in North Carolina. But, it has let a contract with a private food service company to supply lunches at 50 cents a plate.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 1 21 -- A United Nations subcommission that has been looking into the world's discrimination problems suggested today that some discrimination was being practiced against its own membership.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty. The vote was 14 to 1.
Mayor Wagner's fiscal program for 1955-56 will be submitted to the Board of Estimate next Tuesday at a special executive meeting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A leading opponent of the bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act predicted today that it would be approved by the House, perhaps by 250 votes.
" The Passion of Gross," a new play by Harold Levitt, will have its postponed premiere tonight at 8 o'clock at the Theatre de Lys, 121 Christopher Street.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, Jan. 21 -- The army of the future was discussed here today by high-level military experts of France, Britain and the United States.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:...
Two armed thugs used a stolen taxicab to rob a woman bookkeeper yesterday morning of a $1,952 payroll. They later abandoned the vehicle with the victim bound on the floor of the cab.
The West 100th Street police station, which grew out of the wilderness with Manhattan's upper West Side, faces demolition.

Searching out ancient Nordic timber houses and encouraging the continuation of handicraft techniques dating from viking days has provided a lifetime's work for Prof. Gerda Boethius, director of the Zorn Museum in Mora, Sweden.

The five insurance companies of the America Fore Group had aggregate assets on Dec. 31 of $893,926,509, an increase of $156,720,874 for the year. Net premiums written last year totaled $278,574,994, a drop of $12,659,595.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 21 -- United States authorities in West Berlin were informed today for the second time in two weeks that the Soviet Union might be building a power plant for atomic purposes at the Vorkuta slave labor camp in Siberia.

HONOLULU, Saturday, Jan. 22 -- The Navy said early today the transport Fred C. Ainsworth had rescued all seven survivors of a twin-engined Navy amphibian forced down Wednesday night in the Central Pacific.
The City Administration yesterday reinforced the present campaign to sweep litterbugs from New York's streets.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Chinese Nationalist Air Force blasted Red gunboats and motorized junks along the coast of China yesterday.

The Tri-Continental Corporation has just observed its 25th year of operations with net investment assets up almost $60,000,000 to a new high of $236,164,000, Francis F. Randolph, chairman and president, reported yesterday.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Five ships were in distress in the storm-tossed Atlantic today. Gales of up to eighty miles an hour buffeted Bermuda for the second time in a week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Communist China has offered to open its doors to relatives of some of the detained United States prisoners of the Korean war.

Oranges, salad greens and huge sides of beef were being loaded aboard the North German Lloyd liner Berlin when we visited the ship yesterday at her West Fifty- seventh Street berth. Preparations were under way for a fifteen- day Caribbean cruise that sails today.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The divergent trend of Government funds and industrial shares was still pronounced in the stock markets today. The former suffered their sharpest setback of the week, while the latter continued to advance strongly.

Mrs. Annie Lee Moss now has a governmental job again. She would have had one right along if it had not been for the curious activities of former Chairman Joseph R. McCarthy of the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, plus an undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France was reported today to be aiming at a political settlement in Tunisia before next Wednesday, when a North African debate in the National Assembly threatens to cause his downfall.
ANNISTON, Ala., Jan. 21 (UP) -- Sixteen "officers and ladies" of the Women's Army Corps became the first commissioned graduates of the new "West Point of the Wacs," Fort McClellan, here today.

HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 21 -- The Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Texas today called for a curb on the powers of the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, of New York, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- The arrest of a number of Communists and other left-wing adherents today called attention again to one of several scandals with political overtones that have placed Italy among the most scandal-ridden countries.

Including the present Government, the Fourth French Republic has had twenty Cabinets and fourteen Premiers since its foundation at the end of the war, but, except in cases in which the Premier doubled as Foreign Minister, France has had only two fulltime Foreign Ministers -- Georges Bidault and Robert Schuman.
Thirty minutes of pumping re-floated the Panamanian freighter Lake Charles yesterday afternoon after two months on the East River bottom.

TRENTON, Jan. 21 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today appointed former Representative Edward J. Hart, Democrat of Jersey City, as a member of the State Public Utility Commission. He will replace John E. Boswell of Ocean City, a Republican whose term expires in May.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 21 -- Leaders of the Republican-controlled New Jersey Legislature, after an all-day caucus here with the state chairman of their party, decided tonight to continue their cooperation with Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat.

MIAMI, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The Air Force withdrew its crack "Thunderbirds" precision flying team from the annual Aerorama show today after the president of National Airlines said their appearance would be a "senseless extravagance."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Senator Barry M. Goldwater today defended Vice President Richard M. Nixon against what he called a Democratic "smear."
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Carmen Basilio, the No. 1 welterweight contender, gave Germany's Pete Mueller a savage body pounding tonight to win a unanimous ten-round decision.

Senator George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, said yesterday he favored the construction of a four-lane, coast-to-coast highway from Washington to San Francisco. He spoke at the sixteenth annual convention of the Private Truck Council of America at the Statler Hotel.
LIBERIA, Costa Rica, Jan. 21 -- Jubilant field commanders declared today that "the fight is over" after disclosing the fall of two key rebel-held towns to Government troops.

The seventy-eight-family apartment house at 400 East Mosholu Parkway South in the Bronx has been sold by the Park Road Realty Corporation, after an ownership of sixteen years, to Harold Shenker and Irving Spatz. The buyers paid cash over mortgages of $309,981, according to Allan S. Feldman Co., brokers in the sale.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 21 -- Governor Harriman was asked today by James D. Hopkins, County Executive of Westchester, to speed construction of the Cross Westchester Expressway.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Harmonious relations between the United States and France are likely soon to be subjected to strain. And, unfortunately, the timing may coincide with the period when Mendes-France's Government is most threatened with dissolution.

The first entertainment, a carnival, in a series known as the Goddard Gaieties was held last night at the Goddard Neighborhood Center, 599 First Avenue. Proceeds from the series, planned for young people from various private schools in the city, will further the work of the center, which maintains extensive recreational and educational programs for adults and children in a crowded district of the city.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, but the undertone was steady. Prices rose 3 to 10 points (15 to 50 cents a bale).

SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 21 -- Charges of defrauding the state of several tens of millions of piasters have been made against Pham Van Giao former Vice Premier of Vietnam, according to the official Vietnam news agency.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Thirteen men and boys and an Alaskan housewife who risked or lost their lives to save others were cited for bravery today by the Carnegie Hero Commission.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The Conservative Party has retained the Parliamentary seat for Orpington, Kent, in a by-election marked by a light turnout.
Yale's varsity swimming team will seek its 119th consecutive dual-meet victory against Springfield College in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium pool at New Haven today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, voiced today his "wholehearted endorsement" of President Eisenhower's request for $103,000,000 for ship construction in the fiscal year 1956.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, based on the 1947-49 level as 100, remained at 110.1.

A $10 Chirstmas gift from a tenant, which was refused by a landlord, was added yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The gift was among fifty-one that totaled $2,637.74 and brought the present fund to $405,880.59.
The Communist - dominated Hungarian Government lost the first phase of a legal fight yesterday to recover a $9,000 deposit on a building it had leased for a consulate.
ROME, Jan. 21 -- The three gifted Fontana sisters liken their new sleek silhouette to a Greek column, developing the idea consistently throughout their collection.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Stan (The Man) Musial joined Red Schoendienst in a $120,000 St. Louis Cardinal contract signing ceremony today, confident he can equal Honus Wagner's record of eight National League batting crowns.
PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The conference on pooling West European arms production adjourned for ten days today with views wide apart.

NEWARK, Jan. 21 -- The Public Utility Commission said today it was "highly improbable" that a New York Central Railroad petition to discontinue passenger service on the West Shore division March 7 could be considered by that date.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 21 -- The Government announced at the opening of Parliament today that it would in time introduce new legislation to give persons of mixed blood separate representation and put Parliament's authority beyond challenge of the courts.
A color-conscious crowd visited the General Motors Motorama at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- Wes Santee had his first fling at Eastern board-track racing tonight. In it he showed a fine turn of speed to an overflow crowd of 10,000 that showed up at Convention Hall for the eleventh annual Philadelphia Inquirer Games.

THE article by Robert Gorham Davis "In a Raveled World Love Endures" cites the works of the Twenties as reflections of an age and compares this mirror quality to the post-war novels of Carson McCullers, Truman Capote, Paul Bowles, and so forth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- With President Eisenhower looking on, the famed fun-making Alfalfa Club nominated a "Presidential candidate" tonight on a platform of full unemployment (with pay) and opposition to any Administration foreign policy.

The associations for the Comet and Raven classes of racing yachts picked dates for their major regattas and elected officers at annual meetings last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The annual tug-of-war over the Federal budget moves to Capitol Hill next week as members of the House Appropriations Committee deploy in small groups to give the 1956 version a going over.

HARTFORD, Jan. 22 -- Patronage fever gripped the Democratic party in Connecticut this week.

POE NICA, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 12 -- By the time native children reach the age of 6 months in most known areas of New Guinea, 30 per cent have malaria. Before they are 1 year old, all have it.
Among art exhibitions this week is a showing of selections of nineteenth and twentieth-century works from the collection of Claribel and Etta Cone, which was left to the Baltimore Museum.

HALIFAX, N.S., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Forty-seven Royal Canadian Navy seamen were stricken with alcohol poisoning today after drinking a fluid used in mimeographing machines aboard the aircraft carrier Magnificent, the Navy disclosed today.

SCHOOL bells are ringing again at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, where gardeners will have opportunities to brush up on their knowledge of flowers, foliage and pruning tricks. Short courses will be taught in subjects ranging from the planting of flowers to the painting of them.

FURNISHINGS introduced at the wholesale home furnishings markets held here and in Grand Rapids twice a year invariably indicate future trends in design. It is possible to judge from manufacturers' offerings and store buyers' response pretty much what the homemaker will have to select from later this spring.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 22 -- Col. Francisco Cosenza, named by President Carlos Castillo Armas as leader of the plot to overthrow the Government by force Thursday, has gained asylum in the Salvadoran Embassy.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Jan. 1. -- This expedition closed the historic camps at Little America today, probably for the last time. The Navy icebreaker then sailed eastward along the coast to seek a substitute site from which to launch future explorations.

ARMONK, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- Lloyd I. Gibbons, 43 years old, a vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, New York advertising agency, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning early today. He was behind the wheel of his automobile in the garage beneath his home on Route 22 here.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 (AP) -Vehicle, a 20-to-1 shot, held on through the stretch to win the $5,000 Marriage Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

THE sitting room of the suite in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel occupied by Mr. and Mrs. George Montgomery was a florist's delight the other day. There were several vases of roses and carnations and a large white orchid on display.

Resident buying offices note that stores are trying to maintain a maximum "open-to-buy" while covering their immediate needs. Their object is to buy more heavily as fashion trends come into focus.

Interest in the Monthly Investment Plan of the New York Stock Exchange, which will be a year old on Tuesday, has not been dampened by the recent break in the stock market. Offi cials of the Exchange and of its member firms say that, surprisingly, the number of new plans opened in the first ten days of January, when stock prices were weak, was greater than in comparable periods in recent months.

An anonymous donor has given $225,000 to Randolph-Macon College, Ashland, Va., for scholarships to be awarded within twenty years to develop men for moral leadership. The donor expressed interest in those who would become teachers, public servants, newspaper editors and preachers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 -- Department store sales in the Far West continue to roll along at rates considerably higher than for the first weeks of January, 1954. Metropolitan centers in the Pacific Northwest showed particularly heavy gains. Although ahead of last year's figures, stores in San Francisco and Oakland lagged considerably behind the rest of the district.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 22 -- A $5,000,000 renovation and expansion project for St. Elizabeth's Hospital here, including a new seven-story building, was announced this week by Frank K. Sauer, president of the board of managers, and Sister Alice Regina, administrator.
