WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- Coach Jack Riley's Army ice hockey team turned in a fine showing today at Smith Rink as a beat game but outmanned Springfield College, 7 to 2.

A FEW days ago a youngish father was asked to look over a list of qualifications for being what he is -- a father. He did so, then handed it back with a plaintive query: "What am I supposed to be -- the Columbia faculty ?"

Only a grudging human would look down his nose at a machine that can do fifteen years of mathematical computation in two minutes, translate instantly and grammatically from the Russian, absorb the contents of the Manhattan Telephone Directory in a twinkling, operate a railroad switch yard, and wind up with a performance of "Jingle Bells."
Internal revenue agents are now available in their offices for advice to the public in making out income tax returns, it was announced yesterday.

Primary copper and aluminum are both in tight supply. The major reason in each case, aside from the good volume of domestic buying, is the persistently high level of European demand that has kept prices overseas well above quotations here.

THERE is no more important foreign dateline in our newspapers today than Moscow. For, on the nature of the news from the Soviet capital may depend our whole future, our way of life, war or peace, survival or annihilation.

WITH the advent of each new season, home gardeners seem to be driven to feverish activity. It may be weeding, cleaning up, liming or feeding the lawn, spraying, fertilizing, buying new plants and trees and whatever else the season or the obvious needs of the plantings may dictate.
The troubles in the area of Formosa Strait once again last week cast a cloud across the international political skies as Chinese Communist troops overran a small Nationalist-held coastal island.

To thousands of New Yorkers, Helen Martini is known as the lady who raises wild animals in a Bronx apartment. In "My Zoo Family," a straight- forward and absorbing book, Mrs. Martini explains her unusual occupation and provides the reader with much original information.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- British soccer took another slap from the weatherman today as twentysix of the sixty-two scheduled league matches were postponed because of flooded grounds, ice and snow.
Mayor Wagner has asked the City Council to consider the extension of daylight saving time through the month of October.

WHAT Newfoundland claims is one of North America's most unusual "ferry" operations will enable motorists next summer to drive cross-country in Newfoundland from Port aux Basques to St. John's. The "ferry" is actually a railroad service which connects Gander, the airport town, with Clarenville, a port on Trinity Bay.
TOKYO, Jan. 20 -- Unofficial contacts between Japan and the Communist countries are expected to be expanded this year on all fronts, from the athletic to the zoological.
The Citizens Budget Commission is continuing to press its fight for the use of Hudson River water as the city's main new source of future supply.
Heroic action by firemen saved the lives of three members of a family early yesterday when a smoky fire trapped them in their two-story frame house in Brooklyn.

The fighting off the China coast last week sharply focused attention on the Peiping regime and the vast nation it rules. Because Western correspondents are barred from the mainland, it is difficult to find out precisely what China is like today. Nevertheless, some news continues to filter through the "bamboo curtain." Here are some of the highlights of what we know about China.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 21 -- The Commonwealth Government has decided to admit 130 more Japanese pearl divers and lugger crewmen to work for Australian master pearlers operating from Darwin and Broome.

THE tenth annual Dogwood Planting Week begins today throughout the state of North Carolina. Originated in 1946 by Mrs. J. S. Mitchener, then president of the Garden Club of North Carolina, the project has continued to thrive and thereby encourage the use and conservation of this colorful spring tree.
May I inject my opinion on the Nicaraguan-Costa Rican situation?

Formosa -- for five years a focal point in the struggle in the Orient -- is an island of 13,800 square miles (about the size of Massachusetts and Connecticut) with a population of 7,600,000. A spine of mountains divides it into a craggy east and a flat, fertile west.
Michael J. Quill demanded yesterday that the Transit Authority open its books to the union's accountants.
A cheerful Bolivian boy who was born without arms and legs was greeted here last week with the possibility of successful treatment and a shiny procession of new toys.

Most annual reports are dull compilations of figures, dull even when they report a profit. In contrast with routine statistical analyses, the 1954 annual report of the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews of New York is primarily photographs.
Members of the St. Nicholas Society of New York will hold their sixth annual ball on Friday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
MOST seed catalogues of today are far more serviceable than those of a decade or more ago. They are because their seedsmen publishers have kept them up to date to the needs of modern gardening.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- The University of Pennsylvania went into a tie with Cornell for the Ivy Basketball League leadership by defeating Yale, 91 -- 71, tonight before a crowd of 4,938 at the Palestra.

TWO well-known European conductors who have not previously led orchestras in this country are coming here next season for guest stints with the Chicago Symphony. One is Carlo Maria Giulini of Milan's La Scala, who will conduct in November while Fritz Reiner, the regular conductor, is in Austria leading performances of "Die Meistersinger" at the Vienna State Opera.

IF it is true that nothing new may be said for the pot roast, then it is also true that no home cook yet has made full use of this favorite meat for winter men-us. It may be as tangy as sauerbraten (a German pot roast), as tempting as boeuf a la mode (a French pot roast) or as homey as smothered beef.

WHY climb mountains? * ** No answer is completely satisfactory. Perhaps there is no single answer; perhaps each climber must have his own reasons for such an effort. The answer cannot be simple; it is compounded of such elements as the great beauty of clear cold air, of colors beyond the ordinary, of the lure of unknown regions beyond the rim of experience.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower discussed with a New York delegation from the Committee on Foreign Trade Education today ways to stimulate public interest in his program to increase trade through lowering tariffs.

ABOUT twenty years ago a Chinese family -- man, wife and three children -- were living on a little island in the Yangtze River, not far from the city of Chinkiang. The woman became sick. Nothing seemed to help her -- not the ministrations of the local herb doctor nor offerings in the village temple.
NOT every orchestral conductor has a father who is head of the Book-of-the-Month Club. Conversely, not every book-club head has a son who is a performing musician.

THE current Broadway production of "Peter Pan," with Mary Martin in the title role, has been tentatively scheduled for a two-hour television performance in color nine days after the play ends its run at the Winter Garden.

Stores here did well, compared with last year, in the week ended yesterday. However, with ten stores trying to match the sales volume of the eleven that were in business a year ago, and with the weather turning bad at the end of the week, they were just able to better the 1954 mark for the week, it was estimated.

IT will be a quarter of a century this year since a young Englishman looked out of the window of his shabby Berlin room and, writing in his diary, began the second paragraph with "I am a camera with its shutter open, quite passive, recording, not thinking.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Because Democratic leaders are still angry with Republican leaders for what they did to Capitol Hill patronage employes in January, 1953, a number of staff employes of Congress are looking for new jobs in January, 1955.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz. -- Recently completed improvements at Grand Canyon National Park will make things easier for sightseers in the future. In the pine-shaded campground on the North Rim, workmen have finished new roads, installed more water faucets at convenient spots, and built sixty new picnic tables.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Eisenhower's Advisory Committee on Weather Control wants to know just how effective the nation's "rain-makers" really are.

DR. SLAUGHTER has the tale - spinner's knack in three productive fields: stories drawn from the reservoir of the American past (mostly south of the Mason-Dixon line), with a doctor-protagonist who sums up the dilemmas of his era; stories drawn from the Bible; and stories based on his own modern medical knowledge.

Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera" received its second performance of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Zinka Milanov and Richard Tucker were again the chief singers, but two of the other major parts were undertaken by artists who have not previously sung them here.

Farm product prices are failing to follow the trend of previous post-war periods. This is considered generally to reflect to national policy involving price-support operations at home and a foreign aid program which is encouraging sales abroad.

The number of voters who may be interested in the conservation of forests, fish and game is apparent from the fact that approximately 400,000 hunting or fishing licenses were issued last year in New York State.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 22 -- Jerry Moss, 18-year-old United States Junior Davis Cup player from Modesto, Calif., defeated Roy Emerson of Australia, 8 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, today to join three other Americans in the second round of the Australian tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The United States airlines serving the Far East are ready to give free transportation to close relatives of seventeen Americans imprisoned in Communist China if the State Department requests such service.

AS is to be expected from the creators of Mr. and Mrs. North and other mystery-story characters, this is a tale of suspense. It's guaranteed to spellbind the reader who follows the gymnastics of a homeless cat in its efforts to elude the A. S. P. C. A. men during their humane drive to round up the strays of the city streets.
MIAMI, Jan. 22 -- Boston Doge, the unbeaten New England colt, scored his seventh and most impressive victory today when he won Hialeah Park's $20,050 Hibiscus Stakes before 21,421 fans.

MILWAUKEE. FOR the last two years local wags have been calling Milwaukee the city of the three B's -- beer, bowling and baseball. But if the resolute corps of theatre lovers known as Drama, Inc., has its way, a new jewel will be placed in the civic diadem: A community, professional theatre, with a permanent company plus guest stars, presenting plays for two-week runs.
TOKYO, Jan. 22 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama and his chief lieutenants in diplomacy and finance promised the Japanese today more independence, prestige and prosperity.

GENIUS or charlatan? Angel or devil? Devoted father or profligate Don Juan? Exalted artist and creator of the modern art of violin playing or the clown who brought the circus into the concert hall? These matters are still debatable a century after the death of one of the most fascinating figures in musical history, whose entire life was an enigma surrounded by a haze of legends.

UNDOUBTEDLY these four new books of excellent photographs with brief texts will be as much valued by young people as Major Colby's nine earlier volumes which were chiefly concerned with our armed forces.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 22 -- In control all the way except for the first few minutes of the game, Navy's basketball team recorded a 71-48 victory over Penn Military College today.

A growing surge of anti-intellectualism in the United States is having dangerous effects on individuals, on schools and on Government, in the opinion of a group of prominent scholars who last week discussed the subject at a "Great Ideas in Education Meeting," sponsored by Goddard College (Plainfield, Vt.).

SAIGON, Vietnam, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Nationalist Premier Ngo Dinh Diem demanded tonight that the powers that attended the Geneva conference on Indochina extend the 300-day time limit by which residents of Communist North Vietnam may choose to go South.
John McAuliffe, a Chaminade senior who failed to win in his first three seasons, registered his third straight victory of the indoor scholastic campaign when he took the 1,000-yard run last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- The Labor Department predicted today a "slight to moderate" pick-up in jobs in 100 major industrial areas during the first three months of 1955.

WHAT of the quiz shows? The hardy perennials of television manage to continue on and on with generally fewer casualties than other types of programs. Asking questions of assorted panels is probably at once the simplest and most durable format adopted by television from its immediate electronic ancestor, radio.
A 16-year-old boy was killed and another wounded shortly after 1 o'clock this morning when, the police said, they sought to escape after four policemen caught them robbing a Brooklyn grocery store.
A leader of the American Jewish Congress urged the Eisenhower Administration last night to undertake a "fundamental revision" policy in important areas of foreign and domestic policy.
The eleventh annual course for teachers, arranged by The New York Times in cooperation with the Board of Education, will begin Feb. 9. The general topic will be "Main Currents of the News."

THE reports are now in on the recent experiment of the State Department in sponsoring Jose Limon and his company on a brief South American tour, as the first undertaking of its new International Exchange Program, administered by ANTA, and we can all heave a great sigh of relief. It was a roaring success, both artistically and diplomatically.
The stock market has had another quiet week, with price movements indecisive. Trading volume declined considerably.

Professor Bush wrote: "The principle of education for all, however fine in theory, in practice ultimately leads to education for none. I see no reason why the flood of students should be allowed to pour into college, why automatic graduation from school should qualify anyone for admission."
Gil Hodges, the flashy first sacker with the brawny arms of a blacksmith, became the Dodgers' twenty-fourth contract signer yesterday.

Members of the Mary Washington Colonial Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, will hold a Valentine bridge party on the afternoon of Feb. 14 in the ballroom of the Colony Club. The fete will benefit the organization's Tamassee Scholarship Fund and other philanthropies aided by the chapter.

IN his review of F. S. C. Northrop's "European Union and the United States Foreign Policy" Drew Middleton writes that the new formula for Western European defense does not contain "these supranational provi sions which attracted so many * * * to E. D. C., the European Coal and Steel Community, the Council of Europe and the other instruments of European integration."

ANGNA ENTERS, who does not appear in this vicinity nearly as often as she used to do, will give a program of her "Theatre of Angna Enters" tomorrow night, as the first attraction in a Monday-night series being sponsored by the Phoenix Theatre under the title of "Side Show," to supplement its regular dramatic productions.

IT is always dangerous for an American to write about India. The country is so vast, the people so various: anything one says is true. And there is an elusiveness about the tragic subcontinent and the strange dream-like quality of the Indian landscape that baffles the practical-minded American.

There is a good augury in the speed and decisiveness with which the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty is going forward in the Senate. The Foreign Relations Committee has approved it by a vote of fourteen to one, and the lone dissent, that of Senator Langer, was his usual and typical one and certainly not based on any valid objection to the pact itself.

A NAVY project sparked by a young civilian engineer promises to point the way to improvements in airplane design that may revolutionize landings and take-offs and, perhaps, make it possible for regular airplanes to land on small airports well within city limits.
Three men were arrested early yesterday after they allegedly had held up a bar and grill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and had wounded a patron of another tavern.

SEATTLE, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Professional football got its foot in the gate of the University of Washington Stadium today when the Board of Regents voted, 3 to 2, to "continue negotiations" for a game next August.

The double cartoon captioned "Birth of the Two Party Symbols" in your issue of Jan. 2 perpetuates a common error -- that Thomas Nast originated the Democratic donkey. As William Murrell has pointed out, the jackass symbol was frequently used in the early Eighteen Thirties (before Nast was born) in connection with Andrew Jackson.

SEOUL, Sunday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Sixty disgruntled members of the South Korean National Assembly walked out yesterday for the second time in two months in opposition to a sweeping government reorganization bill. The remaining 110 then approved it.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A union representing Internal Revenue Service employes here called today for a Congressional investigation of personnel practices in the Albany office.
Following are excerpts from comment on some of the shows reviewed in The Times during the past week. A full list of the shows opening this week appears in the news section today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 22 -The realization of a long-range plan under which the American Civil Liberties Union's archives will be readily available to scholars was announced today by the union, the New York Public Library and the Princeton University Library.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 22 -- The lunar New Year or "Spring Festival," which falls this year on Jan. 24, is normally a time of great rejoicing for the Chinese.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Denmark's Gunnar Nielsen showed America's Wes Santee a real whirlwind finish tonight. In a spectacular reversal of their Philadelphia race of twenty-four hours earlier, the red-headed Copenhagen pressman whipped the crew-cut Kansas cowboy by 15 yards in a 4:09.5 flat-floor mile.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 22 -- The seventy-fifth anniversary of Thomas Alva Edison's chance observation of the flow of negative electricity, or electrons, is being commemorated here. The Princeton University Library is presenting an exhibition tracing the origin and evolution of the modern electronics industry.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- Another conference to give shape to the pending Western European Union treaty, which is to include a rearmed Western Germany, began in Paris this week. It discussed the French plan to add to the existing treaty a centralized control over armament production and procurement similar to that provided in the rejected European Defense Community project.

OTTAWA, Jan. 22 -- The Finance Committee of Elgin County, Ont., has decided that as far as it is concerned the indigent aged should be allowed to die in comfort, but without "artificial" prolongation of life.

FROM its crimson jacket straight through the book, this is a grand parade of pictures of flowered fields, horses in costume and out, a small town in gala mood -- marching up and down the long, narrow pages. Small children may find the book difficult to hold (it's 17 1/2 inches tall) and difficult to read (the text is hand lettered) but still the shape and the script are part of the fun.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The White House social season had a whirlwind windup this week, a month and two days ahead of Lent. What this breath-taking pace will do to this city's social fabric time alone will tell.

The first few weeks of 1955 have produced encouraging evidence that the rights of individuals suspected of subversion, disloyalty or unconventional opinions are going to be treated more respectfully by both the legislative and the executive branches of the Government.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. -- Skiing in the upper Mid-west was off to a flashing start in early 1955 with the biggest crowds in this section's history swarming over the trails and slopes of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan.

THE friend and biographer of Leon-Paul Fargue, Andre Beucler has written an engaging and nostalgic life of one of the precursors of Dada. He has evoked a whole way of Paris life familiar to at least two American generations, and, in so doing, has given a fascinating illustration of bohemianism.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 22 -- A retired consulting engineer with a passion for tidiness has been spending the last couple of years sorting out useful facts hidden away on 16,000 cards in the town records.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- West Germany has named Felix von Eckardt, head of the Federal press information department, as its permanent observer at the United Nations, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Intercontinental guided missiles with atomic warheads that will flash 5,000 miles at speeds up to 9,000 miles an hour to hit a target area with a radius of about ten miles are being developed.
The recently established Florida chapter of the American Friends of Spain Foundation, Inc., will sponsor a dinner dance on Feb. 18 at La Coquille in Palm Beach, Fla.

PHOTOGRAPHY in the role of direct communication in the purest sense of factual reportage, with text held to a minimum, is effectively employed in three picture books published recently.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Representative Daniel A. Reed said today that the Democrats faced "a certain Presidential veto" if they carried through reported plans for a tax cut in 1955.

ALFRED HITCHCOCK, a peripatetic director if ever there was one, is preparing to shift operations to Marrakesh in Morocco. Last week, Mr. Hitchcock, who journeyed to the Riviera and Vermont to film portions of the completed but as yet unreleased "To Catch a Thief" and "The Trouble With Harry," respectively, revealed that for the first time in a long and illustrious career he will do a remake of one of his successful suspense stories.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The row over the aircraft carrier Midway's visit to Capetown, South Africa, seems to have had a wholesome aftermath.

Columbia University officials reported yesterday that 1,544 students from seventy-three foreign lands were enrolled in the winter session.

AFTER the drama of Spain Portugal is a garden by the Atlantic, gracious and without extremes. In Lisbon it has a capital with the finest setting in Europe and, in the spring, of all European countries it has the richest variety of flowers.

At 1 P. M. on Jan. 20 two years ago Dwight D. Eisenhower completed his Inaugural Address and shook hands with his predecessor, Harry S. Truman. The new President left immediately to sign Cabinet appointments and then watch the inaugural parade. Mr. Truman went off to a farewell luncheon with his Cabinet given by Dean Acheson.

Clarence Faust, president of the Fund for the Advancement of Education, warned yesterday that education was failing to liberate the mind. Instead, he said, it is canalizing thought through "packaged" courses.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- United Nations sources expressed a quiet confidence today that Communist China meant to free still-detained American prisoners of the Korean war within a "reasonable" time. This was an interpretation given among usually well-informed United Nations people of the offer by Chinese Communist Premier Chou En-lai to open the door for visits by relatives to the imprisoned men.

The U. S. Government is a global operation with commitments that range from Formosa to West Berlin, from Panama to Pakistan. At home it exerts a major influence -- by its taxes, its purchases, its regulations -- on the domestic economy. Altogether its expenditures amount to one-sixth of a gross national product (all goods and services) that now totals $360 billion.
RED BANK, N. J., Jan. 22 -The Garden State Parkway will be ready tomorrow to serve Sunday traffic from Clifton to Cape May, the New Jersey Highway authority announced today.

We may reasonably expect our efforts on behalf of world peace to be most effective when they are consist ent with compassion. Man-made religious laws were condemned yesterday morning in a sermon at the Manhattan Seventh-day Adventist Church by Dr. Frank H. Yost, editor of Liberty, a Seventh-Day Adventist quarterly.

" BACK in the days when I played for the Original Celtics," musingly said Joe Lapchick, the coach of the professional Knicks, "we stressed possession basketball. You never dared take a shot unless you could be 90 per cent certain of making it. What does a fellow need nowadays to take a shot?" Joe shrugged his shoulders in mock dismay.

The gold medal of the International Benjamin Franklin Society was awarded yesterday to Dr. Howard A. Rusk, director of the Institute of Medicine and Rehabilitation at New York University-Bellevue. Medical Center. He was honored for his contribution to persons afflicted with physical disabilities and for training others to assist those afflicted.
THE happy phrase, "It's got everything!" can carry various implications. In one sense it is a phrase remarkably appropriate as a preliminary comment upon "The Sultan and the Lady."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Eisenhower's Cabinet- level Council on Foreign Economic Policy has been organized quietly.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Cut branches of early spring-flowering shrubs to force into bloom indoors. Forsythia, flowering quince, even pear and larch branches are easy and prompt. After cutting, smash the lowest two inches of stem and soak branches in water an hour. Stand in water in a light, warm room.

EDITH SITWELL is the nearest thing to a major poet that the British Isles have produced since Hardy, Lawrence and Yeats. With the possible exception of Hugh MacDiarmid she is now the only British poet who possesses that special accent of both individuality and scope which makes a writer a member of world literature.

IN reading Elizabeth Janeway's review of Zoe Oldenbourg's "The Cornerstone" it struck me as disputable to say, as Mrs. Janeway did, that the Renaissance "swept away" the Middle Ages. Taken at its face value this is a statement that history is chary of making.
ISLIP, L. I., Jan. 22 -- In an unusual ruling, a Suffolk County court agreed this week that it took more than speeding to convict a speeder.
The Eminent Achievement Medal of the American Woman's Association was presented yesterday to Jacqueline Cochran, flier and manufacturer of cosmetics, at a luncheon in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

EVERYONE knows that Etienne Gilson is the most authoritative living exponent and interpreter of the philosophy of the Middle Ages. Many students also believe that he probably has no contemporary peer in the lucidity of his mind and the balance of his historical judgments.

A clear call for greater freedom in Soviet scientific research and for open competition among rival schools of scientific thought was published in Moscow last week. The appeal was published in Literaturnaya Gazeta by Academicians Ivan L. Knunyants and L. Zubkov.

FOR her tenth regional book Lois Lenski dips into the Iowa corn country and comes up with unvarnished drama. Around young Dick Hoffman, his family and friends, she builds a series of episodes into a story that is bluntly realistic, occasionally gripping and jam-packed with vivid descriptions of life on the Hoffman farm.

BELGRADE, Jan. 22 -- To foreign observers Yugoslavia's foreign policy may seem to be based on a contradiction. On the one hand, there is Yugoslavia's bid for continued military aid from the Western powers -- Yugoslavs have recently even complained that the United States has been unsympathetic to Yugoslavia's request for naval reinforcements.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 22 -- Communists joined orthodox Hindu leaders today in organizing protest meetings against the slaughter of cows and serving of beef in hotels.

PANAMA, Jan. 22 -- The friction between Costa Rica and Nicaragua has focused attention on the question of quarrels in the American family of nations and the means of settling them. Reason seems slowly to be replacing bloodshed.

ATLANTA, Jan. 22 -- Department store sales in the Southeast are being maintained at a brisk pace. Dollar volume of leading stores in the area last week was 18 per cent above levels of the corresponding 1954 period. Much of the increase was attributed to the emphasis which merchants were placing upon January clearance sales, with price markdowns on a broad variety of goods.

NEW YORK CITY'S traffic problem is the problem of almost all major cities, but multiplied many times over -- how to move freely the steadily increasing stream of cars, trucks and buses over a fixed area, virtually unchanged since the street pattern was laid out in the horse-and-buggy days.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 -- Next week will be to a great extent MacArthur Week in Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 - A pressing need for combining instruction with career-guidance to halt "drop-outs" in high school was set forth today by a group of educators.

WINTER is often a trying period for Northern gardeners; it is especially so if activities are restricted to planning -- with no outdoor "doing." But for the intrepid amateur the schedule will soon include some real "down-to-earth" work.

THE best bridge hand to result from the world championship match (which the British team won from the American team last week) was a hand not played in the match. It was played in a rubber-bridge game in New York City by Maurice Stone.
A Brazilian cargo ship has arrived at a Mobile, Ala., shipyard, ending a long voyage from inner South America, where her hull was smashed in a collision with a tugboat.
PARTICIPATION in light tackle fishing, especially in Southern coastal waters, has provided additional sport and excitement for thousands of anglers who are limited to "budget" fishing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Wolf Ladejinsky, hired by the Foreign Operations Administration after being dismissed as a security risk by the Department of Agriculture, said today he would fly to his new post in Saigon next week.
NEWARK, Jan. 22 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy attacked tonight the idea of American coexistence with the Communist world.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Discovery of a photograph of Abraham Lincoln, believed to be the long-missing "Picture No. 72," was reported today.
Hunter College has named Prof. Leo Gurko, author and critic, chairman of the Department of English. He takes the post made vacant by the death of Prof. Marjorie Anderson.

The Cashmere goat wandering in the high plains of the Himalayas or Iran and the vicuna in the Andes of South America may not know it, but they are losing out to man-made fibers.
Simon Srybnik, 38, and his brother Louis, 30, are confident that they can handle what is believed to be the largest surplus disposal operation ever undertaken by private industry.

MADRAS, India, Jan. 22 -- Most of India's politicians are in Madras this week, but the country's real political drama is shaping up day by day in the rice and tobacco lands a couple of hundred miles to the north.
LAST week we summed up on the Soviet Writers Congress and this week we'd like to sum up on Edward Crankshaw, one of England's Russian experts and author of "Cracks in the Kremlin Wall."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22 -- The Yale University swimming team won its 119th consecutive dual meet tonight as it toppled Springfield, 56 -- 28.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- Paul Paray has signed a two-year contract as music director and conductor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, it was announced yesterday by John B. Ford, president of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, Inc. The agreement extends through the seasons of 1955-56 and 1956-57.

The National Urban League has scheduled a special three-day meeting of 100 volunteer community leaders, the first gathering of its kind in the history of the forty-five-year-old interracial social service agency.
BUSINESS in the new year is living up to advance billing. Production trends are up and they are being more than matched at both the wholesale and retail buying levels.

THE deserted brig San Sebastian, floating serenely off Ireland's west coast, is the sight that surprises young Pat Hernon one summer morning. He and a friend hide the strange old ship in a cave in the sea cliffs. The mystery is heightened when a gang of thugs appears, bent on seizing the brig.
New designs in ship cargo booms are leading the movement to refashion ships for better cargo handling, a group of shipping experts was told last week.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 22 -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrickson Zaharias piled up an early lead today, then got in trouble and barely held on for a one-stroke margin over Louise Suggs in the $5,000 Tampa women's open golf tournament.

THE more I read the literature of mountain climbing, the more convinced I am that mountain climbing is not a sport. Surely Maurice Herzog's "Annapurna," with its extreme suffering and misfortune, and Sir John Hunt's "Conquest of Everest" -- that masterpiece of logistics -- should suggest a revision of the conventional view.

THIS is Moravia's latest story of conjugal love, the most discerning he has written on this labyrinthine theme. "A Ghost at Noon" is a straightforward novel, with few characters and a single conflict, but rich in substance and resonant with meaning.

In recent months criticism has been reveled against the public schools on the ground that they stress too many fads and frills" in the classroom. the charge has been made that the three R's" -- reading, writing and arithmetic -- and beyond that grammar, spelling and history have been neglected.

THE Ninth Annual National Photographic Show will be held Feb. 18-22 at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, the Photographic Manufacturers and Distributors Association, the sponsor, announced last week.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 15 -- West Germany, starting with the Ruhr, is trying to end the gambling craze that has come over the German workingman since the war.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 22 (AP) -- An old Indian treaty that New York State mistakenly sold for waste paper was reported today on its way to the Soviet State Museum in Moscow.
SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 22 -- A missionary team of experts from the Atomic Energy Commission reassured the West this week on the forthcoming nuclear tests.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Sunday, Jan. 23 -- Opposition started building up here today to the idea of evacuating the Tachen Islands with the aid of the United States Seventh Fleet.

Professor Oskar Morgenstern's proposal to abolish military scrip will be a welcome notion to the millions of Americans who have had to use it during the last ten years. However, his discussion of the problem is hardly an adequate basis upon which to consider a change.

THE local exhibition calendar of new photographic shows is highlighted this week by the opening of Edward Steichen's "Family of Man" exhibition on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art. The most important photographic show ever held in this city, it will occupy the entire second floor of the museum and will be on view through May 8.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 20 -- South Africa's production of uranium and thorium is rising rapidly. Three gold mines in the new Orange Free State field starting production this month and next will bring the number of uranium producers to a dozen.

This week a comfortable New Englander who started a business on $30,000 twenty-five years ago will make a $2,000,000 share offering to expand his $14,000,000 corporation by buying 52 per cent of the stock of one of its chief suppliers.

The New York Film Critics presented citations to the winners of their twentieth annual vote on outstanding motion picture contributions during 1954 at a private reception held last evening at Sardi's Restaurant, West Forty-fourth Street.
REGARDING William Saroyan's article in your section last Sunday, I should like to point out that no one prevented him from continuing the "Saroyan Theatre." Even the sound of the name is beautiful.

DESPITE its title, and its relative brevity, this book is in effect the first general work on Argentina since John W. White's near-classic, "Argentina: The Life Story of a Nation," published in 1942. The interval has seen several studies emphasizing the role of Juan Domingo Peron -- and at least one skillfully dramatizing the career of his late wife, born Eva Duarte.

THE $101,000,000,000 plan to modernize the nation's highways in the next decade, which was set forth recently by Gen. Lucius D. Clay (ret.), is an important, if not the key, element in the big toll bridge-highway program sought for the metropolitan area.

TAIPEI, Sunday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Departure of a naval task force from Manila and the sudden sailing of the United States Seventh Fleet flagship from Hong Kong increased speculation today on strategy involving Formosa.
GENEVA, Jan. 21 -- The Geneva trade conference has virtually solved all but five of the important difficulties blocking a new world trade agreement.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 22 -- More than 800,000 coal miners and steel workers staged a one-day strike today in the Ruhr.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 22 -- Goucher College, the only women's institution among twelve colleges and universities that have participated in the early armission program for talented high school pupils, announced today that it would continue the program next year with its own funds.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The state expects to take a greater role and more "sympathetic" attitude toward the school needs of local communities than it has in the past.

OUT in a Connecticut suburb not too long ago a girl of 12 -- nose powdered, lips lightly rouged, strapless "formal" meticulously padded out -- sat tensely at home waiting for her 13-year-old escort-of-the-evening.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Britain is seeking an international formula for ending the fighting between Chinese Communist and Nationalist forces off the China Coast, officials said today.

In the Annual Economic Report made to Congress last week by the Administration there will be found, we believe, the nearest approach to a clear-cut American philosophy of the Government's economic role in a dynamic free-enterprise system to emerge since the first of these reports was made public in 1947.

Bouncing back from a halftime deficit of 6 points, Ken Norton's Manhattan basketball team last night defeated Danny Lynch's St. Francis team, 73 -- 69, before 2,500 at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

The Philadelphia Warriors stopped a last-period bid by the New York Knickerbockers and captured their National Basketball Association game yesterday, 102 to 99. While the spectators at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yelled approval, the Knicks staged a belated spurt. But the visitors, with a high average of shooting in the earlier periods, did not let the locals close the gap.
HENRI - GEORGES CLOUZOT, whom the French regard as their Hitchcock, is a director who works on his exposed nerves.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 22 -- Ogden Phipps' Great Captain, whose major victory last year was in the Saratoga Cup, today captured the $29,250 San Marcos Handicap over Santa Anita's turf course. Poona II finished second in the mile-and-a-quarter race.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 22 -- Steel ingot output in the Cleveland-Lorain district dropped sharply to 85.5 per cent of capacity from last week's revised figure of 96 per cent. Most of the decrease occurred in the Lorain section. New unemployment claims dropped slightly to 3,063, but continued claims climbed from 17,150 to 19,516, highest figure since September.

Details of the world's longest suspension bridge, a span of 4,400 feet to cross the Narrows from Brooklyn to Staten Island, were made public here last week by the Port of New York Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Jan. 21 -- Important political and constitutional changes are scheduled for the Federation of Malaya this year. Strides will be taken taken toward democratic self- government and eventual independence within the British Commonwealth.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company eased its rules yesterday morning to give nine thrilled Cub Scouts a caboose ride from Stamford, Conn., to New Haven and back.
More than eighteen months have passed since the Treasury put out its first post-war issue of long-term bonds and the financial world believes that the time is at last ripe for a repeat performance.

THE $600,000,000 program of toll bridges and arterial highways proposed for the metropolitan New York-New Jersey area will contribute only modestly to the relief of New York City's acute traffic congestion.
Would-be smugglers are "burying" illicit items deeper than ever as a result of new Customs Service methods and machines put into action in New York in the last six months.
Two hundred twenty-one citations for bravery and exceptional police duty were announced yesterday by Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.

IF there is one thing more lamentable than another where the business of buying and selling musicianship is concerned, it is the blind reliance put by managers and public alike upon the press reviews of artists' performances.

TWENTY-THREE paintings, 1930-54, make up the Ben Shahn retrospective at the Downtown Gallery. It is an important event, a proper tribute to an authoritative artist who insists that art's great purpose is to express the grandeur and misery of human beings in this day and age.

TEEN-AGE girls short of money -- as who isn't? -- will find this book an excellent source of ideas. There is a section on working for others and one on managing your own business, plus an introductory chapter on how to be successful in business.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 14 -- Preparations for the meeting of the Organization of Central American States for March in this city are going forward here in spite of the Nicaragua-Costa Rica dispute.

Between 1939 and 1954 stock market prices advanced only about a quarter as rapidly as the economy as a whole. If some optimists in Wall Street are right in insisting that stocks must eventually catch up, prices will have to rise 58 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 -- A move was begun this week, with the approval of Mayor Elmer E. Robinson of San Francisco and his legislative advisers, looking to the transfer of this city's harbor facilities from the state to the city.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 22 -Possibly the highest steady speeds ever achieved in a laboratory, 11,400 miles an hour, are providing scientists here with the first complete set of test data on the problems of hypersonic flight.
Relatives of seventeen Americans imprisoned in Red China found themselves yesterday increasingly torn by the dilemma posed by Peiping's invitation to visit the prisoners.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 22 -- The independent Fur and Leather Workers Union voted overwhelmingly today to merge with the 265,000 - member Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Efforts to revise and soften the McCarran-Walter Act -- properly, the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 -- will be undertaken in this session of Congress with somewhat better prospects of success than existed in the previous Congress.

" BUT parting with the water-colors of John Marin, Charles Demuth, Joan Miro, Fernand Leger, Jules Pascin and Pavel Tchelitchev is more than parting with my pictures, it is like parting with my youth, for we all grew up together and the pictures are relics of friendship as well as prophecies that have become true," said Henry McBride.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Democratic foes of the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract have shelved, for the time being at least, their plan for floor action to void it, Congressional sources said today.

DALLAS, Jan. 22 -- Department stores sales continued last week to move at a pace equal or better than in the same week last year, merchants reported, and other business indicators were good. In one of the first major labor negotiations of the new year, A. F. L. truck drivers in the Southwest this week tentatively agreed on a new six-year contract that would avert a strike called for Feb. 1.

What amounts to a family alumnae association increased its membership in Brooklyn last week when the fifth daughter in a row (out of six) of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Tesser was graduated from Brooklyn College.

The color and gaiety of carnival time in Rio de Janeiro will be brought to the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 11 at the fourth annual Carioca Ball. Held under the auspices of the Brazilian Cultural Society, the ball will benefit the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.
The blame for juvenile over-emphasis on worldly pastimes and lack of attention to spiritual pursuits was assessed yesterday by Rabbi Zev Zahavy.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The Seine River continued to rise in Paris today while hundreds of workers strove to keep the waters under control. The scene was repeated in hundreds of French towns and villages, and, where men lost the struggle, vast areas were inundated.
The bulldozer, workhorse of World War II, soon will get its biggest peacetime working orders from Dwight D. Eisenhower.

NOW, well along through the first month of the new year, it becomes possible to estimate that during 1954 approximately 2,200 major and minor varieties of postage stamps were issued by 157 different countries -- republics, kingdoms, empires, mandated lands, colonial possessions and so forth.

THREE names come to mind with any mention of the famous "gangs" of Midwestern banditry -- the James boys, their partners, the Youngers, and the Daltons. All were famous in their time; all gained a dubious immortality through such media as the dime novel and the motion picture, both of which were far more concerned with melodrama than with fact.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- The American and Canadian professional football leagues agreed to a tentative no-raiding pact today but they failed to solve the big issue -- the settlement of contract disputes of players who have "jumped" across the border.
MIAMI, Jan. 22 (UP) -- A morning newspaper to be known as The Capital Post will begin publication in Tallahassee, Fla., March 20, Leo W. Bowmall, newsprint executive of New York announced here today.
BOSTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The weather forecast and ski conditions at New England developments reported today follow:

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 22 -- Martin Strolz, a 22-year-old Austrian, gained his first American triumph of the season today. Last winter the ski-boot maker placed second in the Federation International de Ski world championships.

TRENTON, Jan. 22 -- Dr. Frederick M. Raubinger, New Jersey Commissioner of Education, announced this week that $500,000,000 would have to be spent on new school facilities within the next decade. He also noted that the state was still plagued by a serious shortage of public school teachers.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Two Queens Republicans proposed today that New York City be given $200,000,000 worth of additional borrowing power to finance a ten-year school building program.

Perhaps New York has seen a more enthusiastic sports and trade show. Perhaps there have been bigger ones. But no old salt in pleasure boating and yachting can recall anything as exciting as the National Motor Boat Show which will wind up a ten-day run in Kingsbridge Armory with a five-hour finale today from 2 to 7 P. M.

PRODUCERS John Byram and Courtney Burr are doing their best these days to populate "Shangri-La." This is the musical version of the late James Hilton's "Lost Horizon," the book about an oasis of serenity in snow-smothered Tibet.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton, N. J. will match his back-court prowes against the net charges of the French junior champion, Jean Noel Grinda, in the final of the Florida State tennis championship tomorrow.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- The seven men who walked unarmed into a besieged cell block at the Massachusetts State Prison this week and achieved a peaceable end to a mutiny may have introduced a new concept in penal procedures.

A variegated fare at the weekly noon-to-2 P.M. concert on Wednesday at the New York Public Library's Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building will offer recordings that begin with Alessandro Scarlatti's "Concerto Grosso," No. 3 in F and end with selections from Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte."

The Puerto Rican Government had a problem. It uses the excise tax money from sales of rum for its "Operation Bootstrap," the plan for building the island's economy. And the mainland was not buying as much rum as the island wanted to sell.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- Ralph Davidson of Boonton, N. J., and Vic Cassman of New York advanced to the final round today in the metropolitan badminton championships at the Westchester County Center.

CENTRAL AMERICA, a region of natural and human volcanoes, has begun erupting again. Violence and instability have long been endemic among the hot little republics at the hemisphere's waistline. From time to time, they break out fiercely enough to earn the area the description of the United States' troublesome backyard.
BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- The Boston Bruins scored in every period tonight to gain their third straight victory, a 3-1 triumph over the New York Rangers, before a Boston Garden crowd of 9,197.

FORTUNATE is the indoor gardener who is completely satisfied. Rare is the one who can claim immunity from the feeling that wintertime activities have somehow fallen into a rut, particularly if the same conventional plants are grown every year.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 22 -- Tommy Bolt of Houston faded to an even-par 72 for a total of 203 in the third round of the $15,000 San Diego open today. Bolt took a three-stroke lead over Jackie Burke of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., who moved up to second place with a 68 for 206.

Commercial bankers will gather at the Commodore Hotel tomorrow to learn more about industry's plans for atomic energy.

Dr. Benjamin F. Wright, president of Smith College, declared in his annual report made public last week.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Ford Motor Company has reached no decisions on the guaranteed annual wage or other matters to be negotiated with the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., this spring and won't until after contract talks have started.
A group of steadfast friends who have never actually met will wave to each other again at 4 P. M. today across the windy Atlantic waters southwest of England.

TRENTON, Jan. 22 -- It became increasingly apparent this week that some action would be taken soon to alleviate New Jersey's serious shortage of potable water. Present supplies are barely sufficient to meet growing demands.
Communism is forcing missioners to work more rapidly with people in underdeveloped lands, according to the Rev. Edward L. Murphy, former editor of Worldmission, Roman Catholic magazine.

VICTOR'S low-priced label, Camden, once limited to special outlets, has recently been put into general distribution and now includes several 12-inch LPs of show tunes culled from recordings that were in the Victor catalogue only a few years ago.

THE N. B. C. Opera Theatre's production of "Tosca" yesterday afternoon, with Leontyne Price, the Negro soprano, in the title part, with David Poleri and Josh Wheeler as Cavaradossi and Scarpia, respectively, was on the whole the most dramatic and convincing performance by this organization that the writer has seen.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Lorne (Gump) Worsley, backed by a stout defense, turned in his fourth shutout of the year as the New York Rangers blanked the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 0, tonight before 12,192 fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Congress is awaiting President Eisenhower's request tomorrow that it confirm his authority to order United States air and naval forces into action in defense of Formosa, the Pescadores and other islands vital to the defense of Formosa.

If Americans are to be as successful as Communists in spreading the philosophy of government, they must make religion "the subsoil of democracy," the Rev. Dr. D. Elton Trueblood declared yesterday. He is chief of religious information of the United States Information Agency.

Net assets of the Adams Express Company amounted to $68,133,974 on Dec. 31, equal to $51.53 a common share, according to the annual report, issued for release today. This represents a new high in the history of this closed-end investment company.

CAIRO, Jan. 23 -- Gen. Nuri as-Said, Premier of Iraq, accused by Egyptian spokesmen of breaking Arab unity by agreeing to sign a defensive alliance with Turkey, may come to Cairo to explain advantages of the pact to heads of governments of other Arab states.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- Ralph Davidson of Boonton, N. J., won the men's metropolitan badminton championship today by defeating Vic Cassman of New York in the final round, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 3, at the Westchester County Center.
Winter returns to the Bronx today after the annual January interlude that made the Kingsbridge Armory a fantasy of summer-time delight.
The benefits and the shortcomings of the $600,000,000 program for arterial highway relief in the metropolitan area were discussed on the air yesterday.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias won the Tampa Women's Open golf tournament today for the third time, posting a 72-hole total of 298 to defeat Louise Suggs by one stroke.
The police on Manhattan's West Side cracked down on Sabbath business yesterday, ordering customers from several midtown stores and forcing them to close.

This letter is prompted by your editorial concerning the visit of the U. S. S. Midway to Capetown, South Africa, which followed a more or less factual account of the visit in the previous day's edition.
Is there really fear among American college and high school teachers and does fear handicap their work? The Fund for the Republic, a Ford Foundation subsidiary, is seeking definitive answers.

With clearing skies reported in the Atlantic after a two-week spell of foul weather, the Coast Guard said here yesterday that three of the six vessels in difficulty around Bermuda were nearing port under tow, while two others were still drifting and the sixth was hard aground.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 23 -- A proposed Brazilian tax of 25 cents (United States currency) on each bag of coffee exported is opposed by the Rural Association of Sao Paulo.

Three artists shared yesterday afternoon's Town Hall program presented by the Concert Society. They were Lisa Della Casa, who was heard in her only recital appearance of the season, and the Graudan Duo -- Nicolai Graudan, 'cellist, and his wife, Joanna, at the piano.

When Senator Fulbright announced a fortnight ago that he was considering an inquiry into the recent excitement in the stock market, the first question people asked was: Can it serve any useful purpose?

J. Irwin Shapiro, State Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday he had received written authority from Governor Harriman to institute preliminary investigations necessary to "keep the state straight."

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- There was considerable selling pressure early last week in all grain and soybean pits, with lower prices. Developments in the Chinese area caused uneasiness and started considerable short covering, but bulges again showed a fading of buying demand, which encouraged local pressure.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 23 -- California's Indians took steps today toward trying to determine their own fate after a century of dictation by the white man.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt completed his conquest of the field in the $15,000 San Diego Open today. He shot a one-under-par 71 for a total score of 274 and a two-stroke victory over his nearest rival.
Six new films, including importations from France and England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Senator Stuart Symington said here today that the United States must negotiate policies to form events instead of allowing events to form policies.
Cash economies and improved administration have assured the city of a saving of at least $12,200,000 in 1954-55, Mayor Wagner said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Washington's Topic A -- Will the President run again in 1956? -- got a small and inconclusive push the other day from the man most intimately concerned.
William Lombardy, New York State champion, and Franklin Howard of East Orange tied in the championship final yesterday at the Marshall Chess Club with 9 1/2 points apiece.
Staten Island's 205,000 residents are not sure of several things about the proposed suspension bridge over The Narrows that is to give them a direct road connection with the rest of the city.

Three women physicians received the annual Elizabeth Blackwell Citations of the New York Infirmary yesterday for their contributions to medicine. One hundred and twenty-five persons attended the presentation ceremony in the infirmary, at Stuyvesant Park East and Fifteenth Street.
Prime Minister Sidney G. Holland of New Zealand arrived here yesterday for a four-day unofficial visit.
A hit-and-run driver was being sought yesterday after he had killed one man, seriously injured another and struck three cars in Brooklyn.

HAMBURG, Germany, Jan. 22 (UP) -- A German sea captain charged with cowardice by members of his crew because he would not try to rescue twelve drowning men on a sinking ship was criticized by a maritime court today.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Unusual week-end diplomatic activity emphasized Britain's concern to seize the opportunity to bring about a relaxation of tension in the Far East.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 23 -- Chiharu Igaya, Dartmouth sophomore from Japan, won the Victor Constant Trophy slalom race today. Martin Strolz, victor in the downhill yesterday, took the Alpine combined honors, although he was second in the slalom.
LAST year Jack Gilford was playing the character of the meek Bontche Schweig who went to heaven to speak one line in "The World of Sholom Aleichem." It was a good line, too.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The first serious skirmish between the new Democratic Governor and the Republican-controlled Legislature will begin this week.

A lack of social impact of the Christian mission programs on rural and urban life over the world was emphasized yesterday at the final meeting of the Third Annual Conference of Mission Experts at Fordham University.
Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, accuses the National Administration of using "Fascist methods" in the Federal employe security program.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Committee to Save the Cruiser Olympia, flagship of Admiral George Dewey at the Battle of Manila Bay in 1898, said today the the Navy had accepted tentatively its application for the warship.

The Hakoah eleven defeated the New York Americans by 3 -- 0 at Brooklyn Field yesterday and tied the Philadelphia Uhriks for first place on points in the American Soccer League. The goal average, however, favored the Uhriks.

NEWS of exceptional talent travels quickly in New York musical circles. Thus, when Mattiwilda Dobbs stepped on the stage at Town Hall last night, even though it was only her second appearance there, a capacity audience of 1,500 was on hand to greet her.

The city's new fireboat John D. McKean will cruise in New York metropolitan waters today with a group of city officials and engineers continuing tests to determine what makes the craft vibrate and to find remedies.

Last September the Soviet journal, Voprosy Istori (Problems of History), published a complaint by three historians telling of the great difficulties imposed on Soviet historical research because of lack of access to Soviet archives. Mayor Wagner's Administration was criticized yesterday for failing to carry out recommendations dealing with relocation of families displaced by public improvements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A Senate subcommittee charged today that a new trend toward monopoly and concentrations of economic power was heading the country for a "devastating business collapse."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The United States Forest Service reaches its fiftieth year Feb. 1. In preparation for the celebration of the anniversary it looked back proudly today at its conservation campaign.

THE deadline for ballots in the election of baseball's Hall of Fame is today. Before any announcement is made as to who -- if anyone -- made it, strong objections will be offered by this exerciser of the franchise. There is at least one restriction to the voting which ranges somewhere between being ridiculous and being downright stupid. Worse still it's utterly pointless and without validity.
BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- The State Prison at Charlestown, scene of an eighty-five-hour revolt, was searched for weapons today.

ATLANTA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Charges of discrimination against Negro doctors at a cancer meeting here Friday were made today by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Dairymen's League today said all its dealers who buy Class 1-A milk had agreed to sign a super-pool agreement and abide by higher fluid prices.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 23 -- The Connecticut Committee Opposed to Legalized Lotteries took sharp issue here today with three Roman Catholic educators who maintained last week that bingo was not morally wrong.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Seven survivors of a Navy seaplane crash in the Pacific told today how they had kept their rubber life raft afloat more than two days by plugging punctures with fingers and corks while sharks bumped against the bottom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Eisenhower's health message to Congress will be a miracle-worker if it leads this session to major health-insurance legislation, its main aim.
VIENNA, Jan. 23 -- Chancellor Julius Raab delivered a warning tonight to the Soviet occupation authorities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Three California farm area representatives reported today assurances from the Department of Agriculture that Government-held stocks of Ladino clover and alfalfa seed would not be dumped on the market below the current price floor.
