Publication of a business economics study entitled "Convertibility and Foreign Trade" was announced over the week-end by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Lois Marshall's song recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall was in large part a procession of slow-moving music. The soprano had programmed the Purcell-Britten "Three Divine Hymns" and Brahms "Vier ernste Gesaenge" as her opening groups; the juxtaposition was not too wise, for a lack of variety made itself felt.
Edmund Wilson, novelist, essayist, playwright and literary critic, has been selected by members of the National Institute of Arts and Letters to receive its Gold Medal for Essay and Criticism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said today that Iron Curtain countries had shown little interest in more trade with the United States despite Administration steps to permit an increase.
DUBLIN, Jan. 22 -- The Irish hunting jacket provided the inspiration for the new look featured in the spring collection shown here this weekend by Miss Sybil Connolly, Irish fashion designer.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Peiping radio in effect rejected today any cease-fire around Formosa, denouncing the plan as a United States "plot" to "interfere in the domestic affairs of China."

DETROIT, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Goalie Terry Sawchuk registered his tenth shutout of the season and fourth in a row on home ice tonight to snap the Detroit Red Wings out of a three-game losing streak. The Wings defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4-0.
Two 18-year-old youths dived into the Hudson River yesterday in the annual Epiphany cross-retrieving rites of the Greek Orthodox Church.

Verdi's "Otello" will return to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera on Monday evening, Jan. 31. The Opera will also serve to introduce Renata Tebaldi, the prominent Italian soprano, to American audiences. On the occasion of her debut Miss Tebaldi will sing the role of Desdemona.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The stock markets continue to conform to a pattern with which we have become familiar in recent weeks. The outstanding feature is continued appreciation in industrial shares and gradual subsidence of gilt-edge securities.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers staged a strong finish tonight to defeat the Syracuse Nationals, 98 -- 89, and tighten the Eastern Division race in the National Basketball Association.

Billy Joe Patton, the spectacular amateur golfer, is scheduled to receive a special honor on Thursday. Within a day or so, the scholarly looking golfer will make one of his rare trips to New York. He is coming to receive the gold tee award of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association.

Soviet-ruled Eastern Europe is one of the key arenas in today's great struggle between freedom and slavery. There are many reasons for believing that it may be the Achilles heel of the Soviet colossus, for even after ten years of Communist rule the 100,000,000 people of this area have not yet been turned into the servile automatons who are the ideal citizens of a totalitarian state.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The Chicago Transit Authority closed its financial books for 1954 with a total of $536,205 in excess of operating expenses and fixed charges, it reported today.

More than nineteen centuries ago the boatmen of Paris erected an altar to Jupiter on ground now occupied by the noble Cathedral of Notre Dame. Paris was established where it is precisely because the River Seine was there, and because the boatmen could go down along the pleasant country from that site to the sea and up along some other pleasant country to the head of navigation.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Jan. 22 -- One of the helicopters ferrying observers and scientists to the plateau of Antarctic ice surrounding Kainan Bay crashed to day, inflicting fatal injuries on the pilot. Kainan Bay is east of Little America.
ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Fritz Feierabend, 47-year-old Swiss bobsledder, flashed to victory today in the two-man world championship.
The election of Dewey D. Stone, New England industrialist, as national chairman of the United Israel Appeal was announced yesterday. The agency is the chief beneficiary of the United Jewish Appeal.
ALGONA, Iowa, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Two families said today they wanted to go to Communist China to visit their imprisoned airmen sons.

The United States Steel Corporation, which did very well with a Christmas promotion for major household appliances that it called "Operation Snowflake," is making plans for another. It will be known as "Operation Wife-Saver" and will make a peak in late April and May.

An ecclesiastical fashion note crept into a church service yesterday when a rector explained to his congregation that he wore a biretta -- a stiff, square cap topped with a tuft -- because his head got cold.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- To be a good Capitol Hill parliamentarian a man has to know:

The one-story taxpayer building containing eight stores at 4701 to 4721 Broadway, in Woodside, Queens, has been sold by Sidney Messinger of the Donsid Realty Corporation of Manhattan to an investing client of Harris Chasanoff, attorney, of Far Rockaway. The price was reported to have exceeded $248,000. Sydney M. Siegel Co., Forest Hills brokers, negotiated the deal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Congress prepared today for a week of routine legislative talks overshadowed by the specter of possible growing conflict in the Far East. Much of the week will be dominated by White House messages.

The six-story and penthouse office and showroom building at 135 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth streets, has been resold by Louis Cooper, who took back a lease on the property for fifty years, starting Jan. 1, 1955. The property is 24.8 by 125 feet and was sold subject to mortgages amounting to $325,000.

A new attitude of concession and cooperation has marked the relations of the port's dockworkers and their employers for the last two weeks, indicating that the prediction of two years of peace on the docks has at least a chance of achievement.

As the post-war years elapse a host of giant construction projects have either been inaugurated or dangled before our eyes in the form of tentative future plans. These range from bus and freight terminals to the recent Grand Central Terminal skyscraper and the mammoth bridge proposals announced last week.
One of the newest chiefs of government in the turbulent tropical area of the Americas got off to a flying start last week on efforts to solve his country's critical economic problems.
I feel that the time has come for me as Consul General of Venezuela to take exception to your frequent derogatory editorial references on Venezuela and its Government.
GENEVA, Jan. 22 -- Now that they can get it more easily, European industrialists and bankers are discovering that they do not want American private capital on any massive scale.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Government of Laos and rival Communist forces have started "cordial" talks aimed at a political settlement for that strife-torn Indochina kingdom, the Peiping radio said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Administration will report to Congress tomorrow that contracts have been closed with private buyers for virtually all of the Government-owned synthetic rubber industry. The selling price is believed to be upward of $300,000,000.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 23 -- So great is the hunger in Switzerland for investments yielding a "fair" return that the 4 per cent 50,000,000-Swiss-franc ($11,667,000) - loan of the Compagnie Francaise des Petroles, offered ten days ago, was oversubscribed two and a half times.

An American edition of Boris Simon's "Abbe Pierre and the Ragpickers of Emmaus" will be issued Thursday by P. J. Kenedy. It is an account of the French priest, a former member of the Chamber of Deputies who, with the help of ragpickers and junkmen, raised money to provide homes for young couples, children and elderly persons without shelter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Treasury Secretary, George M. Humphrey, said today that President Eisenhower's new budget provided for spending between $500,000,000 and $600,000,000 for economic aid to Asia in the twelve months starting next July 1.
Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved narrowly last week and closed with net gains of 7 to 16 points, or 35 to 80 cents a bale.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 --The country's attitude toward its scientists was criticized today by Dr. Blake R. Van Leer, president of the Georgia Institute of Technology.

Charles Shons, Taft School athletic director, teacher, actor, author and one-time artillerist, will retire in June. The news will cause regret among thousands who studied under Shons as a teacher of French or as an athletic coach.

Though it scarcely seems possible it is so old, the Bureau of Labor Statistics is celebrating its seventieth birthday. In that Biblical three-score-and-ten-year period the agency has performed a quietly useful and efficient function for management, labor and the people of the United States.
A youth who spent eighteen months in hospitals with infantile paralysis returned home yesterday to his father, brothers and neighbors in the Bronx.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The 3,548-ton freighter Pergamon, the first German ship to anchor in Israeli waters, arrived at Haifa today. The ship carried from Hamburg 1,000 tons of iron obtained by Israel in Germany under the West German-Israeli reparations agreement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A survey by the Department of Labor showed today that one in every six office workers in major United States cities was covered by union contract.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 11 -- When India is fully industrialized, what will be the effect on folkways, customs, religious beliefs?
CLEVELAND, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Eddie Joost, former Philadelphia Athletics manager, will try out with the Cleveland Indians at their spring training camp in Tucson, Ariz.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 23 -- The investigating commission of the Organization of American States will abrogate the security zone along the Costa Rican-Nicaraguan frontier if rebels have not left there by Tuesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- Eric Johnston left Idlewild airport this afternoon on his third mission to the Middle East, as President Eisenhower's special representative, to try to induce the Arab states and Israel to accept a plan for joint development of the Jordan River valley.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 23 -- A new pattern of mutuality in the missionary field under which Christians of other countries might send missionaries to the United States was urged here today by Dr. Raymond A. Dudley of Boston.
Weather vagaries brought death yesterday to three persons on the icy pavements of New York's suburbs, while the city itself had nothing more than a mildly raw overcast.

BOTH wrote poetry, plays, travel books and novels, those two European writers of world-wide fame. Both are still read with delight and enthusiasm in every civilized country. Both were vain, naive and childlike in many respects. They lived in the nineteenth century and knew each other slightly. But the Frenchman lived with voracious zest, writing more books than he could keep track of, having more mistresses than he could remember.

MANILA, Jan. 23 -- The Philippine Congress begins its annual 100-day session tomorrow by listening to President Ramon Magsaysay's State of the Nation message, the first account of his stewardship since he took office a year ago this month.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 23 -- Although no criminal has fired a pistol here in fifty years, this town has the sharpest target eye in Fairfield County.

Two company acquisitions were reported over the week-end. The Grand Union Company announced completion of negotiations to acquire the Food Fair Super Markets of Washington from Square Deal Market Company, Inc., and the Victor Adding Machine Company bought the Janette Electric Manufacturing Company from the Gerity-Michigan Corporation for $1,200,000.

Net earnings of the Continental Oil Company last year were about $41,700,000, or $4.28 a share, L. F. McCollum, president, reported over the week-end. This compares with $40,900,000, or $4.20 a share, in 1953.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Ray York, who piloted Determine to victory in the Kentucky Derby, was named today for the George Woolf Memorial Award.
ABOARD THE U. S. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Jan. 21 -- A party from this ship landed in Kainan Bay today but failed in its attempts to reach the ice plateau. Crevasses seemed to block all routes.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- The spectacular rise on the French Bourse in 1954 has made financial circles wonder whether a wave of speculation is not going to cause a reversal of the trend in the first few months of 1955.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23 -- The Nepali Congress, the main political organization in the Himalayan kingdom of Nepal, has called off the non - violent civil disobedience movement launched against the Administration Jan. 10.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The State University trustees urged the Legislature today to approve a $13,350,000 dormitory building program for fourteen of its campuses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, special Ambassador to Vietnam, arrived in Washington today from Saigon for two weeks of reports and conferences. He said he expected to see President Eisenhower promptly.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- An exceptionally interesting diplomatic conference is to be held in Moscow this week. Soviet Ambassadors in key posts including Washington, London, Paris and East Berlin have been summoned to report. The result may be consequential.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee staff study revived the question today of whether the United States would want to back elimination of the veto in the United Nations Security Council.
The power and necessity of prayer as a means of expressing to God recognition of His omnipotence and love were emphasized by Msgr. Thomas A. Donnellan yesterday.
DURHAM, N. C., Jan. 23 (UP) -- A spokesman for Duke University Hospital said tonight that Willie Cooke, hemophilia patient, had taken "a very decided turn for the worse."
MADRID, Jan. 23 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco said today that his eventual successor would be required to safeguard the political structure of the present regime.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Jan. 23 -- Communist headquarters in Malaya has moved to the northern fringes of Malayan territory and across the frontier in Thailand. Malayan Communists dominate sizable pockets of Thai territory.

Today President Eisenhower will send to Congress a special message on our policy in respect to Formosa. Presumably he will also ask Congressional approval for specific Executive actions under specific conditions. We welcome this development.
MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- Pictures of what the Soviet Union describes as the first atomic-energy power station in the world were published today in Pravda.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Governor Harriman announced today the appointment of Chief Inspector Francis S. McGarvey of New York City as Superintendent of State Police. His name will be sent to the Senate for confirmation tomorrow night.

The Little Church Around the Corner (Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration), Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, will have a new organist and choirmaster Feb. 1. He is Stuart M. Gardner, who since 1953 has held a similar post at St. Paul's Church, 157th Street and St. Paul's Place, Flatbush, Brooklyn.
Christians know that God will not be blown out of the universe by a hydrogen bomb, Mrs. Douglas Horton, former president of the National Social Welfare Assembly, said yesterday.
"Festival" didn't close after its seventh performance Saturday night at the Longacre, as announced. The Sam and Bella Spewack farce has been reprieved.
Yehudi Menuhin played the single New York recital he is giving this season at Hunter College on Saturday night. It attracted an audience of more than 2,000 persons.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 -- Robert Mitchum will star in March for Samuel Goldwyn Jr. in his initial production venture, "The Deadly Peacemaker," which will be made for United Artists release.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 23 -- Jordanian authorities were reported today to have arrested two men for the murder of two settlers in Israel last Monday night.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- The Commercial Exchange of Philadelphia, a grain trading center for farm crops from the Eastern seaboard to the Midwest, is completing 100 years of public service on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Corporations issuing public reports paid out 8 per cent more in dividends last year than in 1953, the Department of Commerce said today.

Ice, snow and blinding-white "visibility" that distorts distances have presented special hazards to fliers in Arctic and Antarctic expeditions ever since the plane supplanted the dog-sled almost thirty years ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Congress was urged today to ignore domestic producers' pleas for reductions in sugar imports from Cuba.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Alex Goguen of Pittsfield, Mass., and Mrs. Janet Tigue of Wilmington, Mass., skated off with the top titles in the ninth annual Glens Falls winter carnival today.
Twenty-five laymen and two clergymen returned yesterday to their church in Ohio after having lived for a week-end at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization announced today it had granted special tax benefits to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for a $7,730,000 research and development project at Churchill, Pa.

It is the regrettable fact that, a decade after the end of the Second World War, rent control is still a necessity in New York and some other parts of the state. Governor Harriman in his special message to the Legislature recommends a two-year extension of control and, in fact, a considerable tightening of what we have rather than a relaxation.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--The State University of New York has not as yet fulfilled its promise of low-cost college and professional education. However, progress has been made in co-...

TELEVISION critics must learn when to keep their big mouths shut. For several years they complained about "Strike It Rich." What happens? The evening version of the mournful give-away leaves the air and in its place is substituted a new film series called "The Millionaire."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 23--Milovan Djilas and Vladimir Dedijer, two former Communist notables, will go on trial tomorrow. The case is not expected to take more than two days.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Fifteen persons were killed in a train wreck at Sutton Coldfield [cross on map], near Birmingham, this afternoon. Many more lives were saved by two railway men who stopped another express train before it plowed into the wreckage.
The number of persons receiving public assistance increased 11.3 per cent last year over 1953, while expenditures increased 11.5 per cent, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 23 -- Preparations are being made by United States officials here for Seventh Fleet assistance in withdrawing Chinese Nationalist troops from the Tachen Islands.

The Giants added Marvin Grissom to their growing list of signed players yesterday. The ace relief pitcher who, with Hoyt Wilhelm, saved countless games for the world champions last year, came to terms in a telephone conversation with Horace C. Stoneham, Giant owner now vacationing in Phoenix, Ariz. Grissom called from his home in Red Bluff, Calif.
The tremendous surge that has been spurring ship charter rates to increasingly higher levels for the last several months seems to be on the wane.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 -- Virtually all steelmakers and all consumers look for high-level steel activity for at least the first five months of this year.

A new organization known as Jazz Unlimited presented a concert yesterday afternoon in the seventh-floor ballroom of Manhattan Center. Mitch Reed, the master of ceremonies, said the program was planned as the first of a series of Sunday afternoon jazz concerts to be presented by the organization.

An antiques show opens today at 7 P. M. at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. Many leading dealers from New York, New England and other areas are among the 100 participating. The show, which will run through Saturday, is for the benefit of the East Side House Settlement, Stepney Camp and the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery. Admission costs $1.50.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -- After two years of verbal dueling with the Russians, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. says he is convinced that the Soviet's influence in the United Nations is at an "all-time low."

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 24 -- James F. Davey, a 53-year-old bartender, was in Hudson County Jail today awaiting trial on a desertion charge preferred by his wife. Nearly eight years ago a body was buried erroneously under his name.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A new baseball rule that cuts the width of the catcher's box from a maximum of 16 feet to only 43 inches might produce a hit or a balk this season instead of an intentional pass.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The British Transport Commission announced today a plan for the modernization and re-equipment of the nationalized railroad system. Its total cost would be 1,200,000,000 ($3,360,000,000).
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield asked Congress today to increase the cost of mailing both local and out-of-town letters from 3 to 4 cents.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Two frequent opponents on political and economic questions got together today on President Eisenhower's foreign trade program.
For the second time in two years, the Medical Society of the County of New York denied membership last night to Dr. Godfrey Edward Arnold, former Vienna speech specialist.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Tuesday, Jan. 25 -- The United States Seventh Fleet is ready to begin helping the Chinese Nationalists to evacuate the Tachen Islands off the Chekiang coast within "a very few days."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Charles C. Finucane, Assistant Secretary of the Army for financial managemens, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be Under Secretary of the Army.

A Supreme Court jury yesterday directed Representative James G. Donovan and three other defendants in a libel sut to pay $25,000.06 damages. The order stemmed from statements in a Democratic leadership fight in 1951.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The New York Central Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve its employe stock purchase plan.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Seven companies have signed an agreement to participate in the Armour Foundation's nuclear reactor research program, Haldon A. Leedy, director, said today.

IMPRESSIVE indeed was the second dais at the recent Boxing Writers dinner since it served as a showcase for some of pugilism's more noteworthy performers. Among them were such as Mickey Walker, Barney Ross, Tony Canzoneri, Johnny Dundee, Kid Gavilan, Jimmy Carter, Joe Lynch, Paul Berlenbach, Gus Lesnevich, Frankie Genaro, Ruby Goldstein, Sid Terris -- and Tommy Loughran.
CAIRO, Jan. 24 -- Egyptian efforts to build a solid Arab opposition to the projected defense pact between Iraq and Turkey have fared badly here.
Two honorary citizenships in the George Junior Republic were presented last night at its annual dinner in the Westbury Hotel, Madison Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street.

CANTON, Miss., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Matty Netty, owned by A. G. Schorr of South Norwalk, Conn., excelled in the opening round of the National Field Trial Club's derby championship. She turned in a smooth performance and two quail bevies in her one-and-a-half-hour hunt under the gaze of three judges.

Several pastries, rich in chocolate and whipped cream in the Viennese manner, are being prepared for the first time at Lillian's Dainties, 169 East Sixty-third Street. That small shop specializes in sweets with an Austrian, Hungarian or Czechoslovak flavor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Foreign Operations Administration is rushing radio sets, motion-picture units and graphic materials to South Vietnam to help Premier Ngo Dinh Diem establish closer contact with the people of South Vietnam.

J. J. Haggerty Jr., seeded fourth in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association tournament, lost his first-round match yesterday at the New York Athletic Club to W. A. Flagg of the Racquet and Tennis Club, 18 -- 14 14 -- 18, 17 -- 18, 16 -- 14, 15 -- 12.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The Voice of America broadcast today President Eisenhower's message on Formosa through the 'Bamboo Curtain" and into the Red Chinese mainland.
The President's message to Congress yesterday on Formosa means that at last the United States is beginning to draw a military and political line in Asia.
Your editorial "The Teacher's Pay-check" is the perfect brief on behalf of increased salaries for teachers.

Political news from Malaya is even more encouraging than the military reports. The two major groups, one Chinese and one Malay, have apparently composed their differences and will go to the country in the forthcoming election as a united front. This means that there will be, for the first time, an elected majority group in the national legislature.
Life sentences with no possibility of parole were imposed yesterday in Kings County Court on two members of the "kill for thrill" gang convicted of first-degree murder.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Union officials declared today that Theophil C. Kammholz, nominee for N. L. R. B. general counsel, would not be "impartial" in his post.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, showed a decline in sales and earnings last year from 1953 as a result of reduced operations, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Uneasiness over the Chinese situation was largely responsible for a strong market in grain and soybean futures early today. Later in the session, bullish sentiment was engendered by the request made to Congress by the President for specific authority to defend Formosa and the Pescaderos Islands.

MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Rouge Falcon, owned by Mrs. Charles Silvers of Miami Beach, captured the Montecumbe Purse at Hialeah Park today, beating eleven other 3-year-olds in a swift clocking of 1:10 3/5 for six furlongs.
CROTON, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- The historic Ferry House at Harmon in this village has been acquired by John D. Rockefeller Jr. as part of his restoration of the Van Cortlandt Manor House built in 1665.
Directors of the Phillips Petroleum Company have declared a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a common share, payable March 1. The company previously paid a quarterly dividend of 65 cents.

The battle of Detroit roars on as the production commanders keep sending observers to find out how the sales commanders are doing. So far in January the production chiefs are doing well. But the word from the front is hat dealers continue to cut prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Administration's action today, though risking involvement in the shooting along Formosa Strait, was taken in the hope of snuffing out the possibility that a bigger war would flare up by miscalculation.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly, taxed Mayor Wagner today with responsibility for mushrooming slum areas in New York City.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- A wind velocity of 392 miles an hour was recorded high over Philadelphia yesterday, the Weather Bureau said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Congress appeared ready to grant quickly the wide authority President Eisenhower sought today to use military force to protect Formosa. The mood at the Capitol was not unquestioning, however, nor was it, on balance, eager. There was much private anxiety.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Department of Justice asked Congress today to enact legislation that would wipe out more than 32,000 claims against alien enemy property seized in World War II.
The local contract-signing parade for 1955 continued yesterday as the Yankees brought two more players into the fold and the Dodgers four.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The American Automobile Association told President Eisenhower today the ten-year road development program of his highway committee "has a pork-barrel and political potential of serious dimensions."
SACATON, Ariz., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Ira Hayes, one of the six marines who raised the United States flag on Iwo Island's Mount Suribachi in 1945, was found dead today on the Sacaton Indian Reservation.

A business man announced here yesterday that relatives of two of the seventeen fliers held by Red China had accepted his company's invitation to be flown in its plane and at its expense to the starting point of an airlines flight.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 2 to 6 points (10 to 30 cents a bale) net higher than on last Friday.
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday that salary increases for teachers would be included in the city's 1955-56 budget.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Romance and tennis both figure in Maureen Connolly's 1955 plans, she said today. The former national champion disclosed that her comeback try on the courts would be limited to a few major tournaments.
Joseph P. Ryan, former pier union leader, was found guilty yesterday of having accepted gratuities from employers in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Bob Lemon, who says, "I got just what I asked for," signed a contract with the Cleveland Indians today for about $50,000.

Directors of the National Radiator Company approved final terms yesterday of a merger with the United States Radiator Corporation, subject to approval of National stockholders at a special meeting on Feb. 28 at Baltimore. U. S. Radiator stockholders will act on the proposal at a special meeting in Buffalo on Feb. 25.

WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Jan. 24 (UP) -- Navajo braves performed a sacred war dance today for the first time in eighty-seven years to dramatize their claim to a "fair share" of water from the upper Colorado River.

FORT SILL, Okla., Jan. 24 (UP) -- The court-martial of Maj. Ambrose Nugent, accused of collaborating with his Chinese Communist captors, got under way today with defense attorneys asking dismissal of the charges.

Six more members of Fordham University's freshman football team of last fall and two sophomores from the varsity squad revealed yesterday they would transfer in February to schools that have football teams.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 24 -- Harvard University has gained in popular respect, Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president, said today.
A mediator has proposed -- and the parties have accepted -- a peace formula in the dispute between American Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association A. F. L.

President Eisenhower, in his State of the Union message, requested the Congress to authorize 35,000 units of public housing in each of the next two fiscal years. It is most unfortunate that the President set his sights so low.

AN excellent selection of paintings, small bronzes and drawings from the extensive Cone Collection of the Baltimore museum is being shown at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, as a benefit for the museum. Thirty oils -- about one-quarter of those in the collection -- together with eight of some fifty bronzes and about thirty drawings, pastels and water-colors are included in the selection.
Islands that in centuries past have served both as pirate lairs and fishermen's retreats are at stake in the grim crisis shaping up between the Chinese Nationalists and Communists.

Harry E. Beekman, advertising, in 245 5th Ave; Firestone Advertising Agency Inc, in 101 W 31st St; David Schack, George E. Schwarz, Jerome D. Silberstein, lawyers, in 5-7 Maiden Lane; J. Alexander Leventhal, dentist; Bruno C. Klerings, Helmut L. Ehrhardt, dental technicians, in 57 W 57th St -- Harris, Newmark Co, brokers.

Cocoa prices soared the cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by strong London cables, reports of low inventories and the Far Eastern international situation.

Bargains. Everywhere they go they come back with bargains. On a trip to the delicatessen to pick up a little butter for supper they see in a near-by window a desirable bit of personal property. They think, they brood, and on the way home they stop in at the store and then bring home triumphantly another bargain.

Events tonight: "Manon," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Alexander Brailowsky, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "La Sonnambula," American Opera Society, Town Hall, 8:30; Theodore Thomas Orchestra, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
ATLANTA, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Snow in Tallahassee, Fla., which melted almost as fast as it hit, rounded out twenty-four hours of freakish weather in the usually balmy Atlantic and Gulf coastal plain.

Retailers are choosing color and novelty items this year to a greater extent than usual, exhibitors at the New York Curtain and Drapery Show and the National Domestics and Linen Show reported yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The British Government's support of President Eisenhower's stand on the defense of Formosa and the Pescadores Islands appeared certain tonight.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Hatred of taxes, one of France's commonest sentiments, drew more than 50,000 Frenchmen together here today. Their major act was to declare a "tax strike" to begin tomorrow if satisfaction was not obtained from the Government by then.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 25 -- Communist China has rejected the United States suggestion of a cease-fire in Formosa Strait.
The New York Philharmonic will make a tour of Europe in September, after all, and two other American ensembles are likely to visit Europe and Asia this year.

The five-story building containing fifty-seven apartments and eight stores at 1800 University Avenue, also known as 147-49 West Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by George Goodman Co., operators and investors.

The South dominated the United Press college basketball ratings yesterday as North Carolina State moved to the runner-up spot behind top-ranked Kentucky and George Washington advanced to eighth place.

The sympathy of the free world is completely with Austria's Chancellor Julius Raab in his challenge to Soviet lawlessness. It was no light matter for the Chancellor to speak out in protest against the Soviet kidnapping of the chief Austrian interpreter for the Vienna municipal government, Dr. Alfred Sokolowski.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 24 -- The country's biggest union is getting richer.
Net income of the New York Telephone Company in the year ended Dec. 31 amounted to $62,248,040, equal to $7.55 a common share, it was announced yesterday by Keith S. McHugh, president.

The New York Office of the Extension Service in Food Marketing reports halibut steak now costs only 20 to 30 cents a serving. Supplies are especially good; there are several million more pounds of the fish now available than at any time in the last five years.
OTTAWA, Jan. 24 -- Canada will embark this year on the construction of an atomic plant to produce electrical power, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Representative Sam Rayburn, Democrat of Texas, Speaker of the House, today said its committees had no authority to permit picture-taking during hearings.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Rodin's once-controversial statue "Le Baiser" (The Kiss) was assured for the nation tonight. A check arrived in the mail at London's state-owned Tate Gallery that completed the public subscription to buy the famous marble.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs have declined, after rising for three consecutive weeks. It reported that its latest offering of $1,500,000,000 in ninety-one-day bills was sold at a price equal to an annual interest rate of 1.349 per cent.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 24 -- A violent underground explosion has caused at least thirty-eight deaths in the Zonguldak coal basin on the Black Sea.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Mayor Wagner urged the Legislature today to enact measures against bookmaking and vice "loopholes."
Television and radio station representatives were warned yesterday that they shared the responsibility of fraudulent advertising on the air.
Pete Adams, Newark middleweight, scored a knockout victory over Angelo Brisci of Taranto, Italy, in the main bout, scheduled for ten rounds, at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
A specially built ambulance, an oxygen therapy truck, and its auxiliary station wagon, were formally accepted by Mayor Wagner yesterday on behalf of the city.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers, gathered by The New York Times and The Associated Press on President Eisenhower's message to Congress on Formosa:
LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The text of a statement by Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China, as broadcast by the Peiping radio and monitored here today, follows:

CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 -- Congregational Christians are establishing a new church every two weeks, Dr. Henry Leiper of New York, reported to delegates at the opening session of the church's annual midwinter Missions Council tonight.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 2 -- The garment trade will begin to recover its old share of the consumer dollar this year if it plays its cards right, an industry spokesman said today.

The American Jewish Congress filed with the New York State Commission Against Discrimination yesterday a complaint that the Children's Court here was using religious quotas in hiring probation officers. It alleged that appointments were denied to qualified Jews on the civil service eligible lists solely because of their religion.
While engineers Still have the plans for the Forty-second Street shuttle on the drawing boards, they might consider making the shuttle a loop.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Tuesday, Jan. 25 -- Costa Rican troops were poised early today to enter the neutral security zone along the Nicaraguan frontier in pursuit of an estimated 250 rebels on the Costa Rican side of the border.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., Jan. 24 -- Three brothers, the oldest of whom was 6, died of smoke poisoning in their attic bedroom during a flash fire here early today. Firemen and neighbors kept the boys' father from rushing into the burning house in a rescue attempt.

The Republican party, which prides itself on being a party of responsibility, is behaving childishly rather than responsibly when it rushes in with tax-cutting measures at Albany before it even knows the exact size of the Harriman budget or the official estimates of tax revenues in the 1955-56 fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The State Department said today that relatives of two of the seventeen Americans jailed in Communist China had made inquiries about visiting them.

For an experienced ship master -- even one with fifty years at sea behind him -- the last voyage is usually the hardest. And Capt. Harry N. Sadler, master of the Moore-McCormack liner Brazil, is no exception.
Roger W. Lewis, Assistant Secretary of Defense, warned last night that carelessness in weapon planning could lead the nation to disaster as surely as carelessness in actual fighting.
MARY CANBERG, the pianist who made her debut at Town Hall in 1947, played a second recital there last evening.

Ralph Kiner, a member of the American League's Cleveland baseball team, has been granted permission by major league officials to continue as the National Loop's player-member of the pension plan committee. This was revealed here yesterday by J. Norman Lewis, attorney for the players.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Dr. T. F. Tsiang, Nationalist China's delegate to the United Nations, said today that "on the whole" he was pleased with President Eisenhower's message to Congress pledging the United States to defend Formosa and the Pescadores Islands.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- George Halas of the Chicago Bears, a National Football League pioneer and one of the most popular coaches in football, announced today he will quit coaching after the 1955 season.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 24 -- Today the scene of Italian fashion openings shifted from Rome to this city. As a prelude, an exhibit of accessories and boutique clothes was opened this morning at the Grand Hotel.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The situation in the Far East had a dampening effect on stock market activity today, although the industrial lists showed many bright features.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, often a shaky starter in Australian tennis tournaments, had a narrow squeak today in the second round of the Australian national championship.
The Oliver Corporation, farm equipment producer, increased net earnings 32 per cent in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, to $3,707,295 from $2,809,517 in the preceding fiscal year.
DURHAM, N. C., Jan. 24 (UP) -- Willie Cooke died today, ending a medical fight to save his life with a record 400 pints of blood in transfusions.
A 28-year-old former bank clerk was charged last night with a $100,000 mail theft because, authorities said, he could not shake off an old forgery habit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today the Justice De partment was studying charges that four Mississippi Negroes had been denied Government farm loans because they had supported N. A. A. C. P. activities.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Tuesday, Jan. 25 -- Milovan Djilas and Vladimir Dedijer have been convicted of having waged hostile propaganda against Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today on the Formosan situation:
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- The site of a prehistoric settlement, believed to be the oldest yet unearthed, has been discovered in Iraq.
MANILA, Jan. 24 -- President Ramon Magsaysay struck a note of apprehension today in his state of the nation address, as Congress assembled for its annual 100-day session.
The Year of the Lamb came in like a lion as New York's Chinese community welcomed the Chinese year 4652 yesterday with fervor and fireworks.
A management-labor dispute raised the possibility yesterday that 150,000 automobiles might be locked in or out of 700 Manhattan and Bronx garages after Thursday.
A committee of Brazilian shipping officials will arrive here early in March to complete negotiations to buy twelve small coastal vessels from the United States for $7,200,000.

Your criticism of the Democratic party for its attempt to carry out its pledge to repeal the criminal penalties for playing bingo is unjustified. There is nothing in the New York State Constitution that provides that criminal penalties shall be imposed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- An experimental color radar set developed under Navy contract was demonstrated today under operating conditions at the Washington National Airport.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 24 (AP) -- The New York Giants' Willie Mays received the Ray Hickok $10,000 diamond studded belt as the professional athlete of the year tonight at the annual Rochester Press and Radio Club dinner.
TOKYO, Jan. 24 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama dissolved the lower house of Japan's Diet tonight and ordered new national elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Following is the text of the proposed resolution introduced in Congress to carry out President Eisenhower's request for authority to defend Formosa and the Pescadores Islands:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations agreed unanimously today to tackle "unfinished business" left by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, the former chairman.

ANGNA ENTERS, our most celebrated mime, last night gave a program of her unique character creations at the Phoenix Theatre, as the first event in that theatre's extracurricular Monday evening series, which it has termed "Sideshows."

In a dramatic move to avert a new crisis in the Far East which could endanger world peace President Eisenhower has called upon Congress to pass a resolution specifically authorizing him to use the armed forces of the United States if necessary to protect Formosa and the Pescadores from Communist aggression and to "take into account" closely related "localities and actions" which might determine the success or failure of such aggression.
Two new foreign-flag tankers made their maiden appearance here over the week-end.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Mayor Wagner will outline New York City's program for meeting its revenue needs to Democratic and Republican legislative leaders here on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The White House decided today to send no more special messages to Congress until it had disposed of the Formosa resolution submitted today.
TRENTON, Jan. 24 -- The New Jersey Assembly called on New York today for legislation raising from 18 to 21 years the minimum age at which a person may buy liquor in that state.

At the premiere last night of "Holiday for Henrietta" at the Fine Arts Theatre, held for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center, Count Henri de Vilmorin greeted and thanked the audience for helping a worthy cause.
Directors of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation voted yesterday to accept the offer of the Sunray Oil Corporation for a merger of the two companies.
A 25-year-old Brooklyn mechanic turned himself in to the police yesterday as the hit-and-run driver whose car killed one man, seriously injured another and struck three autos last Sunday morning.

Senator William E. Jenner said yesterday that "leaders in our Government" had adopted and "uttered in American accents" the theme of peaceful coexistence, which he termed a Soviet snare intended for this country's destruction.
Truck drivers who deliver newspapers and magazines for city and suburban wholesalers voted overwhelmingly yesterday to strike at midnight next Monday, when their present contract expires.

The Stock market reacted decisively yesterday to President Eisenhower's message asking Congress for permission to fight in defense of Formosa. Industries that would benefit directly from increased military spending recorded notable gains.

ALBANY, Tuesday, Jan. 25 -- Governor Harriman refused early today to give the Republican-controlled Senate Finance Committee an extra fifteen days in which to consider five of his Cabinet appointments.

THE Composers Group of New York City presented last night the second of the four programs it is offering this season at Carnegie Recital Hall. The works performed for the first time were "Driftwood," a piano suite by Harry Hewitt, played by Elieen Flissler, and Sonata for Two Pianos by Herman Parris played by Jean and Kenneth Wentworth.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Governor Harriman's freeze on state construction projects appeared to have thawed somewhat today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- William C. Johnstone, Professor of Asian Studies in the School of Advanced International Studies here, urged this country to develop a clear and consistent policy in Asia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to authorize calculated risks of war aimed at averting Chinese Communist capture of Formosa and the Pescadores Islands.
The steel industry plans to turn out more steel this week than in any other week since mid-November of 1953.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 24 -- Streams of shoppers' automobiles flow smoothly every day into the sprawling parking lots at the Abraham Straus store here. They are unerringly directed to vacant spaces by uniformed attendants carrying portable radio-telephone sets.

First prize for the "most ingenious" real estate deal in Westchester County during 1954 was won by Anthony Cerreta, a member of the firm of William A. Klein, Inc., of New Rochelle. Second prize went to Mrs. Elise L. MacBride of Buttolph Foster of Chappaqua.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The National Football League and nine of its clubs today attacked the validity of a $2,100,000 anti-trust suit filed against them by the bankrupt Liberty Broadcasting System.

Alterations are planned for the three-story dwelling at 163 West Ninety-fifth Street which Roman Sikorski has contracted to purchase from Fred H. Hill, real estate operator and investor. Mr. Sikorski will convert the structure, containing eleven rooms and two baths, into small units and will occupy one of the apartments.
ALTHOUGH this may not be the lime to be thinking of big tuna, those who want to go after the bluefins at the earliest opportunity can plan to be at Bimini not later than May 30.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- President Eisenhower entertained at a White House stag dinner tonight for seventeen friends and Government associates.

Mr. Mikoyan's displacement as Minister of Trade appears to be connected directly with the shift of Communist party policy in re cent weeks away from emphasis on consumer goods and toward renewed highest priority for heavy industry.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Adding to its growing stockpile of Broadway plays and musicals, Twentieth Century-Fox announced today its purchase of William Inge's new drama, "Bus Stop."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Rev. Frederick Brown Harris, Senate chaplain, in a prayer opening today's Senate session to hear President Eisenhower's message on Formosa, appealed for Divine help in the face of "fanatical foes to whom human life is nothing."
Points of issue still blocking operations by the Grace Line at the new Pier 45, on the North River, are to be put through the port's new "harmony" machinery.

Action by the city authorities against New York's dirt now seems to be getting under way. Every effective move in this direction will be watched -- and applauded -- by all New Yorkers whose health is menaced, and whose pride is hurt, by the disgraceful conditions that now exist.
Here at the Community Service Society we keenly feel the loss of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow. She served on our Board of Trustees for twenty-four years, latterly as an honorary vice president.
Marking his first television venture, Alfred Hitchcock, the movie director, will supervise the production of thirty-nine films for television.
James C. Petrillo will appear as himself in a documentary film about music and the union he heads, the American Federation of Musicians.

From thousands of entries, the names of 515 retail concerns have been selected to compete for the national Brand Name Retailer-of-the-Year awards to be made at the annual dinner of the Brand Names Foundation on Wednesday, April 13.
Winston-Salem, N. C., an-i nounced yesterday plans for the sale of $3,000,000 of sewage disposal system bonds. Dated Dec. 1, 195. the bond w/]I come due annually on June I from 1957 to 1979.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- In an all-night session that ended at 5:40 A. M. today, French and Tunisian officials were reported to have made some progress toward an agreement on internal autonomy for France's North African protectorate.

TRENTON, Jan. 24 -- The New Jersey Senate voted today to seek a tri-state compact with New York and Pennsylvania on plans for further tapping the water resources of the Delaware River. Assembly approval is expected next Monday.

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Globe, the attraction is "Cattle Queen of Montana," a Western drama presented by R. K. O. with Barbara Stanwyck, Ronald Reagan and Gene Evans heading the cast. Allan Dwan directed and Benedict Bogeaus produced from a script by Howard Estabrook and Robert Blees and a story by Thomas Blackburn.

New York State bankers took a day off from their lending operations yesterday to learn more about the atom's future in industry. Some 1,500 representatives of institutions in this state and adjoining areas gathered at the Commodore Hotel for the twenty-seventh annual midwinter meeting of the New York State Bankers Association.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Governor Harriman said today it was unfair to hold the Roman Catholic Church responsible for the campaign to legalize bingo.
GROTON, Conn., Jan. 24 (UP) -- The atomic-powered submarine Nautilus was back in port today after a week of "satisfactory" sea tests.

The one-story bulding containing 14,000 square feet of space at 10-02 Forty-fourth Drive in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the W. M. Metal Products Company from Hilda-Belle Gutman. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker in the transaction.
Cardinal Spellman presented last night the 1954 Club of Champions Gold Medal of the Catholic Youth Organization to J. Peter Grace Jr.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 24 -- The Georgia Senate today passed Gov. Marvin Griffin's bill barring the spending of state money for any school in which the races were mixed.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 25 -- Advocates of increasing Soviet consumer goods production at the expense of heavy industry have been denounced by a high functionary of the Communist party.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The level of the Seine started dropping this afternoon, averting major damage to Paris. But downstream hundreds of communities rushed preparations against the crest of the flood, scheduled to hit them later in the week.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 24 -- Lieut. Col. Miguel Angel Mendoza was removed this afternoon as director general of the Civil Guard upon orders of President Carlos Castillo Armas.

There can no longer be any doubt that the federal security program is one of the major domestic headaches of this Administration. It will probably remain so, as it should, until there is some substantial and meaningful reform of the present situation.

BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Massachusetts State Boxing Commission today suspended the license of the Sharkey Athletic Association to conduct bouts and revoked the license of the matchmaker, John Buckley Jr.

Elizabeth cutter Morrow was a woman of such talents, such fine perceptions, such energy in good causes of education and social welfare that she distinguished herself in several fields. Out of her lifelong interest in education she gave devoted service to various institutions, including her own Smith College, where for an interim year she was the first woman president.
After its two-week stand at the City Center, William Saroyan's "The Time of Your Life" may have another hearing at the Playhouse for an indefinite time.
Long cherished belongings from a heyday of the decorative arts are dramatized at an antiques show that opened last night.

Six members of the British Women's squash racquets team arrived here yesterday aboard the Queen Mary. The squad will compete in the United States singles championship tournament and the Wolfe-Noel Challenge Cup matches next month.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to approve the Government's withdrawal from the synthetic rubber industry by selling twenty-four plants to private buyers for $310,565,000.

ROME, Jan. 22 -- Unique fabrics woven on hand looms on the island of Capri are beautifully handled in the collection of Tessetrice Dell' Isola [Weaver of the Island]. The weaver is Baroness Gallotti, who has a shop bearing her name.

Vorkuta, the slave-labor camp from which two Americans were recently released, is the subject of a book that Holt will issue Feb. 17. The author is Joseph Scholmer, a German doctor, who was a prisoner at the camp for more than three years. In "Vorkuta," he tells of his experiences and "the first mass strike ever held in the U. S. S. R."
An American "Salute to France," offering distinguished examples of this country's musical, dance and theatrical accomplishments, will be presented in Paris next spring.

Julian Blaustein, the producer, and Daniel Taradash, the writer, who recently formed Phoenix Productions, have signed a long-term deal with Warner Brothers to release the product of their independent company.

BERLIN, Jan. 25 -- The city planners of West Berlin announced today a new plan for Am Zoo, its "Times Square." The plan is intended to combine the new home of the clothing industry, theatre and restaurants and prevent congestion.
A radio patrol car captured a teen-ager last night minutes after he had assaulted a young United Nations guide on Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- The American Merchant Marine Institute declared today that most of the privately owned United States cargo and passenger fleet was rapidly becoming uneconomical. The group contended that nine out of ten ships would be unprofitable to operate within six to ten years.
An eye-witness account of the slaying last July of a Brooklyn fisherman during a $1 robbery was given yesterday in Kings County Court by one of the alleged participants.

Metal prices, ever sensitive to wars and fears of wars, moved upward in world markets yesterday as the House of Representatives voted to give the President power to act in defense of Formosa. Volume in the various metals was heavy on the New York Commodity Exchange.

Commodity futures prices were strong in heavy trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. The news concerning Formosa pushed coffee, cocoa and wool sharply higher and lent strength to sugar, copper, zinc, lead, tin, hides, cottonseed oil and soybean oil. Potatoes also closed higher. Only rubber and burlap did not end higher in all traded positions. Most items registered or were close to new highs in volume for the year.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- It's enough to make a woman weep to think of what happens to all those fashionable frocks and gowns when Queen Elizabeth, Princess Margaret and the Queen Mother are finished with them.
EAST HAMPTON, Conn., Jan. 25 (AP) -- A private twin-engine plane crashed and burned in Meshomasic State Forest tonight, killing the two persons aboard.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Government securities today ended a long run of declines. A rally was touched off by the reduction in United States Treasury bill rate. On the other hand, industrials reacted further on the Formosan situation, although selling was light.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson has set up a special committee to review his department's security-risk program.

The merger of Chase National Bank into the Bank of the Manhattan Company "would result in an intensification of competition, rather than a lessening of competition," Chase's chairman, John J. McCloy, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

OTTAWA, Jan. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Five Canadian rubber companies, charging the Federal Anti-Combines Injunctions Law is an invasion by Parliament of a Provincial field, were granted leave today to appeal their illegal price-fixing convictions before the Supreme Court of Canada.
Most business men expect sales and profits in the second quarter of 1955 to be better than in the like period of 1954, Dun Bradstreet reports.
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 25 -- The white ballroom of the Pitti Palace was crowded last evening for the showing by Capucci of Rome.

NO one knows a salmon river as well as the man who lives on one. Eldred Bailey, who operates Jack Russell's Camp on the Miramichi in New Brunswick, insists that the upper stretches of that river should not be included in the "indifferent season" reports that covered most salmon waters last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Spokesmen for some business, labor and other groups backed President Eisenhower's foreign trade program at a Congressional hearing today. However, away from the Capitol a big group of the program's foes mapped plans for a bitter fight.
The Brooklyn Eagle told its readers yesterday that it would be forced to suspend publication if craft-union members honored a strike scheduled by the New York Newspaper Guild for midnight Friday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Sewell L. Avery, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., blasted today the move of Louis E. Wolfson to gain control of the mall - order house as a "financial venture launched for the benefit of backers and himself."

TO watch a star made in front of your own eyes is always one of the entertainment world's most exciting experiences; such an event occurred last Sunday on the Jack Benny program. Gisele MacKenzie stepped out from the comparative anonymity of "Your Hit Parade" and was nothing short of sensational as the guest on the comedian's program.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Higher prices were registered for all grain and soybean futures in the early trade this morning. Then there was a midday recession, followed by a strong closing rally in soybeans, wheat and rye. Developments in the Chinese situation started free short covering.

Baseball rule-makers' latest attack on the intentional pass by restricting the movements of the catcher found an assorted array of local ballplayers more or less in accord in their opinions yesterday.

A rugged, 33-year-old war hero who calls his wounds "nicks" -- and doesn't remember how many times he was "nicked" -- gave up his second lieutenant's bars in the Army for the stripes of a master sergeant yesterday.
Space-saving furnishings and "install-it-yourself" floorings are some of the practical decorating ideas in a series of small, pleasant room settings on view at Abraham Straus.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said today he would insist that national security have priority over economizing.

Eight new residents of apartments for the aged in the Carver Houses were busy proving yesterday that you are only as old as you feel. Scrub brushes, dust mops and all the paraphernalia that accompany moving into a new home were being wielded by men and women with a zest that defied their average age of 70.

The National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. announced yesterday that Mrs. Doris Clore Demaree, a farm woman of Franklin, Ind., had won "Protestantism's highest award to a lay person" in 1955.

Greater New York's three major league ball clubs reported six contract signers yesterday. The Giants led with four. The Dodgers and Yanks each had one.
PANAMA, Jan. 25 -- Panama and the United States signed a new treaty on the Canal Zone today.
An agreement was reached last night ending the threat of a strike by 3,200 garage workers in Manhattan and the Bronx.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 25 -- More than 300 cornered Costa Rican rebels marched into internment in Nicaragua today and abated the danger of conflict between that country and Costa Rica.
A mass X-ray program to consolidate the gains already made against tuberculosis was outlined yesterday by Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Representatives of the Maritime Administration and the coastwise and intercoastal dry cargo trade laid the groundwork today for a broad study of the trade's needs.

AMONG the variously rewarding art exhibitions this week is one of special interest, that of about a hundred lithographs by the nineteenth century French artist Honore Daumier. His work is being shown at Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Andy Crevolin's Imbros, ridden by Johnny Longden, beat a talent-loaded field today in the $10,000 Flashco Mile at Santa Anita Park. There were four winners of $100,000 purses in the race.
International Paper Company announced yesterday that it will construct a $20,000,000 newsprint mill in the South.
For the sixth straight week, Kentucky's team is first in The Associated Press basketball poll.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A plot to overthrow President Gen. Alfredo Stroessner has been discovered and crushed, the Government announced today. The country was reported calm.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., permanent representative of the United States here, will represent the United States at the United Nations subcommittee on disarmament in London next month, it was announced today.

An eight-day period of prayer for Christian unity ended last night at St. Patrick's Cathedral. "Missionary Conquest of the World for Christ" was the sermon subject, with emphasis on Roman Catholic missions in Communist-controlled China.

The Harlem Globetrotters and the College All-Americans will begin their sixth annual "world series" basketball tour on Sunday, March 27, at Madison Square Garden. Afternoon and night contests are booked for that date.

To command respect both must have winners which return the glory to the judges by their excellence.
