HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 -- The formation of Crown Productions, the new independent producing company to be headed by Robert Goldstein, Robert L. Jacks and Spyros S. and Plato Skouras, was announced today.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 25 -- The head of the country's biggest union wants authority to invest part of its millions in corporate stocks.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Charfran Stable's Cascanuez was an impressive winner of the Florida Gold Purse before 17,841 at Hialeah Park today. The Argentine-bred 7-year-old son of Partab scored by three and a half lengths over L. Chesler's Assuan under a fine ride by Robert Ussery.

The general manager of Station WABC-TV expressed criticism yesterday of the quality of daytime television programs and announced a new schedule that would eliminate fashion, interview, cooking and beauty care shows from his station.

The 200-room Van Rensselaer Hotel at 13 to 19 East Eleventh Street, a landmark of the lower Fifth Avenue section, has been sold by Rensselaer Estates, Inc., Samuel D. Bierman, president, to Hotel Van Rensselaer, Inc., a former lessee of the property.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 25 -- Governor General Ghulam Mohammed of Pakistan declared on his arrival here by air today that he would be prepared to hold talks with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru on outstanding disputes between the two countries, provided the discussions were initiated by Indian leaders.

Thieves who evidently knew just what they wanted took a full-length brown mink coat val-used at $3,500, a blue frost mink jacket priced at $700 and several boxes of jewelry totaling $20,000 from two bedroom closets and touched nothing else in the ground-floor apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Arden, 155 Riverside Drive.
The engineering crossroads of the world are in two buildings of old-fashioned elegance, nestled back-to-back in midtown New York.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh imposed maximum fines yesterday on landlords who had failed to make court-ordered repairs to tenements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Someday someone may get away with the boast that his ancestors came over with the Vikings. But not today. Not, at least, if Dr. Johannes Brondsted gets wind of it.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams today selected Sid Gillman, head coach of the University of Cincinnati, to coach their National Football League team in 1955. Terms were not disclosed.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Wanda Krylow gave birth today to twins with a combined weight of twenty pounds, four and a half ounces, which is probably a world record.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25 -- The nation's highway transportation system is basically, inadequate and inefficient, traffic safety administrators heard today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Eisenhower will start tomorrow a series of political breakfasts with his women supporters.
MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet Union's declaration of an end to the state of war with Germany follows:
Small hats that call attention to the face were a feature yesterday in the showing of spring milinery at Oppenheim Collins.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The United States champion, Vic Seixas, was set to meet Australia's Lewis Hoad today in the feature quarter-final match of the Australian national tennis championship.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 25 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas served notice to the Guatemalan nation tonight that his administration was through with soft policies toward internal enemies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Atomic radiation experts gave reassuring advice today on how to live with atomic energy in a new industrial age.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 25 -- Franklin L. Coates of Weston, Conn., for twenty years organist and choirmaster at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, (Little Church Around the Corner) New York, will assume these same duties at St. John's Episcopal Church here on Feb. 1.

The warning signal which President Eisenhower has raised against further Communist aggression in the Far East has been duly noted and, except for inevitable Communist misinterpretation, has been greeted with widespread approval both at home and abroad. In one respect it has served to bring a sharper realization of the dangers lurking in Formosa Strait.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy revived today his dispute with the Army over Pvt. Marvin Sanford Belsky.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 -- Ernest R. Breech, who has served as executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company since 1946, was elected chairman today. Henry Ford 2d, president, announced Mr. Breech's election along with four other top-level personnel changes after a meeting of the directors in Dearborn.

Needy boys will continue to enjoy the sports, educational and health activities at Kips Bay Boys Club as a result of the organization's annual dinner dance. The event will take place April 21 in the ballroom of the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Attorney General urged Congress today to deprive the "bookmaking racket" of its private wire services.

An exhibition of memorabilia connected with Ethel Barrymore's career as an actress will be opened to the public today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. A preview for museum members and guests was held yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Overseas exports of coal last year amounted to 15,471,200 tons, an increase of 1,172,500 tons for the year, the Coal Exporters' Association announced today.

THE American Opera Society has done it again. Last night it dusted off Bellini's "La Sonnambula" and let us hear how fresh and exquisite are its melodies. In a Town Hall performance led by Arnold U. Gamson with exciting enthusiasm, the society brought together a troupe of fine singers and proved that the genius of Bellini can work its spell on a modern audience.
Thousands of the city's physically handicapped are being deprived of existing services because of inadequate transportation facilities.
The nation's largest steel producer moved yesterday to split its common stock two-for-one and it raised its quarterly dividend -- by 25 cents a share -- for the first time in more than four years.
PARIS, Jan. 25 -- River levels continued to fall throughout France today and water-logged communities started taking stock of the damage.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A Senate investigating panel urged today that lessons learned from the Korean war be kept in mind as new United States policy on Formosa developed.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The fate of five of Governor Harriman's Cabinet nominees as public servants was unresolved today. The Governor said they still were full-fledged state officers despite the expiration today of what some Republicans considered a deadline for their confirmation.
The merchant fleet of the United States is ill-equipped to take advantage of the new conditions for shipping on the Great Lakes that will result from completion of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The State Board of Parole refused today for the second time in two years to parole Joseph C. (Joey) Fay.

A pre-trial examination of officers of the Colonial Trust Company is scheduled to go into its second session today at White Plains, N. Y. The examination resulted from an equity action brought in Supreme Court in Westchester and New York Counties last month against the bank and several of its officers by Thomas J. O'Neill, a Westchester attorney, and a stockholder in the bank.
The first ship built by the Germans as part of the reparations program negotiated with Israel will arrive in New York on her maiden voyage today
A $500,000 fund set up last May by the Tobacco Industry Research Committee for independent scientific research into tobacco use and health has been increased to $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to remedy a "rather critical" situation by raising the pay of Federal judges.

Seven hundred authors, critics and book publishers responded with a rising ovation here yesterday when Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, assailed today's "remorseless pressures to conform."

An apartment house with offices and stores is planned for the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-second Street. The site has been leased from the Astor estate by the 681 Madison Corporation, of which Joseph P. Blitz is president.

The great Kremlin debate of recent months on economic policy appears to be over, with Nikita S. Khrushchev the clear victor. Anastas I. Mikoyan is the chief loser. At issue in this debate was whether the promises of a rapidly rising standard of living made by Premier Malenkov in 1953 should be fulfilled, even at the expense of heavy industrial expansion.

Delegates to the United Nations from eleven countries looked on yesterday as Sir Pierson Dixon, chief of the United Kingdom's delegation, conducted the draw for the 1955 European Zone Davis Cup competition. Numerous officials of the United States Lawn Tennis Association attended the ceremony at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Shortly before the High Court of Justice today acquitted Georges Hilaire, former Prefect, of charges of collaboration with the Nazis, four other former Vichy officials surrendered to the police and asked for a retrial.

VIENNA, Jan. 25 -- Reversion to the policy of forcing heavy industry that was proclaimed yesterday in Moscow, found a prompt echo today in Hungary. Matyas Rakosi, the Hungarian Communist party's No. 1 man, told a coal miners' meeting:

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on $19,230,000 of notes for the temporary financing of two state-aided projects, Frederick Douglass Houses in Manhattan and Marlboro Houses in Brooklyn. The notes will be dated Feb. 21 and come due on Oct. 10.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Veterans Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives today unanimously approved a bill to let men in service by Jan. 31 keep accumulating "G. I." schooling rights.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The court appointed by the Government to inquire into the dispute that nearly caused a nation-wide railroad strike early this month urged today a detailed study of some aspects of the nationalized railroads' operations.
"The Grand Prize," starring June Lockhart and John Newland, will be placed on exhibition at 8 o'clock tonight at the Plymouth. Shepard Traube is the producer-director of Ronald Alexander's comedy.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 25 -- A Rutgers University course in "Understanding Labor-Management Relations" will begin at 8 P. M., Monday in Newark, but only nine students will greet the teacher, Prof. Monroe Berkowitz.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Sir Winston Churchill rejected today Laborite demands that he meet Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov to discuss the situation in the Far East.
A team of noise-abatment experts had some encouragement yesterday for people who live near airports and wince at the thought of tomorrow's jet airliners.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. ATKA, in Antarctic, Jan. 24 -- Its investigation of Kainan Bay completed, this Navy icebreaker sailed north into the ice pack today in a renewed effort to find an entry into the Sulzberger Bay area of Antarctica.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 25 -- Today's Soviet decision to end the state of war with Germany added fuel to the bitter struggle between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the Social Democratic Opposition over the question of immediate four-power negotiations to reunify Germany.

Jules Bohy gave us his idea the other day of what he would like to serve if he were having a small dinner party in his apartment in a West Side residential hotel. The blithe, bustling little Frenchman is spending the winter in this country as chief representative of the Chevaliers du Tastevin, French fraternity of Burgundy wine lovers.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The Republican - controlled Legislature approved two tax abatement bills today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Ratification hearings on the mutual defense treaty with Nationalist China may get under way tomorrow after two false starts.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (AP) -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, flying through fog to keep an important date, his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary, landed at Los Angeles International Airport tonight to a tumultuous reception.

Newspapers finished the year with an advertising spurt that sent linage 2.3 per cent ahead of the 1953 level in the closing month. However, the rise was not enough to put the total for the year above the 1953 figure.

The House Ways and Means Committee, now considering "H.R. 1," the bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, had before it yesterday a highly competent witness in the person of Daniel W. Bell, former Under Secretary of the Treasury.

FORT SILL, Okla., Jan. 25 (UP) -- Maj. Ambrose H. Nugent charged today that the Army originally had accused him of committing outright treason while a Korean war prisoner but later softened the allegation to keep his case out of a civilian Federal court.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Jan. 25 (AP) -- A newspaper reporter posing as a Soviet colonel had no trouble penetrating the United States' answer to the Iron Curtain yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 25 -- Vigilance against trade abuses provides the strongest bulwark against economic dislocation, the garment industry was told today.
LUEBECK, Germany, Jan. 25 (Reuters) -- The appearance of two turkeys in church frescoes supposed to have dated back to the thirteenth century helped today to convict two German painters for fraud.
The New York Zoological Society received last year $457,498 in grants and contributions for its research, building and wildlife activities.

Today's new film is "The Violent Men," a Western drama marking Columbia Pictures' first CinemaScope offering, at Loew's State. Glenn Ford, Barbara Stanwyck and Edward G. Robinson have the principal roles. Dianne Foster, Brian Keith, May Wynn and Warner Anderson head the supporting cast.
PLAYING of a breadth and tonal magnificence seldom met with in these days characterized the major performances of the recital that Alexander Brailowsky, the pianist, gave last night in Carnegie Hall.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 25 -- The Soviet-Finnish trade pact for 1955 signed yesterday in Moscow was called satisfactory by G. Palmroth, the signatory for Finland, who returned here today.
The New York Zoological Society received last year $457,498 in grants and contributions for its research, building and wildlife activities.

Today's new film is "The Violent Men," a Western drama marking Columbia Pictures' first CinemaScope offering, at Loew's State. Glenn Ford, Barbara Stanwyck and Edward G. Robinson have the principal roles. Dianne Foster, Brian Keith, May Wynn and Warner Anderson head the supporting cast.

ONE day next week the special Old-Timers Committee, headed by J. G. Taylor Spink of the Sporting News, will assemble to vote a couple of ancients into the Baseball Hall of Fame. One candidate worthy of consideration is George (Hooks) Wiltse, the lean and talented left-hander who Joined the Giants a little more than a half century ago.

The secret eyes and ears of the Federal Government, otherwise known as the Central Intelligence Agency, have been receiving an unusual amount of serious attention lately. A special Presidentially appointed group headed by Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle (ret.) made a confidential survey of certain aspects of the C. I. A. last fall, and reported that the organization was doing "a creditable job" but that some changes were needed.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- The implications of another Far Eastern crisis have not yet begun to frighten Europe's public to anything like the same degree as the first summer of the Korean war or the tense days when Washington pondered all-out intervention at Dienbienphu. Neither Britain nor any Continental Power feels emotionally involved in China.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Britain is building up her air power in Southeast Asia under a United States-Commonwealth design to group more strength in the Far East.
Martin Rich, an assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera since 1950, last night made his debut as a full-fledged conductor by leading a performance of "Manon."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner ruled today that Doubleday Co., Inc., could not sell its books through its own book club at prices lower than it fixes for bookstores.
PLAYING of a breadth and tonal magnificence seldom met with in these days characterized the major performances of the recital that Alexander Brailowsky, the pianist, gave last night in Carnegie Hall.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 25 -- The Soviet-Finnish trade pact for 1955 signed yesterday in Moscow was called satisfactory by G. Palmroth, the signatory for Finland, who returned here today.

New issues of corporate debt securities totaling $55,000,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. The securities are obligations of Consumers Power Company and United States Plywood Corporation, and represent the refinancing of old debt and the raising of new money to pay for expansion.
The Brooklyn Civic Council has asked the Transit Authority to fulfill a 1951 pledge by the Board of Transportation to build two subway spurs in that borough.

The industrial property at 2638-40 Park Avenue, running through to 329-30 Canal Place, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Ace Bag and Burlap Company, Inc., through the Joseph G. Platzner Company, broker.
GENEVA, Jan. 25 -- The Geneva trade conference has suddenly taken two important steps toward agreement on a world trade code.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda said today that Far East tension could be relieved only by complete evacuation of United States armed forces from Formosa and by withdrawal of the United States Seventh Fleet from that area.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 25 (AP) -- The folowing report of naval stores selling prices is by the United States Department of Agriculture:

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A pair of German teams posted the best times today in practice for the world four-man bobsled championship, but a quartet of United States airmen assumed a challenging role for the week-end races when they came in close behind the Germans.

Within the next few weeks Mayor Wagner will have to fill three vacancies on the Domestic Relations Court bench. These vacancies afford the city administration an excellent opportunity to raise the caliber of service in this vital and important court.
The perfection of the most accurate timing device known, a molecular clock that will vary no more than one second in 300 years, was announced yesterday at Columbia University.
A civilian passer-by and a policeman ran shouting through a burning building yesterday at 285 St. Nicholas Avenue and sent fifty tenants to safety in the street.

Two widowed sisters used their bare hands and a china vase last night in a plucky but fruitless fight with three masked thugs to save keepsake watches that had belonged to their husbands. The robbers stole $30 in addition to the watches, and fled.
Against official university opposition, a Fordham University Alumni Association committee expressed determination last night to carry on the campaign to restore football on Rose Hill.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Nino Valdes, No. 1 heavyweight contender, knocked out Jack Flood of Spokane, in 2:37 of the seventh round of a scheduled ten-rounder tonight. Valdes weighed 212 pounds and Flood 204.

Employes in the McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West Forty-second Street, will give blood today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Today, also, blood will be collected at St. (Matthias Roman Catholic Church School, 58-15 Catalpa Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, and, from members of Local 1707 Community and Social Agency Employes Union, C. I. O., at 214 East Twenty-first Street, headquarters of the program.
PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Comment here today on President Eisenhower's message on Formosa expressed the hope it would insure peace in the Far East but the fear that it might have the opposite effect.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The House of Representatives voted 409 to 3 today to back President Eisenhower in any military action to safeguard Formosa from the Communists.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- Fiske Kimball has resigned as director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art after thirty years in that post.
PARIS, Wednesday, Jan. 26 -- The French Cabinet decided today to name Jacques Soustelle, a leader of the Gaullists in the National Assembly, as Governor General of Algeria.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The television committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association opened a two-day organizational meeting today in secrecy.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Jan. 25 -- A 55-year-old woman saved her two grandchildren by tossing them from a third-story window into the arms of policemen and then was burned to death in a fire early today. The fire swept through a three-story building at 300 Richmond Street.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Jan. 25 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has established a new double-major course, embodying both liberal arts and science.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- The Soviet Union has tested more hydrogen and atomic weapons than official announcements indicate and now is actually making hydrogen bombs, Highly qualified sources said today.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Mayor Wagner submitted to the state today a program for raising $136,700,000 in additional revenue for the City of New York.
One television and two radio networks have set aside for the first time regular broadcast periods for presentations on President Eisenhower's news conferences.

" TANNHAEUSER" is certainly a romantic opera, in the true Wagnerian definition of that term. This opera proves its strength by its longevity and the delight that its spectacle and its square-toed arias and ensembles give the public.
BERLIN, Jan. 26 -- The East German Communist Government announced today that subsidies to state-owned industries must end.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom has pledged that his Government will take no action to turn South Africa into a republic before the present Parliament ends in 1958.

A tendency for young people to leave home at an earlier age to establish their own households was described last night in an analysis of recent population figures. William Hodgkinson Jr. of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company held the tendency was one of the factors in the creation of 7,500,000 new households in the last six years.

" Sir Henry" must be Robert Nathan's twentieth or thirtieth novel, give or take a handful, and it is one of his best. Toward the end it gets a little boggy with Nathanesque ruefulness and wistfulness. But the irony is well wrought.
A blood bank for pets similar to banks maintained for human beings will be set up by the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital, 350 Lafayette Street, it was announced last night.

From the confines of a three-ton armored truck, manned by three armed guards, a thirty-four-pound sack containing $50 in pennies took wing on First Avenue yesterday. The episode sent a series of cold chills rippling successively through the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank's branch at Lexington Avenue and Sixtieth Street, the Wells Fargo Armored Service Corporation and the three armed guards.
The charge that Government enforcement of anti-monopoly laws has virtually broken down was made yesterday by Senator Estes Kefauver.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- The Inland Steel Company announced today that its net earnings set a new high in 1954. The company had earlier reported record steel production in the year.
Legalizing of bingo to support religious institutions was opposed yesterday by the New York Board of Rabbis.
The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, one of the three leading United States manufacturers of tobacco products, reported yesterday small declines in sales and earnings last year.
A tiny "missing link" crustacean never before observed in nature even as a fossil has been discovered in Long Island Sound.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Twenty to forty thousand children now considered unadoptable might find homes if outmoded restrictions were dropped.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Foes of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act opened their attack today.

OMAHA, Jan. 26 -- John W. Snyder, former Secretary of the Treasury, appeared here today as a witness before a Federal grand jury investigating alleged misconduct in the Bureau of Internal Revenue during the Truman Administration.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The State Department of Taxation and Finance is cracking down on brokerage houses that specialize in "penny stocks."

In Arthur Krock's column of Jan. 14 he wrote that the proposal of Representative Kenneth B. Keating that the Chief Justice of the United States shall address annually a joint session of Congress on "The State of the Judiciary" would expose the Chief Justice to "the suspicion he might take advantage of the opportunity thus offered to make himself President."
The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest industrial enterprise, last year attained the second highest sales and earnings in its history.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh has delivered a stern lesson to all landlords in New York City who trifle with the lives and health of tenement house tenants. Dealing with a remnant of the 3,240 who had appeared in Manhattan court on July 29, he imposed fines of $500 each on sixteen landlords and $1,500 on another.

Sixty-eight high school youngsters toured hospitals, children's shelters, settlement houses and homes for the aged yesterday as part of a Junior Red Cross leadership training program. They learned about Red Cross work in those institutions and about the possibilities of service within themselves.

A large subscription has been reported for the annual dance of the Parents Guild of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The dance will be held on the night of Feb. 11 at Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 -- Four Indian elephants, splendid in ceremonial gold, met the jet age in New Delhi today and did not care much for it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The White House announced today it would make changes in approximately 1,200 identification cards used to gain entry to the Presidential offices. They are issued to Government officials, reporters, photographers and others.

Without in any way undertaking to disparage the remarkable progress which has been made in air travel in recent years it occurs to me that the comparisons as to both volume and relative costs of travel by air and by railroad made in the editorial "Travel Revolution" in The Times of Jan. 20 are the result of comparing unlike things.
The accessory, shoe and millinery meeting of the Fashion Group, held yesterday at the Sheraton - Astor Hotel, endorsed the long, lean look but advocated bright color to enliven the narrow silhouette.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- A Republican bill to legalize bingo was introduced in the Legislature today.

Britain's permanent delegate to the United Nations declared yesterday that "our purpose is peace and there are no hidden intentions'' in the efforts of the United States, British and New Zealand Governments to bring about a cease-fire in the Formosa area.

Today's new film, at the Victoria, is "Unchained." It is a prison drama filmed at the Chino (Calif.) Institution for men. Elroy Hirsch, Barbara Hale, Chester Morris, Todd Duncan and Johnny Johnston have the principal roles in the Warner Brothers presentation.

A new musical comedy, "Plain and Fancy," relating the adventures of two New Yorkers in the Amish section of Pennsylvania, has its Broadway premiere this evening at 8 o'clock at the Mark Hellinger Theatre.

" Korun: Around the World, 1949-52," by Jacques-Yves Le Toumelin, will be issued Feb. 18 by Dutton. The author, a native of Brittany, set out from Le Crosic, France, in 1949 in the Norwegian cutter, Kurun, with one companion, who left him when they reached Morocco.
" No unusual fire hazards" have been found by intensive Fire Department inspections of waterfront hiring halls, according to Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

Without doubt, one of America's outstanding contributions to the art of eating well is the grapefruit. It comes to our stores generally in top condition, both meaty and juicy. Its flavor is equally refreshing, whether the fruit appears at breakfast or concludes a hearty dinner.

Peter Lawrence McLaren, whose colorful career embraced Indian-fighting, mining, sheep ranching and appointment to office by Queen Victoria, died Monday on his ninety-seventh birthday at his home, 759 Clawson Avenue, Oakwood Heights. S. I.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Eight private economists viewed the 1955 business outlook with much reserve and some concern today.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 26 -- Two American Negro troupes opened guest engagements here tonight before packed houses.
The city may have to decide whether to take rapid transit trains off the Manhattan Bridge entirely or build a new bridge, in the opinion of Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.

TORONTO, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and the Montreal Canadiens, scoring three minutes apart in the first period, battled to a 1-1 tie tonight in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 14,270, the largest of the season at Maple Leaf Gardens.

The city of Montreal borrowed $35,000,000 yesterday on an issue of bonds payable in United States dollars at an interest cost of 3.6005 per cent. Montreal plans to use the money to finance various public works projects.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Democratic and Republican leaders in the House of Representatives set out today to reduce the number of investigations.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 26 -Ships and aircraft patrolling Formosa Strait reported today that they had not detected a Communist vessel build-up indicating an immediate invasion of any Nationalist-held island.
The first German passenger-cargo liner built since World War II will make her maiden appearance here late in March.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The stock markets here were brighter today as British Government stocks continued the recovery begun yesterday. Industrial shares also strengthened.
Human adrenal glands, kept alive in a special apparatus for as long as a week, have been observed to produce as many as seventeen hormone-like chemicals.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Odie Spears converted a court-long pass from Bobby Wanzer into a field goal to give the Rochester Royals a 96-94 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 26 -- A new fight was building up today for Sewell Avery.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Robert L. (Bob) Blackman was named head football coach at Dartmouth College tonight shortly after resigning from a similar post at Denver University.
Potato chips with an unusual flavor and a wheat flour teething biscuit for babies are among the new food products now available in grocery stores here.
New York City is moving toward another financial crisis and new taxes "are inevitable," Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Following is the text of Governor Harriman's special message to the Legislature today on juvenile delinquency:
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Sir Anthony Eden upheld United States policy toward Formosa and the Pescadores against a hail of Laborite criticism in the House of Commons today.

Events tonight: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45, and Lonny Epstein, pianist, Ninety-second Street Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The White House announced today the resignation, effective Feb. 19, of Thomas E. Stephens of New York as appointment secretary to President Eisenhower.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Britain told the Soviet Union today that she would not be deflected from the policy of arming West Germany, even if it meant annulment of the British-Soviet treaty of friendship.

Last summer's battering of the Northeast states lifted the technical discussion of hurricanes at the New York Academy of Sciences meeting this week into front page news in terms of public interest. Intensive research on the performances of Carol and of Edna has led the Weather Bureau scientists to the considered conclusion which we hazarded last fall: the entire Atlantic seaboard should now definitely be considered part of the hurricane zone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Eisenhower attended his first "for-ladies-only" breakfast this morning. He urged the women to get down to "brass tacks" to build a strong Republican party at the precinct level.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Soviet skiers outraced cross-country specialists from Norway and Sweden today in an international competition involving stars from seven nations.
The twelve-story office building at 350 Broadway, northeast corner of Leonard Street, has been sold by Nadine Properties, Inc., to an investing client of Daniel D. Cantor, broker in the deal.

BEING a glib and persuasive talker, DeBenneville (Bert) Bell, the lord high commissioner of the National Football League, had virtually convinced most folks of the soundness of his favorite project. For year after year Bell has been sounding off on the subject of the point after touchdown. He wants to abolish it.

The National Can Corporation has acquired two-thirds of the outstanding common stock of the Pacific Can Company, it was announced yesterday. The acquisition represented purchase of approximately 310,000 shares at $28.5714 a share from E. F. Euphrat, president of Pacific Can, his family and associates and the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and M. D. L. Fuller, as trustees.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Department of Agriculture jousted with security again today -- and lost again.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 -- India is deeply worried about the situation in the Far East. There s a fear in this capital that the tensions between the United States and Communist China are at their most critical point.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A Senate committee recommended today limited Federal supervision of employe welfare and pension funds.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 26 -- Nationalist China has agreed "in principle" to withdraw its troops from the Tachen Islands, an authoritative source said today.

RONALD ALEXANDER can write such funny dialogue that he does not like to waste his time putting a play together. His newest play, "The Grand Prize," which opened at the Plymouth last evening, illustrates his genial and irresponsible point of view.
Joseph Paul DiMaggio, son of a humble San Francisco fisherman, swept into baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -- Danielle Darrieux, absent three years from American films, has joined the cast of "Alexander the Great."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Democrats who had been arguing over who gets what choice jobs settled disputes today that threatened to disrupt their return to control of two major House committees.
Two hitch-hikers wearing Air Force uniforms kidnapped and robbed a Pennsylvania milkman yesterday and drove here, where they let him out and took his car.
St. Francis College of Brooklyn defeated Siena College of Albany last night at the II Corps Artillery Armory in Brooklyn, 63 to 48.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 26 (UP) -- Guerrero and his stablemate, Mr. Sullivan, ran one, two today in the $39,810 California Breeders' Champion Stakes at Santa Anita, reversing the order of their finish in a previous stakes race.
A new investment company -- Life Insurance Investors, Inc. -- will offer $22,750,000 of shares to the public today to acquire funds for reinvestment in life insurance companies.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rico, Jan. 26 -- A critical period lies immediately ahead for President Jose Figueres now that the rebellion against his Government has been crushed. At stake, according to experienced observers here, is the President's political stature among his people.
A labor-management agreement in the brewing industry that would have given seniority rights to twenty Negro workers failed yesterday because one of four union locals concerned refused to sign.
Floral prints, linen-like fabrics, the long-torso line patterns and some low prices shared honors yesterday in a fashion show for home seamstresses at Macy's.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Department of Justice asked Congress today for legislation requiring registration of all foreign agents trained in espionage and sabotage.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 -- Some 5,000 longshoremen in the Port of Philadelphia will receive a "package" increase of 17 cents an hour under the terms of a new two-year contract.

Governor Harriman's first annual message to the New York State Legislature on Jan. 5 included proposals of vital significance to the 80,000 civil service employes of the Empire State and thereby to the millions they serve. The Union of State Employes (formerly independent, but now Local 382 of the Government and Civic Employes Organizing Committee, C.I.O.) has for many years included these proposals in its legislative program.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- Ocean-going tonnage moving through the Port of San Francisco last year dropped less than 3 per cent from the 1953 total.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 26 -- A statement issued today by the West German Cabinet in response to the Soviet decision to end the state of war with Germany puzzled Government officials and Government and Opposition Deputies.

Toy guns appear to be a part of every boy's entertainment, Offhand, one might ask what more harm a long-barrel, pearl-handled, six-shooting cap gun does than perhaps annoy the neighbors and fill the playroom with the acrid smell of burning powder.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The five Cabinet appointees of Governor Harriman who have not yet been confirmed by the Senate will continue to receive their state salaries, Controller Arthur Levitt said today.

Bob Jones and Ben Hogan will join tonight in honoring golf stars at the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association dinner. Some 500 duffers, fans and officials will also attend the affair at the Hotel Plaza.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The French Government was not consulted about the United States' decision on Formosa announced in President Eisenhower's message to Congress Monday, it was said on ample authority today.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Laborites criticized in Parliament today alleged failures in the national defense program.
The 1955 variations on the spring suit provided tempting fashions fare yesterday at Russeks' showing at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 19:

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 26 -- Small business needs Government assistance to survive giant competition, a garment industry group said today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- To check illegal trade practices and black marketing in consumer goods the Georgian Communist party has discharged the chiefs of the bread and grocery chains in the Georgian Soviet republic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -President Paul Eugene Magtoire of Haiti arrived today for a threeday state visit. It will be devoted to cultivating good neighborly relations between the United States and Latin America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- No United Nations move toward a cease-fire in the Formosa Strait is expected before next week.
PARIS, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Adalbert Rozsa, first violinist of the Rumanian "People's Ballet" Company which was performing in Paris, long had wanted to escape to freedom.
Coast Guardsmen rescued eight persons yesterday from a military plane ditched in gale-tossed seas 840 miles east of Bermuda.

The Air Force and the Civil Aeronautics Administration reported yesterday "rapid progress" in the installation of a long-range radar unit at Mitchel Air Force Base near Garden City, L. I. The electronic equipment will be used to help control aerial traffic in the metropolitan area.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Harriman urged the Legislature today to support "an all-out frontal attack" on causes of juvenile delinquency. In a special message, the Governor outlined a program aimed at destroying "the forces which distort the behavior of ourchildren and cause untold personal suffering and human waste."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Frank (Pappy) Noel, Associated Press photographer, received the Bronze Star today for his coverage of the Korean conflict and for standing up to the Communists during thirty-two months as their prisoner.

The swift passage of the years is sometimes difficult to realize; but almost a decade has now passed since that bright Sunday morning on the quarterdeck of the battleship Missouri in Tokyo Bay when Gen. Douglas MacArthur reached his greatest hour of triumph.
OTTAWA, Jan. 26 -- The Canadian House of Commons endorsed today the Paris agreements on German rearmament and integration with the West.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, assured Congress today that tension around Formosa need not delay a cut in the army's numerical strength.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Senator Olin D. Johnston fired another blast today at the Administration's personnel security program.

Honduras aims to finance two-thirds of her new $150,000,000 five-year development program herself. The Central American republic is asking a $50,000,000 loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to cover the rest.
Of the $9,400,000,000 estimated gross income of the nation's 130 Class 1 railroads last year, 16 per cent was produced by two systems, the Pennsylvania and the New York Central.
FORT SILL, Okla., Jan. 26 (UP) -- An Army sergeant told a court-martial today that Maj. Ambrose Nugent had offered to help his Communist captors in Korea when they threatened to kill him.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 -- The Atlantic Fishermen's Union, A. F. L., was fined $10,000 today on an anti-trust charge. It was accused of conspiring to monopolize fish catching and distribution in New Bedford, Mass.

An increase of 4,087,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, supplies were 166,285,000 barrels, compared with 162,198,000 a week earlier and 165,815,000 a year earlier.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 27 -- United States Air Force headquarters here announced today that one wing of F-86 Sabrejets had already begun moving from Okinawa to "temporary duty bases" on Formosa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The Government is trying to collect $118,459 in back taxes and penalties from the National Committee to Secure Justice in the Rosenberg Case. United States Tax Court records showed today.
Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, extended an official welcome yesterday to Israel's newest ship, the Dagan, on her maiden voyage to this port.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The text of Britain's note to the Soviet Union on the British-Soviet treaty. (A similar note was delivered by France):

The Tachen Islands are the focal center of the current Formosa crisis as the United States Seventh Fleet prepares for the possible evacuation of the 10,000 to 12,000 Nationalist troops stationed there.
KROTZ SPRINGS, La., Jan. 26 (UP) -- A worker driving through a picket line here died today after "some sort of gas bomb" had been thrown into his automobile.

Mischa Elman, the violinist, was in excellent form for his recital at Carnegie Hall last evening. Mr. Elman had begun well by choosing a program of just the sort of music he plays best -- an example worth emulating by ambitious but inexperienced young recitalists who fill their debut programs with all the most difficult pieces in their repertory, regardless of suitability.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Department of Agriculture rejected today the first competitive bids on 10,000,000 pounds of surplus butter for export to foreign countries. It said the bids were too low.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The moves leading up to Congressional approval of the resolution sought by the President with respect to defending Formosa and the Pescadores are following a familiar path. The House, the popular branch, quickly overcame the misgivings natural in a proposal with such grave potentials and passed the resolution almost unanimously.
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 26 -The dramatic Schuberth collection shown here today belonged for the most part on the stage, in the ballroom scene of an operetta.

GENEVA, Jan. 26 -- From the working man's point of view, 1954 was "probably the best of the post-war years," David Morse, director general of the International Labor Office, said in a statement published here today.

AN awful lot of powder has been burned by riflemen in an effort to attain what is termed "consistent accuracy." And a glance at the record target recently accepted by the National Bench Rest Shooters' Association proves that riflemen have come a long way in recent years.

While the Chinese Communists continue to wage an aggressive campaign, the Russian Communists continue to specialize in psychological warfare based on political maneuvers designed to split the West. The latest move in this direction is the Soviet ukase formally proclaiming the end of the state of war with Germany and the restoration of "peaceful relations."

LOS ANGELES, Jan 26 (AP) -Following is the prepared text of an address by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur at a civic banquet sponsored by the Los Angeles County Council of the American Legion on the dedication of a monument to General MacArthur in MacArthur Park:

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 26 (AP) -- America's Tony Trabert and the three top members of Australia's Davis Cup team reached the semi-finals of the Australian national tennis championships today. The United States champion, Vic Seixas, was among the victims.
Only seventy-five aliens are now in immigration detention in this country, not counting Mexican "wetbacks," Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. reported yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 26 -Unionized truck drivers have scored a major breakthrough in labor's campaign for a guaranteed wage.

The arrival of a new French Ambassador to the United States is at all times an event of friendly significance. This time there is special interest because we have been used to the same Ambassador -- the remarkably successful Henri Bonnet -- for ten years. Before that we had the war years.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- A reexamination of our China policy was urged tonight by a Columbia University historian.
Each of the ten bus companies holding city franchises operated at a profit in 1954, the Transit Advisory Commission reported yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- A pre-trial examination of witnesses, in an equity suit brought by a bank stockholder to halt acquisition of the Colonial Trust Company by Chesapeake Industries, Inc., an Ohio holding company, was adjourned here today and referred to a court-appointed referee.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- The Westchester Planning Department assured uneasy residents today that every big cloud of construction dust in the county had a silver lining.
DUGWAY, Utah, Jan. 26 -- Ordnance experts gave this wintry desert country a Fourth of July appearance today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Two Senate committees overwhelmingly backed President Eisenhower today on the question of military action to safeguard Formosa.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 26 -- Finland is watching the progress of the ratification of the Paris agreements on West German armament with some concern. Helsinki feels that if Norway ratifies the agreements. Moscow may insist that Finland join an Eastern Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Today is the 199th anniversary of the birth of just about the world's greatest genius in delight. The nomination is debatable, of course.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter today appointed Dr. Nils Y. Wessell, president of Tufts College, as chairman of a committee to study the Massachusetts correctional system and penal code. The study was prompted by a revolt of four convicts at the state prison last week.
Contractors serving the armed forces are running into a security problem in their advertising.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Senator Thomas E. Martin, Republican of Iowa, today urged adoption of President Eisenhower's military reserve program. But, he warned, such a step wouId not be the easy way out. '
To help the city's needy, the Volunteers of America spent $100,000 more in 1954 than in 1953.
President Eisenhower, in a message to the American Jewish Committee, called yesterday for strong support from "men of goodwill throughout the world" in behalf of religious freedom.
The directors of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., have elected Joseph F. Cullman 3d as executive vice president, it was announced yesterday by O. Parker McComas, president of the cigarette company.
Two convicted Communist leaders offered yesterday to leave this country if their jail sentences were reduced to the time already served.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 26 -- Some apprehension exists here regarding the possible consequences of President Eisenhower's request to Congress for sanction to use United States armed forces in the defense of Formosa. It is feared the request may result in conflict with Communist China if the United States fights to keep the Nationalists at Quemoy and other islands just off the China coast.
Bert Bell, commissioner of the National Football League, was empowered yesterday by the club owners of the professional circuit to negotiate a "just and honorable" peace with the Canadian leagues.

IT is seldom these days that one gets to hear a program of music devoted entirely to Palestrina. That, in part, helped to account for the sold-out house last night in Town Hall. Another factor was the presence of the Dessoff Choirs conducted by Paul Boepple.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tmorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
John Kiba, a 41-year-old electronics worker of Akron, Ohio, flew here yesterday to confer with officials about visiting his brother, an airman held prisoner in Communist China.

Topics of The Times for Jan. 21 is overly impressed with those findings from college placement departments and business surveys about the importance of "getting along with people" as a must for success in the world of industry. It is even suggested that "schools squeeze in somewhere a course catalogued simply 'People.'"

Erv Palica and Bob Milliken, both righthanded pitchers, returned their signed contracts for 1955 to the Brooklyn Dodgers yesterday. Their acquisition brought the Dodger roster to thirty-one players under contract.

MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Some highly regarded handicap horses, prepping for the $100,000 added Widener, tried out their speed in the $20,550 Palm Beach Handicap today but couldn't catch Maurice Sims' Blessbull before 18,846 fans at Hialeah Park.
Steel shares ran wild on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday under the stimulus of United States Steel's higher dividend and stock-split plan, announced after the close Tuesday.
Another chapter in the history of the old Wanamaker store property was written yesterday. A syndicate of investors announced that it had bought the landmark from the department store family.

Impetus to the March of Dimes drive of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was given yesterday in a ceremony at Governors Island that was attended by nearly 1,000 persons, mostly soldiers.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Following is the text of a statement on Formosa by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today:
The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency will get a thorough briefing in stock market history and procedure before the Fulbright investigation gets under way.

It was a sort of bargain day yesterday in Long Island City (Queens) Magistrate's Court when Magistrate Thomas Fitzpatrick imposed fines totaling $233 on 106 culprits in the city's drive on litterbugs.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26 -- Travel in Yugoslavia by foreign military representatives stationed in Belgrade has been formally restricted.

When Dean Quinby was ringing doorbells in Rochester in the late Thirties he had a big idea and a little business. The plan consisted of selling a plan for accumulating top-grade common stock -- in this case, Eastman Kodak Company.
Two large apartment properties in New Jersey have passed to new ownership. One is the largest of its type in Passaic and the other is a blockfront property known as Lakeview Gardens in Englewood.

S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, told stockholders yesterday that the bank was interested in obtaining more branches in New York City, by either setting up new ones or acquiring existing systems.
MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Vonnie Colby of Hollywood, Fla., beat a strong breeze, fast greens and a field of the nation's top amateurs today to win the medal in the Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament.

The five-story building containing three stores and twenty-nine apartments at 196 Stockton Street in Brooklyn has been sold by B. Klinkowitz to an investing client of Wolin Stein, attorneys. The property occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet.

The formal signing of contracts for a world featherweight championship bout between Sandy Saddler, the defender from New York, and Ted (Red Top) Davis of Hartford, Conn., took place yesterday. The event will be staged in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 25.
A prankish ride atop a subway car from Brooklyn to Manhattan ended in tragedy for a 15-year-old boy last night.
The United States Steel Corporation's plan for a stock split appears to have been one of the best-kept secrets sprung on Wall Street in a long time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Associates of the late Louis Stark a New York Times labor reporter for many years, established a foundation today to honor his memory in the field of labor- management relations.
Two giant turbo-generators have started feeding electrical energy to the Atomic Energy Commission's huge uranium diffusion plant near Portsmouth, Ohio.
A courageous policeman helped to rescue eight persons yesterday from a burning building at 2993 Fulton Street, Brooklyn. He suffered minor burns and smoke poisoning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics urged today "unceasing effort" toward development of atomic power plants for planes.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur tonight urged this nation to "now proclaim our readiness to abolish war in concert with the great powers of the world."
PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France and former Premier Rene Mayer clashed over North African policy today at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Radical party.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Claude M. Lightfoot today became the first Communist party member to be convicted of knowingly belonging to an organization that conspired against the Government.
Dry goods wholesalers yesterday opposed any change in fair trade price legislation or in the 75-cent minimum wage.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 26 (AP) -Joey Giardello, clumsy and a bit slow, rallied in the last three rounds tonight to gain a unanimous decision over Al Andrews in a ten-round bout at Norfolk's Municipal Auditorium.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Representative Daniel J. Flood, Democrat of Pennsylvania, today proposed that ships be required to report their positions at sea every twenty-four hours.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, Soviet Deputy Premier, was conspicuously present today at a reception in the Indian Embassy in Moscow.

A tramp steamer that had run out of fuel and drifted 250 miles in the Atlantic was under way again last night after the skipper succeeded in waving down a passing mariner and getting a "siphon-assist."

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Directors of Commonwealth Edison Company voted today to distribute the company's holdings of 4,982,115 shares of Northern Illinois Gas Company common stock to Edison stockholders. The distribution will be made on or about March 1 to holders of record on Feb. 2, in the ratio of three shares of gas company common for each ten shares of Edison stock outstanding.
The United Sandy Hook Pilots Association has asked the New York Legislature for a $1-a-foot increase in fees for maneuvering transoceanic and domestic shipping into and out of the port.

As one who has frequently written in your columns letters of criticism for the United States Government's policies in Latin America I hope you will accept the present letter of commendation. The attitude of the United States Government toward the recent invasion of Costa Rica is worthy of nothing but praise.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 26 -- President Carlos Castillo Armas, who lashed out at political enemies in a speech last-night, turned his indignation today on economic enemies.
DALLAS, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A $12,000,000 suit against thirteen major league baseball teams was settled today for $200,000.
A flotilla of fireboats and hundreds of firemen braved thick clouds of smoke and high-leaping flames in battling an all-night fire that destroyed an abandoned 950-foot pier in Hoboken.
In an effort to end "intolerable delays" on the northbound lanes of the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive, left turns will be barred at three points, effective today.
Two scientists and a scientific news agency last night received the 1955 awards of the American Meteorological Society. The recipients were:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The fear of being branded unjustly as subversive may cause foundations to stop supplying "risk capital" for philanthropic and educational purposes, Dr. Robert M. Hutchins asserted today.

Chief Inspector Stephen P. Kennedy inspected yesterday the new branch of the crime laboratory that opened Tuesday in Police Headquarters Annex, 400 Broome Street. The $4,000 chemical laboratory will be used primarily to analyze narcotics seized in misdemeanor arrests.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Commodity futures on the New York Exchanges declined yesterday under the pressure of continued profit taking following the sharp rises earlier in the week and liquidation based on the belief of some traders that the Far Eastern crisis has eased.
Protestants, Roman Catholics and Jews were cautioned yesterday against indulging in the "questionable luxury" of attacking one another's faiths.
TULLAHOMA, Tenn., Jan. 27 -- Man-made wind velocities of up to 3,000 miles an hour were brought nearer today.

Operators of thirteen major ski areas in Massachusetts' Berkshire Mountains were hoping yesterday for their first active week-end of the season. More snow, however, was needed at most of the developments to insure good conditions.
OSAKA, Japan, Jan. 26 -- Pressure for increased trade with Communist China is building up in this commercial capital of Japan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, whose affectionate and reverent soubriquet is "the old man," went at once to the heart of the issue today when he opened the formal Senate debate on the Formosa-Pescadores resolution. "I ask each man," he cried, "what is his alternative?"
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Auguste Lecoeur, once a powerful figure in the French Communist party, was excluded from it today for one year.

The National Broadcasting Company plans another monthly series of ninety-minute television programs in color. It will consist of eight established plays to be produced by Maurice Evans and presented every fourth Sunday afternoon, beginning in October.

" Qataban and Sheba: Exploring the Ancient Kingdoms on the Biblical Spice Routes of Arabia" has been written by Dr. Wendell Phillips, who organized and led four expeditions to Southern Arabia to uncover ancient buried cities. He gives an account of those explorations in the book. It will be published Feb. 24 by Harcourt, Brace.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Official reaction was lacking here tonight to Secretary of State Dulles' ban on visits by their relatives to United States prisoners in Communist China. But there appeared little doubt there would be disappointment in United Nations circles.

Young Men's Christian Association, vocational service division, in 11 E 36th St; Fred Gardner, advertising, in 50 E 42d St; Ruth Peffer, public relations counsel, in 341 Madison Ave; Thomas Murray Inc, men's clothing, store in 508 Lexington Ave -- Brown, Harris, Stevens Inc, brokers.
Guido Cantelli, recovered from the virus infection that laid him low at last Thursday's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony, returned to lead the orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night.

LONDON, Jan, 27 -- Charles Creed opened the London collections today on a rather somber note. Fine tailoring and good cloth may be the qualities that inspire confidence but unfortunately they do not make exciting news.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Republican bills to continue supplemental pensions to retired state and local employes was introduced in the Legislature today.

One of the nation's "big three" copper producers, the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, announced yesterday that its domestic price of copper would be increased 3 cents a pound to 33 cents, effective with shipments today.

A shivery mass of Arctic air blew down over the northeastern part of the country yesterday, tumbling temperatures to their lowest level this winter. The mercury, which was up to 40.2 degrees at 4:30 A. M. yesterday, had dropped to 14 at 3 A. M. today.

The present fight over the attempt to rename Leggett Avenue in the Bronx will be of value if it leads the public to realize that a very large proportion of the City Council's time is devoted to renaming streets, squares, etc. Our Council should not be allowed to waste its valuable time on such trivial matters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The White House asked the Senate today to approve John Sherman Cooper, former Republican Senator from Kentucky, as Ambassador to India.
It now appears that man-made steroids superior to hydrocortisone for the treatment of human afflictions can be obtained by altering the basic structure of the powerful hormone.

The General Motors announcement of a $2,000,000 program of aid to education, coming closely on the heels of news that the General Electric Company will contribute more than $1,000,000 in the current academic year, is a measure of the rapidly growing willingness of American business to carry some of the financial burden of private colleges and universities.
The Board of Estimate began a prisoner rehabilitation program yesterday to cope with mounting unrest in three city institutions.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 27 -- Yugoslavia has halted all exports to Turkey. The reason is financial and not political, an authoritative source said today.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- "The Midsummer Marriage," an opera with libretto and score by the English composer Michael Tippett, is probably the only opera that has ever been accepted on its first night when dressed mainly in contemporary costume.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Harriman vetoed two Republican tax-cut bills today just as he had said he would when they were passed on Tuesday.
New uses for inexpensive materials, Such as felt, wrapping twine and burlap, are shown in objects displayed at the annual craft exhibition of the Pen and Brush Club, 16 East Tenth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) - Harold E. Talbott said today that Air Force efforts to find suitable locations for new jet bases were running into "vicious opposition" from local interests.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Gloom over the future of free Indochina is giving way to cautious optimism here.

Wanamaker's passed into oblivion on Dec. 18. But customers from the store's fifty-eight-year-old past and buyers of a new kind turned up at the Broadway and Ninth Street building yesterday to canvass the remains of a multimillion-dollar stock.

Alice Shapiro made her debut as a pianist last night in Town Hall. Her program contained the four Impromptus of Schubert's Opus 90, Samuel Barber's Sonata in E flat minor, Bach's Partita in B flat, Chopin's Ballade in F and a mazurka, and Liszt's "Mephisto Waltz."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A Senate committee opened hearings today on emergency school construction.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 28 -- Communist China has reacted with bitter defiance to President Eisenhower's request to Congress for strong authority to defend Formosa.

A housing development in New Jersey is planned by Levitt Sons, Inc., on a tract of 3,500 acres in Willingboro Township, about eight miles west of Mount Holly. The site is across the Delaware River from Levittown, Pa., where the company is constructing a development of 17,000 houses which is scheduled to be completed in about two years.

Former Representative James Hardin Peterson of Lakeland, Fla., received yesterday the 1954 award of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society for outstanding achievement in the preservation of historical landmarks.

Two leading agencies in the durable goods, agricultural and technical service fields joined forces yesterday. They are Rickard Co. of this city, and Marsteller, Gebhardt Reed, Inc., of Chicago, Pittsburgh and New York. The combined agency will be known as Marsteller, Rickard, Gebhardt Reed, Inc.

CAIRO, Jan. 27 -- Two men were convicted today of spying in Egypt for Israel and sentenced to hang. Six others were convicted, including one woman, and committed to hard labor for terms ranging from seven years to life by the Cairo military tribunal.

DETROIT, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Danny Lewicki and Vic Howe rapped home goals midway in the third period tonight to lift the New York Rangers into a 3-3 tie in their National Hockey League game with the Detroit Red Wings before 10,667 fans at Olympia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The House of Representatives voted 366 to 0 today to extend G. I. educational benefits.
