Where did the money go? Here, neatly printed on Form W-2, is the employer's statement of total wages (before payroll deductions) paid in 1954. Here also is printed the federal income tax withheld. That is a tidy sum, but even so, subtracting it from the "total wages" leaves a pretty large sum of money.
Chances were bright yesterday that the four new members of baseball's Hall of Fame -- Joe DiMaggio, Ted Lyons, Dazzy Vance and Gabby Hartnett -- would be in New York on Sunday.
Negotiations are under way for the construction of a twenty-two-story apartment house at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and Eighteenth Street.

The investigative function of Congress is an important one, second only to its primary duty of legislation. The two are, of course, closely linked, for Congressional inquiry is often a prelude to new law, and new law is often dependent on prior investigation. Nevertheless, even the best of legislative processes can be abused, especially when there is a real or imagined political advantage to be gained.

IT is a curious fact about the art of fiction that one of the most universal and important areas of human experience has been treated so infrequently. It is the experience of being physically ill. In recent years there has been any number of books about the mentally ill. But at the moment I can't think of any about what it is like to suffer from cancer or leukemia or infantile paralysis.

The conviction of William L. Patterson, executive secretary of the Civil Rights Congress, for contempt of court was reversed yesterday in a two-to-one decision by the United States Court of Appeals. Patterson, who has been serving a ninety-day jail term since last Nov. 19, was ordered released.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- A proposed Federal plan to fight juvenile delinquency will fail unless more trained social workers are recruited.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- The Far East news seemed to have lost its effect today on grain futures, which reacted from early highs but with good support on the dips. New crop wheat deliveries fared better than the old, inasmuch as the weather in the drought areas is still unfavorable.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Secretary of State Dulles today ruled out visits to Communist China by relatives of seventeen imprisoned Americans.
ROME, Jan 27 -- The police were hunting tonight for Francesco Moranino, a Communist deputy wanted on charges of many murders and concealment of the bodies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $176,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Boston Metropolitan District borrowed $2,357,000 yesterday on two bond series at a net interest cost of 2.3476 per cent.

A large eagle, carved in plastic and decorated in gold and silver and soft colors by the artist Pierre Bourdelle, has been presented for the United States Embassy in Copenhagen, Denmark. It was the gift of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Borden of 1 Beekman Place, and will be shipped abroad next week.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits said last night that Governor Harriman had evidenced "a singular lack of aggressive activities" in his program for bringing business and jobs to this state.

In Oxford University's recently published first volume of "A History of Technology" there is a picture of an ancient Egyptian shadow-clock. The device consists of two pieces of slate: one horizontal, about fourteen inches long, to which the other, shorter, is attached vertically, at one end.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Representative John F. Shelley, Democrat of California, remained undecided today on whether to accept the presidency of the American Merchant Marine Institute.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Republicans and Democrats alike have given up their idea of late August or early September nominating conventions in 1956.

The 200th anniversary of Moscow University has been observed this week in many parts of the free world, though, curiously, not in the Soviet Union itself. Through the broadcasts of Radio Liberation from Munich, leaders of American academic life and Soviet exiles who were formerly students or professors at the university have been sending messages through the Iron Curtain to that institution's present community.
THE Biggest Bucks in Maine Club admitted 1,015 new members during the recent deer season, including one hunter who should have received a lifetime membership. His buck scaled 346 pounds.
Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; "Don Carlo," Metropolitan Opera, 8, and "Andrea Chenier," Carl Fischer, Concert Hall, 8.

WITH the exception of Giuseppe Napoli, who shows a softly mysterious still-life in the Morandi vein, the thirteen painters exhibiting together at the Korman Gallery, 835 Madison Avenue, are non-objectivists. They make an impression of earnestness; they manipulate their vocabulary of form and color in search of the happiest balance between the two. Some pictures are hits and others misses.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas won the Australian national doubles tennis championship today by beating Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall in a five-set struggle, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 2 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Eisenhower pledged today he would keep a tight personal rein on the use of United States naval and air forces in the Formosa Strait.

The Giants yesterday fetched up with their twenty-third contract signer for the 1955 season. And even if this contract did not call for one of baseball's more sumptuous salaries, it was a welcome one.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Eisenhower dipped today into the growing and bitter fight over sugar.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The General Services Administration said today that it had effected savings estimated at more than $147,500,000 in the fiscal year ended last June 30.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The chemical industry charged today that import competition was blocking an expansion in production needed to meet the country's defense needs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Treasury will issue its longest-term bond in forty-four years next week in a major step toward redeeming the Eisenhower campaign pledge to "stretching out" the national debt.

ROBERT McFERRIN, American baritone, made his debut at the Metropolitan Opera House last night as Amonasro in "Aida." He was the second Negro singer to become a member of the company in its seventy-one-year history.

The dramatic rights to Alan Paton's novel, "Too Late the Phalarope," have been acquired by Mary K. Frank, co-sponsor with the Playwrights Company of "Tea and Sympathy." Mrs. Frank told an inquirer that the dramatization of Mr. Paton's story would be put on by her as an independent venture.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Following is the English text of the address in French by Paul Eugene Magloire, President of the Republic of Haiti, to a joint session of Congress today:
BERN, Switzerland, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Switzerland asked the United States and Communist China today to agree to a reduction in the neutral supervision of the Korean armistice.
For more than twenty years the life of Serge Rubinstein was a struggle between his moral sense -- or lack of it -- and that of the rest of the world.

A much improved club last year, the New York Football Giants stuns to be considerably stronger in 1955 with their picks in the college draft that opened the annual meeting of the National Football League yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- A portrait of ideal adoptive parents was sketched here today by Dr. Abraham J. Simon of the Chicago Institute for Juvenile Research.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 27 (UP) -- A Swiss sled clocked this winter's fastest time on the Olympic bobsled run today as practice for the world four-man championships wound up with the crash of an Austrian team and the elimination of the Olympic champion, Anderl Ostler of Germany.

Beaunit Mills, Inc., is operating a tricot knitting plant in Puerto Rico, Israel Rogosin, president, anounced yesterday. The company has leased the $2,000,000 plant and has an option to buy. Terms of the lease and the option were not divulged.

Cleanliness is keeping pace with prosperity. In 1954 for the first time shipments of synthetic detergents passed the billion-pound mark. The event was disclosed yesterday by J. J. Babb, president of Lever Brothers Company, at the convention of the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Lincoln Kirstein has resigned as managing director of the City Center of Music and Drama after a disagreement with the board of directors on fundamental policy.
A city-wide goal of $5,730,000 for the 1955 Red Cross campaign for funds and members was announced yesterday by Leroy A. Lincoln, general chairman.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 27 (AP) -Control of the A. M. Byers Company, said to be the nation's biggest producer of wrought iron, hung in the balance today as ballots were counted to determine if the present management would be retained.

The fifth annual Animal Kingdom Ball, held last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre, attracted a representative gathering of members of society. The fete, arranged under the auspices of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, served to raise funds for the organization's animal adoption service clinic.
TAIPEI, Friday, Jan. 28 -- Nationalist bombers resumed attack on the Reds' island outpost of Yikiang during the night and continued until dawn today.

THERE is an immense feeling of satisfaction at the news that Joe DiMaggio finally has been elected to baseball's Hall of Fame. And he made it in typical DiMaggio fashion. He struck out in his first two times at bat. Then the Jolter hoisted a titanic blast into the stands, polling 223 of 251 votes cast. That total comes closer to unanimity than any since the earliest days of the election.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The payroll office of the State Assembly worked overtime today.

Leonard Rosenblatt has been appointed New York regional representative of the building products division of L. Sonneborn Sons, Inc., and will coordinate architectural and contract work in the metropolitan area. He has been with the company eight years.

President Eisenhower sent a message of congratulations to the golfing champions honored last night by the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association. A capacity gathering of more than 500 attended at the Hotel Plaza.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- The Soviet Union again put on record today its routine protest against Nationalist China's presence in a United Nations body.

THE extraordinary opera of Mozart, "Idomeneo," received its first stage performance in New York last night at the Juilliard Concert Hall. It was heard in a new English translation of the original Italian text by Sherry Mangan, given by a cast of Juilliard students of the opera classes and the Juilliard orchestra conducted by Frederic Waldman. The work was staged by Frederic Cohen, with Frederick Kiesler as scenic designer.

DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- TheStudebaker-Packard Corporation announced today that it had moved into the field of scientific research and development through the acquisition of the Aerophysics Development Corporation of Los Angeles.

MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The most stunning upset of the Florida racing season materialized when Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Red Letter Day, the 7-20 favorite, finished last in the five-horse field of 3-year-old fillies in the $5,000 Minorca purse at Hialeah Park today.

Representatives of twenty-five television and radio stations in the metropolitan area assured District Attorney Edward S. Silver yesterday that they would give "full cooperation" in his drive against fraudulent advertising on the air.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Thirty-two boys and eight girls, all of them high school seniors, were named here today as finalists in the fourteenth annual Science Talent Search.

TWO newly opened shows make strikingly clear the change in attitude that has come about in a decade in the field of sculpture. One is of the work by Polygnotis Vagis at the Alexandre Iolas Gallery, 46 East Fifty-seventh Street; the other is of recent work by Herbert Ferber at the Kootz Gallery, 600 Madison Avenue.

An anonymous Philadelphia telephone call, warning that "atomic bombs" had been planted for an explosion at midnight last night in New York and Washington, brought from the White House a statement that no atom devices had been discovered and no nation-wide civil defense alert had been ordered.

FORT SILL, Okla., Jan. 27 (UP) -- An Army sergeant testified today that Maj. Ambrose Nugent told him in a North Korean prison camp that it was all right to make propaganda speeches for the Communists if he remembered to say when he got home that they made him do it.

CAIRO, Jan. 27 -- The conflicting views of Egypt and Iraq on the latter's agreement to join in a defense pact with Turkey were aired for the first time today in what was reported to have been a stormy session of the conference of Arab leaders here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Efforts in the Senate to limit President Eisenhower's authority to take war action in defense of Formosa were declining tonight.
A warning that inadequate appropriations were endangering enforcement of the pure food and drug laws was given yesterday by a Government official.
TELEVISION has entered the tranquil life of The Reader's Digest at Pleasantville, N. Y. By now the editors may have made the discovery that TV always pays off in two ways: in money and in problems.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -- A union negotiating committee has been authorized to call a strike after next Tuesday against radio and television stations of the American Broadcasting Company and the National Broadcasting Company throughout the country.

Maurice Couve de Murville, the new French Ambassador to the United States, arrived here yesterday on the liner Ile de France. He left for Washington a few hours later to assume the post recently relinquished by Henri Bonnet.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Air Force is planning an atom-powered intercontinental bombing fleet, Gen. Nathan F. Twining said today.
One outcome of the Army's Fort Monmouth security risk suspensions is that the Federal Government faces back pay bills that could run above $85,000.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Henri Bonnet, former French Ambassador to the United States, urged systematic coordination of French and United States world policies.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation declared an increased common dividend of $2.25 a share yesterday, and announced a $100,000,000 program to expand and modernize its finishing mill facilities.
A new investment company will place on the public market today $25,000,000 of its stock to raise funds for investment in the electronic and atomic fields.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 27 -- Rules for news coverage of a possible Tachen Island evacuation were disclosed here today by spokesmen of the United States Seventh Fleet. Correspondents were told they must abide by five restrictions for eligibility to board United States naval vessels.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The State Department said today that it had discussed with Nationalist China last October the possibility of a cease-fire along the Formosa Strait.
A mysterious strangler put an end early yesterday to the fantastic career of Serge Rubinstein.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States Government will be represented in at least twenty international trade exhibits in 1955.
FORT KNOX, Ky., Jan. 27 -Many of the Army's senior officers and some 800 students at the Armored School here watched a fire-power demonstration today of a tank company in attack.
HONG KONG, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Communist China denounced today President Eisenhower
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -- West Coast shipowners, with fingers crossed, looked forward today to a new waterfront peace.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' letter today to relatives of Americans imprisoned in Communist China:

Loans to brokers and dealers by major New York City banks for purchasing or carrying securieties other than Government obligations climbed $82,000,000 during the week ended Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 27 - The Congregational Christian Churches will raise $6,280,000 annually to support missionary work in the United States and its possessions and in overseas countries.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Porter M. Jarvis, executive vice president of Swift Co. since 1950, was elected president today to succeed John Holmes, who had held the office since 1937. Mr. Holmes was elected chairman of the board and designated chief executive officer, succeeding Harold H. Swift who was elected to the new post of honorary chairman.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- An agreement to peg retail milk prices in New York City for the next three months went into effect tonight.
Militant dockworkers in the Chelsea district once again refused yesterday to handle cargo from Russia.

Directors of the TXL Oil Corporation yesterday elected George A. Wilson, oil and gas executive, as president of the company, established last Dec. 10. Mr. Wilson was president of the Interstate Oil Pipe Line Company and the Yellowstone Pipe Line Company, affiliates of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), both of which posts he resigned to accept this new office, effective Feb. 1.
BY mixing Amish people with regulation showmanship, the producers of "Plain and Fancy," which opened at the Mark Hellinger last evening, have emerged with an interesting if uneven musical comedy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Heavy unemployment in the automobile industry later this year was called inevitable today by a labor official. He said the auto manufacturers were "engaged in another production race" to pile up 1955 models.

In the discussion of Formosa policy the "redeployment" of Chinese Nationalist forces, to which reference has been repeatedly made, means at this stage the evacuation of the Tachen island group. As matters stand, the Chinese Nationalist Government has apparently given its consent to such a move and naval and air forces of the United States are in position to make it possible.

Gross revenues of the Union Pacific Railroad dropped last year to $481,786,451, the lowest level since 1950, but the company managed to report a net income of $69,622,665 or $14.76 a share for 1954. In the previous year, when gross climbed to $530,024,300, net earnings reached $70,965,340 or $15.07 a share.

A small experimental plane appears to have made an important advance in the race to perfect a craft that can take off like a helicopter and then convert to conventional forward flight. The manufacturer disclosed yesterday that the plane had gone through successfully almost half the conversion cycle in a flight of more than fifteen minutes.

A grove of trees in honor of Warren R. Austin, former United States chief delegate to the United Nations, will be established in the near future by the Jewish National Fund of America, the land reclamation and development agency of the World Zionist Organization.

William S. Paley, chairman of the board of Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., announced yesterday that the board of directors had voted to propose a three-for-one stock split. The proposal will be submitted to stockholders for approval at the annual meeting on April 20.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 27 (UP) -- Thirty-nine of the 42 professionals competing shot par or better in the first round of the $15,000 Thunderbird invitation pro-amateur tournament today. Johnny Palmer showed them way with a 10-under par 62.

A gift of $80 from eight children not in need to eight children who are was among forty-one contributions recorded yesterday for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The sum of $1,489 that was received sent the total to date to $407,169,59 from 12,226 donors.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 27 -- A crowd of several thousand jammed La Sabana Airport here today and cheered a good-by to the investigating commission of the Organization of American States. The members of the commission headed by Ambassador Luis Quintanilla of Mexico left in a United States Air Force plane for Panama en route to Washington.
MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Greta Leone, who began playing golf four years ago, upset medal winner Vonnie Colby today in the first round of the Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament.
Eggs are up and bacon is down, but these good companions both fall in the thrifty-buy category this week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Paul Eugene Magloire of Haiti declared today that he sought to make the people of his country immune to communism by raising standards of living.

The aroma of outraged royalty which flavors the opening sentence of your Jan. 20 editorial "Niagara Power and Albany" is probably not the best flavoring for such an essay; i. e., "We cannot believe that majority public opinion is being expressed" by a proposed "turning over Niagara Falls power development to privately owned utility companies."
The judicial and executive branches of the Government stood opposed yesterday, and an ex-convict ended up the loser.
A new $7,250,000 Misericordia General Hospital is to rise on a three-block site in the Woodlawn-Wakefield section of the Bronx after sixty-eight years of service in Yorkville.

In the present danger courage alone is not enough, nor the wisdom of the President in presenting the danger to Congress. We need a very cool appraisal of the realities, for we are a minority people, some 6 per cent of the world, facing a determined coalition of 40 per cent of the world's people.
The Transit Authority agreed yesterday to open its books to Michael J. Quill.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 27 -- The country's biggest union threw a roadblock in the path of labor unity today.
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 27 -- Boutique collections shown at the Pitti Palace this afternoon made a colorful epilogue to the couturier openings that finished here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Democratic majority of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy proposed today that the Administration kill the Dixon-Yates private power contract.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- India has made a cautious appeal for British aid in obtaining Communist China's admission to the United Nations. This adds to the difficulties of the Government's position on the Far Eastern crisis.

A revolutionary "cosmic microscope" for probing into the inner citadel of the material universe, was described here yesterday. This device would use a beam of atomic "light" at least one hundred times, and possibly thousands of times more powerful than any atomic beam now possible.
The "jolt" given the Republican party by its losses in last fall's elections should warn its members that "this is no time to settle back and relax," some of them were told last night.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 27 -- The South African Government will start the removal of 57,000 Negroes from the so-called black spots of western Johannesburg to a new location farther out of the city Feb. 12.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- For the first time in nearly two years the Bank of England has increased the bank rate.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Republican bills to create a special commission on juvenile delinquency were submitted to the Legislature today.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Only sections of three of France's major rivers were still in heavy flood condition tonight, the National Service of Civilian Defense reported.

IDA SCOTTI left the Lighthouse Craft Shop at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street the other night after finishing her work at the Braille press. She stood at the curb at Fifty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue as usual waiting for Missy, her dog, to read the traffic light for her and start her across.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 27 (AP) -- United States naval sources said today the scheduled visit here of the 45,000-ton aircraft carrier Midway had been canceled, apparently to speed the big ship on her way to duty with American naval forces concentrated around Formosa.

The board of governors of the National Hockey League yesterday upheld President Clarence Campbell's decision to suspend Ted Lindsay of Detroit for ten days because the Red Wing star hit a fan with his hockey stick in a game at Toronto last Saturday night.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 27 -- The official Turkish news agency reported today that talks had been in progress since Jan. 20 between the Egyptian and Soviet Ambassadors here and their staffs.
A $250,000,000 state bond issue to finance new facilities for the State University of New York and its community colleges was urged last night.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- President Theodor Heuss of the West German Republic arrived here today from Bonn. His visit has been publicized in a fashion that indicates that the Bonn Government is aware of the psychological crisis here.
This port's dock labor and management were alike excoriated last night in an address by Samuel M. Lane, general counsel and executive director of the Waterfront Commission.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- British Government stocks fluctuated on the increase in the bank rate from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent and ended the day with small losses. But industrial shares hesitated only momentarily before resuming their advance to reach a new peak.

OMAHA, Jan. 27 -- A Federal grand jury investigating irregularities in the Bureau of Internal Revenue during the Truman Administration again heard testimony today by John W. Snyder, former Secretary of the Treasury.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- French Senators today made known their intention of postponing for a few days debate on the Paris agreements on West German arming.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- A motor magnate splashed a little mud tonight on "those big fat cars."
Rival camps of electronic weather forecasters clashed yesterday at the meeting of the American Meteorological Society.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 27 -- A windblown cloud of brown dust darkened this area for an hour today, disappearing shortly after noon. Motorists were forced to turn on their lights, but the dust apparently caused no other inconvenience.

The unhappy realization that every day isn't Christmas appeared to strike Wall Street about 3:15 P. M. yesterday. Many stocks that had been moving up briskly most of the session turned around suddenly and retraced their path.
The forty-year 3 per cent non-callable bond that the Treasury is about to issue will affect financial markets in two important ways.
Three-fourths of a second from accelerator to brake was said yesterday to be the crucial foot-reaction time for stopping an automobile under emergency conditions.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The British Government is understood to be preparing plans for a marked increase in its military strength in the Middle East and Southeast Asia.

Two office buildings at 16 and 18 East Fifty-third Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, have been sold by Louis Denberg and Hugh McGovern to Louis Cooper, operator, in a deal negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Hal Wallis has added "Gun Fight at O. K. Corral" to his expanding list of properties. He will have Burt Lancaster and, possibly, Humphrey Bogart, as his stars.

The projects for strengthening the defenses of the Middle East have suffered at least temporary setbacks as a result of two developments caused by still unresolved rivalries and ambitions in that area.
For sheer beauty, Bonwit Teller's presentation of wedding gowns and trousseau lingerie and negligees was a delight to see yesterday at the store.

DETROIT, Jan. 27 (UP) -- The president of the University of Michigan revealed today that the presidents of Big Ten universities were behind the move of Conference athletic directors to discard the college football "game of the week" plan.

A Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury plans to investigate the finances of James J. Moran, former deputy fire commissioner. Moran is now in Green Haven Prison, Stormville, N. Y., convicted of heading a $500,000-a-year shakedown racket in the Fire Department.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Thomas E. Dewey will receive a state retirement allowance of $2,400 a year for twelve years and $12,412 annually thereafter.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- Dr. Homi Jehangir Bhabha, Indian nuclear physicist, has been asked to head the first world conference on peacetime uses of atomic energy. The parley is to open in Geneva Aug. 8.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 28 -- Although the world looks nervously on Formosa, this capital of 650,000 Chinese and native Formosan is going about its daily existence with an air of detachment.

The article on page 33 of your Jan. 17 issue treats the decimal point a bit cavalierly and, in the caption to the lower picture accompanying the story, grossly misrepresents the extent of the efficiency of Karachi loan sharks in "evil art."

The series of articles by Russell Porter on the Department of Correction were well written and gave an adequate picture of the problems which face Commissioner Kross. It is evident that she desires to make progress in the situation with expedition and as soon as more adequate funds are available.
BOSTON, Jan. 28 -- Adverse publicity for an employer and employe unrest were listed today as factors prompting arbitrators to uphold the discharge of security risks in industry.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 28 -- Moscow's hostile attitude to the Nordic Council, which keeps Finland out of the council, drew sharp criticism here today. It was voiced at the opening session of the interparliamentary group's third convention, held in the Riksdag (Parliament chamber).

The Budd Company, the nation's sole independent automobile body manufacturer and an important producer of railroad equipment, reported yesterday preliminary earnings for 1954 of $6,292,424, equal to $1.60 a share. This compared with $10,829,303 or $2.88 a share earned in 1953.

ANY village, town, city, state or country that can provide good fishing has little to worry about these days from the financial viewpoint. Many anglers with a little money are just as beneficial as a few with a lot.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Clothes designed for a queen, as well as her mother and her sister, were shown today by Norman Hartnell in his salon where the Royal Coat of Arms adorned the mirrors and walls.

A Hungarian watch repairman described life in his native Budapest yesterday, shortly after his arrival in New York. In the watch import firm of his brother and sponsor at Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, 60-year-old Joseph Schwarcz recounted his story.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -- The Army today unveiled a portable X-ray machine that uses atomic energy. It can reveal the extent of a soldier's battlefield wounds within moments after he is cut down.
GENEVA, Jan. 28 -- The Geneva conference has reached basic agreement on two more key features of a trading system for the Western world.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 28 -- A wave of hostility instead of the hero's welcome usually accorded returning prisoners of war met the former Wehrmacht Field Marshal, Ferdinand Schoerner, today. He returned after nearly ten years of Soviet captivity.

Two three-story apartment houses at 95-99 South Grove Street in Valley Stream, L. I., containing seven garages and forty-eight suites, have been purchased by the Investors Funding Corporation in behalf of an investing syndicate.
ROME, Jan. 28 -- A Pontifical Commission for Cinematography, Radio and Television was established today in the Vatican.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. ATKA, Off Antarctica, Jan. 28 -- During the past twenty-four hours this Navy icebreaker has repeatedly sailed south into the icepack, seeking in vain a route to open water along the coast.

Evander Childs High retained the Public Schools Athletic League swimming championship last night. The Bronx school triumphed though its swimmers captured only one event in the Quigley Memorial Pool at New York University.
TALKEETNA, Alaska, Jan. 28 -- About 1,800 United States paratroopers plunged into snow thirty- eight inches deep this morning.
Directors of the Carrier Corporation and Affiliated Gas Equipment, Inc., heating and air-conditioning manufacturers, have agreed to a merger.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Jan. 28 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet Monday to try to stop the fighting between Nationalist and Communist China over the small islands off the mainland.
An octogenarian died last night in a lower East Side tenement fire, which started when he accidentally upset a kerosene stove-heater.

On the coldest day of the season, four, children were found huddled together yesterday in a downtown Brooklyn apartment without heat, gas or electricity. Their mother was at work at East Meadow, L. I., at her new one-day-a-week job as a cleaning women.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent over the week ended Tuesday to 110.2 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The first Roman Catholic priest to take a post in Moscow after the signing of the Roosevelt-Litvinov religious protocol, the Rev. Leopold Braun, has become treasurer of the American Society for the Preservation of Sacred, Patriotic and Operatic Music.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission said today the atomic engine of the submarine Nautilus had greater capacity than the 5,000-kilowatt nuclear power plant the Russians claim to have developed for industrial purposes.
The New York Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., began a strike at midnight last night against. The Brooklyn Eagle, the only daily newspaper in that borough.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Social workers were challenged today to fight racial segregation or quit the profession.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday decreed that any foreign boxer booked to appear in this state for the first time must undergo a thorough examination before engaging in a contest. The move came about as the result of the poor showing made by Angelo Brisci at the St. Nicholas Arena last Monday night.
A Brooklyn couple, co-owners of a television repair service, were found guilty yesterday of fraudulent practices.
Intense police activity that began early yesterday and continued until early today failed to indicate that any major progress had been made toward solving the murder of Serge Rubinstein.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 28 -- A top union official recommended today that President Eisenhower appoint a special commission to investigate welfare fund abuses.

Grand Terminal Liquors Inc, package store, in 501 5th Ave; Brett Winston Inc, men's and women's wear, store in 10 E 53d St through Tankoos Co; Regent Co, textiles and plastics, store space in 443 Broadway; Precise Imports Corp, in 23 E 26th St; Akers' Hair Scalp Clinics; Panagiotis D. Stratakis, lawyer, in 1472 Broadway -- Charles F. Noyes Co Inc, broker.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 28 -- United States Navy and Coast Guard planes, operating from Bermuda and Puerto Rico, have failed to find any trace of the sixty-foot schooner H. S. H. owned by Ward Wheelock of Philadelphia who left Bermuda for Antigua on Jan. 13 with seven persons aboard, five of them American.

Reactionary trends in evidence in the stock market late Thursday afternoon disappeared quickly after the opening yesterday. But the real feature of the day -- a spirited advance in railroad shares -- did not occur until late in the session.
PANAMA, Jan. 28 -- Reappraisal of the inter-American security system is expected to be one result of the futile foreign-aided rebellion in Costa Rica.
TOKYO, Jan. 28 -- It has become apparent that the United States Air Force has gone onto a full war basis in this area.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A labor spokesman accused the Eisenhower Administration today of evading the issue of building schools.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- A new national shrine for the Statue of Liberty was chartered today.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Alain Giletti, a 15-year-old French skater, outclassed thirteen rivals from eight nations tonight to win the men's European figure skating championship.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Sharp criticisms of Moral Rearmament as "psychologically dangerous," "gravely defective in its social thinking," and possibly "a Christian heresy," were made by an organ of the Church of England today.
The Yankees made two moves yesterday that should help keep them in shortstops for years to come.

WILLIAM FAULKNER and Eudora Welty have probably drawn memorable characters from the Confederacy-haunted locality that Louis Cochran writes about in his beguiling turn-of-the-century memoir of a Southern town, "Hallelujah, Mississippi."* Not wholly of course; never directly. No novelist that I know of ever says he has taken a character, without any change whatever, straight out of life itself.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Trade in grain and soybean futures dragged at times today, with considerable evening up for the week-end.

The State Department was obliged to make a difficult decision when it was faced with the question of passports for relatives of Americans detained as prisoners of the Chinese Communists. The decision has now been made. The passports will not be issued.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- J. Edgar Hoover warned police and the public today to be on the lookout for imposters taking advantage of a recent extension of social security coverage.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- A desire to have one's children do well in the world and a genuine enjoyment of them as they grow add up to a sound foundation for successful parenthood, Dr. Benjamin Spock said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Senate tonight overwhelmingly authorized President Eisenhower to take war action, if need be, in defense of Formosa.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 23 -- Israeli reclamation engineers are taking the advice of the preacher of Ecclesiastes and making this year "a time to gather stones together." The result is that broad bands of terraced fields are appearing on hills that seem to forbid modern agriculture.
A major activity among young Protestants next week in hundreds of Christian Youth Councils across the country will be the collecting of Bibles and other books to be sent abroad.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Edgar Faure, who became Foreign Minister in Premier Pierre Mendes-France's Cabinet yesterday, challenged an editor to a duel today.
Tension developed yesterday between Connecticut and New York State over water supplies for two communities in Westcester County.

A community donation to the regional Red Cross blood program will be made from 10:30 A. M. to 4:15 P. M. today at Public School 46, Sixty-seventh Avenue and 218th Street, Bayside, Queens, under the auspices of the Bell Park Gardens Civic Association.
The Society for Seamen's Children elected Mrs. William Y. Daly president for 1955 at its 108th annual meeting yesterday.
EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 28 (UP) -- A former undercover informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today he had given "deliverately false" testimony at the trial of a labor leader.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 28 -- Return of the International Longshoremen's Association to the American Federation of Labor was urged here today by Dave Beck. '
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The economic capacity of the United States, Canada and Western Europe has been found to be "significantly greater" than the combined strength of the Soviet bloc.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 28 (UP) -- A select field of nine, headed by the Kentucky Derby winner, Determine, today was entered in the $163,360 Maturity for 4-year-olds at Santa Anita tomorrow.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The Senate Finance Committee will act next week upon "some or all" of the five Harriman Cabinet appointments pending before it.

HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- Cuba, governed by a military regime since March 10, 1952, when Gen. Fulgencio Batista took power by a military coup, returned to constitutional government today with the installation of Congress.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C. Z., Jan. 28 -- The Governor of the Panama Canal Zone dedicated today a locomotive as a permanent monument here to the men who 100 years ago completed the first rail link between the Atlantic and the Pacific Oceans.
MONTREAL, Jan. 28 -- Arthur A. Schmon, president of the Ontario Paper Company, Ltd., was elected chairman of the executive board of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Rice growers in ten states overwhelmingly approved today strict Government production controls that will slash their 1955 plantings by 24.7 per cent.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 28 -- Powerful building trades unions tightened up their no-strike machinery today. They did this to assure their members a better chance of getting work on President Eisenhower's $101,000,000,000 highway program.

The Investigating Commission of the Organization of American States returned to Washington yesterday after completing a brilliantly successful mission. It will surely go down in post-war history as one of the best examples of how international peace machinery can and should work.
GENEVA, Jan. 28 -- "Coexistence" as the Russians like to interpret it won an important victory in a European gathering here today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Transportation Minister Lucas Lopes resigned today because of disagreement with President Joao Cafe Filho's call on all political parties to rally around a "national union" candidate for the October Presidential election.
Dr. John Slawson, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, asserted yesterday that organized anti-Semitic efforts were being increasingly rebuffed.
The passenger liner United States arrived yesterday from Europe a day behind schedule after experiencing "the stormiest trip" in her thirty-one-month career.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Six out of seven economists agreed today that deficit financing could be healthy for the country. They said it would be wrong to balance the Federal budget in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee today ended hearings on a proposed $10,000 pay increase for Congressmen and Federal Judges.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Federal regulation of natural gas producers is a step toward socialism, Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, a vice president and director of the Shell Oil Company, asserted today at a luncheon of the Executives Club of Chicago.

Commodity futures prices drifted irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Much of the trading involved evening of holdings for the week-end. Coffee, sugar, potatoes, rubber, burlap and hides ended mixed; wool, zinc, lead and copper were higher, and cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and silk closed lower.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 28 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his party whips reaffirmed their determination today to go through with the Bundestag's ratification of the Paris agreements in arming West Germany on Feb. 24.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 28 -- United States Ambassador Karl L. Rankin declared today he did not think there was "great" danger of a major war between the United States and Red China in the Formosa Strait or East China Sea "so long as our actions are within reason."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An application for authority to merge the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway into the Louisville and Nashville Railroad was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Richard A. Sheppard and his wife, Ethel, parents of the convicted wife slayer, Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, left estates that totaled more than $196,000, according to wills filed yesterday in Probate Court.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- Glenn Ford, will portray the young lawyer in Don Mankiewicz' Harper prize novel, "Trial," which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will film.

MIAMI, Jan. 28 (UP) -- The Wheatley Stable's Full Flight, a disappointment thus far this winter but a double stakes winner last season, heads a field of nine in tomorrow's tenth running of the $15,000 added Royal Palm Handicap at Hialeah Park.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 28 -- Seven hundred delegates from this country, Canada, Western Europe and Latin America started the First International Mobilization Conference for Israel here today.

The market for United States Government securities took in stride yesterday a vast accumulation of business touched off by the Treasury's decision to issue a forty-year 3 per cent bond. The issue will be part of the $15,000,000,000 refinancing of Feb. 15 and April 15.
HONOLULU, Jan. 28 -- Hawaiian Islanders appear to be facing a shipping feast after three months of famine.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- The ghosts of early American Indians rose today from cavernous graves under Rochelle Park here to haunt the builders of a $12,500,000 stretch of the New England Thruway.

In the years immediately preceding the First World War, a youngster living on Manhattan's lower East Side got along just fine if he had quick fists and fast feet. There was none better in either respect than a blond 115-pounder named Whitey Bimstein.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 28 -- Yugoslavia has assured the United States that she is prepared to institute a program of controls on exports of strategic goods to the Soviet bloc.
Commercial bankers, who borrow billions from the Federal Reserve System, last week talked of a possible increase in the cost of borrowing these funds.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 -- The Council on Human Relations, formerly a part of the Cleveland Chapter of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, started plans today for promotion of intergroup understanding.
The city's teachers were assured yesterday of adequate pay increases even if it should take more than a year to achieve them.
Twenty-three City Councilmen notwithstanding, two blocks of Leggett Avenue in the Bronx are unlikely to become Jaburg Avenue.

In its first change of ownership in forty-four years, the five-story building at 55 East Seventy-eighth Street has been sold by Warwick and Hamilton F. Potter to Frederick Brown. The building, which occupies a lot 18.9 by 102.2 feet between Madison and Park Avenues, was bought for cash in a deal negotiated by Adams H. Nickerson of Albert B. Ashforht, Inc., broker.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Secretary Charles S. Thomas said today the Navy could handle "the situation in the Formosan Straits or any other emergency."

May I congratulate and thank you for your splendid editorial entitled "The Teachers' Pay Check" which appeared Jan. 22? It is very effective because it states essential relevant facts simply and clearly and these facts speak most eloquently for the teachers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, will leave Washington for rest periods tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the House Small Business Committee, today criticized the Treasury's new bond issue as a threat to the "economic stability of the country."

The most significant thing about the reports that are now reaching Washington from South Vietnam is that Premier Ngo Dinh Diem is increasing in stature and influence as a nationalist leader who is serious about making peaceful, democratic and thoroughgoing reforms in the government of his country.

Prof. Henry DeWolf Smyth, former member of the Atomic Energy Commission, declared last night that physicists "must remind military and political leaders that the strength of science is based on freedom of inquiry, freedom of discussion and freedom of dissent."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Postal workers asked the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee today to give them a wage rise of 10 per cent or $400 a year, whichever is larger.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Marjorie I. Birnie of Paradise Valley, Nev., received a patent this week for a method of making fence pickets from palm fronds.

" Don Carlo" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera last evening with Kurt Adler conducting the opera for the first time there, Nell Rankin making her first appearance as the Princess Eboli and Ettore Bastianini singing his first Metropolitan Rodrigo.
Turnips may be dismissed by some home cooks as being of little interest except as an ingredient for stews. Actually, they are a relatively important vegetable.
Mayor Wagner signed yesterday a local bill creating a statutory Department of Commerce and Public Events.
The legislative committee of the New York District Attorneys Association urged yesterday that if bingo be legalized it be done only through a constitutional amendment.

Professional football took a step yesterday to discourage the feigning of injuries for the purpose of stopping the clock. It also provided a measure of additional protection for the ball carrier knocked to the ground.

" The Kelly," a naval history by Kenneth Poolman, will be published Feb. 23 by Norton. It is an account of the British destroyer Kelly, commanded by Capt. Lord Louis Mountbatten, and her crew in wartime. The author says "the Kelly's war reflects a nation's struggle in those first two dark years of endurance."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (UP) -- George Johnson, a middleweight from Trenton, N. J., floored Ramon Fuentes in the final round tonight and gained a split ten-round decision over the No. 3 welterweight contender from Los Angeles. The bout was held at Convention Hall.
CAIRO, Jan. 28 -- Representatives of five Arab States were delegated tonight to draft a compromise resolution that must reconcile the opposed views of Iraq and Egypt on Middle East defense.

A basic split in matters of artistic policy exists among members of the board of directors of the City Center of Music and Drama. This division has been highlighted by the resignation, revealed Thursday, of Lincoln Kirstein as managing director of the center.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- Communist East Berlin will proclaim this coming week-end "kiss freedom." The annual carnival is starting and a series of decrees are being prepared by the eleven ministers of the "nonsensical government."
A hundred business leaders gathered yesterday to organize an employers' subcommittee of President Eisenhower's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped.

Disabled persons in the state who have become "job-competent" are about to receive greater assistance in finding employment. Dr. Isador Lubin, State Industrial Commissioner, has announced that the State Employment Service will add twenty selective employment interviewers to its staff to aid in locating suitable jobs for those handicapped who have received specialized training by a rehabilitation agency.

The Lutheran Society of New York presented distinguished service citations last night to Dr. Henry Beisler, a Belleville, N. J., layman, and Miss Mary Elizabeth Banta, for fifty years a missionary at the True Light Chinese Lutheran Church in New York's Chinatown.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- Britain asked the Soviet Union today to use its influence with Communist China to prevent any incident that might lead to "general hostilities" in the Far East.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 28 -- In the Middle East, as in Europe and the Orient, United States diplomacy is seeking to accomplish two essential objectives. The first is to define a no-trespassing line which, if violated by the Soviet bloc, would clearly provoke the menace of war.
The world premiere of Thornton Wilder's new play, "The Alcestiad," will take place next summer at the Edinburgh Festival of Music and Drama.

The average market price of all bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange as of Dec. 31 was $100.07. This compared with $100.13 at the end of November and was the lowest level since May, 1954 when the average figure was $100.
Amendments to New York State's anti-monoply laws to enable the Attorney General to give better protection to the consumer and small business are being drawn in his office.

TRENTON, Jan. 28 -- Orrie DeNooryer, chairman of the New Jersey Highway Authority, predicted today that the Garden State Parkway and the New York State Thruway would be linked before the end of the year.
MIAMI, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Barbara Romack, national amateur champion, defeated two more opponents handily today to reach the semi-finals of the Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament.

CAIRO, Jan. 28 -- The first major stage of the excavation of the funerary ship of Cheops was completed today. The last of the massive blocks that had formed the sealed roof were removed from the underground chamber in which the ship had lain for forty-seven centuries beside the Great Pyramid of Cheops at Giza.

The legalism whereby the United States seeks to justify its commitment to defend Formosa is not appreciated by the bulk of the peoples of the world. They will consider us the aggressor if that commitment leads to our bombing China.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Sir Anthony Eden spoke in a conciliatory vein toward Communist China tonight in urging United Nations action on the Formosa issue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had revised its policy with respect to investment company sales literature and advertising.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- The long-dormant interim committee of the United Nations General Assembly, the "Little Assembly," was called into session here today just long enough to elect officers for 1955.
Three labor leaders were convicted in Federal Court here last night of extorting money from a sugar company on the threat of causing trouble on a Philadelphia pier.
Louis G. Pacent Jr. has beeen named works manager of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation.
A bird that ought to be in a marsh in Florida or Georgia amid pickerel weed and water lilies was seen yesterday in mid-Manhattan. It was watched for two and a half hours before it flew away.

The sixth annual dinner and ball of the St. Nicholas Society of New York was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Spring flowers were used in the decorations. On the stage of the ballroom were displayed the society's flag and the national emblems of the United States and The Netherlands.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Johnny Palmer remained in front in the $15,000 Thunderbird invitation golf tournament today, shooting a 4-under-par 68 for a 36-hole total of 130.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- A meeting in the near future of the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France to discuss Indochina is expected by officials here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the independent oil producers told Congress today that growing oil imports menaced United States national security.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Former United States Ambassador William O'Dwyer announced today he had accepted the presidency of Mexico's largest marine construction company, the Compania Mexicana de Construcciones Maritimas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Maj. Gen. Kenneth D. Nichols is understood to have resigned as general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A "bureau of personnel" attached to the White House was urged today. James C. Worthy, who retires Tuesday after two years as Assistant Secretary of Commerce in charge of administration, proposed that such a bureau rank with the Bureau of the Budget in its access to the President.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The organization of the National Right-to-Work Committee was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- The Inter-American Peace Commission said tonight it felt it had accomplished its mission and restored to "Costa Rica the feeling of security to which she is entitled."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Erie Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to offer $40,288,200 of income debentures in exchange for its outstanding preferred stock.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- The New York Caledonian Curling Club, celebrating its 100th birthday, played host to eighteen invited rinks at its centennial bonspiel which began today at St. Andrew's Golf Club's indoor arena. Five Canadian rinks journeyed here.

The two buildings containing thirty-nine apartments at 718-22 East 212th Street in the Bronx were bought by George Goodman Co., operators and investors, and resold to a client of Howard Rikoon, lawyer. The buyer paid cash over a purchase money mortgage of $35,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A Federal Judge ruled today the Postmaster General may conduct experiments with sending first class (three cent) mail by air, but said they must not be "prolonged."
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 28 -- The top leaders of India and Pakistan today gave one of the warmest public displays of good fellowship since partition of the two countries in 1947.
" Game of Love," the French drama currently on view at the Baronet Theatre, has received a "Class C," or "condemned," rating from the National Legion of Decency, Roman Catholic reviewing body.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 28 -- Col. Anastasio Somoza Jr., chief of the Nicaraguan armed forces and son of the President, had to intervene last night to quell a disturbance of interned rebels of the Costa Rican conflict. The rebels taunted members of the mission of the Organization of American States seeking to interview them.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 29 -- Moscow has made overtures to the Japanese Government for ending the state of war between the two countries.

MANILA, Jan. 28 -- President Ramon Magsaysay and legislative leaders in conference today decided to accept an invitation to attend the meeting of Asian and African nations at Bandung, Java, in mid-April, Red China will be a conferee.
A NEW enterprise, The Riley Gallery, opens its doors at 26 East Fifty-fifth Street with a conservative show of paintings by Franz Felix, a contemporary Austro-American artist.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- On a party line vote of 10 to 8 the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy recommended today that the Administration cancel the Dixon-Yates contract.
Congress was urged in a circular letter yesterday to vote a program recommended by the Association on American Indian Affairs.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The Legislature of the sovereign State of New York met today.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Two upsets were registered in quarter-final play today in the South Florida tennis championships when Al Harum of Coral Gables and Karol Fageros of Miami Beach were knocked from the running.
Two more major copper producers announced yesterday that they would advance their price 3 cents a pound to 33 cents.
There are smiles on the faces of the Mine Hosts of our town these wintry days, not because spring may be just around the corner but because the buyers are here.

A new booklet entitled "Jews in American Agriculture" has just been published by the Jewish Agricultural Society in place of its usual annual report and as part of its contribution to the American Jewish Tercentenary celebration. Dr. Theodore Norman, general manager of the society, sums up in the booklet the organization's work for the past fifteen years, both before and after the Second World War.
The Treasury's decision to put out a long-term 3 per cent bond seems to have had little if any effect on the public market for new corporate and local government issues.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall surprised today by defeating America's Tony Trabert in straight sets, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, to enter the final of the Australian national tennis championships.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday that 740 successful candidates would be sworn in as probationary patrolmen Tuesday. This group will bring the strength of the department to a record high of 21,565.

Eight private economists with varying backgrounds appeared before the opening session of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee to give their views on the President's annual Economic Report, sent to Congress a week ago.

Marion (Marty) Osterhout of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute Figure Skating Club of Troy, N. Y., won the juvenile ladies' singles as the Middle Atlantic figure skating championships began yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The stock market was quieter here today, but Government bonds were steadier and some industrial shares rose moderately in response to selective buying.
Governor Harriman was criticized by Republican speakers yesterday for imposing a "high-tax administration" on the state.

While American air and naval forces deploy in the Far East to discourage further Communist aggression, the main design of President Eisenhower's China policy, which calls for United Nations intervention to end the present hostilities, is beginning to make progress.

THE latest musical import from Italy, Maria Tipo, breaks precedent in not being a string player. In the last few seasons, chamber organizations from Italy have been making no little stir in these parts. Miss Tipo is a pianist, and last night she made her American debut in Town Hall.

This is an era of speedy reading. There are those who now read half as much in order to read twice as much. When they read Somerset Maugham's chopped editions of "Moby Dick" and "Wuthering Heights" they read, in theory, two books instead of one of ordinary length.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Jan. 24 -- A struggle for the loyalty of the aborigines of the jungle-covered mountains in the center of Malaya has become a vital part of the war against the Communist insurgents.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The State Department stepped into the background today to let the United Nations maneuver toward a cease-fire in Formosa Strait.

Waterfront management and labor struck back yesterday at Samuel M. Lane, general counsel and executive director of the Waterfront Commission, who castigated both the International Longshoremen's Association, independent, and the employers in a speech Thursday night.
FORT SILL, Okla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- A witness identified the voice in a recording played in court today as that of Maj. Ambrose H. Nugent.

The Missouri - Kansas - Texas (Katy) Railroad Company has completed its plan of recapitalization designed to satisfy dividend arrearages of $150.50 a share on its 667,005 shares of $7 preferred stock and will file terms of the plan with the Interstate Commerce Commission next week.
Jewish organizations in New York protested yesterday against the death sentences passed by the Egyptian Government against two Israelis convicted of spying in Cairo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Farm product prices increased 2 per cent between mid-December land mid-January, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 29 -- The defending champions, James Ethridge and Carl Badger of the Field Club of Greenwich, moved toward their third-straight Greenwich invitation doubles squash racquets title at Greenwich Country Club today. They won two matches to reach tomorrow morning's semi-finals.

IN the dim dirt-road past a trail blazer slashed signs of his passing on trees along the way. Today trail blazers are round aluminum signs, eighteen inches across and reflectorized, too. Complemented by arrows and occasional bits of prose like "Next Right," they guide motorists to express toll highways like the New Jersey Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and the New York Thruway.

Charles P. Cooper, president of the board of the Presbyterian Hospital at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, praised 300 hospital volunteers at the annual awards tea last week for "their banner year."

PARIS, Sunday, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The Soviet Union and her East European satellites have 6,000,000 men under arms with their fighting power "greatly increased by mechanization and modernization," Lord Ismay, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, reported today.
Most Americans, including those living in localities with freezing temperatures, will be able to enjoy fresh fruits and vegetables at meals today.

A new device with which it is possible to generate a vibrating signal which calculations indicate would not vary more than one second in 300 years was described here last week before the 1955 annual meeting of the American Physical Society.

THE 146th anniversary of the birth of Felix Mendelssohn-Bartholdy on Feb. 3, 1809, comes next Thursday It will be interesting to compare, are the verdict of coming decides upon his character and music with that of the half-century behind us.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Social work schools must step up their "output" of graduates to meet the serious shortages of trained personnel in the field.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Former President Hoover suggested tonight "birth control" of Federal documents to cut down on needless paper work.
A former mud chemist in Trinidad who seeks an M. D. degree from Harvard University will pass another milestone toward his goal tomorrow.

Aside from the thirty-ninth Annual Exhibition of American Graphic Artists, opening on Friday at the Kennedy Galleries, 785 Fifth Avenue, most of this week's numerous events are one-man shows of painting.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- Employment gains in Pennsylvania factories during October and November were maintained in December, when 1,022,000 workers averaged $71.99 a week, or about 50 cents above November.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- Two old sculptors who worked for many years in the Americas under Western influences are represented in the current All-Union Art Exhibition in Moscow.

TRENTON, Jan. 29 -- The New Jersey Legislature will reconvene Monday to receive the annual budget message of Gov. Robert B. Meyner. The Republican majority in both houses has promised to enact a number of important but controversial bills later in the day.
The Department of Hospitals is solidly behind the Health Department's budget request for $535,000 in supplemental funds to fight tuberculosis.

Of all possible plants, annuals have the greatest flexibility for making color compositions. The annuals chosen for the plan below are limited to those which can be sown directly in prepared ground to flower there. Five groups of yellow zinnias are used to give unity to the pattern of the plan and to provide contrast in form and texture with the mass of softer flowers.

JANUARY brings seed and nursery catalogues as surely as May brings lilacs and August sweet corn. Catalogues, lilacs and sweet corn -each one is a crop to be savored. The catalogues, however, have a special importance, for they are one key to the finest of flowers and harvests and gardens.
Polarization of the proton, heart of the hydrogen atom and one of the two fundamental building blocks of the nuclei of the atoms of which the cosmos is constituted, has been achieved.

Circumstances have compelled the United States and its friends to take a firm stand in various parts of the world. We will not, for example, permit the conquest of Formosa by the, Chinese Communists. We will not permit the invasion of Western Europe by Communist forces.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A program for the orderly withdrawal of the Government from the fields of private business was dramatized by the Administration this week.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- The favored Wolverhampton Wanderers advanced in the Football Association Cup race today with a 1-0, fourth-round victory over Arsenal.

LENINGRAD, U. S. S. R., Jan. 14 -- Contrary to some Western impressions, communism has not purged the sense of humor of the Russian people. They still laugh at themselves and at the foibles of the Socialist system. They are often amused by the same things that foreigners find ludicrous in this country.

RED CHINA, with an immense population of 583,000,000 (more than three and one-half times that of the United States) and an annual steel output of around 2,000,000 tons (about one-fiftieth of the United States output) presents a striking paradox in this sixth year of Communist rule.
MIAMI, Jan. 29 -- To the Hasty House Farms' Sea O Erin went first money of $12,600 in the $18,175 Royal Palm Handicap at Hialeah Race Course today.

Stuyvesant High won the twentieth annual interscholastic fencing tournament yesterday on the New York University strips. The peglegs went unbeaten in five bouts to capture the Castello Trophy, which was held for the past two years by Brooklyn's Boys High.

Uranium mining activity in the rocky canyons and mesas of the Colorado Plateau has expanded sharply in two and a half years. Today about 600 uranium mines are being operated in that high tableland stretching across tens of thousands of square miles in Colorado, Utah, New Mexico and Arizona. The figure also includes a few properties in Wyoming and South Dakota.

Shifts of four high-ranking Fire Department officers were announced last week by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. The transfers were made in connection with the department's new Bureau of Personnel and Administration, Uniformed Force.

PLANTINGS of the small fruits and grapes are the answer for the average property owner. For these crops are easy to manage with a comparatively moderate amount of equipment and "know-how." The main tree fruit crops are best left to the nurserymen who have the necessary spray and pruning equipment and technical knowledge to grow them successfully.

THE Rolleicord, low-cost twin of the Rolleiflex camera, appeared with new features last week in the model V, priced at $149.50 with eveready leather case. The principal innovations are the cross-coupled lens diaphragm and shutter speed scales, recently introduced in the f/3.5 Rolleiflex; the large focusing knob, with improved readability of the scales, and built-in film speed reminder; three-way synchronization lever for flash exposures at all shutter speeds and electronic flash, plus built-in self-timer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A leading expert warned today against premature closing of tuberculosis hospitals on the theory that the disease now may be treated by drugs alone.
Henry Salaun of the University Club, Boston, gained the semi-final round of the ninth annual Harry Cowles squash racquets tournament at the Harvard Club yesterday.

VERSAILLES, France, Jan. 20 -- The 300-year-long struggle by French kings and presidents, courtiers, politicians and lackeys to keep warm in the Palace of Versailles is scheduled to end successfully in 1956.

The general support given to President Eisenhower on the defense of Formosa appears to have strengthened the Administration's hand on prospective tariff cuts for Japanese goods. Such reductions would be aimed at increasing Japan's trade with the free world.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 29 -- The appointment of Dr. John Turkevich, a member of the Princeton faculty for nineteen years, as Eugene Higgins Professor of Chemistry was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.
A NEW line of traffic-control devices, designed to keep pace with faster airplanes and more of them, is beginning to emerge from the laboratories for installation at the nation's busier airports.
SAXTONS RIVER, Vt., Jan. 29 -- Vermont Academy was host today to Deerfield and Kimball Union for winter carnival festivities dating back to 1909.
LYNN, Mass., Jan. 29 (UP) -- Fire swept a three-story wooden lodging house that housed many aged persons here early today, killing three and injuring nine.
Privately financed home building last year reached its highest volume since 1950 throughout New York State.

DRIED arrangements, the vogue during winter months, are often accented with the tall, delicate stalks of honesty, Lunaria annua. These stately branches trimmed with shimmering circles of silver make a beautiful arrangement suited to any decor.
A key group of American executives view the immediate business outlook with cautious optimism. That is the finding of the January survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- Wes Santee broke all listed indoor records for the mile run tonight. He clipped off eight furlongs in 4:03.8 on the eleven-lap Boston Garden track in the featured Hunter Mile of the sixty-sixth annual Boston Athletic Association games.

THE prison, as now tolerated, is a constant threat to everyone's security. An anachronistic relic of medieval concepts of crime and punishment, it not only does not cure the crime problem; it perpetuates and multiplies it. We profess to rely upon the prison for our safety; yet it is directly responsible for much of the damage that society suffers at the hands of offenders.
The record volume of trans-Atlantic air traffic in 1954 probably will be exceeded in 1955, airline executives believe.

Nat (Sweetwater) Clifton's lay-up four seconds from the end of the five-minute overtime period gave the New York Knickerbockers a 95-to-93 triumph over the Milwaukee Hawks in a National Basketball Association game at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

Restoration of a recreation center for tuberculous children will be advanced by the March 24 performance of "Three for Tonight." The musical, starring Harry Belafonte and Marge and Gower Champion, opens here March 21.

The New York State Board of Business and Professional Women's Clubs presented citations yesterday to the South Brooklyn Savings and Loan Association and the Abraham Strauss department store for their policy of placing women in executive, managerial and supervisory posts.
Many of New York's ill and undernourished babies and children will continue to receive free milk as a result of the March 8 performance of "Tosca" at the Metropolitan.
Scientific and manpower experts warned last week that the United States was losing the battle for engineering manpower to the Soviet Union.

" IT'S the hardest thing in the world," a mother told us recently, "to think of what to buy my 10-year-old for his birthday. He isn't consistently interested in anything any more. Oh, he keeps busy enough.

The Panel of Americans, a program aimed at bettering interracial and interreligious relations, will be presented tomorrow evening at 8:30 P. M. at the Hunter College High School Auditorium, 930 Lexington Avenue.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 29 -- President Eisenhower flew down today to his favorite golfing retreat for two days of rest and play.
TORONTO, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Any move to disfranchise the Toronto Argonauts may cost the other three clubs in the Big Four League $30,000 and a $1,000,000 law suit.

WITH the opening of the New York City Ballet at the City Center on Feb. 15 we will begin the annual spring freshet of ballet seasons, long and short. This time, indeed, the definite announcements extend over into next fall, for already S. Hurok has made official the visit of the Sadler's Wells Ballet for another American tour.

JAZZ, Langston Hughes says firmly, is fun. Unlike many of its devotees, he doesn't regard it as a peculiarly esoteric art; instead he writes with a refreshing lack of pomposity and with a clarity which will delight those who might be, reasonably enough, confused at the differences between cool and hot, swing and bebop.
World-wide ship construction under the supervision of the American Bureau of Shipping increased considerably in December with the placing of twenty-three orders for large ocean-going tonnage.

A NEAR-PERFECT account of polar exploration, "The White Desert," describes an international expedition to Queen Maud Land, the Norwegian Antarctic territory. The expedition represented an effort to counter unpleasant nationalism that had arisen in that remote quarter.

IN these days of suddenly reduced record prices, and an even greater spurt in the discount business, record bargains are plentiful. But a bargain of bargains is the six-disk set of all the six Tchaikovsky , on Victor's Cam- label.

THE recent appearance of a new life of Gauguin ("Noble Savage," by Lawrence and Elisabeth Hanson) will bring to mind for many readers a novel by Somerset Maugham which was published here in the distant world of 1919.

HARTFORD, Jan. 29 -- The Connecticut General Assembly has received 2,300 bills.

The International League met in the Commodore yesterday, ratified a 154-game schedule and formally welcomed Columbus into the circuit. Columbus, which for years operated in the American Association, temporarily became a city without a ball club last November when its Association franchise was shifted to Omaha. EVERY prominent American river has its folk portrait in the gallery of the national consciousness. From that bridge the river below looked a mile wide and an inch deep.
