IN the television age, it has become something of a fad to mourn the demise of the art of conversation. Miscellaneous experts have concluded that the country's narcotic preoccupation with the TV screen has shut off the flow of good talk. The nation's households, it is suggested, have become little tombs of dark silence, broken only by the voice of urgency coming from afar.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Government officials say that far more persons are getting unemployment payments through fraud and error than had been thought.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 29 -- The endorsement by Congress of President Eisenhower's "defend Formosa" policy cleared the way here today for the withdrawal of Chinese Nationalist troops from the Tachen Islands with United States Seventh Fleet assistance.

SIMONE DE BEAUVOIR, a recent winner of the Goncourt Prize, is a skilled and accomplished technician who brings to her writing the variety and richness of a well-stored mind. Her panoramic novel, "All Men Are Mortal," contains many ideas, none of them new, but at least here newly assembled in orderly pattern.
Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson appealed yesterday for greater responsibility and cost-sharing by local governments to promote efficiency and savings in Washington.

Stravinsky was the featured composer at yesterday's young people's concert of the Little Orchestra Society in Hunter College Auditorium. This was unusual, for generally the composers introduced to the children are such figures as Beethoven, Brahms, Wagner and Tchaikovsky.

THIS is the fascinating report of a treatment with Freud which lasted nearly four months. It reads like a novel and at the end many a reader will sigh: "Is this what psychoanalysis is?" Some scientists will look at it as an objective, honest document wherein are closely revealed the errors of a psychological system and its creator. Yet, one cannot take this book merely at face value.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 29 -- The bitter political warfare between the Government and the Opposition has abated notably in recent weeks. The outlook for the development of genuine parliamentary Democracy in Turkey has improved correspondingly.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- If the name of Stalin stands for anything in the Soviet Union it stands for the rapid industrialization of this country and for a war victory that was won on the basis of industrial power.

OF the many books published by Bertrand Russell none has the air of such desperate urgency as this one. He believes that the world is in a bad way, with poor prospects of survival. Despite a concluding chapter painting a vivid picture of what human society might be, we are almost persuaded by the earlier chapters that our situation is hopeless because of the imminence of atomic warfare.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 -- A bulldog that was eligible for further judgings died today at the opening of the two-day dog show of the Maryland Kennel Club.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics filed the contract of another "if" pitcher today and read hopefully encouraging reports on his ailing arm.

THE National Book Award -- our book industry's counterpoise to the Pulitzer Prize -- this week gave gold medals to William Faulkner (see page 4) for his novel "A Fable," to Joseph Wood Krutch for a work of nonfiction.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Navy confirmed today that Leonard Benzi, 185-pound guard from its Sugar Bowl champion football team, would be ineligible for play next fall.
AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- The Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company today announced plans to end its century-old carpet manufacturing here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- The United Nations' first international conference on the peaceful uses of atomic energy will have a broad agenda that will enable all nations to appraise more accurately their resources and potentialities in the atomic age, Prof. I. I. Rabi, United States physicist, said today.

A major aspect of the post-war international scene has been the economic competition between the free world and the Communist world, competition in speed of development of resources and in industrialization. For some time there has been concern expressed both by Government officials and by private citizens in the free world over the outlook for this competition in the future.

A strike threatened for 12:01 A. M., Tuesday, was averted early yesterday when agreement was reached between the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, and newspaper and magazine wholesalers.

IN "Admiral Kimmel's Story" a man sorely buffeted by circumstances beyond his control seeks to convince a wide public of the honesty and ability of his stewardship in a situation of extraordinary difficulty. As such, his book deserves respectful examination.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- For three days specialists from varied fields have urged adoption workers meeting here to be more flexible and less perfectionistic.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Western Europe's reaction to recent developments in the Far East and in Washington range from Britain's concern to Germany's disinterest in any problem that does not affect the basic issue of reunification of the country.

TALKEETNA, Alaska, Jan. 29 -- Airborne engineers worked through the bitter subarctic night to build a wilderness runway. Other troops of the 503d Airborne Regimental Combat Team closed with a simulated invading force.

Last week Pakistan's Governor General, Ghulam Mohammed, went to New Delhi, the Indian capital, to join in the celebration of India's Day of the Republic. After several days of cordial association with Indian friends of long standing, he and his party have now returned to Karachi.

PHILADELPHIA -- Purchasing a railroad and Pullman ticket at the Pennsylvania Railroad's Thirtieth Street Station here is no longer a simple, hand-made transaction. Since last Sunday it has been a transaction involving electronics, facsimile machines, photo-electric cells, electrically sensitive paper, and prefabricated matrices that print the tickets fresh for each customer.

" UNTOUCHABLE, unreachable and unquotable" -- this is the way a friend of his sums up Robert Cutler, the Special Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs. The description is apt -- both because of the nature of Cutler's job and the nature of the man.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- In four short weeks relations between Governor Harriman, a Democrat, and the Republicans in control of the Legislature have reached the game-cock stage despite early protestations of a desire for mutual cooperation.

Adelphi College of Garden City, L. I., retained its winter collegiate track conference championship at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. Adelphi totaled 51 points to City College's 49 in the eight-hour competition.

Studies which may throw new light on the origin of life on earth are being supported by a grant of $20,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York. The studies will be conducted at Queen's University, Kingston, Ont.

HOLLAND is planning a great exhibition in Rotterdam that will introduce visitors to the people of the Netherlands. The name given the exhibition is "E 55 -- a Manifestation of Dutch Energy." According to the announcement, "E stands for Energy and 55 for the year 1955 and 5 plus 5 make 10 -- for ten years of achievement since the end of World War II."

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 29 -Admiral Stump, 60, a lanky aviator with 37 years of service, an outstanding combat record, a keen tactical mind and a sometimes salty temper, directs Army, Navy and Air Force units in an area twenty times the size of the United States.

The date was Thursday, Jan. 20 -- Dwigitt D. Eisenhower's second anniversary as President. The occasion was a meeting of the nation's highest policy-making body, the National Security Council. On entering the Cabinet Room the President was surprised by a festive gathering of White House aides; for an anniversary present they gave him books on painting.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Suggested changes in the State Constitution to legalize bingo have drawn attention again to a fundamental difference between New York State's Constitution and the Federal Constitution.
TRIESTE, Italy, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Yugoslav frontier guards shot and wounded an Italian soldier today in the first border incident between the two countries since Italy took over Trieste last Oct. 26.

AN interesting sidelight on the subject of the motorist who tries to combine drinking and driving is provided by a report which has been prepared by the New York State Department of Public Works in cooperation with the Bureau of Public Roads.

Adherents of the three major religious faiths were called upon yesterday to make up their minds on the ethical and social problems in the playing of bingo to raise funds for religious and charitable organizations.

" THE FAMILY OF MAN," a sweeping panorama of more than 500 photographs which symbolize the universality of basic human emotions as recorded by 257 photographers and representing incidents in sixty-eight countries, was opened at the Museum of Modern Art last week after more than two years of preparation under the direction of Edward Steichen, head of the museum's department of photography.
MOST hunters who are really interested can stretch their sport far beyond the narrow confines of the actual hunting season. However, the duck hunters seem to have the greatest opportunities.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- Proposals for a cease-fire in the Formosa Strait were denounced here today as "nothing less than blackmail" against Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -- The Government expects mounting losses on all but one of the six basic crops in the next two years.

MONTICELLO, N. Y. -- The report has reached here that ski enthusiasts are experimenting with the use of "plastic snow." It is a story that is being met with mixed emotions in these parts where officials at two popular resorts, Grossinger Country Club and the Concord Hotel, have invested thousands of dollars on artificial snow-making apparatus.
SANDS POINT, L. I., Jan. 29 -- The Sands Point Community Synagogue has won a major victory in its two-year fight to establish a house of worship here.

WORLD FIRST--The oldest town in the world has been found. It is M'lefaat, in northeastern Iraq. The establishment of the town marks the point more than 7,000 years ago when man first turned from nomadic hunting to agriculture. This is considered the first great revolution in man's history.
A smoky fire broke out in a superstructure on the roof of the Sheraton-Astor Hotel in Times Square shortly after 8 o'clock last night, but caused little damage and no injuries.

" The free world," says the American Tariff League in a full-page ad in your Jan. 20 issue, "is doing fine." So why, asks the league, should we concern ourselves with building up the free world's strength with more trade? More precisely, why continue the reciprocal trade agreements program?

WHEN they recently replaced the floorboards of an upstairs room at Croft Rectory in Yorkshire, childhood haunt of Lewis Carroll, they uncovered, among other items, a thimble, a small white glove, a child's left shoe and a piece of scantling which bore the penciled legend.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- The host New York Caledonian curling club's No. 1 rink, skipped by Frank S. Baker, led the way into the semi-finals of the Caledonian's centennial bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club today. Also advancing in afternoon quarter-final matches were rinks representing the Thistle Club of Montreal, led by Dick Walsh, and the Utica (N. Y.) Curling Club, piloted by Ward Murray.

A KAFFEEKLATSCH is a Viennese coffee party of immediate appeal to Americans. We are now the largest coffee consumers in the world, downing the bracing beverage at the annual per capita rate of 680 cups.

HOUSE plant growers may find the answers to their perplexing problems at the New York Botanical Garden. A new exhibit "House Plants and Their Care" is now on display in the conservatory and will continue through Feb. 13.

GARDENERS have at least two things in common -- optimism and short memories. With last year's failures forgotten, the gardener, comfortable in an easy chair, visualizes anew a beautiful lawn, clean, luscious fruits and vegetables, trim shrubs and colorful flower beds.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Food and Drug Administration released today a rather reassuring report on the effect of an atomic blast on forty-two common drug preparations.

I WENT to a wedding recently that was like many weddings these days: the groom was a graduate student, the bride a college junior, and both were going back to the university after their honeymoon. The occasion was unusual in one respect: the bride's mother, too, had married in her junior year and had gone on to get her degree -- but only by keeping her marriage secret.

EVERYONE loves a parade -- the flags, the uniforms -- especially the rousing music of the bands. Familiar tunes like "The Washington Post," "The Thunderer," "El Capitan" and "The Stars and Stripes Forever" set millions of feet to beating time.

Before February, and Ground-hog Day, and all the other distractions one might as well sit by the fire an hour or so and see if the answers are visible in the flames or audible in the wind in the chimney. Why do beech trees hold their sere leaves all winter? Why don't the wythes of red osier dogwood look really red until the sap begins to rise ?

AS the author says. "The Day Lincoln Was Shot" is "about a day, a place and a murder -- and about a wide variety of men and women." The elapsed time is 24 hours 22 minutes, starting at 7 A. M. on Good Friday, April 14, 1865, the day of Lincoln's assassination.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The State Department's refusal of passports to relatives of American airmen held in Communist China as "spies" today met with the approval of thirteen of those relatives who met here for a dinner in their honor.

CAIRO, Jan. 29 -- Arab dissension over the decision of Iraq to sign an alliance with Turkey appeared tonight to have reached a new extreme of bitterness. It again threatened to shatter the Arab League.

BRYAN MacMAHON, a Kerry school teacher, some six years ago published a book which added a new name to the considerable list of living Irishmen who write good short stories. In 1952 he published a novel, "Children of the Rainbow," a highly colored picture of a Munster village in a series of its fetes and festivals.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan 29 -- Army caught Columbia's favored basketball team napping today but was unable to capitalize on it. The result was a 75-to-69 defeat for the cadets after a five-minute overtime period in the contest played on the big field-house court.

RECENT events have focused attention on the extraordinary degree of American preoccupation with the question of security in Government employment. Never in the past, not even in wartime, has the issue excited so much public attention and provoked so much controversy.

The New York Public Library's recorded concert on Wednesday between noon and 2 P. M. in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building will include a selection by Kirsten Flagstad from "Die Walkuere," the opera in which the Wagnerian star made her debut here twenty years ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Government was confident tonight it had discovered a solution to the difficult butter surplus problem.
BERLIN, Jan. 29 -- The Soviet declaration ending the state of war with Germany is expected here to be followed by the release of many Germans from Russia.
BERLIN, Jan. 29 -- The official newspaper of the Soviet High Commission and the Soviet Army pleaded today for a "German-Russian bond of friendship" that would guarantee the peace of Europe.
AN investigation of the tactics of pitchmen on radio and television, begun formally last week in Brooklyn, has met with widespread public approval.

RICHARD III, the crook-backed, malevolent murderer who rose to the throne of England dripping the blood of many victims, is the latest figure Laurence Olivier has chosen to bring to life on the screen. "Richard III," due here in the fall, is Olivier's third major movie taken from Shakespeare, and offers him the challenge of a role far different from the forthright, heroic warrior of "Henry V" or the brooding prince of "Hamlet."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today that a super super bomb might be in the works.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Willie Mays, New York Giants' center fielder who won the National League batting title last season, added the Puerto Rican Winter League title to his list of honors with a percentage of .395.

" THE CRUCIBLE," Arthur Miller's forceful drama about the witch trials in colonial Salem, which opened a respectable 197-performance stand on Broadway back in January, 1953, seems headed for the movies at long last.

WHEN gardeners think of protection they visualize many things -mulches, windbreaks, fences, shading, etc. -- all related to their plants. But when the Federal Trade Commission thinks of garden' protection its thoughts are of the gardeners themselves.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Send in orders promptly for seeds, both those to be sown outdoors and those to be started early in a cold-frame or the house. Order roses, shrubs and fruits to be certain of getting desired varieties.

THE complaint voiced recently by New York City Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley that the new American automobiles are too long, too wide and too powerful recalls a drive to and from Florida taken recently in a European pygmy automobile that is none of these things.

WITH the "peace" getting a little shaky as a result of the Chinese Communist threat to Formosa, a new note of uncertainty has crept into the economy. Industry might find itself quickly in a position similar to that of June, 1950, when the United States took up the defense of South Korea.

United States Immigration inspectors have been sent to Bermuda to begin on Tuesday a new system of examining travel documents of plane and ship passengers before they leave the island rather than after they land here or in Washington.

THE hardest-working dog on Broadway is a whippet-sized actor getting on toward his middle thirties named Norman Shelly. On television or in mufti, Shelly looks a little like Jose Ferrer and is fairly crawling with what is known as empathy for dogs, having had some emotional involvements with them at an early age.

Fordham's basketball team last night scored a bit of an upset by defeating Seton Hall, 75--55, at the Rams' gymnasium. It was not so much an upset so far as the victory went, but the margin of 20 points certainly was unexpected.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew clamped an iron grip on the lead in his bid for a tenth senior men's title today at the halfway point of the national outdoor speed-skating championships.

A RECENT announcement of British operations in Antarctica said that one or more bases would be established on Deception Island. The news put a brief spotlight on one of the many places in the world which carry grim and meaningful nomenclature.
For the last week the citizens of Disputanta, a village of 250 on the edge of Virginia's peanut belt, have viewed with satisfaction and relief the culmination of a year's work.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 - Sixteen thousand former service men are awaiting admission to Veterans Administration hospitals for treatment of mental disorders.

As tension mounted in the Far East, there were moves by Soviet Russia indicating it felt tension was also rising in Europe. To what extent the moves reflected genuine concern, as distinguished from propaganda aimed at the West, was uncertain. They came in the related fields of Soviet economic policy and Soviet foreign policy.

Small business -- concerns employing 500 or fewer -- has had a healthy share of the $5,500,000,000 cash disbursed by the Air Force in 1954. Figures from Wright Field last week for the first time disclosed the actual total cash expenditures.

The five Red Cross Chapters in New York City are recruiting women between 23 and 40 years old to be Red Cross clubmobile workers in Japan, Korea, Okinawa and the Philippines and Red Cross overseas secretaries.
MIAMI, Jan. 29 -- Barbara Romack's chipping finesse and Pat Lesser's on-target putting today carried the two West Coast girls to the final of the Helen Lee Doherty amateur golf tournament.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast the following text of the Soviet statement handed to the Japanese Premier:

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29 -- Although beaten to the wire by a neck, the stretch-running Determine won the $163,360 Santa Anita Maturity today when Calumet's Miz Clementine was penalized for bumping the little gray in the stretch.

THE air is full of news about American opera companies. In Chicago the Lyric Theatre announced that it had lost so little money in last year's three-week season that next fall it will give a five-week season. In Boston the San Carlo Opera Company, dormant since 1951 when Fortune Gallo retired to write his memoirs, will come to life with an eight-day stand, starting tonight.

American railroads, which spread a network of 35,000 mailing points over this country between the Eighteen Fifties and the Nineteen Twenties, are worried that someone is going to do to them what they did to the canal and wagon routes they supplanted.
The Citizens Union has urged the Temporary State Commission on the Courts to avoid recommending additional Supreme Court justices at this time.

NEW YORK owes its eminence primarily to its natural advantages. New York is a "natural city." Its matchless deep harbor, its navigable rivers and creeks, marshes, the Sound, the rock ridge of Manhattan, the Palisades, its moraines and glacial outwashes, meadowlands, forests -- all these were here when Henry Hudson came.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 29 -- Twenty small shop owners say they will file suit in Superior Court in Trenton next month to block a proposed $10,000,000 redevelopment project.

RENEWED activity is evident among new independent producing sources. The variety and scope of their efforts, though not stupendous, were indicated by the fact that no less than five newcomers to the field contributed to the news last week.

The Cyrus Sulzberger column of Jan. 22 dealing with the complex problem of American relationships with France on the Vietnam issue is a most realistic appraisal of the situation. The fact that Paris "has secretly concluded an agreement with the Ho Chi Minh Government granting the equivalent of recognition" with all the implications of that statement is out in the open.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 29 -- Business activity, as measured in the movement of goods, is in for a slight decline during the first quarter of 1955 in the Ninth Federal Reserve District, on the basis of figures compiled by the Northwest Shippers Advisory Board.

The Hall of Fame special committee on baseball veterans gathered for their biennial meeting yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore to vote on stars and other notables active in baseball more than twenty-five years ago.
TALKEETNA, Alaska, Jan. 30 -- Pvt. Stanley Melczak of Hamburg, Pa., plunged 1,000 feet yesterday with an unopened parachute and is talking about it today.
Apparently oblivious to the nipping winter weather, smiling President Paul E. Magloire and Mme. Magloire led a party of eleven prominent Haitians in two ceremonial appearances here yesterday.
What the church can do for youth and what youth can do for the church highlighted a Youth Sunday sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Grain and soybean futures moved up sharply on the Chinese situation, stimulating general buying as well as much short covering in all pits. After the initial run-up in prices, however, there was profit taking, and buyers were inclined to be cautious in following upturns.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 30 -- "The tallest dog in Ireland" won best in show tonight in the forty-second event of the Maryland Kennel Club.

GEORGE LE VIND has been an engraver for sixty-three of his seventy-eight years. For the last fifty-eight he has worked for Gorham and for Black Starr and Gorham, jewelers and silversmiths. He is probably the dean of his vanishing craft.

LE COUDRAY-ST.-GERMER, France, Jan. 14 -- Television has brought new life to this small French village. It has helped to rekindle a spirit lost after World War II, when the youth left the land and moved into the city.

William Lombardy, New York State champion, and Franklin Howard of East Orange, N. J., played to a draw yesterday, in the thirteenth round of the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club. The match went to thirty-nine moves. With 10 points each to their credit, Howard and Lombardy remained in a tie for the lead.

Italy, like France, has just sent us a new Ambassador and it goes without saying that Rome picked the best man who could be found. Manlio Brosio arrives today to take the place filled with such distinction for ten years by Alberto Tarchiani.

Unless Soviet Russia restores elemental human rights within its borders there is no reason to believe the Kremlin desires to become a "peaceful member of the family of nations." This declaration was made yesterday by the American Jewish Committee.
The French Line has named Jacques Y. Douguet, assistant general manager of the company here, to be director of Algiers operations.

The Temporary State Housing Rent Commission recovered $245,272 last year for tenants in 2,655 cases involving overcharges, bonus payments, tie-in sales and fraudulent commercial leases, according to the annual report yesterday by Charles Abrams, Rent Administrator.
Soviet leaders appear to be preparing their people and their economy against the possibility that current international tension may lead to war.

Chuck beef, potatoes and instant nonfat dry milk are all thrifty selections in the markets. The three may be combined in a hearty hot dish that is an appetizing and nutritious fortification against winter weather.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 -- Two giants of the auto industry are preparing to come to grips with a union giant on the question of a guaranteed annual wage.
GARRISON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- When Malcolm Kenneth Gordon, 87 - year - old master of history at the Malcolm Gordon School here, talks about hockey, he really dips into the past.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Art Devlin of the Lake Placid Sno Birds captured the trophy in the thirty-fourth annual meet of the Norsemen Ski Club at this resort's 50-meter hill today. He topped a field of six Class A competitors that included the United States champion, Roy Sherwood, who fell in the second round.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30 -- A dispute that threatened to wreck the fifty-year-old labor peace machinery in New York's giant construction industry appeared on its way toward a settlement today.

In a deal in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn three houses with a total of fifty-one apartments at 545-53-57 Forty-sixth Street have been sold by Mayer Halpern to the Kalgo Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $101,000. J.Milton Weinstein was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $123,000.
A 30-year-old man, free on bail on a charge of receiving stolen goods, was found shot dead yesterday afternoon in the front seat of a cream-colored car parked on a Greenwich Village street.

THE Concert Society of New York assembled first-class artists for its twelfth concert of the season late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. For the chamber works there was the Trio di Trieste, which has not played here since its first United States season in 1948-49. For Wagner's "Wesendonk Lieder" there was the Metropolitan Opera soprano, Margaret Harshaw.
A telephone call, apparently from a crank, made personnel at La Guardia Airport jittery early yesterday by reporting that someone would board a plane with nitroglycerine to commit suicide.
The men's clothing industry operated at 71 per cent of capacity last year, compared with 79 per cent in 1953, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States of America.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30 -- An American Federation of Labor leader praised President Eisenhower today for his policy toward American shipping.
Third Avenue and Fourteenth Street to Twentieth Street continues to experience a flurry of realty trading presaging new housing developments.

Indications increased yesterday that intruders were in the home of Serge Rubinstein at 814 Fifth Avenue before he returned from a night club about 1:30 A. M. Thursday. He was killed there a few hours later.

WARM SPRINGS, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A model of the Pilgrim ship Mayflower, made from timbers of the original vessel, was presented to the former Little White House today in conjunction with the observance of President Roosevelt's birthday.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30 -For centuries a hunters' paradise, India this week will plan Government action to prevent the extinction of many species of beasts and birds.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Ronald Paterson showed a new silhouette, the Goblet, in his collection.

The boards of the Pacific Fire Insurance Company, the Bankers and Shippers Insurance Company of New York and the New Jersey Insurance Company of New York have voted to increase the capital stock of these companies by transferring funds from surplus and to issue corresponding stock dividends to shareholders.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- A soft-molded feminine line was a feature of the last day of the half-yearly showings by the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers, at which the main spring and summer couture collections were shown.

As never before in our history this nation's security rests in the hands of its scientists and engineers in the technological front lines of scientific progress. Nuclear weapons, intercontinental guided missiles, supersonic jet planes, radar warning nets, these are the sorts of complex instruments on which depends our ability to preserve peace and to resist aggression if it comes.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Koppers Company, Inc., said today it had received a contract for the design, engineering and procurement of equipment to be used in construction of the largest blast furnace in Spain.
TOKYO, Jan. 30 -- Negotiations between Japan and the Soviet Union to end the technical state of war have been shifted from Tokyo to United Nations headquarters, Japanese sources said today.

" When Men Are Free," an explanation of the beliefs and ideals that have guided the development of American institutions since Colonial times, will be published Feb. 10 by Houghton Mifflin. The authors are a group from the Citizenship Education Project at Teachers College, Columbia University.
Canon Darby W. Betts of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) said yesterday that he feared the American business man and his church were at odds with each other.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A "city boy" drafted into the Congressional farm group set out today to discover what it's all about.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -- Winthrop G. Brown, economic counselor of the United States Embassy in London, denied here last week that the United States was reversing its liberal trade policy.
Following closely in the footsteps of the National League, the American League yesterday made it clear it, too, was in no great hurry to expand to a ten-club circuit.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Stanley Benham went out today, less than twenty-four hours after being barred from international competition for three years, and smashed two more records in piloting his bobsled to the Adirondack A. A. U. two-man championship.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Franz Kapus, a Swiss chauffeur, nosed out his countryman, Fritz Feierabend, by three-hundredths of a second today to capture the world four-man bobsled championship for the first time.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Mortie Dutra of Los Angeles developed a magic putting touch on the incoming nine today to win the National P. G. A. senior golf tournament by four strokes.

Gary Towlen, a 12-year-old pianist, made his debut with a program yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. He played Bach's C minor Partita, Schumann's "Papillons" and pieces by Rachmaninoff, Liszt and Villa-Lobos.

RYE, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Efforts by three persons to save a young skater who had broken through the ice of Long Island Sound were futile today and the three would-be rescuers had to be dragged from the water themselves.
PARIS, Jan. 30 -- The index of living costs in France shows a steady rise from the end of August to the beginning of January.
ULLSWATHER, England, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The campaign to bring the world water speed record back to Great Britain is scheduled to begin this week when Donald Campbell tests his new hydroplane.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden called here tonight on Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India to discuss the situation in Formosa.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 30 -- The living symbol of the twentieth century has come to be that tragic jetsam of destiny, the refugee, a harsh word for an unwanted and homeless human being. Millions of Russians, Poles, Indians, Germans, Chinese; of Christians, Jews, Moslems, Hindus and Buddhists have fled the cruel waves of chaos successively engulfing our time.
HARTFORD, Jan. 30 -- Voting habits of many Fairfield County commuters would be seriously affected by an absentee ballot bill before the Connecticut General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -High officials of the Department of Agriculture told Wolf Ladejinsky as late as Oct. 15, 1954, that he could not be spared from his post as agricultural attache in Tokyo.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 30 -- The bright red stub of a movie ticket saved the life of Evert Stenmark, 25-year-old professional ptarmigan trapper, in the Arctic wilds of Sweden today.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30 -- An American Federation of Labor union pledged full cooperation today in efforts to oust Communists from plants manufacturing glass and plastic containers.
Publication of The Brooklyn Eagle was halted again yesterday by a strike of the New York Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., which began on Saturday.
Unified action by Government and private capital is needed to replace 85 per cent of the nation's privately owned tankers, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Six recommendations for providing better education for gifted children in public, private and parochial schools were made today by the Regents Council on the Readjustment of High School Education.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 30 -Mayor W. Gerould Clark Jr., Republican, announced today that he had appointed John H. Perry, a New York City schoolteacher, to the Englewood Board of Education.
Scouting charges that "baseball is dying," Commissioner Ford C. Frick declared last night that more Americans were interested in the game today than ever before.

Sears, Roebuck Co., mail-order house and retailer through its own stores, is to enter the trading stamp field, according to an Associated Press dispatch from Chicago. It has organized a subsidiary, Four Star Stamp Company, which will issue trading stamps in 25-cent denomination to retailers in a group of Illinois cities.
Operations of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company last year resulted in a deficit of $4,592,295, contrasted with net income of $4,248,078 for 1953.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UP) -- All officers of Local 1010 of the United Steelworkers Union, C. I. O., were suspended by the union today.

Walt Whitman's "Leaves of Grass" occupies the stage in an exhibition opening today at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. This is the centennial year of the publication of the first edition of "Leaves," and the show arranged in tribute makes available the library's riches in Whitman material.

Governor Harriman makes public this morning a prefatory section of his annual budget message to the Legislature, the whole of which will be delivered tomorrow afternoon. This is an innovation, adopted doubtless to assure more public attention to what he regards as a sort of fiscal hole that the twelve-year Republican regime has dug for a Democratic administration.

THE relative merits of live television and television on film probably will be argued as long as there is a video medium. But to hand this morning are two cases about as different as they could be -- the new programs of Eddie Cantor and Fulton Lewis Jr. -- that make a viewer wonder anew why use of film so often must be synonymous with poor quality in terms of a presentation's content.
The National Broadcasting Company announced a contract agreement had been reached with a C. I. O. union last night as negotiations continued between the union and the American Broadcasting Company.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Big changes are near for the bulging parking lots at railroad stations in Westchester County and southern Connecticut.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- The closing down today of the official United States newspaper Neue Zeitung has created somewhat of a cold-war propaganda problem here. The final edition appeared just at the time-when Berlin was filled with rumors that the occupying powers would seek co-existence with a divided Germany and possibly the absorption of West Berlin into the Soviet sphere.
Herman L. Weckler has been elected a director of the Clevite Corporation, manufacturer of automotive-type bearings.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- When Britain's Princess Margaret flies to the West Indies Monday to begin her Caribbean tour, she will take with her a magnificent holiday wardrobe. On some days of the tour Margaret will have to change five times to be suitably dressed for appointments.

At this time of year a good deal of thought naturally is given to the winter. Some say this about it, some say that. A great many shudder at the thought that it will go on, even on calendar pages, until mid-March.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Senate Republican Leader William F. Knowland is getting along more amicably with the State Department than he has for many months.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Leffert Holz, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, was reported in line today for appointment as State Insurance Superintendent.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 30 -- Communist East Germany has an armed force of about 100,000 men equipped with heavy weapons and tanks, the West German Federal Ministry for all German Affairs reported today.
CAIRO, Jan. 30 -- Arab leaders will fly to Baghdad tomorrow in an effort to heal the breach between Egypt and Iraq that threatens to disrupt the Arab League.
Five new films, including an import from Italy, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 30 -- Union Theological Seminary in Virginia announced today that Dr. Benjamin R. Lacy Jr. would retire as its president next January.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 30 -- A Federal agency and the American Cancer Society gave a total of $100,000 here today for the continued development of an electronic instrument designed for extensive testing for early cancer.
ROME, Jan. 30 -- The possibility of Italy's joining the Balkan pact will be discussed during four-day conversations starting tomorrow.

VIENNA, Jan. 30 -- A belief now said to be entertained by the Austrian state police that Dr. Alfred Sokolowski, chief interpreter of the Vienna city government arrested by the Russians Jan. 15, was a Soviet agent was published today in Die Presse.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins expressed "cautious optimism" tonight that South Vietnam could be strengthened to resist Communist control.

DETROIT, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Glen Skov and Marcel Bonin each scored twice tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 7-1 rout of the Montreal Canadiens before 14,983 fans, the largest crowd of the National Hockey League season at the Olympia.
Grain seized the initiative in the charter market last week and accounted for the biggest rate increases.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- When a long-expected blow actually falls, the hurt it inflicts is almost invariably greatly softened by preparations made beforehand for meeting it. That is just what has happened in the rise in the British bank rate from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent.
The president of the International Longshoremen's Association, independent, raised last night the possibility of scrapping the new waterfront peace pact if changes were made in hiring practices.
Opponents of H. R. 1 -- the bill providing for a three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act -- were mustering their forces last week in earnest.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 30 -- Communist light bombers struck at the Nationalist-held Tachen Islands this afternoon, the Defense Ministry announced.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 30 -- The Chinese Chamber of Commerce will appeal to the British Crown in an effort to make Chinese one of the languages of the new Singapore Legislative Assembly to be elected in April.

CAROLA GOYA, who used to be a frequent performer of Spanish dances hereabouts, returned to the recital field last night, after a considerable absence, in a program at the Ziegfeld Theatre, with a young man calling himself Matteo as her partner. Though it was still fundamentally a program of Spanish dances, it was entitled "Dances of the World," and included numbers from Scotland, India, Ceylon, Cuba and Italy.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Pat Lesser, an old nemesis, defeated Barbara Romack, national amateur champion, 6 and 5, today in the 36-hole final of the Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament.
Henri Salaun of Boston won the Harry Cowles tournament, and Edwin rare or Yale captured the Harvard invitation event in squash racquets play at the Harvard Club yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks beat the New York Rangers, 4 to 2, tonight for their first victory in twelve games and ninth of the season.

APRIL 14, 1865, was a Good Friday. Abraham Lincoln got up much later than usual and emerged from his bedroom at 7 A. M. He was 56 years old, thirty-five pounds underweight, tired. He "walked like a man with sore feet." The day that faced him was crowded. He hoped to hear of the surrender of the last Confederate army to Sherman.
The Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Jr. raised vigorous opposition yesterday to the proposed legalizing of bingo for religious and charitable purposes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- United States officials are considering whether to urge the Soviet Union to use its influence with Communist China to prevent any incident that might lead to general hostilities in the Far East.

The hallmark of the true Christian is confidence in God unalloyed by fear in time of peril, the Rev. Patrick V. Ahern declared yesterday. A member of the clergy staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral, he preached at solemn mass there yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- The Soviet Union delivered to the United Nations today a cease-fire plan of its own for the Formosa area.
Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas called last night for the seating of both Communist and Nationalist China in the United Nations.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 29 -- Nicaragua seems to have got a white bear by the tail in its newest big dollar-earner, cotton.

Dispatches to this newspaper from New Guinea tell that important work is being done in residual spraying with DDT to kill the Anopheles mosquito, the prime vector of malaria. Tests made thus far have shown an almost incredible reduction in infant and juvenile illness.
Norman Thomas, elder states-man of American socialism, and a panel of six high school students agreed yesterday that most "isms" -- except extremism -- were good for the nation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Following are the texts of a Soviet letter to the president of the Security Council, Sir Leslie Knox Munro of New Zealand, and of a draft resolution submitted by the Soviet Union:
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30 -- The Israel bond campaign got off to a $6,187,000 start here today.

In a city of luxurious restaurants, yet another has just opened, Ken Later's Patio, 111 East Fifty-seventh Street, at Park Avenue. In a setting designed to simulate "an elegant outdoors," as Mr. Later phrased it, a kind of cooking that straddles American and French styles is served with much flourish.
Virginia Hoyns of the Philadelphia Skating Club and William R. Kipp of the Penguin Figure Skating Club, Allentown, Pa., yesterday won the Middle Atlantic senior dance championship.
Nine persons, including three children, were fatally burned yesterday in three Manhattan fires. A tenth person was in a serious condition.
Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, has become sponsor for a study of Jewish historical experience and its "relevance to contemporary life in the United States."

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France returned from a trip through his home district to preside tonight at negotiations for a settlement with Tunisia. It was hoped that progress might be made on this issue before the critical North Africa debate begins Wednesday in the National Assembly.

Control of the Alliance Realty Company, one of the city's oldest property investment organizations, has been acquired by Charles F. Noyes, I. Jerome Riker and Duncan M. Findlay. Alliance, which was formed in 1899, owned properties from the Battery to Dyckman Street and has assets of more than $12,000,000.
The American Jewish Tercentenary was celebrated last night in. Carnegie Hall with a program sponsored by the Mizrachi Organization of America.
ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, at Sea, Jan. 30 -- The Cunard liner Queen Mary heeded an urgent message for help and took aboard two injured seamen from the Greek freighter Liberator early today.
LONDON, Jan. 30 --A storm of controversy broke today over the "debunking" of "Lawrence of Arabia."

Following "The Rainmaker" into the Cort on Feb. 17 will be Paul Vincent Carroll's comedy-fantasy "The Wayward Saint," with Paul Lukas and Liam Redmond assigned to the leading roles. Ben Washer, spokesman for "The Rainmaker," starring Geraldine Page, said yesterday that another house was being sought for the N. Richard Nash play, which leaves the Cort after the performance of Feb. 12.
The first American center for research on the British Commonwealth will be established at Duke University under a $350,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 30 -- Dutch trade with the United States continues to show an increasing import surplus, owing to liberalization measures.

War is inevitable under present circumstances in international life, the Rev. Donald Harrington declared yesterday. He pointed to the danger in Formosa Strait and said there was a possibility at any moment that a spark could set off a world conflict.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Curlers from the Thistle Club of Montreal, skipped by Dick Walsh, routed two rival rinks at the St. Andrew's Golf Club indoor arena today to win the New York Caledonian Curling Club's centennial bonspiel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -Mr. McCormack agreed that "strong sentiment" was springing up among Congress members for action this year on income tax cuts.
HONOLULU, Jan. 30 -- Longshoremen's union officers recommended that Hawaii Local 142 withdraw its 24,000 members "forthwith" from Harry Bridges' international.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew glided to his sixth consecutive senior men's title and the tenth of his career today in the national outdoor speed skating championships.

The Music Education League presented an unusually good crop of audition winners yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. For the eighth year, Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society provided the instrumental support, and there was an audience of more than 1,000 to applaud the sensitive young artists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Democratic majority of the House of Representatives is about to be put under the lashes of fifteen new whips.

The proposal to convert some of the United States butter surplus into "ghee" for distribution and sale in the Middle and Far East is imaginative and provocative. It may work. Certainly it should not be dismissed as fantasy, on the one hand, or as over-complicated, on the other, until it has been fully explored.

On Jan. 17 you published a letter from the Board of Water Supply which charged "certain patent errors" in my letter to you published Jan. 7. That letter explained the unwisdom of moving forward with the $200,000,000 Cannonsville dam, reservoir and tunnel without first completing a final study of a pumping, filtration and treatment plant at Hyde Park on the upper Hudson River at an estimated cost of about $50,000,000.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Governor Harriman today made a personal plea to the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company to reconsider plans to shut its Amsterdam plant.
MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- A Soviet doctor reported today that cooling the human body during heart operations undoubtedly had a "great future" as a surgical technique.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30 -- Even before the current Far Eastern crisis developed, the steel market had strengthened considerably this month.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Clement R. Attlee, leader of Britain's Labor party, declared today that President Chiang Kai-shek and his top Nationalist officials should be exiled from Formosa.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 27 -- An inflation threat to the finn-mark has developed with the demands of the labor unions for more pay.
It would be in the public interest to correct certain misapprehensions which appear to exist concerning the recent investigation of pari-mutuel harness racing.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -- United Artists has deals pending, which are expected to be announced soon, with Van Johnson, Cornel Wilde, Richard Widmark and Van Heflin. The studio has proposed making the stars financial participants in addition to guaranteeing them basic salaries and freedom to approve selection of story, director and producer.
Administrative reform of the state courts was urged yesterday by Allen T. Klots, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Administration's planned cuts in the military shaped up today as the week's major issue in a Formosa-conscious Congress.

Cotton futures moved higher on the local exchange last week. At the close of trading on Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange final prices had registered gains of twelve to thirty-three points, or the equivalent of 60 cents to $1.65 a bale.

STUTTGART, Germany, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, on the eve of taking command of the United States Army in Europe, disclosed today he had asked Washington for more armor to increase the mobility of his forces in atomic warfare.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 30 -- The United States naval chief in the Pacific said today his forces were completely prepared to begin within hours the removal of Chinese Nationalist troops and civilians from the Tachen Islands.
Corporations, both foreign and domestic, raised $6,464,278,820 last year through the sale of underwritten securities in this country, according to an annual survey by the Investment Dealers' Digest.
The Diamond Match Company is planning to buy the assets of the General Package Corporation, Chicago manufacturer of egg-packing equipment.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Harriman disclosed today that he wanted the state's tax structure revised to produce more money.

STUTTGART, Germany, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, on the eve of taking command of the United States Army in Europe, disclosed today he had asked Washington for more armor to increase the mobility of his forces in atomic warfare.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan 30 (UP) -- The $15,000 Thunderbird invitation golf tournament ended in a three-way tie today. The 1954 winner, Fred Haas, Mike Souchak and Shelley Mayfield each posted 18-under-par scores of 270 for 72 holes.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Following are excerpts from the first section of Governor Harriman's 1955-56 Budget Message that was released today:

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, in a statement issued here tonight, reiterated that the way to reduce tension in the Formosa area was to respect the rights of Communist China, cease interfering in China's affairs and not threaten the Peiping regime.
C. Dana McCoy has been appointed New York manager and international director of the Rust Engineering Company, Pittsburgh.
ABOARD THE U. S. S. ATKA, Off Antarctica, Jan. 30 -- Six times this ship has been turned back in her effort to break through the Antarctic icepack and reach the coastline.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Planes began a search today for an "unidentified object" spotted on the sea 605 miles southeast of Bermuda during the hunt for a missing schooner carrying Ward Wheelock, Philadelphia advertising executive, and six other persons.

I read on Jan. 24 the story entitled "Malay Reds Move Base to Thai Line" by your correspondent, Tillman Durdin, in which he accused the Thai authorities of being tolerant toward the Malayan Communist guerrillas.
WINDSOR, Ont., Jan. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Ford of Canada workers voted overwhelmingly today for an agreement ending the strike that began Oct. 10.

In his Town Hall debut recital Saturday evening, Alfred Mouledous provided some interesting piano playing. Not an outstanding technician, he nevertheless displayed some original ideas of his own, and the spirit of his musical conceptions kept the program moving smartly along.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -Representative Emanuel Celler today proposed legislation to "correct" the controversial refugee relief law and oust Scott McLeod, its present administrator.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- A jumble of conflicting traffic laws and directional signs in the country was blamed today for thousands of fatal highway accidents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -Representative Daniel J. Flood announced today he would introduce a resolution tomorrow calling for establishment of a commission to clarify the differences between communism and democracy.

A Presidential commission of scientists and laymen to review the basis and effectivness of the Federal security risk program was advocated yesterday by the American Chemical Society's weekly Chemical and Engineering News.

Net income of the United Corporation, former public utility holding company and now becoming an investment company, was larger in 1954 than in any year in the company's last twenty-two years, its annual report showed yesterday.

The United States premiere of Richard Strauss' "Arabella," in an English translation by John Gutman, will be the feature of the fourteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera. It will be performed on Feb. 10 as a benefit for the Metropolitan Opera Employes Welfare Fund.

WINE may improve with age but the baseball writers' show doesn't improve a bit. It even got more vinegary this year. Bitter, indeed, were the gulps some of the folks had to take. There was, for instance, a skit involving that Mutual Admiration Society (or is it?), comprised of Eddie Stanky and Leo Durocher.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Goalie John Henderson chalked up his fifth shutout of the National Hockey League season as the Boston Bruins blanked the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 0, before 9,544 fans at the Boston Garden tonight.
Pattern inspiration was drawn from a variety of sources for two new collections of decorative fabrics introduced last week. Both are available through decorators.

Fred H. Hill, who recently bought the five-story residence at 1134 Madison Avenue, near the northwest corner of Eighty-fourth Street, has entered into a contract to resell it to Morris Schmuger in a deal negotiated by Louis Harrow.

Net income of the United Corporation, former public utility holding company and now becoming an investment company, was larger in 1954 than in any year in the company's last twenty-two years, its annual report showed yesterday.

With at least two of its television shows scheduled for more tours shortly, the National Broadcasting Company is becoming more excursion minded. There are even future plans to dispatch "Home," the daytime show with Arlene Francis, to Mexico City and resort areas in the Canadian Laurentians.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The House Committee on Rules gave its support today to three inquiries.

The Treasury will bring out this week the longest-term bond issue to be offered by the Federal Government since it floated a fifty-year issue in 1911 to help pay the cost of building the Panama Canal. The forthcoming bond will have a maturity of forty years and will bear an interest rate of 3 per cent.
PARIS, Jan. 31--Experts of France and the Saar began today talks to modify their economic union and permit greater West German trade with the Saar.

HARTFORD, Jan. 31--Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff announced tonight he would hand to the State Senate tomorrow the nomination of Thomas J. Spellacy, former Mayor of Hartford, for State Insurance Commissioner.

A new quick, low-cost method of constructing safety islands to channel traffic will be tested today when the Traffic Department improves the complex intersection of Dyckman Street with Nagle, St. Nicholas and Hillside Avenues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--If they are saying on Jacobs' Beach tonight that what the Supreme Court needs is a majority who were amateur boxers instead of justices who grew up on the baseball sandlots, it will not be the first time that the backgrounds of the black-robed brethren have been cited in bitter explanation of their decisions.
A lively expansion is under way in foreign markets for American refrigerators, washing machines and other electrical appliances.
Manlio Brosio, new Italian Ambassador to the United States, arrived here yesterday. He declared the danger of the Communist party in Italy had been overrated.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31 (AP) --Ohio State won its second straight basketball game without the services of its top pointmaker, Robin Freeman, defeating St. John's of Brooklyn, 67--61, in a rough-and-tumble contest tonight.

TRENTON, Jan. 31--Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, presented to the Republican-controlled Legislature today the major part of a record budget. It is expected to exceed $275,000,000 and may approach $300,000,000.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall emerged as the strong man of Australian tennis today when he overcame a long-time jinx to beat his Davis Cup teammate, Lew Hoad, for the Australian national championship.

We said it before and we will say it again: the kerosene stove is too deadly for the crowded tenement house of New York City. Now we have six more dead in one fire, caused by such a stove igniting curtains on Sunday morning in a lower East Side flat.
LONDON, Jan. 31--There is no firm sign that the Soviet Union is ready to agree to free elections in Germany, Sir Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31--United States economic prospects were described today as "broadly" favorable for the next ten or twenty years.
New financing in January set several records. Public offerings of bonds here touched the highest level for the month in twentynine years. Stock issues were the biggest for a January since 1953.

A delicious hodgepodge will be the main dish next Friday when the Collegiate School, 241 West Seventy-seventh Street, serves a Dutch supper to New Yorkers attending its kermis. Kermis is the Dutch word for fair.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31--The general disposition of grain traders today seemed to be to stand by pending further moves in the Chinese situation. Demand was slow in all pits, and there was enough commission and local selling of wheat to make for a sharp reaction with the near-by delivery especially heavy.

TAIPEI, Jan. 31--Pilots of the Eighteenth Fighter-Bomber Wing, now based at an airfield about twenty miles from here, said today their primary mission was the defense of Formosa and the Pescadores. They said they did not expect to take part in an evacuation of the Tachen Islands.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 31--Negro students began enrolling today in high schools here that previously had been restricted to white pupils.

In mid-April 2,000 yards of fabrics will be pulled out of packing boxes, pressed and exhibited to the public on the ground floor of the Museum of Modern Art. The occasion will be the most extensive exhibit of Indian textiles ever held in this country.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Surely a great weakness in the United States' position on Formosa stems from our continued espousal of the lost cause of Nationalist China. Although, our stated policy is to discourage or even prevent the Nationalists from any attempt to reconquer the Chinese mainland, we carry the torch for an ideal that can only be achieved through all-out assault with our own military backing.

HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 31--Last year's Agricultural Trade Development and Assistance Act "is proving of real assistance" in getting American farm production into the hands of foreign consumers, Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said here today.

The amazing disparity between the salaries of federal and New York judges has been referred to on this page in recent weeks; and we are glad to see Attorney General Brownell advert to it once again in urging an increase in the compensation of both United States judges and Congressmen.

A new apartment house is planned for the southeast corner of Third Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. The site has been leased by Joseph P. Blitz, as president of the 200 East Fiftyseventh Corporation, from the Astor estate.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31-- Sponsors of a move to bring the left-wing International Fur and Leather Workers Union into the American Federation of Labor revised their strategy here today.

The five-story store and office building at 14 East Fortyeighth Street has been purchased by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator. The seller was the estate of Julian Benjamin.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 31 (AP)-- Richmond climbed into first place in the Southern Conference basketball standings tonight with a 106-67 triumph over West Virginia before a crowd of 6,000 in the Arena.
Almost as many tragic tenementfire deaths are caused by careless tenants as by dishonest landlords, Deputy Housing Commissioner Bernice P. Rogers said yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 31--Princess Margaret quit the gray drizzle of midwinter England today for a month's ceremonial tour of the sun-drenched British West Indies.

Spokesmen for major boxing interests yesterday called the Supreme Court's anti-trust ruling a first-round victory for the Justice Department. They predicted they would win the final decision after a long legal bout.

The New York Chapter of the National Defense Transportation Association will reconvene a panel discussion on "Transportation in the New York Area During an Emergency." The participants will meet Friday evening in the Statler Hotel.

FOR a movement of a piano concerto to be encored is a rare event in the concert world. But this is what happened at Town Hall last evening, when the French pianist Nicole Henriot played Ravel's G Major Concerto with Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society.

VERDI'S incomparable "Otello" was performed last night for the first time this season in the MetropolitanOpera House, with the famous and very gifted young Italian soprano, Renata Tebaldi, making her American debut as Desdemona.

PARIS, Jan. 31--The strong current of hostility in the National Assembly to the Cabinet of Premier Pierre Mendes-France showed itself today in rejection of a bill for money to run the Government during February.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway told Congress today that President Eisenhower's plan to cut Army ground forces "jeopardizes" the safety and security of the nation. The Army Chief of Staff broke openly with his Commander in Chief in testimony before an obviously sympathetic Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives.
The notes or a piano, the many tones of hillbilly and jazz bands, the pealing of an electric organ --these recognizable instrumental sounds have been conjured out of an electronic machine.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 31 -- What was described in official quarters today as a "possible misunderstanding" appears to have arisen here in regard to the formula for a Nationalist evacuation of the Tachen Islands with United States support.
There is no discrimination against Negroes in the International Longshoremen's Association, Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the now independent dock workers' union, asserted yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 31--Mock twopiece frocks for all hours of the day and night, designed by Marc Bohan, arc presented by Patou in his tailored collection.

Tentative assessed valuations of real estate and special franchises for the fiscal year 1955-56 were made public yesterday by the city's Tax Commission. They showed a total of $21,193,785,567, a net increase of $915,942,035 over the present fiscal year, which began July 1.

Not a single case of lung cancer has been reported among Yemenite Jews in Israel in the last fifteen years. This disclosure was made yesterday by Dr. Kalman J. Mann, director of the Hadassah Medical Organization in Israel. His report was delivered before several hundred leaders of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, at its midwinter conference at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

Two barge worker locals have left John L. Lewis United Mine Workers and affiliated with the American Federation of Labor's United Marine Division, it was announced here yesterday by Capt. Joseph O'Hare, general manager of Local 333 of the federation unit.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31 --Michael Todd is going ahead with his projected filming of Tolstoy's "War and Peace" in the big-screen Todd-AO process. Robert E. Sherwood and Fred Zinnemann will collaborate as scenarist and director.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 31--An equity suit brought by a bank stockholder to halt acquisition of the Colonial Trust Company by Chesapeake Industries, Inc., a holding company, was discontinued here today. The suit was brought in Supreme Court by Thomas J. O'Neill, Westchester and New York attorney and a stockholder in the bank.
A plea by Governor Harriman failed yesterday to keep the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company in the state.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--Mayor Wagner will ask this week for legislation aimed at creating new apartment houses for so-called middle-income families.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Senate hearings on school construction bills closed today in a wrangle over an anti-segregation amendment.
ALBANY, Jan. 31-Republican legislators read Governor Harriman's budget preface today as meaning an immediate tax increase with no prospect of a future reduction.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 31--The Foreign Ministry said today that information had been sent to the Council of the Organization of American States in Washington regarding Saturday's fighting along the Nicraguan border.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Gulf Oil Corporation lost in the Supreme Court today an appeal from a lower court decision that it was subject to New York City's gross business tax.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP)--The Weather Bureau today issued a list of skiing conditions and made the following forecast for tomorrow: Cloudy and likely followed by light snow iate in the day or at night; temperatures remaining well below freezing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Senate expects to open debate tomorrow on the Southeast Asia collective defense treaty.

UNLESS I have miscounted, the Rivers of America Series now contains forty-eight volumes. Since there aren't that many American rivers of any importance as bodies of water or as centers of significant American history the editors, in their determination to keep a good publishing project alive, included books on some of the most unimportant rivers in America: the Chagres, the Gila, the Humboldt and the Powder.

Part of old New York--a Dutch, kermis, or fair--will be recreated Friday afternoon at the Collegiate School, 241 West Seventyseventh Street. Seventeenth century Nieu Amsterdam's kermis, held in the market place that today is Whitehall Street, was a day of fun and merrymaking.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 31--A few minutes before 11 A. M., today Arkady A. Sobolev, Moscow's top spokesman here, made an unobtrusive entrance into the Security Council chamber, greeted a few delegates and turned at once to a last look at his official documents.

Account on the loose: American Airlines, with the assistance of Ruthrauff Ryan, is looking for an agency. The two are ending their association, which dates back some eighteen years. May 1 is the date decided on for the parting, but both sides said yesterday that the agency would stay on after that day if a new agency had not been chosen.

The writer of the following letter was a member of the International Secretariat of the United Nation Conference on International Organization and was Director of the World Peace Foundation from 1942 to 1946. He is now Professor of International Organization and Administration a Columbia University.

CAIRO, Jan. 31--Two young men convicted as spies and saboteurs in Egypt on behalf of Israel were hanged this morning in Cairo Prison. Eleventh-hour pleas for clemency by their families, the French Government and Jewish religious leaders failed.
MIAMI, Jan. 31 (AP)--Ada L. Rice's Cerise Reine, idle for almost a year, found her best form at Hialeah Park today as she easily won the featured Poinsettia Purse before 20,109 spectators.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--The Jockey Club has asked Governor Harriman and Republican leaders to join in a bipartisan drive to modernize three of the state's four flat tracks at a cost of $30,000,000.

TRENTON, Jan. 31--The New Jersey Assembly overwhelmingly approved today a Senate bill authorizing the New Jersey Turnpike Authority to build a new east-west superhighway from Somerville to South Amboy.

YESTERDAY (Jan. 31, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Received Maurice Couve de Murville, New French Ambassador, who presented credentials; and Jose Luis CruzSalazar, Guatemala's Ambassador, who thanked the President for United States economic aid.

A NUMBER of angling and hunting groups have devoted considerable time to the discussion of the problems created by the increased posting of lands. One New York chapter of the Izaak Walton League has formulated a farmer-sportsman cooperative program that should prove effective.

A detailed study of stock market transactions between Dec. 8 and Dec. 15, 1954, issued by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, showed that 52.5 per cent of all business, other than that of brokers or exchange members, was on "margin," or borrowed money.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31--The American Federation of Labor reported today that unionized workers had fared better on the wage front in the "recession year" of 1954 than in any other postwar year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- Twelve members of the National Advisory Council established under the Vocational Rehabilitation Act of 1954 were appointed today.

Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, conferred 544 degrees last night at the college's 107th commencement exercises. Thirty-nine students were graduated with departmental honors, and fifteen received scholarships and awards.
Armco Steel Corporation directors yesterday voted a twofor-one stock split and declared a dividend of 90 cents a common share, up 20 per cent. The company had been paying 75 cents a quarter.

New celestial wonders will make their appearance today at the Hayden Planetarium in three seemingly three-dimensional murals. The murals, six months in the making, are the last in a series of sixteen begun more than two years ago in the wide, twisting corridor on the planetarium's first floor.
Arthur (Dazzy) Vance, elected to baseball's Hall of Fame last week, was made Brooklyn's first citizen yesterday at a ceremony at Brooklyn Borough Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Fourteen, aliens ordered deported as Communists received from the Supreme Court today notice that it would test the right of immigration authorities to hold them in "supervised parole."
Iron and steel companies in this country spent $680,000,000 last year for plant expansion and improvement, the industry's leading trade association reported yesterday.

PANAMA, Jan. 31--A special commission of the National Assembly has decided to recommend the formal indictment of Jose Ramon Guizado for complicity in the murder of his predecessor an Panamanian President.
Danny Jo Perez, West Side welterweight, boxed a draw with Orlando Zulueta of Havana in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The telephone switchboards at the trading desks of Wall Street's big bond houses blinked away incessantly again yesterday as the dealers in Government bonds coped with investment switches touched off by the Treasury's $15,000,000,000 refunding operation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--President Eisenhower renewed today his request to Congress for enactment of a broad program for "better health for a stronger America."
"Brooklyn is too close to Manhattan," Albert Conway, Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, declared yesterday.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregularly up yesterday. Potatoes, hides, rubber, zinc, copper, tin, lead and burlap were stronger; cocoa, coffee, wool, cottonseed oil and soybean oil eased, and sugar was mixed.
An ex-Communist who was a key Government witness in the trial of thirteen convicted secondary Communists leaders branded himself a professional perjurer yesterday.

The "war babies" -- or some of them -- led the stock market higher yesterday. Machine tools, aircrafts, oils and steels soared. Most automobile issues lagged and the rail list in general was quiet -- puzzling behavior if a war boom is really building up.

Having engaged Reginald Denham as director, Cheryl Crawford virtually has completed plans for the Broadway presentation of Roald Dahl's comedy, "The Honeys." Co-starring Jessica Tandy, Hume Cronyn and Dorothy Stickney, "The Honeys" will be placed in rehearsal on Feb. 14 and will open in New York as a Theatre Guild subscription attraction on April 14.
Participation by problem youngsters in community affairs was recommended yesterday as a way to curb juvenile delinquency.

February's Square Holes This is the day the bills come in, and they are bound to be scorchers. Not only will they include all the items purchased during January, which was a desperately long month of thirtyone days, but also they will say in effect, "Remember Christmas ?"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Senator William E. Jenner said today that means must be found to curb the activities of United States citizens whom he accused of spreading Communist propaganda after returning from Red China.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture recommended today that Maine growers reduce this year's acreage of potatoes 15 per cent from last year. The Department set a planting guide of 1,023,500 for the nation's late potato crop, a reduction of 5.5 per cent from 1954.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed tighter curbs on the amount of debt a stock brokerage may have in relation to the capital it holds.
Haiti looks to foreign investors and tourists to expedite her reconstruction, President Paul E. Magloire said yesterday.
The writer of the following letter, director of the Woodrow Wilson School of Foreign Affairs of the University of Virginia, served in Formosa in public administration work in 1952 and 1953.

Louis Schleifer, real estate operator, has sold the fourteenstory Central Terminal Building at 415 Lexington Avenue to a syndicate headed by Daniel S. Levy. The Advance Realty Company was the broker in the transaction and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 31 (AP) --Don McDermott of Englewood Cliffs, N. J., flashed to a national record in the 500-meter event today. He led two other sprinters to berths on the United States Olympic speed-skating team.

Many parties will be given at the annual luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Catholic Big Sisters, to be held on Feb. 16 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Christopher B. Wyatt is president of the beneficiary and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy is honorary president.
HONG KONG, Jan. 31--Communist China made new attacks against any Formosa cease-fire agreement today. It also accused the United States of wielding threatening atomic weapons against it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's Message to Congress today outlining his health program: TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES: Because the strength of our nation is in its people, their good health is a proper national concern; healthy Americans live more rewarding, more productive and happier lives.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 5 points lower to 2 points higher (25 cents a bale lower to 10 cents higher) than on last Friday.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--Carmine G. DeSapio and two others who were appointed to major offices by Governor Harriman were confirmed by the Senate tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 31--The stock market was generally depressed today although most losses were limited to a few pence among the leading industrials.
The Sanitation Department is sending more than 100,000 notices to commercial and industrial enterprises in the city, reminding them how to handle their refuse.
The price of milk has been frozen effective today to protect hard-pressed farmers supplying the metropolitan area.
John Franklin (Home Run) Baker and Raymond William (Cracker) Schalk yesterday were named to baseball's Hall of Fame.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Supreme Court ruled today that the legitimate theatre and professional boxing were subject to the antitrust laws.
Serge Rubinstein was buried yesterday, while the police continued a painstaking but vain search for tangible clues to the person or persons, who strangled him.
More ships went to wrecking yards the world over last year than in any year since 1935.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 31--The United Nations Security Council invited Communist China tonight to help end hostilities in the islands off the China mainland.

Meeting under the shadow of a gathering crisis in the Far East, the Security Council of the United Nations has now become the scene of another diplomatic struggle between the free world and the Communist bloc. The issue is joined over two rival propositions, submitted by the free nations and by the Soviets respectively.
Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange in January was less than in December, the volume was the largest for any January since 1929.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 31 (AP)-- The New York Knickerbockers got off to a slow start, but defeated the Fort Wayne Pistons, 91--84, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 31--Plans for civilian control of the British military base in the Suez Canal area soon will go into effect.

An interesting development of recent days has been the agreement under which Japanese technicians will go to Ceylon to aid in the methods of rice cultivation on the island. It has been reported that some early experiments have already shown that Japanese methods applied in Ceylon can produce a spectacular increase in productivity.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 31 (UP)--Noel and Herta Field assured Christian Ravndal, United States Minister, at a face-to-face meeting today that their decision to stay in Hungary was "entirely voluntary."
