Debate about the importance of Formosa and of its coastal outposts of Quemoy and Matsu, can have no realistic settlement unless two questions are answered: How important is Formosa to the United States in the current world conflict?

The shutdown by the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company of its carpet plant in Amsterdam, N. Y., may worry Governor Harriman and the plant's 1,650 employes but it will not mean much to the housewife with her eye on a new carpet.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31--Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov told the British Ambassador today that the Soviet Union was "alarmed by the dangerous situation" in the Formosa Strait.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture today set an allotment of 49,842,697 acres for this year's corn crop in a designated commercial area of 805 major producing counties in twenty-one states.
The International Business Machines Corporation last year increased its net income 36.4 per cent to $46,536,625 from the previous peak of $34,119,210 attained in 1953, the company reported yesterday.
Three brokerage firms announced the admission of new partners, all effective today.
Gene Fullmer scored his twentyseventh straight victory last night, winning a unanimous tenround decision over Marcel Assire of Paris at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.
ROME, Jan. 31--Good as relations between, Italy and the United States are, the Italian Government hopes they will be improved still further by the new Ambassador in Washington.
Constant preparedness to meet any emergency was emphasized last night by Senator Alben W. Barkley as a goal of the United States.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Shelley Mayfield, 30-year-old Chicopee, Mass., professional won the $15,000 Thunderbird invitation golf tournament today. He sank a birdie 3 at the twentieth overtime hole to defeat Mike Souchak of Durham, N. C., in a "sudden-death" play-off.

PARIS, Jan. 31 (AP)--Seraphin Ferrer, undefeated 24-year-old French lightweight champion, tonight knocked out former world light-weight king Paddy DeMarco of Brooklyn in 2:30 of the fifth round of a scheduled ten-round fight in the Palais des Sports.
Decreases of $90 to $184 in the delivered prices here of 1955 Hudson cars were announced yesterday by dealers.
Stirred by the deaths Sunday of six persons in a fire caused by a kerosene heater, the Fire Department has redoubled its warnings to city residents of the dangers of these heaters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Political talk was indicated tonight by the guest list of another stag dinner given by President Eisenhower at the White House.
Instead of worrying about the possibility of another full-scale depression, business men should tackle three crucial problems now facing the country, a leading economist suggested yesterday.
A plot to liberate the prisoners at the Sing Sing death house by capturing the prison warden and using his wife as a hostage was described here last night.
ATLANTA, Jan. 31 (AP)--Georgia Tech, which amazed the basketball world by upsetting Kentucky less than a month ago, did it again tonight, trimming the top-ranked Wildcats, 65--59.

The "other side" of the Krebiozen (an anti-cancer drug) controversy is scheduled for publication late in March by Beacon Press. Written by Dr. George Stoddard, the book will be titled "Krebiozen: The Great Cancer Mystery."
An eighty-four page brief was submitted yesterday to George P. Monoghan, New York State Harness Racing Commissioner, by the attorneys for nine horsemen he suspended last Nov. 10.

Lack of proper information for answering children's questions about sex is the complaint of many a parent when first faced with this problem. Lack of educational sources for obtaining such information has been another complaint as well.
New electronic devices that may alter common aspects of living in the near future were described here yesterday by David Sarnoff.

Winter housekeeping presents its own seasonable problems. The latest information from home economists deals with the cleaning of so-called "winter" cotton dresses and the cold weather care of motor-driven appliances.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 14,000 head: market now fairly active and uneven, steady to mostly 25c lower on butchers: mostly steady on heavies 300 pounds and heavier: sows scarce, mostly
LONDON, Jan. 31--The British Government combined strong support for the United StatesBritish alliance today with a continued conciliatory attitude toward Communist China.
GENEVA, Jan. 31--A study of the causes of growth and stagnation in the European economy was published here today by the United Nations. It is the work of Prof. Ingvar Svennilson of Sweden.
Net income and sales of Continental Baking Company increased in the year ended Dec. 25, according to a preliminary report issued by the company yesterday.
MIAMI, Feb. 1--Last year Hal Price Headley's race mare, Aesthete, didn't pay for her keep. She earned only $623. It's a different story this year.
ABOARD THE U.S.S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Jan. 31 -- This icebreaker slugged at the antarctic icepack for twelve hours last night with its 6,500-ton fist.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--President Eisenhower has confided to political intimates that he would rather not run for re-election in 1956.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 1 (UP) --Eddie Arcaro today was suspended for ten days by Santa Anita's board of stewards for his failure to keep Miz Clementine on a straight course in last Saturday's $163,000 Maturity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--A small, gray-haired lady whose autograph collection begins with "A. Lincoln" today celebrated her 100th birthday by signing up Dwight D. Eisenhower. She is Mrs. Nettie A. Moulden of Washington.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having made it clear that the United States will not permit Peiping to determine Formosa's future by unilateral action, we owe it to ourselves and to the world to make it equally clear that we impose the same restraint upon ourselves.

More electric meters ticked off more kilowatt hours last week than ever before. The steel mill operator and the housewife, the school teacher and the corporation executive all are using more power and light. Every indication points to this trend continuing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Eisenhower Administration believes an uneasy stalemate in the Formosa Strait is more likely than either fighting or a formal cease-fire.
TOKYO, Feb. 1--Japan's initial price to the Soviet Union for a peace treaty will be support for admitting the Tokyo Government to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--A new drive for civil rights legislation got under way in the Senate today. It appeared, however, that it would not get far.
"The Wisteria Trees," the final fortnightly revival in the eight- week drama festival at the City Center, opens at 8 o'clock tonight at the municipal emporium of art and culture.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 1--The American Federation of Labor warned today that unemployment might reach a peak of 4,000,000 in the next eight weeks.

Dr. Charles W. Hughes, an admitted ex-Communist who was dismissed from Hunter College for "conduct unbecoming a member of the staff," was denied a new trial yesterday. His dismissal came after a trial by a committee of the Board of Higher Education.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 1--President Eisenhower's chief labor officer was accused today of instigating "new and novel gimmicks" to undermine union wage standards on billions of dollars in Federal construction projects.
A Thirty-fourth Street property is bringing more than $300 a square foot, one of the highest prices paid in recent years for real estate in the busy midtown shopping district.
The Baldwin - Lima - Hamilton Corporation acquired complete ownership yesterday of the Madsen Iron Works, Inc., in Los Angeles County, Calif.

Another chapter has ended in the nation's efforts to ease the adjustment of its service veterans back to civilian life. Men and women who now enter the service will not receive the various benefits provided by the Veterans Readjustment Act of 1952. Meanwhile, the Senate has yet to act on a House-approved bill permitting those who began service careers before Jan. 31 to accumulate eligibility for educational benefits.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee deferred action today on a resolution intended to put the Senate behind the United Nations effort for a Formosan cease-fire.

Walter Johnson, a writer and historian, was co-chairman with Leo A. Lerner of the Draft Stevenson Committee. He has written a day-by-day story of the 1952 Democratic convention as he saw it behind the scenes. Entitled "How We Drafted Adlai Stevenson," the book will be published Feb. 21 by Knopf.

SIR MALCOLM SARGENT was guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. How he played the Vaughan Williams overture to "The Wasps" of Aristophanes we do not know, for we were late.

Problem of Snow The winter's problem of snow removal must be one of the oldest known to man. It is all too easy to imagine the expression of the first householder as he emerged from his cave one morning to find before him ten inches of newly fallen snow.
ALBANY, Feb. 1--A 2-cent-a- gallon gasoline tax increase, effective April 1, was proposed today by Governor Harriman. The levy now is 4 cents.

Governor Harriman's first budget contemplating $1,345,200,000 expenditures, an increase of $107,700,000 over the last Dewey year, represents in large part a continuation of past programs. Much of the increase, but not all, is the legacy of policy inherited from past legislative and administrative policy.

WHAT'S the matter with foxhunting? The spattering of ink around the question mark indicated the vehemence of the writer. We tried to recall anything we had written that might have stimulated the wrath of an ardent foxhunter to this extent.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Wednesday, Feb. 2--Nationalist planes in undisclosed strength again dropped bombs on Yikiang Island last night, the Nationalist Air Force said this morning.

EVERY Tuesday afternoon for the last three years artists of all ages and in all conditions of accouterment, from raggy poverty to the neatly tailored with chauffeurs to drive them, have climbed hopefully or despairingly up three dingy flights to the Little Studio at 74 West Forty-seventh Street.

The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor is in session this week at Miami Beach to consider the report of its research staff and on the basis of those findings develop an economic policy for the coming year. The report of the research staff notes, among other things, an increasing acceptance by employers of the idea that wages should go up faster than living costs.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (UP)--Six world records by American track and field athletes, including feats by Wes Santee and Parry O'Brien, were officially certified today by the International Amateur Athletic Federation. Eighteen men's and nine women's standards were certified.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 2 --In a major statement published today the Central Committee of the Communist party confirmed that heavy industry would continue to have priority in the next stage of the country's development.

BOSTON, Feb. 1(AP)--The Weather Bureau tonight issued the following forecast and lists of ski condtions for New England: Cloudy and cold with snow; cloudy and cold tomorrow with a chance of snow tomorrow.

ALL the world's a stage to Angna Enters and not the least so in her fanciful paintings, the latest of which are now on view at the Newhouse Galleries, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street. Taste, skill and certain agreeable naivete are her leading gifts, and she gives her imagination full rein when it comes to illustrating and inventing.
Amid chuckles at its witticisms and exclamations at its beauty, the eleventh annual March of Dimes fashion show unfolded yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
TUNICA, Miss., Feb. 1--At least twenty-nine persons were killed and 125 injured by tornadoes in this area today.
PEOPLE who have been baffled by the plays of Jean Anouilh ought to be very happy about his "Thieves' Carnival," which was put on at the Cherry Lane last evening.
Skeletons of long-buried jetties are being uncovered at Rockaway as the sea wears away this city's beaches.
ALBANY, Feb. 1-- Governor Harriman's five-and-a-half-pound Budget Message, submitted to the legislators today, is full of all kinds of miscellaneous information.

BUFFALO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A thirty-nine volume report by the New York-New England Interagency Committee suggests that fourteen sites within the Adirondack Mountain preserve would be economically sound for construction of hydro-electric power dams.
Coffee prices tumbled the 2 cents a pound daily limit in the March position yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Dipomatic officials watching Formosa developments paid close attention today to the statement of Sir Winston Churchill that Formosa had become an international problem.

The Olin Mathleson Chemical Corporation turned in net earnings of $35,343,000 for 1954, preliminary unaudited figures disclosed yesterday. The result represents the combined income of Olin Industries, Inc., and the Mathieson Chemical Corporation, which were merged last Aug. 31.

In 1883 an 8-year-old violinist, the youngest student at the Vienna Conservatory, wrote a little Fantasie, dedicated it to his teacher, Joseph Hellmesberger, and signed it with a flourish, Friederick Kreisler.

Modern interpretations of an ancient craft and ancient motifs applied to a modern craft are reviewed in two exhibitions opening today. The displays are at the American Craftsmen's Educational Council, 32 East Fifty- second Street, and the Brooklyn Museum.
Stocks pulled through yesterday's irregular and uncertain market with slight gains, thanks to strength in a handful of issues that advanced on corporate developments.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 1, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Conferred with Republican legislative leaders. Received Justices of Supreme Court in annual visit. THE SENATE Ratified 82 to 1 Southeast Asia Mutual Defense Treaty.

Joseph P. Ryan, former president of the International Longshoremen's Association, was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison and fined $2,500. He had been convicted of taking $2,500 in gratuities from a trucking concern in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Tommy Heinsohn, Holy Cross center, got off the bench tonight to score 20 points and break open a tight basketball game as the Crusaders defeated St. Francis of Brooklyn, 82--56.
Because of a large increase in tha city's needy, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy asked yesterday that his budget for 1955-56 be $17,670,798 above the current total.

LONDON, Feb. 1--Sir Winston Churchill rejected today a Laborite suggestion that Formosa be handed over to Communist China under terms of the Cairo Declaration. The future of the island is now an international problem, and the question of its future sovereignty was left undetermined by the Japanese peace treaty, the Prime Minister told the House of Commons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Government hopes of collecting millions in additional taxes on "windfall" profits of postwar housing developers have been lessened by a court ruling.
The arrest of two Harlem landlords was ordered yesterday after they had failed to appear in court on charges of maintaining violations of the building laws.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP)--The Department of Agriculture report on today's livestock markets follows:

PRESUMABLY the Supreme Court is guided only by the legal facts in any case it deigns to review. But the court is not entirely a legalistic machine. It consists of nine human beings whose sensitivities reach into the outer world.
Fires from Kerosene stoves can start in many ways, but "the most important thing is human carelessness."
PARIS, Feb. 1--A tremendous and continuous ovation greeted Christian Dior's new A-line in the showing of his collection here today.

It has been some years since Fritz Kreisler has lifted his bow in public. But in his time he was a virtuoso of the highest rank and a sovereign artist. As Bruno Walter said of him: his right hand was made for the bow, his left hand for the finger board. To this was added the warmth, humanity and insight into the music that characterized all his performances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, introduced legislation today designed to force persons seeking to gain control of corporations by soliciting stock proxies to "make a full disclosure of their identity and the identity of their associates."

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--Louis E. Wolfson, New York and Florida industrialist, scored an important victory today in his campaign for control of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc. Circuit Judge Harry M. Fisher ruled that Ward's stagger system of electing directors was unlawful.

Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" received its fifth and final performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The roles of the Countess, Cherubino and a peasant girl were all undertaken by young members of the company who had not previously sung the parts.
The development of a small portable electric device to save life in cases where electrical shock has sent the heart into spasm was advocated here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Administration asked Congress today to extend the draft for four years to maintain military strength and safeguard the national security.
Helen Keller was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given by the American Foundation for Overseas Blind, Inc., in the "Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE February exhibition of paintings at the City Center Gallery, was juried this month by Franz Kline, Herbert Katzman and Colleen Browning. It is as varied as the names of the jurors might lead one to expect.
Pole vaulting probably is the most exacting event on a track and field program. It involves speed, spring, strength, coordination, timing and shock resistance to crash landings.
WITH THE SEVENTH FLEET, in Formosa Waters, Feb. 1--The commander of the United States Seventh Fleet is a soft-spoken admiral who began his career as an enlisted man.

QUEBEC, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press)--When the Lady Grey sank today after a collision with a ferryboat, it was the second time the old icebreaker disappeared beneath the water of the St. Lawrence River. All of the crew were saved.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Legislation limiting the number of fields in which a corporation could operate was suggested today as an effective curb on giant corporations.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Following are excerpts from the Budget Message submitted to the Legislature today by Governor Harriman: The Budget Plan for 1955-56 For the first time, this message will provide a comparative view of current and prospective fiscal years in terms of total income and total expenditures.

The Prudential Insurance Company has made a first mortgage loan of $5,750,000 on the thirty- five-story office and bank building at 63 Wall Street through Brooks, Harvey Co., brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
Mayor Wagner and Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams attended yesterday a ceremony adding 740 policemen and four policewomen to the department. The force now is the largest in its history.
TRENTON, Feb. 1--Those "little green stamps" given away by retailers all over the country are the center of a new legal battle.
The first all-van door-to-door household moving service between Puerto Rico and the United States was announced yesterday by Louis Schramm Jr., president of Allied Van Lines, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (UP) --The National Football League commissioner, Bert Bell, told Canadian professional football it would have to get its house in order before settling difficulties with the N. F. L.
That terrific spurt in auto production shows signs of slackening. However, cars are still rolling off assembly lines in far greater numbers than a year ago.
The port's tugboat workers have voted overwhelmingly in favor of a return to the American Federation of Labor, clearing the way for the opening of contract negotiations this afternoon.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Harriman forced the Legislature today to give him a voice on the Heald commission studying state aid for education.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Salary increases of 50 per cent and upward for members of Congress were proposed by Senate and House committees today.

THE other day I was talking to a gentleman who speaks with impressive authority about the sale and distribution of new books. His job is cold-bloodedly commercial and does not allow him to worry much about books as literature. To him they are commodities. Naturally, then, he said, he was not interested in collections of short stories unless they were written, by William Faulkner.

The regional Red Cross blood program, received 9,001 pints of blood in January. The largest donations were made by Police Academy classes, which gave 365 pints Jan. 8 at the New York Red Cross Chapter House, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, and the Brooklyn Chapter House, 57 Willoughby Street, and by Army personnel at Camp Kilmer, New Brunswick, N. J., who gave 327 pints on Jan. 19.
The ghastly sacrifice of thirteen lives in four recent days to the uncontrolled hazards of fire should arouse the people of New York to the importance of strengthening the city's fire-fighting force.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Jan. 21 your paper reported on the hearings before the General Welfare Committee of the City Council re the proposed Commission on Intergroup Relations. The amended bill, giving the Mayor the opportunity to give his consent to investigations into alleged discrimination by city officials, appears entirely reasonable and in keeping with good administration.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 1--The eight church bodies affiliated with the National Lutheran Council raised $2,835,218 last year for emergency relief activities in this country and overseas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- Two Congressmen who have supported the reciprocal trade program in the past joined textile industry spokesmen before the House Ways and Means Committee today in emphasizing the need to protect manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Israel is seeking military ties with the United States, Britain and France.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1--Some of the largest companies incorporated in Illinois, and many smaller concerns, may have their bylaws upset by Judge Fisher's decision.

In the gradual achievement of desegregation in this country's school systems it is usually only the occasional outburst of disorder that receives wide public notice. But the fact is that in many areas, particularly of the border states, integration in hitherto segregated public schools is being effected quietly and without incident.
ROME, Feb. 1--A decline of Communist strength is indicated by the results of shop steward elections in many parts of Italy.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--The first Democratic Governor in twelve years recommended today that New York City receive a slightly smaller percentage of state financial aid in the next fiscal year. The total sum, however, will be larger than it was in the last budget, but still some $18,000,000 less than Mayor Wagner had asked.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--Liquidation of grain and soybean futures bought on the Far East crisis forced prices down early today. On the setbacks, commission buying and short covering brought a partial recovery.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1-- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., has lifted its ban on working overtime in port on West Coast ships.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--John L. Lewis demanded today that the Government quit buying coal from "dogholes in the mountains."

POOR old radio! As if the sound medium did not have enough troubles in the visual age it was the subject of a rather odd tribute on Ed Sullivan's television program, "Toast of the Town." One more "tribute like Sunday night's and radio will be taking its place beside the Franklin stove and the horse.

Minneapolis-Honeywell A two-for-one split of the common stock of the Minneapolis- Honeywell Regulator Company was proposed by directors in Minneapolis yesterday. Stockholders will vote on the plan at the annual meeting April 26.

LONDON, Feb. 1--A rally by British Government securities helped the stock markets to strike a firmer note today. After a hesitant start gilt edge securities rallied to close with gains of five shillings (seventy cents) among medium and long-term issues.
New York City's ten big department stores started 1955 at a fast pace. A survey by The New York Times found they did 7.5 per cent more business in January than in the same month last year.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 1-- Some distance north of here in the Sind Desert through which the sluggish Indus River runs is the wreckage of a great city. Today it is nothing but a mass of crumbling bricks set amid sand and scrubby tamarisk bushes thick with dust.
The first court order to grant immunity from prosecution and compel a witness to testify in an espionage investigation was obtained here yesterday by the Government.

The Atomic Power Development Associates announced yesterday their member companies had approved a 1955 budget of $3,815,000 for research and development toward finding economically practical means of using nuclear fuels in generating electric power.
President Paul E. Magloire of Haiti received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Columbia University yesterday. He will receive another L.L.D. today from Fordham University.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, defended today a sixty-to-ninety-day delay in construction of United States air bases in Spain.
A light snow, not predicted by the Weather Bureau, caused hazardous driving conditions yesterday in the New York metropolitan area.
When the Dodgers yesterday announced the signing of Russ Meyer, their thirty-second satisfied player, they practically dropped out of the local baseball picture, so far as contract signings go.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 1-- On the eve of his eighty-seventh birthday, Charles B. King, manufacturer and driver of the first automobile in Detroit, felt like a landlocked sailor tonight.
The monochromatic color scheme is pleasantly varied by touches of accent shades in five new model rooms at Stern's.

The city's full return from its amusement tax was threatened yesterday. The Appellate Division, Second Department, ruled that the city had no authority to collect more than 5 per cent of the established admission price.

A ban on the sale and use of "killing kerosene oil stoves" was agreed upon yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. They will recommend either city or state legislation to this effect.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Lewis L. Strauss denied today that the Dixon-Yates contract controversy had interfered with atomic developments or weapon production.
Ninety per cent of the 40,000 North African immigrants expected in Israel this year will aid that country's agricultural economy.

William H. Harrison, president of the $600,000,000 International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation system, said yesterday that, while the company has written off the value of its seized assets behind the Iron Curtain, it hoped to recoup such losses.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Within the next few weeks Wall Street will make the acquaintance of J. William Fulbright, the junior Senator from Arkansas.
The investigation of the murder of Serge Rubinstein centered again yesterday in the home at 814 Fifth Avenue where his body was found a week ago tomorrow morning.

A yield spread of 14 1/2 percentage basis points--slightly more than one-eighth of 1 per cent interest--was designated yesterday by a syndicate of investment bankers as suitable difference in investment income between a highest-grade forty- year corporate bond of new issue and the new Treasury 3 per cent obligation of like term.
A play about the murder of Leon Trotsky, written by a former American secretary to the exiled Bolshevik leader, will be televised on Sunday, Feb. 20, from 9 to 10 P. M.
PARIS, Feb. 1--Premier Pierre Mendes-France suffered another defeat in the National Assembly today over the budget. It was the second such defeat in twenty-four hours.

CAIRO, Feb. 1--Eric Johnston President Eisenhower's special representative in the Middle East, arrived in Cairo today for the third round of the talks with representatives of the Arab states on proposals for international development of the Jordan River watershed.
PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 1--Princess Margaret took over Trinidad with a smile this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Senate overwhelmingly approved today the Southeast Asia collective defense treaty.

DENVER, Feb. 1 -- The National Jewish Hospital at Denver, free, nation-wide nonsectarian medical center for tuberculosis and chest diseases, announced here today the election of Paul Felix Warburg of New York as vice president for the tenth consecutive year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 --The producing team of William Pine and William Thomas has signed with United Artists to make a series of top-budget films for the company, which will arrange the financing.

In conformity with the decision of the Security Council, Secretary General Hammarskjold has now sent an invitation to the Chinese Communist Government to join in the effort of the United Nations to end present hostilities in the Formosa Strait and to send a representative to New York to take part in the discussions.

Homeless children and women will continue to receive temporary shelter and help at St. Barnabas House, 304 Mulberry Street, as a consequence of the evening performance on Feb. 12 of "The Desperate Hours." Starring Nancy Coleman and Karl Malden, the play opens Feb. 10 at the Barrymore.
Gabriel Banat, a young violinist, played a recital of considerable distinction at Town Hall last evening.

Allegheny County, Pa., borrowed $7,200,000 yesterday on institution district bonds due from 1956 to 1985. The issue was sold at public sealed bidding to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.07 for obligations bearing 2 3/8 per cent interest.

Advertising and publicity cannot be interchangeable but "they can be coordinated toward very effective company promotion," John Sasso, vice president of G. M. Basford Company, industrial advertising agency, said last night.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1--Dishonest dealer practices in automobile repairs were denounced today as a death threat to motorists.

Last night when chefs and gourmets, members of Les Amis d'Escoffier, sat down to a classic French dinner at the Pierre Hotel, no women were present. But a delegate from this department did attend a preview of the meal served last week to a select and highly critical tasting committee of the organization that honors the great French chef August Escoffler.
ABILENE, Tex., Feb. 1 (UP)-- Slingin' Sammy Baugh, one of professional football's great stars with the Washington Redskins, was hired tonight as head coach of Hardin-Simmons University.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 1, 1955) THE GOVERNOR Submitted his $1,345,200,000 budget for 1955-56 to Legislature and special message for immediate passage of bill increasing size and extending life of Commission on Educational Finance.

PARIS, Feb. 1--The question of standardizing armaments among the Western Allies has been raised in a new form by the French proposal of an arms-production pool. The current conference here of Western European experts dealing with the proposal is expected to arrange for a special study of the standardization already achieved.

MIAMI, Feb. 1 (AP)--William Carl's 80-foot yacht Valiant slogged into the lead late tonight in the Miami-to-Nassau yacht race. The entire fleet was proceeding slowly along the 184-mile course, hampered by the lack of wind.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with prices 7 to 11 points (35 to 55 cents a bale) net lower on active months.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 1--The Western powers do not plan to present a cease-fire resolution if Communist China participates in the United Nations Security Council discussions of the Chinese coastal islands. An invitation was cabled to Peiping last night by Secretary General Dag Hammerskjold.
Subject to the enactment of proposed legislation, a leading bank has agreed to finance the plan to consolidate into one racing association Belmont Park, Jamaica, Aqueduct and Saratoga.
Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches of America will seek $9,500,000 in their 1955 united appeal for overseas relief and reconstruction.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 1-- The first comprehensive report on the economic development of Pakistan was issued today by the government.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 2 -- A $1,000,000 program designed to expedite the resettlement of refugees in this country was approved today by the National Lutheran Council.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 2-- Princeton's basketball team defeated Rutgers, 75--37, in a nonleague game before 1,000 fans in Dillon Gymnasium tonight. The Tigers led virtually all the way in scoring their fourth victory in eleven contests this season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The House Ways and Means Committee got a grass-roots lecture on the reciprocal trade program today.

RALPH KIRKPATRICK last night took his audience on a musical tour. He started with England, presenting harpsichord works by the great William Byrd. Then Holland, by way of Sweelinck. Germany came next; Froberger, Pachelbel and J. S. Bach were the composers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The Senate Agriculture Committee decided today to determine whether the State Department was blocking foreign sales of surplus farm products.
Miami, Fla., borrowed $6,000,000 yesterday on revenue bonds to finance capital improvements.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2-- Republic Pictures, which made only eight features last year, expects to turn out about twenty this year on budgets ranging from $700,000 to $2,000,000 each.
Economic troubles in South America are causing some United States exporters more concern than wars and threats of war in Costa Rica and Formosa.

Senator Richard L. Neuberger, Democrat of Oregon, said last night he was convinced there was a relationship between campaign contributions and the Eisenhower Administration's program on natural resources.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board bowed to an order from President Eisenhower today and issued long-awaited rulings on United States air routes in the Pacific.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--President Eisenhower, plainly deferring to the United Nations, put the lid today on further Administration comments about the Formosa problem.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- An American group tonight withdrew an offer of more than $50,000,000 for control of Borax Consolidated, Ltd., owner of one of the world's largest deposits of lithium in California.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 26: Increases of $373,000,000 in holdings of "other" securities, $348,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and $472,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and a decrease of $807,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.
The city will seek to ban the sale and use of "killing kerosene oil stoves" by local law, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. announced yesterday.

The Senate Judiciary Committee is taking its own sweet time to get around to considering the appointment of John Marshall Harlan to the Supreme Court. In doing so the Judiciary Committee is lowering its own standing in the eyes of the American people, and is seriously impairing the important work of the United States Supreme Court as well.
Joseph. W. Frazer disclosed yesterday that he had sold 400,000 shares of common stock of the Standard Uranium Corporation to Charles A. Steen, uranium geologist, and had resigned as president.

The gold and dollar holdings of foreign countries increased $1,900,000,000 during 1954, according to the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise compares with one of $2,600,000,000 in 1953.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 2--An official American source said today the United States had agreed with the Chinese Nationalists on a formula for announcing a United States-supported evacuation of the Tachen Islands.
Where is Wall Street? Technically, it runs a few short blocks in downtown New York but, in effect, it is a broad avenue of investment extending the length and breadth of the country.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 2-- India and the Soviet Union signed an agreement today for the Russians to construct a 1,000,000-ton steel plant in central India.
LONDON, Feb. 2--The jet engine of the Hawker Hunter fighter, the only modern swept-wing aircraft in British military service, stalls when the plane's cannon are fired.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--President Eisenhower and Democrats traded verbal blows today over the Dixon-Yates contract.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 2 (AP)-- Twelve straight points late in the fourth quarter brought the Minneapolis Lakers a 96-81 triumph over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association contest before 4,740 tonight.
The Customs Service has revised its procedure for clearing inbound passengers and their luggage from the city piers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Tom Gola and his La Salle teammates walloped Georgetown, 85--58, tonight before a capacity crowd that included Pennsylvania's Governor George M. Leader.

Premier Menderes of Turkey has concluded a three-day visit to Rome which turned into a demonstration of Italian-Turkish solidarity and led to results which should strengthen Western defenses on the southern flank of the North Atlantic alliance. According to an official communique couched in unusually cordial terms, his conferences with the Italian statesmen took place in an atmosphere of the "most intimate and constructive collaboration" and produced an agreement that is cause for reciprocal satisfaction.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 2 (AP)-- A 23-year-old Fitchburg, Mass., file clerk today gained a berth on the United States Olympic speed skating team by winning the 5,000-meter trials.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday. Prices rose 4 to 10 points, or 20 to 50 cents a bale.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced last night a "quite noticeable" decrease in crime in the first two months of the police saturation experiment in Jamaica, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--President Eisenhower put the so-called Formosa crisis in better perspective today by insisting emphatically on reducing the size of the United States Army.
Railroads must improve service and lower rates if they are to recover the freight volume of fresh produce lost in recent years to trucks, spokesmen for growers and shippers said yesterday.
STORRS, Conn., Feb. 2--Fordham's Ed Conlin scored 17 points in the second half as the Rams' quintet came from behind to defeat Connecticut, 70--65, at the field house tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Democrats tentatively decided today to take their 1956 national nominating convention to Chicago.
ALBANY, Feb. 2--Governor Harriman warned today that Republican refusal to approve his revenue program would mean cutbacks in state grants for education and highway construction.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- Recent United States policy statements on the Formosa area have been called to Communist China's attention by a Western country maintaining an embassy there.
ALBANY, Feb. 2--A proposal to apply the techniques of modern business management to the state's court system was laid before the Legislature today.
Futures prices of coffee, cocoa, potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber, tin and copper ended higher yesterday. Sugar, wool, hides, silk, burlap and zinc were lower.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 2 (AP)--Chet Forte, a 5-foot 9-inch guard, scored 34 points and put on a sensational ball-handling exhibition tonight to lead Columbia to a 79-51 victory over Brown.
Ground radar introduced in 1952 has been a boon to air traffic flow in and out of airports in weather like yesterday's.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP)--The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecast and lists of ski conditions for New England: NEW HAMPSHIRE Fair and continued very cold tomorrow. Franconia-Cannon: 5-36 inches 1 inch powder; good. Mittersill: 7

Dr. J. V. Dunworth head of the physics reactor division at Harwell, England, in an interview broadcast on the United Nations radio, said recently that scientists were "awaiting with great eagerness Moscow's report on the operations of its 5,000kilowatt nuclear power station."

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, presented yesterday its seventh annual Henrietta Szold award for Distinguished Humanitarian Service to Dr. Mordecai M. Kaplan, Professor of Philosophies of Religion at the Jewish Theological Seminary.

August Kubizek, an Austrian musician and composer, was 16 years old when he first met Adolf Hitler, who was then 15. In Linz and later in Vienna they led the "narrow scraping existence" of poor students. Kubizek made good in music.
Claudette Colbert has signed her first television contract calling for a series of appearances in dramatic roles. All will be made over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
The Turkish Maritime Lines will begin next month the first regular Turkish-flag cargo service between East Coast ports and Greece, Israel and Turkey, the Thule Ship Agency announced yesterday.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your Jan. 22 editorial entitled "For a Clean City" makes more sense than anything said to date regarding the problem of making New York City clean.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 2 (AP) --Navy's basketball team weathered a brief second-half scare and then went on to trounce Syracuse, 91--79, today.
ALBANY, Feb. 2--The State Commission on Pensions recommended today that Federal Social Security coverage be extended to all public employes in the state.
The mystery of the murder of Serge Rubinstein goes into its second week today, with the police apparently no nearer a solution to the crime.
MIAMI, Feb. 2--Paul Andolino's unbeaten colt Boston Doge won for the eighth time today --but he threw a scare into every last one of the Hialeah customers who had bet him down to 2 to 5.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A plan substituting direct payments to farmers for the present system of farm support prices was suggested today by Senator Ralph E. Flanders.
ALBANY, Feb. 2--The State Conference of Mayors asked Governor Harriman and the Legislature today to grant cities greater taxing and home-rule powers.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP)-- Porterhouse from the Llangollen Farm of Virginia closed fast to beat the favored Imbros and take the $23,450 San Carlos Handicap at Santa Anita Park today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP)-- The House Armed Services Committee heard today that badly needed scientists drafted into the armed forces were "peeling potatoes."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The authority to invoke economic controls in a national emergency is not considered by President Eisenhower to be a matter of "terrific importance" at this time.

CAIRO, Feb. 2--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser threatened today to pull Egypt out of the Arab collective security pact. He would also sponsor a new grouping of states pledged to remain aloof from all outside alliances.
PARIS, Feb. 2--A new attack on the Government's North African policy was unleashed in the National Assembly today in an effort to oust Premier Pierre Mendes-France and his Cabinet.

The Supreme Soviet, prototype of rubber - stamp legislatures everywhere in the Communist world, is scheduled to meet today in what is obviously an extraordinary session. It was called to meet on extremely short notice, announced only last week, and this is much earlier in the year than is usually the case.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 2--The job of getting the world's first atoms-for-peace conference to run smoothly has been handed to a United States engineering expert.
THREE one-man shows of the week present particularly wide diversity in theme and treatment.
Canada's economy is growing so fast that even projects in the building stage are almost outdated, a Canadian power official declared here last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--A Senate committee received a report attacking the radio and television industry today, and decided to investigate.

THE laurels of literature bloom in the coldest months of the year. But that isn't the reason why they sometimes get such chilly receptions, is it? Look at the most recent prizes, the National Book Awards. They went to such distinguished authors as William Faulkner, Wallace Stevens, E. E. Cummings and Joseph Wood Krutch.

The City Council, which two weeks ago voted, 23 to 2, to change the name of a two-block section of Leggett Avenue in the Bronx to Jaburg Avenue, has now reversed itself and put the bill in a pigeonhole. We hope the Council has learned something from this episode, and will not be so happy-go-lucky in the future about changing street names.

Don Marshall the milliner approaches spring from four different hat angles. During his showing at the Pierre Hotel yesterday, he offered the "jaunty profile," the "level look," the brimmed hat and the deep silhouette.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 2--The national debate on arming the Federal Republic was carried into the streets of Frankfurt today by prominent members of the Government coalition and the Social Democratic Opposition.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (UP)--The Boston Bruins won their sixth game in the last eight starts tonight, scoring in the final period to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3--2, in a National Hockey League game before 3,180 Chicago Stadium fans.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP)--The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock market follows: HOGS Salable hogs 10,000 head: market fairly active, steady to 25C higher on all weights butchers: sows slow, steady to 25c lower: most choice 200 to 220 pounds butchers,

A syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers will place on the market today a new issue of $16,425,000 of common stock of Allied Stores Corporation. The offering consists of 300,000 shares priced at $54.75 each.

Too Cold, Too Wet, Too Muddy This is a season when certain people say that it is too cold to do anything outdoors, or too wet, or too muddy. They say, if one suggests they go out and throw a football around to keep warm, that nobody throws a football around at this time of year.

Alex Taylor Co., sporting goods store, will move in a few months from the six-story building at 22 East Forty-second Street it has occupied under lease for thirty-five years to the ground floor and basement in the twelvestory structure at 7 East Thirtyeighth Street.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 2 (Reuters)--England beat Australia by five wickets today to clinch victory in the most exciting international series cricket has seen for many years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Although President Eisenhower was below his best news conference form today, the White House cleared nearly two-thirds of his performance for national television.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 2, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Held news conference. THE SENATE Not in session. Agriculture Committee voted to investigate charges that State Department was blocking overseas sales of surplus farm products.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Members of The National Automobile Dealers Association in convention here were told today that the burden of guilt in car bootlegging rested with them.
ROME, Feb. 2 (AP)--Italy and Turkey agreed today to bolster the West's Mediterranean bastion against any aggression from the East.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Britain's 5,000,000 motorists were promised new road construction by their Government today. For fifteen years, since the start of World War II in 1939, few new roads have been built in Britain.
HELEN HAYES is reappearing in Joshua Logan's "The Wisteria Trees," which is the last production in the City Center's winter series. It opened last evening.

TORONTO, Feb. 2 (UP)--Reports of a "friendly discussion" between executives of the Toronto Argonauts and Bert Bell, National Football League Commissioner, indicated today that a peace pact between the Canadian and American leagues was unlikely before 1956.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 2-The Nationalists are preparing a large-scale defensive air operation for the evacuation of the Tachen Islands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White Souse has authorized direct quotation of some of the President's answers to questions. Elsewhere the President's remarks are in indirect discourse, as required by White House rules.
Recent showings of new major appliances indicate a movement to lessen stooping in the kitchen.
Voluntary health insurance plans are satisfactory as far as they go, but they do not go far enough, in the opinion of labor union members.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP)-- The Senate Agriculture Committee decided today to consider parceling out unplanted cotton acreage to relieve hardships of small cotton farmers. Its move had the effect of sidetracking proposals to increase national cotton agreage this year to 19,500,000 acres.

Assets of the Electric Bond and Share Company, a "special situation" investment company, amounted to $166,053,900 at the end of 1954, the company's report to stockholders showed yesterday. This was an increase of $36,316,900 or 28 per cent over the year before.
President Paul E. Magloire of Haiti ended his official visit to New York yesterday.

Childbearing and sewing are the only family responsibilities still "securely monopolized" by women, while "arduous physicalmaintenance" chores are the only household tasks men still can call their own.

The paper-bound books will be carrying paid advertising before very long. Pocket Books, Inc., which since it began in 1939 has sold over 500,000,000 of the volumes at 25 cents and more and has played a major part in affecting the country'a reading habits, is offering its circulation to advertisers.

Senator J. William Fulbright, who, as head of the Banking and Currency Committee, is preparing to look into the subject of security speculation, says that his purpose is to "study" the phenomenon rather than to "investigate" it. The purpose of the coming inquiry, he says, is not to prove any wrongdoing, but to determine whether there is any reason for concern, in the prolonged rise in share prices since September, 1953.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP)-- Senator Irving M. Ives said today many of the troublesome Republican patronage problems stemmed from the fact that "we have some people in the White House who are not too familiar with problems at the local level."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The old issue of controls over the economy of the United States, recently stimulated by high stock market levels which Senator Fulbright is about to "study," and then by the threat of war in the Far East, edged its way briefly into the President's news conference today.

American-Marietta Stockholders of the AmericanMarietta Company have approved increases in the authorized preferred stock and the two classes of common shares, and a 2-for-1 spilt of both classes of common.
Two ships were standing by the Panamanian freighter Liberator in bitter Atlantic weather late last night after responding to a radio appeal for help.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 2 -- A mass effort by Communist-led unions to get into the American Federation of Labor was reported here today.
Generals and some of Army's greatest football players assembled at the Lambs Club yesterday to do honor to Sgt. Marty Maher.
LONDON, Feb. 2--The Ambassador of Indonesia laid before Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India today a proposal that the five Colombo Plan powers be called to meet and consider the Formosa crisis.

A towering office building costing $15,000,000 will rise at the Avenue of the Americas and Fortieth Street overlooking Bryant Park. This is in the rapidly grwing textile center on the rim of the Times Square area.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Some operators of small, mountainside mines do not regard themselves as "doghole" producers, as John L. Lewis calls them.
LANCASTER, Pa., Feb. 2 (AP) --The Liberty Can and Sign Company, founded here in 1919, is being taken over by the J. L. Clark Manufacturing Company of Rockford, Ill.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 2 (AP) --Allie Reynolds, the New York Yankees' right-handed pitching ace, tonight retired from baseball on the advice of his doctor.
The writer of the following letter is the former chief of the Division of Foreign Tariffs of the Department of Commerce and Chief Economist of the United States Tariff Board.
ANOTHER entry in the race to reduce the weight and recoil of shotguns will arrive at the starting gate today, when the new Browning "Double" auto-loader makes its debut.
The Port of New York Authority was accused yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa of going back on its promise to make first-class terminals of the city's airports.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

PARIS, Feb. 2-- Balenciaga showed knee-length unfitted column-like tunics in a magnificent collection here today. Ease in fit, handled with the utmost, sophistication, distinguishes this designer's new fashions.

A feline commoner that made so bold yesterday as to try to kiss a feline queen quickly discovered the perils of lese majeste. The commoner, Alley Kat by name, was taking part in the preview of the Empire Cat Club's thirty-eighth annual show at the Belmont Plaza Hotel when his attentions were spurned with a regal hiss by Grenadier Pyewacket.
Oils and an assortment of aircraft issues gave a surface appearance of strength yesterday but the stock market was generally soggy and closed lower for the first time in six sessions.

The eightieth birthday of Fritz Kreisler, the violinist, was celebrated yesterday afternoon with a reception at the St. Regis Roof under the auspices of the Musicians Emergency Fund. Mr. Kreisler is chairman of the board.
LONDON, Feb. 2--Prices of industrial shares rose sharply to a new 1954-55 high today. Leaders in tobacco, motor, engineering, textile and radio groups gained about 3s (42 cents).

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 2-- An attorney-accountant, who once taught Federal taxation at Columbia University, was killed by a train here tonight a few hours after the Government had accused him of failing to file income tax returns for 1951-53.

In his latest message to Congress President Eisenhower has forthrightly declared the health of the American people to be "a proper national concern." The proposals he makes also show that he believes the Federal Government should accept a large measure of responsibility for the protection and improvement of our physical and mental well-being.
MIAMI, Feb. 2 (AP)--Valiant, catching all the available breeze in her big sails, closed to a slim lead over Ticonderoga tonight in the 184-mile Miami-to-Nassau yacht race.
One of El Greco's most famous paintings was sold a few days ago to Stavros S. Niarchos.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 2--The Chileans have been shocked this week into a realization that they face runaway inflation.
Students at James Monroe High School in the Bronx were asked yesterday to support a strike of school cafeteria workers by bringing their own lunches

CHICAGO, Feb. 2--A generally weak tone dominated the grain and soybean futures market early today, but in all pits there was a strong trend later. Selling was not regarded as heavy bat buyers were cautious except on the declines, when there was absorption by commission houses.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Formosa resolution, with its sanctioning of American armed attack even against the China mainland itself, if deemed necessary, raises two basic considerations. The first is military; in the words of Senator Flanders: "This is preventive war."
The round-trip service American Airlines offers daily between Westchester County Airport and upstate New York Will be canceled as of Feb. 24.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The Commander in Chief of the nation today firmly asserted his authority and responsibility to overrule the Army Chief of Staff on manpower cuts. President Eisenhower, who himself served as a wartime five-star General of the Army, left no doubt of his view that elected civilian officials had an ultimate responsibility that could not be delegated.

The Central Zone Building, a twenty-five-story structure at 305-13 East Forty-fifth Street through to 306-12 East Fortysixth Street, occupied largely, by the printing trades, has been sold by the Central Zone Building Corporation to the A. M. Corporation of which Harry Forsyth is president.
College basketball returns to Madison Square Garden tonight after an absence of three weeks. Seton Hall (11--4) will face Cincinnati (15--3) and Manhattan (11--2) will oppose St. John's (7--6).

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 2 --Gifts to educational, religious and charitable institutions totaling $330,000 are designated in the will of Mrs. Dwight Whitney Morrow. It was filed here today for probate in Bergen County Surrogate's Court.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Feb. 2-- Lady Salvage is chairman of the committee in charge of a benefit entertainment for the North Country Community Association, one of the oldest charitable organizations on Long Island. The event will further the association's scholarship fund.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)--A Democratic move to oust seven staff members of the Seriate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations was attacked today by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin. He called the action "cheap, petty politics at its lowest and dirtiest ebb."

La Rochelle, a ten-story and penthouse apartment building for ninety families at 57 West Seventy-fifth Street, northeast corner of Columbus Avenue, has been purchased for investment by the Efpol Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Wishnow Horowitz, brokers, for cash over mortgages of $400,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Harriman appointed three New Yorkers to major posts in his Cabinet today. They were: Leffert Holz of Manhattan, a lawyer, to be Superintendent of Insurance at $18,500 a year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--President Eisenhower is said to have on his desk a transportation policy report recommending relaxed regulation of railroads.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation is sharply reducing manufacturing costs through extensive use of automaton processes. This was disclosed yesterday by Benjamin Abrams, president, at the annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel here.

A sharp drop in the mercury, following fast on a record snowfall for the season yesterday, has brought New York its coldest spell of the winter. The mercury dipped to 8.9 degrees at midnight last night, well below the previous low of 12 last Friday.

NOT since the gloriously exciting days of Glenn Cunningham and Bill Bonthron has there been an indoor track season with the captivating promise of this one. Or so it seems to one railbird. Wes Santee, the rollicking cowboy from Kansas City, already has run an indoor mile faster than anyone ever ran one before, a spanking 4:03.8 effort.

So many new 25-cent books for children reach newsstands, drug stores and super markets every week that at least one group of parents and teachers has taken action to see that families do not flounder in the steady stream.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Senate's delay in confirming Judge John Marshall Harlan to the Supreme Court is "unfortunate," President Eisenhower asserted today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 30-- President Eisenhower's plan to cut Tennessee Valley Authority appropriations about 75 per cent will mean the dismissal of onefourth of those on the work rolls.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 2--The American Federation of Labor renewed its attack on the Eisenhower Administration today.
PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Britain submitted today a proposal for an arms production agreement closely allied with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and shorn of supranational provisions.
Continued improvement in the economy, expected this year, will be moderated by a slowdown in the steel and automobile industries, the National City Bank of New York said in its February bank letter.
"The Southwest Corner," a new play by John Cecil Holm starring Eva LeGallienne, will open at the Holiday Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock under the auspices of John Huntington.

PORT - OF - SPAIN, Trinidad, B. W. I., Feb. 2--Princess Margaret had her first real contact with the people of the West Indies today when she attended a garden party given in her honor by the Governor of Trinidad and Tobago, Maj. Gen. Sir Hubert Rance.
LONDON, Feb. 2--The Formosa crisis has stimulated the Labor party by reviving an old charge that the United States and British foreign policies are too close for comfort.
For helping make possible the first trans - Atlantic telephone cable, Dr. Oliver E. Buckley received yesterday the 1954 Edison Medal, one of engineering's highest awards.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that higher city taxes on general and financial business were "highly likely" unless more state funds were received than were now budgeted.

Hank Bauer yesterday became the first regular outfielder to sign his contract with the New York Yankees--if Hank, even after six good years, can be called a regular. He was the thirtieth Bomber signer.

Down in the canyons of Wall Street a special task force is getting braced to tackle one of the biggest precision jobs in financial history. Employes of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., will soon be handling hundreds of thousands of subscriptions to the $350,000,000, record-breaking General Motors Corporation stock issue.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 2-- Turkey is pressing negotiations with Iraq for a binding mutual security treaty despite lost ditch opposition from Egypt. A high Foreign Ministry official said tonight that the pact would be ready for signature "in a matter of weeks."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--President Eisenhower's nomination of Joseph Campbell for Controller General met strong Senate opposition today.
Supplies of light fuel oil--the type used in home furnaces--declined 6,838,000 barrels last week to 89,032,000, it was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

Mrs. Cecile Ruth Sands of Brooklyn was appointed to the Board of Education yesterday by Mayor Wagner. She will fill the vacancy created five weeks ago by the resignation of Arthur Levitt, who left to become State Controller.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Vonnie Colby of Hollywood holed out a blast shot from a sand trap for a birdie on the ninth extra hole today to keep the defending champions in the women's international four-ball golf tournament.
MADRID, Feb. 3--Generalissimo Francisco Franco is apparently considering nominating someone to succeed him as Chief of State in his lifetime.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 3-- Turkey has begun a diplomatic courtship of Syria in the belief she now wants a Turkish guarantee against absorption by Iraq.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--Department store sales in the United States last week were 1 per cent above those in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

With the stale and shop-soiled arguments of Soviet propaganda the Chinese Communist Government has, for the present at least, rejected the Security Council's invitation to join in the United Nations' effort to end the present hostilities in the Formosa Strait on lines proposed by the Council.
Jack McGuire ended his college basketball career by leading C. C. N. Y. to a 92-84 victory over Montclair State Teachers last night at the Beavers' gymnasium.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Friday, Feb. 4--Red China's rebuff to the United Nations has introduced a new element of tension into the general Formosa picture.
Speculator buying and short covering firmed most commodities late yesterday on the New York exchanges. The strength resulted from news of renewed tension in Asia.

QUEMOY ISLAND, Feb. 3-- The Nationalist Chinese commander of the garrison here said today he was certain the Chinese Communists would try to attack Quemoy once they had succeeded in taking over the Tachen Islands farther north.

JACKIE GLEASON'S determination to be an actor as well as a comedian ran into a snag on Wednesday evening in the television revival of the George Kelly play, "The ShowOff." He had a different part to play.
The Union Bag and Paper Corporation had net earnings of $10,794,000 last year, equal to
Army authorities and city officials are heading toward a showdown over the maintenance of city piers used by military transports.
ST. PAUL, Feb. 3 (AP)--Chuck Burke, an apprentice steamfitter from Chicago, and Gene Sandvig of Minneapolis today filled out the eight-man United States Olympic speed-skating team for 1956.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) higher to 3 points lower yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 3--Attorney General Jacob K. Javits said today that certain job protections provided by civil service law to veterans do not apply to those of the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--Personal income in the United States last year set a record.
The 1955 Soviet military budget will apparently permit the Soviet Union to have the largest peacetime armed force it has had since the demobilization of the huge forces employed in World War II.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--Congressional opinion toward Communist China hardened today. The Administration probably will be asked to re-examine, its policy of seeking a ceasefire in the hostilities involving Formosa.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3--The grain futures market in a late rally recovered some of its earlier losses today.

It would be presumptuous for the inexpert layman to make judgments as to the precise manpower needs in each of our defense categories. There are differences of opinion among the experts. And, it should be pointed out, each of the experts who has given an opinion is devoted not only to his particular branch of the service but to the welfare of the nation.

The life of the Mendes-France Government is threatened by a new political crisis, this time over North Africa. The extremes of Left and Right are forming, as usual, the core of an opposition that is trying to bring about the downfall of the most dynamic Premier Prance has had in years.
Three television producers were shifted to new assignments yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System, which said the changes were nothing unusual.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--December sales of manufacturers totaled $24,900,000,000, an advance of 2 per cent on a seasonally adjusted basis from November, the Department of Commerce said today.

The new Internal Revenue Code provides special relief for employes who are absent from work because of illness or injury and who, during their absence, receive payments under a wage continuation plan financed by their employers.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 3--The feasibility of importing Italian laborers to replace future German army conscripts will be discussed within the framework of trade negotiations in Rome this month.
LEETONIA, Ohio, Feb. 3 (UP) --Six cars of a Chicago-to-New York Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train jumped the tracks here today, but only one of 111 passengers aboard was hurt.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)-- President Eisenhower had another group of Republican leaders as guests at a stag dinner tonight. They were among seventeen, guests.

TWO exhibitions are sharing the rooms at the Barone Gallery. 202 East Fifty-first Street. The larger is of paintings by Geoffrey Holder, a Trinidad artist who is playing a leading dance role in the "House of Flowers."
The election of Charles H. Silver as head of the New York City Board of Education is in the best Horatio Alger tradition.

LONDON, Feb. 3--Business was quieter in the stock markets here today and price changes were smaller than yesterday. Industrial shares continued to advance, especially those of companies connected with road making, which will profit from the Government road building program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--The Department of Defense said today that it hoped in the near future to complete the terms on which the United States would supply some atomic information to Allied nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $209,000,000 the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Manhattan won its ninth straight game and Cincinnati its seventh in the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. The Jaspers routed St. John's, 88--61, following Cincinnati's 88-78 comeback triumph over Seton Hall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--The Administration's request for extension of the draft to June 30, 1959, was approved unanimously today by the House Armed Services Committee.

The American Committee for Cultural Freedom, charged yesterday that the recent trial of Milovan Djilas and Vladimir Dedijer "make it clear that Yugoslavia ... is unable to break the rigid mold of Communist despotism."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP)-- An attorney for Louis F. Wolfson said today any effort to postpone the April 22 annual stockholders' meeting of Montgomery Ward Co. would be opposed. William Shea of New York said "we want that meeting held April 22."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)-- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, has rebuffed a demand from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that a dishonorable discharge be given to a private physician who invoked the Fifth Amendment last year before the Senate investigation committee.
Charles Schinitsky, 39-year-old former Army captain, is a perfectionist who is determined to make the legal profession sit up and take notice.
PARIS, Feb. 3--Genevieve Fath, widow of Jacques Fath, one of the big three of Paris couture, who died at 42 last November, presented her first collection today.
Company health plans that pay extended costs of sick care for employes were attacked yesterday as "socialistic" and defended as a bulwark of free enterprise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Alaska, outermost bastion for the defense of the Western Hemisphere, is being operated on a "calculated risk" basis. The odds, however, are deemed to be in favor of the United States.

WHEN Lou Boudreau was managing the Cleveland Indians in 1948, he spoke with the brisk assurance of a man who knew he had a solid ball club to back his words. Thanks to the magnificent shortstopping of a certain Lou Boudreau, the runaway pick as the American League's most valuable player, the Tribe won the pennant and world series.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. --The anticipated establishment this week of the Continental Army Command to replace the Army Field Forces initiates a period of sweeping redeployment and tactical and administrative change for the Army.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)-- The Armed Forces are using about three times as many doctors as they apparently need in peacetime, the Government's Health Resources Advisory Committee reported today.
The New York Yankee officials, unconvinced Wednesday night, yesterday were resigned to the fact that Allie Reynolds would not pitch for them again.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 3-- Lutheran World Relief has shipped $38,000,000 in food, clothing, medicines and other supplies to twenty-eight countries since it began operations in 1946.

Being a British Princess is a task that might be attractive to many young women, although perhaps not as much fun as being a successful motion-picture actress. Princess Margaret, the 24-year-old sister of Queen Elizabeth, wasn't ashed whether she wanted to be a Princess or not.
FROM Mildred Walker's pastoral novel, John Cecil Holm has made a tender little play, "The Southwest Corner," which opened at the Holiday last evening.
Otto Kohn, a Czechoslovak professor of architecture who has turned his talents to furniture design, lists a bedroom group, a sideboard and a commodious wall unit in his new collection.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 3-- Dartmouth College officials would like to exchange a portion of cold weather for another blanket of snow. With the forty-fifth annual Winter Carnival slated to start here tomorrow the one noticeable complaint on the campus is that "it is too cold."
Baltimore County, Md. Baltimore County, Md., will accept bids until Feb. 16 on $10,000,000 of metropolitan district water and sewer bonds date next March 1.

Charlotte Ebener, who describes herself as "a woman reporter who has been traveling in odd corners of the world for ten years," has written an account of her experiences. It will be published Feb. 21 by Knopf under the title "No Facilities for Women."
ALBANY, Feb. 3--Mark A. McCloskey was selected today to lead the state's fight on juvenile delinquency.

So delicious is roast pork that it inspired one of the most famous essays in English literature -- Charles Lamb's "A Dissertation Upon Roast Pig." Roasts from the pig this week are not only tempting but also thrifty.

The writer of the following letter served as consultant to the Legal Department of the United Nations Secretariat in 1948. He is Professor of Law and John Harvey Gregory Lecturer on World Organisation at Harvard University.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3-- Warner Brothers, which once had an extensive list of stars and feature players under contract, is making plans to replenish its talent pool. The studio, according to Jack L. Warner, vice president, soon will undertake "a canvass of the whole country" in line with a long-range program to bring more fresh personalities into movies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Administration contended today that Democrats were without a legal leg to stand on in their resolution aimed at killing the Dixon-Yates private power contract.
Plans to merge the Commercial State Bank and Trust Company and the Metropolitan Industrial Bank were announced yesterday. A statement signed by D. Mal-
Justice in New York is "too slow, too costly and too uncertain."
TOKYO, Feb. 3 -- Communist China has offered informally to bring Japan into the scope of the friendship pacts that the Peiping Government concluded last year with India and Burma.
UNLESS weather conditions improve rapidly, the Adirondack deer herd will face the worst starvation threat in ten years, the Conservation Department reports.
ABOARD THE U.S.S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Feb. 2--In the hope that a circulatory ocean current may open a chink in the icepack, this ship again turned south today.

Controller Gerosa complains to the Board of Estimate that the Port of New York Authority has not lived up to its 1947 contract with the city for development of International and La Guardia Airports. He charges the authority with spending, in the first seven years, only 54 per cent of what it agreed to spend in that period.

THE thirty-ninth annual exhibition by the Society of American Graphic Artists will be opened to the public today at the Kennedy Gallery, 785 Fifth Avenue. The exhibition this year includes 230 prints by 212 artists.

The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York will eventually inherit nearly all of the $8,000,000 estate of John A. (Fishhooks) McCarthy. This was learned yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.
A taxpayer building containing five stores at 117-121 Hillside Avenue in Williston Park, L. I., has been sold by the builder, the Queensboro Corporation, to Elias J. Leighton and Dorothy Kaufman.
The stockholders of the Burlington Mills Corporation voted yesterday to change the name to Burlington Industries, Inc., at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del.

Probably no major industry fell on harder times last year than railroad-car building. Orders dwindled to a trickle; makers suspended operations or went out of business entirely. Now there are strong signs that the worst is over.
Total daily newspaper circulation in the United States exceeded 55,000,000 last year for the first time in history, Editor Putolisher magazine reported yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3-- American flag ship operators of the West Coast have asked the State Department to defend "stoutly" abroad the "fiftyfifty" shipping law covering foreign aid cargoes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--The political issue over the Dixon-Yates contract and the proper scope of the Tennessee Valley Authority has obscured, the legal issue, now that the Democrats who have made both a partisan dispute are in control of Congress.

In the face of the most promising outlook of the season, thousands of skiers from the metropolitan area were preparing for week-end trips yesterday. Adding to the rosy picture was the prediction temperatures would remain cold.
KEELUNG, Formosa, Feb. 3-- Keelung harbor was crowded today with United States and Chinese Nationalist warships and transports standing by to take part in the evacuation of the Tachen Islands.

The man awakened reluctantly. His exposed nose seemed almost not a part of himself. Without disturbing the warm bubble of air beneath the blankets, he turned to the window. The panes were covered with two-dimensional jewels translucently sparkling sunlight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 641,979 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,326 cars, or 1 per cent more than in the preceding week and 13,786 cars, or 2.2 per cent, more than in the corresponding week last year, but 55,463 cars, or 8 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate you on the most interesting and educational series of articles by Walter Sullivan from Antarctica. I have read each article with unflagging interest. Mr. Sullivan has that rare journalistic touch of making the reader feel that he, too, is experiencing the adventures so entertainingly chronicled.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 3--Communist China sharply turned down tonight the invitation of the United Nations to send representatives to the Security Council to discuss the hostilities off the Chinese mainland.

Helen Keller will be 75 years old next June. Since she was nineteen months old she has heard nothing and seen nothing. Yet she went through college, she has written brilliantly and continues to do so and she has never faltered, since she was restored to creative and conscious life by the late Anne Sullivan Macy, in her devotion to others who are blind or deaf and to all who suffer.

Ken Bantum, Charley Pratt and Charley Serra of Manhattan and Joe Sefcsik of St. John's won the gold medals yesterday in the outdoor phase of the thirteenth annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships.
A New York County grand jury and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan issued recommendations yesterday designed to reduce the number of accidental deaths caused by gas poisoning.
A chemical from the Indian snakeroot plant is offering promise as a new weapon against the most serious form of insanity-- schizophrenia.
Franklin O. Nichols of 409 Edgecombe Avenue, assistant to the personnel officer of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died unexpectedly at his home here yesterday. His age was 65.
