The text of Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams' summary of the crime situation follows: Throughout the year 1953 (the first full year for which valid statistics are available), crime rose rapidly, with the result that during 1953, 108,731 felonies and 153,249 misdemeanors had been reported.

"Continued progress" was reported yesterday afternoon following the second contract negotiations meeting between representatives of Local 333, United Marine Division, A. F. L., and the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association.

When an Army musician sounded the chow call last evening at the Sheraton Astor Hotel, he was not just blowing his bugle. He was calling hundreds of prominent men and their wives to a $15-a-tray turkey dinner, Army style.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 3--Princess Margaret proved today that she had scored a major success in a sensitive area for the British Crown.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3-- Unions are less pleased with the new Democratic chairman of the House Labor Committee than they were with his Republican predecessor.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 3, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Had breakfast with Nelson A. Rockefeller, his special assistant. Conferred with members of the National Security Council. Received Manlio Brosio, new

IN the ancient city of Peiping, in a huge compound with many courtyards and hundreds of rooms, a girl was born in 1917. Her father was a Vice Minister of Education, a Vice Minister of Justice and a general. He also was a scholar, an esthete, a master calligrapher and a political royalist loyal to the fallen Manchu dynasty.

THE snowfall that started after midnight Tuesday and spread a white coverlet on city walks and pavements has been pretty well reduced by Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain's salt and small-plow tactics, even in the face of the freeze.
Two divisions of the Protestant Council of the City of New York held their annual meetings, elections of officers and campaign dinners yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3--United States experience in developing a corn-hog economy has been adopted by the Soviet Union as the basis for its program to double the output of livestock products in the next six years.

ALBANY, Feb. 3--The Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee asked today that dwelling units be released from state rent controls as they become vacant. The committee represents the bulk of New York City landlords.
Lucky the bride who selects her wedding dress at the Rosette Pennington Shop, for each of its new gowns, in addition to being beautifully simple, bears its own little good luck token.
MIAMI, Feb. 3--Ted Atkinson made use of two horses to get to the winner's enclosure after Hialeah's sixth race today.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 3 (AP) --Hoot Mon, the 39-foot yawl from Biscayne Bay Yacht Club of Miami, today successfully defended her championship in the 184-mile Miami to Nassau race.

The mercury dropped to zero here yesterday--a record for the date--as a bitter cold wave enveloped the northeastern part of the country. The temperature reached its low at 6:45 A. M. It rose to a peak of only 16.3 degrees at 3:15 P. M. before starting into another decline.
LONDON, Feb. 3--The Commonwealth Prime Ministers will discuss tomorrow the courses of action by which they could help solve the deepening crisis over Formosa.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent untimely death of Thacher Winslow in Washington is a great loss not only to the Washington branch of the International Labor Office, of which he was the director, but also to those members of Congress who had come to look to him for detailed and dispassionate reports about labor conditions the world around.

WHEN Guido Cantelli gave his fiery performance of the Verdi Requiem with the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, the Westminster choir and the soloists assembled in Carnegie Hall last night, we thought of the remark that Brahms made upon hearing this work for the first time.
MOSCOW, Feb. 3--An increase of nearly 12 per cent in Soviet defense expenditure was proposed by the Government today in its budget for 1955.
FORT DIXON, Malaya, Feb. 3 --The story of the unending war against the Communists here is told in the faces of the men who are fighting it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP)-- The chairman of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee charged today that Harvey Matusow, turn-about witness, had been "planted" by the Communists as a Government informer.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 4 (UP)-- The Japanese Government decided formally today to open negotiations in New York for the "normalization" of relations with the Soviet Union.
DETROIT, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Don McKenney's third - period goal lifted the Boston Bruins into a 1-1 tie with the Detroit Red Whigs in a National Hockey League game.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A labor union has been told that the Army, in its buying, cannot take note of a company's noncompliance with a Government labor order.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Feb. 3--Julio Lozano Diaz, Honduran Chief of State, decried today what he described as lack of cooperation from his Council of State.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 3 (UP)-- Ralph Neves, a jockey who once was declared dead after a spill from a horse, rode the 2,500th winner of his career today at Santa Anita, taking the second race with Lovely Site.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP)--Department of Agriculture report of livestock trading here today: HOGS Salable hogs, 10,000 head; trading moderately active and uneven, but averaging around steady on butchers and sows; trade closed slow, weak on a few lots; most choice

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 3 (AP)-- The Minneapolis Lakers tonight defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 90--83, for their eighth National Basketball Association triumph in ten games. It was the second night in a row the home club defeated the New Yorkers.
A fixed-wing jet aircraft that rises and descends vertically, hovers like a helicopter and flies horizontally has completed its first tests.
A high-ranking Buddhist lama arrived here yesterday and found New York colder than the Tibetan highlands-- "the roof of the world."
PARIS, Feb. 3--Premier Pierre Mendes-France asked the National Assembly tonight for a vote of confidence on his North African policy.
What is E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., going to do about the General Motors Corporation's pending stock offering?

Children in the metropolitan area's congested sections will benefit from the annual Valentine Bridge Party held for the Play Schools Association. The event will take place Feb. 14 in the ballroom of the Pierre.
Charles H. Silver was elected president of the Board of Education yesterday.

LANCASTER, Pa., Feb. 3-- W. Robert Brossman, director of public relations at Cornell University, was elected head of District 2, American College Public Relations Association, at the district's annual convention here tonight.
More crimes were committed in this city in 1954 than in any previous year.

A trend toward more home life and family living in this country can mean "huge new markets" for consumer and industrial goods and services, Arno Johnson, vice president and director of research at J. Walter Thompson Company, said yesterday.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa renewed his attack on the Port of New York Authority yesterday.

Kid Gavilan, former welterweight champion, will face Ernie Durando of Bayonne in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight will be the first for Gavilan since Oct. 20 when he lost the 147pound title to Johnny Saxton in Philadelphia.

Mrs. Florence A. V. Twombly, a granddaughter of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, left a gross estate of more than $22,000,000, but inheritance taxes have taken so much of it that $320,000 she hoped to give to churches and hospitals will not be paid.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 3 (UP)--Gene Littler sank a seven-foot birdie putt on the eighteenth hole today to take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the $15,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.

A Greenwich Village property that had been in the hands of the sellers since 1891 passed to new control with the purchase by a client of Walter Scott Co., brokers, of the twenty-family apartment house at 163 West Tenth Street, at Seventh Avenue.

Jams and Jellies Every now and then the encyclopedia comes along with a remark so cynical as to represent absolute truth. In a discussion of a subject no one would look up were he not always hungry it observes: "The manufacture of jams and jellies has become largely commercial."
Loans to business by major New York City banks declined $36,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 3--Following is the text of a reply from Premier Chou En-lai to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's invitation to Communist China to attend talks at the United Nations on a ceasefire in the Formosa Strait:
Mark A. McCloskey has been closely allied with the juvenile delinquency problem since he was a boy on the West Side in Hell's Kitchen.

In an unusual burst of activity, Stanley Gilkey has extended his lines of operation. He has just purchased a third script, called "Lexington Avenue Entrance," once held by Kermit Bloomgarden and later by the new Courtney Burr-John Byram combination.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3--Six major rail unions decided today to make the guaranteed annual wage their chief target in 1955 negotiations with the nation's railroads.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation demonstrated yesterday new ware it plans to offer besides the airplanes and engines that are its principal business.
CAIRO, Feb. 3 -- Representatives of the Arab states reconvened here today, still at loss for solution of a dispute threatening the future of the Arab League.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 3--The Allied High Commission published a law today transferring the responsibility for the final liquidation of the I. G. Farber chemical trust to the West Germans.

Radio Corporation of America took automation in the electronics industry farther out of the theoretical stage yesterday with a new machine which is expected to assure substantial cost and time savings.
Representatives of the nation's five principal engineering societies have recommended moving their headquarters from New York to Pittsburgh.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The manufacturers of almost everything from cigarette lighters to manicure sets today sought relief from the reciprocal trade program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A report of the Department of Agriculture showed today that despite a 5 per cent general decline in farm prices in 1954, farmers' returns for many products averaged higher than in 1953.

Problems of the Far East, including Formosa, are expected to get a place in the forthcoming deliberations of the executive committee of the World Council of Churches in Geneva, Switzerland. The committee will meet Monday through Thursday primarily on administrative matters.
Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, Shah of Iran, yesterday described the United States policy of peace backed by strength as the greatest factor contributing to the peace and security of the world.
LONDON, Feb. 2--Britain, like the United States, is seriously concerned about her shortage of scientists, engineers and technologists.
More emphasis on sex education to stem juvenile delinquency and immorality was recommended yesterday to 1,000 Roman Catholic instructors.

Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York, exchanges. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, silk, hides, burlap, zinc, copper and tin gained; coffee, potatoes and rubber eased, and cocoa, sugar and wool ended mixed.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 4--In a drastic move against Communist peneration the American Federation of Labor threatened today to expel one of its biggest unions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--The State Department made clear today its lack of appetite for a conference like that at Geneva on a Formosa cease-fire.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (Reuters)-- A United States Navy transport brought aid to the stricken Costa Rican tanker Darnel 200 miles off the Spanish coast. The tanker reported two men killed, three seriously injured and many slightly hurt in a boiler explosion.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP)-- The Maritime Administration gave Congress a preview today of the designs for seven types of new ships it has planned for the merchant marine of the future.
FORT RICHARDSON, Alaska, Jan. 31--Along the vast icy frontier between Alaska and Soviet Siberia a line of Eskimo scouts keeps a vigil for signs of war.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 4, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Nominated Ross Rizley of Oklahoma to be member of Civil Aeronautics Board; Trevor Gardner to be Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, and 552 new postmasters.
A strong denunciation of all types of racial prejudice as sin was proclaimed yesterday by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4--Grain futures had a generally easy undertone today in spite of developments in the Far East. Soybean futures staged a brisk rally but wheat and corn were hard to budge and even rye, which has been strong recently, was inclined to sag.

In a move to get more firemen "back to the job of fighting fires," Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. announced last night that he was cutting thirty-seven men from the department's band and glee club.

JOKKMOKK, Lapland, Feb. 4--The 350th annual market of the Lapps of the North Swedish border area of which this is the center opened here yesterday and will continue throughout tomorrow. Before there were roads and railways in this district the market was important to the Lapps as one of their main points of contact with traders. It also was a time of religious festival.

TOKYO, Feb. 4--Japan seems to have little expectation, that her claim to her former territories will be honored by Moscow in peace talks to be resumed soon. Nor are such negotiations expected here to produce much benefit to Japan in trade.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--A program to aid juvenile delinquents was introduced in the Senate today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 4--Soviet citizens will be expected to invest about twice as much in Government bonds this year as in 1954.

The Depot Plaza Building, occupying a block opposite the New York Central Railroad station in White Plains, N. Y., is under contract, of sale by the New York Central to Marvel Realties Company. The buyer is a partnership formed by Marvin J. Silberman and Samuel J. Silberman, investors.
An intimate revue, "Watch the Birdie," featuring Sono Osato, Jack Gilford and Zero Mostel, will make its New York debut at the Barbizon Plaza Theatre on March 15.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 4-- Dartmouth College's swimming team defeated Navy, 44-40, today, capturing six first places on the ten-event program.
CAIRO, Feb. 4--An attempt by Lebanon to delay a break between Egypt and Iraq over Middle East defense policy has met with a cold reception.

Added security rather than economic gains will again be emphasized by the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., in contract negotiations with Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipowners. The present agreement expires on June 15.

THE hazards of a onecomposer program apply peculiarly to Debussy. Even though he composed some of the most colorful piano music in the repertory, a succession of his pieces under any but the most skillful hands can easily degenerate into a tour through a perfume factory where, after a while, the senses are completely dulled.
LONDON, Feb. 4--Formosa cast a deeper shadow over the stock market today. Prices fell in nearly all divisions, though losses among industrials were reduced in the absence of much selling.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 4 (UP)-- Johnny Palmer brushed past Gene Littler with a 35-foot putt on the eighteenth hole today to take a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the $15,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 4-- Sweeping tactical and administrative changes in the Army and a major redevelopment are impending. They will result from cuts in, manpower and numerous other factors.

The Henkind-Walsey Company, a syndicate of investors, has purchased the thirty-nine family apartment house at 1890 Crotona Parkway, the Bronx, from a client of Bernard Friedmah, attorney. The property is assessed at $102,000. Title insurance was furnished by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Trust Company.

The Boston Celtics, who have turned back the New York Knickerbockers in five of their seven meetings this season, will engage the locals in a National Basketball Association contest at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points lower to 5 points higher yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--A wheelchair that climbs curbs was patented this week by two New Yorkers in behalf of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The chair's large front wheels are pushed up onto the sidewalk with a pair of rods, which then are retracted. The small back wheels are raised with another pair.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 4--The debate in the French Nations Assembly on North Africa has been followed here with passionate interest.

Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, has long been a highly vocal opponent of mergers, big and small, apparently he is also a man who is not easily embarrassed. Yesterday he had something to say about the projected merger of Commercial Bank and Trust Company and Metropolitan Industrial Bank of Brooklyn.

An "electric mouse," born of the ingenuity of engineers of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, is conquering a problem that long has plagued electric companies with extensive sive underground distribution systems.

When Soviet citizens picked up their morning newspapers a day or two ago they found that most of their reading matter consisted of the six pages of Communist party First Secretary Nikita S. Khrushchev's latest speech. Among other remarks, Mr. Khrushchev declared that it was "inadmissible" to emphasize the production of consumer goods "when imperialist states are frenziedly preparing for war."

The amateur Savoyards of the Blue Hill Troupe will give performances of "Utopia, Ltd." on April 13, 14, 15 and 16 for the benefit of the Legal Aid Society. The 31-year-old troupe will present the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta in the Hunter Playhouse on East Sixty-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP)--Hog prices dropped to a new low since December, 1952, as producers unloaded 9.000 salable head on the market today. 2.000 more than had been expected. Only 700 fresh receipts were available In the cattle section, mainly cows. Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:
Seventeen officers from outof-town police departments received certificates yesterday for their successful completion of a one-year advanced training course at the Police Academy here.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4-- The domestic sugar industry plans to seek amendment of the Sugar Act at this session of Congress to give it "a little elbow room."

Tuning up for the big intercollegiates three weeks hence, Manhattan's powerful squad romped to its sixth straight team victory in the metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track and field championships last night.
Snow and ice turned to slush in New York yesterday, as the temperature rose above freezing for the first time in three days.
HENDERSONVILLE, N. C., Feb. 4--Philip D. Reed, chairman of the General Electric Company, predicted tonight that the free world would ultimately benefit from present international tensions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Chief Justice Earl Warren said today that he would "be happy" personally to discuss with Congress the problems of the Federal judiciary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--New York Republicans in Congress opposed today President Eisenhower's reciprocal trade program in its present form.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)-- The Senate voted $482,000 today to committees for investigations. This was over the protests of Senator Alien J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, that figures should be cut.

Many young people entering marriage think that warmth, love and romantic feelings are all-important and assume that the partnership does not have to be worked at very hard in the beginning, Dr. M. Robert Gomberg declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission said today it is misleading advertising to represent spaghetti as a low calorie food while at the same time recommending that a fattening sauce be poured over it.
AN ABUNDANCE of thrills for the hot-rodders is the one satisfaction assured by Twentieth Century-Fox' "The Racers," which roared into the Roxy yesterday.
Plans of the New York Central Railroad to discontinue passenger service on its West Shore Division were blocked--at least temporarily--by the State Public Service Commission yesterday.

The police questioned yesterday another man who had spoken recently to Serge Rubinstein about possible investment in a Canadian oil venture. But there was no indication of progress toward a solution of the financial manipulator's murder on Jan. 27.
NIMBORAN VALLEY, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 14-- The boldest experiment yet tackled in this country is being tried out in this fertile stretch of flatland cradled within a range of low-lying hills.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 4--This year the United States is investing $105,000,000 in economic assistance to Pakistan. Agreements committing this considerable sum, in addition to military aid already pledged, were signed last month. At the official rupee rate this represents more than a seventh of total Pakistani expenditures budgeted for 1955.
Beer is mainly a between-meals drink in this country, according to a recent marketing survey.
A single adjusted electric rate for the 450,000 customers of the Long Island Lighting Company was ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission.
PARIS, Feb. 4--Madeleine de Rauch excels in beachwear. Her collection opens with a black jersey swim suit with long tight sleeves.

Snapping and crackling of wood fires built by skaters beside the frozen willow pond. Beginners' whoops on the ski slopes. The derisive whistle blast of a cruise ship departing for tropical seas. The agonizing straining of trees laboring under a coat of thickening ice.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 4--The United Nations Security Council is expected to meet next week to consider Communist China's refusal to participate in its debate.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 4--Governor Harriman said today that he would veto the Republican bill freezing state aid to schools.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4--The Philadelphia Orchestra Association signed an agreement tonight with Local 77, American Federation of Musicians, making possible the orchestra's first concert tour on the European continent this spring.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--The Dixon-Yates contract generated more heat and power politics on Capitol Hill today. There were these developments:

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 4-- The idea of an agreed "peaceful" withdrawal by Nationalist Chinese forces from islands off the China mainland is being discussed in this capital as a formula for easing tensions in Formosa Strait.

Forty-eight lots in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn on Remsen Avenue, Avenue N, East Ninetyfirst Street and Avenue M have been sold by Haven Homes, Inc., to Shore View Homes, Inc. The new owner plans to construct thirty-seven two-family dwellings. Murray O. Handel was the broker in the transaction.
Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan ordered the Government yesterday to halt its plans for downgrading forty-nine customs employes.

Three groups of happy people were lined up in front of the Swiss chalet on the Concord Hotel ski slopes at Kiamesha Lake, N. Y. There were, in two sections, sixteen adults, mostly young men and women in their twenties and early thirties.

Recent letters appearing on this page testify to the increasing concern of the people of New York over the dirt in public places that mars our city and often menaces our health. Three of these letters have been especially significant and welcome.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--President Eisenhower nominated 552 postmasters today. They included forty-one in New York State. It was the largest group of civilian nominations the President has submitted.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 4 (AP)--Three field goals by Gary Clark in the final 75 seconds lifted Syracuse into a 74-70 upset basketball victory over Holy Cross tonight. The triumph, only the fifth in fourteen games for the Orange, snapped a six-game winning streak by the Crusaders.

The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker: A disposable dust and wall mop made of paper is now available it Abraham Straus. The mop has a rubber base, over which snaps a sheet of disinfectant paper.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 4 (AP)--Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom declared today the Western powers might as well cross off right now such nations as India, Pakistan and Ceylon as potential allies in any way against communism.
After six days of dips and minor advances, during which The New York Times' combined average rose only 1.30 point, the stock market moved into high gear yesterday.
Broad, general health insurance is regarded by employes as more important than protection against major illness in the view of two employer representatives and four union officials.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 4 --Rebel forces were reported today to have captured a village and airport. This might be the reopening of the revolt.

A well-known psychiatrist brandished a bull whip before a comic books hearing yesterday. He said he had obtained it through an advertisement published in a magazine bearing the seal of approval of the new industry Code Authority.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--The National Press Club today elected its first Negro member.
The Police Department asked yesterday for a 1955-56 budget $40,144,074 higher than the current one of $144,647,230.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) --Barbara Romack, the national amateur champion, defeated Pat Lesser and Virginia Denehy almost single-handed today in the quarter-finals of the women's international, four-ball golf tournament.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., has decided to maintain its present 22.6 per cent investment stake in the General Motors Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)-- The Navy said today that it had canceled more than $1,000,000,000 worth of orders for about 1,000 planes because they "could not perform to specifications."

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 31-- Anatolia's earliest written records, excavated recently in central Turkey, trace more than 100 years in the lives of rich Assyrian merchants, with whom history begins in this part of the world.
CARBONDALE, Pa., Feb. 4 (UP)--More than 400 persons were left homeless today from fires in four northeast Pennsylvania communities. Damages were estimated at $3,000,000.

An interpretation of American politics and political thought in the light of Western history is the subject of a new book by Louis Hartz entitled "The Liberal Tradition in America." The author discusses such problems as the rise of democracy, the failure of socialism, the nature of "progressivism" and the "hysterias" of the present century.
An unscrupulous waterfront baggage operator who gouged a refugee traveler out of $100 a year ago was brought to book yesterday after a long search.

Investment banking groups are weighing plans for financing additional generating facilities for the Tennessee Valley Authority by means other than the Federal Treasury. The proposal is related to growing power shortages among Tennessee municipalities and has nothing to do with the dispute over the Dixon-Yates contract to supply power to the T. V. A.

Astor Place Prospect Brightens Announcement that Cooper Union is taking over Bible House, occupying the whole block north of it and seated there since 1853, when Peter Cooper was laying the foundations of his now famous institution for free education in the arts and sciences, gives ground for hope that Astor Place may continue to hold a spot of distinction on the map of the city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)-- President Eisenhower nominated Philip W. Bonsal today to be Ambassador to Colombia.

Reserpine, a new "wonder drug" extracted from the Indian snakeroot plant, offers promise is a tranquilizer for narcotic iddicts. This effect, it is expected, will serve as an important aid in the treatment of addiction to narcotics.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Harvey M. Matusow, a large-scale informer on Communists before Congressional committees and courts, was subpoenaed today in an effort to get at the truth of his testimony.
The Ketay Instrument Corporation and Norden Laboratories Corporation have merged, it was announced yesterday by Morris F. Ketay, who has been named president of the combined company.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Feb. 4-- Still lacking a municipal budget and tax levy for 1955, officials of this city of 19,000 have decided to send a call for help to the State Legislature.
PARIS, Saturday, Feb. 5--The downfall of Premier Pierre Mendes -France and his Cabinet ended a singular interlude in French politics.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4-Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent over the week ended Tuesday to 110.2 per cent (1947-49 equals 100) according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 4-- Dartmouth's skiers held the advantage at the end of the first day of the college's forty-fifth Winter Carnival.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Ross Rizley of Oklahoma was nominated by President Eisenhower today for a six-year term on the Civil Aeronautics Board. The post pays $15,000 a year.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 4 (UP)--W. G. Reynolds, a vice president of the Reynolds Metals Company, said today his firm had plans drawn up for an indoor harness racing track at the request of several New York interests.
Conversion of New York City's Camp La Guardia, near Chester, N. Y., which houses homeless men, into a state-operated rehabilitation home for delinquent boys was proposed yesterday.

The Kremlin facade of "collective leadership" appears to have been dented. The Communist party's First Secretary, Nikita S. Khrushchev, has given a growing public demonstration of his personal influence and power.
WATERFOWL prospects for 1955, as far as breeding ground conditions are concerned, appear to be bright, according to winter surveys by Ducks Unlimited.
New Jersey needs more industry to retain its population and avoid unemployment, Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared yesterday.
TRENTON, Feb. 4--Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that he would forbid the use of Newark Airport or the field at Morristown as a base for an Air National Guard jet fighter squadron.

The shabby business of the paid professional informer, which has reached new dimensions under governmental encouragement during the past few years, has been given a blow by one of the well-known practitioners of the art who now says he has been lying all along.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--The Government announced today that it would appeal the dismissal of a two-count perjury indictment against Owen Lattimore.

LONDON, Feb. 4--Sir Anthony Eden advised Communist China today that any attempt to take offshore Chinese islands would endanger peace and security. He acknowledged, however, that all these islands "undoubtedly" were part of the Peiping Government's domain.
Canada's economic expansion will help keep the United States economy growing, Henry C. Alexander, president of J. P. Morgan Co., said last night.

A Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury indicted a sales promoter and a jewelry manufacturer yesterday on charges of violating the postal laws. They were accused of sponsoring "Count the Diamonds" contests in which all entrants were "winners" even though they finished as losers.

Kid Gavilan found the target practice more trying than he expected at Madison Square Garden last night. The former welterweight champion of the world, from Camaguey, Cuba, was the top-heavy favorite over Ernie Durando of Bayonne.
Wes Santee, the cowboy from Kansas who has run the mile faster than any other American, will make his New York debut tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Representative John F. Shelley, Democrat of California, said today he had declined an offer to become president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

The blunt refusal of the Chinese Communist Government to participate in the Security Council's effort to end hostilities in the Formosa Strait except on its own terms has shocked and dismayed most members of the United Nations as a deliberate slap at the authority of the world organization which Communist China seeks to join.

Convinced by the recent tragic accumulation of deaths from fire, Mayor Wagner has ordered legislation drafted to outlaw the portable kerosene stove. The evidence for such action was overwhelming, as Fire Commissioner Cavanagh reported to the Mayor in advising the new law.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 4--Overseas press correspondents are now in Johannesburg "hoping and praying that there will be trouble" when the Negroes are moved from so called black spots of western Johannesburg to a new site eleven miles put of the city, Eric H. Louw, Minister for External Affairs and Finance Minister said last night.

MOSCOW, Feb. 4--Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov and Sir William Hayter, the British Ambassador, had another meeting today. It was their third session in the last eight days. At the previous meetings they discussed Formosa.
PARIS, Saturday, Feb. 5--Premier Pierre Mendes-France and his Cabinet were voted out of office by the French National Assembly early this morning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4-- The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L., has ruled out any free entertainment at the "Oscar" awards nominations ceremony. It will be seen Feb. 12 on the National Broadcasting Company network from 9-10:30 o'clock in New York.
MIAMI, Feb. 4--The McLennan Handicap, with thirteen entrants, will have its twentieth running at Hialeah tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--John G. Adams, Counselor of the Army and a principal in the Army-McCarthy dispute, resigned today. Secretary Robert T. Stevens accepted the resignation. It will become effective March 31.
Evidence that the Senate Banking and Currency Committee is in truth engaging in a "study" rather than an "investigation" of the stock market reached Wall Street yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP)--The British Treasury announced tonight it is selling on the London Stock Market its holdings of forty-eight American securities.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I extend congratulations on your excellent editorial of Jan. 22 about the effort to make New York a cleaner city.
BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP)--The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecast and list of ski conditions for New England: Fair, with little change in temperature tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--The Government will appeal the dismissal of the anti-trust suit against the du Pont empire and the General Motors Corporation.
The proposed merger of the American Woolen Company with Textron, Inc., and Robbins Mills was approved yesterday by the American Woolen Stockholders' Fact Finding Committee.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 4-- The commander of the United States Far East Air Force declared today that the Chinese Communists now had about half their air strength within range of Formosa, the Pescadores Islands and Nationalist-held offshore islands.

TWO painters, a man and a woman, combine as a single artistic personality, SimpsonMiddleman, in geometrical abstracts at the Heller Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street. How the collaboration works, whether one is the brains and the other the hand with brush, is not revealed.
ABOARD THE U.S.S. ATKA, Feb. 3--On orders from Washington, this ship concluded her exploratory work on the Pacific side of Antarctica today and set out for the Atlantic coast of the Continent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--President Eisenhower resubmitted to the Senate today the nomination of Trevor Gardner to be Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for research and development.

GRASSY POINT, N. Y., Feb. 4 --The only water main to this hamlet of 200 residents on the Hudson River's west bank froze solid in the subzero weather last night. Because of the lack of water the Schermerhorn Tavern burned down at 3 o'clock this morning before volunteer firemen could rig a hose line to the icy river.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 5 -- Once more Dartmouth skiers carried off the laurels in their own winter carnival today. As the two days of competition in the forty-fifth carnival ended, the Indians were well ahead of the seven other college teams.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Emil Rieve, general president of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., said today that the union would forego wage increase demands this year. He said the industry "is and has been in its most serious depression in twenty years."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Government census takers will start knocking at the doors of 25,000 householders a week from Monday to find out how many smoke and how often

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- "Chiang Planes and Guns Hit Reds: 2 Ships Blow Up." When headlines like this one in The Evening Standard begin to march across the front pages of thier newspapers Britons think that war is appreciably nearer.

ON Wednesday the United Nations will commemorate the tenth anniversary of the International Civil Aviation Organization, one of the U. N.'s specialized agencies, with 3-cent blue-gray and 8c dark carmine stamps.

A QUESTION that will tantalize the social historian reading James W. Prothro's book is whether the institutions or attitudes he has picked for his scrutiny are really representative. If the judgment is affirmative, there will be universal agreement on the writer's perspicacity; if not, one will say, how singular are the conduct and the ideas presented.

THE rabbit's foot (Davallia divaricata) is so satisfactory a house plant that it deserves to be grown more widely than it is. Many of these ferns or pieces of them have been handed down from mother to daughter, although a few florists still raise them for sale. Anyone who is fortunate enough to obtain one will have a good-looking, green house plant for many years.
PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Not merely the North African policy but all the chief features of the MendesFrance program were called into question by the downfall of the French Cabinet early today.

THIS book is an attempt to show through the eyes of Joel, a modern small boy, that Jews had a part in America's beginnings. It is well done where historical events are recorded such as the story of Don Abarbanel.
SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 1 -Fully a year before the Presidential campaign begins here there are significant political stirrings.
Four shots were fired through a fourth-floor window of the Egyptian Consulate at 900 Park Avenue at 12:45 P. M. yesterday.
The basic problem facing the Civil Aeronautics Board is a chaotic situation stemming from uncertainties in regulating nonscheduled airline operations.

EMORY COOK, the Stamford, Conn., sound engineer whose "Sounds of Our Times" recordings have taken him to all sorts of unlikely places, is revealed by his latest disk to share an affection for burlesque.

EVEN though Hollywood's studios are not as active or numerous now as they were in the last great boom year, 1946, gross film rental income for 1954 reached an all-time high, estimated at $650,000,000. And movie-makers, still shaking from the "jitters," they developed in the lean years, see in this bulging of total income great tidings of financial joy.

ATLANTA, Feb. 5 -- With merchants pushing heavy promotions of spring goods, customers are continuing to crowd department stores in the Southeast. Keeping dollar sales well ahead of last year. Winter clearance bargains also have stimulated trade.
The Interstate Sanitation Commission says progress is continuing in the pollution abatement program for waters in the New York metropolitan area.

In a defense of the budget proposed by Governor Harriman, Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, reminded Republicans yesterday that former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey had proposed a record tax increase of $168.000,000 in 1949.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Send soil, samples to be tested as soon as possible for a prompt report before the spring rush. Not more than a pint is needed. It should be not just surface soil but from a cross-section about six inches deep. Mail in a clean container clearly marked with address of sender.
Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway testified last week that in his opinion the Administration's plans to cut the size of the Army by 143,000 men by July 1, 1956, would "jeopardize security to a degree."

THE Joint Chiefs of Staff are the principal military advisers to the President, the National Security Council and the Secretary of Defense. Their main business is planning for war. Under the law they do not make national policy; they give advice. The President may, and most often does, accept that advice.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Administration is moving to end any impression that Federal aid to schools is a question of "children vs. roads."
The Port of New York Authority has announce da program under which youths between the ages of 18 and 21 will be trained for careers as police with the bi-state agency.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- Industrial activity in Pennsylvania in December was slightly ahead of the previous month, but still under that of a year ago. The index of industrial activity of the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University stood at 104 in December, compared with 102 in November and 110 a year ago.

FEBRUARY is one of the big months in tournament bridge. Two groups of seventy-two players each are winding up the annual masters' individual contests today at the Delmonico Hotel. Then, beginning Feb. 18 and lasting through Feb. 23, come the annual team-of-four tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- British Commonwealth leaders turned today to private discussion of possible solutions of the situation in the Far East.

FAMOUS gardens are legion throughout Europe and every year tourists and green-thumb hobbyists visit them during the height of their flowering season in spring and summer. In fact, some of the large garden organizations within this country have arranged conducted tours to see the highlights of many foreign lands.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 5 -- Government forces recaptured the airstrip of Los Chiles this afternoon.

FUTURE sociologists, if not literary critics, may find the popular and commercial writers of our day as rewarding as those who are published in the literary quarterlies. It is often assumed that popular writers lack something essential to serious consideration, that they are without exception false to life.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 5 -- An estimated 4,700 workers will be hired or recalled by Greater Cleveland employers in the next six weeks' with the largest gains expected in automobile, aircraft parts and primary metals industries. The increase was estimated on results of a survey among 296 concerns representing all types of industry, and was the most encouraging since mid-1953, starting point of the post-Korean downtrend.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 5 -- Princeton University's swimming team swept to its third straight Ivy league triumph as it handed Columbia a 57-27 setback in the Dillon gymnasium pool today.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- Pennsylvania defeated Cornell, 84 -- 76, tonight for undisputed possession of first place in the Ivy Basketball League.
Welfare organizations here and in France will benefit from the fourth annual April in Paris Ball, to be held on April 15 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE Middle East -- land of olives, honey and shishkebab -- has much to teach us about cooking white rice. It is the bread and potatoes of Greece and Turkey and their neighbors, a delicious running accompaniment to innumerable foods. Its blandness never tires the taste, as more emphatic flavors do.
WASHINGTON. Feb. 5 -- Chou Enlai, who is supposed to be the resident genius of Communist China, has badly misjudged the temper of Washington.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 6 -United States jet fighters shot down two of eight attacking Communist jet aircraft yesterday between Communist China and Korea.
HARTFORD, Feb. 5 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff is expected to ask the General Assembly to increase the state's cigarette tax from 3 to 4 cents a pack.

SOME of the best of our history books persistently portray Sam Houston as a romantic swashbuckler and border hero. They give him no status as a national statesman but present him as the man who wrenched Texas from Mexico, attached it to the Union and so hurried on the Civil War.

AFTER eight years stark and steady drop-off in the aggregate yearly attendance at American movie theatres, amounting to more than 60 per cent in the national volume between 1946 and 1953, the flow of paying customers took a healthy upswing last year.

DALLAS, Feb. 5 -- Southwestern business men had one of the brightest Januarys in years, reports from the Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank and other surveys of business conditions indicated this week. Department - store sales, which usually slow down after the holiday rush, were far above January a year ago -- 18 per cent higher in the first part of the month.
I read with much interest your editorial in The New York Times of Jan. 28 entitled "Business Gifts to Colleges."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Three years to the day before Pearl Harbor the United States Ambassador to Tokyo expressed doubt that "anything short of force" could block the Japanese war lords' course of conquest in Asia.
WHO will be first among four producers on two continents to back out of the contest to film "War and Peace"? That was the $64 question here last week in view of the following circumstances:
MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 5 -- Nassau County has offered to sacrifice its last plant preserve and wildlife sanctuary to help overcome opposition to the proposed $35,000,000 Oyster Bay-Wantagh Expressway.

Grosvenor Neighborhood House's varied services will benefit from the April 13 performance of Cole Porter's musical, "Silk Stockings" at the Imperial Theatre. Starring Don Ameche and Hildegarde Neff, the revue opens here Feb. 24.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A pair of New York girls established discus and javelin throw indoor records tonight -- because there were no previous championship marks.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 5 -- Gene Littler and Jay Hebert drew even with Johnny Palmer today to throw the $15,000 Phoenix open golf tournament into a three-way tie at the end of fifty-four holes.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- A decision of importance to Florida tourists just handed down by the State Supreme Court upholds the constitutionality of a law passed by the 1951 State Legislature affecting advertisements of rates for hotels, motels, apartments and rooming houses. It reverses the decision of a lower court in Dade County last year which declared the law denied "constitutional guarantees of the Constitution of the United States and of the State of Florida."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 5 -- Gifts and grants totaling $2,289,113.94 were received last year by the University of Notre Dame. This is an increase of about 55 per cent over the 1953 total of $1,470,851.13.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Indian officials today received a sample of American ghee -- clarified butter -- to judge how well it goes with traditional rice curries and other Eastern dishes.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Irish-bred Blue Butterfly nosed out Miz Clementine today in the $56,500 Santa Margarita Handicap which decided the filly and mare championship of the Santa Anita meeting.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Vonnie Colby and Mrs. Roslyn (Cookie) Swift Berger, the defending champions, and Joyce Ziske and Wiffi Smith, 1954 runners-up, today gained the final of the women's international four-ball golf tournament for the second successive year.
Japanese efforts in recent years to increase exports of raw silk are beginning to show results.

THE standard practice of replacing live television shows with filmed productions is about to receive a jolt. It was learned last week that a nationally known sponsor is plotting to buck a trend by replacing a film show with a live program.

HOW to live in one room and like it is a perennial problem in a city such as ours. It requires careful selection of furnishings that can serve more purposes than one. It calls for a thoughtfully chosen color scheme, quiet enough to live with all day long.

New York's department store sales dropped noticeably last week. They were 5 to 10 per cent below the like 1954 period. Spring business was to have begun on a large scale in the stores during the week. But snow and cold weather thwarted hopes for appreciable volume.

TOKYO, Feb. 5 -- Two of Japan's highest officials spoke with unaccustomed sharpness today on relations with Red China and the Soviet Union. One, Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu, praised the United States' policy of showing a stern front to the Communists.

BACK in 1946 one of baseball's best kept secrets was the fact that Mickey Vernon had won the American League batting championship. But because Ted Williams was the best hitter in the business, most folks assumed the Boston Belter was the top batsman. A rather analogous situation now holds forth in golfing circles.

Several rabbis paid tribute in their sermons yesterday to the memory of the four chaplains of three faiths who sacrificed their lives in the sinking of the troopship Dorchester in the North Atlantic on Feb. 3, 1943.
New York's respite from bitter cold continued for the second day yesterday, and even warmer temperatures were predicted for today. The forecast was for rain and thermometer readings in the forties.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Men and women from the conservative wing of the Republican Party will join in an unusual rally next Saturday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 -- Business along the Pacific Coast was humming at the end of January. Retail trade is 5 to 7 per cent ahead of a year ago, judged by reports from the Federal Reserve banks, while auto sales are far ahead of a year ago.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., Feb. 5 -- Ned Collins of the Amateur Ski Club won the downhill race at the annual New York City Ski Council interclub championship today. Collins was timed in 1:03.2. He beat Otto Weber of the Swiss S. C., the defending champion, by a second.

Engineers and musicians who heard last week at the meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers the first public demonstration of the new electronic music synthesizer of the Radio Corporation of America were astounded at what they heard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- As it does each year without fail, the Government declared again this week that it is time to do something about the rising cost of medical care.
MIAMI, Feb. 5 -- In a rousing race, which had a photo-finish, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Social Outcast won $50,600 in the McLennan Handicap at breezy Hialeah today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- A high percentage of Chicago area business men are paying their bills as they come due or are discounting them, the Chicago Association of Credit Men reported. In a survey of a large sampling of accounts at the end of November, the report showed 86.2 per cent of retail accounts were paid as due or discounted, compared with 87.5 per cent three months before and 80.5 per cent a year before.

BILOXI, Miss. -- This charming city, with its indolent airs and its history, which stretches hack to the time when the fleur-de-lis flag of France was planted here in 1699 and it became the capital of the Colony of Louisiana, is expanding today as a vacation center and tourist resort.

TO be left out of a Valentine party -- that is real trouble when one is 5 years old. So thought Cathy, who had never been to one and yearned to see all its lacy glories. Cathy, though, was of stern stuff. If there was a party, go she would. Off she went and thereby almost missed the party -- which turned out to be a surprise especially for her.

PHOTOGRAPHY below the surface of the water has been attracting such a steadily increasing following in the last few years and the need for practical information in consequence has become so pressing that an authoritative manual was inevitable.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5 -- The American Federation of Labor backed President Eisenhower today in his program of resistance to Communist aggression in the Far East.

It has long been widely known that General Matthew B. Ridgway, Army chief of staff, has been unhappy about the Administration's program for scaling down Army manpower. The program calls for a cut in Army strength from 1,170,000 last July to 1,027,000 by July, 1956.

IT is disconcerting to find two books so different in quality issued at the same time in the new Myths and Legends Series. Mr. Reeves' book is a rehash of familiar English nursery tales intended for children only; Miss O'Faolain's is a collection of Irish myths which will appeal even to teen-age readers and adults.

THE 2-year-old has been having a little more trouble than usual today with his attempts at self-feeding. He's tiring some; it's late; dad takes over. "Here you are, Buster," he says, loading the spoon.

THE 1955 models of the 4x5 Pacemaker Crown and Speed Graphic cameras, just announced by Graflex of Rochester, incorporate three new features, the Graphic built-in rangefinder, an optical view-finder that automatically corrects for parallax, and a wire frame finder made of flexible coil stainless steel wire.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- Changes in New England business during recent weeks have been minor. Conditions are a little better than six months ago but there has been little pep to the upturn. While employment has increased since last summer, the labor force has also been increasing, with the result that there are about as many jobless as there were six months ago.
Cargo men and ship owners are studying a revolutionary plan that would cover long-term shipping contracts in the same way that cost-of-living indices cover labor agreements in many industries.
This week's Treasure Chest is given over to the full text of William Faulkner's address on the occasion of his receiving on Jan. 25 the National Book Award for his novel, "A Fable."

A long-range study to suggest ways of assisting high schools to provide economic instruction has been inaugurated by the National Association of Secondary School Principals. Dr. Galen Jones, director of secondary education of the United States Education Office, is to direct the survey, leaving his post to devote full time to the new project.

THE current exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art packs a terrific emotional wallop. It is a show not of paintings but of, photographs: Edward Steichen's tremendous "Family of Man" exhibition, consisting of over 500 photographs of man's moods from birth to death.

The cold beauty of the figure skater twirling magically on crackling ice forms a world all its own. Father of the modern international style of skating -- which involves sixty-nine stylized figures -- was Jackson Haines, an American who won the national championships in 1863.

Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, chairman of Eastern Air Lines, has been regarded by his aviation colleagues as a man who has known both sides of a nickel ever since he introduced four-wheel brakes to the automotive industry on the Rickenbacker car of the Twenties. He admits that venture was "at considerable cost."

The China Trade, 1785 to 1860, is the subject of an exhibition opening Tuesday at the Brooklyn Museum. Examples of export objects brought to this country during the period and related material will be shown.

OFTEN when people are surrounded by many notable buildings and centers of culture they sometimes take them for granted and forget their significance. Such might be the case with New Yorkers who daily go about their business amid landmarks which are famous the world over and are usually admired only by the sight-seer or newcomer.

HAROLD ROME is a fortunate man among composers for the Broadway theatre. Because he has an engaging, if minor, talent as a singer and because a recording company, Heritage, is interested in putting his performances on disks, he is not completely at the mercy of the professionals who interpret his work.
An increase in the number of students entering professional and practical nursing schools in the United States and its territories has been reported.
Knox College, Galesburg, Ill., has received a grant of $20,000 from the Ford Fund for the Advancement of Education to establish a teacher internship program.

ENOROTALI, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 19 -- Early on a Sunday morning, high in the mountains here where civilization is only now beginning to edge into a primitive corner of the world, a strange procession may be seen.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Navy and Mississippi received a record $160,000 each for playing in the Sugar Bowl football classic last Jan. 1.
PARIS, Feb. 5 -- The precipitate fall of Premier Pierre Mendes-France early this morning has produced confusion in France and some uncertainty in the foreign and domestic situation.

For ten years the political power of the Arab world has been wielded largely by the Arab League, a loose confederation of eight states -- Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Syria, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Yemen and Libya. The eight are bound together by Arab nationalism, religion, and, above all, by resentment against Israel.

Dr. Marvin S. Belsky, Bronx physician, denied last night that he was a Communist. He had been separated from the Army on Friday "under honorable conditions," after a long controversy between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Army Secretary Robert T. Stevens.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Partial success was reported today in President Eisenhower's campaign to end racial discrimination in jobs covered by Government contracts.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- It has been a long time since London has seen a literary controversy like the one precipitated by a sharply critical biography of Lawrence of Arabia, hero of World War I.
The Board of Education has started a long-term study to determine the weaknesses in the city's educational structure.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- Something like the Nazi Student League's thought control has appeared on the East German university campuses. A campaign by the Communist Federation of German Youth makes it obligatory for members of the organization to report on the ideas, activities and utterances of their fellow students and their professors.

ONE of the friendliest and sprightliest of personalities among the birds that visit my winter feeding stations is the tufted titmouse. From crested head to longish tail, the bird surely is a perfect embodiment of the old saying about never a dull moment.

THERE are only two choices before the world today. One is co-existence between the two great nations and nation-alliances which represent opposing ideals of human life and government. The other is war. In the past forty years the world has endured two major wars.

When each of two companies in the same industry has something the other wants and needs, there's a good chance they will get together. That is the story behind the recently proposed merger of the Sunray Oil Corporation and the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation.

MARGARET KENNEDY. who reminded so many reviewers of a new Jane Austen in her "Lucy Carmichael," is just as rewarding and delightful in "Act of God." This latest mixture of tenderness, irony, humor and malice is pure Kennedy at its best.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee has undertaken the difficult task of determing what is believable from the lips of an admitted false witness.
FOR several years observers of the American literary scene have been noting, sometimes with puzzlement, the steadily mounting flow of volumes dealing with That War, the war of the Blue and the Gray.
HONOLULU, Feb. 2 -- Federal Judge J. Frank McLaughlin has ordered criminal contempt citations against three International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union officials.

PLANTS, like people, need food in order to maintain their health and vigor. What kind of food to use, how much and how often are questions to which old and new gardeners must find an answer every year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The State Department announced today that an investigation was under way to determine the nationality of the MIG fighter planes. Although the MIG's are generally assumed to have been Chinese, the department evidently wanted to make sure the pilots had not been Russians.

Fordham's hopes for a National Collegiate basketball tournament bid received a jolt last night when the Rams bowed to the alert Villanova quintet, 79 -- 69, before a crowd of 3,500 at the losers' gymnasium in the Bronx.

NAMED to the Supreme Court in 1804 at the age of 32, William Johnson of South Carolina was the first Jeffersonian appointee to that body. Defeated at the polls four years earlier, the Federalists had retired into the bastion of the judiciary.

Chinese history, like Western history, seems to repeat on the ancient principle of "nec bis idem" -- "but not exactly the same thing twice." Nearly three hundred years ago the last loyal defenders of a lost cause moved out from mainland China to the island of Formosa and there maintained themselves as an independent state for twenty-two years.

THIS story in the Stevenson tradition opens in a lawyer's office. There young Stephen Garnet learns, first, that his father has died penniless, leaving him only a yacht; second, that part of an invention on which his father had been working for the British Government had disappeared -- along with one of the elder Garnet's partners.

IN astonishingly few pages, Sir Harold Nicolson sketches the history of diplomacy from ancient Greece to the present and lays down guiding rules for governments and their agents in this all-important art. It is high time that his quietly brilliant observations -- based on a life spent "in the practice and study of diplomacy" -- should be made available to the American reader.

IF there is a single most debilitating influence on the artistic standards of television, it may be the critical judgment that almost invariably is expressed in these words: "It wasn't so bad for television," or, "Well, compared with most of the shows on television * * *."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Georgetown threw a scare into the defending National Collegiate champion, La Salle, tonight. The visitors gained a first-half lead of 22 -- 21, but the Explorers finally solved the visitors' zone defense to take a 74-46 victory before 5,000 fans.
OMAHA, Feb. 2 -- Work on projects of the Pick-Sloan plan for development of the Missouri River Basin depends now on what Congress does with the President's budget.

FOR all the official attention that the principal players in movies get -- and by principal players we mean those people who fill the leading roles -- it often happens that the most interesting and most constructive performances are turned in by those who are called upon to fashion the minor characters.
PARIS, Feb. 5 -- The directors of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany met today to allocate the $10,000,000 to be received from the West German Government this year.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 5 --Army's basketball team turned in some heavy precision cannonading in the second half today to down Yale, 84 -- 72, on the cadets' big field house court. The winners trailed at the intermission, 41 -- 38.

FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Sigge Ericsson, Swedish champion, turned in the biggest upset of the European speed skating championships today when he defeated the world record-holder, Kees Broekman of the Netherlands and won the 5,000-meter race.

LEAFING through catalogues and making a list of the new flowers and vegetables to try out this summer is one of gardening's most fascinating tasks. So much, in fact, that it is possible to be carried away and completely forget tried-and-true favorites. For example, three years ago I forgot the tomatoes.
VIENNA, Feb. 5 -- The Soviet authorities in Vienna protested tonight against an alleged attempt by two Americans to induce the Soviet consul here to commit "high treason."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- The Japanese Government, through Renzo Sawada, its official observer at the United Nations, notified the Soviet Union today of its acceptance of a Soviet proposal to discuss normalization of relations between the two countries.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The basic objectives of United States foreign policy are now being subjected to a severe test in the Formosa dispute.

New York could save $15,000,000 a year and greatly improve its port facilities by turning over the municipally owned waterfront to the Port of New York Authority, the Citizens Union declared last week.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America, which claims to be the largest mortgage lender in the nation, has sold about $60,000,000 of home mortgages to commercial banks since Jan. 3.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Communist Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria have opened campaigns to lure political refugees back behind the Iron Curtain.
Tucked away in the middle of the seventeenth semi-annual report of the Atomic Energy Commission, distributed last week-end, is the following paragraph:
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Navy routed Pittsburgh, 77 -- 65, in basketball today. The Panthers made only a brief show of opposition after the middies jumped to a 10-0 lead.
The half-yearly financial report of the Transit Authority is written in bright red ink.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 5--Iraqi Premier Nuri as-Said has rejected one of two conditions set by Egyptian Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser for a meeting here, according to a spokesman at the Presidential Palace.
Citations for spiritual stewardship and service to interfaith goodwill in the last year were presented last night to the Chiefs of Chaplains of the three armed services.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 5 -- The champions of undiminished French authority here exulted today when they heard the news of M. lVfends-France's defeat. They had been waiting for this and thought they had won a great victory.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 -- Minnesota farmers weathered 1954 with a decline in their cash sales of only three-tenths of 1 per cent from 1953's peak, the annual farm price study of a University of Minnesota agricultural agronomist showed.

The Long Island Rough Riders defeated Squadron A in the feature game of the Polo double-header at the Squadron A armory last night, 9 to 6. The game was a regularly scheduled event in the New York Polo Association and was witnessed by a crowd of 500.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 5 -- A move is being made to control, by legislation, the growth of trees in Connecticut.

THANKS to an ingenious photographic process, virtually all the dramatic works published in the United States and England from the inception of playprinting (about 1500) through 1830 are now available for the first time in a single collection.
EDGEWATER, N. J., Feb. 5 -- A protest walkout by fifty workers at the Ford Motor Company here led today to a shutdown of the entire assembly plant.

HUGH H. BENNETT, father of the soil conservation movement in this country, has added new fires to the bitter controversy over Secretary Benson's reorganization of the Soil Conservation Service, and has staked out the ground for another battle yet to come.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- A Chinese Communist reply to a personal message sent by Dag Hammarskjold may sway the action of the Security Council session expected next week.
The Soviet Union's policy shift toward maximum development of heavy industrial output promises to create new problems for those countries.

An adding machine would have been handy last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. where the New York Knickerbockers outscored the Boston Celtics, 115 -- 107. Never had so many points been totaled in a game at the old Lexington Avenue drillshed.
Lunch-time crowds at the Rockefeller Plaza skating pond were treated yesterday to a preview by members of the United States pre-Olympic figure-skating team.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 5 -- To raise enough money to finance the Toledo Orchestra the rest of the season and to dispel the threat of its death, a small group of volunteers has been writing letters, ringing doorbells and making pleas on radio and television. They have raised $8,172.43 of a $10,000 deficit.
Uranium ore is piling up at depots and mills on the Colorado Plateau. It is being blasted and scooped from the earth faster than it can be processed.

THIS memoir describes four war years spent in Hungary by a man with an Italian passport, a New England lineage and a fin de siecle temperament. Born in 1904, Ralph Brewster lived as a dilettante. He loved rather than practiced archaeology, architecture, cinematography, music, painting and literature.

DIPLOMACY in Rumania was not a career but the career, says the author of this book and he tells how his mother and her friends "constituted themselves into a sort of Society for the Breeding and Improvement of Rumanian Diplomacy."

IT will be three to five years before American jet transports are ready for airline operations. But with the public understandably leery of high-altitude jet flying as a result of the British Comet disasters, the Boeing Aircraft Company, builder of this country's first jet liner, already has begun a campaign to show how safety is being engineered into the Boeing plane.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- The Public Libraries Division of the American Library Association this week issued a list of "notable books of 1954." It includes thirty-five titles.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 5 -- A petition for appointment of a receiver for the Frank H. Lee Company, Danbury hat manufacturers, will be heard Feb. 17 in Superior Court.

TOLD originally to one little boy -- the author-artists' son -- this is a just-right picture story for all small boys who consider automobiles the most fascinating things in all the world. As the d'Aulaires tell and picture it, it seems perfectly reasonable that an old car and a new car should race through a moonlit night to prove which is the best car on the road.

The unrestricted immigration policy prior to 1921 gave the United States much of the "skill, talent and imagination" that fortify our world leadership today, former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind asserted last night.
To spend or not to spend -- that is the perennial question at the City Center of Music and Drama.
May I express my appreciation of the article by Gertrude Samuels on the refugee problem in the Near and Far Eastern countries ("On the World's Conscience" -- Jan. 16).

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The British Government's concern over ultimate ratification of the Paris agreements, already great, increased sharply today. The defeat of M. Mendes-France and the expressed distaste of some members of the Council of the Republic, France's advisory Upper House, for the accords, make it extremely difficult to expect complete ratification in France by spring, if then, officials said.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, starting its 113th year in business, has announced that in 1954 the company paid out a record $141,200,000 in benefits. More than 57 per cent of the total, said Louis W. Dawson, president, comprised "living benefits" paid to policyholders in the form of endowments, annuities, income payments, disability benefits, dividends and other payments.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- Home-made rains are now available in the Punjab for about $30,000,000 per 2,000 square miles. Financially and operationally, their production has been reduced to the elemental level. All that is needed is a supply of old kerosene cans, quantities of powdered salt, and a clutch of hand blowers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Eisenhower defended tonight the Administration's modified Universal Military Training plan.

THE resignation of Lincoln Kirstein from the managing directorship of the City Center of Music and Drama is a disturbing development in that institution's affairs. It points to two things that have become increasingly evident of late.
A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Desperate Hours" on Friday night at the Barrymore Theatre for the benefit of the Rehearsal Club.
HALIFAX, N. S., Feb. 5 -- The Home Lines' Homeric, latest addition to the North Atlantic luxury fleet, touched briefly at this Nova Scotian port tonight on her maiden run to New York.

WITH "Plain and Fancy" Helen Tamiris has happily been saved at last from her own competence. Because she is an expert craftsman with the ability to see values clearly, to work quickly and simply and with a complete awareness of theatrical essentials, she is always being called in to rectify other people's mistakes.
The record industry sells harmony, but there was little of it in business reports last week.

TODAY Broadway's brilliance stems mainly from its musicals. While the serious theatre falters, lacking the stamina that more new plays and playwrights might give it, the song-and-dance shows grow, flourish and delight the populace with their frequent boldness, freshness and variety. Ten musicals are now running in New York, all prosperous, and four more will be along before summer to brighten Broadway -- "Silk Stockings," "Three for Tonight," "Ankles Aweigh" and "Seventh Heaven."
LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Professional boxing in Europe is a sick sport. It suffers from paralyzing taxation and a shortage of talent. The sport may be near death.
Enrollment in Barnard College's interdepartmental program in education has doubled this year with twenty-four students practice-teaching in both private and public schools.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- Whatever hope there was of forming a European arms pool on federal or supranational lines has undergone a severe setback. This is the net result of the first series of meetings of the conference on the pool plan.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The United States and Britain are understood to be weighing resumption of arms deliveries to Middle East countries.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 27 -- American day-old chickens and turkeys are to be flown to Israel to beget new generations of fatter, more wholesome and more economic poultry for meat-hungry Israelis.
Top military and industrial leaders in the New York area will join in a National Resources Conference here in May.

It is conceived and written on about that level. Mysterious females of assorted hair colors slink in and out of the story, attired in tight bodices cut daringly low, native sarongs, or attractively snug buckskin trousers.

A new mode of radio communications in a pipe has been developed by scientists of the Bell Telephone Laboratories at Holmdel, N. J. It is said to be potentially as superior to the coaxial cable as the cable is to an open-wire line.

John T. Kenney believes in fisherman's luck. It was while engaged in his favorite sport along the Farmington River in Connecticut that he made his most successful catch -- though he ended the day without a trout in his creel.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Feb. 5 -- H. D'O. Baker and Henry Warren of the Greenwich Field Club, the 1954 winners, today led the way through the preliminary rounds of the eighth annual Piping Rock invitation squash racquets doubles tournament, winning two matches.
This country will have to depend increasingly on its own abilities to contain international communism, the national commander of the American Legion said here yesterday.

RICHMOND, Feb. 5 -- Fifth District department store sales in January were 13 per cent higher than in the first month of 1954. Shoppers continue to pack metropolitan area stores in response to attractive promotional appeals. Winter apparel, furniture and household appliances are in greatest demand.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A New York wife learned from the police tonight that her husband who took his own life here four] days ago was not an Army officer and respectable doctor.

Psychological aid for problems of child rearing, personality development, aging and education will be discussed tomorrow at 6:15 P. M. at a free lecture at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The lecturer will be Jacob Kisnewsky, case supervisor for the Department of Welfare.
