WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The Dixon-Yates contract is "far more favorable to the Government" than two power contracts negotiated by the Democrats for the atomic energy program.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A slow, soft voice now speaks for the nation's largest and most influential farmer organization.

On the basis of my five years of Federal service, I can say Dorothy Fosdick's forthright description of how the State Department really functions ("How a 'Global Policy' Is Evolved" -- Jan. 23) is entirely accurate. For every capable, informed, intellectually honest analyst, there are three pompous, verbose, self-designated "experts: unanimously dedicated to "playing it safe," and to avoiding any expression of opinion which might remotely be considered controversial or unpopular.

SINCE all the other local newspapers have received "Plain and Fancy" rapturously, the following comments constitute a minority point of view. They grow out of an impression that the second act does not fulfill the rich promise of the first.

HURST PARK, England, Feb. 5 -- Queen Elizabeth went racing today -- and the royal family ran straight into luck. She and Queen Mother Eliza beth watched the Queen Mother's 9-year-old gelding Devon Loch win at 11 -- 2 in the New Century Steeplechase over two miles 275 yards.
Gunnar Nielsen of Denmark evened the score with Wes Santee and erased the Kansan's week-old indoor mile record, to boot, in a riotous Wanamaker Mile last night.

The International Longshoremen's Association, independent, renewed last week its active opposition to the Waterfront Commission's proposed new hiring regulations. In another blast at the bi-state agency the union called the new rules "meddling" and "unwarranted interference."

IN 1940 your section printed a letter by a member of the newly organized school and theatre committee of the Board of Education, in which a plea was made for recognition by the people of the theatre of the needs of the large potential high school audience.

President Eisenhower hailed Boy Scout Week in a message yesterday. He congratulated the Scouts and their leaders on the forty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the organization. The celebration will start today.
TRENTON, Feb. 5 -- Dr. Frederick Raubinger, State Commissioner of Education, has received detailed charges of discrimination against the Englewood Board of Education.

LIKE Zane Grey, Doc Holliday was a dentist who went West. Zane Grey probably killed more men, but he didn't have to shoot or be shot at. Reading John Myers' biography of Doc Holliday, one gets the impression that all the men (16 for sure) he killed needed killing.
Securities of public utility concerns have become the leading investments of the nation's investment companies.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 -- Official San Francisco seems about to resolve a spirited controversy over lobbying at Washington.

General Electric reports that bacteria are being used at the Hanford, Wash., plutonium plant to clear up uncertainties as to the exact biological effects of various forms of radiation. In the tests, Lactobacillus casei, the bacteria which sours milk, is placed in test tubes.

WHEN the rehabilitation of the Slav has finally been accomplished for devotees of light reading in the West, special credit should go to the indomitable goodwill of American tourists generally, and to the dauntless effervescence of David Dodge in particular.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 5 (UP) -- Louisiana State University today discharged Gaynell (Gus) Tinsley, head football coach, and accepted the resignation of R. P. (Red), Heard, athletic director.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON -- A major historical restoration, on the order of Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia, is being blueprinted in this early-American Hudson Valley village forty miles from Times Square.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sunday, Feb. 6 -- United States and Nationalist Chinese fleets put to sea today to evacuate the Tachen Islands. The action is on orders from President Eisenhower and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

DURING each session of Congress dozens of bills suggesting subjects for new stamps are introduced. Although many of these fall by the wayside and are not adopted by Congress, the ideas contained in them may be revived repeatedly and reintroduced at subsequent sessions in new legislation.

WASHINGTON -- This spring visitors to the national capital will again be able to enjoy a view that has been denied to sightseers for the past fifteen years: the spectacular view down the Federal Mall from the Capitol terraces.

BEFORE the month is out, Dior, Balmain, Balenciaga and the other great names of Paris haute couture will have shown their 1955 spring and summer Paris collections which promise, at the very least, provocative change in women's fashions and, at the most, revolution.
SCARBOROUGH, Tobago, Feb. 5 -- Princess Margaret continued her goodwill conquest of the West Indies today with a series of festivities here.

FIFTY years ago, when the Fauves liberated color from its subservience to form, they set off a chain explosion of liberation movements that has not apparently yet reached its end. Step by step color has learned to lead a life of its own and the drama of this progress is strikingly illustrated in four current exhibitions.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5 -- Chet Forte, Columbia University's sophomore guard sensation, scored 33 points tonight to lead the Lions to a 76-71 Ivy Basketball League victory over Harvard University.

Senator John W. Bricker criticized yesterday "some present day scientists" who talk publicly about political matters that are outside their fields of "special competence." He declined, however, to identify the scientists.

RALEIGH, N. C. -- Motorists heading south this winter will encounter something new in highway safety signs as they drive through North Carolina on U. S. 1. In a campaign to kid the motorist into better road manners, the State Highway Commission has posted blue-and-white signs -- in the tradition of the Burma Shave advertisements -- at two-mile intervals along the 182-mile stretch of road
One day last fall a team of Army officers stationed in New York went to Fairfield, Conn., to break the news that a certain plot of land in town had been picked for Nike installation.

THE American motion picture business has pulled another last-reel surprise. Instead of curling up and dying, as it appeared destined to do under the phenomenal onrush of television, which has markedly affected American life since World War II, it has made an amazing recovery of popularity within the last year. And, as 1955 progresses, even a new "golden age" appears in view.

FOR almost three decades esthetes of the novel have hugged the stark Flaubertian dogma that the writer must not voice opinions about his characters and story. All judgment and interpretation he must dissolve into the dramatic presentation, nor dare, as novelist, to say "I think" or philosophize in person.

CHICAGO -- The National Automobile Dealers Association, with more than 30,000 members representing every state, takes a very dim view of General Motors Corporation's attempt to curb passenger-car bootlegging by offering to take back from dealers their unsold cars or to have such cars transferred to territories where they will sell more readily.

THE Vienna Opera will open its rebuilt opera house next November with an enormous splash. Within the first four weeks it will present no fewer than seven new productions. To have that many ready within so short a span, intensive work will begin in May, for by then the stage will be usable for reheasals.

We regret and deplore the Cabinet crisis in France and the temporary eclipse of Premier Mendes-France. In the seven and a half months that he has held office he has given his country the sort of vigorous and imaginative leadership that our French friends need.

Ever since the war, France has been struggling to achieve strong and stable Government. Success has not been conspicuous. The average life-span of Governments in the Fourth Republic is just over six months. But when Pierre Mendes-France came to power last June, it appeared that his dynamic policy might command enough popular support to assure a long stay in office.

French and Venetian furniture, a Gobelins tapestry series, paintings and other works of art and decorations will be auctioned on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The material is from the estate of the late Elizabeth Stuyvesant Brown of New York and others.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- A Royal Navy helicopter bucked gale-force winds today to carry a towline from a rescue tug to a British warship with fifty-two men aboard drifting helplessly near jagged reefs off England's southwest coast.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Seventh Fleet has been ordered to help the Chinese Nationalists evacuate the Tachen Islands.

Tenants remaining in tenements on the site of the proposed Godfrey Nurse Houses in Harlem have complained to the courts. They say that the landlord evidently is trying to hurry their evacuation by making living conditions uncomfortable.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Refusal of the Communist Chinese regime to appear at the United Nations did not surprise French Far Eastern experts who had expected admittance of Peiping to the United Nations would be necessary for even a tacitly accepted cease-fire in the Formosa region.

G.," as his nation calls him, believes that in order to survive Israel must open up the Negev wilderness, which is more than half the country, and also "have a pioneering, adventurous youth who will develop the land."
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 5 -- A Presidential system of government like that of the United States has been approved for adoption by the Pakistani Cabinet.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- Yale's swimming team registered its 120th straight dual meet victory by beating Cornell, 52 -- 32, in the Teagle Hall pool.
BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecast and list of ski conditions for New England:

MONTREAL, Feb. 5 -- The Montreal Canadiens nipped the New York Rangers, 3 -- 1, for their fifth straight National Hockey League victory against the Blue Shirts at the Forum tonight before a crowd of 14,404.

"ONE of the greatest-pleasures of poetry is the discovery that a poem which you have always known means far more than you could realize when you first met it and liked it," says Janet Adam Smith in her preface.
HARTFORD, Feb. 5 -- For the first time in Connecticut history, a woman is expected to be nominated to a high court post.

After twelve months of soaring coffee prices, the market has fallen back to the level of a year ago. However, prices remain about 10 cents a pound above the level of August, 1953.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 5 -- The fall of Premier Pierre Mendes-France came as a blow to the West German Government. The overriding concern of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his associates was the effect of the political crisis on France's ratification of the Paris agreements to arm the West Germans.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -The Izaak Walton League has offered a plan for eventual elimination of farm price supports.

INDUSTRY is holding its own despite international developments that might ordinarily upset a steady upward trend. While there is concern about possible future events which could throw the country into armed conflict, there is no sign of panic in the market place.

Willem de Vries, director-general of navigation for the Netherlands Government, arrived here last week to attend United Nations transportation meetings. The sessions will be held this week.

Superficially this is Constance's own account of her shut-in Parisian life. Impetuous and inquisitive, she conceives the idea of a reunion of her dead, heroic brother's school friends in order to form the M. A. S. (Mutual Aid Society).

THE counter - revolution against television has begun. Two local farmers took the bull by the antenna recently and threw their television sets out of the house. ALTHOUGH it may not be widely conceded, the rewrite desk on a morning newspaper is Utopia. Art critics may have quieter offices, but one doesn't get into the racket for quiet anyway. Guns and machine tools, not butter and television sets, are once again the unchallenged primary objectives of Soviet production.
