Zionist leaders called yesterday for strengthening their movement to help Israel "in this critical period" and to build up Jewish cultural life outside Israel.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 5--Investments in copper mines representing hundreds of millions of dollars in American money received a reprieve this week-end when the Chilean Congress passed a new copper law.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Monday, Feb. 7 (AP)--Following is the text of the statement issued by the Chinese Nationalist Government: In order to meet the new challenge of international Comunist aggression, the Government of the Republic of China has decided to redeploy the forces defending certain offshore islands and to strengthen the defense of other important islands such as Quemoy, Matsu, etc., with the forces now in the Tachen area.
All Patrolman Joseph J. Bravchok of Traffic A wanted was a well-lighted place to take notes on a minor two-car collision. He chose the Western Union office at 18 Delancey Street.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 6 --Last week the main provisions of the law drafted by the German Economies Ministry to liquidate the former Reichsbank and Gold Discount Bank became known in Switzerland. They caused bitter disappointment.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 6 --The Administration of President Jose Figueres apparently has been victorious in the struggle against internal and external enemies, for the time being at least.

ALBANY, Feb. 6--The Public Service Commission has been asked to reconsider its order on speed recording devices. That order would require the installation of the devices on all buses with runs of thirty-five miles or more.
TOKYO, Feb. 6--The United States Sabrejets that shot down two Soviet-built jet fighters yesterday were attacked by the Communist planes about ten miles off the coast of North Korea.

IT may astonish townsfolk to learn that the flying-saucer spasm hasn't completely, ended. Right, now, for example, you can dial FIlmore 8-6507 if you spot a saucer, or if that's not convenient you can send your report by regular or air mail to James and Margaret Rigberg at their book shop, 1597 Third Avenue.
ALBANY, Feb. 8--The Republican State Chairman called today for the renomination of President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon next year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Defense Department officials said tonight they assumed the evacuation of the Tacher. Islands was under way.

A half interest in the Guide Realty Company, which was formed fifty years ago, has been sold by the Arlington C. Hall Estate to a client of John P. McGrath through John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker. The assets of Guide Realty consist of properties on the West Side and upper part of Manhattan and the Bronx.

WALTER HENDL, who became in 1945 assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic -Symphony Society and in 1949 musical director and conductor of the Dallas Symphony, returned as guest leader of the Philharmonic Symphony Saturday night in Carnegie Hall.

ABOARD THE U. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Feb. 5--The Navy called today for volunteers for next year's Antarctic expedition. Hardly had the message from Washington been received when five men aboard the icebreaker lined up to apply.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 6-- Erich Ollenhauer, Socialist leader, cited today the fall of the French Government of Premier Pierre Mendes-France as an imperative reason for delaying ratification of the agreements to arm West Germany.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Reserve Officers Association called today for a "crash" program of training military reserves.

IT was the insult supreme. The Canadians could not have been more outraged if the Russians had dragged the Maple Leaf flag through the mud and then disdainfully trampled on it with hobnailed boots. For the better part of a year our brothers to the north have been carrying their shame with bitter resentment and growing anger. And they don't intend to be disgraced again.

In the Formosa Strait the United States Seventh Fleet has now gone into action. It is not covering an invasion of the mainland of China. It is not attacking the Chinese Communists. It is undertaking to protect a peaceful withdrawal--as we hope it will be--of a Chinese Nationalist garrison from the Tachen island group, together with as many civilians as wish to seek refuge on Formosa.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 6--The Dutch Government has decided to ask Parliament for authorization to sign the 1953 London German debt agreement.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6--Moscow, like Washington, London and Paris, is in the midst of a legislative session. But here in the Kremlin legislators act somewhat differently from those on Capitol Hill, in Westminster and at the Palais Bourbon.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Feb. 6--Chiharu Igaya, Dartmouth sophomore, made a second run of 1 minute 10 seconds and had a combined time of 2:25 to win the sixteenth annual Gibson Memorial Trophy race at Cranmore Mountain today. Thirty-one competed in the event.

Four hundred persons, including prominent city officials and members of the judiciary, attended yesterday a funeral service for former State Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller in the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East Eighty-seventh Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb 6 --Dr. Victor A. Belaunde of Peru, president of the Security Council, said today that he intended to discuss with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold the question of a meeting of the Council this week.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Feb. 8-- Yugoslavia has abandoned collectivization of agriculture. This was revealed today by Vladimir Bakaric, one of the country's top Communist leaders and president of the Croatian Parliament.

ABOARD U. S. S. ESTES, in Formosan Waters, Monday, Feb. 7--A United States armada of seventy-five ships, "prepared for any eventuality," converged on the Tachen Islands today to help evacuate Chinese Nationalist troops and civilians.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--An investigating commission of the Organization of American States spent four hours tonight studying reports on the latest fighting in Costa Rica.
The fifteenth week of opera at the Metropolitan will open next Monday with the season's final performance of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci."
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 6(AP)-- Gene Littler shot a one-over-par 71 to win the $15,000 Phoenix Open golf tournament today with a 72-hole score of 275. He collected $2,400 for his victory.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Feb. 6-- The fall series Frostbite sailboat series at the Riverside Yacht Club was won by Bob McCullough's Scotch Cooler. The series, scheduled to consist of ten regattas, was ended following eight programs.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh proposed yesterday that a city agency be empowered to chop the debt structure of rundown tenements and turn the properties over to "real" owners instead of "slumlords."

Maine winters certainly must be cold. An indoor hockey rink is being planned for the Kents Hill school but there is no provision for making artificial ice. It's quite a switch in this era of machine -made skating surfaces.
HARTFORD, Feb. 6--Connecticut's Superior Court judges have adopted new court procedure rules.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was interested in reading the article by Arthur Krock on the plan proposed by one of my successors in Justice to "Put the Chief Justice Before Congress." I note that John W. Davis favors the plan, which ordinarily would give me pause, but I am constrained to offer a mild dissent.

WHEN the Concert Society of New York presents a singer, it is generally only to offer a song cycle as the middle work in a chamber music program. But late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall the society paid William Warfield the same compliment it has paid Elizabeth Schwartzkopf.
ALBANY, Feb. 6--Governor Harriman has notified Republicans that Democrats are taking over control of the State Equalization Board.

PARIS, Feb. 6--The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany ordered today a protest to the West German Chancellor, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, on the way the German indemnity program is being conducted.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 7--The participation of the United States Navy in the Nationalist evacuation of the Tachen Islands may start "a major war," the Chinese Communist radio warned today.
Five of six representative high school students in a panel said yesterday that the United Nations should persist in trying to induce Communist China to sit at the conference table.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--President Eisenhower is expected to send an education message to Congress this week.
A post-graduate co-ed at New York University was murdered early yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 6--The American Federation of Labor decided today to focus all its political strength on a short-cut approach to nullification of state "right-to-work" laws.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The United States will urge the United Nations to send an observation mission to Formosa and the Pescadores to report on any aggressive action in that region.
A steady rain fell over New York yesterday, bringing with it the wamest weather in more than a month, but also washouts, flooding and fog. The Weather Bureau warned of sharply colder weather ahead.

James A. Michener, the writer, announced yesterday the incorporation of the Fund for Asia, of which he is president. The fund was described as a nonprofit public interest organization expressing the concern of the American people for their Asian friends.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 6 -- Patrick M. Malin of New York said here today that in great moments of insecurity the United States has "been able to draw on the basic quality of our country, which is space and freedom."

WAITSFIELD, Vt., Feb. 6-- The German Ski Club took the team championship today at the annual New York City interclub races at Mad River Glen. But the individual honors went to Ned Collins of the Amateur S. C.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP)--Wiffi Smith and Joyce Ziske, weathering a strong rally by their opponents, won the women's international four - ball golf championship today. They defeated the same girls who beat them for the title a year ago.

The announcement each year about this time that the real estate assessment rolls are completed and open for the taxpayer's inspection prompts a varied response, of course, depending on the point of view. But in New York the occasion emphasizes anew how large and valuable a city this is, physically -- worth $21,193,785,567, plus $7,594,575,464 in tax-exempt property--and secondly that we are a booming city.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6--A tall, courtly Chicago business man who has served two terms as Mayor has become the key issue in a municipal primary election campaign.

Two four-story apartment houses with a frontage of fifty feet at 28-47 and 28-49 Thirty- fourth Street, in Astoria, Queens, have been sold by Paul Herzich to a syndicate of investors headed by Sidney Gross. Assessed at $90,000, the property contains forty apartments and was sold in a deal negotiated by George Brezel, vice president of Sydney M. Siegel Co., brokers.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 6-- A red carry-all drawn by two black ponies today brought the Rev. Dr. Daniel Bliss and forty costumed parishioners to the Second Congregational Church.
A bomb scare, fist fights and general disorders developed yesterday afternoon at a mass meeting here.
The Bible "should be our book to live by and to die by" because it "presents to us Him who was with God in the beginning," the Rev. Francis X. Duffy said yesterday.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $78,637,076,506. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 6--The Southern Regional Conference of the American Zionist Council denounced today the execution of two Egyptian Jews by the Government of Egypt. Copies of a resolution were sent to the Egyptian Ambassador in Washington and Secretary of State Dulles.
Inefficient and costly surface operation is steadily dragging the Transit Authority deeper into the red.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 6--American Protestantism--in the minds of its youth--still is emphasizing the "old-time religion" while neglecting or playing down modern techniques. Such techniques were described as marriage counseling and vocational guidance.

Feb. 23 has been reserved temporarily for the premiere of "The Dark Is Light Enough" at the ANTA Theatre. Previously scheduled for Wednesday night, the opening had to be called off because of the illness of Tyrone Power, who is co-starred with Katharine Cornell in the Christopher Fry drama.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 6--Officials of the Bear Mountain Sports Association ran into trouble in staging the Telemark Ski Club's annual jump today --the last major event of the season here. Rising temperature which brought rain and poor visibility caused the difficulty.
ALBANY, Feb. 3--It was said during the last war that it took three workers at home to keep one man at the front.

Week Ended Feb. 4, 1955 Softness of the British pound and a steady Undertone in the Canadian dollar represented the only changes of significance last week. In neither case, however, was the trend accompanied by any substantial turnover--on the contrary, turnover was light.

Symphony concerts for children need not be accompanied by "cute entertainment gimmicks" to keep the youngsters amused and occupied. That is the opinion of Dr. Herbert Zipper, director of the Community Music Center of the North Shore in Chicago and conductor of the Manila Symphony Orchestra in the Philippines.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 6--Pakistan is more a geographical expression than a nation. The idea of a separate Moslem state in India was invented by a poet. It received political backing from the independence movement only in 1940--seven years before the British pulled out.

An American edition of "Conquest by Man," by Paul Herrmann, German scholar and editor, will be published Feb. 28 by Harper. It tells how man, "driven by curiosity, greed, accident and ingenuity," has explored and discovered the lands and seas of the world.
People must put more emphasis on religion than on ethics if they want to "do the right," Dean James A. Pike said yesterday.
Living on a daily food budget of $1 for each person is one of the challenges offered student residents in the new Home Living Center at the University of Utah.
The delicacy department of B. Altman's this week doffs its hat to St. Valentine.

Despite the fact that the year 1954 bore the brunt of the transition of the economy from the shooting war in Korea to a cold war, figures of the Department of Commerce show that personal income of the nation as a whole set a record. At $286,500,000,000 it topped the previous high, set a year earlier, by $400,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- American Airlines renewed today charges of secret deals and monopolist efforts by Eastern Air Lines, Inc.

Shrill adolescent voices counting cadence played hob with Sunday quiet on Fifth Avenue yesterday as 4,000 Roman Catholic Boy Scouts marched to St. Patrick's Cathedral for the opening of Boy Scout Week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--There is a chance that the Aug. 13 date set by the Democrats for opening their 1956 convention may have to be moved forward.
MIAMI, Feb. 6--For Donald Thomas Brumfield, these are happy, busy, bankroll-fattening days at Hialeah Race Course.

WHEN Puccini's "Tosca" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night, there were four singers in the cast who had not been in the two earlier productions this season. Three sang their parts for the first tune at the Metropolitan.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Monday, Feb. 7--A Nationalist Defense Ministry source said today the evacuation of the Tachen Islands began last night. There were no reports of Communist interference.

PARIS, Feb. 5--The National Assembly's withdrawal of its confidence in Premier Pierre Mendes- France presumably will detract nothing from the doubts about France reported in the United States. The doubts were aroused chiefly by two events of M. Mendes-France Administration: The partition of Indochina and the rejection of the European union ideal as represented by the European Defense Community.

TAIPEI, Monday, Feb. 7--An official United States source here said today plans had been made for carrier-based Seventh Fleet aircraft to fly cover over a 230-mile lane from the Tachens to Keelung, Formosa, during the evacuation of Nationalist Chinese troops and civilians.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The men responsible for continental defense are embroiled with two distinct Battles of North America.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 6--A vast project to help solve California's critical water shortage was proposed here yesterday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 6-- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem appealed today to the French to aid in the economic improvement of South Vietnam.

Perhaps, as Coach Bob Giegengack of Yale maintains, the mile isn't the only thing that counts in a track meet. However, there's no question of what will live longest in the memories of the 14,736 spectators who jammed Madison Square Garden for last Saturday's Millrose Games. They'll be talking about the 1955 Wanamaker Mile for years to come.
LONDON, Feb. 6--The Commonwealth Prime Ministers are to renew their efforts to find a peaceful solution of the Formosa dispute at their final conference session tomorrow.
PARIS, Feb. 6--Antoine Pinay agreed tonight to make the first attempt to form a Cabinet to succeed that of Pierre Mendes- France.
VIENNA, Feb. 6--The United States charged today that a Soviet consul had attempted to entrap two Americans.

Maurice Richard, the famed Rocket of the Canadians of Montreal, made up for lost time at Madison Square Garden last night. In his four previous appearances in New York this season, Richard was held scoreless by the Broadway Blues.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--A House of Representatives subcommittee on military operations has recommended that the Defense Department "vigorously" seek amendments to French- United States military agreements.
Freeman F. Gosden and Charles J. Correll, the creators and original portrayers of the "Amos 'n' Andy" characters, are proving to be as adventuresome as The Kingfish.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Approximately 100 Republican orators will take the stump this week at a series of Lincoln Birthday anniversary dinners.

Almost from the day that Peter Minuit bought Manhattan from the Indians, there have been attempts to avert fires by safety legislation. The problem has grown with the city. It lies dormant for long stretches at a time. Then, suddenly, it erupts to plague the public conscience.

"Grand Inquest: The Story of Congressional Investigations," by Telford Taylor, will be issued Feb. 28 by Simon Schuster. It is an account of how Congressional investigations came about; why they are a "vital" part of our government; how they are abused and what can be done about it.

Three airlines submitted briefs to the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington yesterday, each contending it was the logical candidate to operate non-stop passenger service between New York and Mexico City.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP)--Hogs made a modest recovery from their two year lows today, butchers selling strongs to 25 cents higher in a fairly active trade Sows gained 20 to 50 cents. Salable receipts at 11.00 head were the smallest for a Monday this year. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

San Francisco yesterday wrested the No. 1 rating from Kentucky in The United Press college basketball poll. The West Coast Dons, possessors of a fourteen-game winning streak, were the first-place choice of twenty-seven of the thirty-five leading coaches on the United Press rating board.

Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, has sold the property at 361-63 West Forty-second Street and 352-60 West Forty-third Street to the Danrye Corporation. Joseph L. Lefkowitz was the broker and E. Louis Gothelf was attorney for the seller.
Peter Campbell Brown, Investigation Commissioner, is to be the city's new Corporation Counsel.

THE first of a projected series of annual exhibitions by the National Society of Painters in Casein has opened at the Riverside Museum, Riverside Drive at 103d Street. After several small shows restricted to work by members, this event was opened to nonmember as well, and includes eighty-eight entries by as many artists.

LONDON, Feb. 7--Exchanges between Britain and the Soviet Union over the last week have indicated deep concern in Moscow over the results of the intransigence and belligerence of the Chinese Communists. This concern is accepted as sincere in some authoritative quarters.

From the outside the house looked fine. It stood on a Lower West Side street in the part of Manhattan known as Chelsea. It was built as a two-family dwelling some thirty years ago. It was the kind of a house to make a district proud.

WILMINGTON, N. C., Feb. 7-- E. Yates Webb, a retired Federal jurist and an active prohibitionist for more than half a century, died of a heart attack in the Cape Fear Hotel here this morning. He was 82 years old. A resident of Shelby, he had been vacationing along the Carolina coast.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- The Senate Labor Committee unanimously approved today a bill to let 1,4000,000 members of the armed forces continue accumulating educational benefits.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Mayor Wagner asked the Legislature tonight to let New York City regulate its own drive against unsafe tenements.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 7, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Nominated Julius C. Holmes to be Ambassador to Iran. Met with Secretary of State Dulles on the Formosan crises. Received Manuel A. de Moya, retiring Ambassador of the Dominican Republic.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 7--Westchester County was notified today that Governor Harriman's curb on capital construction would not affect financing for the $40,000,000 Cross-Westcheater Expressway.

Only ninety-one pints of blood were obtained by the regional Red Cross blood program on Friday. Saturday's total was 156. The latter included ninety-one pints contributed by members of St. Theresa Council, Knights of Columbus, at St. Clare's Roman Catholic Church, 138th Avenue and Brookville Boulevard, Rosedale, Queens, and sixty-five given by members of the Brooklyn Catholic War Veterans at St. Vincent Ferrer's Church, Glenwood Road and East Thirty-seventh Street, Brooklyn.
Late selling in aircraft stocks demolished a promising rally on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and left the market with only moderate gains.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ambassador Sevilla of Nicaragua in his letter published in your editorial page on Jan. 26 accuses both the Government of Costa Rica and The New York Times of presenting inaccurate information on Costa Rica's charges that Nicaragua has committed an aggression.
Chamber Music Business Tonight at 8 o'clock, up on West Sixty-seventh Street, the Committee for Organization of the Amateur Chamber Music Players holds one of its infrequent meetings.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 8-- Chinese Communist aircraft attempted unsuccessfully to give battle to United States planes flying over Communist-held offshore islands yesterday, the Peiping radio reported today.
President Eisenhower and the Shah of Iran joined last night in applauding the self-help programs carried on for twenty-five years by the Near East Foundation.
ALBANY, Feb. 7--The Harriman administration favors a rise in the farm price of milk. That would mean an extra cent or cent and a half a quart for New York City consumers.
The first American Productions playwriting grant, to be given annually to the most "promising young playwright," has been awarded to Harry Ridgefield. The grant carries a cash prize of $1,000.

THE tranquil realism of Fairfield Porter's landscapes and portraits at the de Nagy Gallery, 206 East Fifty-third Street, is a style that records not only the surface things that any sensitive eye can see, but also the more profound things that have to do with the structure and internal life of a picture.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Secretary of State John Foster Dulles expressed confidence today that an Asian war could be averted so long as the United States stood firm in its support of Nationalist China.

More than four years ago a subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee reported favorably on the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide--the U. N. treaty popularly known as the genocide convention.

Dividends on common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange aggregated $6,438,821,220 last year, according to The Exchange, magazine published by that institution. This was a gain of 8.8 per cent over the 1953 figure of $5,918,290,020.
The 26,000-ton liner Homeric steamed gracefully into New York yesterday on her maiden North Atlantic run as flagship of the Some Lines.
Holders of General Motors common may subscribe at $75 a share for the 4,380,683 shares the company is issuing to help finance its expansion program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Congress was advised today that prices offered by the Government for atomic materials provided no incentive to private industry to construct commercial atomic-power plants.
A broadened teaching and research program at Columbia University to meet "changing needs and new developments in the public health field" was announced yesterday.
SAN JUAN, Feb. 7 (UP)--Willie Mays smashed two singles and scored twice in a 6-2 victory over Caguas tonight that gave Santurce the championship of the Puerto Rican League.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7-- The University of Notre Dame will be the subject of a motion picture to be produced by Columbia. Negotiations for clearance on the story, which the studio will develop, have been in progress for several weeks.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Governor Harriman jettisoned today a proposal to have the Democrats take over control of the State Board of Equalization.
TACHEN ISLANDS, Tuesday, Feb. 8--The first Chinese Nationalist evacuation convoy arrived at Lower Tachen Island early today.

ELGIN, Ill., Feb. 7 (AP)--Elgin National Watch Company announced today the purchase of American Microphone Company, Pasadena, Calif., manufacturer of microphones, phonograph parts and other communications equipment. No price was given.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Elsenhower reversed himself today to restore competition an the airline route between the Pacific northwest and Honolulu.
The Investors Funding Corporation of New York, realty brokerage and investment concern, has sold two of its apartment house properties in the Bronx.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Feb. 7--Last fall's hurricanes weren't without benefit, at least to a Long Island carpenter whose hobby is making black walnut furniture. For the high winds blew down a prize black walnut tree at Commack that Robert (Tip) Seerveld had had his eye on for some time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Everything happening in this troubled world continues to derive in part from an act or policy or personal trait of an American President who died ten years ago. And the domestic and international conditions to which he so importantly contributed still powerfully shape the daily lives and ultimate destinies of hundreds of millions who lived in his time and hundreds more who came afterward.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7-- The Soviet Union is reported here to have proposed a conference on the Far East outside the United Nations and excluding Nationalist China.
LONDON, Feb. 7--The Far Eastern situation again had a dampening effect on stock market business today and most of the leading industrial equities declined.
FORT DIXON, Malaya, Feb. 4 --As night falls in this jungle in which a war is being fought a strange chanting and hollow booming sound can be heard.

The giant automotive and home appliance industries face stiff competition in 1955 from a comparative newcomer. That warning was issued yesterday by Howard P. Larson, sales director of Evinrude Motors, one of the largest producers of outboard motors.
The court system of New York State and City "is archaic; its procedures snail-like and confusing; its administrative personnel complacent."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)-- The United States Supreme Court decided today that Indiana may not levy a 1 per cent tax on gross profits made on stock bought on margin. The tribunal had held previously the tax could not be applied to profits on stocks purchased outright.
The Fund for the Republic, Inc., an, organization that seeks to promote civil liberties and racial and religious tolerance, is planning to engage in television activities.
LONDON, Feb. 7--The withdrawal of Chinese Nationalist forces from Quemoy and Matsu is being urged here as the next step toward establishment of a situation of safety in the Far East.

VICENTE ESCUDERO, the old master of the flamenco dance, returned to New York after an absence of twenty years to open a two-week season at the Playhouse last night. It goes without saying that we have every reason to congratulate ourselves, for he is one of the almost fabulous dance figures of our time.

Unusually heavy penalties were imposed yesterday in Municipal Term Court, Brooklyn, on six tenants of multiple dwellings who had stored more than ten gallons of kerosene. This is a violation of the Administrative Code.

Eight drivers under suspension since Nov. 10 were reinstated yesterday by George P. Monaghan, the New York State harness racing commissioner. At the same time Monaghan continued in full force the one-year suspension he had imposed on Edward T. Dougherty, president of the Standardbred Owners Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Following is the text of the Formosa treaty statement that Secretary of State Dulles gave to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today:
ALBANY, Feb. 7--Governor Harriman called today for state scholarships for the training of nurses.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 7-- Stockholders of Textron, Inc., voted approval today of the proposed three-way merger of Textron with American Woolen Company and Robbins Mills, Inc.
ALBANY, Feb. 7--Roosevelt Raceway proposed today that the Legislature give back to the harness tracks an extra share of the state's pari-mutuel revenue.

MIAMI, Feb. 7 (Ap) -- Taylorcrest Stable's Some Question may have earned himself a starting berth in the $100,000 Flamingo on Feb. 26. The colt a 7-2 shot, today toyed with eleven other 3-year-olds in taking the $4,500 Riviera purse before 20,777 at Hialeah Park.
ALBANY, Feb. 7--Republican opposition to increasing the gasoline tax reached formidable proportions in the Legislature today.

Rubbish in and around buildings is part of the dismal picture of New York City dirt -- especially in the poorer sections of town. The menace to health in scattered or heaped-up garbage is obvious enough. Owners and occupants of buildings violate Health Department rules when they allow it to collect.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The National Press Club's board of governor's tonight approved the final election of its first Negro member.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Tuesday, Feb. 8--The Chinese Communists are standing back a respectful distance as the United States Seventh Fleet proceeds with the evacuation of the Tachen Islands.

Vietnam's Premier, Ngo Dinh Diem, has made an appeal to France to use technicians and capital to work out a new economic relationship and to promote the economic and social reforms that have been projected. This is designed, in part, to reassure French interests that have been apprehensive over losing some advantages as the newly independent state of Vietnam emerges.
The home cook who likes to fold her hands and let some one else do the work on occasion will applaud Pillsbury's newest product, quick cinnamon rolls.
PARIS, Feb. 7--Mme. Gres lifts the bosom line to a new high, the highest that Paris has yet seen.

THOSE who are not firmly committed to a Southern fishing trip, and have a fondness for caviar, might find it interesting to turn to Lake Winnebago, where they will have an exceptional opportunity to spear sturgeon through the ice.
Tugboat employers were told yesterday by their employes to come up with a "satisfactory" counter-offer by tomorrow at midnight or face a strike fortyeight hours later.

Work on this year's school construction, program will proceed speedily. Mayor Wagner declared yesterday. The program encompasses thirty-four school projects. Including eight largescale modernization jobs.

Two college basketball games of major interest will be played here tonight. Columbia's contest with Pennsylvania on the Morningside Heights floor will have a direct bearing on first place in the Ivy League. Fordham and St. John's, meeting in the Rams' gymnasium, will be seeking to improve their standing in the metropolitan race.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Thirteen New York teachers lost today an appeal to the Supreme Court over dismissal from their jobs. They had refused to answer questions of a Senate subcommittee about membership in the Communist party.
Rocking chairs should be standard equipment in hospitals to help nurses comfort very young patients who may be experiencing their first separation from home.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 7-- Anti-Communist Vietnamese nationalists here were relieved by the fall of the Government of Pierre Mendes-France.

William H. Weintraub Co. is setting up what it calls a women's field corps of typical American consumers, to operate on a permanent basis in various areas of the nation. It is all part of the agency's expanded research and merchandising program, which follows a number of major changes in personnel and direction.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP)--Britain's top bookmakers today slated 9-- year-old Quare Times as favorite to win the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree March 26.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 7--Elmer B. Boyd, president of The Home News Publishing Company, died today at his home, 114 New Street. He was publisher of The Daily Home News and The Sunday Times. Death apparently came from a heart attack early this morning.

CAIRO, Feb. 7--An Egyptian Minister ridiculed today the timidity and indecision of the leaders of the other Arab states in defining their attitude toward the proposed treaty between Iraq and non-Arab Turkey.
A married man who had dated Miss Ann Yarrow, 23-year-old graduate student at New York University who was murdered early Sunday, was questioned by the police for eight hours yesterday.
A promise of more "flexible" enforcement of the Federal laws against price discrimination was held out yesterday by Edward F. Howrey, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.
ENID, Okla., Feb. 7--The Air Force's experimental abolition of "kitchen police" at the flight training base here seems to be working out well.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 7--Union leaders sought a compromise formula tonight to prevent labor unity negotiations from blowing up over the issue of inter-union raids.

Extension of the draft, an essential part of the national defense program, will be debated in the House today. It has been unanimously approved by the House Armed Services Committee, and should have no difficulty getting through Congress long before the Government's induction powers under present law expire on June 30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--If United States planes are attacked during the Tachens evacuation, they may engage in "hot pursuit" even if it takes them over the China mainland, a Defense Department spokesman said today. This is different from the rules observed in the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The Supreme Court passed up today a chance to rule on the President's power to negotiate international agreements. Such accords become binding without the approval of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Hightariff advocates were accused today of readiness to sacrifice Japan to the Communist orbit to escape competition with Japanese goods.
Chico Vejar, welterweight contender from Stamford, Conn., won a unanimous decision over Joey Klein of the East Side in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

HARTFORD, Feb. 7--A Connecticut law on absentee ballots appears to be restraining the Democratic National Committee from setting Aug. 13, 1956, as the starting date for the Democratic National Convention.

Despite a sales decline of $4,991,137, earnings of the G. C. Murphy Company last year held within 7 per cent of the 1953 earnings of the variety chain, according to the annual report yesterday of W. C. Shaw, board chairman, and J. S. Mack, president.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 2 to 12 points net lower than on Friday.

IN East Head, a pleasantly stodgy town on the Bristol Channel, nobody knew what to think of Conrad Swann's new statue called "Apollo." It was made of metal, had no recognizable shape, was the color of dried blood, and ugly spikes radiated in odd directions. But Swann had an international reputation.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 (AP)--The Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra is going to the United States for a tour of nineteen cities, beginning Feb. 27. The trip may show whether music-lovers there are willing to forget about the tainted past of some of its members.
AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Feb. 4-- This is an apprehensive, but determined city. Stunned by largescale unemployment, it is trying to regain industrial vitality.
BONN, Feb. 7--Two parties in the Government coalition urged Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today to postpone final ratification of the Paris agreements in view of the French political crisis.

The free world's supply of copper --the first metal to be used by man--is tighter today than at any time since the war-scare buying days at the beginning of the Korean war. That's why the Government has initiated steps to conserve the domestic industry's supply.
PARIS, Feb. 7--Austria was accused today of stalling on the enactment of legislation to compensate Jews for World War II hardships.

When the Senate voted 49--44 last August to substitute flexible farm price supports for the rigid 90 per cent supports obtaining in the nation's so-called "basic" farm commodities it marked the culmination of one of the most difficult and important struggles in the entire legislative program of the Eisenhower Administration.
VLADIMIR HAVSKY, a piianist who made his recital debut at Town Hall in 1949. returned to play a recital there last evening.

Hany Gallatin, who never has missed a game since he joined the New York Knickerbockers in 1948, will be honored tonight at Madison Square Garden. Between contests of the doubleheader, in which the Knicks will face the Minneapolis Lakers and the Boston Celtics oppose the Syracuse Nationals, Gallatin will receive a number of gifts.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. ESTES, Off the Tachens, Feb. 7-- United States Seventh Fleet units arrived off the Tachen Islands this morning to evacuate Chinese Nationalist civilians and troops. At dawn minesweepers began clearing a safe channel to the east of the islands and in the narrow stretch of water between Upper and Lower Tachen.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 7 --The Royal Caledonian Curling Club team or twenty touring Scottish curlers completed two days of competition against the metropolitan area's Grand National representatives at St. Andrew's Golf Club today.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7--Dr. W. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, said today that the university would not compromise its educational standards to accommodate increased enrollments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The Formosa controversy is still confused because the Governments of the United States and the Republic of China are working for different, and in some ways contradictory, objectives.

The mightiest American naval and air armada assembled since the height of the Korean war is now deployed within sight of the China coast in an operation that is both a demonstration of our own peaceful purposes and a test of Communist intentions.
BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP)--The Weather Bureau today issued the following weather forecast and list of ski conditions for New England.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 7--A topranking Protestant educator said here today that he took a "negative" view of the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale's "Power of Positive Thinking."
An experiment in increasing the safety of conventional twinengined transport planes by adding small jet-power plants is under way.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 7--Tuberculosis experts agreed today that the synthetic chemical compound isoniazid had come of age.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 7 (AP)-- The Kansas City Star began today its defense in the Government antitrust action against the newspaper and Emil A. Sees, its advertising director.
ALBANY, Feb. 7--George Loring Hubbell Jr. of Garden City, L. I., is to be nominated tomorrow by the Republicans of the Legislature for the term to 1966 on the State Board of Regents.

A quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable on March 21, has been authorized by directors of the Jewel Tea Company, Inc. Previously the company paid a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share.

Allergy symptoms in asthma and hay fever stem from inherited faults in the body's defenses against disease. This was the substance of a report given yesterday at the eleventh annual meeting of the American Academy of Allergy at the Statler Hotel.

William Clark, who has lost several skirmishes in a running battle with the State Department since his ouster in 1953 as Chief Justice of the United States High Commission's Court of Appeals in West Germany, received a rebuff from a different source last night.
Sixteen public housing authorities plan to borrow $131,031,000 next Tuesday by the sale of short-term notes.

A new plan that would provide a sixty-five-story office building at Grand Central Terminal but preserve the present station's concourse and front is under study. This makes the third proposal now pending before the New York Central System and the New Haven Railroad.

ALBANY, Feb. 7--The Senate confirmed tonight Governor Harriman's nomination of Miss Angela Parisi of Brooklyn, vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee, as chairman of the Workmen's Compensation Board.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Arkansas Supreme Court today held unconstitutional the "fair trade" or price-fixing law.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 7-- Gov. Munoz Marin pictured today a time when Puerto Rico would assume responsibilities and functions now in the hands of the Federal Government.
MOSCOW, Feb. 8 (AP)--Georgi Malenkov resigned today as premier of the Soviet Union, saying his "lack of experience" had held back Soviet economic development.

Coffee prices tumbled the daily limit of 2 cents a pound in almost all positions early yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The volume, 209,500 bags, was the heaviest since trading reopened after World War II in October, 1946.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 7--The American Federation of Labor called on West German unions today to drop their resistance to German rearmament.
Economic growth will provide a continuing and expanding need for trust services, Homer J. Livingston, president of the American Bankers Association, said yesterday.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 7 --Ray White, business agent of the Seafarers International Union, who is charged with plotting to kill Paul Hall, its secretarytreasurer, surrendered here this morning.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Benjamin Fine's excellent report of Jan. 24 on allegations that New York State's program for higher education is lagging prompts me to repeat a suggestion for the organization of higher education that I have made many times before.
Progress in the proposed Washington Square Southeast redevelopment project has been halted by a taxpayer's suit against the city.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 8 (AP)-- The United States Sabrejet pilots who shot down two MIG jets Saturday said yesterday the Communist planes had struck without warning over the sea off North Korea.

HAVANA, Feb. 7--Vice President Richard M. Nixon, today began talks with Government officials that the Cuban people hope will result in some help from the United States in Cuba's problems, particularly sugar.
CAIRO, Feb. 7--Representatives of four Arab states and the United States have reaffirmed agreement here on the principle of international control of the waters of the Jordan River.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 7--Tucked away behind towering gasoline storage tanks here, Alphonse DeLieto's stock farm has enjoyed comparative obscurity for the last eight years.

THE old-timers were in a tizzy yesterday as a result of the extraordinary finish of the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games on Saturday. They were enthralled and aghast at the combination wrestling match and mazurka dance that Messrs. Wes Santee and Fred Dwyer engaged in after Gunnar Nielsen of Denmark had streaked past them both in the homestretch.
DETROIT, Feb. 7 (UP)--Steve Gromek, who made one of baseball's best comebacks last year with the Detroit Tigers, signed his 1955 contract today for a sizable pay increase.
MOSCOW, Feb. 7--A decree changing the status of the chairman of the committees of State Security in the republics of the Soviet Union was ratified today by the Supreme Soviet.
Abdol Rassoul Kassae, sick with acute leukemia at Memorial Hospital, received a bedside visit yesterday from the Shah of Iran.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The Secretary of Defense urged Congress today to provide some $730,000,000 annually for additional pay and benefits to the armed forces.

Acquisition of the Bank of Gowanda, at Gowanda, N. Y., by the Marine Midland Corporation of Buffalo, N. Y., was announced yesterday by, Charles H. Diefendorf, president of Marine Midland, and Stanley A. Neilson, president of the Gowanda bank.
PARIS, Feb. 7--Antoine Pinay announced tonight that he intended to ask the National Assembly Friday to approve the Cabinet he is attempting to form.
The man everyone in Washington knew and no one knew much about--Henry W. Grunewald-- went on trial with three former tax officials and a lawyer in Federal Court here yesterday.

Net income of the Rheem Manufacturing Company increased last year to $6,027,000 from $4,982,000 in 1953 as a result of extraordinary income from the sale of certain company investments, it was reported yesterday. The 1954 net is equal to $3.67 a share on 1,541,648 shares and compares with $3.63 each on 1,249,308 shares the year before.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7--Substantial price recessions in grain and soybean futures today coincided with reports that the evacuation of the Tachen Islands had started with no interference by the Communists.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Highranking State Department, Treasury and Export-Import Bank officials are meeting Brazilian officials in Rio De Janeiro today to discuss Brazil's pressing economic problems.

The eagerly awaited Administration proposal on school construction has now been put forward by President Eisenhower. As was to be expected, its emphasis is on helping local communities help themselves; but it also cautiously recognizes the principle of direct federal aid to meet what is truly an emergency need.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP) set a women's course record in the qualifying round of the Palm Beach women's amateur golf tournament today.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 8-- An impressive offensive display carried Princeton University's basketball team to a 71-47 triumph over Cornell before 2,000 fans tonight.

The six-story apartment house at 814 Tenth Avenue, near Fiftyfourth Street, has been sold by the estate of Jonas Weil to George Goodman Co., real estate operators and investors. The building, on plot 42 by 100 feet, contains three stores and thirty-eight apartments.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 8--A 51year-old grandmother who has spent most of her adult life on a farm was named tonight the "Christian Lay Person of 1955."

Educational, research and historical restoration projects of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York will be aided by the proceeds of the seventyeighth annual dinner of the group. The fete, marking the 223d anniversary of George Washington's birth, will be held on his birthday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The seven New York newspapers registered a linage increase of 6.71 per cent in January over the comparative period of 1954. A study based on data supplied by Media Records, Inc., finds the seven papers piled up 12,453,775 lines in the latest month, against 11,670,127 a year before.
The change in the top leadership of the Soviet Government may result in Moscow's persuasion of Communist China to be "more cautious" in the Pacific, Alexander Kerensky said yesterday.
Apollo, the sun deity, is replacing Chronos, god of time, as the city's lamplighter in a test on Lexington Avenue.

KEELUNG, Formosa, Wednesday, Feb. 9--The first United States Navy ship with Chinese Nationalist civilians evacuated from the Tachen Islands docked here this morning. She was an 8,000-ton transport with 3,816 civilians on board.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP)--The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecast and list of ski conditions for New England: NEW HAMPSHIRE Cloudy and continued cold tomorrow, with a chance of a little light snow in the afternoon.

Twenty dancers who were formerly members of the Ballet Theatre and four choreographers will appear with that company for its fifteenth anniversary season, beginning April 12 at the Metropolitan Opera House.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP)-- Government officials told the Joint Congressional Economic Committee today that President Essenhower's foreign economic program was essential to the free world's security.

LONDON, Feb. 8--Uncertainty in the stock markets was heightened today by the Soviet Union's change of Premiers. Prices drifted lower after looking firmer at first, though at the close they were rising again in some directions.

HARRISON, N. Y., Feb. 8-- Mrs. Virginia S. Wagner of Old Greenwich, Conn., a Scarsdale school teacher, won acquittal in Police Court here today on a charge of driving past a stopped school bus. On trial, she had pleaded on advice of counsel that the vehicle had been poorly marked.

Improvements in existing designs rather than drastic innovations mark 1955 models of appliances and housewares, according to Mrs. Helen W. Kendall of Good Housekeeping magazine. She spoke before the monthly meeting of the Electrical Women's Round Table held at the Gramercy Park Hotel last night.
Harvey Matusow was ordered yesterday to testify about his self-admitted perjury at the trial of thirteen convicted Communist leaders.

The Belmont Stakes on June 11 will be the last of twenty-one stake races at Belmont Park's 1955 spring meeting. More than $500,000 will be distributed to horsemen as a result of those feature races, the dates of which were released yesterday.

Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin almost certainly is a compromise choice as Soviet Premier. He apparently represents a coalition of the party forces of Nikita S. Khrushchev and the army group headed by Marshal Georgi G. Zhukov.
The Daily Worker declares in an editorial in today's issue that the Soviet Union's policy of settling questions "at the conference table" will continue unchanged by the shift in command at Moscow.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8-- The Matson Navigation Company withdrew today an objection to a proposed competing service by the liner Laguardia of the Hawaiian Steamship Company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 8--The belief was expressed here today that Soviet issues before the United Nations would be complicated by the power shift in Moscow. Indications of a "tougher" internal and external policy were stressed.
VIENNA, Feb. 8--Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's resignation not only is expected to have farreaching consequences in the Soviet satellites, but has been foreshadowed by recent events there.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 8--Public gatherings in Johannesburg and the neighboring town of Roodepoort were banned today by the National Government.

A plan for the nation's first nuclear reactor entirely owned and operated by private industry was announced here yesterday by the American Machine and Foundry Company. It would use radiations for confidential experiments for cooperating companies.

Louis E. Wolfson made known yesterday that he owns 31,000 shares of Montgomery Ward Co. The Florida industrialist who is seeking to obtain control of the big mail order company at the annual stockholders meeting on April 22 also disclosed that, with a committee of thirteen others, he controls directly or indirectly 195,630 shares.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 8 (AP) --The New York State Society of Newspaper Editors declared today that the state law pertaining to the publishing of taxexempt lists was "being violated in a number of cities."
Hoyt Wilhelm, the knuckleball relief artist, yesterday became the world champion Giants' thirty-third contract signer. Ramon Monzant, a rookie righthanded pitcher, also signed yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8--In the wet slush of a fresh snow a group of sight-seers stood outside the Kremlin walls today. Tourists from the provinces, they were blighly unaware of the unexpected resignation of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and his replacement by Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin.

BERLIN, Feb. 8--East Germany announced today that 8,000 young persons were in Parliament and other governing bodies. Young, in this case, means roughly between the ages of 18 and 25. O mayor is 18 years old.
Two members of the New York City Youth Board emphasized yesterday the need for additional services in the Bronx to prevent teen-age crime.
LONDON, Feb. 8--The fall of Georgi M. Malenkov was interpreted in expert British circles today as indicating the end of the drive for co-existence with the West.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 8--The first day of "make or break" conferences on labor unity resulted in unexpectedly good headway today.
In the month, ending Jan. 31, shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose 1 per cent in value, from $53.36 to $53.91, the Exchange reported yesterday.

Tatiana du Plessix, designer of custom millinery for Saks Fifth Avenue, likes the very small or very large hat. In her collection shown yesterday at the SavoyPlaza Hotel, she has developed both types with charm and originality.
DOVER, Del., Feb. 8 (AP)-- Racial segregation in the public schools won an appeal in the State Supreme Court today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP)-- The Government's Commodity Credit Corporation has been authorized to swap surplus farm commodities with friendly countries for strategic materials.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The House of Representatives voted 394 to 4 today to continue the draft for four years.
THE GOVERNOR Vetoed Republican bill freezing state school aid on present basis. Spoke before Empire State Chamber of Commerce, Inc.
Developments in the international situation brought about a last-hour break on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The break wiped out all gains in the price average since Jan. 28.

IMMEDIATELY after the world series more than one disgruntled Cleveland fan tartly remarked, "Whazza matter with that guy? Why didn't he use Bobby Feller in the fourth game instead of a tired Bob Lemon?" Every fan, of course, is endowed with the constitutional right of making the second guess. Naturally enough, such hindsight is infallible.

MIAMI, Feb. 8--There's a 4year-old colt named Hangover. He was named for his dam, Cornlikker. Hangover is not a stakes horse. But when a sprint is run the way he likes to have it run, he sometimes looks like a reasonable facsimile of Citation.
Life-saving drugs are pouring out of the laboratories in bewildering numbers. The rapid obsolescence of old "new drugs" is driving manufacturers to seek more balanced operations.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP)--Following are excerpts from the foreign policy speech by Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov today as broadcast from Moscow: Ten years have passed since the ending of the second World War.

THE National Broadcasting Company did handsomely by television drama enthusiasts on Monday night--an hour-and-a-half revival of Clare Boothe Luce's "The Women," followed immediately by Robert Montgomery's appearance in an hour-long version of "The Lost Week-End."
The National Academy of Sciences has been asked by the White House to help formulate a loyalty policy relating to Federal grants for unclassified research.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- President Eisenhower urged tonight a continuing effort to "intensify the will for freedom in the satellite countries behind the Iron Curtain."

Wall Street seems to have decided that the more the Russians change, the more they stay the same. Yesterday, following the news of the fall of Premier Georgi Malenkov, there was little activity in the repudiated dollar bonds of Czarist Russia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress on education today: TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES: For the consideration of the Congress, I herewith propose a plan of Federal cooperation with the states, designed to give our school children as quickly as possible the classrooms they must have.
One hundred objects, each of which has earned museum approval not once but twice, make up an exhibition of home furnishings opening at the Museum of Modern Art today.

A dispatch from Albany reports that Republican opposition in the Legislature to increasing the gasoline tax has reached "formidable" proportions. Earlier a conference of Republican leaders had decided unanimously to take no position on the tax increase or other budget matters until after a public hearing on the budget Feb. 16.

BOSTON, Dec. 8--Louis E. Wolfson of Miami expressed confidence here today in bin ability to achieve control of Montgomery Ward Co. The 43-year-old financier is in Boston to acquaint investment dealers with his plans in connection with the mail order corporation.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 8--Leading bacteriologists and tuberculosis specialists have found that large masses of virulent tubercle bacilli manage to survive even the most modern anti-tuberculosis chemicals and antibiotics.

FRENCH and Italian landscape paintings by Julius Schulein at the Schoneman Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, are decidedly picturesque and reflect the artist's training, first in Munich and later in Paris.
Directors of Warner-Hudnut, Inc., and the Lambert Company yesterday proposed to merge, forming a drug concern with sales of $100,000,000 a year.
New evidence has been found to underscore the importance of the American merchant marine to the farms and industries of the Midwest.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The United States Government, concentrating on its plans for blocking Communist expansion, refused to comment today on the battle of the dictators in the Soviet Union.
Pennsylvania stood off Columbia's dangerous second-half bid and scored a 62-54 victory in an Ivy Basketball League game last night.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (Reuters)-- Following is the text of the communique issued tonight by the Commonwealth Prime Ministers it the end of their meetings: The Governments of the member nations of the Commonwealth are resolved to do their utmost to ease international strain.

Sidney O. Raphael, counsel for Edward T. Dougherty, the president of the Standardbred Owners Association who was suspended for a year by the New York State Harness Racing Commission, said yesterday he would file an appeal in the New York County Supreme Court.
St. John's basketball team rallied in the second half to beat Fordham, 64-56, last night at the Fordham gymnasium in the Bronx.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 8-- Frank C. Moore, chairman of the State Board of Equalization, called today for a strengthening of New York's town and county governments in the face of growing responsibilities.
Excellent seasonings distinguish six versions of tinned chicken casserole introduced this week at B. Altman, Gimbels, Abraham Straus in Brooklyn and in delicacy shops throughout the city.
Nikita S. Khrushchev appeared to have emerged yesterday as the most powerful single person in the Soviet Union, the heir to Stalin's mantle.

Momentous news arrived from Moscow yesterday, but not without previous warning that something of the sort was on the way. As readers of this newspaper know, evidence of a Soviet change of line and of shifts of power among Soviet leaders has mounted steadily these past few months.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 8--The church-state quarrel in Argentina was brought to public notice again today.
Charles H. Tenney, a long-time friend of Mayor Wagner, was named yesterday to be Commissioner of Investigation.

The Shah of Iran received the city's official greetings yesterday. He appeared first at a City Hall ceremony and later at a luncheon attended by city officials and high-ranking members of the armed services.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP)--Following are the texts of the announcement of Georgi M. Malenkov's resignation as Soviet Premier and of Nikita S. Khrushchev's speech proposing Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin as Mr. Malenkov's successor, as broadcast by the Moscow radio:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A $2,800,000,000 outlay for construction last month set a record high for January, the Government reported today.
ALBANY, Feb. 8--The Legislature today nominated George Loring Hubbell Jr., Garden City, L. I., attorney, and Edgar W. Couper of Binghamton as members of the State Board of Regents.

Directors of the Chase National Bank and the Bank of Manhattan Company are expected in the next few days to announce the date on which special meetings will be held for stockholders to vote on the proposed merger of the two institutions.

Following are close-ups of the three principals in the shake-up in the Soviet hierarchy: Marshal Nikolas A. Bulganin, the new Premier; Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Communist party's first secretary, and Georgi M. Malenkov, who resigned as Premier.
Contrasting appraisals of Henry W. Grunewald, Washington lobbyist, were given in Federal Court here yesterday in an income tax bribery case.
The City Council voted by 16 to 3 yesterday to urge the Legislature to continue and strengthen rent-control laws. The existing law will expire on June 30 unless it is extended.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 8 (AP)-- Willie Shoemaker returned from a 5-day suspension today and rode three Santa Anita winners, hut a 10-1 shot, Dawn Lark, took the feature under Leroy Nelson.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8--Sales and earnings of the United States Gypsum Company set record highs in 1954, the company disclosed in a preliminary report issued today.
MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 8-- The fourth annual women's bonspiel of the Westchester Wicks for the Hovey Trophy and Siebert Medal began at the St. Andrews Golf Club's curling arena today.

The New York Rangers will meet the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. In this, the sixth match here between the clubs this season, the Broadway Blues will be seeking their first 1954-55 Garden victory over the Hawks. The game will start at 8:30.
The Board of Water Supply declared yesterday that Hudson River water wag unfit for New Yorkers to drink.

Air-borne molds seem to play an important part in the development of asthm aand hay fever in the metropolitan area. This was reported here yesterday at the eleventh annual meeting of the American Academy of Allergy at the Statler Hotel.

Harry Gallatin was the standout on his "night" as he led the New York Knickerbockers to a 98-95 victory over the Minneapolis Lakers at Madison Square Garden last night. Before this game the Syracuse Nationals, adding to their Eastern Division lead in the National Basketball Association, defeated the undermanned Boston Celtics, 115--88.

President Dave Beck proposed at a recent Executive Board meeting that 20 per cent of the Teamsters' $38,000,000 treasury be invested in common stock, now prohibited by the union's constitution. This raises many questions far from easy to answer but urgently in need of full and frank discussion.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 8-- Mrs. Margo Mahony of Chappaqua, N. Y., second in the domestic seeding, moved a step ahead of the rest of the field as the women's Connecticut State squash racquets championships began at the Field Club of Greenwich today.

MAHWAH, N. J., Feb. 8--Voters in a school board election gave victory today to candidates advocating the reinstatement of former Superintendent of-Schools Roy S. Austin, who was ousted from his job last year.
Victor Mishcon, top official in London's municipal government, arrived here yesterday from Great Britain for a ten-day study tour of how this city administers its affairs.
ALBANY, Feb. 8--Republican legislators today proposed a super -lending agency to improve business and employment in the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--An old "scandal" charge against the Truman Administration was revived today.

ROME, Feb. 8--Georgi M. Malenkov's disappearance from the Soviet political leadership was regarded in official Italian circles as the most important world event since the death of Stalin. It was generally interpreted as heralding a return to the "tough" policy of Stalin's days.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8--On nomination by Nikita S. Khrushchev, first secretary of the Communist party, Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin became head of the Soviet Government today. He replaced Georgi M. Malenkov, who had been Premier since the death of Stalin March 5, 1953.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)-- The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives today voted a $10,000 a year pay rise for members of Congress and increases in the pay of Federal judges ranging from $7,500 and $10,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb 8--By a 2 to 1 vote, the Atomic Energy Commission has turned down a Democratic demand that the Dixon -Yates private power contract be canceled.
The ideal solution to the slumfire problem would seem to be new housing.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 8 --The Government confiscated 1,100,000 acres of cultivable land today. It had been granted by the British rulers to loyal subjects before Pakistan was separated from India.
Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company proposed yesterday a 4-for-1 split in the common stock and increased the dividend by 25 cents to $1 a share.

BARBARA CUSTANCE, Canadian pianist who made her debut here in 1943, gave her fifth New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her relatively brief program was made up chiefly of short works from the standard repertory, with Beethoven's Sonata in D minor, Op. 31, No. 2, being the major selection.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the defense treaty with Nationalist China on Formosa. The vote was 11 to 2.
LONDON, Feb. 8--A more united and more realistic approach to Far East problems was the most important result of the British Commonwealth conference, which ended today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8 (AP)--Tom Heinsohn, playing only three-quarters of the game, dropped in 27 points tonight as the Holy Cross basketball team defeated Yale, 80--56.

THE PRESIDENT Sent to Congress a message urging adoption of a three-year school program calling for $7,000,000,000 in Federal, state and local expenditures. THE SENATE Received Administration bill to carry out recommendations in President's school message.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP)--The report of the Department at Agriculture on today's livestock markets follows:
ALBANY, Feb. 8--Governor Harriman placed a gloomy interpretation today on events in the Soviet Union.

LORRIE GOULET is having her first show in six or seven years at the Sculpture Center, 167 East Sixty-ninth Street. Besides work in various woods and stones, she is showing some novel small pieces called "Designs on Stone."
Borden Company The chemical division of the Borden Company has acquired the American Monomer Corporation and Monomer-Polymer, Inc., chemical concerns of Leominster, Mass., it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 8--Premier-designate Antoine Pinay obtained some help today from the Tunisian Premier in his efforts to form a French Cabinet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--President Eisenhower proposed today a three-year $7,000,000,000 Federal -state-local school construction program.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 8--By a majority of more than 99 per cent, the Cambodian people approved today the policy followed for three years by King Norodom Sihanouk.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 8--Hadji Sahib, Mirza Ali Khan, Faqir of Ipi and the man who would be king, is a little old Pathan with orange turban, baggy trousers and skin the color of tobacco juice. His eyes squint and his beard is turning gray; but across is slight frame drapes a heavy bandoleer of cartridges. For Mizra Ali considers himself at war--with Pakistan.

The Long Beach, Calif., Unified School District borrowed $16,250,000 yesterday on bonds due from 1956 to 1975. The issue was sold to a syndicate headed by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association at a bid of 100.29 for 2 1/2 per cent bonds.
TACHEN ISLANDS, Feb. 8-- Another chapter in the seemingly endless saga of the refugee was written on the bleak Tachen Islands today.

IN 1953 Reginald Reynolds made a journey from "Cairo to Cape Town" with the intention of writing a book about it. This was hardly an original idea. Dozens of writers have done the same in the last few years. But Mr. Reynolds in no way resembles other authors of books about the present state of affairs in Africa.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 8-- Crowds milled around the newsstands today in search of fresh news from Moscow. The radio report of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's fall from power produced a sensation that caught up the ordinary citizen as well as the sophisticated politician in an extraordinary current of excitement.

LONDON, Feb. 8--An African chief in lion's mane headdress, an elderly admiral who won his Victoria Cross forty years ago and 188 other persons received the insignia of their honors from Queen Elizabeth II at an investiture today.
Yesterday's shifts in the Kremlin were the latest phase of a struggle that had raged for more than two years.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 9-- High Japanese officials were confident today that changes in the Kremlin would have no effect on moves toward normal relations between Tokyo and Moscow.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The overthrow of Mendes-France once again highlights the instability of French Governments. There will now be a spate of letters and articles ascribing this evil to proportional representation, to the multiparty system or to the dependence of the Executive on parliamentary majorities.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8-- Twentieth Century-Fox has scheduled for filming this summer "Woman of the Woods," with Sheree North, Richard Egan and Rita Moreno in the principal roles.

Cocoa prices fell the 1-cent-apound-a-day limit yesterday for the second consecutive day on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by weakness in London, lower prices on the stock market here and nervousness over the Brazilian exchange regulations.

The strike at The Brooklyn Eagle, which has caused the borough's only newspaper to suspend publication, passed its eleventh day yesterday. The newspaper management and the New York Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., which represents 315 striking employes, saw no sign of hope for an agreement.
TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council continued general debate on 1953 annual report on conditions in the Cameroons under British administration.
Prices of cotton futures declined 5 to 13 points (25 to 65 cents a bale) yesterday in a moderate volume of business.
Mayor Wagner disclosed last night that his relations with the Transit Authority were not harmonious. He added that he would soon make a series of recommendations about its operations.

The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations gave overwhelming approval yesterday to the mutual defense treaty with the Republic of China headed by President Chiang Kai-shek. Except for the opposition of two dissenters the vote showed such bipartisan unanimity as to guarantee approval by the whole Senate and final ratification.

Going to Bed Early This, as doctors know only too well, is about the time of year when people begin to run down, and are best revived by large amounts of sunshine, for which most of them have a long time to wait.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The West Germans are trying to regain their assets in the United States which were seized during the last war. They do this in spite of the Bonn Convention of 1952, by which they renounced their claim for these seized assets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today that the armed forces must ids put on "a basis of more immediate readiness."
GLOVERSVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 5--This area, in its struggle for economic improvement, has accepted a conflict between aggressive and cautious business groups.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP)-- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey announced today that the Government had been able to postpone paying off 94 per cent of a $15,000,000,000 chunk of public debt.

The National Broadcasting Company is giving serious study to the areas of television comedy for next season. Tentative plans include a revised schedule for Milton Berle and Martha Raye, the introduction of new comedians and the discontinuance of the Sunday night "Comedy Hour" in its present form.

PARIS, Feb. 8--French experts on the Soviet Union reached the tentative conclusion today that the downfall of Georgi M. Malenkov as Premier of the Soviet Union had little to do with foreign affairs. Some suggested the result might be a slackening of effort abroad in favor of attention to the domestic battle.

SIXTY-ONE years ago tonight thirteen lads in Psi Upsilon Fraternity House at Cornell University pledged themselves to meet every five years for the rest of their lives and to come from earth's farthest corners, if need be.

"Inherit the Wind" will bring back Paul Muni to the Broadway stage on April 13 after a six-year absence. This became known yesterday after the star had signed an agreement to act in the Jerome Lawrence-Robert E. Lee drama.
The opening of the China trade to the young American republic in 1784 is the theme of an exhibition on view today at the Brooklyn Museum.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8--Grains and soybeans declined in early trading here today. But the decline met considerable commission absorption, and moderate recoveries from the low points were scored.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP)-- The House Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to revise, its procedures for handling "relief" bills to block the deportation of aliens.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 8--The Scandinavian countries asked today for a maritime conference in the hope of limiting the scope of the future InterGovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization.

Ernest Jackson, married friend of Miss Ann Yarrow, was questioned again yesterday in the murder of the 23-year-old New York University graduate student. It was the third successive day on which he was interrogated.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Governor Harriman vetoed a Republican school aid bill today. He called its passage "premature."
LONDON, Feb. 8--Britain's financial position has improved considerably as compared with a year ago.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 8--The big Danish foreign policy question is ratification of the Paris agreements on arming West Germany.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent speech Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers and the C. I. O., asserted that the auto industry has the capacity to produce nine to eleven million cars a year although it planned to produce not more than 5.8 millions in 1955.

Howard Nemerov, author of "Federigo, or The Power of Love," published recently by Atlantic-Little, Brown, has been chosen for the Kenyon Review Fellowship in Fiction for 1955. The award carries with it a stipend of $3,000. Under the Fellowship Mr. Nemerov will work on a new novel and short stories.
New York City is seeking to extend from 1959 to 1964 the date by which it must cleanse its surrounding waters.
THE first sportsmen's show of the winter, the Long Island Boat and Sportsmen's Show, will open Saturday at the 104th Field Artillery Armory in Jamaica, Queens.

Issues of new corporate securities totaling approximately $42,600,000 will be offered to investors today. The flotations include new capital stock of a closed-end investment company, mortgage bonds and preferred stock of public utility concerns, and new common stock of a cement enterprise.

Organdy, dotted Swiss and batiste, usually utilized for simple, youthful fashions, held their own in highly sophisticated company yesterday at a fashion show of Swiss cottons. The show, was sponsored by the Swiss Fabric Group at the Pierre Hotel.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8--Claiming superiority for the Soviet Union in hydrogen weapons, Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov delivered to the United States today a warning of the strength of the world Communist forces.

The Lehrhar Realty Corporation has sold the ten-family apartment building at 57 St. Pauls Avenue in Jersey City, N. J., to the Lyma Realty Corporation. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Max Druz for the seller and Benjamin Arons for the buyer.
CAPODISTRIA, Yugoslavia, Feb. 8--Partition of the Free Territory of Trieste has run into a hitch.
Production of cotton textiles should rise 5 to 10 per cent this year, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, said at its annual meeting yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 8 (AP)--Harry Hopman, the stern tennis taskmaster who has been criticized widely for his so-called "tyrannical" methods, was reappointed today captain-manager of Australia's Davis Cup forces.
Bellevue Hospital celebrated yesterday the completion of $1,216,000 of reconstruction on four of the eight floors of its out-patient department.
JERSEY CITY, Thursday, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A fugitive and a teenaged girl motorist whose auto he had commandeered were killed early today in a flaming crash on the Pulaski Skyway.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9 (AP) -- An insurgent group of stockholders -- blocked in their efforts to gain control of A. M. Byers Company -- filed suit today to oust one of the company's directors.
Educators are placing increased emphasis upon moral and spiritual values, Dr. Carroll V. Newsom, Associate Commissioner of Education of New York State, said last night.
Shocked Staten Islanders will meet tonight to discuss the Army's plan to quit its island terminal.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- Governor Harriman tonight defended the $107,000,000 increase in expenditures in his budget.
Men seem to be smarter than women in at least one respect. They eat breakfast.

A French scientific expedition will set sail from Rouen in October for Antarctica, to prepare bases for France's part in the International Geophysical Year, 1957-58. The latter is a simultaneous effort by thirty-six countries to conduct observations of many sorts in all parts of the world.
