Contract negotiations in the local tugboat industry bogged down yesterday. Union officials refused to entertain employer-proposed changes in the present working rules. The union issued a formal strike notice for mid-night tomorrow.

Worthwhile to remember is advice from the United States Department of Agriculture on short cuts in preparing dried beans, peas and lentils. These items always are a food bargain both from the standpoint of price and nutrition.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Weakness in March deliveries featured the grain trading here today. Further liquidation and closing of spreads gave a weak tone to March wheat, while the backspreading gave a firm undertone to the new crop months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A bipartisan group in Congress urged President Eisenhower today to invite the North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers to a conference looking toward formation of a tighter Atlantic union.

A group of prominent transportation executives from West Germany and Holland completed yesterday a two-day inspection of four local installations of the Railway Express Agency.The group is in this country on a study tour of American transportation facilities.
TORONTO, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The eventual merger of two big Canadian unions, the Canadian Congress of Labor and the Trades and Labor Congress, was regarded as "automatic" today.
MEXICO, Feb. 9 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon pledged today the United States' co-operation with Mexico in working out common problems.

The demand for investment money this year will exceed the supply of funds by about $1,600,000,000 and thereby exert an influence for slightly higher interest rates. This is the outlook according to the annual survey of the new capital market by Salomon Bros. Hutzler.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Governor Harriman appointed Thomas J. McHugh of Buffalo today as Commissioner of Correction. Mr. McHugh was immediately confirmed by the Senate.
TO insure better control and adequate food supplies for the existing deer herd, the Maine Fish and Game Department has proposed a longer hunting season this year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Civil Defense workers will have a chance to watch the effects of an atomic blast on a community at mid-April tests in Nevada.
BAD NAUHEIM, Germany, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The United States ice hockey team trounced the West German team of Bad Nauheim, 9 -- 0, before 4,000 fans tonight.

An assertion that advertising should be put to work "to lower business costs and risks and to increase and stabilize profits" was made yesterday by Marion Harper Jr., president of McCann-Erickson, Inc.
TACHEN ISLANDS, Feb. 9 -These islands were the scene today of feverish military activity along embarkation beaches and roads leading to them.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 9 -- Following is the text of the joint statement issued here today by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations:
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- A woman lawmaker asked the Legislature today to take a Ferdinand-like respite from state issues and consider the rose.
ATLANTA, Feb. 9 -- A new antibiotic -- cycloserine -- described as a potent anti-tuberculosis remedy, stirred experts here today.
In a letter published Jan. 16 Edward Ennis comments on a special article in The Times of Jan. 9 on the subject of the 1,135 Spanish sheepherders who were brought to the United States in recent years.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 9 -- A Coast Guard board of inquiry has forwarded its recommendations on the steamship Mormac-kite disaster to the Fifth Coast Guard commandant in Washington. Details of the report were not made public.

Cold weather has its critics and its friends, as is plainly evident to anyone who listens to conversations between acquaintances at windy bus stops. It is not with the critics -- who are on their way, about now, to vacations in warmer climes or who wish they were -- that this department today is concerned, but with the friends, such as the proprietors of grocery stores and supermarkets.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Prices fell again on the stock markets here today after yesterday's weakness, touched off by the Russian Government changes. South African gold mining shares alone were able to resist the lower trend.
Memories of sixty-one years and twenty-eight Cornell classmates of the last century flavored a Martini last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- The Senate Rules Committee, with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, absent, approved today $125,000 for an investigation of the Administration's personnel security program.

TOKYO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Prospects of a tougher Soviet world policy today sent heavy industry shares booming on Japan's stock market. Prices rose sharply and reached a near-record high of about 10,000,000 shares in the morning session alone.
Twenty-seven television stations affiliated with the Columbia Broadcasting System protested yesterday against the terms of a report made last week by special counsel to a Senate committee.

PIERRE MONTEUX has a way with Tchaikovsky, as he proved once again at Carnegie Hall last night when he conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra. It is a way that avoids sensationalism and sentimentality and that manages at the same time, to capture the fullness of the composer's emotion.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 9 -- Five of the seven members of the British women's team in the Connecticut State squash racquets championships triumphed today. All except three of the singles quarter-final brackets were filled by the tourists at the Field Club of Greenwich.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Harry Gallatin, New York's rugged forward playing in his 501st consecutive game, scored 30 points to lead the Knicks to a 118-112 victory over the Minneapolis Lakers in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- A United Nations commission voted today against calling a maritime conference to narrow the scope of the future inter-governmental maritime consultative organization.
The two largest cities in the world exchanged greetings yesterday.

The United States Gypsum Company has authorized payment of a quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock, it was announced yesterday. Distribution will be made on April 1 to holders of record on March 4.
PARIS, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Hugh Stewart of Pasadena, Calif., upset Kurt Nielsen of Denmark in straight sets today to reach the semi-finals of the French international indoor tennis championship.
San Antonio, Tex., borrowed $6,000,000 yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.3559 per cent. The borrowing was secured by expressway and street improvement bonds maturing from 1957 to 1970.
A 6-weeks-old baby was saved from drowning and his 19-year-old mother from being raped yesterday in a Queens home.

It is interesting that the same issue of The Times, dated Feb. 7, should carry the first of three articles dealing with fires and overcrowding of slums and your editorial discussing "The Booming City." This is a fabulous city -- magnificent in most respects -- but, as you point out in restrained language, the housing situation remains a major disappointment.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. indicated strongly tonight that President Eisenhower would seek re-election next year.
BUFFALO, Feb. 9 -- The deer don't know it, but if only they were consistent about crossing the State Thruway a problem would be eliminated.
An analysis by the City Club of New York of seventy pre-election promises of Mayor Wagner asserts that he has fulfilled twenty-four pledges, partly fulfilled sixteen and done nothing about thirty.

Desserts, predominate in the new food products being introduced here this week. They include a canned pineapple filling for pies and an applesauce-raspberry puree that is rich red in hue, deliciously tangy in flavor.

ROME, Feb. 9 -- Italy's first subway was inaugurated here today by President Luigi Einaudi. He and his official party took a fifteen-minute ride in a streamlined, gray train. They passed through stations with such names as Colosseum and Circus Maximus.
WASHINGTON Feb. 9 -- President Eisenhower said tonight that the Government's role in improving the health of the nation must always be secondary and supplementary.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Bob Baker of Pittsburgh, fourth-ranking heavyweight contender, knocked out Willie James of Roxbury, Mass., with a right to the chin tonight at 2:50 of the second of a scheduled ten-round bout.
More than any other top Soviet leader today, Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov has ridden the roller coaster from poverty to fame to obscurity and now back to the heights.

February is the month of birthdays, so it has been said. The holidays give children an excuse for the parties they love. Lincoln's Birthday, Valentine's Day and Washington's Birthday provide occasions for younger members of the household to invite their friends in for fun and food.

The American Legion magazine will publish in its March issue an apology to those offended by a letter in the current issue that said one could not be a Legionnaire and a Roman Catholic. The letter, by Kenneth F. Klinkert of Menomonee Falls, Wis., said: "The two don't go together."
Turkey can be relied upon as "a bastion of democracy," Kasim Gulek, secretary general of the Republican People's Party there said here yesterday.

The special committee of The Jockey Club has completed a preliminary sketch for the proposed "racing center" at Belmont Park. The plans, released yesterday, reveal many changes in the set-up that has served Belmont for many years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- The Foreign Operations Administration told Congress today a world-wide shortage of ships might be ended by summer.

Plans for a fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building have been announced in connection with the sale to Louis Cooper of the blockfront on the east side of Second Avenue from Seventieth to Seventy-first Streets.
Too many students choose their colleges on the basis of snob appeal rather than academic standards, a college president declared yesterday.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Desperate Hours" on Monday night at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre for the benefit of Greenwich House. Mrs. Herbert Scheftel is chairman of the benefit committee, and Mrs. William C. T. Gaynor is co-chairman.
The Miller Brothers Hat Company, Inc., has bought the wholesale division of Adam Hat Stores Inc., for more than $500,000 cash and other unspecified considerations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Eisenhower today discussed the Kremlin shake-up as calmly and objectively as a man speculating on some vaguely disturbing development on another planet. He attributed the Moscow change of command to internal dissatisfaction.

WITH NATIONALIST FLEET, Feb. 9 -The commander of the Chinese Nationalist Navy said today he had been assured that United States carrier-based planes would aid in the defense of Matsu and Quemoy Islands any time they were needed.
Merging of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations would have no immediate effect on members of independent unions.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 9 -- Upstate dairymen are pressing for a $6 a hundred average, year-round return for milk. They were warned today, however, that their demands might backfire in the form of consumer resistance and increased milk surpluses.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Feb. 9 -- Representatives of Islam and Christianity from fourteen countries met here today to form an organization devoted to strengthening understanding between the two faiths.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 9 -- Governor General Ghulam Mohammed's recent dismissal of the National Assembly was ruled illegal today.

It has been quite a while since Edward Ringwood Hewitt attended the cornerstone-laying of the American Museum of Natural History. Nearly eighty-one years, for it took place June 2, 1874.
Although it is not common, a true form of allergy may be produced by smoking, the American Academy of Allergy was told here yesterday.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Mrs. Bernard Schnees learned today that her son born Jan. 28 would have a twin about March 22.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Senator Warren Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said today he had asked Senate investigators to assemble data "on reports of fixed fights and other complaints from captive audiences of televised sports events."
" The Desperate Hours," Joseph Hayes' dramatization of his best selling novel of the same name, will open at the Barrymore Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.
WICHITA, Kan., Feb. 9 -- The Air Force's student pilots will be flying soon in jet planes almost from the start of their training.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 9 -- The forced removal of natives from their homes in Johannesburg began today.
Lester Markel, Sunday editor of The New York Times, gave advice yesterday on how to read a newspaper.

Glittering accents, vivid color combinations and long lines characterized the Dan Millstein suit and coat collection for Arnold Constable. The fashions were presented yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Former Premier Antoine Pinay seemed today to have little hope of forming a new French Cabinet. It was expected that tomorrow he would have to tell President Rene Coty he had found the task impossible.

William and Helen Kobielski have purchased the four-story apartment house at 3 Armstrong Avenue in Jersey City, N. J., from the Meyer Realty Corporation. The building contains twenty-one suites of two to four rooms. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.

A maxim of Henry Clews, who in 1908 wrote a classic account of his fifty years in Wall Street, was: "The man who runs his business with an eye to profits in the stock market often winds up with no profits and no business."
Supplies of light fuel oil declined sharply last week for the second consecutive period.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the initial financing of the Dixon-Yates contract. The vote was 4 to 1.

Efforts to restore unity in the American labor movement have been going on since Jan. 22, 1936.
The election of Ben Touster, New York industrialist and Jewish communal leader, as president of the United Hias Service was announced yesterday.
Joe R. Hanley, former Lieutenant Governor, was quoted yesterday as having said he was "third-degreed" into giving up his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor in 1950.

Stockholders of the Missouri Public Service Company will vote on a proposal to increase the authorized common stock from 530,000 to 2,000,000 shares at the annual meeting on April 12. The increased capitalization would be used to provide stock for a proposed three-for-one split and for future needs.

Cocoa prices rose 64 to 76 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on (the New York Cocoa Exchange after declining the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit for two consecutive days. The market opened lower, reflecting continued liquidation induced by the uncertainty concerning the Brazilian cruzeiro.

An "Orchestra da camera" of players from the Philharmonic- Symphony, headed by concert- master John Corigliano, gave a concert last evening at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Remus Tzincoca was the conductor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The value to the country in these critical times of a President who doesn't scare or get flurried is incalculable. Today General Eisenhower again appeared to be such a President, in a news conference shadowed with the gravity of events in the Communist world which Western intelligence is wholly unable to evaluate.

Governor Harriman has justifiably vetoed a Republican-passed bill on state aid to schools. Several things were wrong with the measure. The Governor found it premature and piecemeal legislation. As a matter of fact, almost anything that costs money is premature until Republican budgetary and tax policy makes more sense than it does at this moment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Leaders in Government, by and large, had kind words for today's decision to merge the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Transit Authority police called for assistance in handling rush-hour crowds yesterday when signal trouble tied up the north-bound express line of the I. R. T. Seventh Avenue subway south of the Wall Street Station for fifteen minutes.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Iain Macleod, Minister of Health, announced today a program for building new hospitals. He decribed it as the first of its kind in Britain since before the war.

Six buildings and a gasoline station at the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Twelfth Street have been sold by St. Vincent's Hospital and the Archbishopric of New York and will be razed to make way for an eighteen-story, air-conditioned apartment house.

Highs in telephone usage and construction were reported yesterday by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, a leading operating unit in the Bell System.

RENATA TEBALDI, who had made her New York debut Jan. 31 (and not her American debut, as this writer had erroneously stated in his account of her first performance here), made herself known to the Metropolitan last night as the impersonator of Mimi in "La Boheme," and this was something of a revelation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A House committee approved today a bill to expedite legal showdowns with witnesses who show contempt for Congress.
NEWARK, Feb. 9 -- The Municipal Council approved today this city's 1955 budget after cutting $222,131 from the total submitted by Mayor Leo P. Carlin last month.

It's said with a menacing intonation of the voice and it works best on awed apprentices. So the greenhorn steers his horse wide of the rail and permits a city slicker such as Arcaro to slip inside. There's no skulduggery involved. It's an instinctive reaction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate voted without debate today to extend full G. I. educational benefits to a possible 1,400,000 veterans. The vote sent the measure to the White House.
The Chicago Black Hawks maintained their jinx over the New York Rangers last night by battling the Broadway Blues to a 2-2 tie in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
The high cost of attempted income tax evasion was told in Federal Court yesterday by one who said he had tried it.
The police turned their attention to a new suspect yesterday in the slaying of Ann Yarrow, 23-year-old New York University graduate student.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9 -- professional soldier took command of the Soviet Union's defense establishment today. At the same time the nation's new Premier proclaimed defiance of United States "threats" and "aggression."

Today's new film is "The Long Gray Line," a Columbia drama in Cinema Scope and color with Tyrone Power and Maureen O'Hara, at the Capitol. Robert Arthur produced and John Ford directed from a screen play by Edward Hope based on a book by Marty Maher and Nardi Reeder Campion.
In its first evaluation of small taxicabs the Hack Bureau of the Police Department has reported that the stock models have had fewer accidents than jumbo-size cabs.

RYE, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- Yale University's hockey team gained its sixth victory of the season tonight in a benefit match at Play-land Ice Casino. The Eli sextet scored over the New Rochelle Eagles, an amateur team, 12 -- 4.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer will finance and distribute two pictures to be produced by David O. Selznick's independent company, Seliznick International Pictures.
Stocks recovered their Tuesday losses yesterday and pushed close to the Monday highs.

Sal Maglie is "not exactly a holdout." However, he still does "not see eye to eye" with the Giants' front office on the figures in his 1955 contract.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Legislation designed to dissuade couples with children from seeking divorces or annulments was introduced in the Legislature today.

Cyrus S. Jullien, president of the Queens County Jockey Club, said yesterday that his group would hold a special meeting on Tuesday. The purpose will be to review the local racing picture and to consider going ahead with independent plans for the reconstruction of Aqueduct.
What are Soviet economic strengths and weaknesses in the light of the latest Moscow debates and decisions on economic policy?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 2:

Life in Soviet Russia no doubt has its harsher aspects, but in one respect and for at least one group -the Soviet journalists -- it must be a bed of roses. No initiative to be exercised; no tough editorial decisions to be made; no need to worry whether this story or that story is more important, and where it should go in the paper.
Sal Maglie is "not exactly a holdout." However, he still does "not see eye to eye" with the Giants' front office on the figures in his 1955 contract.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Legislation designed to dissuade couples with children from seeking divorces or annulments was introduced in the Legislature today.

Cyrus S. Jullien, president of the Queens County Jockey Club, said yesterday that his group would hold a special meeting on Tuesday. The purpose will be to review the local racing picture and to consider going ahead with independent plans for the reconstruction of Aqueduct.
What are Soviet economic strengths and weaknesses in the light of the latest Moscow debates and decisions on economic policy?
Net earnings of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company last year rose to $21,538,965, second largest in its history, the annual report disclosed yesterday. In 1953 it earned $16,267,386.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Feb. 9 -- The Allies charged today that the Communists had violated the Korean armistice agreement by bringing combat aircraft and other military materials into North Korea.

Actors Studio, an experimental theatre workshop where professional actors, directors and playwrights may study, will benefit from the March 9 premiere of the CinemaScope production of "East of Eden" at the Astor Theatre. Elia Kazan's film production of John Steinbeck's novel in WarnerColor, stars James Dean, Julie Harris and Raymond Massey.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- Communist China's trade with the free world dropped sharply during the first half of 1954, the statistical office of the United Nations reported today.

Eighteen men and women were selected yesterday for literary awards by the Christophers, an organization that emphasizes higher standards of education, government, labor relations, literature and entertainment.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of the merger agreement signed today by leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations:

The movies and television, which never have been extra good friends, are taking digs at each other in printed media. The movies have had a gratifying rise in attendance lately. Reporting this fact in their trade advertising, movie producers say it is at the expense of television, the "novelty" of TV having worn off.

The party scene of Strauss' "Arabella" calls for potables and edibles. When the opera, with its Viennese locale, receives its American premiere tonight at the Metropolitan, the potables probably will be cold tea, but one of the edibles will be as authentic as a Viennese Sachertorte.

One of the largest awards in a negligence case was returned yesterday in Manhattan Supreme Court. A jury awarded $350,000 to a 56-year-old widow who was seriously injured when she was struck by a police radio car.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House has authorized direct quotation of most of the President's answers to questions. Elsewhere the President's remarks are in indirect discourse, as required by White House rules.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Senate Armed Service Committee heard Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson defend the Administration's military manpower cuts today.

Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 290 Park Avenue, for members of the special reservations committee for the benefit premiere performance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on March 30.
A syndicate has been formed that will spend that $20,000,000 to bring farmers' markets to ten suburban areas in the United States in the next year and a half.
The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company yesterday purchased the Baker Manufacturing Company, which makes attachments for crawler tractors.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Landlords and tenants clashed sharply today over proposal to change the state rent law.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Export-Import Bank of Washington approved today a $75,000,000 credit for Brazil.
The importance of color in the home was discussed by Howard Ketcham, color engineer, at a luncheon of the National Homes Fashions League yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Eisenhower publicly admitted his error in a major airlines case today. Thus he brought into sharp focus the White House staff system of briefing the President on vital decisions.

NEWARK, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge Mark A. Sullivan granted a temporary injunction today restraining the Niles-Bement-Pond Company of Hartford, Conn., from affiliating with the Belco General Corporation.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India said today he hoped for a "peaceful solution" of Formosa's future. But the Indian leader emphasized his belief that the Chinese Communist regime should be admitted to the United Nations and said its exclusion "verges on the absurd."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Progress was reported today in experiments to reorganize the United States Army for atomic combat.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 10 (UP)--The West Point Board of Visitors cleared the way today for Army's football team to appear in the Sugar and Cotton Bowls "whenever it is invited," Representative F. Edward Hebert, Democrat of Louisiana, announced.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, B. W. I., Feb. 9--Race rivalry has become a critical problem in West Indian politics. It is one of the chief obstacles to plans to federate Britain's colonies in this part of the hemisphere and eventually give them dominion status.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 --Henry Fonda has joined the growing list of film stars entering independent production. He has signed with United Artists, which will finance him in the making of six pictures during the next three years.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 10 (UP) --A group of New York Shipbuilding Corporation shareholders today charged that Louis E. Wolfson, chairman, with illegal use of he company's funds to purchase stock of Montgomery Ward Co.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby said today that President Eisenhower's education program offered the states the "very quickest way" to get needed schools.
THERE are still more fish than fishermen in the Bahamas, although reports indicate the islands are attracting a record number of anglers this season.
LONDON, Feb. 10--Leaders of the British Government rejected today Laborite demands that they call international conferences to discuss the situations in the Far East and Germany.
Martin Belasco emphasized hates with a backward tilt in his collection of spring custom millinery, shown yesterday at Jay Thorpe.
Action to ease the financial burdens of the City Center of Music and Drama was taken yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--High official sources here think the impending arming of West Gernany may have triggered the fall of Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and the rise of the harsher, anti-Western Khrushchev clique.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP)--Department of Agriculture reports at livestock trading here today follow: HOGS Salable hogs 9.500 head; market moderately active and uneven: steady to 25 cents higher on butchers: most advance on weights over 230 pounds: sows steady to strong: bulk
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10-- Sales by retailers last month reached a volume of $13,300,000,000, a gain of 10 per cent over the totals of January a year ago, the Government reported today.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 10--The International Court of Justice began hearings today on a dispute between Guatemala and Liechtenstein over the assets and nationality of a German-born millionaire.
Mayor Wagner accused the Federal Housing Administration yesterday of failing to make good $10,000,000 in housing funds pledged to the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The Administration's reciprocal trade program cleared the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee by a vote of 20 to 5 today. It headed for a major floor battle next week.

The Feminine Fifties, as one fabric stylist has called this decade, are in full flower for spring and summer. Roses bloom in profusion on print after print, violets shine on dark grounds, daisies tell on distinctive textiles.

St. Patrick's Day--March 17-- is a great day for the Irish. The Irish Linen Guild, tying in, is planning its annual Irish. Linen Week, March 14 through 19, promoting Irish linens of every kind for fashion and household house.
ALBANY, Feb. 10--A new legislative battle began today over whether savings banks should be permitted to open branches in suburbs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I take this occasion to thank The New York Times for its accurate news story concerning my report to the Board of Estimate regarding the failure of the New York Port Authority to live up to its agreement with the City of New York for the development of the municipal airports, Idlewild: and La Guardia.
In its first change of ownership since 1888, the blockfront on the west side of Eighth Avenue from 124th to 125th Streets has been sold by Vincent Astor to Jack Resnick, operator.

LONDON, Feb. 10--The Soviet Union's reported conditional willingness to withdraw its communications troops from Poland is regarded here as a new and significant move in the campaign to defeat the rearmament of Germany.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10-Details of the licensing system by which the Government will curb exports of copper scrap this month and next were disclosed tonight.

Fourteen artists, writers and composers have been elected to membership in the National Institute of Arts and Letters. The selections were announced yesterday by Marc Connelly, president of the institute.
Employer concessions yesterday afternoon and their first "cash" offer buoyed hopes that the port of New York could avoid a crippling strike of tugboat and oil craft workers.

Probably the most important thing about the Senate's ratification of the mutual defense pact with Nationalist China is the overwhelming vote by which it was approved. Only six Senators voted against it. The Senate obviously believes that this commitment expresses the will of the American people and therefore should have its endorsement.

Another book dealing with Congressional investigations is scheduled for publication this season, with Viking Press putting out on April 1 "Government by Investigation," by Alan Barth. Previously announced for Feb. 28 publication by Simon Schuster was Telford Taylor's "Grand Inquest: The Story of Congressional Investigations."

Fordham rallied to beat Iona's basketball team, 52 to 45, at the Fordham gymnasium last night. The Gaels led twice during the second half but Ed Bugniazet tossed in a field goal at 10:25 to put the Rams ahead, 35--34.

Some major changes are pending for "Norby," the television program starring David Wayne. One proposal up for consideration is a thorough reorganization of the program's format, including a switch from the current film production to a live performance.
A Queens grand jury began yesterday, to inspect the files of certain funding corporations.
THE repeat performance on Wednesday evening of Rod Serling's play, "Patterns,"? which was every bit as successful as the original presentation a month ago, is an encouraging television development.

The much-discussed lightweight trains that six of the nation's leading railroads have been promising for the last year are now the subject of a bitter intra-industry dispute. The timetable for actual delivery is more uncertain than ever.
Harvey Matusow was shown yesterday to have called himself "a coward and dishonest," and a person who "would do anything for a buck."

MUNICIPAL Applications for the following examinations issued at 96 Duane St.: PHYSICAL THERAPIST, there are approximately fifty-five vacancies in the Department of Hospitals and the Department of Health at $3.425 per annum. Applications issued until further notice.

Boycotts by teachers have reduced extracurricular activities in the city High schools by 43 per cent in the last five years, the High School Teachers Association reported yesterday. The activities that still exist, the group declared, are conducted largely within the school day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UP)-- The Advisory Commission on Information today called for greater Government efforts to combat stepped-up Communist propaganda.
Peg Fischer has concentrated on witty little hats this spring. All the models shown yesterday in Miss Fischer's collection at the Plaza Hotel were pert, tiny and brimless.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 10 --President Eisenhower hunted quail in fading light amid the scrub pines of southern Georgia late today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 10--Reports of possible violent resistance to the removal of the Negroes from their Johannesburg homes caused the Government ban on public meetings here. The reports also resulted in the heavy concentration of the national police for the start of the shift yesterday.

PASSING mention was made here the other day of Eddie Goodwin, the old cycling champion from the Irish-American A. C. That mention brought into the office some letters, some telephone calls--and Eddie Goodwin.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 10 (AP)-- Bob Rosburg of San Francisco left a sick bed today to shoot his best golf of the year and share the lead at the end of the first round of the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP)--Pat Lesser of Seattle and Wiffi Smith of Lacanada, Calif., were upset to extra-hole matches today in the quarter-finals of the Palm Beach women's amateur golf tournament.

Of no other subject on which the New York Legislature will act at this session can it be so truly said as of rent control that the final action will please nobody. This was made clear at the hearing at Albany before the "temporary" State Rent Commission, which will make recommendations to the Legislature on where we go from here.
Twelve youngsters after the President's own heart managed to win it completely on a recent White House call.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP)--Mary Lena Faulk played as a professional for the first time today. She shot a fiveunder-par 69 for the first-round lead in the $5,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 --Dr. James B. Conant today rejected the idea that any area of science or scholarship could be neutral in the ideological conflict between the free world and the Soviet world.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Walter P. Reuther expects a united labor movement to be more influential politically than labor is now.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 -- A teamsters union move to resume deliveries for three of the five struck department stores here failed today.
Cliche of Snow To be blunt, snow has outlived its usefulness. In this particular period of the twentieth century, snow is no more than a disreputable cliche, which probably should be abandoned.
ATLANTA, Feb. 10--While modern treatment has been widely effective against tuberculosis, the disease continues to smolder dangerously.
American exporters of automotive equipment face greater competition this year, including some just beginning to come from Communist countries, the Overseas Automotive Club was told yesterday.
A campaign to rewrite history so as to highlight the past role and importance of the Communist party's First Secretary, Nikita S. Khrushchev, appears to be well under way in the Soviet press.

The simultaneous resignation of six directors of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company was viewed in shipping circles yesterday as the result of recent major changes in stock ownership. The resignations were announced Wednesday by Edward P. Farley, board chairman.
PARIS, Feb. 10--Nina Ricci's use of mother of pearl Cellophane fabric veiled by Chantilly lace is one of the attractive ideas to be remembered in the recent Paris openings.
LONDON, Feb. 10--The stock markets here rallied today in the wake of the advance on Wall Street yesterday, although less business was transacted than yesterday or a week ago.
Montefiore Hospital has received a $250,000 gift for the construction of a nurses' residence that will have all the comforts of a modern apartment.
ADD to the current stock of literate thrillers "The Desperate Hours," which opened at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre last evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The most unattractive exhibition of partisan politics the capital has witnessed for years is the row over the Dixon-Yates contract. The attack on this contract by some Democratic legislators and by the National Committee has been adopted as a party line.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Nationalist China's Foreign Minister asserted today that the United States was pledged to defend "all the offshore" Chinese islands in addition to Formosa and the Pescadores.

THE performance of Richard Strauss' "Arabella" in its American premiere last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was one thing; the opera, in our opinion, another. The opera is singularly devoid of musical invention, genuine characterization or very much of anything that carries conviction or sincerity to the listener.
The Transit Authority is continuing to lose passengers by the millions.

The agreement of the joint negotiating committee of the A. F. L. and C. I. O., proposing a merger of the two organizations, is a feat of statesmanship and--especially on the C. I. O. side--of personal forbearance and a willingness to forgo short-run gain for long-term advantage.
Determined buying pushed up the blue chips yesterday, and a large majority of other stocks followed their advance. All previous highs for the year and the recovery movement were surpassed.
Reconstruction of the southern end of Bruckner Boulevard was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
Although a certain baker may not know it, her dog received a bath yesterday afternoon along with eleven others in preparation for a pet show Sunday.
Louis E. Wolfson revealed yesterday that one of the weapons he would use in his fight for Montgomery Ward Co., would be coffee.

The National Biscuit Company has leased six floors in the thirtystory office building to be erected at 425 Park Avenue. Principal offices of the company have been in the eight-story building at 449 West Fourteenth Street since 1898.
Uncle Sam collected $24,688,920 last month from 1,331 planes and 730 ships that put into New York from foreign ports.

STEFAN LORANT, who has just done the pocket book "Life of Abraham Lincoln," another of his illustrated biographies of the Emancipator, was in town from his home in Lenox, Mass., the other day telling how he ran into Lincoln photographs that had been hidden, in some cases, for almost ninety years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The country's first private atomic electric power plant will be built near New York City.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 10-- Nationalist officials said today they "had good reason to believe" that the United States would devote as much naval strength to the defense of Nanki Island as to Quemoy and Matsu. They said the civilian population of slightly more than 2,000 would be evacuated within the next few days and the military garrison built up.

TOKYO, Feb. 10--Prime Minister Ichiro Hatoyama said today Japan would seek an economic arrangement with the Soviet Union before taking up certain "political" issues. Among these are the return of former Japanese islands occupied by the Soviet Union.
Taxpayers are reminded by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue that careful attention should be given this year in their tax returns to income derived from dividends.
TRENTON, Feb. 10--New Jersey started legal action today to recover from the South Amboy Trust Company $300,000 in missing state deposits.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10--The Soviet Union has almost overcome the United States long-held advantage in technical manpower.
BOSTON, Feb. 10 (UP)--The Boston Bruins beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 4--2, in a National Hockey League game before 7,219 Boston Garden fans tonight.

The March and May rubber options reached a new high for the life of the contract yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Final quotations were 35 to 65 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on 1,950 tons. The near-by months were strongest.

HAVING concluded only last year what was announced at the time as the last of his "Items on the Grand Account," a series of more or less autobiographical volumes of unflagging, or, at any rate, persistent, charm; Elliot Paul has now produced a small book of large categorical imperatives about the French people, whom he admires with a becoming intemperance.
BEAUMONT, Tex., Feb. 7-- The thin line that has differentiated tactical from strategic air power is becoming more and more smudged by new developments.
Parental concern over that sometimes risky combination, a boy and a gun, can be eased by a school-arranged community program on firearms safety.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 10 (AP)--A strange looking airplane with movable helicopter blades mounted on its wingtips was unveiled today.

Trustworthy sources felt confident yesterday that "The Captain's Paradise," the frothy film identified with Alec Guinness' superb portrayal as a farceur, would reach the musical stage. On the job putting the component parts together is the Theatre Guild.

The sixty-ninth annual Lincoln Day Memorial Service will be conducted in Union Square at noon tomorrow. A wreath will be placed at the Lincoln Statue, opposite Sixteenth Street, and there will be a massing of the colors.

Three integrated investing and and mortgage processing organizations have been formed to serve the building industry on Long Island. The principals are Emil M. Keen, a director of the First Suffolk National Bank; Ernst Heumann and Eric J. Frank, partners in the Trylon Realty Company; Morton D. Bildner, William Feder and Herbert M. Unger, mortgage brokers, and Samuel Spitzbart, mortgage counsel for the First Suffolk National Bank.
ALBANY, Feb. 10--State revenues from existing taxes are insufficient to meet foreseeable needs through 1962.

Any antics that develop at Madison Square Garden tomorrow in the New York Athletic Club games probably won't be new in the experience of that organization. The Winged Footers have been conducting indoor track and field meets for eightyseven years.

There is reason to commend the officers of our Government for the temperate language in which they have dealt with the shooting down of an American plane near the Tachen Islands evacuation operation. They have shown objectivity, perspective and good common sense.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10-- Diplomats with Peiping contacts now believe there is no hope of reaching a negotiated agreement to ease the crisis in the Formosa Strait. The conviction is growing in New Delhi foreign circles that the best that can he expected is a long stalemate without war.
PARIS, Feb. 10--Former Premier Antoine Pinay abandoned today his effort to form a Cabinet. Pierre Pflimlin was asked to head a new French Government.
Forty-one donors have contributed $1,171.43 more to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for 1954. The latest gifts bring the total of contributors to 12,267 and the amount to $408,341.02.

Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, has sold the Hampton Apartments at 41-69 Parsons Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, to Joseph Barden. The four-story building on plot 175 by 173 feet at the corner of Sanford Avenue contains fifty-eight apartments.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--The United States will agree at the Bangkok conference to begin putting "teeth" into the Southeast Asian collective defense treaty.

Manhattan College succumbed to the court wizardry to Tom Gola and La Salle of Philadelphia, 76--62, before 6,438 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. Manhattan's second-half collapse was followed by a mismatch in which the Billikens of St. Louis overwhelmed New York University, 87--66.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 10-- President Chiang Kai-shek has warned the West against any sell-out of the Chinese Nationalists.

LONDON, Feb. 10--The opponents of capital punishment lost a crucial vote in Parliament today. As a result, Britain is likely to remain one of the three Western European countries still exacting the death penalty.
A Government witness retold under cross-examination in Federal Court yesterday how he paid out $125,000 to $140,000 in bribes to avoid criminal prosecution in 1949 for admitted income tax evasion.
Two cities have expressed interest in adopting the Symphony of the Air (the former N. B. C. Symphony). The latest in a series of offers have come from Miami, Fla., and Newark.

PANAMA, Feb. 10--A commission named by the National Assembly reported today that former President Jose Ramon Guizado was implicated in the racetrack slaying Jan. 2 of President Jose Antonio Remon. It recommended that Senor Guizado be brought to trial.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 (AP)--Western diplomats groped today for the significance of the momentous changes in the Soviet Government. Satellite envoys had an even bigger task of interpretation.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 10--The only potential holdout against labor unity climbed on the merger bandwagon today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--During the week ended yesterday member bank reserves decreased $261,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Chrysler Corporation suffered a 75.2 per cent drop in earnings from those of 1953 and sales were down 38.1 per cent last year, the thirtieth annual report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Department store sales in the United States last week were 1 per cent below those in the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Multnomah County, Ore., designated March 9 yesterday for the sale of $15,500,000 of road and bridge bonds. Dated March 15, 1955, the bonds will come due on March 15 from 1956 to 1975.
Former Representative W. Kingsland Macy declared yesterday that top Republican leaders tried to get him to repudiate or burn the famous Joe R. Hanley letter during the 1950 state campaign.

Domenico Cimarosa, who lives today almost entirely through his opera, "II Matrimonio Segreto," composed a stage work named "II Fanatico per gli Antichi Romani" in 1777. It had to wait until last night to receive its first performance from the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 10--The President of the People's Chamber (Parliament) of East Germany said today the Soviet Union had offered conditionally to withdraw its troops from Poland. The proviso was that the four occupying powers agree to evacuate their forces from Germany.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (UP)--The explosion of a super hydrogen bomb would contaminate 10,000 square miles, an area the size of Maryland, with lethal radioactive fall-out.
The J. C. Penney Company has staked its future on the belief that the textile industry can create new demand by creating new products. A. W. Hughes, president, said yesterday.
The biggest news about groceries this week-end is the drop in coffee prices.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 to 10 points (15 to 50 cents a bale) yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 10--A plea to Protestant churches to expand their week-day religious education programs was voiced here today.
Loans to business by major New York City banks in the week ended on Wednesday increased by $25,000,000, the first raise this year, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

As the outside world tries to look through the opaque windows of the Kremlin to gauge the meaning of the latest upheaval in the Soviet regime, there is a general agreement on at least one point, and that is the emergence of the Russian Army as a major power factor in the Soviet empire.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 10-- The International Commission controlling the Vietnamese truce has criticized the French following an investigation of an incident at Balang, in Communistcontrolled North Vietnam.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 10--Vice President Richard M. Nixon was greeted today by the largest crowd thus far on his Caribbean tour when he visited the Basilica of Guadalupe, Mexico's most sacred shrine.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10--Wheat futures showed unexpected strength in early trading today. The March delivery was especially strong, with short covering and commission buying in evidence. At the same time there was a heavy tone in corn and oats, with no aggressive buying it any time in the feed grains.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 10, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Had breakfast with Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson and Under-Secretary True D. Morse. Met with members of the National Security Council.

If the general public has been under the impression that the books and records of stock brokers are inspected as regularly as those of banks, the general public is mistaken. Yesterday the Securities and Exchange Commission revealed that it does not have the funds to make regular inspections of all such records.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10-- Loyalty oaths prescribed in California as a prerequisite to obtaining property tax exemptions bave been, ruled unconstitutional. However, the ruling will be appealed.

TACHEN ISLANDS, China, Feb. 10--The evacuation of Chinese Nationalist military forces from the Communistthreatened Tachen Islands began today and was proceeding smoothly. The number of soldiers involved in the withdrawal was kept secret for security reasons.
Domestic steel production rose to 8,838,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last month --the highest level since October, 1953, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

GENEVA, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Executive Committee of the World Council of Churches cautioned today against "unilateral action" in the Formosa crisis. It urged an agreed settlement within "the framework of the total world situation."
WEST CHESTER, Pa., Feb. 10 --Pierre S. du Pont left the major portion of a $55,000,000 to $60,000,000 estate to the Longwood Foundation.
A covenant is a covenant and should be kept, even if it is 108 years old, Thomas L. Purdy Jr. told the Public Service Commission yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Walter Reuther attacked President Eisenhower's economic report today for failure to consider the social impact of "automation."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 640,735 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,244 cars or 0.2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 16,350 cars or 2.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 19,878 cars or 7.2 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--A Congressional hearing on peaceful uses of the atom produced another bitter wrangle today. Again it involved the effect of the Dixon-Yates private power contract on the country's atomic effort.
MIAMI, Feb. 10--From the third race through the sixth, there were $25.80, $67.10, $35.20 and $17.50 surprises at the Hialeah horse park today.
DETROIT, Feb. 10--The general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission refused today to hand over to a Federal Judge an investigation report sought by the court.
The Committee of 10,000,000 Americans announced last night that it was disbanding. It was created last November to protest the Senate censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

Heaped-up rubbish and litter in and around buildings in New York -- especially multiple dwellings -- is a dangerous fire hazard. To allow such conditions to exist is a violation of the laws of the city and state, punishable by fine and even imprisonment. We had assumed that proper inspection of multiple dwellings and effective enforcement of the law would prevent such fires by eliminating the tinder on which they feed.

CANNES, France, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Tony Vincent of Miami, Fla., gained the semi-finals of the Cannes tennis tournament today and became a leading contender for the winner's cup by beating Jean Andreux of France, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- George K. C. Yeh, Nationalist Chinese Foreign Minister, retreated today from his assertion that the United States was pledged to defend Quemoy, Matsu and "all the offshore islands."
SORONG, Netherlands New Guinea, Jan. 22 -- A massive private effort to draw oil from the swampy jungle is under way here.
The bottom dropped out of New York's premature spring yesterday as a bitter cold wave moved in on the East.

WEST MEMPHIS, Ark., Feb. 11 (UP) -- The Dixon-Yates group announced today it had exercised its options to buy a near-by site for its proposed $107,250,000 steam-electric generating plant. The site includes 600 acres south of here on the Mississippi River.
Ona Munson, actress, who in private life was the wife of Eugene Berman, artist and designer, was found dead yesterday in their apartment at 225 West Eighty-sixth Street.
DETROIT, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Henri Salaun of Boston defeated John Fowler of Chicago in straight games today in the opening of singles competition in the national squash racquets championship.
WITH AMPHIBIOUS FORCE, off Tachen Islands, Saturday, Feb. 12 -- The evacuation of the Tachen Islands ended last night.
ROME, Feb. 11 -- The sum of $53,000,000 in United States aid was made available today to bolster Italian economy.

DENVER, Feb. 11 (UP) -- The Air Force Academy announced tonight that Lawrence T. (Buck) Shaw, college and professional coach on the West Coast for nearly two decades, has been hired as "special consultant" to the academy's freshman and intra-mural football coaching staff for 1955.

Coquille St. Jacques -- scallops poached in butter and then browned in the delicious French manner -- is a complicated dish and one that American home cooks seldom attempt. But Andre Prince, gourmet and excellent amateur chef, devised a simplified version that he recently forwarded to us.
W. Kingsland Macy testified yesterday that he believed Thomas E. Deway inspired 1950 newspaper stories that "falsely" depicted Mr. Macy as aspiring to be Senator.
Four hotel ballrooms were linked by a closed television circuit for a ceremony yesterday as 312 retiring hotel workers received the first pensions in the industry.
From the appearance of the Olliffe apothecary, founded in 1805, when alchemy and pharmacy were kindred arts, the store would not seem to be "in transition."
Supported by the strength of a relatively few issues, The New York Times' industrial and combined stock averages made new twenty-five-year highs yesterday.

It is unfortunate that, right on the heels of Senate approval of our mutual defense treaty with the Chinese Nationalist Government, something like a controversy is boiling up over the implications of our ties with that Government, and especially over the precise obligations the United States has assumed.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 11 (UP) -- All-America Fullback Alan Ameche of Wisconsin signed a two-year contract today with the Baltimore Colts of the National Football League for a sum estimated at $25,000 a year.

Upper Hollow Farm, the 868-acre farm-estate of State Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer in Hillsdale, N. Y., is under contract of sale to Mortimer F. Harman, White Plains attorney, according to Previews, Inc.

The average rate of interest earned by the Marine Midland Corporation last year on loans and discounts of its banks was 4.87 per cent. This compared with 4.66 per cent in 1953. The figures were given in the annual report, issued yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- An appropriation of $1,000,000 to convert the old Western Avenue studio here of Twentieth Century-Fox to television film production was approved today by the company's board of directors.

CREDIT the Equity Community Theatre players with a measure of Shavian impudence in assaying the master's "Misalliance.'' Credit them, too, for carrying off the attempt with a measure of success at the DeWitt Clinton Youth and Adult Center in the Bronx. The initial performance was given there last night and another is scheduled for this evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended last Tuesday to 110.3 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Slightly lower average prices for farm products more than offset a rise in the index for all commodities other tha n farm products and foods.

TORONTO, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press) -- R. Howard Webster of Montreal was announced tonight as the successful bidder for The Toronto Globe and Mail. The price was reported as "considerably in excess of $10,000,000."

The Terrace Gardens apartment development for forty-eight families on Glenwood Avenue in East Paterson, N. J., has passed to new ownership in a transaction negotiated by the Alexander Summer Company as broker. Sery Nicosia was attorney for the seller and David Hamer acted for the buyer.
The Temporary State Commission on Fiscal Affairs of the State Government will recommend to the Legislature that New York City be allowed to raise $27,500,000 more in real estate taxes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The State Department announced officially tonight that the evacuation of the Chinese Nationalists on the Tachen Islands had been completed.

THE increased utilization of New York State's public camp sites by anglers and hunters has led to the selection of those areas as the theme for the Conservation Department exhibit in the forthcoming Sports and Vacation Show.

Next week, Monday through Friday, will be Bank Week for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. On each day blood will be given at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street, by employes of downtown Manhattan banking institutions.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Russell Stanger, 30-year-old Massachusetts musician, this afternoon conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra through a long and sharply varied program.
I have always had a great deal of respect for the fair-minded and accurate reporting of The New York Times and I was therefore disturbed at your editorial appearing Feb. 8 which said in part:

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler told Britain today that her exports were not rising fast enough to keep pace with imports. He also said the cost of the imports was increasing.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Social Democratic party, strongest of Brazil's numerous parties, last night named Gov. Juscelino Kubitschek of Minas Gerais state as its Presidential candidate in the October elections.

The decision of General Motors Acceptance Corporation to enter the public market to borrow $250,000,000 had a sobering effect on the bond market yesterday. The prospect of an increase of this extent in the supply caused outstanding investments to be marked down slightly in price.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Soviet Russia's speed skaters went about long-range preparations for the 1956 Winter Olympics today in a business-like manner that included testing Cortina's ice with a toy-like gadget never before seen here.

The New York City school system set up yesterday a special committee to determine if the city can share in the $7,000,000,000 school building program proposed earlier this week by President Eisenhower.
A psychiatrist's contention that bull whips and throwing knives were obtainable through comic books approved by the industry's new code authority was substantiated on two fronts yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped 1 to 6 points yesterday after fluctuating in a narrow range all day.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, Feb. 12 -- The first Nationalist troops from the Tachens arrived in Keelung, North Formosa port, yesterday, aboard the Washburn, a Seventh Fleet cargo ship. The Washburn brought 1,185 regulars and a small cargo of military equipment and supplies.
Harry Kessler is a complex machine whose cogs first turned in St. Louis fifty-four years ago. If he would hold still long enough for you to take him apart, you'd have eight main pieces.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A current New York milk hearing, urgently sought by state dairymen for months, was abruptly canceled by the Agriculture Department today.
MIAMI, Feb. 11 -- The stewards did a thorough job of number-juggling after Hialeah's seventh race today, and the favorite that had finished third wound up with first money.
A one-armed jeweler used his right fist with punishing effect against a two-armed thug yesterday. In doing so he thwarted an attempt to rob him of gems worth $7,000 to $10,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- The House of Representatives Un-American Activities Committee urged Congress today to make it easier to put members of the Communist party in jail.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 9 -- The giant ten-engined B-36 bomber, once described by the Navy as a "billion-dollar blunder," has justified the faith of the Air Force.

New Yorkers must have felt an inner warmth of hometown pride when they learned yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company had shown the pioneering spirit to express readiness to build a $30,000,000 to $40,000,000 atomic power plant, to be situated south of Peekskill on the Hudson River.

Two freighters collided in low visibility off the approaches to New York Harbor at 1:30 P. M. yesterday. A garbled first report indicating that a passenger liner was involved alerted a fleet of rescue and observation craft an hour after the crash.
Testimony directly linking Henry W. (The Dutchman) Grunewald and four others in an alleged attempt to fix an income tax fraud case was begun by the government yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- Germans who acquired Jewish-owned property during the Hitler regime but had to return it opened today a campaign for compensation. About 97,000 such properties in Berlin have been taken from Germans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Dr. Ernst F. W. Alexanderson of Schenectady, N. Y., who is credited with achieving the first home reception of television in 1927, received a patent this week for a television color receiver.

Your columns recently carried a letter written by Representative Carroll Reece, chairman of the House Special Committee, which in the last Congress conducted an investigation of the tax-exempt foundations of the nation. The burden of Representative Reece's letter was an attack upon your newspaper for the manner in which it reported these hearings and upon me for the manner in which I participated in the hearings.

A banker and a labor leader last night received the Urban League's teamwork awards for 1955. They were Earl B. Schwulst, president of the Bowery Savings Bank, and Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.
Few American living rooms will boast color television sets this year unless engineering, production, pricing and programming near-miracles materialize soon.

A bronze mask of Abraham Lincoln, made from the last life mask of the martyred President, will go on exhibition today at the American Museum of Natural History. The sitting for the life mask, made by the sculptor, Clark Mills, took place on or near Lincoln's fifty-sixth birthday and about two months before he was assassinated.
Wayne F. Strong has been elected president of Iron Fireman Manufacturing Company. He was vice president in charge of manufacturing.

The Actors Studio, founded in 1947 as a noncommercial venture to assist gifted actors in studying their craft, has virtually completed arrangements for the purchase of a building to house its varied activities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Two of the State Department's experts on the Soviet Union are in line for important new diplomatic assignments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Dr. Fred Soper, director of the Pan American Sanitary Bureau, charged today that the United States was "deliberately" not cooperating in a campaign to eradicate yellow fever in this hemisphere. Countries in Central and South America, he added, are working on this project.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Frank Lloyd Wright, soothed by "affection and thoughtfulness I never knew existed," has decided he is appreciated in his native state after all.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Ronnie Delaney of Akron, Ohio, upset Johnny Saxton, the world welterweight champion from Brooklyn, in a non-title bout tonight. There were no knockdowns during the ten-rounder.
MARANA AIR BASE, Ariz., Feb. 10 -- This is a leading processing center of one of private industry's most unusual products: fliers for the United States Air Force.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet Monday to discuss further the fighting off the coast of China.
DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 11 (UP) -- Albert Woolson, the last survivor of 2,600,000 Union soldiers of the Civil War, celebrated his 108th birthday today by sleeping "late." He got up at 7 o'clock.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The crash of a Comet jet airliner into the Mediterranean thirteen months ago was explained by the bursting of the pressurized cabin due to metal fatigue, in the report of an official inquiry court today.

" Leonardo da Vinci," a twovolume work by Ludwig H. Heydenreich, will be issued Feb. 21I by Macmillan in the Holbein Art Books Series. The first volumeI l is a detailed study of Leonardo's life and his artistic and scientific genius.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Feb. 11 -- The claim that "automation" in industry will lead to mass unemployment was called "vicious propaganda" by Benjamin F. Fairless today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 11 -- In the last five months six judges of the Soviet Supreme Court have beer relieved of their duties and seven new judges appointed.

THE concert of the visiting Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, under the leadership of William Steinberg, apprised us again last night in Carnegie Hall of the manner in which Mr. Steinberg is building this fine orchestra to a state of constantly higher excellence and effectiveness in interpretation.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 11 -- President Eisenhower got good news but no quail today.
The thymus gland, one of the body's most mysterious organs, has at last yielded a vitamin-like chemical that may provide vital clues to the secret of growth, normal and abnormal.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The lightweight champion, Jimmy Carter, and the Boston welterweight contender, Tony De Marco, battled to a ten-round draw tonight in a non-title bout that drew 12,163 fans to the Boston Garden.
On the tenth anniversary of the Yalta Agreements, men who served their governments before their lands were overrun by communism warned yesterday against new concessions to "Soviet imperialism."

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Arvo Viitanen, a superbly conditioned little woodchopper from Finland, swept to a surprise triumph in the 15-kilometer cross-country ski competition of Europe's "Little Olympics" today.

The three-story building at 332 East Thirtieth Street has been sold by Sylvain Alliaud to Sidney Rife in a deal negotiated by Culver, Hollyday Co., brokers, who said the property was resold immediately to the Sigma Epsilon Delta Fraternity for national headquarters.

The National Labor Relations Board dismissed in Washington yesterday a charge that the New York Shipping Association and its members had discriminated against the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., in the hiring of dockers.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Pierre-Andre Lefaucheux, president and director-general of the nationalized Renault automobile factories, was killed this morning in an automobile accident near St. Dizier. He was 56 years old.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- A Westchester parkway authority to cure the ills of the outmoded parkway system was advocated today by County Executive James D. Hopkins.

Columbia had little difficulty downing Dartmouth, 63 -- 51, in an Ivy Basketball League game before 1,500 fans at Morningside Heights last night. Although this was not one of the better exhibitions by Coach Lou Rossini's Lions, the inexperienced Indians from Hanover, N. H., never really threatened.
DETROIT, Feb. 11 -- Passenger car production in the United States is scheduled to reach a record level this week.

PARIS, Saturday, Feb. 12 -- Pierre Pflimlin informed French President Rene Coty today he had accepted the task of forming a Cabinet. M. Pflimlin told the President that he would ask the National Assembly for endorsement Monday or Tuesday.
DES MOINES, Feb. 11 -- Trustees of the Herbert Hoover Foundation held their first annual meeting here today. Formal organization of the group was completed.
MOSCOW, Feb. 11 -- Cuts will be made this year in wholesale prices of products of Soviet heavy industry and in freight rates for heavy goods.

The blockfront apartment property at 706 Lefferts Avenue, corner of Troy Avenue, in Brooklyn is under contract of sale by Jerry Estates, Inc., to the Estate Securities Company. J. Milton Weinstein is the broker. The six-story building on plot 100 by 150 feet contains forty-nine suites.
Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the Shah of Iran, and Queen Soraya sailed for Europe yesterday after an eight-week visit to the United States.
MIAMI, Feb. 11 (AP) -- John Gray, Kansas City Athletics pitcher who does his own caddying, fired the best qualifying round today in the fifteenth national baseball players' golf tournament.

The Kansas Gas and Electric Company has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of $10,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds and 60,000 shares of $100 par value preferred stock. Both issues are to be sold at public sealed bidding.

LANDSCAPE paintings by Count Raben, a retired Danish diplomat, at the American-Scandinavian Foundation, 127 East Seventy-third Street, announce the fact that the artist is equally at home in Denmark, England and the south of France.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 -- The state of Andhra in southeastern India started today to choose between communism and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party.

SAUK CENTRE, Minn., Feb. 11 (AP) -- At least twenty persons were reported injured tonight when the Western Star, Seattle-Chicago passenger train of the Great Northern Railway, derailed near West Union, ten miles north-west of here. No one was reported seriously hurt.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 11 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer suggested tonight that the emergence of Nikita S. Khrushchev as the most powerful man in the Soviet Union might facilitate negotiations on the reunification of Germany.

Harold Johnson knocked out Paul Andrews of Buffalo with a solid right-hand punch to the jaw at Madison Square Garden last night. The Philadelphia light heavweight floored his opponent for the full count in 1:46 of the sixth of the scheduled ten-round event.

Gunnar Nielsen, Wes Santee and Freddy Dwyer will match speed in the mile run again tonight. Their return engagement and the other features of a star-sprinkled program arranged by the New York Athletic Club promise to fill Madison Square Garden with track enthusiasts.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A railroad president tonight called on the industry to cease its attacks on other transport and concentrate on improving its own operations.
State courts should be consolidated to speed and simplify justice, Allen T. Klots, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, said yesterday.

With a wealth of material readily available to any biographer of Abraham Lincoln -- his humble origins and dramatic career, his humor, kindness, courage and wisdom -- few writers have bothered to dig into the routine business Lincoln had to carry on through the urgent and tragic business of conducting a civil war.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Hundreds of British businessmen are waiting like nervous debutantes to receive a commercial accolade from Queen Elizabeth II.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The British Government put on view today tunnels for testing models of new aircraft at wind speeds approximating 3,000 miles an hour and disclosed that new tunnels being built would reproduce winds of nearly 7,000 miles an hour.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Wilfrid Pelletier conducting, young people's concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Pierre Monteux conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30, and National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Town Hall, 5:30.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Birdies on the final two holes enabled Bob Rosburg of San Francisco to take an undisputed lead in the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament at the end of thirty-six holes with a seven-under-par 133 today.
Ten policemen and three civilians were accused yesterday of engaging in a conspiracy to pervert and obstruct justice by a traffic courtesy-card racket.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- United States officials took a skeptical view today of an overture by the Soviet Union to withdraw its troops from Poland as well as Germany.

Hard-pressed itself for money, the city government through the Board of Estimate has done the gracious and generous thing in instructing the preparation of a ten-year lease at $1 a year for the benefit of the City Center of Music and Drama. It is also willing to forgive $57,000 of unpaid back rent if this is legal, or forget it if not.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The United States intends to retire from situations imperiling peace such as insistence on the occupation of islands near the Chinese mainland, Herbert Morrison said today.

Almost all coffee options tumbled the 2 - cents - a - pound daily limit in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Volume was 152,500 bags. May was the only position that did not register a limit decline, the month was off 195 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- L. Judson Morhouse, Republican State Chairman, proposed today that next year's spring and fall primary elections be combined on June 5.

Parents and teachers sometimes place too much faith in the "rational process" in trying to get across to children the importance of certain rules of behavior.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- A House Agriculture subcommittee moved today to relax controls on cotton plantings to relieve "hardships" among individual farmers.

Two Texas toll turnpike projects costing about $186,000,000 are to be financed late this month by the public sale of revenue bonds. The underwriting syndicates announced plans for the offerings yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- The list of occupations for which draft boards will grant deferments of military service is being cut in half.
A group of Swiss highway planners sampled the hurly-burly of New York traffic yesterday, and it made them homesick.
ORLEANS, France, Feb. 1 -- The United States Army is completing a supply network across France that at a moment's notice could support American forces in Germany.
Religious services this weekend will emphasize closer accord among the races as a proper way to commemorate the anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's birth.
