WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Federal Communications Commission took a wait-and see stand today on pay-as-you-see television.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Stock prices continued to recover today, though business showed little if any expansion. Sentiment again was influenced by the strength of Wall Street.
Two elderly men on their way to a Brooklyn synagogue and two middle-aged women leaving Manhattan buildings were the victims of mugging attacks yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- A proposal to tap the Barge Canal to irrigate New York's "fruit belt" posed new water problems today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that the Senate Juvenile Delinquency subcommittee had shelved a proposed report on the effect of television crime programs on youths.
Two years of peace on the waterfront seemed assured yesterday as tugboat operators and union officials reached agreement on a contract covering 4,000 deckhands, cooks and tugboat captains.
Eight per cent of the women in this country range in height from 5 feet 8 inches to 6 feet 3 inches.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits has held that John F. O'Connell; a Republican, may remain as chairman of the State Liquor Authority even though the body soon will be dominated by Democratic appointees.

A court ruling was issued this week that may well set a precedent with regard to company mergers and proposals for exchanges of stock. Judge Mark A. Sullivan Jr., of the Superior Court in Newark, N. J., issued a temporary injunction preventing the Niles-Bement-Pond Company from exchanging 631,715 of its common shares for 1,020,000 of Bell Aircraft Corporation's common stock.
Harvey Matusow tried yesterday to "undo the harm" he had caused many persons by falsely labeling them Communists before Congressional committees.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 11 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon's party was trapped in an elevator today in the Administration Building of the National Mexican University.

AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 11 (AP) -- A crack Maine Central Railroad train plowed into a washout near here tonight. It sent two empty milk cars hurtling into the Kennebec River but left four passenger coaches derailed on a steep embankment.

The method of selecting judges in New York State is a farce. The people, in overwhelmingly large percentage, don't know whom they are voting for. They are merely acting as a rubber stamp on decisions made for them by political leaders. There is no prospect that time will cure the defects of the present system.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Second Lieut. Dandridge M. Malone of Orlando, Fla., began his Regular Army career auspiciously today.
HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 11 -- A Birmingham, Ala., surgeon reported here today that a nylon "no-kink artery" had been used for the first time in a human being.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today approved financing proposed by the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation for a $163,000,000 line from New Mexico to deliver natural gas to the Pacific Northwest for the first time.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 11 -- J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was charged here last night with displaying a "vicious attitude toward intellectuals."
A broken rail made 35,000 commuters on the New York Central and The New Haven Railroads four to forty minutes late in the rush hour yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Representative Chet Holifield suggested today that Lewis L. Strauss and his fellow commissioners resign from the Atomic Energy Commission. This would end the "demoralizing dissension" within the vital agency, the California Democrat said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed opened an assault on President Eisenhower's liberalized foreign trade program today. He charged that some future President might abuse the powers it called for.

TWO approaches to abstraction are illustrated in the paintings by Morris Davidson at the Passedoit Gallery, 121 East Fifty-seventh Street, and those by Allen Wolf at the Barzansky Gallery, 664 Madison Avenue.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11 (AP) -- United States yachts swept the first five places today in the opening race of the Lightning Class competition for the Pan American Cup.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 11 -- Marshal Tito returned to Yugoslavia today and immediately restated his foreign policy in what he described as "the serious international situation."
The Rohm Haas Company lifted its earnings 90 per cen in 1954 :over the year before, while sales went up only 10 per cent, according to the preliminary annual report issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The televised Presidential news conference is here to stay, according to President Eisenhower's associates.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 11 -- A prolonged drought has brought near famine in many parts of southern Tunisia. Increasing alarm is felt in official circles here.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Wheat futures developed a steadier undertone today although there were fractional setbacks at times.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Nebraska Supreme Court ruled today that the state's "fair trade" act is unconstitutional.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 -- For some time perceptive Americans have been worried about the extent to which United States prestige and popularity are slipping in Asia. There is no doubt that our policy is disliked in India. In Pakistan the esteem in which we are generally held is not so high as we imagine.
The Ely Walker Dry Goods Company more than doubled its income last year, owing to the sale of its holdings in Pacific Mills.
Rare sixteenth to nineteenth century Americana and English literature of about the same span will be auctioned at 1:45 and 8 P.M. Wednesday at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

AZUSA, Calif.--Tourists approaching Los Angeles on transcontinental U.S. 66 may be surprised to find themselves going through this town, which many people have thought must be a figment of radio comedians' imaginations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Congress moved close to final action this week on the extremely delicate but urgent matter of raising its own salary level.
The Columbia Broadcasting System's newest offspring is out to show its parent this year that it is already passing through its adolescence in the business world.
The title of "Waterfront Man of the Year, 1954," was conferred last week on a modest physician who has devoted the last fortyeight years to keeping contagious diseases out of the United States.

THE New York City Ballet opens a four-week season at the City Center on Tuesday, its last engagement here until next November, after its European tour. From London the Festival Ballet pays us its only visit on Friday and Saturday over in Brooklyn.

For the sixth consecutive year, Long Island home builders in 1955 will erect at least 4 per cent of the new homes built in the nation, according to Emil M. Keen, new president of the Long Island Home Builders Institute.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12-- George Washington scored an 80-49 victory over Army tonight to run its winning streak to eight games.

WORCESTER, Mass, Feb. 12 --Holy Cross had an easy time tonight, scoring a 85-59 basketball victory over New York University.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 12 (AP)--Pat Gibson of Madison, Wis., newly crowned women's national champion, today streaked to an early lead in the North American outdoor speedskating championship.
Play in the Sherman Memorial indoor polo tournament started at the Squadron A Armory last night with the Huntington, L.I., trio defeating the Alliance, (Ohio) team, 16 to 3.

ALTHOUGH hospitalized here, Tyrone Power has three professional irons in the fire simultaneously. The recent local premiere of "The Long Gray Line" brought fresh dramatic laurels to his lengthy film career.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The Navy and Air Force announced today that normal operations were being resumed now that the evacuation of the Tachen Islands had been completed.
A re-examination of the ideals and motivating influences in Abraham Lincoln's life was urged yesterday by Rabbi Zev Zahavy. His sermon was one of several commemorating the date of Lincoln's birth.

IN his preface to this worthy addition to the field of Lincolniana, David Mearns of the Library of Congress observes that Lincoln's mastery of language was "surpassing" and that his "eloquence is as durable as the Republic which called it forth."

DETROIT, Feb. 12 (AP)--Henri Salaun of Boston, the runner-up last year, and Ernest Howard of Toronto, the winner in 1953, will play for the singles title in the national amateur squash racquets tournament tomorrow.
KUALA LIPIS, Malaya, Feb. 10--The British are winning the jungle war against the Communists. There is danger they will lose a war of subversion, however. This may now be under way.
Increasing numbers of American merchant seamen were beached within the last year by be generally slow conditions of be shipping industry and by the transfer of more than 130 ships to foreign flags.

CASCAIS, Portugal, Feb. 12-- Princess Maria Pia of Savoy, 20year-old daughter of exiled King Humbert of Italy, and Prince Alexander Karageorgevitch of Yugoslavia, were married today in the parish church of this fishing village.
Changes in the rules for depreciating new property will cost the Federal Government about $1,000,000,000, in taxes this year, one expert estimates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Political seasons descend upon Washington with the inexorable regularity of a church calendar, and the city this week settled into one of its accustomed periods of ritualistic calm as Republican statesmen in large numbers deployed over the countryside to invoke, each according to his fashion, the spirit of Abraham Lincoln, whose birthday anniversary is today.

The need for new shopping centers to serve the nation's expanding suburban markets will continue to grow with predicted population gains over the next twenty years. This is the prediction of Nelson E. Finch, president of the Harry Thoens Corporation, shopping center development and leasing specialists.

AIRPLANE crews are trained to handle emergencies, and getting out of trouble when it happens is considered, in the trade, just part of the job. But the crew of a United Airlines Convair 340 recently extricated their crippled plane from such an extreme and apparently hopeless emergency that the airline did a rare thing.

THE 26,000-ton liner Homeric entered the North Atlantic passenger shipping picture last week and completely captured the fancy and admiration of casual viewer and hardboiled travel agent alike. The enterprising Home Lines has again taken a vessel with a score of years in her wake and turned her into a cruise liner with a grace and appeal that matches the best in the trade.

BOCA GRANDE, Fla.--This community of some 500 permanent dwellers (including babes in arms) on Gasparilla Island, off the Florida lower west coast, is still classifiable today as fairly unknown. It is also entertaining--in an unusual sort of way, though lacking in night clubs or other organized hoopla.

Its armies number perhaps ten million. Its capitals are Moscow and Peiping--each a city that for centuries lagged behind in the march of history, now close allies in a challenge to the capitals of the West.

If Abraham Lincoln were President today, how would he face the problem of co-existence with the Communists who dominate half the world?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12-- Memo to Americans: Each one of you owns $26.30 worth of food and fiber in Uncle Sam's storage. In addition, each American has $18.20 invested in loans outstanding to farmers.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 12-- Manhattan took an early 13point lead tonight and went on to set back Canisius, 66--59. The game was the second in a Memorial Auditorium basketball doubleheader before 7,687 fans.
St. Francis' reserve power proved too much for the City College basketball team to handle and the Beavers went down to a 94-79 defeat last night at the Beavers' gymnasium.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12--For three hours this afternoon, the ninety-piece Student Concert Band at Yale University gave a special peformance for more than one hundred music educators in order to prove a point.

HOLLYWOOD. THE technicians still are on the march in Hollywood. Twentieth Century-Fox is far from finished with its CinemaScope developments. At the moment, work is progressing on a new type of camera using a single strip of 35-mm. film which, it is said, will give the CinemaScope image as much height as pictures made in the Todd-AO process.

The discovery of what appears to be a powerful new weapon against tuberculosis was reported in Atlanta, Ga., last week. The compound is an antibiotic named cycloserine, which apparently blocks one of the nutrients essential to the life of the tubercle bacillus.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12--Changes of policy and changes of personnel come in this country like flashes of political lightning. These flashes briefly illuminate past occurrences, reveal the significance of current events and sometimes light up the future.

IN 1946, Joseph Wechsberg published a moving, brilliantly written account of his return to his home-town, Moravia Ostrava (Maehrisch Ostrau), after an absence of fourteen, fateful years. As in his earlier stories in The New Yorker, almost every ounce of sentiment in "Homecoming" was set off by an equal measure of irony.
President Eisenhower's program for moderate tariff reductions under a three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act will face its first real test in the House this week.

THIS enchanting, sincere and beautifully constructed novel is certainly Colette's most nearly autobiographical, although friends and contemporaries have leave to doubt that, as the publishers claim, it was her "favorite." Too close to intimate pain to be a favorite, "La Vagabonde" explores, with Colette's infinite patience and precision, the beating heart of woman in an age when love is not passionate romance nor tender dream but an abiding duel.
BERLIN, Feb. 12--Dr. Otto Suhr, the new Mayor of Berlin, started this week a fight against unemployment.

PHOENIX, Ariz.--With all the palm trees growing around this winter vacationland and in the Valley of the Sun, one might think that they were a part of the native desert scene. But they aren't. They are more like the tourist who comes to Arizona, decides he likes it and stays.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 12-- The Turkish-Iraqi treaty, to be signed this month in Baghdad, will obligate the signatories to "collaborate in order to oppose by joint measures any aggression directod against them, whatever its source."

Private financing for the restoration of blighted areas is advocated by Irving H. Lurie, president of the Lurie Mortgage Corporation. He said his company is prepared to entertain applications for temporary first mortgage building loans for new construction or alterations anywhere in Manhattan.

LONDON, Feb. 12--The British Government has proposed to the Soviet Union that Nationalist China be invited to the international conference on Formosa suggested by the Soviet Union, according to authoritative sources.
John A. Miller has been appointed assistant general manager of marketing for the Esso Standard Oil Company. Gordon D. Donald has been named manager of division sales.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Much of the current concern over the Formosa question seems to center around the status of Formosa rather than around the immediate danger of a large-scale war. By maintaining the uncertainty of the legal status of Formosa many seem to think, including officials in high places, that the action of the United States in the Formosa Strait will be justified.

The first important legislative step toward enactment of the President's reciprocal trade program has now been successfully taken with a 20-to-5 vote approving the measure in the House Ways and Means Committee. There is good reason to hope that by the end of this week H.R. 1 will be safely through the House and on its way to the Senate.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP)--Headquarters of the American Medical Association said today the association "still believes" the proposed medical reinsurance program advocated by President Eisenhower "will not achieve the desired results."

WHEN I was a younger playwright, I had a bee in my Irish bonnet about reforming people through the medium of the stage. I suppose I caught the bug from such dramatizing conversationalists as Bernard Shaw and Alexis Tolstoy, and ignored the warnings of true dramatists like J.M. Synge, who never wanted to reform anybody.
The 146th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln was celebrated here yesterday in ceremonies at Union Square and Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

"HE was a pint-sized Robinson Crusoe with a jet black beard and the eyes of a mystic. His only clothing was a pair of ragged pants. His body was deeply sun-tanned, and on his head sat a bleached and shrunken canvas hat.

THE questions precipitated by the resignation of Lincoln Kirstein as managing director of the City Center of Music and Drama are questions that now have to be answered by the board of directors of that institution, of which Mayor Wagner of New York is president.

THE Twenty-first Annual New York International Salon of Photography sponsored by the Pictorial Photographers of America will be held April 2-17 at the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue. Eligible entries, which must be in by March 12, include blackand-white, natural color and hand-colored prints.

Bulganin for Malenkov Two years and three weeks have passed since the Moscow radio put forth this announcement: The heart of the comrade and inspired continuer of Lenin's will, the wise leader and teacher of the Communist party and the Soviet people, Josef Vissarionovich Stalin, has stopped beating.

JOHN L. LEWIS, last of the old-line labor barons, was 75 years old yesterday. The man who has commanded more idolatry and more hatred than any union leader in the country's history approaches the end of his career with domain shrunken, dream shattered, ambition unslaked and temper far more amiable than when his orders sent a half-million coal diggers popping in and out of the mines with such dizzying frequency they seemed jet-propelled.

CENTER MORICHES, L.I., Feb. 12--Herbert Raymond Smith, a former State Assemblyman from Bronxville, N.Y., and a retired lawyer, died here today in a convalescent home after a long illness. His age was 78.

As more spring goods are ordered it becomes clear that color is playing a major role in spurring sales in both men's and women's wear, resident buying offices report. Sheer fabrics look promising for all types of women's wear.

Search for Premier In Paris last week French politicians were going through the familiar ritual of Government crisis. Would-be Premiers shuttled back and forth between the Assembly and President Rene Coty's Elysee Palace.

"BIOGRAPHY," wrote Boswell, who ought to know, "occasions a degree of trouble far beyond that of any other species of literary composition." He was, of course, thinking of himself, and of the kind of biography that he was to create, but the observation is valid enough for biography in general, even for biographies in brief.

A furnished apartment is on display at Pierce Manor, a 360unit garden - apartment development under way in Elizabeth, N.J. The model two-bedroom unit was decorated by Dorothy Draper, interior designer.

TODAY I should like to make some marginal comments on a provocative article which appeared in these pages two weeks ago. An English novelist who is also a physicist, Mr. C. P. Snow, had some interesting things to say about the impact of science upon the writing of fiction.
CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 12 (AP)-- Cheyney (Pa.) State Teachers College defeated Rutgers of South Jersey today, 71--48, in a basketball game that tested five proposed changes in court rules.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP)-- Gen. Alfred H. Gruenther said today that the United States' military reserve system "is one of the weakest in the entire North Atlantic Treaty Organization."
THE devil will be depicted as a sophisticated, sly, incorrigible optimist and a man of good taste in a television program being developed by the Theatre Guild and the American Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP)-- Key Democrats on the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee said today the Formosa crisis had killed off prospects for an early effort to cut income taxes.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Republican State Chairman, L. Judson Morhouse, tonight accused Governor Harriman of breaking "another of his pledges" by vetoing this week a G.O.P. measure to continue state aid to schools on the present basis.

TRAVELERS planning European trips early in the season can outwit the weather and catch a premature breath of spring simply by including in their itineraries a visit to the Scilly Islands. The Scillies, lying about twenty-five miles off Britain's Cornish coast, can be recommended at any time of the year to people who like simple surroundings and peace and quiet.

WHEN a painter turns to photography, people often assume that he is deserting a legitimate art for a less demanding medium. In my own case, this has certainly not been so, for I have continued working at both arts and have found them extremely compatible and mutually helpful.

The municipal radio station WNYC began yesterday the eleven-day music festival in which it will broadcast more than seventy -five programs of American music. The first of the programs was a public concert at Town Hall which attracted more than 1,550 persons.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews announced yesterday thirty-five winners of its annual awards. They were chosen from all divisions of mass communication media "for outstanding contributions promoting the cause of good-will and understanding among the people of our nation."

"PROPAGANDA?" said the bluesuited Chinese official, sipping thin tea beneath the portrait of Chairman Mao. "Of course; intensely important. What is propaganda but education? But as to who runs it-- I suppose you could say the Government."
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12-- The Sierra Club came out punching this week in the big battle over the Upper Colorado River project.

PARIS, Feb. 12--Pierre Pflimlin, Popular Republican leader, who is trying to assemble a new French Government, began making Cabinet appointments today. The work was slow and the Premier-designate was not expected to announce his Ministers until tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12-- Center Jim Francis controlled the boards at the right moments tonight to lead the Dartmouth basketball team to a 78-70 upset victory over Penn, Ivy League leader, at the Palestra.

FOR most people, immortality means personal survival beyond death. The soul leaves the earthly body and continues its conscious existence in another state or place, the form of which has been variously imagined by different classes of believers.
Moscow boasted of its military strength last week as its dramatic shifts in power confessed political weakness.

THE term "FIPEX" is a new word to philatelists, but during the coming months it will be read and spoken often by collectors the world over. It is the contraction, announced last week, for Fifth International Philatelic Exhibition.

We have reason to be proud of the promptness, skill and courageous and specific restraint with which the withdrawal from the Tachen island group was carried out by the Chinese Nationalists with the powerful aid and cover of our Seventh Fleet. It is a satisfaction to be able to say and to hear "mission accomplished" when the mission has been both difficult and dangerous.

SARASOTA, Fla.--Outside this town, just off Highway 301, it is Circus Day all winter long. It is Circus Day with a difference, to be sure, on account of no spangles, and hardly a clown. But there are lions and elephants and performing horses.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP)--Ike Canty and Phil Haughey led Harvard to its first home basketball victory of the season tonight, a 69-57 Ivy League triumph over Princeton.
THIS is the time of year when it is interesting to experiment and force some branches and twigs into bloom indoors. Often it is quite surprising what can be accomplished with little effort.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The United States sold India ten tons of heavy water today for use in research on peaceful applications of atomic energy.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 12--Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived in Guatemala today from Mexico. He came here bearing goodwill greetings from the United States.

IT is our great good fortune to have Vicente Escudero back in this country for a tour after twenty years' absence, still unpredictable (his return itself was considered in advance to be merely a managerial fantasy), still breaking with tradition in his very devotion to keeping it alive, still a master of his art.

MORAL for this week: If you're a novice mystery writer, pick an unusual background which you know well. Then the reader, bored by an endless succession of English villages and American nightclubs, may be sufficiently fascinated by your background material to overlook weaknesses of construction and characterization.

WHAT chance would a country five miles long and three miles wide, whose anachronistic army of twenty-four (more like a platoon than an army)--most of whom are outfitted with bows and arrows and all of whom are caparisoned in fourteenth-century armor--have against the United States in a modern war?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The United States and Britain agree that no useful purpose would be served by a conference on Formosa from which Nationalist China was excluded.

IN just twenty months, November, 1956, American shooters will be competing in the Olympics against the finest marksmen in the world. In the light of our showing at the last Olympics and the recent International matches, it would seem that tomorrow would not be too late to begin our plans and training.

WHERE there's salvia, there's fire--either the bright red torches of the annual S. splendens varieties or the blue flame of S. farinacea. Any of these salvias are valued for the gay brilliance of their blossoms which never shrink unseen in the border.

The Federal Communications Commission has taken a wise step in ordering the beginning of consideration, next May 9, of one of the thorniest problems ever to face this administrative body, the problem of toll television. There are obviously important questions of fact and of law which the F.C.C. must decide, and it can reach decisions only after all groups involved, including the great mass of us who are simply called "the public," have been heard.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 10-- Oregon Republicans continue to support President Eisenhower's "partnership" plan for power development in the Pacific Northwest.

LONDON, Feb. 7--The fossilized hand bones of what promises to be the most important ape in the pedigree of man have been found. They are being dissolved out of a slab of gray rock in the geological department of the British Museum of Natural History.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 12--Dr. James B. Conant proposed today some changes in United States education to meet the challenge of what he called a world divided yet contracted.
BERNE. THE news out of Berlin and Vienna these days points to an East-West "Saengerkrieg" in the offing, the like of which has not been seen in Germany since the collapse of the Third Reich.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 12--A new generation of labor leaders fashioned the unity compact signed here this week. The men most responsible for the original split were absent or dead. The inheritors of their power felt no need to keep alive the hatreds that inflamed relations between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations for twenty years.

Department store sales in the United States in the week ended Feb. 5 were 1 per cent less than in the like week a year earlier, according to the Federal Reserve Board. In the previous week they were 2 per cent higher, in the four weeks ended Feb. 5 they were 7 per cent higher and in the year to that date they were 8 per cent higher than in the like periods of 1954.
NEWARK, Feb. 12--Protection against "tax lightning" by means of a balanced budget and a capital improvement structure was proposed today as the mainstay of this city's fiscal policy.

TO THE EDITOR: I enjoyed reading Ralph S. Banay's article "Should Prisons Be Abolished?" (Jan. 30) very much. I agree completely with Dr. Banay's thesis and his conclusions that we should substitute for prisons a new kind of hospital-like institution to which those with antisocial impulses could go for appropriate therapy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10-- Completion of a comprehensive $2,500,000 survey of the San Francisco Bay area by the Army Corps of Engineers, with recommendations, by the winter of 1958-59 was forecast this week.

MERCURY, Nev. OF all the myriad communities that dot the face of the earth, this one is closest to that momentous preoccupation of mankind which has acquired the generalized label of "the atomic bomb."

TAVARES, Fla.--A comparatively new tourist attraction in central Florida is the 400-acre recreation and wildlife area that has been opened to the public in the Ocala National Forest by the Alexander Springs Association.

HAVERFORD--High Standards Calling for high academic standards in the face of increasing enrollment, Dr. Gilbert F. White, president of Haverford College, last week recommended more small colleges in more communities instead of enlargement of existing institutions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The Eisenhower Administration's policy on the Formosa issue clearly has been a great tour de force, in the domestic sense certainly, and perhaps in the world sense as well.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP)--Polly Riley, the links star from Fort Worth, Tex., won the Palm Beach Women's amateur golf tournament for the third time today. She defeated 18-year-old Joanne Goodwill of Plymouth, Mass., by 1 up in the final.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 12 (AP)-- Minnesota's five clawed back from the edge of defeat twice today to subdue Illinois, 78--71, in double overtime and stay in the Big Ten driver's seat.
BONN, Feb. 12--Two events which occurred within the week illustrate the neurotic character of Bonn politics in relation to the problems of armament and reunification.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 12 (UP)--Tony Seiler of Austria left caution behind him on a mountain-top today and whizzed to a record triumph as he and his countrymen made a near sweep of the downhill event in Europe's "Little Olympics."
It will be an all-Pakistani final in the national professional squash racquets championship at the New York A.C. today. It also will be a brother act.

ACROSS-SECTION sampling of the work being done by photographers of Magnum Photos, Inc., whose staff includes such leaders as Henri Cartier-Bresson and Ernst Haas, is on display through March 1 at the Village Camera Club, 65 Bank Street.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12--Yale swimmers shattered the world 400-yard free-style relay mark at the Yale pool tonight. In a race against the clock, the four Elis lowered the standard by threetenths of a second. Their time was announced as 3:21.3.

The seventy-ninth Westminster Kennel Club dog show will occupy Madison Square Garden tomorrow and Tuesday. It is America's most distinguished bench event, although not always its largest. Some years it is surpassed in numbers by Morris and Essex.

The Riverside Branch of the New York Public Library opened its doors at 190 Amsterdam Avenue fifty years ago. A celebration of its anniversary--and also an observance of the tenth year of its community discussion program, one of the earliest in the library system--will be held there Tuesday at 8 P.M.

PRESUMABLY there is always a market for books about the stories of opera--and it is a market that Ernest Newman, England's distinguished writer on music, undoubtedly has found profitable. In recent years he has published "The Wagner Operas" and "More Stories of Famous Operas."
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 12 --Army swept all five field events today to defeat Princeton in track, 64-45. The meet was keenly contested, with the outcome in doubt until the last two events.

New York's sick and injured pets will benefit from the proceeds of the seventh annual spring frolic, a tea dance, given by the Humane Society of New York for its hospital and free clinic for animals. The dance will be held April 15 at the Plaza.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12--Frank S. Sims, vice president of the CocaCola Bottling Company of Chicago and president of the Civic Federation here, died today in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 50 years old.

To the Drama Editor: Last Sunday, you printed a letter by Members of The Friday Drama Group in Montclair, N.J. These ladies wished to "protest vigorously" the theme of "House of Flowers." So far, no quarrel. * * * The picture conjured of the Friday Drama Group, their offended sensibilities at a Stradivarian pitch, sitting down all in a huffandapuff to write a letter to The Times, is, come to think of it, rather endearing.

ONCE upon a time George Halas was the owner, coach, captain and star end of the Chicago Bears. About a quarter of a century ago Coach Halas dismissed Player Halas. Just a few weeks ago Owner Halas summoned Coach Halas into his office, transfixed him with steely glare and issued an order.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12-- Laymen, inclined to scoff at "the ivory tower'' of the research scientist might well profit by a visit to a small brick laboratory on the grounds of the Institute for Advanced Study here.

Leo van Munching had a big job. The American market was a-froth with beer, domestic and imported brands, all doing quite well. His task was to introduce still another beer, Heineken's, a premium beverage.
Robert G. Hess has been appointed vice president-operations of the Pesco Products division of Borg-Warner Corporation.

Excellent work by their big men, Ray Felix and Nat (Sweetwater) Clifton, led the New York Knickerbockers to an 88-82 victory over the Fort Wayne Pistons last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The triumph moved Joe Lapchick's club into a second-place tie with the Boston Celtics in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.

THE primary purpose of a cookbook is to inspire and instruct the reader to produce (or at least partake of) better food. In this all four books under consideration succeed admirably. TO THE EDITOR: SIR PHILIP MAGNUS passed by a great opportunity in his "Gladstone: A Biography" to enhance still further Gladstone's character and at the same time do justice to another of the great souls of England, Sir William Watson.

LOS ANGELES -- Despite its traditional association with palm trees, California possesses every altitude known in the continental United States, from the highest point (Mount Whitney, 14,495 feet) to the lowest (Death Valley, minus 280 feet).

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 13--The stock market was not affected by the political changes in Moscow last week. There were no signs of wholesale liquidation. On the contrary, keen demand developed on Thursday, especially in internationals, which again were bought for American account.
BOSTON, Feb. 13--Three centuries of economic development have made New England complex, resilient and dynamic.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Feb. 12--These islands of the Dutch West Indies are annoyed at the insistence of Latin-American countries in the United Nations that they be regarded as colonies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- This week the Congress of the United States is going to start doing right by a deserving group of people--the Congress of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--Following are excerpts from the report of the (Hoover) Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government on "Personnel and Civil Service": CHAPTER I The Civil Service System as It Stands Today The Federal Government as of June 30, 1954, employed 2,345,718 civilians in almost every conceivable type of occupation and its total annual payroll is approximately $9,000,000,000.

KUOPIO, Finland, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Rimma Zhukowa of Russia, holder of the women's world championship for all - around, 5,000 and 3,000-meter speed skating, today won top honors in the women's world speed skating championships.

"Air Commando," the personal experiences of Serge Vaculik, a French paratrooper, will be published March 17 by Dutton. The author is a Czech who grew up in France. After the fall of France, he joined the Free French forces in England and became a member of a picked group of paratroopers assigned behind the enemy lines.

WHEN a tourist starts to think in terms of the Florida training camps, which open operations a fortnight hence, his mind flits about in various directions. One fellow he'll be meeting eventually is Charles Walter Dressen, the quondam letter-writer from Brooklyn. But Charlie will be wearing a different uniform this time. He'll be wearing the spangles of the Washington Senators.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13--Elia Kazan was cited tonight by the Screen Directors Guild of America as the top man in his profession last year for his direction of "On the Waterfront"

DENVER, Feb. 13 (AP)--The Western League adopted a 150game baseball schedule today. Gov. Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado decided to continue as president and treasurer of the league "until everything's straightened out."
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 13 (AP)-- Tommy Bolt of Houston, Tex., scored two birdies in a row to win the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament with a 14-under-par 266 today.

The Rangers completely outclassed the Canadians of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Conceding a first-period goal to the Flying Frenchmen, the New York skaters struck back with force to carry off a 4-to-1 decision, to the delight of a crowd of 11,859.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP)--Patty Berg shot 73, one stroke under par, today to cling to the lead after fifty-four holes of the seventy-two-hole St. Petersburg women's open golf tournament.
The American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., announced yesterday that its 1954 Heywood Broun Award had been won by Anthony Lewis, reporter for The Washington Daily News.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Smooth integration of labor's two federations may take years after the merger itself is finally approved.
At 7:45 o'clock tonight the curtain will go up on the premiere of "The Immortal Husband" at the Theatre de Lys.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 13 (UP) --Billy Uhl tossed in 31 points tonight to spark the Dayton Flyers to a 94--79 victory over Loyola of the South. Before the game Uhl had received a threatening phone call ordering him to throw the game or face the consequences.

When do-it-yourself fans begin to lose faith in their talents, they might look in at an East Side shop where the proprietors practice what they preach: "Why do it all yourself when we can do it for you."

Brazil will soon have a new dollar-earning export-burlap. Systematic cultivation of jute, the source of this fabric, was started in the Amazon Valley by Japanese planters about eight years ago. Production now is in excess of domestic requirements.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 13--A program to raise $60,000,000 for the Jewish Theological Seminary of America during the next ten years was adopted here today.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 13--Four ancient scrolls, including the oldest known manuscript of the Book of Isaiah, have been acquired by Israel, Premier Moshe Sharett announced tonight.
A device designed to save fuel and increase speed has been installed in this country on two ships.

MIAMI, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Alvin Dark, captain of the New York Giants, defeated Al Lopez, manager of the Cleveland Indians, on the 22nd hole today in the final of the fifteenth national baseball players' golf tournament.
A Protestant minister yesterday entered the controversy over the oration delivered at the funeral service of Serge Rubinstein.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 13 -- Heavy selling on foreign accounts is the explanation given here for the recent price declines for most German stocks and bonds. The downtrend has come during a period when investment securities have been firm on all leading stock exchanges outside Germany.

It is good news that this country has sold ten tons of heavy water to India. This is a practical step toward furthering international cooperation in harnessing the atomic nucleus to serve men's needs. In this case, the heavy water will facilitate Indian construction of an atomic reactor producing radioactive materials needed for research in varied fields.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 13 (AP)--Antti Hivarinen of Finland soared to victory over thirty-eight other ski jumpers from seven nations today to wind up the three-day Olympic preview competition.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--A sweeping Government employment program to attract and hold more top-level talent was recommended to Congress today.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13--A noted spiritual leader tonight called on religious institutions of all faiths to pursue an intensive role in the civic and political affairs of the nation.
A forty-six-page "how-to-doit" booklet on organizing a parent education program will be published today by the Child Study Association of America.
A Roman Catholic preacher reminded other preachers yesterday of their "sacred responsibility to sow, not to scatter, the seed, which is the Word of God."

HARRISON E. SALISBURY, a Minnesota boy who wanted to be a newspaper man and became a famous one, returned to this country last autumn after spending nearly six years as the Moscow correspondent of this newspaper. After so strenuous an assignment it would have been understandable if Mr. Salisbury had taken a six-month vacation.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (UP)-- The Detroit Red Wings moved within a point of the National Hockey League lead tonight with a 5-to-1 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks before 5,860 fans.
MIAMI, Feb. 13--It was 8:30 A. M. Ten horses were being led around the walking ring outside Hialeah's barn. James E. Fitzsimmons was in the middle of the ring, watching the horses walk.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13--If the prairie Republicans are blazing with third-party sentiment, they kept the fires well damped this Lincoln Day week-end here.

PARIS, Feb. 13--Pierre MendesFrance, retiring French Premier, said last week that one of the most important events of his term of office had been the development of oil discoveries in the south of France.
PARIS, Feb. 13--There has been speculation within the last week about the future of Pierre Mendes-France, whose Government met defeat in the National Assembly Feb. 5.

SCRANTON, Pa., Feb. 13-- Worthington Scranton, financier, industrialist, civic leader and a member of the family from which this city received its name, died today in St. Mary's Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Scranton, who was spending the winter in Florida, suffered a heart attack Friday.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 13 (AP)--Willie Mays, slugging outfielder of the New York Giants, collected four hits and drove in three runs, including the gamewinning tally, as Puerto Rico clinched at least a tie in the pionship today by edging Cuba, Caribbean professional cham7--6.
A 15-year-old boy was shot and killed by an off-duty rookie patrolman in Brooklyn yesterday after a teen-age beer party.

The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, called yesterday for a "grassroots" movement to break down "the walls of partition" that separate persons of differing religious denomination.

Eleven stakes, including three $50,000 events, have been approved by the Queens County Jockey Club and will be presented during the 24-day summer racing meeting, starting June 13 at Aqueduct. The stakes will be worth $310,000 in added money.

Irving Maidman, a heavy investor in realty in the area just west of Times Square, has added to his holdings there through purchase of the restaurant building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 308 West Forty-second Street from the Ludin Realty Company.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13--The uninterrupted evacuation operations in the Tachen Islands caused war fears to fade last week, and with that incentive gone the grain markets found limited buying support. Long lines accumulated under war fears were unloaded at declining price levels.
Mayor Wagner's charge that the Federal Housing Administration owes the city about $10,000,000 in slum clearance housing funds was supported yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.
Prostitution was viewed yesterday as a social problem that could be solved by a preventive program rather than by arrests.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13--The Democratic party plans to open its 1956 convention on July 23, three weeks earlier than previously planned.

A mixture of fine importations and American-breds of equal quality came through for triumphs in the annual pre-Westminster specialties of nine terrier parent clubs at the 212th AAA Group Armory yesterday.
THE Concert Society of New York presented to its listeners good performances of three chamber music works at its fourteenth concert of the season late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

THE Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble gave another of its excellent concerts on Saturday night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. As in the past, the musicians of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony showed their flair for locating new contemporary works of good quality.
ALBANY, Feb. 13--An intense behind-the-scenes battle between railroad and trucking interests is being waged in the Legislature.
Cotton prices in the domestic market last week held to a narrow trading range. Final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 6 to 11 points, or 30 to 55 cents a bale.
MIAMI, Feb. 13--Negroes were forced to leave a Republican dinner here last night celebrating the birth of the Emancipator of the slaves.

People generally have an avid interest in crimes and those who commit them--before they go to jail. The interest flares up again if some of them break out. But as to what happens to them while they are inside, the public cares relatively little. Yet there are compelling reasons why "those outside" should care.

LAS VEGAS, Feb. 13--The thirty-second, atomic explosion on this continent will be set off in the Navada desert on Tuesday morning. It is scheduled for 8:45 A.M. Eastern Standard for 8:45 A. M. Eastern standard time weather permitting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) --The Veterans Administration reminded veterans of the Korean War today of deadline dates of eligibility for certain benefits.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The Democratic announcement of a change in the date of the convention will be conditional, linked with an appeal to a few states to change existing laws so as to allow later nominating conventions and shorter electoral campaigns.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13-- The feeling here is that political changes in Moscow may strengthen the Sino-Soviet alliance. Khrushchev and Bulganin visited Peiping last October. They negotiated economic concessions and retrocession of Port Arthur.
Madison Square Garden will become America's foremost dog house this morning. It will remain that until close to midnight tomorrow while the seventyninth Westminster Kennel Club show lasts.

ROME, Feb. 13--Premier Mario Scelba and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino left by train today for London, where they will be guests of the British Government for a five-day official visit. They will pause briefly in Paris to visit the North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquaters and attend the session of the Atlantic Council.

Antoine Dadone, 74-year-old president of the Vendome, today opens the doors of his famous delicacy shop at a new address, 15 East Forty-eighth Street. It is the fourth site his store has occupied on the East Side since Mr. Dadone bought it in 1914.
The plot in the mile has thickened with Freddy Dwyer's smashing victory over Gunnar Nielsen and Wes Santee in the New York Athletic Club games.

Dr. Gabriel S. Hauge, President Eisenhower's administrative assistant for economic affairs, is not quite 41 years old. He thinks of himself as a young man. But yesterday, surrounded by a group of collegiate economists, he began to wonder.
A warning against "quick and easy" cures for juvenile delinquency will be submitted today to the State Legislature by the Prison Association of New York.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, Off Antarctica, Feb. 12 -- For ten days this icebreaker has been steaming eastward around Antarctica to the Atlantic coast. There has been no chance for exploration, but this has been a busy ship nevertheless.
Barrage of Quality Hill, a fawn and white dog, was named best of breed at the twelfth annual specialty show of the American Boxer Club last night at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.
A Negro soprano, Adele Addison, is one of the thirteen new singers engaged for the spring season of the New York City Opera Company, which opens March 17.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 13--Princeton University is undergoing a thorough examination of its curriculum and facilities. This is in anticipation of the coming "bull market for higher education" described by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton, in his latest report to its board of trustees.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 13-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer indicated tonight that the United States had rejected a proposal to sound out the Soviet Union on a four-power conference.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 13 (UP)--Two new tankers collided in fog early today fifteen miles off the Southern California coast.
AFTER the televising of the nominations for the "Oscar" motion picture awards, the video and film industries can stop worrying about competition. The only thing they have to fear is cooperation.
To make high-precision experimental transistors, the Bell Telephone Laboratories has created a "Mr. Meticulous."
ALBANY, Feb. 13--Governor Harriman called today for new state laws to curb the fire hazard caused by portable oil heaters.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Monday, Feb. 14--Chinese Nationalist artillery on Quemoy engaged Communist batteries on near-by Tateng Island in a three-hour exchange yesterday. This was the longest exchange in weeks.
A deal has been made for "Adventure Theatre," a live drama series, to make its debut over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network on Sunday, April 3, from 10 to 10:30 P.M.
SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Feb. 13 (AP)--Jay Hasbrouck of Newburgh, N. Y., the 1954 intermediate champion, won the senior men's title of the North American outdoor speed skating championship today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Three of the twelve members of the Hoover Commission on Government Organization dissented today from the report to Congress.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 13 --Competing with his left forearm in a cast, Arthur Devlin of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds captured the Brattleboro Outing Club's open invitation ski jump today.

The people of New York State are accustomed to expecting little in the way of visible accomplishment from the Legislature in its early weeks. The present session is now five weeks old and the pace appears alarmingly slow. The general impression given is of a political stalemate between the Democratic Governor and the Republican majority in the Legislature.

ROME, Monday, Feb. 14--A Belgian airliner carrying twentynine persons disappeared last light a few moments after radioing Ciampino Airport that it was preparing for a routine landing. Four Americans and an Italian beauty queen were listed among the twenty-one passengers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government is a twelvemember body headed by former President Herbert Hoover. It was created by Congress in 1953.
Howard Butcher 3d, Hill School alumnus, class of '19, certainly is sold on squash as a sport.
PARIS, Monday, Feb. 14-- Pierre Pflimlin, the young Popular Republican candidate to succeed Pierre Mendes-France as French Premier, gave up his efforts to form a Cabinet early today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)-- Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that a special spot check of Federal Reserve member banks showed that $7,245,000,000 of their loans--about one-eighth of the more than $60,000,000,000 outstanding--were "apparently secured by stocks and bonds."
LONDON, Feb. 13--Concern over the fate of the Paris agreements to arm West Germany has been developing within official circles here during the last three weeks.

Great Britain's answer to the Soviet Union on the proposal that a ten-Power conference be held to discuss the "dangerous situation" in the Formosa area seems to us to be close to a model in diplomatic correspondence. The proposal, naturally, was not accepted, as the Soviet Union knew that it would not be when it was made.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 13--Vice President Richard M. Nixon paid tribute to the Roman Catholic Church the world over today as "one of the major bulwarks against communism and totalitarian ideas." In a conference with Msgr. Mariano Rossell y Arellano, Archbishop of Guatemala, Mr. Nixon said: "You were an inspiration to all people during the dark days of Communist domination here."
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 13 --The arrival of the New YorkBuffalo Thruway in Sleepy Hollow is jarring the countryside into wide-eyed wakefulness and some amazement.
MOSCOW, Monday, Feb. 14-- Soviet Government leaders declared today that friendship between their country and Communist China assumed "firstrate importance" in the present international situation.

Plans for a six-story apartment house have been announced in connection with the sale of a plot 39.6 by 100.5 feet at 33941 East Fifty-seventh Street in the Sutton Place section by the Sutton Fifty-seventh Street Corporation, J. Breitman, president.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The Hoover Commission's report was based on studies of a task force group.

The foreign exchange market was in the doldrums last week. The undertone was soft from its opening, resulting in a steady attrition of values. At least this applied to the British and Canadian remittances. On the Continent, the Netherlands guilder was weak, but others in that group were steady and little changed.

Michael J. Quill poured cold water yesterday on the agreement to merge the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
The Standard - Vacuum Oil Company made five new appointments over the week-end in its executive marketing staff, serving fifty countries in the Eastern Hemisphere.

The United States Maritime Administration is engaged in a comprehensive planning project for future merchant marine building and has come up with some preliminary ship designs. They will be used as a basis for discussion with shipping industry executives considering replacement tonnage.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $64,416,087,349. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
MADRID, Feb. 13--The Spanish Government has made clear that it is dissatisified with the amount of economic aid it has received from the United States.

AT three score ten and three, Jacob Rauch is one of the few master painters expert at realistically graining doors and walls. He has written books on the subject and has lectured on it. One of his better jobs was the graining on the swinging doors in the Long Island Rail Road waiting room below Pennsylvania Station, done twelve years ago.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 (UP)--Brian Cullen, a rookie, fired home his third goal of the season with less than two minutes to play to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-3 tie with the Boston Bruins tonight before a Boston Garden crowd of 10,500.

OTTAWA, Feb. 13--I walked into the pilots' room of the 139th Squadron, Fifty-first Wing of the United States Fifth Air Force, on Dec. 4, 1952, and found my name posted on the warning board for a mission the following morning. Our outfit was stationed about twenty miles south of Seoul.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits charged yesterday that Governor Harriman was seeking more taxing powers than were needed to balance the next state budget.

Taking a really comprehensive view of an important segment of the world economy has curious psychological effects on the reader. He becomes a Monday morning quarterback on a grand scale. Those poor little struggling humans! What a mess they have made of things!

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 13 (AP) --The Government has ordered the selection of South Vietnam's first post-war provisional Assembly. It will include representatives of all classes and sects and will meet in April.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13--Signs in the steel industry last week pointed to new output peaks in the current recovery phase. This view was bolstered by reports that new steel business was expanding rapidly in volume.
The cadet corps of the United States Military Academy came to town yesterday to attend a movie.

Trademarks of Love Like so many of our festivals, Valentine's Day has felt the cold hand of commercialization. But just as Mother's Day remains a tribute to Mater despite the extra sales help in the specialty shops, so does Valentine's Day continue as the day for lovers no matter how numerous the advertisements for the heart-shaped boxes of candy.

LONDON, Feb. 13--With the Russian political upheaval piled on top of the Formosa crisis, the continued weakness of sterling and the still prevalent fears of a further rise in money rates, the last week has been a testing time for the stock markets.
A Congregational group yesterday urged rejection of proposals to withdraw the United States from the United Nations if it recognizes Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, raised the question of leakage of Government secrets last week. He promptly was challenged by Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP)--The New York Knickerbockers defeated the Boston Celtics, 105-- 103, in a National Basketball Association thriller at Boston Garden today. Jim Baechtold dropped in a jump shot just before the final buzzer for the game-winning tally.

TOKYO, Feb. 13--Communist China is making a powerful propaganda bid for neutralist Asian support on the Formosa issue. It is appealing obliquely to sensitive nationalist and racist feelings in India, Burma and Indonesia.
The delinquency rate for youths over 16 years old in this city increased 52.7 per cent last year.
THE first of four concerts the Symphony of the Air will give in connection with radio station WNYC's sixteenth annual Festival of American Music took place late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12--Long negotiations for private foreign investments in Argentina's petroleum resources are at last coming to a head. Estimates vary on whether the talks will last another month or six months, but it is agreed that great progress has been made and that the end is coming into sight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--A new drive for the creation of a United States Academy of Foreign Service is under way in Congress.
Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice," missing from the repertory since the 1941-42 season, will return to the Metropolitan Opera Thursday evening, Feb. 24.

As in his Carnegie Hall concert last year, Wilhelm Backhaus addressed himself to Beethoven. And, again as last year, the piano playing was monumental. The veteran pianist, now more than 70 years old, plays with the ardor of youth, the musicianship of a master and the technique of a virtuoso.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 13--The Security Council will resume discussion tomorrow on a proposal to consider measures to end hostilities in islands off the China mainland. It will meet at 11:30 A. M.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 14--Vice President Richard M. Nixon recommended today stronger free trade unions in Guatemala as a deterrent to communism.
Michael J. Quill was chided yesterday for balking at the proposed merger of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor.
THE GOVERNOR Spoke briefly at annual Legislative Conference of State League of Women Voters. Received delegation of Rockland County residents protesting Thruway route.
A two-week seminar on newspaper advertising opened yesterday at the American Press Institute at Columbia University. The topic at the first session was rate structures.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14-- Clarence Gordon Morse was reported today to have been selected to be chairman of the Federal Maritime Board and Maritime Administrator.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 14 (AP)-- The Syracuse Nationals came from behind with three minutes to go tonight and defeated the Milwaukee Hawks, 82-81, in a National Basketball Association game.
OTTAWA, Feb. 14--On the fourteenth day after I was shot down over North Korea, the interpreter came into the room where I was being held in solitary confinement by the Chinese Communists.
NEWARK, Feb. 14--Several thousand commuters today won a reprieve until June 30 for trains on the West Shore Division of the New York Central System.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 14-- Bids on the old Stamford lighthouse were opened this afternoon in Boston. But no decision as to a new owner can be made until the Government has determined whether the structure could be defined as a "historical monument."

SECURITY COUNCIL Suspended its effort to stop fighting over islands off China, in view of Communist China's refusal to send a representative; rejected, 10 to 1, Soviet demand for withdrawal of United States forces from Formosa and other islands.
For the first time in the history of the American Stock Exchange, a chairman of the board has been elected for the fifth time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The gross national product was $357,000,000,000 in 1954, the Department of Commerce said today. This was about 2 per cent less than the record level of 1953 but 3 per cent above that for 1952.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 14 --A copy of the Bill of Rights occupies a place on the wall of the California Division of Architecture's office in Los Angeles.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 14 --Premier Adnan Menderes predicted today that an era of political harmony was destined to make Turkey a "real land of liberty."

Maurice Schwartz, producerdirector-actor of the former Yiddish Art Theatre, opens tonight at the Downtown National Theatre in the English-language presentation of "The Grass Is Always Greener," the Sholom Aleichem comedy.
The changing face of world shipping is pictured toy the latest statistical tables of Lloyd's Register of Shipping.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP)--Butcher hogs dropped 25 to 50 cents today selling around the low prices for several years in a slow trade.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 --F. Hugh Herbert, the playwright and scenarist, and Mark Robson, the director, have formed a partnership to produce a movie version of the stage comedy, "The Little Hut."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The new French Ambassador to the United States said today that ratification of the Paris agreements to rearm Germany would mark for France the beginning of a new post-war era.
ALBANY, Feb. 14--The cost of institutional care for juvenile delinquents would be shared equally by the state and New York City under bills introduced in the Legislature today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP)--Patty Berg shot a par 74 today for a 292 total to win the St. Petersburg women's open golf tournament by one stroke.

TRENTON, Feb. 14 (AP)--The New Jersey Supreme Court today voided rent controls that have been imposed on apartment projects built between Feb. 1, 1947, and Aug. 1953, and containing more than fifty units.
MIAMI, Feb. 14 (UP)--The Mayor of Miami apoligized to the nation today because a group of Negro Republican leaders had been ejected from a Lincoln Day dinner here.
ALBANY, Feb. 14--The New York League of Women Voters opened its annual legislative conference here today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) --The Weather Bureau, which is not always right, proved today that it is at least brave.
Bob Wiesler, 24-year-old lefthander from St. Louis, yesterday became the thirty-fourth satisfied Yankee.

A CONCERT was presented at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening by Encore Artists, featuring the Radio City Music Hall Brass Ensemble, the Classic String Quartet, Earl Schuster, oboist, and Ashley Miller, organist.

A 72-year-old woman landlord went to jail yesterday for ten days rather than pay a $50 fine. A second landlord received a sixmonth term in the workhouse on charges of filing false records with the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission.

LONDON, Feb. 14--Most high class industrial issues lost ground today in sympathy with the sharp decline in British Government securities. Reversal of the buoyant trend of last week was attributed to a hint by Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler of new inflation curbs.

The writer of the following letter is chairman of the Department of Political Science at Ripon College. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently a group of forty-seven leading Americans has urged that with some exceptions restrictions on trade with Communist nations be removed.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 14 (UP) --The New York Knickerbockers continued their domination of the Fort Wayne Pistons tonight by defeating the Pistons for the fifth straight time, 92--88, before 1,979 fans.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers wants a 22 1/2 per cent pay rise.
A Kings County grand jury will investigate the slaying early Sunday morning of a 15-yearold boy by an off-duty policeman.

ROME, Feb. 14 (AP)--Search by more than 1,000 persons for a missing Belgian airliner was halted temporarily at dusk today. The plane disappeared north of Rome last night with twenty-nine persons aboard, including four Americans and an Italian beauty contest winner.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP)--Five teams tied for the medal today in the twentieth annual mixed foursomes two-ball golf tournament at the Everglades Club.

SPAIN and Spaniards seen realistically but with romantic overtones, are the themes of paintings at the Milch Galleries, 55 East Fiftyseventh Street, by the late Maurice Fromkes (1872-1931). Fromkes' imagination was an exclusive one.

William and Milarde Brent, a husband-and-wife writing team and former Hollywood script writers, answered a newspaper advertisement seeking a couple to manage a Western motel. They have written of their experiences, both "comic arid tragic," in "Grand Motel."

BALBOA, C. Z., Feb. 13--The task of averting a possible rock fall that might block the Panama Canal at Contractors Hill has reached midway point.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14--Many uranium companies on the Colorado Plateau "seem to have been more interested in mining the public investor than mining ore," the mineral industry was told today.

A wiry young man, Pablo Ford, who looks as if he never ate a square meal himself, is turning out good food at moderate prices at a simply decorated restaurant at 232 East Fifty-eighth Street. Not inappropriately, it is called Pablo's.

MIAMI, Feb. 14 (AP)--Hal Price Headley'a Aesthete, a mare that could not win a race in 1954, drove to her second straight victory today when she nosed out Darby Dan Farm's Clear Dawn before 23,587 at Hialeah Park.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The first report to Congress of the current Hoover Commission marks the fundamental difference between the function assigned to the original group and to this one. The LodgeBrown Act of 1947 directed a commission headed by former President Hoover to recommend better procedures and administrative practices in the Federal Government as it is.

Imports of aluminum from Canada to this country dipped last year. But, according to Ward Van Alstyne, president of Aluminium Limited Sales, Inc., United States distributor for Aluminium Ltd., that decline was only temporary.

The one-story taxpayer containing three stores at 65-02 Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside, Queens, has been purchased by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator. The property, assessed at $110,000, occupies a corner plot 100 by 100 feet at Sixty-fifth Place.
The Dallas Power and Light Company borrowed $7,000,000 in the public market yesterday through the sale of an issue of sinking fund debentures due on Feb. 1, 1980.

Coffee futures tumbled the daily limit of 2 cents a pound in all positions yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was influenced by continued rumors that Brazil, will modify its exchange regulations to permit lower coffee prices, and by reports that shippers have requested that coffee be sold in a free market without minimum export prices.
THE PRESIDENT Conferred with top political advisers on time and place for 1956 Republican National Convention.

Gene Fullmer, West Jordan, Utah, middleweight, extended his victory string to twentyeight last night. He gained a unanimous decesion over Paul Pender, Brookline, Mass., in the main event of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.

THE Musicians Guild gave a concert last night at Town Hall of the sort that explains how this group has succeeded in holding its audience through nine seasons. The recipe is first-class music performed by members who as musicians have the devotion, skill and sensibility to play together and who as artists have enough individuality for their work to have color and vigor.

Manhattan (14-3), Louisville (16-6) and Niagara (14-5) accepted bids yesterday to participate in the eighteenth annual national invitation college basketball tournament.
Joseph H. Cohen Sons, Inc., one of the largest manufacturers of men's clothing in the country, plans to increase production 20 per cent.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 14--The Security Council suspended today its efforts to stop the fighting between Nationalist and Communist China over the small islands off the China coast.
RIJEKA, Yugoslavia, Feb. 10 --Under the leadership of a onetime British citizen who spent twenty-two years in Canada, this port city is seeking to establish itself as a new gateway to Central Europe.
The Ideal Toy Corporation is planning to double its advertising in newspapers and magazines to fight pressure to increase its discounts, which the company says would have forced a quality decrease.

The six-story apartment house accommodating forty-eight families at 645 West 160th Street has been conveyed by the TransNew York Corporation, of which Mortimer Harman is president. Abe Mathews contracted to purchase the property through Robert B. Hill, Inc., as broker, but sold his contract to an investing client of Emanuel Goldberg, attorney, who acquired the property thrugh Max Fluss, Inc., as broker.

Following the successful evacuation of the Tachen Islands, in which both sides observed encouraging discretion, the question of peace in the Formosa Strait has shifted back to the diplomatic level, where it is proceeding on two fronts. One front is represented by the United Nations, whose Security Council resumed debate on that question yesterday but postponed final decision pending developments on the second front.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)-- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended revocation of all operating licenses of North American Airlines today.
BOSTON, Feb. 14--Capt. W. Peter Carey, 37 years old, of Swampscott, Mass., has been discharged, it was made known today by Northeast Airlines.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 14 (Reuters)--President Celal Bayar of Turkey has postponed until March 4 his visit here to sign a mutual defense pact with Iraq.
ALBANY, Feb. 14--Mayor Wagner will make a personal plea to the Legislature Wednesday for help in solving New York City's fiscal problems.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The United States is not committed to defend Quemoy and Matsu, just off the China Communist mainland. The islands are held by the Chinese Nationalists.

A city-wide fight against Mayor Wagner's program for higher real estate and business taxes was organized yesterday. Realty, mercantile and industrial leaders, civic and taxpayer organizations formed the opposition.
In cross-examination of Harvey Matusow yesterday the Government developed the theory that the former Communist would "do anything for a buck" and was working hand-in-hand with the Communist party.

IN the year of our Lord 1541 Gonzalo Pizarro, younger brother of the conqueror of Peru, led a large expeditionary force across the Andes from Quito in Ecuador into the Amazonian jungles in search of a fabled land of cinnamon and the legendary El Dorado. The expedition was well equipped and included droves of hogs, hundreds of fierce mastiff dogs and numerous Indian slaves used as porters and drovers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14--Long liquidation was heavy and general in soybeans, rye and old crop wheat deliveries today. The declines were especially severe in rye and soybeans. Corn held fairly well, as did the oats market. In wheat there appeared to be continued backspreading with sales of March and May against purchases of the new crop deliveries.
ALBANY Feb. 14--The State Public Works Department awarded $106,116,202 worth of contracts for highways, parkways and urban arterial routes last year.

The expedition was well equipped and included droves of hogs, hundreds of fierce mastiff dogs and numerous Indian slaves used as porters and drovers.
