The first recommendations to be made by the new Hoover Commission since its re-establishment by Congress in 1953 deal with the thorny problem of federal personnel and the civil service. Based on the findings of a distinguished task force headed by President Dodds of Princeton University, the report makes some interesting and even daring proposals that deserve the closest attention of Congress.

THE major individual sailfish tournament on this coast, the annual Silver Sailfish Derby of the Palm Beaches, completed its four-week run with a total of 572 fish, of which 402 were released to fight again.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 14 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Heffelfinger, Republic National Committeewoman for Minnesota, has decided to resign the post she has held since 1948.
ALBANY, Feb. 14--New York City taxes are a major factor in persuading businesses to move away from the city, a legislative committee's study indicated today.
PARIS, Feb. 14--Christian Pineau, a Socialist, began today an effort to break through the deadlock in the politics of France.
ALBANY, Feb. 14--Nassau County started a drive today for changes in the state's optional permanent personal registration law.
LONDON, Feb. 14--Col. Alexander Scotland, a retired British spy, has threatened to bypass the Official Secrets Act and publish his war memoirs in the United States.
TRENTON, Feb. 14--Gov. Robert B. Meyner today odered the immediate dismissal of two top officials of the State Division of Employment Security.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the plans of the State Administration $350,000,000 is allocated to construction of mental hospitals in order to relieve the crowded conditions now existing. Before carrying out this program it might be worth while to take note of what happened in the State of Kansas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)-- General Motors Corporation and the Government both failed today in appeals to the Supreme Court. The appeals involved their separate quarrels with a single United States Court of Claims decision involving G. M. refrigerators.
How good is book value as a measuring rod of a stock? A recent study would seem to indicate that its relationship to market value is quite distant.

IT was a very strange race. Pete Bowen and Morgan Taylor were the two best quarter-milers in the world on that sizzling July day in 1930 when the National A. A. U. championships were held at the Pitt Stadium in Pittsburgh. And they didn't like each other. The 440-yard final was the footracing equivalent of a grudge fight.
LONDON, Feb. 14--The bejeweled body of a Jutish woman of the sixth century has been unearthed from a large cemetery recently discovered in southeast Kent.

The debate in the Security Council yesterday had little of the openly expressed venom--the drama of bitterness--that marked the famous "Month of Malik" of some years ago, or that also marked many similar debates. The voice of Vishinsky, and to some extent the malice and bad manners of Vishinsky, had disappeared.

The thirty-first annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx will be held Saturday, Feb. 26, at the Commodore Hotel. Leonard V. Lavelle, head of the board, will be toastmaster. The principal speaker will be Henry G. Waltemade, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

HAVANA, Feb. 14--Charles de Cardenas of Havana, the world Star Class champion, today sailed Kurush V to victory in the first race of the Bacardi Cup Series of the twenty-fourth annual international Star Class regatta.

Commercial products such as furniture polish, home permanent solutions and skin fresheners are perfectly safe when used as directed. But they present serious problems to the family doctor when the curiosity of small children results in poisoning.

HAVANA, Feb. 15 -- The American yacht Kathleen, skippered by Bert Williams of the South Lake Michigan fieet, today won the first race of the Cuba Cup series of the twenty-fourth international Star Class regatta. Kathleen was timed in 1 hour 36 minutes 46 seconds for the ten-mile course.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Scientists at the General Electric Research Laboratory here have for the first time created exact duplicates of the diamond.
Tea may not stale as rapidly as bread, but on the other hand it does not age gracefully.
I read with great interest the thoughtful letter of Stanley M. Isaacs concerning housing which you published Feb. 10.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, OFF ANTARCTICA, Feb. 14 -- A bit of British-United States cooperation warmed the frigid atmosphere of Antarctica today. It also may have helped provide a few carloads of margarine for British housewives.
DETROIT, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Earl (Dutch) Reibel whacked in Ted Lindsay's rebound with less than a minute remaining tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

Thirteen men aboard the 300-ton Liberian freighter Luana were rescued yesterday by the British destroyer Venus as an American destroyer, the Rush, stood by, The Associated Press reports. The freighter had radioed that she was sinking sixty-five miles southwest of Jamaica.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UP)--The Eisenhower Administration, which favors statehood for Hawaii, moved out today in open opposition to admission of Alaska to the union this year.

ONE is inclined to the belief that the greatest of Gluck's operas in the grand style is "Iphigenie en Tauride," the last of his masterpieces, given in concert form last night by the American Opera Society in Town Hall.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation has authorized a quarterly dividend of 45 cents a share on the common stock, payable on April 1. Yesterday's dividend action places the stock on an annual dividend basis of $1.80 a share, the company said.
The boxer Champion Bang Away of Sirrah Crest and the young son that beat him in the breed judging at Westminster Monday night were a prime topic in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

SO widespread is the popularity of the overblouse that it has been developed in numerous interpretations for spring. Shown at the right is one of spring's high-fashion slim box jacket suits with a middy blouse. Above are three other versions of the overblouse suggested to wear with it.

Two notorious gangsters and a union official were indicted yesterday for a kickback racket in labor welfare funds. The racket was said to have netted them $299,000 in a twoyear period. The defendants were named in a seventeen-count indictment that charged they had received the illegal payments from Louis B. Saperstein.

BOSTON, Feb. 15 -- A Brookline, Mass., couple seeking to adopt a child of a different religious faith looked today for a legal loophole in the state and Federal barriers that appeared to be erected against them.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15 (AP)--The Soviet press unleashed a barrage against United States newspaper men today. It accused them of "ink gangsterism" in their interpretations of Soviet Government shake-ups last week in which Georgi M. Malenkov lost his job as Premier.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 15 -- Mme. Maria Cimpu, wife of a Rumanian legation chauffeur who sought Danish asylum Saturday, said today she did not want anything to do with her husband.
Any doubt that it's a woman's world--so far as automobiles are concerned--was dispelled yesterday by the country's principal insurance companies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act was cleared today for House debate under a "closed rule."

The cornerstone for an International Culture Center for Jerusalem's youth will be laid there in the late spring or early summer, Spyros P. Skouras, president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation said yesterday.
The Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, under fire for alleged subversive activities, announced yesterday that it had dissolved.

The United States Public Health Service is seriously concerned about the outbreak of smallpox in France and its spread to Belgium. Tighter precautions against the disease at all quarantine stations have been ordered.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Premier Mario Scelba and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino of Italy held the first of their discussions of the European situation with Sir Winston Churchill and Sir Anthony Eden this afternoon.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams appointed 115 more women yesterday to the corps of Queens school crossing guards. At the swearing-in ceremony at Headquarters the Commissioner told the women, mostly mothers, that not one child had been injured at school crossings where guards have been assigned since the program started last September.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda took India's Prime Minister Nehru to task today. It quoted him as having said he "did not see any reason" why the Chinese Nationalists should not be invited to a conference on the Formosa problem.

BERN, Switzerland, Wednesday, Feb. 16 -- Six armed Rumanian anti-Communists seized the Rumanian Legation here yesterday. They swore to hold it "until death" unless their Communist nation freed five resistance leaders from prison. Last night, 100 steel-helmeted policemen ringed the building. rest and extradition of the "gang of Rumanian Fascists."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today recommended letting six Eastern railroads roads keep on matching highway truck rates in their piggy-back operation.
The city is expected to ring up $12,528,876 more in general fund revenues in this fiscal year than in 1953-54.
The Bankers Trust Company, the nation's ninth largest bank, and the Public National Bank and Trust Company, forty-third in size, yesterday announced plans to merge.

The special gifts committee of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity for the 1955 fund appeal of New York Catholic Charities will have John A. Coleman of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Adler, Coleman Co., as its executive chairman this year.

The Eighty-fourth Congress convened exactly six weeks ago today, and in that period the legislative wheels have started turning with surprising rapidity. The President himself has set the pace, for he has already sent to Capitol Hill a spate of messages proposing Congressional action on a wide variety of subjects.

The entire twenty-second floor in the twenty-five-story office building under construction at 300 Park Avenue has been leased by the Henry J. Kaiser Company of Oakland, Calif. The space will be used as the New York headquarters of the Kaiser industrial operations.

IT may be a false assumption but the impression has been growing steadily here that college basketball is losing ground to the professionals. Or maybe it's just losing ground, period. Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, when asked yesterday if W. Kingsland Macy had threatened to publish a sensational letter unless he received the 1950 Republican Senatorial nomination, declared he had drawn "inferences" from Mr. Macy's attitude.
A 14-year-old boy was fatally shot and two of his companions were seriously wounded by an unidentified youth on upper Fifth Avenue last night.
SAIGON, Vietnam Feb. 15 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem and his ministers opened today a congress of provincial civil and military authorities of South Vietnam.
The Red Cross was described yesterday as "a giant disaster insurance company in which we are all beneficiaries and to which every American owes a premium."
Net income of the B. F. Goodrich Company last year increased to a record $38,815,737 from $34,226,745 in 1953 despite a 6.5 per cent decline in sales.

The lack of an adequate force to police the rapid transit system is an "open invitation" to crime in the city's subways, the City Council was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that its index of production at the nation's factories and mines -- a widely used barometer of the nation's general economic well-being -- continued to rise in January, for the fifth successive month.

An expedition of historians, city officials, museum people, architects and engineers will meet at City Hall tomorrow morning to hunt for buried treasure. This is City Hall's "missing" cornerstone, formally laid in 1803.

Fifteen local housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $130,955,000 yesterday on notes of various short terms maturing up to March 9, 1956. The borrowings were at interest rates ranging from 0.55 to 1.10 per cent and averaging 0.96 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Unions in the Congress of Industrial Organizations were cautioned today to be on guard against Communist infiltration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP)--President Eisenhower announced today he would send his highway program to Congress early next week. Meanwhile, a Senate subcommittee fixed next Monday for hearings on a rival plan backed by Democrats.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The State Judicial Council had both good and bad news today in its annual report on congestion in the state's courts.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- A veteran copper executive warned the mining industry today that it must pay higher salaries if it is to avoid an engineer shortage of serious proportions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -- The Studs Lonigan trilogy by James T. Farrell will form the basis of a motion picture to be made for United Artists by the newly organized Lew Kerner Productions, Inc. Signing of contracts by the film companies with the author and his publisher, Vanguard Press, was announced today by Arthur B. Krim, president of U. A.
The Hempstead, L. I. Union Free School District No. 3 borrowed yesterday $4,931,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of bonds maturing serially from 1955 to 1984.
A chronic trouble spot on the Brooklyn waterfront made news again yesterday. Longshoremen picketed the Isthmian Steamship Company terminal at the Erie Basin Breakwater but failed to halt operations.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Britain has committed herself to a ten-year program for building twelve electric power stations run by nuclear energy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Feuding Democrats buried the hatchet today in an unusual party harmony move.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives appeared to hesitate today over clearing a bill to give members of Congress a 70 per cent salary increase of $10,000 a year.

This is D-day for the 1,307,000 stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. At noon the nineteen directors of this behemoth of communication systems -- parent of a score of state and regional phone companies -- meet for quarterly dividend action.
ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The State Banking Department introduced today a bill to ease restrictions on the use of the word "savings" by different banking institutions.
BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- The East German Communist republic has intensified its campaign for recognition outside the Communist world.

OTTAWA, Feb. 15 -- The president of the World Presbyterian Alliance rejected tonight the assertion by Vice President Richard M. Nixon that the Roman Catholic Church was "one of the major bulwarks against communism and totalitarian ideas."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine told the midyear graduation class at Temple University this afternoon that the end was in sight for the "political demagogues who question the Americanism of anyone who may disagree with them."

CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 15 -- No one would try to size up Indian policy without first sizing up Nehru. For at this juncture, governmentally speaking, Nehru is India. Therefore his prejudices, biases and predispositions are mirrored in national and world affairs.
Gunner's Might of Land Fall, a pedigreed Labrador retriever, dropped from possible champion to possible bum in one day. He also dropped from sight.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- British science writers honored Waldearm Kaempffert, science editor of The New York Times, at a dinner tonight. The dinner celebrated the award of the Kalinga Prize to Mr. Kaempffert as the world's leading science writer of the year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The hydrogen bomb tested by the United States a year ago polluted a 7,000-square-mile area with lethal radioactive fall-out.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles defended the United Nations today after the Senate Republican leader had charged it with failure. In a speech Senator William F. Knowland of California found fault with the United Nations on two scores: the continued imprisonment by the Chinese Communist of fifteen United States airmen and the unsolved threat of war in the Formosa Strait.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- The United Nations' near-bankrupt Korean aid program received new promises of help today. However, the contributions promised to the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency are not expected to stave off for long the prospect of gradual liquidation.

Borrowings by members of the New York Stock Exchange declined in January, the exchange reported yesterday. The reduction was due entirely to smaller commitments secured by United States Government bonds and notes, which fell to $124,835,091 from $171,128,701 at the end of December.
GROSSINGER, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Rocky Marciano has a handsome, rebuilt nose and is ready to fight again.
ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Ashley T. Cole has informed legislative leaders that he favors the Jockey Club's super-track plan for the New York metropolitan area.
VIENNA, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The defending champion, Hayes Alan Jenkins of Colorado Springs, Colo., took a good lead in the opening event of the world figure skating championships today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board ruled today that the Labor Youth League was a Communist front organization.
A top purchasing executive called last night for the junking of "many concepts, procedures and policies that long have been held dear by purchasing agents."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- The United States submitted data today charging that Communist China maintained a network of at least 2,000 forced-labor camps. Between 8,000,000 and 18,000,000 workers are confined to them, delegation spokesmen estimated.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 15 -- The bodies of a young Israeli couple, who disappeared in December while hiking near the Dead Sea, were traced to Jordan today.
A program for control of a major disease of the heart and arteries was presented here yesterday.
Mickey Mantle, the Bombers' home-run hitter, yesterday became the thirty-fifth Yankee to agree to terms.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Oxford University's crew for the March 26 eight-oared boat race against Cambridge University was picked today. It includes six "Old Blues," oarsmen who have previously rowed in the classic.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 15 -- Landing ports for helicopters at Virginia Beach and Portsmouth are being studied by representatives of National Airlines and the Civil Aeronautics Administration. This follows establishment of a heliport site near the heart of Norfolk.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The executive secretary of the National Education Association declared today that the Administration school bill "provides too little aid, too much control."
MOSCOW, Feb. 15 -- Georgi M. Malenkov, who was Premier of the Soviet Union until a week ago, has taken charge of one of the fastest growing sectors of Soviet industry: the electric power system.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped two to seven points (10 to 35 cents a bale) yesterday.

Development of foreign markets will be emphasized at the seventy-eighth annual convention of the American Paper and Pulp Association, E. W. Tinker executive secretary, announced yesterday. The meeting will open fat the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Saturday and continue until Thursday.
The American Society of Mechanical Engineers was organized on Feb. 16, 1880, in the offices of the technical publication American Machinist, which was then at 96 Fulton Street.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Favorites won as expected today in the mixed foursomes two-ball amateur golf tournament at the Everglades Club. Three former winning teams advanced to the second round.
Events tonight: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, and "La Boheme," Carl Fischer Concert Hall, both at 8.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Directors of Republic Steel Corporation voted today to split the outstanding common stock two shares for one and to increase authorized common shares from 20,000,000 to 28,000,000.

Robert Bishop, a young man with a sense of humor and a flair for arranging artificial fruits and flowers, is giving New Yorkers something to smile about as they walk down Madison Avenue these blustery days.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Union told Japan today it was ready to start negotiations for normal relations "at the place the Japanese Government considers most adequate."
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday the approval of transfer to foreign registry of one passenger liner, two tankers and one dredge.

Wall Street men, by and large, had a ready explanation yesterday for the recent strength in railroad stocks: History never repeats itself. What they meant, specifically, was that the carriers' January earning statements are expected to make far brighter reading than those of January, 1954.

The Kansas City Power and Light Company borrowed $16,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of first mortgage bonds due in 1985. Most of the money raised by the sale will be used to pay off bank loans.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- The two-year closing of the Bronx River Parkway near here will end Friday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today final results of subscriptions for its exchange offer for three Treasury issues maturing today and on March 15.
PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Six persons, three of them children, were killed tonight when a kerosene stove exploded in a basement home about twelve miles west of here.
The Fifth Avenue Association re-elected all officers for another two-year term at its bienniel meeting yesterday at the Barclay Hotel.
A peaceful solution of the Formosa situation should be possible because "all the parties concerned do not want war," in the opinion of Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India.

The Society of the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases will benefit from the Feb. 27 evening performance of the film "Cinerama Holiday" at the Warner Theatre. Proceeds will assist the society's projects at the center.
PEIPING, Feb. 15 -- Communist China announced today plans to make 80,000,000 men liable for military service.

THE Television Playhouse presented this week another play -- "The Rabbit Trap," by J. P. Miller -- that in some ways might be regarded as characteristic of the Sunday night drama series (9 to 10 o'clock) over the National Broadcasting Company network.

CAIRO, Feb. 15 -- Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian Prime Minister, arrived in Cairo today for a two-day visit. Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser met Mr. Nehru at International Airport and conferred with him three times during the day, once for a two-and-one-half-hour private talk at the presidency of the Council of Ministers.
ROME, Feb. 15 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Italy, attended the opening tonight in Naples of "Porgy and Bess."
Coffee futures dropped the 2 cents-a-pound daily limit yesterday for the third consecutive day on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

BOMBAY, Feb. 15 -- The new Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation announced here today that the Indian public had offered to buy all $3,000,000 worth of shares available to it. This represents less than one-third the $10,000,000 of privately subscribed capital of the $35,000,000 corporation.

A hold-up man and ex-convict was "taken for a ride" and murdered early yesterday morning in Brooklyn. It is believed he was soon to testify as a state's witness against others involved in a hold-up in Baltimore.
ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Both state and local taxes will have to be increased to meet rising government costs of the next six years.
There are indications that Robert E. Sherwood and the National Broadcasting Company will terminate the playwright's television contract, which allots him $25,000 for each one-hour script.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- One hundred four Laborite Members of Parliament backed a motion, introduced in the House of Commons tonight by Aneurin Bevan, calling for discussions with the Soviet Union before West Germany receives permission to arm.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 15 -- The Government's program to separate communities on racial lines was being advanced in the South African Parliament today. Meanwhile, the second forced removal of natives from their Johannesburg homes occurred.

Harvey Matusow admitted yesterday that he had fabricated a blacklist of radio and television personalities for an advertising agency. He added that many of these persons whom he had branded as "Reds" were not known to him.

While a few issues behaved spectacularly, yesterday in the stock market was primarily a day of solid gains scattered through a majority of the list. The averages made new highs for the year and the upward movement.

An American edition of Hermann Kesten's new biography, "Casanova," will be published Feb. 23 by Harper. The life of the eighteenth-century diplomat, fortune hunter, musician, card-sharp, litterateur, alchemist, convict, confidence man and common adventurer has already been published in Germany, Italy, Holland, Denmark, Sweden, England and France.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Two officials of the American National Theatre and Academy urged Congress today to create a great cultural center here.

THE disciplined mastery of Jascha Heifetz' violin playing remains undimmed. In his only New York appearance of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, he played with the precision and commanding authority that are the hallmarks of his art.

IT is family night at the Downtown National Theatre, Second Avenue and Houston Street. Maurice Schwartz is the star, speaking English at the moment. Sholom Aleichem's "The Grass Is Always Greener" is the play, which opened last evening.

It said the Russians had the equivalent of the United States Nike to shoot down planes, and also had developed pencil-like, jet-powered anti-aircraft rockets.

THE New York City Ballet, in fine shape and full of pep, opened a four-week season last night at the City Center. The nearest thing to a novelty that the evening contained was the return of Melissa Hayden after an absence of a year or so.

The five-story building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 254 West Forty-seventh Street, adjoining the Mansfield Theatre, has been purchased by the New Dance Group, Inc., a large school teaching modern dance and the ballet. The school moved recently from 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, part of a plot taken by Commercial Investment Trust for a new building.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 15 -- Egypt's Premier, Gamal Abdel Nasser, assured Iraq thirteen months ago that he would be ready to cooperate in forming a Western-aided Middle East defense organization as soon as the Suez dispute with Britain was settled, the then Iraqi Premier Fadhil el Jamali said here today.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Growing fears that the bank rate would rise again kept the stock markets dull today. British funds fell sharply and industrials weakened in sympathy, though selling was light.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 15 (UP) -- Week-end golfers from Corpus Christi, Tex., and Ridgewood, N. J., shot 3-under-par 69's today to share the first- round lead in qualifying for the annual championship of golf club champions.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 15 (UP)--Joey Giardello, top-ranking middleweight from Philadelphia, scored an eight-round technical knockout over Andy Mayfield at the Auditorium tonight after flooring the Miami Negro four times.

The Third Avenue El used to be the only decent and comfortable way to get up and down town. The destruction of the lower portions, first to South Ferry and then to City Hall, took away most of its remaining usefulness and drove its customers into the daily mayhem of the subway, unbearably foul and hot from May to October.

Once more the question of government by law or government by scientists has come to the fore. Prof. Harold C. Urey, at a dinner in Chicago Feb. 12 reported by The Times on Feb. 13, is quoted as being convinced that a grave injustice has been done the Rosenbergs and Morton Sobell, who were convicted in connection with treason to the United States in revealing secrets of the atomic bomb to Russia.

The consumer today often finds herself lost in a maze of labels and unsure of her own taste while striving to keep within her budget. And when experts cannot agree, whom can she trust!. A good example of what the housewife is up against was demonstrated at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.
The Berkshire Fine Spinning Associates and the Hathaway Manufacturing Company agreed yesterday on terms of a merger of their companies under the name of Berkshire Hathaway, Inc.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15 -- President Juan D. Peron promised last week that Argentina's "state of internal warfare" would be lifted soon.

Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., members of the United States Davis Cup team, head the draw for the national indoor tennis championships. The tournament starts Friday evening at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue Sixty-sixth Street.
A-71-year-old Captain Corcoran wooed and won an 80-year-old-Little Buttercup at the Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon as H. M. S. Pinafore once again put to sea.
HARTFORD, Feb. 15 -- The highest biennial state budget in history was recommended today by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff to the Connecticut General Assembly.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- The "supreme court" of medicine ruled today that a New York doctor did not violate medical ethics in a case involving solicitation of patients through advertising by a health group.
YONKERS, Feb. 15 -- The city corporation counsel denied today charges made by a citizens' group that school conditions here were "deplorable."

While the rest of the world centers attention on the upheaval in Moscow and the new perils in the Far East the Paris politicians have seen fit to indulge in the luxury of another Cabinet crisis which after ten days is still unresolved. New candidates come and go, programs and party combinations are formed and fall, and the political merry-go-round continues to whirl to the tune of political and personal rivalries.

Two new films will open today at first-run theatres. "The Wages of Fear," a French-made suspense drama with Yves Montand, Charles Vanel and Vera Clouzot, is at the Paris. Henri-Georges Clouzot directed and adapted the Filmsonor-C. I. C. C. production from a novel by Georges Arnaud, Peter Eyck, Folco Lulli and William Tubbs head the supporting cast.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Claude M. Lightfoot, executive secretary of the Illinois Communist party, was sentenced to five years in prison and fined $5,000 today. He was sentenced for intending to bring about the violent overthrow of the Government as a member of the party.

The trail to Broadway has been a nerve-racking one for a pair of new producers, Bruce Becker and Robert Ellis Miller, whose initial offering, "Tonight in Samarkand," finally arrives at 8 o'clock this evening at the Morosco.
SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 15 -- Guatemala expects accelerated assistance from the United States to get her economy rolling.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Following is the report of the United States Atomic Energy Commission on the effects of hydrogen-bomb explosions:
DAGENHAM, England, Feb. 15 -- The British Army has adopted a new 9 mm. submachine gun. In time it will become a standard personal weapon for all British ground forces.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Israel sent a reminder today to the Security Council that Egypt still held the Israeli freighter Bat Galim. The 500-ton vessel was seized Sept. 28 when she attempted to enter the Suez Canal, which has been barred to Israeli ships.

The New York Legislature in March, 1953, authorized appointment of a temporary commission to appraise the fiscal affairs of the state government, its relationships with the Federal Government and the units of local government. The final report of this commission, which was headed by Frederick L. Bird of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was delivered yesterday in a 326-page volume and a companion volume of staff reports of even larger magnitude.

Commercial paper outstanding on the books of dealers at the end of January amounted to $713,000,000, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This represented a decline of 3 per cent from the December level, but it was 12 per cent above the volume outstanding a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Nearly-one-half of this country's combat forces are stationed overseas.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 15 -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, said today there was need now for "a full-fledged investigation of the power industry and the private monopolies of the utilities" in this country.
ROME, Feb. 15 -- An American aircraft sighted today what is believed to be the wreckage of a Belgian airliner missing with twenty-nine persons since Sunday night.

Thinking of buying a carpet ? Perhaps the following glossary of carpeting terms may be of some help. It has been compiled by the Ludlow Jute Manufacturing and Sales Company, a large processor of jute which is widely used in rugs as backing.

The "hottest" team in the National Hockey League, the Bruins of Boston, will skate against the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Bruins have an unbeaten string of eight games and have lost only three times in their last fifteen starts.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- Christian Pineau, Socialist leader, came out firmly tonight for ratification of the Paris agreements on West German armament in outlining the program he hoped would help him to become Premier.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration identified twenty-two metropolitan areas tonight as "large" air traffic hubs, and forty as "medium" hubs.
ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The Senate adopted today two measures that would impose a new water bill on New York City.
TOWNSFOLK will get their first look at the new three-wheel Messerschmitt one-cylinder car at Madison Square Garden from Sunday through Feb. 27 during the Travel and Auto Sports Show.
There are eighty-four inducements to relax and spend some time on the new third-floor furniture department at Georg Jensen. All of them are chairs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- The Transport and Communications Commission closed its seven-day session today with recommendations to the Economic and Social Council on problems in the field of shipping and travel.

The two six-story apartment houses at 1692-96 Washington Avenue in the Bronx have been purchased by George Goodman Co., operators and investors. They were sold by clients of the Kreisel Company, who had owned them forty years.

Advertising is moving more foods at lower cost, Bernard C. Duffy, president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., said yesterday. He told the St. Paul Advertising Club that the ratio advertising to total income has decreased from 4 per cent in 1920 to about 2.4 per cent today and commented that he liked the trend.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A program of economic aid to Asia has been approved by the Executive Branch. It will involve a "significant increase" in expenditures for economic development.
The clock lacked twenty-five minutes to midnight in Madison Square Garden last night when a California bulldog rose to the highest distinction American bench show competition has to to offer.

At a moment when, with President Eisenhower's endorsement, a nation-wide Crusade for Freedom is under way to keep the torch of liberty burning behind the Iron Curtain, the American people will gladly join in spirit and in sympathy the Lithuanian nation, which, though under the Soviet heel, still observes today the thirty-seventh anniversary of its independence.
ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Feb. 14 -- This ship penetrated through a gaping hole in the icepack today to the coast of Queen Maud Land.

Several days after Harvey Matusow had contracted to write a book about his experiences as a Government witness who testified falsely, he deliberately lied to two Department of Justice attorneys, the former Communist declared yesterday.
A Representative in Congress earns $15,000 a year, more than five times the pay of his opposite number in the British Parliament.

HAVANA, Feb. 16--Charles de Cardenas of Havana, the holder of the world Star Class sailing championship, today won the second race of the Cuba Cup series in the twenty-fourth international Star Class regatta with his yacht Kurush V.

The directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company proposed yesterday a record new issue of 650,000,000 of convertible debentures. Stockholders will vote on the recommendation at the annual meeting on April 20.

Members of the special gifts committee of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity for the 1955 fund appeal of the New York Catholic Charities were urged by Cardinal Spellman yesterday to bend all efforts to meet the goal of $1,000,000.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 16, 1955) THE GOVERNOR Signed bill extending reporting time for Temporary State Commission on Town and Village Laws.

QUITE a few opera lovers came to the Metropolitan Opera last night primed for "Aida" with Renata Tebaldi in the title role. They heard instead Puccini's "Tosca," with Zinka Milanov making her first appearance at the Metropolitan in that part.

OTTAWA, Feb. 16 -- About three weeks after signing the statement I had agreed to give to the Chinese, I was taken from my cell into the large interrogation room, where I found my three American companions-- Capt. Harold E. Fischer of Swea City, Iowa; Lieut. Lyle W. Cameron of Lincoln, Neb., and Lieut. Roland Parks of Omaha, Neb.
A Rochester Republican testified yesterday that he had taken a photostat of the famous Joe R. Hanley letter to a 1950 talk with the Democratic state chairman and Democratic campaign manager.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Dixon-Yates planned today to go ahead immediately with construction of its private power plant to feed energy into the Tennessee Valley Authority.
Michael J. Quill yesterday accused Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, of a "sellout" in agreeing to merge with the American Federation of Labor.
LONDON, Feb. 16--Clement R. Attlee, leader of the British Labor party, urged today the exploration of the Soviet Union's attitude on free elections in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board issued orders today to carry out President Eisenhower's decisions on trans-Pacific routes for three United States airlines.
A major test of the port's new "harmony" machinery is developing in a dispute between the independent International Longshoremen's Association and the Isthmian Steamship Company.
PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 17 -- Christian Pineau, Socialist leader, was completing his prospective Cabinet early today. He planned to present it to the National Assembly on Friday.

PAINTINGS of the last three years by the British artist John Piper are being shown at the Curt Valentin Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. In this latter work Piper is seen blending his essentially traditional English vein of romantic landscape with a greater degree of abstraction akin at times to work by Braque-- especially in the broken color of such an example as "Rowlestone Carving With Hanging Lamp."
ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Governor Harriman's record high $1,345,000,000 budget was attacked from two directions at a legislative hearing today.
John Foster Dulles invited the Soviet Union and Communist China last night to renounce the use of force.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--Secretary of State John Foster Dulles will visit Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam, as well as Burma, after he has attended the first council meeting of the Manila pact powers at Bangkok, Thailand, Feb. 23-25.

LONDON, Feb. 16--The Comet jet airliner was given a vote of confidence by the British Government today with the announcement that British Overseas Airways Corporation was increasing its long order for new types of Comets.

VIENNA, Feb. 16 (AP)--Hayes Alan Jenkins swept to his third straight men's world figureskating title tonight. Tenley Albright took a strong lead in the women's division, which virtually assured a United States sweep of individual honors in the championships.

A stepped-up attack on juvenile delinquency is being planned by the city's Protestant welfare agencies. A special seven-man committee has been appointed by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies to take the lead in the campaign.

Third Avenue--outgoing itself as a bazaar of the extraordinary -- yesterday offered something very special for the person who has just the right place to use it. An advertisement in The New York Herald Tribune called attention to a "terrific bargain" in a steel swring bridge 302 feet long, 63 feet wide and capable of carrying "100,000 vehicles, 500,000 pedestrians, or 10,000,000 chickens daily."
CAIRO, Feb. 16--Egypt's Premier tonight declared his "identity of views" with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India.
Prospects for a new $10,000,000 Police Academy brightened unexpectedly yesterday.

TOKYO, Feb. 16--Japan received today a second note expressing the Kremlin's willingness to discuss ending the state of war between the Soviet Union and Japan. Authorities here expected that the talks would begin shortly between representatives of the two countries at the United Nations headquarters in New York.

Irvington House will be the beneficiary of the sale o fa special collection of antiques at the annual National Antiques Show, which will open March 7 at Madison Square Garden and continue through March 13. The collection has been donated for the occasion by prominent persons.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 16, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Conferred with Republican eaders from the Capitol. Talked with Budget Director Rowland R. Hughes and his special consultant on foreign programs, Nelson A. Rockefeller.

Cutter Laboratories, Berkeley, Calif., producer of fine biologicals and pharmaceutical, has purchased Ashe Lockhart, Inc., Kansas City, Mo., for an undisclosed amount of cash. Ashe Lockhart, Inc., sells a complete line of veterinary biological products to graduate veterinarians only.
The Commercial Credit Corporation in 1954 attained the highest income in its forty-three-year history, with a consolidated net of $24,228,773, according to the annual report released today.

FOR the second program of its season at the City Center, the New York City Ballet last night presented Melissa Hayden in Jerome Robbins' "The Cage" for the first time in several seasons, and three ballets by George Balanchine --"Prodigal Son," "Bourree Fantasque" and his version of "Swan Lake."

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Feb. 15--Scanning a coastline where, for a stretch of 850 miles, no human being is known to have set foot, men standing watch on this icebreaker spotted a party of explorers early today.

The Manhattan and Niagara quintets, entrants in the 1955 National Invitation Tournament, will appear at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Jaspers will meet New York University in the first game of a double-header and then Niagara will engage St. John's.
"TONIGHT IN SAMARKAND," which opened at the Morosco last evening, is a play about magic that needs a little more magic in its own right.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP)--Carl (Bobo) Olson boxed masterfully and viciously to win his nineteenth straight victory with a unanimous ten-round decision over Ralph (Tiger) Jones in a non-title bout at the Chicago Stadium tonight.
Heavier turnover on the American Stock Exchange last year was reflected in more favorable operating results, the institution reported yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16-- The G. O. P. elephant will reign next year in a great pavilion built for livestock shows.

The latest report of the Atomic Energy Commission indicates that "the very large thermonuclear device fired at the Bikini atoll on March 1, 1954," was adequate over an area of about 7,000 square miles. The territory "was so contaminated that survival might have depended upon prompt evacuation or upon taking shelter or other protective devices."
Serge Rubinstein is believed to have been the victim of an unsuccessful kidnap plot by underworld thugs seeking a huge ransom.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A leading opponent of the bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act renewed his prediction today that it would pass the House by a two-to-one vote.

After William Beckford, the Author of "Vathek," was banished from England by his family in 1787 because of a scandal, he spent more than a year in Spain and Portugal. During that time he kept a "frank" diary from which, until now, only extracts have appeared in print.

The Boston Bruins overcame a two-goal deficit to tie the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd 6,809 looked on, the speedy Bruins chipped away at the home sextet's lead and brought about a tie at 2-all.
Paul Vincent Carroll's latest play, "The Wayward Saint," starring Paul Lukas and featuring Liam Redmond in the title role opens tonight at the Cort Theatre at 8 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A hope that the need for world peace and disarmament would be re-emphasized prompted President Eisenhower to approve publication of the deadly effects of hydrogen bomb radiation.
BOSTON, Feb. 16 (AP)--The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and list of winter sports conditions:

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 16-- Israel and three Arab states are reliably reported to have agreed to use the Sea of Galilee as the main water storage reservoir in a proposed Jordan Valley development project. The Arab states are Jordan, Syria and Lebanon.
Removing the fat from duck before cooking produces an appetizing bird. Most of the fat is just under the skin, to which it clings. It is easily taken off by skinning the bird.
The National Labor Relations Board has tightened its rule against electioneering by employers just prior to union voting by their employes.
LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 17 --British hopes for an early cease-fire in the Far East have been dampened by Secretary of State Dulles' speech in New York last night.
The Sanitation Department went into reverse yesterday and scattered litter along Fifty-ninth Street. However, it was all for the sake of a cleaner city.
Israel is ready for a liberal type of Judaism, Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The House Interior Committee today approved an Alaska - Hawaii statehood bill permitting the President to reserve 40 per cent at northwestern Alaska for military defense purposes.

BERN, Switzerland, Feb. 16 (AP)--Three Rumanian anti-Communists yielded the Rumanian Legation late today under the threat of being blasted out. Sleepy-eyed and unshaven, they surrendered quietly to Swiss authorities.
MIAMI, Feb. 16--An Argentine -bred horse that could have been claimed for $4,000 at Belmont Park last spring won first money of $24,900 in the Bougainvillea Turf Handicap at Hialeah today.

The House That Jack Made Since The Times came to Times Square there have been many changes along the main line to the Grand Central by way of Forty-third Street --most conspicuously, the Hippodrome has come and gone and been replaced at long last by a huge container in layers of motor cars off active duty.

The Federal Reserve Board's index of production, after being adjusted for seasonal influences, is reported at 131 for January, a rise of one point over the adjusted figure for December. A year ago, however, the figure declined between December and January.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The Republican party will hold its 1956 nominating convention in San Francisco's Cow Palace in the week of Aug. 20. Leaders plan a short, streamlined convention lasting only four days with a single daily session from 2 P. M. to 7 P. M., Pacific time.

THE professional football draft of collegiate seniors was droning along disinterestingly toward the end a few weeks ago. The talent supply was comparatively skimpy to start with and by the last round the cupboard was bare.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--A small, prim grandmother continued to wreak havoc today with the Government's case against Edward Lamb of Toledo, Ohio.
A new way to make the classic French souffle fits in the time schedule of "after-5 cooks." The method is quick, easy and, not to be forgotten in all the haste, productive of airy, appetizing results.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The Supreme Court last week refused a chance either to revive or inflict a mercy death on last year's Senate controversy over limiting treatymaking powers, but it gave the proponents a new argument for revival. This was that, though the tribunal ignored a lower court decision that the President exceeded his authority in a certain Executive agreement, it implied he had not by treating as valid a contract necessitated only by the agreement.

ALMOST every novel that Colette wrote might be said to be, in a certain cogent sense, a retelling, in her own sensuous, subtle and remorseless terms, of an early nineteenthcentury fairy tale, "Undine," by the Baron Friedrich de la Motte Fouque, a writer of the German romantic movement. From the psychoanalytic point of view, at the very least, it is a disturbing story.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 16--Opposition forces in Parliament warned today that extreme application of the Nationalist Government's segregation policies would mean "economic disaster."

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 11,000 head; moderately active alter a slow start; unevenly steady to as much as 25c lower; mainly steady to weak: sows scarce, mostly steady: most

The price movement in coffee futures was reversed yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The near-by options rose the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit, and the deferred options were up the 2-cent limit from the lows of the day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers said today business was looking up but it would be better if taxes were cut.

Title has been passed by the Robert Walton Goelet Estate on an old realty holding at 69 Water Street which at present is occupied by a bonded warehouse. The property is near Hanover Square at the lower end of Manhattan.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 16--Harold Holt, Minister of Labor, said today that the principle laid down in the amending legislation adopted in November that shipowners should have the exclusive right to recruit waterfront labor would be abandoned.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 16-- Senator Albert Gore charged here today that large private concerns were conducting "voracious raiding" among the Atomic Energy Commission's technical personnel. The Tennessee Democrat declared that this threatened a monopoly by a few big companies of the "know-how" of atomic processes.

RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 16--A fabric substitute for the Human heart's principal artery -- the aorta and the Y-shaped aortic arch--has been developed. Successful experiments have been held in the School of Textiles at North Carolina State College here.
LONDON, Feb. 16--Continued fears of another rise in the bank rate, and official cautions about the way terms of trade have been moving against Britain, depressed the stock market here further today.
Something like half of the nation's manufacturers are taking advantage of faster depreciation under the new tax law, a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board indicates.

The marbles season, along with spring and the first crocus, will be at hand in a matter of weeks, and the Post Toasties people are not going to be caught napping. The Post Cereals division of General Foods was so successful last season with an offer of marbles, neatly packed with Post Toasties, that the company is expanding the promotion and planning an extensive national campaign for it, to break late in March.

To a person just learning English, the American scene is full of pitfalls. One of these is "per gal." The "word" came up the other night at the English classes for foreigners, conducted Monday nights by the Junior League at 130 East Eightieth Street.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Feb. 16--Princeton rolled up a record score of 74 points in defeating Pennsylvania and Columbia in the seventeenth annual Polar Bear track meet today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 6 points (30 cents a bale) higher yesterday.
The ranks of the city's Boy Scouts increased 9.5 per cent during 1954.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--This week's debate over the Quemoy and Matsu Islands has overshadowed the new Communist overtures to Japan.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 --Helen Hayes will make her first movie in four years. She will co-star with James Cagney in "All Our Tomorrows," which is to be produced by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- Cotton representatives in Congress promoted another increase in planting allotments today.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 15-- About 75,000 Formosa - born Chinese are to be called to the colors within six months to rejuvenate the Chinese Nationalist Army. They would bring its United States-equipped infantry divisions up to strength.
Diamonds were made synthetically as long as three years ago for cutting, grinding and other trade uses.

ONE of the younger French contemporaries, Georges Dayez, is showing paintings at Galerie Moderne, 49 West Fifty-third Street. It is easy to see in his semi-abstract still-lifes and figures intelligent recapitulations of Braque and Picasso.

Stocks of light fuel oil, used mostly for heating homes, declined 5,657,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 76,158,000 barrels, compared with 81,815,000 a week earlier and 73,257,000 a year ago.

One more of last year's "sick" industries continues on the road to recovery. Last month the nation's freight car builders--both the contract companies and the shops operated by the railroads --received more new business than in any previous month since January, 1953.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16--Wheat futures sold off sharply after a firm opening but later rallied to make new highs for the session today. Commission-house absorption on the setbacks took the slack out of the pit, and short covering was a factor later.
Following is the text of a speech by Secretary of State Dulles delivered before the Foreign Policy Association last night, as recorded by The New York Times.
A news executive raised the question yesterday whether the time had not come to demand not only objective newspapers but also objective readers.

MADRID, Feb. 16--The directorate of the Falange party has rejected the resignation of the national head of the Students Union following an anti-Monarchist demonstration on Feb. 9, Falangist circles said today.
A new "electronic supervisor" that automatically controls as many as forty remote operations in store, office or factory was demonstrated yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The "social life" of twelve- and thirteenyear-olds is putting little wrinkles in the brows of school administrators, teachers and parents in at least twenty-three states.

In his speech last night before the Foreign Policy Association Secretary Dulles emphasized again that the goal of American foreign policy is peace with freedom, for ourselves and for other nations, as the essential condition for the preservation of our way of life.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 16--Mandatory imprisonment for professional gamblers was advocated today by a Westchester County grand jury. It had been studying gambling and its underlying causes since May, 1951.

A housing colony is planned for the Vanginhoven flower farm in East Patchogue, L. I., which has been purchased by Roy Katz and H. Jerome Harris. GaleOppenheimer was the broker and the attorneys were Elihu Berman for the buyers and Charles T. Koop for the sellers.
ANGLERS who have been impressed by the comparative scarcity of bluefin tuna in our northern coastal waters during the past few years may look toward Spain for the answer.

American Potash and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $7,000,000 of convertible subordinated debentures due in 1970.
The blood assurance program announced on Tuesday by the New York State Medical Society and the five county medical societies here has not been approved by the Greater New York Hospital Association.
An early decision should be made by the Board of Estimate on how to preserve the safety of Manhattan Bridge, Mayor Wagner was told yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. l6--Mrs. Oveta that the Hobby told Congress today that the Administration's school construction program was "comprehensive and flexible."

Within the metropolitan area New York will soon have two great bridges to name, the $220,000,000 crossing of harbor waters between Staten Island and Brooklyn and the $60,000,000 Thruway bridge across the Hudson River between Tarrytown and Nyack.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 9: Decreases of $318,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $296,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $245,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and $188,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.
Fifty years after giving up wearing short pants in order to work for the Cunard Line, Jesse L. Austin can go back to dressing as he pleases.

Argument in an appeal from an award of $175,001 to Quentin Reynolds, author, against Westbrook Pegler, columnist, and the Hearst papers, began yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The Government today increased by 50 per cent the amount of lower grade natural rubber it will sell each month. The action is designed to make room in the Government's stockpile for rubber of better quality.
Three right-handed pitchers with an aggregate age of 107 years signed 1955 contracts with the three local baseball clubs yesterday. Despite their ages these fellows are important to their teams.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The board of directors of Youth House is appreciative of the editorial published Feb. 14, "Youth House Must Expand." It is a most important reminder of the continuing condition of overcrowding that has obtained at Youth House far too long.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15--David E. Lilienthal said today the nation was overemphasizing the atomsfor-peace program in the face of a much more urgent problem-- a growing water shortage.

A Labrador retriever, with a pedigree as long as his tail, was back home in Newport, R. I., yesterday after two nights of wallowing in the gutter here. Gunner's Might of Land Fall, who won a prize at the Westminster Kennel Club dog show at Madison Square Garden on Monday, seemed bedraggled but contented after an escapade unusual in his well-bred family.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16--George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, said here tonight that there was nothing in the international situation to cause the Eisenhower Administration to alter its program for reducing expenditures.

The House of Representatives begins two days of debate today on a bill that the chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee describes in these terms: "In my opinion, there is no one piece of legislation coming before the Congress this session which will contribute more to our own prosperity and at the same time to the solidarity and security of the free world."
In his speech here last night John Foster Dulles seemed to have turned the "divide and conquer" tactic against the Soviet Communist party's First Secretary, Nikita S. Khrushchev.
A fond mother and her money are soon parted, for it takes a strong will to resist the pleasure of dressing the baby in style, decorating the child's room or trying out new "mother savers."
The Baltimore County, Md., Metropolitan District borrowed $10,000,000 in the public market yesterday on serial bonds to finance various public improvements.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 16-- Princeton stormed back from a 12-point deficit early in the second half to upset Columbia, 53--52, at Dillon Gymnasium tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The House of Representatives voted today, 283 to 118, for a $10,000a-year pay rise for members of Congress. Members of the Judiciary also would get increases.
Net sales of the General Tire and Rubber Company for the year ended Nov. 30 increased 5.7 per cent above the previous year's volume.
LONDON, Feb. 16--The British Government said today it had devised a "better defense than anyone else in the world" against an enemy air attack by night.

Ideas expressed last Sept. 29 in an address by Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, have already been embodied in bills before the legislatures of New York, Connecticut, Georgia, Maryland, Massachusetts and Ohio.

ELENA NIKOLAIDI made her first guest appearance with the Bach Aria Group last night at Town Hall and she provided one of the high points of the evening when she sang Es ist vollbracht" from the St. John Passion.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17-- President Eisenhower was asked today to appoint a commission to study ways to guard the nation from totalitarian dangers without sacrificing liberties.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--Joseph P. Kelly, former treasurer of the Bronx Democratic Organization, was named today to the $15,000a-year post of Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway earned more money last year hauling merchandise -- largely manufactured goods-- than it did from hauling coal, its traditional traffic leader. The company's annual report, sent to shareholders yesterday, disclosed that merchandise traffic revenues reached $143,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The security program governing defense workers in private industry is being revised to improve its fairness.
The big wind roaring through the subway tunnels these days will not slow down the labor unity express.
Ten motorcycle policemen and three other defendants pleaded not guilty yesterday to conspiracy charges in the courtesy card racket.
Fenway Shops Inc. furniture and interior decoration, in 710 Lexington Ave; Samuel Harris, custom tailor, floor in 714 Lexington Ave--Leo J. Dropkin, broker.

Original patent papers of Samuel F. B. Morse's first telegraph instrument are on display for the first time outside the United States Patent Office. The documents are part of the Morse Telegraph exhibit that opened yesterday at the Bronx campus of New York University.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--Governor Harriman is planning a statewide war against commercial frauds.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--The Legislature was urged today to join in a campaign against head-on collisions on the highways.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The apparent consolidation of power behind Nikita Khrushchev indicates the Kremlin is divided into two factions: a more belligerent "war-soon" party, and a relatively more peaceful "war-later" party. It now appears that the conciliatory overtures by Malenkov were comparatively "sincere," though his power and the counter-balancing powers of competing factions never produced really forthright minimal peace overtures satisfactory to us.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The Church of England Assembly declined today to take a formal position on the Moral Re-armament Movement after the Archbishops of York and Canterbury had appealed for restraint on a potentially acrimonious debate.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 16 --The Grand National Assembly unanimously approved today West Germany's admission to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. At the same time it ratified without a dissenting vote the alliance binding Turkey to Greece and Yugoslavia.

This spring's trends in patterned papers for walls are summarized in a new collection introduced yesterday by Katzenbach Warren, 575 Madison Ave. The papers, available there through decorators, may be found also at Macy's, W. J. Sloan and Bloomingdale's.
St. Francis College defeated a determined Brooklyn College quintet, 81--67, at the II Corps Artillery Armory in Brooklyn last night.
Stocks advanced yesterday until the final hour, when they ran into trouble. They ended with moderate losses.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--Mayor Wagner urged the Legislature today to go beyond Governor Harriman's budget recommendations in helping New York City meet its financial problems.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 17 --Pakistan and Turkey were reported today to be drafting a plan that might pave the way for Egypt's leadership of a ninenation defense group.

The writer of the following letter, a long-time resident of the Orient, is the author, among other books, of "Basis for' Peace in the Far East." He is Professor of International Relations at Columbia.
PARIS, Feb. 17--Some disquietude was caused here by the speech of Secretary of State Dulles last night.

As in the several previous sessions, the stock market advanced for three or four hours yesterday and then dropped just before the close. The net change was small but on the plus side. Airways were strong and aircrafts weak.
LONDON, Feb. 17--The British Government announced today that it had the "ability" to produce the hydrogen bomb and would do so.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest your thoughtful editorial of Feb. 9 which stressed the importance of proper investment of union funds. Union welfare funds, the editorial emphasized, should clearly be "invested to assure maximum cash benefits to their beneficiaries with a minimum of risk" and "the public as well as union members has an obligation to see that this is done."
The State of South Carolina announced plans yesterday for the sale of $20,000,000 of school bonds. Dated April 1, 1955, the obligations will come due annually on April 1 from 1956 to 1975.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--After examining a number of subtle theories being advanced for the Republicans' choice of San Francisco as their national convention site next year, Democratic party strategists, have sadly rejected them all. They have decided that the reasons are simple--namely: The Republican leaders intend to renominate the President and the Vice President.
Loans to business by major New York City banks increased $73,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The rise, the second in a row, was contrary to the usual seasonal downturn at this time.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 17--The manner in which the American family disposes of its money will be the subject of one of two studies to be conducted by Yale University's economics department and financed by the Ford Foundation.

THE Master of the Roses is ill at 67 and heart-break is about to overtake him. Within the month, in all likelihood, he must dispose of the enterprise his forbears started in Bruges, Belgium, 235 years ago.
Straw brims dominate the spring millinery picture, judging from Ohrbach's showing at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 17, 1955) THE GOVERNOR Held press conference. Visitors included Dr. Persia Campbell, the Governor's consumer counsel; A. B. O'Connor, director of Civil Defense for the northeastern United States with headquarters at Newton Highland, Mass.; Susan Brandeis of New York, former member of the Board of Regents and sister of the late Associate Justice Louis Brandeis of the Supreme Court; Assembly Minority Leader Eugene Bannigan of Brooklyn.
Smoked ham is a favored meat for the week-end. Chains feature it as a week-end special and the City Department of Markets reports that average prices are at their lowest in three years.
"MEDIC," the National Broadcasting Company's series on the medical profession, seldom has been more timely and genuinely educational than it was this week.
If plans of a newly organized "foundation" materialize, parents soon can expect youngsters to start minding their p's and q's with enthusiasm.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--The President of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., said today that the remark of John V. Riffe about labor unity yesterday were contrary to the union's position.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--Britain and the United States showed determination today to resist any widening of their difference over China's coastal islands.

LONDON, Feb. 17--Once the Paris agreements have been ratified Britain can talk with the Soviet Union either at the highest level or at a conference of foreign ministers, Sir Winston Churchill said today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17 (AP)--Dartmouth, paced by Jim Francis and Ron Judson, rolled over Yale's basketball team, 78--62, tonight. The Indians thus avenged an Ivy League loss to the Elis earlier in the season.

Short covering, buying by Brazilian interests and speculator purchasing strengthened coffee futures yesterday for the second day on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. All options rose the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit.

BOSTON, Feb. 17--Royal Little, Rhode Island industrialist, achieved today the merger of his own diversified interests with two textile operations. The combined assets of the new organization total $161,000,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 17-- The National Rural Electric Cooperative Association called upon the Atomic Energy Commission today to cancel the Dixon-Yates contract. It also urged Congress to deny the required appropriation.

A $250,000 libel suit by former Representative W. Kingsland Macy against The New York World-Telegram Corporation is to be sent to a jury today by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer. It will be the ninth day of trial.

The pilot of the Italian Airlines plane that crashed here last Dec. 18 declined a suggestion that he land at Washington unless the New York weather improved, an official of the airline testified yesterday.
MADRID, Feb. 17--The newspaper ABC said today Spain intended to honor all her commitments to the United States but that Washington's "haggling and thriftiness" was not facilitating cooperation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--A one-vote margin in the House today saved the President's reciprocal trade program in its present form.

WHEN Walter Lippmann's first book, "A Preface to Politics," was published in 1913 its brilliant author was only 24 years old. Now, nearly forty-two years later, his twenty-first book, ''The Public Philosophy," * is published. It is just the kind of book Mr. Lippmann's loyal readers would expect it to be--learned, lucid, intellectually provocative and a little vague and abstract.
Harvey Matusow said yesterday that he found courage to undo the harm he had caused many persons by falsely labeling them 'Reds" while working in the children's polio ward in Dallas, Tex.
HAVANA, Feb. 17--Robert Lippincott of the West Jersey fleet won the Cuba Cup series in the twenty-fourth international Star Class regatta today.
ALBANY, Feb. 17--Governor Harriman voiced a willingness today to sit down with Republican leaders to discuss changes in his $1,345,000,000 budget.

The announced plans for the Republican National Convention of 1956 are so interesting one can hardly wait. In the first place, and this is said with all due respect to the people, scenery and climate of Chicago, the Republicans have chosen one of the loveliest cities of the Western Hemisphere.

A CONCERT of music written for the Sigma Alpha Iota Modern Music Series published by Carl Fischer, Inc., was performed at Carl Fischer Concert Hall last evening by a choral group of women's voices under the direction of Margaret Hillis. Marya Sielska was pianist and Suzanne der Derian, soprano.
ALBANY, Feb. 17--The state Attorney General urged a new law today to give him power to combat unfair trade practices and frauds.
ALBANY, Feb. 17--A bit of advice that recalls a Brooklyn baseball slogan has been offered to Mayor Wagner by Governor Harriman. It is, "Wait till next year!"
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moxed six to seventeen points (30 to 85 cents) lower yesterday. The volume of business was fair.

Irving Potash, charter member of the American Communist party and one of its convicted leaders, wants to live permanently in Communist Poland. And the United States Government is not going to stand in his way.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 17-- The Executive Committee of the West German Trade Union Federation decided today to support the campaign against the Paris agreements.

Pakistan is less than eight years old as an independent Government. It is trying to solve some highly complex economic and social problems. It is trying to write a constitution. It is trying to establish a basic rule of law.

A. Federal Court hearing to determine whether the Civil Service Commission should be enjoined from downgrading fortynine customs employes has been postponed until Thursday. It had been scheduled for yesterday.
A double-parked truck cost the town of Lockport, N. Y., about $5,000 in interest charges this week.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., Feb. 17-- An American mountaineer will leave here tomorrow for the Himalayas to challenge the second highest unclimbed peak in the world.
The fourth annual Mardi Gras Ball of the Junior League of New York was held last night in the ballroom of the Sheraton Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--National Education Association witnesses today opposed President Eisenhower's school building plan. The President seeks to obtain $7,000,000,000 in school building in the next three years by stimulating state action and private investment.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- New weapons against obscene and objectionable "comic books" were proposed to the Legislature today.

"Betrayal of an Ideal," the first two volumes of the autobiography of G. A. Tokaev, is planned for publication later this year by Indiana University Press. The Caucasian idealist, who believed that the Russian Revolution of 1917 would bring liberation to his country, was expelled three times and each time reinstated in the Communist party.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 17 (UP)--Billy Goodloe of Valdosta, Ga., turned in his third straight round of sub-par golf to advance in the twenty-third annual national championship of golf club champions.

Plans for altering the dwelling at 108 East Thirty-sixth Street into apartments have been announced in connection with the sale of the property to Herbert Kalisch, builder, in a deal negotiated by G. Vitagliano, broker. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title to the property, which was sold for cash.

A five-acre tract on Hutton Avenue in West Orange, N. J., has been purchased for improvement with a luxury-styled garden apartment project to accommodate eighty-five families. The property was acquired from the estate of Ellett G. Scarritt by Morris Tzeses and associates of Llewellyn Gates, Inc., in a transaction negotiated by Frank H. Taylor Son, Inc., as broker.
Independent railroad unions are giving serious thought to bringing their 500,000 members into a unified labor movement.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company retained its leadership as the world's largest corporate enterprise last year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Senator John W. Bricker renewed today his criticism of four television networks.

The effort of the Defense Department to improve security procedures affecting workers in private industry is welcome and commendable, but it should not be allowed to obscure the need for more far-reaching changes in the federal employe security program.

Two of Broadway's illustrious ladies of the stage, Helen Hayes and Mary Martin, will appear this spring before Parisian theatregoers in "The Skin of Our Teeth," the Thornton Wilder Pulitzer Prize-winning play.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17-- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., has notified the House Merchant Marine Committee that it "welcomes an investigation of the maritime industry."

Following is the text of an official summary of findings and recommendations made yesterday by the State Temporary Commission on the Courts looking toward modernization of the state's judicial system: Findings 1. The existence of twentyone separte courts in the state with "great complexities as to jurisdiction, administration, financing and personnel," created over the past century "without concern for the development of a coherent system."
The complaints, hopes and pleasures of 9,948 commuters of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad came into public focus yesterday.
Dined and honored yesterday from morning to late in the evening, members of the victorious United States Davis Cup team will go into action today in the national indoor tennis championships.

House Is a Crack There are a good many definitions and usages of the word "crack." Whips can be cracked, so can petroleum, cocoa and jokes. But when the temperature registers at zero or below, brooding citizens learn--and do it the hard way--the ultimate definition of "crack."
Gov. J. Bracken Lee of Utah declared last night that "We have in Washington today what to my mind amounts to a dictatorship."
JERUSALEM, Feb. 17--David Beh-Gurion, former Premier, is returning to the Israeli Cabinet. He will fill a breach created by the withdrawal of Defense Minister Pinhas Lavon.

Ezzard Charles, former heavyweight champion, makes his first start since he was stopped by Rocky Marciano last September, opposing Charley Norkus of Jersey City tonight at Madison Square Garden. Charles is a 3-1 favorite to defeat the ex-Marine in the scheduled ten-round bout.
The city's most valuable piece of waterfront property remained idle yesterday because of a minor labor dispute, but a settlement of the trouble appeared imminent.
A NEW YORK private collection of twentieth century French paintings about to be disposed of is now being shown at the Cadby-Birch Gallery, 21 East Sixty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The drive to nominate President Eisenhower for a second term gained new momentum today.

Thirty is a significant word in the printer's world. It means the end of the story. It doesn't mean that, we are sure, when the magazine The New Yorker reaches its thirtieth birthday, as it does this week. The New Yorker may have grown up quite a lot but it hasn't become senile.
Short interest figures for the New York Stock Exchange, as of Feb. 15, will be out tomorrow. Wall Street expects them to show a drop.
"Guys and Dolls," "Finian's Rainbow" and "South Pacific" have been chosen for the second annual program of New York City's Light Opera Company. For each, it will be the first local revival.

American President Lines yesterday took the first concrete step toward implementing a tenyear $175,000,000 fleet replacement program. It submitted the only bid to the Maritime Administration for the purchase of four new and speedy Marinerclass dry cargo ships.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Herbert Brownell Jr. stepped up today his inquiry into the Harvey Matusow case.
MIAMI, Feb. 17--C. V. Whitney's stable scored its first victory of the Hialeah meeting today. Fly Wheel, third choice at a bit over 4 to 1, ran off with first money in the six-furlong feature.
The East Coast's first fleet of flying radar stations will begin arriving March 1. It will soon extend the Atlantic radar-warning net hundreds of miles out to sea.
