MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 17 (AP) --John W. Galbreath and Mrs. Dorothy Bryan Firestone were married today at All Souls Protestant Episcopal Church. Mr. Galbreath is a prominent sports figure and one of the nation's leading real estate men.
THIS is the danger season for upland game in the north.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 --"Hans Brinker," the Mary Mapes Dodge book about the Dutch boy and the silver skates, will be made into a motion picture by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
Michael J. Quill traveled to Brooklyn yesterday to open wage talks with the Transit Authority but he found the agency unwilling to discuss the subject.

Directors of Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company who will serve on the board of the institution created by a merger of these two banks were named yesterday in letters to stockholders.

Long Island defeated Yale University, 16--14, and New York beat the University of Virginia, 21--7, in first-round matches of the third annual Sherman Memorial handicap indoor polo tournament at the Squadron A Armory yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (UP)--Nick Mickoski scored two goals and two assists tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks swamped Boston with their biggest scoring outburst of the season, 10--2, to stave off elimination from the Stanley Cup play-off race.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Feb. 15--This ship scouted the uncharted shores of Weddell Sea today as far as her "point of no return." Then she sailed back toward comparative safety east of Cape Norvegia.
MEMPHIS, Tenn.--The DixonYates controversy has generated a full head of opposition steam here in an old political machine.

IT was the slickest promotional stratagem since the shrewd Jimmy Johnston, the Boy Bandit, was conning newspaper men into giving his uncaged tigers yards and yards of undeserved space on the sports pages. There wasn't a better space-stealer than the impudent Boy Bandit. He was so smart and so publicity-conscious that he even requested in his later years a change in nickname.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 643,859 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,124 cars or 0.5 per cent more than for the preceding week, 20,153 cars or 3.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 37,745 or 5.5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ballet setting of Mendelssohn's "Scotch Symphony" was the principal item on last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center. It is a lovely work, full of poetic imagination in choreographic terms, and managing in characteristic Balanchinian fashion to imply the presence of a dramatic line without any actual story or specific pantomime.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 17, 1955) TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council heard closing statements on French Togoland, and resumed questioning special representative for British Togoland.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Democratic farm, leaders in Congress took up pounding Ezra Taft Benson today at the point they left off last year.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 17 (UP) --The New York Knickerbockers checked a closing rally by Fort Wayne in the Auditorium to win, 93--86, before 2,069 fans tonight. It was the Knicks' sixth straight National Basketball Association victory and their sixth in a row over the Pistons.
An illegal wiretapping center capable of intercepting conversations on telephones of six midtown exchanges here has been discovered in a secret police raid, it was reported yesterday.
Combined production of newsprint in the United States and Canada last month set a new January record, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 17--New York City cannot solve its mounting welfare problems without the help of more professionally trained social workers.
ROME, Feb. 17--The Mayor of Florence, one of the most unusual men in Italy, this week expropriated an iron foundry and handed it to its workers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 17-- While Brazil and Colombia are unlikely to make a formal pact to set a floor under sagging coffee prices, a "gentlemen's agreement" for this purpose was thought probable here.
THANKS in large part to Liam Redmond's glowing performance, Paul Vincent Carroll's new play is enchanting. It is a "comedy-fantasy," labeled "The Wayward Saint," and acted at the Cort last evening.

VIENNA, Feb. 17 (AP)--Tenley Albright, who overcame polio as a child, recaptured the women's world figure-skating championship tonight. Her victory gave the United States a sweep of the individual honors.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 17 (AP)-- Patt Berg missed two short putts for birdies but still knocked a stroke off women's par today to take the first-round lead in the $5,000 Serbin invitation golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--An investigating commission of the Organization of American States implied today that Nicaragua was responsible for the revolt in Costa Rica last month. It said "a substantial number of the rebel forces" and their supplies had come from across the Nicaraguan border and that Costa Rica's "territorial integrity, sovereignty and political independence" had been violated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday remained unchanged from the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Stockholder approval of the merger of the American Woolen Company, Textron, Inc., and Robbins Mills, Inc., can be deemed' a personal victory for Royal Little, chairman of Textron. Only his tenacity in the face of huge odds enabled Mr. Little to achieve the gigantic consolidation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 11,000 head: trading moderately active, steady to 25 cents lower on butchers in a spotty trade: most declines on weights under 230 pounds: choice No. 1

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 17 --A record budget of $5,837,996 for 1955 was approved here today by the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church. The budget figure is more than $100,000 higher than last year's.
MONTREAL, Feb. 17 (UP)-- The Montreal Canadiens rallied tonight to gain a 4-2 victory over Detroit and regain the National Hockey League lead from the Red Wings.

LONDON, Feb. 17--The stock markets here remained plagued today by uncertainty. Investors and business men were unable to find comfort in the maintenance of the bank rate, and a range of unusual fluctuations left the prices of most domestic securities, both Government issues and industrial shares, well below yesterday's levels.
One experiment may not have produced sufficient evidence to warrant a change, but college basketball, played under professional rules, was not hard to take last night at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $65,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Alice Christensen, a Danish pianist studying in this country, made her debut last night in Town Hall with a program consisting of four works--Mozart's Sonata in C (K. 330), Schumann's "Carnaval," Niels Viggo Bentzon's "Woodcuts" (a charming title for a suite), and Carl Nielsen's Theme and Variations.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 17 --Maj. Gen. Charles W. Christenberry, president of the American Korean Foundation, tonight described the 4-H Club movement in South Korea as the backbone of that country's agriculture.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 15-- The return of German assets seized in the United States during World War II is described here as a test of relations between the two countries.

Army engineers, equipped with a mine detector, opened phase 1 yesterday in Operation Cornerstone at City Hall. The maneuver to uncover the historic stone that was laid on May 26, 1803, ended in failure.
PARIS, Feb. 17--The National Assembly has been summoned to vote tomorrow afternoon on the program and the left-center cabinet of Christian Pineau, Socialist.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) --Julius C. Holmes testified today that he made a $270,000 profit on a $10,000 investment in a 1947 surplus tanker deal.
WAVERLY, Iowa, Feb. 17 (UP) --An all-white delegation handed a Negro Air Force officer the keys to an apartment today after learning he had hesitated to move in because of "racial pressure."
Brig. Gen. George F. Schulgen, U. S. A. F., retired, former Chief of Staff of the First Air Force, died yesterday at his home in Suttons Bay, Mich. His age was 56.
Edward R. Murrow has canceled plans to make a television film of the "Porgy and Bess" opening night festivities at La Scala in Milan, Italy, next Monday.
ROME, Feb. 17--The Shah of Iran has asked Italian authorities to "protect" a 7-year-old prince considered heir presumptive to the throne of Iran.

The $250,000,000 public borrowing planned by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation will consist of $200,000,000 of debentures due in 1972 and $50,000,000 of debentures due in 1960, Charles G. Stradella, president of the company, said yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 17--The City of Memphis threatened today to short-circuit the Dixon-Yates power proposal by building its own power plant. The city buys its electric power from the Tennessee Valley Authority, to which the Dixon-Yates plant would supply power.

DIMITRI MITROPOULOS, conducting the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall, had the initiative to open the program with the early, little known and, it would appear, little valued overture of Felix Mendelssohn to "The Wedding of Camacho."
A Federal mediator will make a fresh effort today to end the strike that forced The Brooklyn Eagle to suspend publication three weeks ago.

Skiing enthusiasts were viewing the Eastern scene through rose-colored glasses yesterday. Exceptionally good conditions were reported from most centers and it looked like another busy week-end--the twelfth in succession this season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- The technical assistance program of the "United States is shifting from helping to stay hunger toward helping to stay political chaos.
LONDON, Feb. 17--Sir Godfrey Huggins, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, was made a viscount by Queen Elizabeth today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17--Corn futures sold off here today as long lines were liquidated.
LONDON, Feb. 17--A Northampton teacher who caned all but one of her thirty-eight 9year-old pupils has been reprimanded and transferred to another school.

In a move to loosen the tongues of teachers suspected of Communist affiliations, the law committee of the Board of Education has recommended that they be required to tell all under oath or face charges.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 17 (AP)-- Mike Souchak kept his power in check in favor of accuracy today. He blasted the Brackenridge Park course for a recordtying 60 and the first-round lead in the $12,500 Texas open tournament.

Television is being used to report an advertiser's plans. Through such techniques as the film recording and the closedcircuit telecast salesmen and retailers are learning of a company's merchandising plans, what the advertising will say and where it will appear.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 17-- A 20-year-old Canadian, Judy Kirby, captured the first event at the Middlebury College Winter Carnival opening today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 17--A hunting preserve of 1,100 acres in southern Dutchess County was acquired today by the Nuclear Development Associates of this city for conversion into a research center.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--All the testimony of Mrs. Marie Natvig, turnabout witness in the Federal Communication Commission's case against Edward Lamb, was junked today as "completely incredible."

The authorization of twentyone new justices for the State Supreme Court was recommended yesterday by the Temporary State Commission on the Courts. Sixteen of the jurists would be assigned to this city and nearby areas.
The Federal Government has agreed to look into the problem of Staten Island's polluted air, windblown from neighboring New Jersey.
The retail business is a growing and powerful force in the nation's economy, according to J. Gordon Dakins, executive vice president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
A mild upset, in which Fordham's basketball team routed Holy Cross, 73--61, last night on the Maroon floor, may be the vehicle on which Johnny Bach's Rams may ride into a post-season tournament.

Georges Simenon, author of 152 novels under his own name and of 200 others under seventeen pseudonyms, has been elected the eleventh president of Mystery Writers of America, Inc. The organization's 400 members include most of the leading detective story writers of the United States as well as many foreign authors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18-- The Democrats attained a formal majority in the Senate today for the first time in the Democratic Eighty - fourth Congress. Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon was officially received into the party fold amid the huzzahs of leaders and rank and file.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Senator Lister Hill linked a New York investment banker today with the Administration's development of the Dixon-Yates private power contract.

Art experts have long recognized the vitality and uninhibited, quality of childish drawings. The primitive lines of kindergarten Picassos and the brilliant colors chosen by grade school Van Goghs have been the delight and despair of adult artists striving to recapture the fine careless rapture that comes so easily to the young.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18--Further liquidaion in new crop wheat deliveries caused a sharp dip in those months today. There were predictions for snow in the Southwest and blizzard conditions in Kansas and Nebraska. At the same time March and May wheat showed strength, presumably the result of backspreading operations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--Secretary of State John Foster Dulles left for Bangkok this afternoon to take part in the organizational meeting of the Manila Pact powers.
MIAMI, Feb. 18--The top handicap of the Florida racing season will be run tomorrow at Hialeah. It's the mile-and-a- quarter Widener.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Traffic lights in main traffic arteries are still timed as they were years ago. The consequence is costly delay during rush hours, nervous strain and "weaving drivers." And has anyone ever computed the loss of gasoline caused by this stopping and starting?

HAVANA, Feb. 18 (AP)--Kurush IV of Havana won the Bacardi Cup by default today as Dingo, skippered by James Schoonmaker of the Central Long Island Sound (Conn.) fleet was disqualified for interference in the second leg of the three- race series in the annual Star Class regatta.

CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 18--The United States is not popular in India for reasons both political and psychological. Neither country has a particularly acute understanding of the other. The result is, as one distinguished Indian says, "a touch of a sneer on both sides.''
MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 19 --Moscow proposed today that all nations should freeze the strength of their armed forces at the level of Jan. 1, 1955, and destroy all nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) --Known cases of hepatitis have tripled in the last three years--but health officials don't know why. The disease rose to fifth place of prevalence in the Health Department's list of communicable diseases.
The pilot of the Italian Airlines plane that crashed Dec. 18 was warned several times that he was coming in too low and made a "very abrupt" climbing maneuver shortly before the sudden final plunge.
The biggest board game in town--with life and death stakes --is played around the clock by thirty intent men in a downtown office building.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 --The special effects experts at Columbia will attempt to duplicate the eruption of Krakatoa, Aug. 26-28, in 1883. The studio estimates it will cost mone than $500,000 to simulate the convulsions that rocked the island in the Netherlands Indies and caused tidal waves that resulted in an estimated 36,000 casualties.

Turkey roasted without stuffing is an excellent possibility for Sunday dinner. It may reappear again, sliced cold, on the holiday table for Washington's birthday. In fact, if the bird is prepared today, it will not be necessary to do any elaborate cooking either tomorrow or on the holiday.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, Feb. 19--Nationalist bombers attacked a submarine and presumably sank her yesterday, Chinese Nationalist Air Force officials said last night.
Six months of painstaking detective work paid off last night in the arrest of a burglary suspect who admitted robbing 750 apartments of $500,000 in loot in little more than a year.
New light on the Soviet agricultural situation has been provided by Moscow's purchase of more than 200,000 short tons of Cuban raw sugar.
A real breakdown in the administration of justice in New York City and State is threatened if something is not done quickly about congestion and delay in the courts, according to Harrison Tweed.
Delegates to the convention of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., voted yesterday to raise both the members' dues and the salary of their president, Michael J. Quill.

Whatever differences seemed to exist between the Foreign Operations Administration and the Department of the Treasury on aid to Asia have been resolved. An Administration program, supported by the National Security Council, will shortly be sent to Congress.
The Coast Guard investigation into the crash of two merchant ships a week ago in New York harbor continued for the fifth day yesterday.
ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Feb. 17--This Navy icebreaker has discovered a potential airfield and camp site on the Atlantic side of the Antarctic continent.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 6 to 17 points (30 to 85 cents a bale) net higher than Thursday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Feb. 18--The Soviet Union's proposal today for an arms freeze was generally interpreted as another move to block the arming of West Germany.
The most exciting indoor track and field season in years will reach its high point tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's sixty-seventh American championships.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 18-- Repeated rumors of an impending Syrian Army coup seem to be completely without foundation.

LONDON, Feb. 18--Doubts about the seaworthiness of welded ships built in the United States have been allayed here by a British Admiralty committee. Performance under service conditions compared favorably with those of riveted ships built in Britain, the committee found.
Federal and local investigations of wiretap operations in an East Side apartment house were begun yesterday.
The two Texas toll expressways to be financed under the auspices of private, non-profit companies received the blessing yesterday of the Texas State Highway Commission.

EL ZAMORANO, Honduras, Feb. 18--A new hope for hemisphere solidarity was expressed here today by Vice President Richard M. Nixon. He presided at the tenth graduation exercises of the Pan American Agricultural School.

The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker: To help eliminate the crowding of clothes in a closet there is a rod fitted with sliding hooks, from which hangers are suspended, Called the Wunda Roll, the rod can be screwed on the underside of a closet shelf.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP)--The biggest price tumble since 1951 hit the London Stock Exchange today, with dealers hurriedly unloading in all sections.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18-- Forty states were represented today as opposed to President Eisenhower's school construction bill.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 18 --A young man switched on a lamp in his room here yesterday morning and then turned on a television set. Both acts were wondrous feats to him because his body and arms and legs have been paralyzed for three years. A victim of polio, 25-year-old Edward Siegler of 17 Arrandale Avenue can move his head one inch to the right only.

A conference on "Our Responsibility to Our Troubled Children" under auspices of the Department of Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will be held on March 11 at the Biltmore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)-- Do you pay a baby sitter an average of $4 a week?

Will Begin at 8 P. M. Meetings, in this town where so many are held, never begin on time. Our correspondent, who has attended big ones and small ones, long ones and short ones, in the line of duty more often than he likes to recall, is an authority on the subject.

Washington, Feb. 18 (AP)-- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption in January averaged 35,564 bales each working day. This compared with an average of 33,923 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 32,070 for December. The daily average consumption of linters was 4,546 bales, compared with 4,103 a year ago and 4,002 for December.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The average price or butcher hogs sank to the lowest level since April, 1950, and the top fell to a new low since December, 1952, today.

JANE SCHLEICHER, soprano, made her debut in a song program at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening. A native of Massachusetts, Miss Schleicher studied at the New England Conservatory of Music and in 1952 was the recipient of the Eleanor Steber Vocal Scholarship.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 (AP)--The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and list of winter sports conditions: NEW HAMPSHIRE Fair tomorrow, with little change in temperature. Franconia--Cannon Mountain: 14-50

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 18 (AP) --Fourteen colts were entered today in tomorrow's $137,500 Santa Anita Derby. The Murcain Stable's Blue Ruler, winner of five straight races, is the probable favorite to capture the seventeenth running.

The program drafted by the American Federation of Labor for dealing with the union welfare fund problem is especially commendable because it is primarily based on self-discipline by the unions themselves. The A. F. L. has been less forthright, hitherto, than the Congress of Industrial Organizations in cracking down on welfare fund abuses.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18 --Jacob K. Javits, Attorney General of New York State, urged tonight a fundamental standard of ethics for political candidates.

KOLSAAS, Norway, Feb. 15-- The left flank of the free world, extending 1,500 miles from Schleswig-Holstein to North Cape, in Norway, could not resist a major attack, with its present defenses, according to the consensus of military experts.

One of the most intensive manhunts in the city's criminal history was pressed all day yesterday and through the night. The fugitive, a murder suspect, had disarmed three detectives in Harlem early yesterday and an hour later had survived a pistol battle with four other detectives.

The backlog of new corporate issues of bonds and preferred stocks for which marketing dates have been set totaled $549,558,000 yesterday, according to the Investment Dealers Digest. This compares with 5503,000,000 a week earlier.

New Yorkers who live in single rooms that they consider inadequate for any kind of cookery might take a lesson from Miss Thyra Samter Winslow, writer and cookery enthusiast. In a hotel room equipped with a one- burner hot plate, she manages to prepare not only her own meals but successful dinners for as many as six guests.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The report in the Feb. 13 issue of the anti-Eisenhower G. O. P. meeting in Chicago is of interest in showing the change in position of the "isolationists."
DETROIT, Feb. 18--The automobile industry is expected to set a record high, for passenger car production this week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Harvey Matusow, the self-proclaimed liar, had more company today.

THE over-abundance of predators in many eastern states has resulted in proposals by many sportsmen's groups for an increase in bounty payments on some of these predators and the addition of others to the bounty list.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 (UP)--The State Department of Commerce today reported the following winter sports conditions: Alpine Meadows--12 inches new, 6-15 inches packed; skiing good. Bearpen Mountain (Prattsville)--1 inch windblown, 18-50 inches old; good.
TRENTON, Feb. 18--The cost of milk in New Jersey dropped an average of 2 cents a quart today as an aftermath of the suspension of state retail price controls.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The State Department left the door unlatched today for a possible international conference on Formosa.
The Dixon-Yates power proposal was defended here yesterday by Eugene A. Yates.

When Joe Schwartz was 9 years old, his father, the late Horton Schwartz, a Huntington (L. I.) jeweler, put him on a horse. Joe was winning prizes with open jumpers when he was 10 and began pestering his parents for a steed of his own.
SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 18 (AP)-- Mike Souchak scrambled to a three-under-par 68 today to retain his lead at the halfway mark in the $12,500 Texas open tournament with 128.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Man's lengthening life span may be expected to bring an increase in blindness and other eye troubles, a state welfare official warned today.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 18 --Atomic scientists played tag with wild, wintry weather on the Nevada desert for twelve hours today.
TAULLIERVILLE-EL AROUSSIA, Tunisia, Feb. 11--The fever of politics carries all before it in Tunis, but here in the Medjerda Valley, barely twenty miles away, the principal issue ia economic survival.

A grand total of 763 pints of blood given in Bank Week of the regional Red Cross program was completed yesterday. The week, with downtown Manhattan bank employes giving blood at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street, began on Monday. Yesterday's total was 144.
ROME, Feb. 18 (UP)--A mother gave up today her fight to stop her 7-year-old son, the heir presumptive to the Iranian throne, from following a course that one day might make him the Shah of Iran.

"Aren't any of the old rules any good?" That question might well have been asked yesterday by technicians in Wall Street as they quit the downtown canyons for the week-end. The action of the market in the last three sessions had defied past behavior patterns. The chart readers had expected a continued upsurge in stock prices after Tuesday, along with, greater activity. Instead, prices gave ground.
ALBANY, Feb. 18--Governor Harriman confessed today that he really is seeking a bigger office.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 18 --The University of New Hampshire team held a fractional advantage at the end of the first day of the Eastern intercollegiate ski championship.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your report of Feb. 10 of the introduction into the Senate by Senator Kefauver and fourteen other Senators of the resolution for an Atlantic exploratory convention states that this group urged the President to invite the NATO Powers to a "conference."
DOWN in the Village, the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue, a fortress of tradition amidst the advance guard, is holding its annual exhibition of oil paintings.

THE Symphony of the Air, which was once the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, keeps on doing things that are unusual and worth doing. Last night at Carnegie Hall it presented a program devoted entirely to Sibelius, and though the Finnish composer's position has long since been established, all-Sibelius programs are rare.
SHREVEPORT, La., Feb. 15-- At last unification has come to the services: the Air Force is now swinging hammocks in its jet bombers.

The New York State Temporary Commission on the Courts, with Harrison Tweed as chairman, has reached a definite conclusion that the state needs a complete rebuilding of its judicial structure, along simplified and integrated lines. The commission has as yet no specific program to propose, either about the organization of the courts or their procedures.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The Export-Import Bank opened credits totaling $6,570,000 today to aid three export companies in financing sales of productive machinery abroad.

It evidently seemed to the Administration a few months ago very simple to contract with Mr. Dixon and Mr. Yates to build a private power plant in West Memphis to replace power that the Tennessee Valley Authority was delivering to the Atomic Energy Commission near Paducah.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (UP)--A viscount's son and his American wife tried today to give up their right to become a lord and lady, but the House of Lords turned them down. They were told in effect that their inheritance of the titles must take its natural course.
Tony Trabert and Hamilton Richardson of the Davis Cup team scored decisive victories last night in the opening round of the national indoor tennis championship.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 18 (AP)-- Fay Crocker of Montevideo, Uruguay, made a strong bid for her first United States golf victory today when she surged into a three-stroke lead at the halfway point in the $5,000 women's open (Serbin) tournament.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18-- President Eisenhower threw the full weight of his personal prestige today behind House passage of an unmodified reciprocal trade bill. He won by seven votes.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 18 --Pakistan and Turkey, partners in a mutual defense pact, were hopeful today that eight other Moslem states would join them in the alliance. The eight are Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, Saudi Arabia and Yemen.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith told Congress today that push-button war of the hydrogen age required more, not fewer, fighting men.
A staff of fifty-nine persons, with three deputy commissioners, is contemplated by the new Department of Commerce and Public Events. One deputy would earn $20,000 a year and the others $15,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The problem of selecting competent judges is again to the fore. The admirable editorial in your Feb. 12 issue aptly points out that the election of judges is a perfect farce. In my opinion, not more than two or three out of every hundred voters-- with the exception of lawyers-- know anything at all about the candidates.

Ezzard Charles chopped his way to victory over Charley Norkus of Port Washington, L. I., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The former heavyweight champion of the world gained the unanimous decision, to the satisfaction of the 5,304 fans in attendance.

Although Wall Street had expected a decline, the aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange-the borrowed stocks that have teen sold in expectation of replacing them at a lower figure -- rose between Jan. 14 and Feb. 15.
All cocoa futures fell the cent- a-pound limit yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 --A Californian received a patent this week for a swimming pool cover designed for protection "against children, dirt, leaves, papers and other foreign matter."

CHICAGO, Feb. 18--Armour Co. had a profit in the first quarter of its current fiscal year, as compared with a loss in the corresponding period a year ago, F. W. Specht, president and chairman, told stockholders today at the company's annual meeting. Armour's fiscal year ended last Oct. 30.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18-- The Southern Pacific Company is going into the pipeline business. A railroad that has operated trucks and steamships, it announced plans today to build an 800-mile $30,000,000 pipeline to transport refined petroleum, products.
The states of the upper Midwest are out to break the bonds of dependence on agriculture.

A Supreme Court jury awarded $50,000 damages yesterday to former Representative W. Kingsland Macy in his $250,000 libel suit against The New York World - Telegram Corporation. The former Suffolk Republican leader called this "a great vindication."
The trucking industry has come a long way in the last decade, the American Trucking Associations showed yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 18 --The Eastern and Western delegations will differ on how the economic provisions of the Manila Pact should be put into effect when the members hold their first council meeting here next week.
PARIS, Saturday, Feb. 19--By a vote of 312 to 268, the French National Assembly refused its confidence early today to the Cabinet submitted by Christian Pineau.

Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Saint of Bleecker Street," which had been tentatively scheduled to close Feb. 26 unless public support was forthcoming, will remain at the Broadway Theatre at least through April 2.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 18--The Nationalist Government has used much of the last two days in Parliament for a reply to the Opposition charge that a total segregation policy would wreck the South African economy.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18--Harold Stassen said today the new long- term economic aid program for Asia had been approved.

The decision of the House of Representatives yesterday to extend and enlarge the reciprocal trade agreements program was a victory for continued internal economic progress and for a sound and stable foreign economic policy as well.
Stocks weathered a heavy wave of selling yesterday afternoor and then pushed through to new twenty-five-year highs.

A former Government attorney and two business associates were convicted yesterday by a Federal Court jury of evading $850,000 in income taxes. They will be sentenced March 8 by Judge Lawrence E. Walsh.
St. Peter's of Jersey City rallied in the second half to defeat Brooklyn College, 79--67, in basketball at Roosevelt Hall gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night.
EASTVIEW, N. Y., Feb. 18-- The unloading of sixteen miles of huge pipe for a still unauthorized natural gas line across Westchester County has been completed.

A record net income of $11,678,645 was attained last year by Thompson Products, Inc., and it's subsidiaries, despite a decline in sales from 1953. The report by F. C. Crawford, board chairman, and J. D. Wright, president, was issued yesterday.

The ninth annual National Photographic Show opened yesterday in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue. It will run through Tuesday. The show will be open to the public daily from 1 to 10 P. M. and tomorrow from 2 to 10 P. M.

BERLIN, Feb. 18--Erich Ollenhauer, leader of the West German Social Democratic party, asserted today there had been massive United States intervention in the West German Parliamentary elections. He expressed doubt that on that basis the Bonn Government had an actual mandate from the people to arm West Germany.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 18 --The United States Merchant Marine Academy basketball team defeated the Long Island Aggies, 83--66, in O'Hara Hall tonight.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 17-- West Germany has become the third-ranking trading power in the world, according to official reports published here.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 18, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Had breakfast with Dr. James B. Conant, High Commissioner to Germany. Sent message to Chiang Kai-shek hailing evacuation of Tachens as example of "effective cooperation."
LONDON, Feb. 18--Hermann Field said today Poland had paid him $50,000 in indemnity for his unjust imprisonment.

Louis and Marie D. Dieu have sold the five-story house at 110 East Seventieth Street, near Park Avenue, to an investing client of Julius Wikler, attorney, who plans to occupy the triplex apartment in the building. The house is 20 by 100 feet and recently was altered into a nine- room garden triplex suite with four bathrooms and a duplex with six rooms and three baths.
MOSCOW, Feb. 18--In a swirling snowstorm a brand new United States flag showed its bright colors atop Dynamo Stadium in Moscow today.
If 114 city agencies were to have their way, it would cost $224,609,964 more to run New York City in 1955-56 than in the present fiscal year.

Louis and Marie D. Dieu have sold the five-story house at 110 East Seventieth Street, near Park Avenue, to an investing client of Julius Wikler, attorney, who plans to occupy the triplex apartment in the building. The house is 20 by 100 feet and recently was altered into a nine- room garden triplex suite with four bathrooms and a duplex with six rooms and three baths.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) Senate juvenile delinquency investigators demanded today that publishers clean up crime and horror comic books that demonstrated depravity to children.

STEPHEN POTTER, who is the author of three admirable books on making enemies of your best friends, "Gamesmanship," "Lifemanship" and "One-Upmanship," has now undertaken to demonstrate in a book which is at once a dissertation and an anthology just what the English sense of humor is.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- If this were an ideal world in which Government officials told the truth in response to questions about the Far East crisis, the transcript would be about as follows:
THE No. 1 public health problem today is not heart disease or cancer or any of the other ailments that have received wide attention in recent years. The No. 1 problem is mental illness.
THEY are beginning to compare Renata Tebaldi with Kirsten Flagstad because the new soprano from Italy has become an instantaneous magnet at the Metropolitan Opera House.
One factor in United States industrial leadership has been the steady improvement here of specialized instruments for measuring and controlling manufacturing processes.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19 -- Princeton's undefeated varsity swimming team extended its streak to eight victories today by defeating Army, 44 -- 40, in Dillon Pool.
Plans have been formulated at recent meetings for the annual Loyola luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Jesuit Missions to be given March 10 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

ROCHESTER -- Numerically, the Nineteenth Rochester International Salon of Photography, Inc., which was judged here last week-end, is the most successful in this association's long career. In line with its reputation as "the world's largest salon of photography," the sponsor received a total of 7,032 pictures in all categories from 1,790 photographers in various parts of the United States and thirty-one foreign countries.
The Government is worried again about the bulging volume of United States exports of scrap iron and steel.

WHEN Jadih Yazhi was 5 years old he unwittingly spent a night in a cave with a bear. Among the Navajo this is a serious matter and at 12, that long-ago experience, only suspected, never admitted, still sets Jadih a little apart from his people.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA off Antarctics, Feb. 18 -- The six emperor penguins brought aboard this icebreaker three days ago have begun to eat fish -- and also to nip the noses of those shoving it down their throats.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The meaning of next week's Southeast Asia defense conference at Bangkok stands out in sharp contrast to that of the Afro-Asian conference scheduled for April in Indonesia.
The Greek-Argentine shipping operator Aristotle Socrates Onassis is reported to be working on a modification of his oil tanker contract with the Government of Saudi Arabia.

A KIND of Kentucky mountain "Cotter's Saturday Night," this book is a treasure of the stories, language and songs of Balis and Abigail Ritchie, their fourteen children, and numerous kinfolks who live in and around the village of Viper in the Cumberland Mountains.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 19 -- Yale won seven of ten events today to defeat Navy's swimming team, 58 -- 26.

In spite of expanding educational facilities for the training of health personnel, our national population growth and the rising demands for health services will cause a continuing personnel shortage "for many years to come."
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Sir Anthony Eden will press British proposals for Nationalist China's withdrawal from Quemoy and Matsu when he meets Secretary of State Dulles next week.

After reading your article on our art being exhibited in Europe, I am wondering: Why do we keep on sending to Europe paintings dating from colonial times and the birth of the republic, work by the genre painters of the Nineteenth Century and landscapes by the American followers of Impressionism?

THIS is an engaging little volume that recounts those action-packed days in Chicago during July, 1952, when the Democratic convention overcame the reluctance of Adlai E. Stevenson, then a candidate for reelection as Governor of Illinois, and forced upon him its nomination as President of the United States.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, denied today economic grants to Asia would be raised from $700,000,000 a year to $1,000,000,000.

PREPARATIONS for Ireland's annual spring festival and home-coming, May 8 to 29, indicate that this year's An Tostal will provide visitors with top entertainment. Racing, sports events, contests, with traditional Irish games like Gaelic hurling enliven the more measured pageants, dramas and chorals.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Administration sources appeared confident this week that Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York would be confirmed very soon as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
The Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission asked New York and New Jersey for $300,000 yesterday to expand its studies of metropolitan transit needs.
Around-the-clock police protection was provided early today for Mrs. Mary Aronowitz, whose husband was slain in Brooklyn last Tuesday. Her life was threatened yesterday.

THERE is something to be said for the innumerable children spawned out of Norman Douglas' "South Wind" -- the sidelong glance, the cold ironical glow, the twisting of so many guttering intellectual knives, the old ladles busy at their knitting while the lovers tumble and the diplomats prattle and the world fades into Nepenthe.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 17 -- India is examining the possibility of commercial exploitation of ramie, a fiber plant that grows in great abundance in Assam and all along the foothills of the Himalayas.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Conservation groups clashed today over two proposed constitutional amendments that would change the state's forest preserve policy.

Frozen, canned, smoked, pickled or just plain fresh fish come into their own this week. Wednesday is the start of Lent, a period when millions of persons reverse their usual practice of eating meat six days a week and fish on only one day.
NEWPORT, R. I., Feb. 17 -- The ocean area off Narragansett Bay has been officially designated Rhode Island Sound by the United States Board of Geographic Names.

SPANISH zarzuelas are not presented in United States theatres, but there is increasing evidence that the unique genre they represent is becoming a part of America's musical consciousness. The latest proof is that Columbia has followed in the footsteps of Montilla, Soria, Angel and London in recording these irresistible Spanish operettas.

THE old joke about the little Indian who sneaks into the baggage car of the Santa Fe Chief at Albuquerque and mutilates movies in their transit from Hollywood to New York (which accounts, so they say, for the frequent disparity between the studio descriptions and the local reviews of films) might be taken as a serious indication of what happens to some foreign pictures in their passage from abroad.

Probably the Eisenhower Administration has done nothing with better intentions than in its proposal to put federal money into the construction of school buildings in the states. The device chosen has been tried in some states, such as Pennsylvania.
MANILA, Feb. 19 -- The Manila treaty was ratified and put into force today.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 19 -- A deadlock has been reached in a dispute between the trustees of the Nanyang University and Dr. Lin Yutang, American-educated philosopher and author who left New York to become chancellor of the university now being built.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19 -- Bill Cleary scored two goals and assisted on three others today as Harvard's hockey team gained a 6-2 victory over Princeton.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 19 -- In a picturesque winter setting, the Middlebury ski team retained the Eastern intercollegiate title today.

THE Vanderbilt Cup tournament is under way at the McAlpin Hotel. Many of the best bridge players in the United States (and in the world) are in it. They will play with an awareness that would be incomprehensible to the casual player, and after every session they will conduct post-mortems in which every slip will be criticized mercilessly.

SINCE the late Nineteen Forties, the influence of Existentialism on French fiction has conspicuously declined. Jean-Paul Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir, to be sure, have become securely established as major figures on the French literary landscape.
PARIS, Feb. 19 -- A forty-eight strike of Air France pilots was ordered today. The strike, which is to begin at midnight, will affect departures from Paris and Algiers only.

BOSTON -- For the first time in several years, black ink is outselling red in northern New England ski areas. A blanket of snow that settled over the mountains in early December remains as thick as a Yankee bed puff. Beneath it, resort operators are snuggled down in a reality of profits instead of nightmares of foreclosures.
OTTAWA, Feb. 15 -- The National Research Council of Canada has developed an underwater television unit which promises to be of considerable benefit to the fishing industry in this country.
DARTMOUTH, N. S., Feb. 19 (UP) -- A blizzard that turned into a rainstorm today forced postponement of the opening of the international ice horse racing meet.

A FEW months before the Declaration of American Independence was proclaimed, Father Francisco Garces of the Spanish missions in Mexico and Arizona set out from the mouth of the Gila River to explore a route toward California.
IN his discussion of the National Book Awards in In and Out of Books, Harvey Breit asks why "Hadrian's Memoirs," by Marguerite Yourcenar, was not considered by the fiction jury.

Some 750 musicians of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., signed a petition yesterday asking the board of directors to prevent the scheduled appearances of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on March 1, March 30 and April 1.

DOES a wife with a successful business career "diminish" her husband? Stephen Ryland hadn't felt "diminished" till scheming Lisa Bowes made the term her scalpel. True, Kay Ryland's decorating business brings in a larger income than her husband's, which can make for touchiness and domestic friction.

THE gray-and-silver Anscoflex box camera designed by Raymond Loewy Associates for Ansco has been selected for inclusion in the semi-annual "Good Design" show sponsored jointly by the Museum of Modern Art and Chicago's Merchandise Mart.
Two museum shows and a major annual exhibition are among the outstanding art events of the week.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- This city, recalling its golden age as the leading port on Lake Ontario, is busy planning for the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, today predicted victory in the Senate for President Eisenhower's tariff-cutting foreign trade program that has been approved by the House.

When a circus man is plotting his spring itinerary, or a banker is looking for a promising branch location, or a market researcher needs to know how much tinsel is imported, he calls up the United States Department of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, disclosed today that he had discussed with President Eisenhower a gift of United States wheat to the Soviet Union.
Sandy Saddler, featherweight champion of the world, will defend his title against Red Top Davis of Hartford, Conn., at Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

Every year about this time the Mayor of New York City makes a number of journeys to Albany in search of more state aid to the city. In past years, the trips have usually ended in acrimony. Last year was typical. When Republican Governor Dewey turned down Democratic Mayor Wagner's request for aid, the Democrats charged the city was being "short-changed."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Administration is putting the finishing touches on proposed reforms of its employe security procedures.

It is only twelve days since Marshal Nikolai Bulganin took over the premiership from Georgi Malenkov, and Party Secretary Nikita Khrushchev -- apparently -- took over the reins of real power in the Soviet Union. The shift in power was accompanied by the proclamation of higher goals for heavy industry and agriculture, and a new belligerence toward the West.

Tony Trabert and Hamilton Richardson returned to the business of swatting tennis balls yesterday as the second day of play was completed in the national indoor singles championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Feb. 19 -- Negotiations for the sale of historic Price's Hotel at Pleasure Bay here are under way. The famous hostelry, which was 100 years old last summer, was once the rendezvous point for Presidents, society figures and notables of the stage and sporting world.

DOWN in Sarasota, Fla., the John and Mable Ringling Museum last week opened a novel loan exhibition, provocatively entitled "Director's Choice." In this show, thirty-three museum directors have put themselves on record by choosing, from among the works acquired by their institutions during the last twenty years, a personal favorite.

February seems to weary a little of itself, about now, and not wish it were long as other months. Most of us agree. February comes at an unfortunate time, when we are willing to have an end of winter and when spring is not yet ready to make an entrance.
More than 90,000 passengers crossed the North Atlantic last year in Italian Line passenger vessels.

James A. Phillips, the new Democratic leader of Queens, announced yesterday a program to strengthen the party. It will seek to coordinate the party's activities with the interests of Queens civic, industrial and labor groups.
BROOKHAVEN, L. I., Feb. 19 -- The "most spectacular" birds in the world can be found only a short distance from Manhattan, in the opinion of a hobbyist who paints them.
Formation of a committee whose work may lead to higher interest payments on savings accounts will be announced tomorrow by the New York State Bankers Association.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Feb. 19 (UP) -- The International Olympic Committee, expecting possible amateurism squabbles at the Olympics next year, today attempted to draw a strict line between amateurism and professionalism in soccer and skiing.

A fleet foursome from Lincoln High of Jersey City that included three brothers uncorked a spectacular clocking of 3:24.4 for the mile relay at the National Amateur Athletic Union interscholastic track and field championships at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
Columbia's track team maintained its supremacy over Rutgers with a 85 1/2-23 1/2 victory over the Scarlet at the Morningside Heights campus yesterday afternoon.
In his letter of Feb. 6 Dr. Leo Szilard predicts the beginning of the next world war for the near future and advocates the search of new means for its prevention.
BERLIN, N. H., Feb. 19 -- Leo Massa, a building contractor of Red Bank, N. J., today won the 18-kilometer international cross-country ski race in 1 hour 2 minutes 35 seconds.
Fifty persons were picked up by the police in gambling raids in Brooklyn and Manhattan yesterday.
The Board of Health has designated Rikers Island Hospital, run by the Department of Correction, as a place to send the rare tuberculosis patient who deliberately endangers the health of others.

HOVE, England. SO much has been written during the last half-century about the sociology, psychology and symbolism of Ibsen's plays that, instead of stimulating healthy appetites, it has succeeded only in deadening the interest of theatregoers, dulling the wits of interpreters, and confounding producers and critics alike.

" THE general is remarkable for a most elegant letter," observed an Englishman, who knew him well, on the eve of the Revolution. George Washington had left school at 15; yet Jonathan Boucher was correct in his estimate, for, as Saul K. Padover tells us. The National Conference of Christians and Jews, sponsor of the observance, is striving toward a goal of unity in which the religious ideals of brotherhood and justice will become the standards of human values.

HOME gardeners often wonder if they can grow blueberries in regular garden soil or if they need a special, highly acid soil for success. And on the basis of a few years experience and working with some 300 bushes of the Atlantic, Rubel, Pemberton and Jersey varieties I can safely say yes to the first question.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Most of New York State's population growth since 1940 has been in the suburbs of the larger cities.
Sixty-four qualifying contract bridge teams played first-round knockout matches here last night for the Vanderbilt Cup.
OUR mail one morning late last month was considerably enlivened by a firm and forthright communication from a Wilmington, Del., boy.

WHILE industrial and retail activity may have slackened slightly in recent days, there is nothing visible in the economy which might tend to reverse the long-term rise. Merchants and producers are aware of a sense of "positiveness" in the air induced, no doubt, by a continuing strong demand for almost all types of consumer goods, and a general firmness of prices.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 10 -- Government research programs at universities were described today as possible "serious dangers" to this country's cultural life.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- House Democrats aimed today at cutting $20 from the income tax of every taxpayer next year, with an additional $20 allowance for each dependent.

AUDEN is the Great Ruminator of modern poetry. In many ways he is also the typical poet of our age. In him are the rare words no one really wants to look up. In him are the negative convictions which are the trade-mark of modernism.

HONG KONG, Feb. 19 -- Since the Chinese Communists first came to power in 1949 they have helped to lead the world from one crisis to another. In the process they have relied on propaganda as well as on military action.

Cruelty to children in New York is just as shocking today as it was eighty years ago, but now more cases are detected and corrected, according to Elbridge T. Gerry, president of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

Out-of-town buyers about finished their inspection of women's better summer apparel lines last week, buying offices report. Stores were looking for immediate delivery of these lines to freshen spring dress stocks.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Feb. 12 -- The oldest Jewish congregation in the Western Hemisphere has rounded out three centuries of activity here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- William Randolph Hearst Jr., back from Moscow, said after a White House visit today that he had told President Eisenhower he thought "his policy of strength without provocation -- keeping our guard up -- was paying off over there."

RICHMOND, Feb. 19 -- Fifth Reserve District department stores are not maintaining the fast pace set in the early weeks of the year and while volume to date is 6 per cent higher than it was in the same 1954 period, trade for the last four weeks has just broken even.

THE independent, identical and sometimes intransigent twin brothers Boulting, makers of "Seven Days to Noon," are on their own again for the first time since that "Oscar" - winning enterprise, which has by now almost paid its way on American television alone with, they report, a score of some 600 screenings.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 19 -- An 11-year-old boy, James Levine, will be piano soloist with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra in a United Fine Arts Fund concert Monday. He will play the Mozart Piano Concerto in E flat major.

INTERESTED in hi-jinks with hi-fi? Columbia has recently issued a disk named Strange to Your Ears in which Jim Fassett takes canaries down a couple of octaves (sounds almost like the Eighth Avenue Express going through a local stop), drops a pin so you can hear it, and in general disports himself with acoustic phenomena with the activity of a kid turned loose in a toy shop.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- Boris Shilkov, Russian speed-skating ace who went to Japan to win the world title last year, gained the lead today before the home folks in the first half of the 1955 championships.

A modern graduate program to prepare superintendents and other administrative personnel for public schools is proposed by Dr. John K. Norton, head of the department of educational administration at Teachers College, Columbia University, in the current issue of the Teachers College Record, the college's professional journal.

THIS summer it is planned that the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre will be ready for a season of repertory at Stratford, Conn., which is between New Haven and Bridgeport on the Housatonic River.

CAPETOWN, Feb. 19 -- The high-riding Nationalist party forces of Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom had an unsettling experience this week. They had to sit quietly in Parliament, and listen to some blunt talk about the adverse effect of their racist policies on the South African economy.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 -- The last car will roll off the assembly line of the twenty-five-year-old Ford assembly plant at Richmond, Calif., soon after 3 P. M. on Thursday. Operations at the Ford division's new assembly plant near San Jose, Calif., will start four days later.
A fashion-plate robber, who dawdled the afternoon away at an art auction, failed last night in an attempt to hold up the Savoy Art and Auction Galleries.

LIKE Graham Greene, Geoffrey Household writes two kinds of fiction. "Fellow Passenger" is of the order of "Rogue Male" and "A Rough Shoot," not a novel but a "romance," a distinction which seems to say to the reader, "You mustn't look for heavy matters here.
Mayor Wagner's trip to Albany last week to ask the Legislature for more money for New York City public schools again pointed up the problems confronting the nation's largest school system.

STAN MUSIAL took the first snip. While cameras clicked, Stan the Man ceremoniously posed with wire-clippers in hand and then cut the first strand of the right-field screen in St. Louis. Thus did the dismantling job begin. By this time the pavilion screen in Busch Stadium has been removed and left-handed hitters will have their most inviting target since the barrier was put in place twenty-five years ago.

To millions of Americans, believers in Almighty God and His Providence, and the supernatural and natural truths He has revealed to men by inspiration and by the light of the intellects He gave them, Judge Hand's paean for agnosticism and relativism will be shocking.

Dick Ricketts of Duquesne and Ed Conlin, Fordham's high-scoring star, were named yesterday to the East squad for the annual Fresh Air Fund East-West College All-Star basketball game at Madison Square Garden, March 26. They are the first players to be selected for the team.

FEEDING house, plants through their leaves is a practice I heartily endorse. The foliar application of fertilizer solutions achieves three objectives -- it feeds the plants, cleans their foliage and creates one of the most delightful indoor fragrances in winter, the smell of plants that have just been watered.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, proposed legislation today that would give the Civil Aeronautics Board the final word on award of overseas airline routes, except in cases involving national defense and foreign policy.

THE cowpunchers who drove the Longhorn herds from the Rio Grande north to Abilene or Dodge City in the late Eighteen Hundreds over Jesse Chisholm's trail had plenty of troubles to tell, It was a real man's work -- contending with choking dust, rustlers, stampedes, rattlesnakes in the bedrolls, lobo wolves, quicksand and Comanches.

TRENTON, Feb. 19 -- The Joint Appropriations Committee of the New Jersey Legislature opened hearings here this week on the record $254,289,289 partial budget submitted to the Legislature Jan. 30 by Governor Robert B. Meyner.
Concern over the possibility that the strike-bound Brooklyn Eagle may never resume publication was expressed yesterday by the president of the Brooklyn Civic Council.
ROME, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Princess Christiane Pahlevi vowed today that she would never leave the side of her 7-year-old son, Ali Patrick, a possible heir to the throne of Iran.

In an unusual venture in American education, St. Louis and Washington Universities in St. Louis, the former Catholic and the latter nonsectarian, are offering parallel courses dealing with the problem of religious understanding in American life.
Navy won the tetragonal fencing tournament at the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The midshipmen captured a total of fifty-four bouts with the three weapons -- epee, foil and saber.

WE assume the reader to be plowing conscientiously ahead and within a few brief moments he will find himself on Page 10, where he will come upon Frank Rounds' estimate of a book on slave labor in the Soviet Union. In the line of duty, Mr. Rounds, once a United States attache in Moscow, went back to a two-volume work titled "Siberia and the ExLie System," by Ceorge Ir.nn.n

OCALA, Fla. -- The tourists in Ocala are easily distinguishable from the natives this month, for the latter are all growing beards. This is in preparation for the Whisker Derby, a feature of the Southeastern Fat Stock Show to be held from Feb. 28 through March 6.
ONE thing is certain about the future of pay-as-you-see television. The controversy over putting a box-office in the nation's home is going to be a wing-dilly that could last for years.

A last-second field goal by Dick Farley gave the Syracuse Nationals an 80-78 victory over the New York Knickerbockers last night. Exactly one tick of the clock remained when the rookie from Indiana broke the tie and prevented one of the season's roughest game from going into overtime.

IN each of his three novels Gerald Sykes has been concerned with the problem of the participation of the intellectual in the life of the present day, but he differs from most writers in that theme by being neither angry nor desperate.

" THE boy walked along the narrow deserted street between walls that bared teeth of broken glass against thieves. * * * He walked in his echo, in the very middle of the road, swift and confident in his solitude." So begins Anne de Tourville's story of a Homeric youth, Yves Gael, the epitome of the far-roving Breton wanderer.

A twelve-month salaried internship under the supervision of the Kansas City city manager is included in the University of Kansas City's (Mo.) new graduate program in public administration. The university, headed by Dr. Earl J. McGrath, former United States Commissioner of Education, has introduced a graduate program in city planning leading to a Master of Arts degree.

HONOLULU, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dulles and Admiral Felix B. Stump, commander in the Pacific, conferred for two and a half hours today preparatory to their departure tonight for the Bangkok conference.
WHEN Don Herbert unwittingly grasped a steaming hot silver teapot at a restaurant here the other afternoon, he released it quickly and exclaimed, "Gee, that's a good conductor of heat."
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 19 -- Dartmouth overwhelmed the Army hockey team with eight goals in the last period for a 10-4 triumph in the Davis rink tonight.

IN the last forty-some-odd years, Cole Porter, a small, well-burnished and infinitely recherche man of 61, has written the words and music of about 500 songs which have been distributed, as circumstances required, among Yale University, of which he is a fairly atypical graduate ('13), nine motion pictures and twenty-five musical comedies. The twenty-fifth is called "Silk Stockings" and will open Thursday in a fashionable ha. Porter is fashionable but looks askance at brouhaha.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Rex C. Ellsworth's Swaps, perhaps the outstanding California-bred colt since Your Host, captured the $137,500 Santa Anita Derby by a half-length from Jean's Joe today.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb, 19 -- Fighting grimly for her first major golf victory in the United States, Fay Crocker of Montevideo, Uruguay, came through the third round of the $5,000 women's open tournament today still clinging to a narrow lead.

IT is a pleasure to read a well-written book about an American artist, a book that is alive in its portrayal of the artist and the period in which he worked and fought. Particularly when that artist was a stubborn fighter who believed that art was a fight along with life, and that the condition of art in his period called for rebellion.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 19 -- Mike Souchak stood off the pressure with a 7-under-par 64 for a fifty-four-hole total of 192 today. He increased his lead in the $12,500 Texas open golf tournament to two strokes over Freddie Haas.

IT is a pity that we Americans as a group, even most of the "eggheads" among us, are so little interested in philosophy. Aside from the intrinsic charms of philosophical speculation itself, a greater interest in philosophical questions would arm us better in the struggle for survival today in this era when the brilliant spell of Marxist philosophy chains the minds of so many in other lands, both free and unfree.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Four Purdue coeds representing the Lafayette Swim Club set an American record of 2 minutes 30 seconds for the 200-yard medley relay today in defeating the Women's City Club of Detroit, 44 -- 34.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- An Indian delegate to the United Nations said today that Asiatic countries should not align themselves with either the United States or Russia because "alignments make for danger to peace."
Seventy per cent of the prescriptions now filled at the corner drugstore use drugs unavailable fifteen years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Few careers offer less job security than politics. The Senator, the Representative, the Governor -- each holds his job at the pleasure of a whimsical electorate, and when the electorate says "nay" statesman and hack alike are out of work.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., Feb. 19 (AP) -- An airman testified today in the collaboration court-martial of Master Sgt. William H. Olson that the Army man was made squad leader in a prisoner-of-war camp after telling the Chinese Communists he was well read in Marx and Lenin.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Civil Service system has grown ver the years from the "bottom up." This week, the new Hoover commission reported it was time to do something about the "top."
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 19 -- Ways to strengthen the ties between Laos and Thailand will be explored here this week-end.

ALTHOUGH the race to produce a movie version of Tolstoy's classic "War and Peace" seemingly has more than one entry, it appeared last week that the Italian production team of Carlo Ponti and Dino De Laurentiis was leading the field by a few lengths.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand -- The Pacific offers the greatest scope for tourist development of any area in the world, in the opinion of delegates to the recent fourth annual conference of the Pacific Area Travel Association. Its potential is fabulous, they believe, and as yet it has hardly been touched. This is especially true for the South Pacific.
On the urging of Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Communist party, two major moves have been ordered to tighten control over and increase pressure on Soviet farms and farmers.

MANY beginning gardeners -- and even some misinformed old - timers -- hesitate to start annual plants indoors from seed in the belief that doing so requires expensive equipment, difficult if not impossible conditions and complicated procedures.
Though it contains much delicate and beautiful music, Ravel's short opera, "L'Enfant et les Sortileges," is difficult to present.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Red China's Olympic committee protested yesterday because Nationalist China athletes on Formosa also have been invited to the sixteenth Olympiad at Melbourne next year.

Increased industrial activity in South America accounts for the gains in north-south travel in the Western Hemisphere, according to Edward G. Bern, vice president of Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra).

THE non-gardening days of February are ideal for investigation of pruning. This phase of maintenance should not be considered on a catch-as-catch-can basis. Rather, the wise gardener will explore the principles involved before starting out with clippers to snip indiscriminately on the first mild February day.

On Wednesday of this week high-ranking representatives of eight nations will meet in Bangkok, Thailand, to discuss ways to make effective the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization. From halfway around the world the foreign ministers of the two great English-speaking nations are flying to meet there with the ministers from Pakistan, the Philippines, Thailand, France, Australia and New Zealand.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- In a report on trends, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said there is nothing to indicate business would not rise moderately this year. Favorable forecasts by business analysts along with favorable trends have generated a feeling of confidence.
I AM the chef on Parry Island of Eniwetok Atoll. It is far from being an enchanted South Sea Island for this one is devoid of vegetation, except for some bedraggled palm trees.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Spur On, stretch-running son of Whirlaway, today registered a three-length victory over Bobby Brocato in the $14,725 Lecompte Handicap at the Fair Grounds.
While the coffee drinker is enjoying the recent price declines of as much as 16 cents a pound, the trade is having a difficult time.
An agreement was reached yesterday afternoon on a three-year contract between the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, L. I., and the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L.
While statesmen debate the question of European unification, a group of scholars and students in Bruges, Belgium, are working for the day when that dream becomes a reality.
The bid by Texas civic interests for major toll turnpikes ranking with those of the central and northeastern states is at last reaching the financial stage.

TOM GALT'S dramatic version of the Greek story of creation offers more than incredible adventure and larger-than-life characters. It administers knowledge painlessly; the gods and goddesses referred to so often in literature come alive and develop into memorable figures.

A change in racing tactics paid off handsomely for Wes Santee last night. The Kansas cowboy stayed off the pace for once and, with a scorching last-lap sprint, took the national Amateur Athletic Union indoor mile title in 4:07.9. His time set a championship record.
IS the private hunting preserve unfair?
The American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers presented a number of medals and awards at its annual meeting last week in Chicago.

THE thriller, "Witness for the Prosecution," is top theatre, of course. But it is my opinion as a lawyer that the author and "judge" err grievously on a crucial legal point. In one scene, the most damning evidence against the defendant is supplied by his wife.

Wild birds have been linked conclusively to the spread of encephalitis by a group of researchers from the University of California (Berkeley and San Francisco campuses), the California Department of Fish and Game and the Public Health Service. Encephalitis is a frequently fatal infection of the brain.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Moscow's new proposal for the destruction of nuclear weapons has come when the major Western Allies are split over Formosa and French - German relations are suffering from the political crisis in France.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- The Tuxedo Gold Racquets tournaments opened today at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club before a capacity crowd. Both the racquets and court tennis tournaments have the holders of the outstanding world titles playing.

Huntington trounced the Suffolk Blues in the Sherman Memorial polo tournament match at the Squadron A Armory last night. Paced by Joe Rizzo, who scored eight goals, the Huntington trio rode off with a 16-to-2 triumph.
Ten persons were injured last night when a bus collided with a doctor's car and hurled it onto the sidewalk at the corner of Eighth Avenue and Twentieth Street.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 19 (AP) -- West Germany's booming automobile industry expects to roll out more than 800,000 new vehicles in 1955 in its biggest production year since World War II.

ONE of the world's most closely (and brutally) guarded secrets today -- indeed, what is really the most massive mystery in the modern history of mankind -- is the story of slave labor in Russia. Once in a great silent while some of the terrible truth gets out.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- During the past ten days, Soviet workers have been meeting under Communist party auspices from one end of the land to the other, to put their stamp of approval on the recent changes in the Government and its policies. By this time they cannot fail to understand what their endorsement involves.

Mervyn Shorr and Herb Jacobsohn led City College's basketball team to a 68-43 triumph over Rider College last night in the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium. The victory raised City to the .500 mark again with a 7-7 record. Rider suffered its fourteenth loss in twenty-two encounters.
MUSICAL detectives will have a field day with The Heart of the Opera, seven disks of operatic excerpts brought out by R. C. A. Victor on its Camden label.

Four free lectures are scheduled this week at the New York Public Library to acquaint adults with the "Lifelong Education" classes presented jointly by the library and City College. Registration is now open.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Tentative labor unity is about to meet its first test. It comes in the international field.

The bitter 1952 campaign ended with many Democrats and Republicans, and especially the principals, agreed on one thing: It was high time to shorten the Presidential campaign -- for reasons of cost, which had become astronomical with TV, and the limits of endurance of both candidates and voters.

CORRESPONDENTS appear to have become increasingly interested in the discussions in this column of certain phases of the musical direction of the City Center. Among the letters received are some that can and some that can not be published. Here are paragraphs from one letter that takes issue with our estimate of the work of Dr. Joseph 1Rosen-I stock, the director of the operaI company:

THE drama phase of "Salute to France," which the American National Theatre and Academy is organizing for presentation in Paris this spring and summer, appears to be moving in the direction of a "dream program."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 19 -- Navy evened its season's record at 9 -- 9 by defeating the Georgetown University quintet today, 77 -- 54.
Evidence in the wreckage of an Italian Airlines plane that crashed short of an Idlewild, Queens, runway Dec. 18 indicates the landing gear was in the up position.

CHORE OF THE WEEK: Between Washington's Birthday and St. Patrick's Day is an advantageous time to feed trees. Special commercial fertilizers may be scattered over the lawn from trunk to outermost branches to be carried to the roots by rain and melting snow. Better yet is boring holes and dividing the proper amount of fertilizer among them.

THE pronouncements of Walter Lippmann on our foreign policy and foreign relations have achieved an eminence in the public mind of quite exceptional quality. In "Essays in the Public Philosophy" Mr. Lippmann views with alarm the course of recent history, during which liberal democracy has been embattled with two forms of totalitarianism.

On the fifth anniversary of the Chinese-Soviet alliance last week, both Moscow and Peiping took pains to reaffirm their "unshakeable unity." Last week, too, John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, suggested the potential of this alliance by noting that the two nations' "combined power can dominate the Eurasian continent."
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- Union leaders here took a cautious stand this week in discussing the possible scope of the proposed labor merger.

THERE has been great activity out in Farmingdale, L. I., for the past few weeks. For there, more than 1,200 students and faculty of the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute have been making preparations for the thirty-sixth annual Country Life-Open House Program, which begins Thursday and will continue through Saturday.

After the defeat in the Assembly of the third candidate upon whom he had called to form a French Cabinet, President Rene Coty has summoned party leaders into consultation to place the issues squarely before them. It is earnestly to be hoped that Presidential leadership can finally win out where Parliamentary procedures have been seriously bogged down.

THAT so arcane a work as Bach's Art of the Fugue should be represented by no less than five LP versions is an indication both of the extent of the recorded repertory and the capacity of the American public to absorb it. This Bach work is a difficult nut to crack.

The average beginning salary of school teachers with a college degree is $3,115 in cities with populations of 100,000 or over, according to a survey just published by the Tax Foundation, a private research organization. The average maximum for a teacher with a Ph. D. degree is $5,805.
Applications for season playing and locker permits for golf and tennis will be accepted, starting Feb. 28, at the five borough offices of the Park Department.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -- A second-half scoring spree by Hal Haabestad helped the Princeton basketball team defeat Yale tonight, 62 -- 48, before a crowd of 1,000. It was the Elis' sixth consecutive defeat.

BUFFALO, Feb. 19 (UP) -- St. Francis of Brooklyn took charge late in the first half and skillfully carved out a 71 -- 64 basketball victory over St. Bonaventure tonight at Buffalo's Memorial Auditorium.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Feb. 19 -- Part of this resort city's famed boardwalk as well as two floor levels of the Convention Hall went nautical today as the nine-day Jersey Coast Boat Show opened.

Dr. Ralph Banay's article, "Should We Abolish Prisons" (Jan. 30) was excellent. The fact that Boston, the hub of the nation and the intellectual center of the United States, still houses inmates in a prison built in 1805 must fill our admirers around the world with respect for our concern about the rights of man.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 15 -- Puerto Rico's industrialization program is being re-evaluated to adjust it to changing conditions.
A 35 - YEAR - OLD dealer in books and stationery has come into national prominence here on a simple but sure-fire program. His name is Pierre Poujade and he doesn't like taxes.
The annual demonstration of goodwill among faiths will begin today and continue through next Sunday. This is Brotherhood Week.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 19 -- Military specialists are challenging the West German Government's defense plans as inadequate and impractical. These experts nevertheless support the Paris agreements to arm this country.

On Friday the instruments of ratification of the Southeast Asia defense treaty were formally deposited in Manila. The Manila Pact is now officially in force. This is a proper prelude to the eight-nation meeting that opens in Bangkok day after tomorrow.
