Inspired by a celebrated Revolutionary War incident that took place in New York's Murray Hill section, where he was reared, Robert E. Sherwood has written a comedy, entitled "Small War on Murray Hill." The recipient of four Pulitzer Prizes said yesterday that the Playwrights Company, of which he is a charter member, would present the attraction here in November.
Arnie Sowell was named yesterday as the winner of the Col. Charles J. Dieges Trophy as the outstanding performer of last Saturday night's Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships.

Axel Forslund, athletic director and ski coach at Mount Hermon (Mass.) School, was sitting in his office early last week bemoaning his luck. The wrestling coach, Vincent Alexander Douglas Argyle Campbell, was listening.
The three-day hunt for August Robles, squint-eyed killer, ended violently about 5 P. M. yesterday. He was shot dead in an East Harlem flat after a twohour siege by several hundred policemen.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 21 (UP) --Two Japanese coastal ships carrying 335 persons, which had been missing in a storm, were reported safe today. Both ships were in Ryukyu waters, near Okinawa.
ALONG and well-arranged program of piano music was played earlier in the afternoon in Town Hall by Charles Milgrim.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial "Middle East Setbacks" as well as continuing accounts in your news columns of the Zionist leaders expressing indignation at the execution in Egypt of two spies, persistently being identified by their religion, call for clarification.

THE LaSalle String Quartet, a group in residence at the Cincinnati College of Music, made its New York debut on yesterday's late afternoon Town Hall program, presented under the auspices of the Concert Society.

A five-story loft building on plot 78 by 100 feet at 107-13 Franklin Street has been sold by the Halden Realty Corporation, Herman Laden, president, to Dalamal Sons, exporters, in a deal negotiated by Harry G. Silverstein, broker.
Fear that state "right to work" laws might be used to block labor's basic organizing rights was expressed yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union.
A thirty-three-man track and and field squad was named yesterday to represent the United States in the Pan-American Games At Mexico City on March 12-26.

Gian-Carlo Menotti, composer and librettist, declared yesterday that art and music could be used to foster international brotherhood. Unfortunately, he added, art is often "used as a means of self-aggrandizement."

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Neither the City generally nor the stock markets in particular can be said to have been encouraged by the decision last week to refrain from making any further change in bank rate. On the contrary, there was a feeling akin to disappointment and even of disapproval that the rate was not further advanced 0.5 per cent to 4 per cent.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP)--Sigge Ericsson, a steel-nerved athlete from Ostersund, Sweden, today won the world speed skating championship in a dramatic wind-up to the four-event competition. He defeated two of Russia's top skaters before 60,000.
The world's largest communications enterprise had a net income of $549,931,223 in 1954.
UNITED NATIONS. N. T., Feb. 20--After three years of cautious operation, a United Nations Technical Assistance project covering 6,600,000 Indians of the Andean high plateaus is picking up momentum.

Taxes collected by the state from the pari-mutuel pools in 1954 set a record, at $57,025,000. This is a golden egg of such consequence to the revenue system that the state has a distinct self-interest in examining sympathetically any proposal having to do with the tracks' material health.

LONDON, Feb. 20--Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade in the former Labor Government, suggested today that Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek and his chief lieutenants be "safely stowed away" on St. Helena. He asked that the United States Seventh Fleet be sent there to guard them.
Sprain Construction, Inc., Robert Beckley, vice president, has purchased a plot 135 by 100 feet at 209-21 East Fifty-third Street for improvement with a twelve-story and penthouse apartment building.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the issue of Feb. 9 The New York Times published a report of its special correspondent under the heading "Argentina Denies Political Jailing." This report quotes Mr. Benitez, chairman of the Chamber of Deputies, as saying "Thera is nobody in jail in the Argentina Republic for his religious ideas, nor are there political prisoners."

Prominent women here have formed a committee whose aim is to create more interest in the forthcoming convocation of the United Negro College Fund. It will be held March 20 in the Metropolitan Opera House.
LONDON, Feb. 20--The Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom expressed its anxiety today over what it termed the steady increase in flag discrimination.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 20--Finance Minister Johan van de Kieft last week again strongly rejected the idea of guilder revaluation.

Julia Correa has never walked in her twelve years of life. She never will. But for a few hours yesterday afternoon she experienced the sensation of dancing, like a feather in a spring wind, on the stage of the City Center of Music and Drama.
The Dixon-Yates power proposal was attacked from a new angle yesterday--that of possible "hidden earnings."
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20 (AP)-- A key union resolved its dispute today, clearing the way for a possible end to Pittsburgh's fifteen -month department store strike.

Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" will return to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera after a year's absence Thursday evening, March 3. Set Svanholm and Astrid Varnay will sing the title roles, with Blanche Thebom as Brangaene and Josef Metternich as Kurvenal Rudolf Kempe will conduct.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20--A ten-year $44,000,000 modernization, and improvement program for the Port of New Orleans is in its initial stages.
The disposition of the American tramp fleet has become as mysterious as the top-secret plans of the Navy in time of emergency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) --President Eisenhower's program for ridding the Government of security risks came under attack on three fronts today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--John Foster Dulles said today that the services performed by the Red Cross were manifold and essential--in war or in peace.
An array of domestic and foreign automobiles was presented yesterday at the opening of the Universal Travel and Auto Sports Show in Madison Square Garden.

THE orchestral programs of WNYC's American Music Festival have been stronger than usual this year. One reason has been the participation of the Symphony of the Air, formerly the pride of the National Broadcasting Company.

A television program designed to encourage young people toward careers as scientists and engineers is under preparation. It would be presented by the American Broadcasting Company in cooperation with Johns Hopkins University.

There is an almost shocking touch of optimism in "The Black Market Yearbook"* this year. Franz Pick, its author, admits that the world's currency tangles are less spaghetti-like and permits himself the hope that a fifth edition of his annual will not be necessary.
BERLIN, Feb. 20--Communist youths are to be made responsible in the East German republic for seeing that their elders behave themselves in trade and commerce.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government is a twelve-member body headed by former President Hoover.

Scoring twice in each half, the Wacker Sport Club of Vienna turned back an All-Star eleven selected from the Amercan Soccer League and the German American League, 4 to 1, at Zerega Oval, the Bronx, yesterday.
A preview of this country's cultural "Salute to France" was staged at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening before 600 dinner guests.
The Robles gun battle with the police yesterday turned back the city's calendar of crime twenty-four years to Francis (Two-Gun) Crowley.

The attainment of his greatest ambition reduced Mal Whitfield to tears yesterday. On receiving the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy as this country's outstanding amateur athlete of 1954, the great middle-distance runner broke down and cried.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20--There was no let-up last week in the heavy flow of orders to steel mills; nor was there any indication that the upward movement had become spent.

Fewer Latin-American countries are paying their bills promptly on imports from the United States, compared with six months or a year ago. This is indicated in the fifty-third semi-annual survey conducted by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau.

Superlatives are the normal language to use in speaking of New York International Airport with its 5,070 acres, equivalent to all of Manhattan Island south of Fortyninth Street to the Battery. The Port of New York Authority's new $60,000,000 terminal plans, announced this morning, are appropriate to the magnitude of the field as well as to the astounding present and the even more challenging future of commercial aviation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) --James P. Mitchell, Labor Secretary, said today that states were making the biggest bid in twenty years to improve unemployment compensation benefits.
Warren B. Shannon, the third man in the East Side wiretapping case, was continued in $1,000 bail yesterday for a hearing March 7 on charges of malicious mischief.

Current revelations in this city of what appears to have been wiretapping on a wholesale scale for private gain must disturb any thinking citizen. Such wiretapping is not only illegal under Section 605 of the Federal Communications Act of 1934, but it violates every citizen's basic right of privacy.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 20 -- Hard fought contents marked the semi-final round of the Tuxedo Gold Racquets tournament today at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club. Geoffrey Atkins of Chicago and Clarence C. Pell Jr. of New York advanced.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)-- Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, announced tonight that twenty financial and industrial experts, both in and out of government, would testify in the Senate investigation of the stock market.
The events leading to the killing yesterday of August Robles by New York policemen began last summer in Baltimore.

FRANKLIN STETSON CLARK left Community Church in East Thirty-fifth Street between Park and Madison Avenues the other day. He worked westward with his special cane, a slender bamboo one with a tungsten, carbide tip.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 20--Vice President Richard M. Nixon's visit to Nicaragua is proving a stimulant for opposition movements.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Feb. 20 -- The hundreds of initials scratched on the marble top of a circular radiator in the waiting room of the New York Central Railroad station here will be preserved.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The Administration found little to cheer about today as it surveyed its foreign policy after twentyfive months in office.
Although Helen of Troy managed very well without haute couture in her day, Greece is now in great need of it.

Weakness in the British pound and Canadian dollar, which were carried off to new lows on the movement, beset the foreign exchange market last week. Netherlands guilder also suffered a sharp setback. Other Continentals remained firm.
Do-it-yourself may be the trend in home decorating, but in the kitchen today's cook seems to feel some one else should do the work for her.

Why "Dangerous" Forty? There comes a time when one cares not who first called forty the dangerous age; one wonders not who, but why. Why do some people say, with a wink, that so-and-so needs an eye kept on him--because he is getting into his forties, now.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The Hoover commission's recommendations on paper work in Government were based on a report by a task force headed by Emmett J. Leahy of Darien; Conn.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 20 (UP)--Art Tyler, Rochester, N. Y., bobsledder, smashed two records today to top a field of nine drivers in the four-man tryouts for berths on next year's United States Olympic bobsled team.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--The Hoover Commission called on President Eisenhower today to order cuts in Government red tape.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 20 (AP)--The Syracuse Nationals broke today's game wide open in the fourth period to sweep their week-end series against the New York Knickerbockers with a 104-84 victory. The contest attracted 7,089 fans, the season's largest National Basketball Association crowd in Syracuse.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 20-- Middlebury College continued its domination of Eastern intercollegiate skiing today as it added the Harvard-Bromley giant slalom to its list of laurels.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 20 (AP) --Chinese Nationalist planes sank a Communist gunboat and "a considerable number" of wooden craft today in the third straight day of air blows near invasion-threatened Nanki Island, the Defense Ministry said.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) --Val Peterson said today that use of the fearsome cobalt bomb might lead to the death of everybody in the world.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP)--Storms along Europe's coasts have sunk two ships and taken at least three lives. Gusts of wind up to 118 miles an hour swept across the French Riviera and lashed the Ligurian Sea of Italy yesterday and today.
The General Electric Company had net earnings last year of $212,613,000, highest in its history.

Modern American society, with its emphasis on industrialization and the glorification of youth, has swung so far from the veneration of age characteristic of ancient cultures that a crucial situation has developed.
ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Feb. 19--This Navy icebreaker "spliced the main brace" today. Her crewmen received a ration of beer on a nearby ice field.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (UP)--The Chicago Black Hawks scored three times in the last period tonight to whip the third-place Toronto Maple Leafs, 4--1, in a National Hockey League game before 9,812 in the Chicago Stadium.
Squalid Harlem tenements became fortresses of bullets, flame and tear gas yesterday as the police ended the stormy life of August Robles.
THE New York City Ballet in its week-end programs at the City Center had no new works to offer, but it had several new castings that were of interest.
August Robles' desperation to find a place to make what turned out to be his last stand drove him Friday evening to take over a four-room apartment occupied by two of his cousins-- at gunpoint.

The Detroit Red Wings exploded for three goals in the second period of their game against the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. That outburst was more than enough as the visitors registered a 5-to-0 conquest of the Broadway Blues.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona has told the Republican National Committee that the odds are "heavily stacked" against the party's efforts to regain control of the Senate in 1956.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Harry C. Carr, chairman of the board of the First National Bank of Philadelphia, shot and killed himself today in his home in suburban Rosemont.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 --Philip Carey will relive a personal wartime experience when he stars in "Battle Stations," to be produced by Bryan Foy for Columbia.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 20 (AP)-- Mike Souchak strode through mud and near-freezing temperatures to a record 257 today to win the $12,500 Texas open and post his first major victory along the tournament trail.

IF the various parts of Bach's B minor Mass are allowed to sound clearly, and if the tempi are right, the music will make its own way. Margaret Hillis, who led the work last night at Town Hall, knows this, and accordingly she concentrated on clarity and a steady beat.

Net income of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., for the nine months ended Dec. 31, the new fiscal year-end, amounted to $9,098,982 on consolidated net sales of $217,008,564. The net is equal to $2.85 a share on 2,887,233 common shares outstanding.
The upsets that traditionally plague top seeded contract bridge teams in the annual Vanderbilt Cup team-of-four national championship play were in evidence again yesterday.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20--On orders of the Communist party more corn will be planted in the Ukrainian Republic this year than in the whole of the Soviet Union in 1954.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20-- The Democrats are preparing to push ahead this week with their drive to outflank the Eisenhower Administration on its major legislative proposals.

ONCE upon a time the winning of turfdom's Triple Crown was, like virtue, its own reward. Except for the record books, there was no tangible proof that the diadem had been won. Not many years ago, however, the Thoroughbred Racing Associations decided that this comparatively rare feat rated a trophy and hence a handsome specimen of the silversmith's art was ordered.
An explanation of the new dock-hiring regulations that go into effect on March 1 has been mailed out to 30,000 registered longshoremen in the port.

Marriages in most parts of the United States can no longer be held together by outer pressures, a group of family-life specialists agreed last week-end. Instead marriages need a kind of "inner cement."
Many phrases innocent in themselves become tarnished by association with malpractice of one kind or another.

IN some amusing after-dinner asides at a recent meeting of the P. E. N. at Town Hall, Peggy Wood wryly observed that one of her problems in the television age was trying to remain Peggy Wood. In the public's mind she was so firmly established as the Norwegian matriarch in "Mamma," she said, that sometimes she felt as if she mislaid herself.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--A prominent member of the Republican National Committee explained at the White House last Thursday why he couldn't stay for lunch with President Eisenhower.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 20--Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. left New York today to take part in the disarmament talks in London beginning Friday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 20 --Three members of Pakistan's nine-man delegation to the Southeast Asian conference left tonight for Bangkok. They were Agha Shahi, Deputy Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Capt. S. Ahsan of the Navy, and Rashid Inrahim, Deputy Secretary of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Monday, Feb. 21--Turkey and Pakistan have completed secret negotiations with Iran, Lebanon and Syria for a grand defensive alliance. This disclosure was made early today by a high Pakistani Government official who has been guiding negotiations for more than six months among leaders of the Moslem states.
China's monetary revaluation appears to be important primarily for reasons of psychology and convenience rather than for any immediate economic effect.

An almost spring-like weekend brought Sunday drivers, small-boat enthusiasts and park strollers out of hibernation yesterday. Streams of motorists sped along New Jersey, Westchester County and Long Island highways toward shore resorts.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 20 --All three great commercial banks of Switzerland--the Swiss Bank Corporation, Credit Suisse and the Union Bank of Switzerland -- published their balance sheets and annual reports for 1954 last week.

Rudolf Bing made sure that he had a strong cast for his production of Richard Strauss' "Arabella" when he introduced it at the Metropolitan Feb. 10. Saturday night, when it received its second performance, one of the parts was changed and the new singer upheld the strength and balance of the ensemble.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 20 (AP)-- Fay Crocker, from South America, defeated the Chicago professional, Patty Berg, today in a down-to-the-wire battle for the championship of the $5,000 (Serbin) invitational golf tournament.

HEGGELIA, Norway, Feb. 17 --The only significant land force covering free Europe's northern flank has taken its stand around this command headquarters. Its location is 260 miles west of the Soviet frontier and 175 north of the Arctic Circle.
Last year New York City had 1,108 fewer fires than in 1953 Civilian fire fatalities also declined.
ALBANY, Feb. 20--The two top Republican legislative leaders announced tonight their endorsement of a Port of New York Authority plan to spend $300,000,000 to ease traffic congestion in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--George Washington's Mount Vernon estate down the Potomac River was far more than a country gentleman's estate in the first President's day. It was the site of some of the nation's initial experiments in scientific farming.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $64,330,818,349. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20--A bloodhound described by the judge as one of America's great dogs became best-in-show tonight in the thirty-third event of the Elm City Kennel Club.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 20 -- A Danish shipping company has been formed to carry passengers between Denmark and North America. Its name is the Denmark-America Lines, Inc.

Chief Justice Warren raised a startling question in a speech in St. Louis on Saturday. He said some thoughtful persons had begun to wonder "whether ratification of the Bill of Rights could be obtained today if we were faced squarely with the issue."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The United States Senate now has before it a proposed extension at the Selective Service Act which apparently still makes no provision whatsoever for World War II service in the United States merchant marine. To those of us who served for lengthy periods therein this seems to be a legislative inequity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission rejected today a request that it enforce state "fair trade" laws on price-cutting discount stores. The policy-making decision marked the first time the F. T. C. has officially taken a stand on statesanctioned pricing agreements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Secretary of State John Foster Dulles is taking a file on the "atoms-for-peace" plan to Bangkok for discussion with the Manila pact powers, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines said today.
The detective who fired the last shot into the bullet-riddled body of killer August Robles told last night the story of the siege as it appeared to those closest to it.
Leaflets were distributed outside many Harlem churches yesterday urging worshipers to support a drive for more jobs for Negroes in radio and television.
PARIS, Feb. 20--Edgar Faure is avoiding haste in forming a new Cabinet.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20--One of the greatest obligations a society owes its individual citizens is intellectual freedom, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, declared here tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20--Long liquidation was the outstanding feature in grain futures last week, first in wheat and then in corn.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, was sharply critical yesterday of the radio program "This I Believe."
State Controller Arthur Levitt declared yesterday that the number of school teachers in the state must be increased annually by 2,000 to 4,000 because of the rising birth rate.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 21-- The Peiping radio announced today that Communist China would issue new currency. One new yuan will be given for 10,000 old yuan.
Recognition of a Supreme Being is the most basic expression of Americanism, President Eisenhower declared last night.

WHETHER the novel is declining as a literary form, as some doleful critics have proclaimed, it is certainly true that certain serious and talented novelists have discouraged and depressed numerous readers. Their determination to write introspective, symbolical, static studies of frustration, neuroticism and despair is almost suicidal.

The importance of the virtue of hope that "stands firmly on the goodness of God" was stressed by the Rev. Charles J. McManus in a pre-Lenten sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

A multi-million dollar airport city will rise on the framework of New York International Airport in the next five years. As a first step, $60,000,000 will be spent to develop modern passenger terminal facilities on the 5,070-acre tract at Idlewild, Queens.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 20-- When the SEATO Foreign Ministers confer here this week one area they will almost certainly not discuss is Tibet. Yet it is from that quarter China ultimately hopes to outflank Southeast Asia if it is unable to gain this strategic area by direct assault.
The Brooklyn Eagle was accused yesterday of using a "strike-insurance nest egg" to prolong the twenty-three-day-old strike on the newspaper.
Professional baseball is an extensive -- and expensive -- operation. Not the least of its financial problems involves that annual jaunt known as "spring training."
Edward Moylan's winning streak came to an end yesterday in the national indoor tennis championships.
Tammany Hall and Secretary of State, said yesterday that a sample poll in Manhattan indicated Mayor-Wagner to be more popular today than when he was elected in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20--Following are excerpts from the report of the (Hoover) Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government on "paper work management" in the United States Government:...
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The United Nations Command formally charged today that the Communists had violated the Korean armistice by bringing MIG-15 jet fighters into North Korea.

BERLIN, Feb. 20--Dr. Gerhart von Westerman, manager of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, could say nothing today about the effect of a protest made in New York yesterday against the orchestra's scheduled appearance next month at Carnegie Hall.
Assemblyman John R. Brook, Manhattan Republican, announced yesterday that he was proposing an amendment to the State Constitution to give New York City autonomy in taxation.

Charles H. Silver received yesterday the ninth annual Brotherhood Award of the Men's Club of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun at 257 West Eighty-eighth Street. The president of the New York City Board of Education, industrialist, philanthropist and civic leader, was honored for "his notable services for the improvement of brotherhood, goodwill and understanding among the members of various faiths and races in the community."
James Archer's strong comeback in the 147-pound open bout highlighted the annual New York Golden Gloves program at Madison Square Garden last night.
A millinery manufacturer in Tarrytown, N. Y., notified his 120 workers yesterday that he would shut his three plants there April 15.
Spring bedrooms, as glimpsed on Lord Taylor's eighth floor, are bright and flowery.

Two hundred Sanitation Department veterans went back to school yesterday as the first step toward stiffer enforcement of the anti-litter laws starting in mid-March. They began a week of study at the department's training center, 155 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn, to be followed by two weeks of field exercises in taming "litterbugs."
PARIS, Feb. 21--French criticism of the political game played in the National Assembly is now as severe as any foreign criticism.

College basketball coaches soon will agitate for separate rules to govern their games, Howard Hobson, the Yale mentor, disclosed yesterday at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's Restaurant.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Spokesmen for organized labor opposed the Administration's school construction bill today.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 21-- President Rajendra Prasad told the Indian Parliament today that India backed Communist China's claims to Formosa and the offshore islands.
The Vanderbilt Cup team-of- four championship moves today into the four-team semi-final round with the three favored contract bridge teams still in the running.
The stocking's silhouette has been dictated by nature but hosiery designers have produced some new textures and colors for spring.
West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, one of the largest producers in that industry, announced plans yesterday for a $100,000,000 investment in new plant and equipment during the next five years.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--The Legislature was urged today to divert some prospective state pari-mutuel tax revenue into a building fund for harness racing tracks.
LONDON, Feb. 21--The solution of the armaments race must by one that all nations can trust, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., declared on his arrival here from New York today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21--Further long liquidation of grain futures, with indifferent demand, caused sharp declines on the Board of Trade today. The lack of buying activity coincided with the reports of rain in the Southwest, and liquidating longs found a thin market until late in the session, when there was evidence of short profit taking.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Justice Department took its first formal step today on the growing problem of "turnabout" Government witnesses.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday the city should have been consulted about any Republican plans for introducing state measures dealing with New York traffic.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- The United States began today a major effort to help Japan become self-sustaining by building up her export markets in the free world.

Several thousand I. R. T. subway riders were delayed yesterday morning by two separate tie-ups on the Times Square- Flushing line. The inconvenience also spread to the B. M. T. division because of the transfer of passengers at Queens Plaza.

"BAMBOO CROSS," presented by the Blackfriars Build as its second offering of the season, is a tribute to the work of the Maryknoll Sisters -- particularly those trapped in Red China. Within its small framework, the melodrama ran its modest course last evening on Fifty- seventh Street to the evident appreciation of the audience.

LONDON, Feb. 21--The high price of tea, the warmest domestic political issue in Britain, today brought new Parliamentary protests. One Laborite demanded that the Food Minister, Derek Heathcoat-Amory, resign if he could do nothing to bring down the price.

The Democratic majority of the House Ways and Means Committee approved yesterday a proposal to give a rebate of $20 to every income tax payer in 1955 and raise the allowance for each dependent by the same amount. This represents the application of politics to tax-making in as pure form, we think, as even the oldest inhabitant will recall.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 21-- Reports from the Chinese Nationalist Military Information Service indicated today that Communist forces were preparing to make the Matsu Islands an invasion target.
With peace and economic stability, the American Jewish community will move forward and develop, Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland said last night.
PARIS, Tuesday, Feb. 22-- Edgar Faure, held up by indecision among the political factions, postponed early today his decision on the formation of a new French Cabinet.

THE postman's ring is never more welcome than when he brings a letter from Ty Cobb, whose .367 lifetime batting average makes him the greatest hitter who ever lived. The Georgia Peach took pen in hand-- he wrote with his fist, too, and not with a typewriter--to put in a generous word for an old team-mate.
The Eastern Steamship Lines' passenger vessel Acadia, the last member of a once large group of widely known coastal liners flying that company's flag, has been sold.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Planning Commissioner Goodhue Livingston Jr. writes in The Times of Feb. 16 interestingly on a vital point in respect of New York's housing task. For the whole population --poor, middle-income and well-to-do--it has passed its laissezfaire stage.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--More than $10,000 in State Department funds were reported missing today.
The Institute of Navigation will hold its Eastern regional meeting at Friendship Airport, Baltimore, on Friday, April 29.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) --A Los Angeles Negro was adjudged today to have been subjected to unlawful discrimination when he was required to change bus seats in Texas in February, 1953.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES After motoring for six weeks through Sicily and Italy and up through the Boot to Naples, to Rome, to Florence, to Milan and Genoa, I send you what seems to me to be some interesting facts and observations:

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21-- Mayor Norris Poulson welcomed 2,700 delegates to the opening business session today of the thirty-seventh annual convention of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers here.
While most of the leading industrials drifted lower, railroad stocks advanced vigorously yesterday.

CORDOBA, Argentina, Feb. 19--In this most Roman Catholic and traditional of all Argentine cities there is a widespread conviction that the campaign of the Government against religious opponents of the regime is far from over.
A 15-year-old boy told the police yesterday he had accidentally shot and killed an 11-year-old boy with a zipgun they had found in a Bronx lot.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 21 --Arthur Tokle of Fox River Grove, Ill., today won the first Masters invitation ski jump under the sponsorship of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds.

A Brooklyn suspect named John Buongiovanni (Good John to his Italian friends but alias the Rabbit to the police in deference to his elusiveness) was wounded and captured yesterday after an hour-long chase by twenty-five policemen.

HONG KONG, Feb. 21--Three members of an Israeli mission declared today after a visit to Communist China that they had been impressed with what they had seen there. They said they had reached the conclusion that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek Chinese Nationalist leader, was "discredited" on the Chinese mainland.

The first of three games this week between the New York Knickerbockers and the Philadelphia Warriors will be played tonight at Madison Square Garden. The contest will ba supported by a meeting between the pacesetting Syracuse Nationals and the Boston Celtics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--President Eisenhower gave some Democrats as well as Republicans a preview of his road building message today. The Democrats were not favorably impressed. The message will go to Congress tomorrow.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 (AP)--The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecast for New Hampshire, Vermont and the Berkshires: Considerable cloudiness and continued mild tomorrow with thawing temperatures.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Air Force announced today selection of the Western Electric Company, Inc., to build the radar warning system across the Canadian Arctic.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21--The long strike at five downtown department stores was over for all practical purposes today but the larger unions were not ordering men back to work.
One of the most impressive gatherings of sports notables New York has seen turned out yesterday to honor Asa Bushnell.
An unusual legal situation related to the sinking of the freighter Mormackite is expected to be resolved soon.

BIRKENHEAD, England, Feb. 21--The Ark Royal, Britain's newest and largest aircraft carrier, will be commissioned tomorrow in this snow-swept port. With her sister ship Eagle, already operational, she will spearhead the post-war Royal Navy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to a recent news dispatch Representatives A. C. Powell and Frank C. Osmers Jr. have introduced bills in Congress to establish Government-financed scholarships in the field of engineering, physics, chemistry and related sciences.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A massive 1843 statue of a half- clad George Washington is about to emerge from the shadows.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday and closing prices were 3 points lower to 10 points higher than on last Friday.

An industry-wide program to stimulate the sale of automatic electric household dishwashers is in the planning stage. There will be national and local-level advertising, sales education and publicity efforts, under the guidance of a division of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

Shakespeare and Sean O'Casey compete for theatrical attention tonight in the off-Broadway districts. The former's "The Merchant of Venice" will be revived at the Jan Hus Auditorium, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street, at 8 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The first step to put a Democratic tax cut through the House of Representatives was taken today.

Alterations are planned for the five-story building at 343 East Eighty-sixth Street which Thomas Bornstein has purchased from the Dotro Realty Corporation. The building, on plot 25 by 100 feet in the block between First and Second Avenues, contains two stores, two offices and twelve apartments.
TRENTON, Feb. 21--Conflicting views on the merits of compulsory automobile insurance were voiced here today at a public hearing conducted by a legislative committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--Admiral Arthur W. Radford said today it would be "impossible" at present for the Chinese Communists to conduct a successful major invasion of Formosa.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Tuesday, Feb. 22--Official reports said Chinese Communist war vessels were heading toward Nationalist -held Nanki Island today. Nationalist planes were said to be rushing out to attack them.

By way of marking the publication of Van Wyck Brooks' life of John Sloan, the Kraushaar Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, is presenting a selection of drawings and graphic work by the American painter, who died in 1951.

Stanley de J. Osborne and Eugene F. Williams Jr. have been elected directors of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Coporation. Mr. Osborne is executive vice president in charge of the company's international operations. Mr. Williams is an officer of the St. Louis Union Trust Company.

The First Boston Corporation said yesterday that what Senator Lister Hill, Democrat of Alabama, had told the Senate last Friday about Arthur H. Wenzell's part in the Dixon- Yates private power contract had "long been known in Government, financial and utility circles."
DETROIT, Feb. 15--Northland, the giant shopping center here, has proved a fabulous success in its first year.
Tony Trabert and Hamilton Richardson, Davis Cup teammates, will meet today at 2 o'clock for the national indoor tennis championship.
MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- "How easy international relations would be if they depended only on sports," a member of the Moscow diplomatic corps remarked today.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (AP)--A selling wave hit the London Stock Exchange today, slicing millions of pounds off share values.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Congressional-judicial pay increase proposals ran into roadblocks in the Senate today.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, off Antarctica, Feb. 20--This United States Navy expedition concluded its work in Antarctica last night. Its final task was to survey what appears to be the most suitable base for projected operations it has found.

"Manon" was staged at the Metroplitan Opera last evening with Eugene Conley singing his first Des Grieux with the company, and with Eleanor Steber making her first appearance of the season in the title role. Mr. Conley was replacing Giuseppe Campora, originally scheduled for last night's performance.
TOKYO, Feb. 21 -- The Jap- anese police reported today a record number of election law violations in the campaigning for a new House of Represent- atives.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21 --The Navy listed five dead today following a series of explosions aboard the submarine Pomodon, berthed at the San Francisco Naval shipyard.
Record earnings and a peace- time sales peak were attained by the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., in the year ended Nov. 30.

BERLIN, Feb. 21--The Communist Government in East Germany sent a delegation of mothers to the West German Parliament in Bonn tonight to appeal for rejection of West German armament. The appeal terminates an immense propaganda campaign.
San Francisco led the United Press ratings yesterday for the third straight week. Minnesota's Big Ten leaders advance to the No. 4 spot from eighth last week.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 21--David Ben-Gurion, Israel's war-time leader, returned to the Government today after an absence of more than a year on a remote communal farm in the Negev wilderness.
The conference at Bangkok of the Southeast Asian Collective Defense Treaty nations, starting tomorrow, opens a new chapter in Asia.
GENEVA, Feb. 21--The United States has asked the Governments of Western Europe to prepare a program for joint American -West European economic aid to Communist-threatened countries of Asia.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--Republic can conferences to decide party policy on Governor Harriman's budget and rent control proposals have been scheduled for later this week.

A Vestgial Muscle Vice President and Mrs. Nixon were trapped in an elevator for fifteen minutes the other day in Mexico City. In an interview with reporters later Mr. Nixon said that he muat be a jinx for elevators since this was the third time he had been stuck in one.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 21 --"A Time Out of War," a two- reel movie that has figured in two international film contests and is an Academy Award contender, has been chosen by the Screen Producers Guild as the winner of its second annual In tercollegiate Medallion Film Award.
LONDON, Feb. 21--The agreement between Britain and the European Coal and Steel Community was approved by the House of Commons tonight. There was no vote and there was only one dissenting voice.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--Republican leaders proposed tonight an extensive legislative investigation of illegal wiretapping and the use of electronic eavesdropping devices.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 21 --The United States Merchant Marine Academy's basketball team ended its season with an 87-66 triumph over New York University in O'Hara Hall tonight.

MANILA, Feb. 21--Pausing here overnight en route to the Bangkok conference, Secretary Dulles made a point of thanking President Ramon Magsaysay for his recent statement in support of the United States position on Formosa.
WHEN is a salmon not a salmon? According to most fishermen who curb their impatience until the fresh-run fish make their appearance in the river, the answer is: "When it's a slink."
Investment funds mean different things to different people.

Naturally we think about George Washington on this anniversary. He is the Washington of the Monument, of the Cherry Tree, of Valley Forge, of Crossing the Delaware. He is the Washington of the Farewell Address. He may be the Washington of Braddock's Defeat, or of the Journey to New York.

Another effort to break the eight- year deadlock on disarmament is to be made this week when representatives of the five principal atomic Powers-the United States, Britain, France, Canada and Soviet Russia-- meet in London. They meet as a subcommittee of the United Nations Disarmament Commission, and they will talk behind closed doors in the fashion of "traditional diplomacy," as they did in May and June last year.

In recent years brokerage concerns have stirred up considerable new business by setting up exhibition booths at county fairs. The "pitch" has produced such good results, in fact, that Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Beane have now decided to duplicate the set-up for the benefit of city folk.
Mayor Wagner expressed the hope last night that the city would have a "real" civil rights committee in the near future to stamp out discrimination in housing.

Washington, Feb. 21 (UP) --The State Department came out today for admission of Alaska and Hawaii as states despite opposition by the top defense official and a dubious view by the Interior Department.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Administration twice prohibited the Federal Civil Defense Administration from disclosing the vast extent of hydrogen bomb fall-out.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The State Department said today that it would begin negotiations with Switzerland on means of compensating her for the United States tariff increase on Swiss watches.

Carmelo Costa, Brooklyn featherweight, administered a boxing lesson to Bobby Bell of Youngstown, Ohio, at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Making his first start this year, Costa recorded a unanimous decision over Bell.

It can hardly be accident that there should be a renewed threat upon Thailand's northeastern border at the precise time that the eight signatories of the Manila Pact are convening in Bangkok. This sort of pressure was to have been expected.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 21-- Four zoning commissioners meeting in the basement of Town Hall here tonight approved a new zoning map. It sets forth restrictions designed to preserve "Millionaires' Row" on the shore front at Greens Farms, two country clubs and broad areas of rolling back-country land at present held for the most part in generous estates.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 21 (AP)--The New York State Bridge Authority announced today it would issue $21,000,000 in new state bonds to complete the Kingston-Rhinecliff Bridge. The span is under construction between the two communities on opposite sides of the Hudson River.
Thousands of New York's aged already are mentally or physically ill and live in institutions. More than half of these ailing aged are supported at public expense.

MIAMI, Feb. 21--Belair Stud's Nashua, the horse that Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons calls "the best 3-year-old prospect I've ever had," made his first 1955 start at Hialeah today. He won a mile-and-a-sixteenth race on which there was no betting.

NORTH of the Arctic Circle and north of the northernmost point pf the Ural Mountains, only some fifty miles from the Arctic Ocean, lies Vorkuta. There the long polar winters are so terrible that Czar Nicholas I. decided that it was "too much to demand of any man that he should live there." But beneath the barren tundra of Vorkuta lie some of the richest coal mines of the Soviet Union.
Net income of Household Finance Corporation and consolidated subsidiaries last year rose to $16,861,796 from $15,766,006 in 1953, the company announced yesterday.

There are no official Armed Forces Day programs or service publications of any type for which advertising is solicited. A warning to this effect has just been issued by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc., which quotes the official manual issued on connection with Armed Forces Day, Saturday, May 21, as follows:
The penitential season of Lent will begin tomorrow for Christians the world over. It will continue for forty days, excluding Sundays, ending on Easter, April 10.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Tuesday, Feb. 22--Delegates to the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty conference gathered today in an atmosphere made tense by the Thai Premier's report that Communist "Free Thai" forces were massing close to Thailand's border.

The chinchilla fur trade, extinct at the turn of the century, has returned to a steady basis. The bigger operators among the 15,000 members of the National Chinchilla Breeders Association are sending a small but regular flow of the gray-blue pelts to fashionable furriers in New York under private contracts.

Combined assets of the companies in the Travelers Insurance Company group amounted to $2,828,435,000 at the end of 1954. This was a gain of $183,861,000 during the year, Francis W. Cole, chairman, and J. Doyle DeWitt, president, reported yesterday to stockholders.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 (UP)-- Detroit moved into a first place tie with Montreal in the National Hockey League tonight as a result of a 2-2 draw with the Boston Bruins. The Red Wings tied the score on Marcel Pronovost's solo dash late in the second period.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 21 (AP)--Classical records from the West are sweeping Communist Hungary. Radio broadcasts from Western Europe long have been popular, but the exciting new boon to music-lovers is the long- playing disk.
Field salad is in the market. A delegate from this department who spotted it at a greengrocer's earlier this week brought back the report that will be good news to gourmets.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--The Senate Finance Committee deferred action again today on the confirmation of Dr. Isador Lubin as State Industrial Commissioner.
The law ran into some snags yesterday in closing the book on August Robles.
New York State has extended its campaign against racial and religious discrimination to cover agencies distributing literature here for resorts outside the state.

The color of Spain has been recorded vividly by Dorothy Draper, designer, in a new collection of home furnishings expected at W. J. Sloane in mid- March. Tables, chests, chairs, fabrics and wallpaper were all conceived during a tour of that country last summer.
A forgetful bus driver gave several thousand school children an unscheduled holiday yesterday.
Mayor Wagner and State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits oppose an increase in the retail price of milk.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 21-- Refugees from Communist rule who fled to Turkey will shortly begin moving in numbers to the United States, Australia and elsewhere, it was reported today. Officials estimate there are 1,000 to 1,200 East European refugees in this country.

CHAROVIT, Israel, Feb. 15-- This month-old cluster of cabins is the beginning of a farm region in which 12,000 families are to find homes and work. It is situated on an almost vacant section midway between Jerusalem and Ascalon.

The steel industry's operating rate was expected to edge higher again this week. The 89.2 per cent of theoretical capacity, which was anticipated, would reflect a growing demand for a broader range of products and a seasonal increase in sales of construction items.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 21--Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived in Costa Rica today. He bore assurances from Gen. Anastasio Somoza, President of Nicaragua, that so far as the latter was concerned there would be no further tensions and disturbances along the Nicaraguan-Costa Rican boundaries.
The price spread, particularly at the wholesale level, between various brands of frozen concentrated orange juice was reduced again by two more price increases yesterday.

TAPPAN, N. Y., Feb. 21-- New York Central executives are unwilling or unable to answer questions pertinent to the proposed abandonment of passenger service on the railroad's West Shore Division, it was charged here today.

The idea of seven Pentagons stuffed to the attic with letters, documents, files and other assorted varieties of Government paper is an appalling one; but we have the Hoover Commission's word for it that there are enough federal records on hand to fill all those Pentagons if anyone wanted to take the trouble to do it.

YONKERS, Feb. 21 -- Employes of the Otis Elevator Company here voted today, almost 3 to 1, to accept the management's production cost- cutting proposals rather than see the company leave town after 101 years.

THOMAS SCHERMAN makes it a practice of giving solo opportunities to members of his Little Orchestra Society, and last night in Town Hall, at the season's seventh concert, the soloists were Jan Tomasow, the concertmaster, and Eileen Flissler, the society's pianist.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP)--A very sharp cut in shipments of hogs to market enabled prices to climb from their 4 1/2-year lows on the livestock market here today. Salable receipts were only 5,000 head, less than half of what has been received on every other Monday this year. Butchers sold steady to mostly 25 cents higher, while sows held steady to strong.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 21--The Yale University Department of Drama will be established as the Yale School of Drama. It will become the university's tenth graduate or professional school on July 1, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president, said today.

The near-by potato contracts fell to new seasonal lows yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices closed 19 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower to 2 points higher on 2,169 car lots. The volume was the heaviest since trading opened in 1941.
The tenth annual observance in honor of George Washington, the Mason, was held yesterday on the steps of Federal Hall at Nassau and Wall Streets.
New high marks in output and consumption of wood pulp are expected by the nation's pulp manufacturers.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--The Jockey Club's plan for a new super- track in New York. City cleared its first hurdle today.

The one-story building at 238240 Freeman Street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn has been leased by Parsons Express, Inc., from the 144 Greenpoint Avenue Corporation through the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.

Earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., for 1954 were equal to $7.33 a common share, it was announced yesterday. This represents an increase of 48.4 per cent above share earnings of $4.94 a share in 1953.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- Harvey Matusow loudly insisted to the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee today that he once had been "a perpetual and habitual liar."

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board disclosed yesterday that it had asked for review of an unfair labor practices case that was dismissed in Washington Feb. 10 by one of the board's trial examiners.
Operations of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company last year resulted in a consolidated net income of $48,055,196, according to P. W. Litchfield, chairman.
ALBANY, Feb. 21--A sweeping program to overhaul the system of dealing with youths who break the law was introduced in the Legislature today.
TOKYO, Feb. 21--The navy that destroyed Japan's once formidable sea power ten years ago was helping today to train a new sea force.

A new and complete edition of Sir Leonard Wooley's "Ur of the Chaldees" is planned for March 1 publication by Crowell. Newly titled "Excavations at Ur: A Record of Twelve Years' Work," the volume will contain more than twice the material of the earlier work.
The Rev. Dr. Phillips P. Elliott of the first Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, was elected president of the Protestant Council of the City of New York last night.
John B. Russell of the Seabright Lawn and Tennis Club and H. Thomas Chester Jr. of the Greenwich Country Club won the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's doubles championship yesterday.

THE GOVERNOR Presided at the swearing-in of Edward T. Dickinson of Syracuse as State Commerce Commissioner. Visitors included Controller Arthur Levitt, Paul Herzog, Tadecisz Bielecki, Senator Walter J. Mahoney, Assemblyman Eugene F. Bannigan, State Parks Director James F. Evans, Assemblyman Bertram Baker and Miss Patricia Brown, Byron W. Vagg and State Budget Director Paul H. Appleby.

While the pace of other legislation continues slow at Albany it is encouraging to learn that the Republican leaders of the Legislature are ready to clear major projects of the great bridge-building program for the New York City area announced here on Jan. 17.
The American Committee for Cultural Freedom yesterday sharply protested a move by several hundred musicians to prevent appearances of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra in Carnegie Hall.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- More than 50,000 lawyers knocked at the door of the Federal Social Security System today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) --The Federal Trade Commission has dismissed charges of price discrimination brought nine years ago against the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, and two subsidiaries.
ALBANY, Feb. 22--A State Supreme Court justice asserted today that the Temporary Commission on the Courts was aiming at a system of appointive, rather than elective, judges.

St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn led the way into the semi-final round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball championships at Madison Square Garden before 4,000 spectators yesterday.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, Feb. 23--The first council meeting of the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty opened today.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Feb. 22--President Eisenhower hailed Pennsylvania State University on its 100th anniversary today as "one of the great universities of our country."

" YOU'RE going to try out for the Olympic team, of course," the fellow said. "No," answered Ralph Craig with a shake of his head. "I'm engaged to be married, I have a new job and I just haven't the time to train."

One of the greatest shortcuts for the modern home cook is the frozen spinach--leaf or chopped -- that requires only cooking before it is ready to serve. No longer does the housewife have to spend long periods washing off the sand.

President Elsenhower's message to Congress yesterday set forth the problem of our highways clearly, briefly and logically. The facts are irresistible. The reasons for extending, and modernizing our road system are compelling.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 22 (AP)--J. C. Bradford, head of a Nashville investment banking house, said today his concern had joined Blyth Co. of New York in forming a huge syndicate to bid on Tennesse Valley Authority bonds if any should be offered.

Secretary of the Treasury Humphrey spent two hours before the House Ways and Means Committee on Monday in a futile effort to dissuade the Democratic majority in that body from adopting its suddenly improvised scheme for a general $20 rebate to individual income tax payers for themselves and each of their dependents.
LONDON, Feb. 22--The British Navy has started designing guided-missile ships to replace its "aging" cruisers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--Republican leaders predicted today that President Eisenhower would throw all his influence against the Democratic plan to cut income taxes, starting Jan. 1. The predictions were made after a White House conference.
With Joe Schwartz stroki ten goals from his No. 2 position, Manhattan turned back Commonwealth trio, 13 to 6, the annual Sherman Memorial handicap polo tournament yesterday at the Squadron A. mory.

The one-story taxpayer containing three stores at 65-02 Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside, Queens, has been resold by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, to an investing client of the Advance Realty Company, broker in the transaction.

Van Norman Company, machinetool maker, and its subsidiary, Morse Twist Drill and Machine Company, reported consolidated net profits for 1954 of $323,898 (including a credit adjustment of $179,894), or 87 cents a common share.
ALBANY, Feb. 22--The stage was set today for a major legislative battle on whether trucks should pay more or less taxes for the use of highways.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22-- Indian Communists indicated today they thought they might be losing the elections in Andhra.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--The Administration proposed today that Congress authorize immediately a special commission on civilian defense.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)-- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's highway message to Congress today:
LONDON, Feb. 22--A sharply accelerating demand for steel in the next four years was predicted by the Iron and Steel Board, top planning body for the industry, in a report to Parliament today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Police Athletic League, our city's most valuable agency for counteracting juvenile delinquency, will be forced to make drastic curtailment in its activities unless adequate funds are immediately made available.

CORDOBA, Argentina, Feb. 20 --Argentina now has a Christian Democratic movement that apparently is here to stay. It is not revolutionary and it does not threaten the regime of President Juan D. Peron so long as he is alive and in command.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP)--Marjorie Campbell, 17-year-old high school senior of Red Hook, N. Y., today won the 1955 national cherry pie baking contest.
THE lovely Ladies' Parlor in the old Fifth Avenue Bank at Forty-fourth Street will be saved more or less intact, probably even including its floorboards, when the bank moves downstreet on Friday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 --Princeton, saved by George Hackl's second goal, tied Yale, 2--2, in hockey tonight. Hackl took passes from John Butsch and Kim Townsend to score his second marker with twenty-six seconds left of regulation time.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (Reuters) --Marshal Zhukov accused the United States tonight of "carrying on an active preparation for war." He said the Soviet armed forces "are ready at any moment to carry out the order of their Government."
BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 22-- One of the oldest existing universities and one of the younger ones entered into an alliance today. As a result, the culture of the Western world is expected to profit.
A Left Wing fur union officially became part of the American Federation of Labor yesterday, despite objections by the federation's high command.
Martin Yamin, former Baltimore magistrate who allegedly joined the underworld, balked yesterday at further questioning in the murder of Joseph Aronowitz.

Some 4,500 visitors passed through the United Nations buildings in this city yesterday. These visitors spend about an hour and as much as a dollar for this guided tour. The girls who take them, around and tell them about the work of the U. N. may be working for the United Nations itself in another month or so, instead of the non-profit-seeking American Association for the United Nations that now sponsors them.

Leaders of 12,000 unionized millinery workers, who had been demanding a larger employerfinanced pension fund, decided yesterday to take the money in the form of a $1,000,000 fund to promote sales of women's hats.
HONG KONG, Feb. 22--Communist China's Defense Minister declared today that his Government could not be frightened into giving up its struggle for Formosa.
The writer of the following letter is the former editor of The Hankow Herald.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 22-- Navy's basketball team defeated Dickinson, 74--42, today.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (UP) --George Gardiner's St. Vincent raced to a three-and-a-halflength victory today in the $29,400 Washington's Birthday Handicap to set a new American record.
The port's dock workers will ask the Federal Court in New York to stop enforcement of the new hiring regulations of the Waterfront Commission.

YESTERDAY (Feb. 22, 1955) THE GOVERNOR Signed bill permitting harness racing season to open April 1 instead of April 15. Redesignated Frank C. Moore of Buffalo and Mrs. Emily Smith Warner of New York as Chairman and Vice Chairman of State University Board of Trustees.

Senator William F. Knowland declared here last night that the United States must not trust its future and safety to the "collective ability of the United Nations to function in the event of aggression."

Although the teen ager struggles in school to learn the use of the Latin subjunctive or the gender of French nouns, he was born a natural linguist. In babyhood, he learned to speak his native tongue and, had he lived in an environment where more than one language was spoken, he could have picked up easily at that age one or more of 234 foreign tongues as well.

ALTHOUGH they recognize the impossibility of putting a stop to hunting or shooting by legislation, a number of state legislators each year sponsor measures that apparently would bring no civic benefits.

Jewelry stores don't usually sell dishes, and stores selling dishes keep them quite apart from the jewelry department. The Boonton Molding Company of Boonton, N. J., wants to add jewelry stores to its outlets for its Melmac dinnerware because, as William Stopford, sales manager, noted, "successful test campaigns have proved that Boontonware has an unusual sales potential in jewelry stores."
EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 22--The Township Committee here voted tonight to abolish this community's full-time police force. Economy was the assigned reason.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 22 --Egypt was reported today to have agreed to reconsider her opposition to the pending TurkishIraqi pact.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce said today that business activity continued to climb in January.
In the face of a new attack by the Citizens Budget Commission, the city prepared yesterday to go ahead with plans to build a new $140,000,000 reservoir at Cannonsville, N. Y.

BERLIN, Feb. 22--Dr. Otto Suhr, Mayor of Berlin, disclosed today that a matter that would have fascinated Harry the Horse and other characters of Damon Runyon's Broadway world has become an issue of high political significance.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22--Lawyers who invoke the Fifth Amendment are unworthy members of the bar, American Bar Association leaders were told today.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 22 --The Colombian Government published drastic new import restrictions today in an effort to offset the loss of foreign exchange through the drop in world coffee prices.
Sixty - nine cadet - midshipmen will be graduated on Friday from the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I.

THE concert given last night in Carnegie Hall by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, was the occasion of the first performance anywhere of Howard Hanson's "Sinfonia Sacra," or fifth symphony.
If women would select bright neckties for older men and more conservative patterns for younger men, there would be fewer neckwear mistakes crowding American closets.

Just when 15,345 fans were beginning to wonder what constituted a safe lead in a basketball game, time ran out and the New York Knickerbockers defeated the Philadelphia Warriors, 103--102, last night at Madison Square Garden.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22--The expected future increase in college enrollments will not bring a corresponding expansion of Yale University, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale, declared today. Educators are predicting a 70 per cent rise in student rolls by 1970. However, Yale may expand 10 or 12 per cent, but probably no more than that, Dr. Griswold said.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 23--Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Soviet Defense Minister, called on the armed forces today to stand ready for the defense of the country.
OTTAWA, Feb. 22--Louis St. Laurent, Prime Minister of Canada, denied in the House of Commons today that his Liberal Government was anti-monarchic.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 22 (UP)--Although Maureen Connolly announced her retirement from tennis tonight in a copyrighted story in The San Diego Union, she qualified the announcement slightly.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 22-- Princeton's basketball team kept alive its hopes for the Ivy League title tonight with a 92-54 triumph over Yale.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 22 --The probable prototype for an atomic missile warhead exploded today with a force that jarred cities 135 miles away. The predawn flash of the small nuclear device was seen 400 miles away.
HAMBURG, Feb. 22 (AP)--The world's biggest oil tanker is eight months old but has never carried a cargo and is costing her owner a fortune tied up idle it dock.

Three items of news these past few days give additional insight into the Soviet agricultural problem, the nominal cause of Premier Malenkov's "resignation," and the consequences of this problem. Last week Moscow suffered a severe meat shortage, with most meats almost unobtainable in state stores.
MIAMI, Feb. 22--Last month Lyle Dilger, a horse trainer, claimed the 4-year-old filly Rare Music for $8,000. He claimed her in partnership with W. D. Parr, an optometrist in Hot Springs, Ark.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 22-- Professors and intellectuals in general have been getting low grades from the American public instead of the A's they deserve, it was charged here today.
Tony Trabert of Cincinnati added a new crown to his collection of tennis diadems yesterday.

This summer, a music student will study at the Fontainebleau School of Music in France as a result of the concert and art exhibition to be held on Saturday under the auspices of the Fontainebleau Alumni Association. The dual event will take place between 3 and 6 P. M. at the association's headquarters, 122 East Fifty-eighth Street.

ROME, Feb. 22--Pope Pius XII attended forty-five-minute meeting of the Roman Catholic Church's Sacred Congregation of Rites today. The session approved steps toward beatification of fifty-six martyred victims of the Chinese Boxer Rebellion and of two nuns.

ALBANY, Feb. 22--The Legislature ordered today an investigation of illegal wiretapping and electronic eavesdropping --and marked it "rush." Both, the Senate and the Assembly voted unanimously to create a six-member joint legislative committee to conduct the inquiry.
MADRID, Feb. 22--The citizens fined for having participated in a recent pro-Monarchist demonstration have lodged a strong protest with the authorities.

Bill Thieben of the winners set an individual scoring mark for the losers' gymnasium with 36 points as Hofstra College upset Manhattan College, 81 to 74, in an overtime game on the Jaspers' court last night.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 22-- If SEATO is to survive, its first conference must be a pronounced success. For this new alliance is opposed by external forces of great strength. China's dynamic communism and India's suspicious neutralism dislike it with almost equal intensity.

Community Opera, a semi-amateur organization established last season to give young singers opportunities to appear in opera, is giving a young Brooklyn composer a chance to try out his first opera. His name is Rocco di Giovanni, and his opera is a 45-minute setting of Euripides' "Medea."
The 223d anniversary of the birth of George Washington was celebrated yesterday with civic and religious ceremonies rededicating Americans to the ideals of the Founding Fathers.
WASHINGTON, England, Feb. 22--Washington Old Hall, home of the earliest known ancestors of George Washington, is being restored as a memorial to the first President.

A petition protesting the forthcoming Carnegie Hall concerts of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra will be presented today to Al Manuti, president of the musicians' union local here. The petition has been signed by 1,000 members of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians.

WAS the murderer of Leon Trotsky just a crazy mixed-up kid? Such a conclusion might be warranted after watching "Assassin," an attempt by Bernard Wolfe, erstwhile translator for the exiled Soviet commissar, to make a dramatic reconstruction of the celebrated homicide in Mexico City in 1940 (Television Playhouse; 9 P. M. Sunday on the National Broadcasting Company network).

Warner-Pathe News, Inc., has leased the seventh and eighth floors and part of the ninth floor in the twelve-story building at 33 West Sixtieth Street, directly opposite the new Coliseum development. The company is moving from 625 Madison Avenue, where it has occupied space for the past fifteen years in the building which is to be demolished to make way for a new seventeen-story office structure.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 --Hitting the jackpot in the field events, Yale won the Big Three indoor track and field title for the third straight year at Coxe Cage today.

An eye-witness account of the bombing of Hiroshima and of the conditions there in the weeks that followed will be published in an American edition by the University of North Carolina Press on Aug. 6. That day will be the tenth anniversary of the atom bomb's use in warfare.

The Symphony of the Air, the former N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, will leave the United States on May 1 for a tour of the Far East. The tour is under the sponsorship of the International Exchange Program of the American National Theatre and Academy.
Venereal diseases are on the increase again. Three national organizations, in a joint statement issued yesterday, described the situation as "alarming."

"The Dark Is Light Enough," with such luminaries as Katharine Cornell and Tyrone Power in the vanguard of the company, will be ushered in at 8 o'clock tonight. Welcoming Christopher Fry's verse drama will be the elegantly refurbished ANTA Theatre.

THE National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, will open its 130th annual exhibition with a preview for members and guests at which awards and prizes will be officially presented. Beginning tomorrow the exhibition will be open to the public daily from 1 to 6 P. M. until March 20.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (Reuters)-- A total of 225,200,000 bushels of wheat and wheat flour was bought and sold under the International Wheat Agreement during the 1953-54 crop year, according to the International Wheat Council.
ALBANY, Feb. 22--State income tax evasion has amounted to more than $34,000,000 in the last three years.

Assets of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark amounted to $1,559,100,972 at the close of 1954, it reported yesterday. This was an increase of $70,108,000, or 4.7 per cent, for the year.

As a source of ideas for Lenten menus, "Loaves and Fishes" (Morehouse - Gorham, 128 pp., $2.95) by Mrs. Katharine Morrison McClinton and Mrs. Julianna Morrison Ashley, has much to recommend it. But the recipes in the book, published today, are in many cases so sketchy that considerable knowledge of cooking would be required to use them successfully.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 (AP)--The New York Assembly's Excise Committee today was urged to act favorably on a bill that would increase from 18 to 21 the minimum age for purchase of alcoholic beverages.

GIACOMO CASANOVA, an eighteenthcentury Venetian adventurer, is one of the most celebrated men of his time. Although he was versatile and energetic, he won enduring fame for no creditable achievement --only for making himself the "prototype of all seducers." Casanova's name is synonymous with insatiable lust and innumerable sexual conquests.
The New York Rangers will meet the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The match will start at 8:30.

New York had its second "crazy bargain" day yesterday. This form of sales promotion originated a good many years ago in Washington, D. C., where it again was observed yesterday. Its adoption by some stores here last year represented an effort to make Washington's Birthday a banner shopping occasion on the order of Election and Armistice Days.
PARIS, Feb. 22--The head of the French Steel Federation severely criticized the European Coal and Steel Community and its founder, Jean Monnet, today.
Two internationally known contract bridge teams will play today a sixty-four-hand contest for the 1955 Vanderbilt Cup team-of-four championship.

Walt Disney and the American Broadcasting Company have agreed to present a second television series to be produced by Mr. Disney. Titled the "Mickey Mouse Club," a film show for children, it will be televised from 5 to 6 P. M. on Mondays through Fridays beginning Oct. 3.

The Western Electric Company, main equipment-supply concern for the Bell Telephone System, reported yesterday a net income of $55,836,430 for 1954. This compared with a net of $52,604,613 for the previous year.
ALBANY, Feb. 22--Governor Harriman nominated James A. Farley as a member of the State Banking Board today.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 22--Two measures to restrict South Africans' liberties are being pushed through Parliament.
NEWARK, Feb. 22 (AP)--Bargain offers for Washington's Birthday brought thousands of persons today into S. Klein's department store in downtown Newark and to eight Cury stores in North Jersey.
The American paper industry is at the beginning of a vast new expansion, spurred by mounting demand from abroad, leaders in this field declared yesterday.

The Paramount Theatre announced yesterday plans for the installation of a new screen, which the management called "the largest motion picture screen in the world." It was designed to project the film company's new, wide-screen VistaVision process to the fullest advantage.
ALBANY, Feb. 22--The Legislature set a record today for the introduction of bills.
ALBANY, Feb. 22--Unless the present state equalization rates are frozen for another year, school districts will be cut $42,000,000 in education aid.
LIBERAL, Kan., Feb. 22 (UP)--Mrs. Binnie Dick led the United States today to its second consecutive victory over Britain in the fifth annual international pancake race.
"TWELFTH NIGHT" was no accident at the Jan Hus Auditorium. "The Merchant of Venice," which opened there last evening, is also vigorous, to the point and interesting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)-- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' speech at the opening of the Manila pact conference in Bangkok, as made public here: I am proud to be representing the United States of America at this historic conference.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 (AP)--Yale identified today as one of its freshmen the Ivy League student referred to as having been declared ineligible for athletics by the Ivy Group Eligibility Committee.
LINCOLN, Neb. Feb. 22 (AP) --Legislative anger erupted today around a new mural in the rotunda of Nebraska's gleaming capitol building.
PARIS, Feb. 22--Edgar Faure agreed tonight to form a new French Cabinet. His will be the fourth attempt to replace the government of Premier Pierre Mendes-France, which fell Feb. 5.
BOSTON, Feb. 22--Tom and Pearl Sheahan's Ch. Fancy Bombardier, a bloodhound, made the first step in defense of his biggest dog show honor a successful one today.

Across National Boundaries The United Nations is generally considered to be the world's most promising effort to date toward a sound basis for international understanding and the peaceful negotiation of disputes and differences.

The first meeting of the Council of the newly formed Southeast Asian Defense Organization opens in Bangkok today for the purpose of building new bulwarks against Communist expansion on two fronts --military and economic. Action on both fronts is envisaged in the Manila Pact and in the Pacific Charter, and action on both is necessary if the still free Asian nations are to remain parts of the free world.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Eisenhower sent to Congress today a road-building program that some controlling Democrats had rejected in advance.
More shipping splashed into the sea from the world's shipways in 1954 than in any other year since 1900, Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The London Stock Exchange experienced an erratic session today, marked by an early advance, a sharp noontime slide and a partial recovery just before the close.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 22 --John Albert Davis Jr., of Grand Rapids, Mich., was appointed today,organist and cadet chapel choir conductor at the United States Military Academy here.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22--Mayor Martin H. Kennelly tonight conceded his defeat for nomination for a third term on the Democratic ticket.
JERUSALEM, Wednesday, Feb. 23--Joint Arab-Israeli development of the water resources of the Jordan Valley appeared to be close to final agreement today.
The increase in the population of the aged is piling huge medical bills on the younger wage earners and taxpayers.
Friday will be the forty-second anniversary of modern accounting in the United States, according to a brochure published today by Dun Bradstreet.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 22 (AP)-- The Kansas City Star and its advertising director were convicted today of trying to monopolize the dissemination of news and advertising in the Kansas City area.
LEYDEN, the Netherlands, Feb. 22--A Roman Catholic insisted today that he and other members of that faith had a right to belong to the Netherlands Socialistic party of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) --Senator Henry M. Jackson said today a Senate Interior Subcommittee might call Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, to explain his "mysterious" objections to statehood for Alaska.
