CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,500 head: smallest Tuesday run since Oct. 19: trade slow: weak to mostly 25c lower: one small lot of meattype lightweights $17.35: a few small lots $17.25: few choice lean barrows and gilts

Seven hundred alumni of the New York University College of Medicine met yesterday for the first annual alumni day ceremonies in the new Medical Science Building of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 22 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his party chiefs seem worried by what may ensue from Thursday's debate on the Paris agreements.

YONKERS, Feb. 22--The Otis Elevator Company agreed today to plan for continuance and modernization of its factory here instead of moving to the Midwest. It has 2,100 employes who are paid $10,000,000 a year.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Wednesday, Feb. 23 (AP)--Chinese Nationalist planes were said to have attacked more than 200 Communist armed junks and gunboats yesterday close to Nanki Island. Pilots said six vessels had been sunk and many damaged.

When Boston Doge won the Hibiscus Stakes Jan. 22, Willie Hartack rode him. When the unbeaten 3-year-old made his record eight for eight in the Bahamas Feb. 2, Eric Guerin rode him. Neither Hartack nor Guerin has the assignment for Saturday's $100,000 added Flamingo Stakes.
LONDON, Feb. 22--Prime Minister Churchill today parried Laborites' questions on India's proposal for a ban on further hydrogen bomb tests.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with great interest your article regarding the Narrows Bridge, so-called. Anyone who has had the thrill of passing under the Golden Gate Bridge at the end of a long voyage will know the meaning of passing under this new bridge.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It must be obvious to the American readers by now that France is not governed by political appointees as America is, but is administered instead by stable civil services staffed at the top level by trained and responsible men.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 22--The winners of Freedoms Foundation's sixth annual awards were honored today for their contributions in 1954 to a better understanding of the American way of life.
One American premiere and ten revivals will be included in the repertory of the Ballet Theatre during its fifteenth anniversary season at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning April 12.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 --Doris Day and James Stewart will co-star in Alfred Hitchcock's remake of "The Man Who Knew Too Much."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Harvey Matusow, the self-proclaimed liar who swears he is now an honest man, accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today of sending him on a lie campaign in 1952.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 23-- Bob Marchant sent the puck into the Boston University net in 7:42 of a sudden-death overtime period to give Dartmouth a 5-4 triumph tonight.
Fog and a light rain slowed transportation around the city yesterday morning and virtually halted air travel for five hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)-- Following is a stenographic transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, all of it released for direct quotation and public viewing: THE PRESIDENT: Good morning. Please be seated.

After an interregnum of nineteen days France again has a Government --its twenty-first since the war. Like many of its predecessors, it is a right-center Government. It is headed by the Finance Minister of the previous Cabinet, Edgar Faure.
VIENNA, Feb. 23--A Czechoslovak figure-skating star said today she was seeking asylum in the United States because she wanted freedom, including freedom to dress as she liked.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings for the Easter tea dance to be held on April 10 in the ballroom of the Ambassador for the benefit of the New York City Center Art Gallery of the City Center of Music and Drama.
The city of Milwaukee, Wis., borrowed $7,000,000 on taxsecured sewer and bridge bonds yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 23--Indictments against seven alleged Connecticut Communists were dismissed today by Federal District Judge Robert T. Anderson.
Oxford University Press, Inc., has purchased a five-acre site in the Fair Lawn Industrial Park in Fair Lawn, N. J., and will erect a building for its accounting, stock and shipping departments.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday 5 points higher to 12 points lower than on Monday. Only the near-by March gained.

The French baritone Gerard Souzay, singing his fourth Town Hall recital, gave a conclusive demonstation last evening that he is one of the most gifted and expressive song interpreters now before the public.
Church services here yesterday marked Ash Wednesday and the opening of Lent. Ashes were put foreheads in liturgical devotions as a reminder that man is made of dust and will return to it.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 --Suspension of filming operations by Moulin Productions was indicated today by an announcement that Alfred Crown has joined Allied Artists as a vice president and special studio representative. Mr. Crown had been president of Moulin since January, 1954.

One of the apple varieties in good supply how is the Rome Beauty, which is green or yellow with a mottling of red. The large specimens, which cost a little more than a dime a pound, are especially suitable for baking.
In anticipation of an annual oil traffic volume in excess of 90,000,000 tons, the Suez Canal Company has decided to go ahead with its eighth improvement program for the vital waterway.
Two new issues of corporate debt securities totaling $30,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)-- Following is the 62-24 Senate vote today to raise Congressional salaries from $15,000 to $22,500 and give comparable increases to Federal judges: FOR PAY RISE--62 Democrats--30
Millinery workers voted unanimously but without enthusiasm last night to ratify a three-year pact worked out by their union and employers.
Dock workers in the Port of New York will go to Albany this afternoon to plead against enforcement of the controversial new waterfront hiring regulations.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 23--The proposed natural gas pipeline across Westchester County was endorsed today by the Consolidated Edison Company.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23-- Paul Douglas, the actor filed a $1,000,000 damage suit against Paul Gregory, the producer, in Superior Court today.

The Vanderbilt Cup team-offour national contract bridge championship was won last night by the three-time world championship team of Howard Schenken, B. Jay Becker and George Rapee of New York and Sidney Silodor and John R. Crawford of Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices dropped 25 to 50 cents today and the Department of Agriculture said the average price was at another new low since April, 1950. Salable receipts at 12,000 head and limited demand caused the price drop.
Volume in futures improved in most of the New York markets yesterday.

TO the baseball writer the robin is not the first harbinger of spring. It is the publication of the Green Book by the National League, a fascinating statistical gold mine. Florida always seems at least a thousand miles closer when Dave Grote's annual masterpiece reaches a press box tenant. Suppose we flick over the pages for a quick look.
THE last deer season provided a record harvest of bucks for New York hunters, plus a bonus of 1,963 anterless deer.

HAVANA, Feb. 23--Presidentelect Fulgencio Batista, who will be inaugurated tomorrow, announced his Cabinet today. Its members are: Premier--Senator Jorge Garcia Montes. Minister of State--Senator Carlos Saludrigas.
Sales and earnings of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation last year were the highest in its history, Gwilym A. Price, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement.
PANAMA, Feb. 23--President Jose Figueres of Costa Rica has agreed to meet President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua "more than halfway" in stopping tension between the two countries.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23--Montgomery Ward Co. asked the Illinois Supreme Court today to protect it from raids by "financial pirates." It asked the high court to overrule a lower court decision outlawing the company's practice of electing only three of its nine directors each year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The State Department disclosed today that the air clash last Feb. 5 in which United States fighter pilots shot down two Communist jets had ended over North Korean territory.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Present law forbids the sale or barter of surplus agricultural products to Iron Curtain countries, the White House was advised today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)-- Women are putting their manicured fingers to running electric power tools, laying sewer pipe, building barbecue pits as well as hanging wallpaper and painting the house inside and out.
While public and private agencies seek frantically for means to cope with the soaring cost of illness among the aged population, they quake at the prospect of the future.
KATHARINE CORNELL has found a good part in a heavy play, Christopher Fry's "The Dark Is Light Enough," acted at the ANTA Theatre last evening.
PARIS, Feb. 23--The National Assembly voted 369 to 210 today to confirm Edgar Faure as Premier.
The $100,000 added Belmont Stakes, which will be run at a mile and one-half at Belmont Park on June 11, has attracted 118 3-year-olds.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (AP) --Two foul shots by John Lavin with 12 seconds left in the second overtime period gave Pennsylvania an 87-86 victory over Syracuse tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--A Democratic Congressional foreign policy leader accused Secretary of State Dulles today of a lack of clarity or candor on the policy on Formosa.
